HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Three-Day Gold Rally Ends As Profit Takers Move In

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Profit taking pushed prices of gold futures lower yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange, ending a three-day rally that peaked when the contract for April delivery failed to find support above $430 an ounce.
Silver futures also turned lower and, in other commodity markets, oil futures were mostly lower.
Gold futures settled $1.10 to $1.50 lower, with the contract for delivery in February at $421.30 an ounce. Silver finished 2.3 cents to 2.4 cents lower, with March at $5.33 a troy ounce. 
Gold for February delivery had surged a total of $10 an ounce in the three previous sessions, mainly on supportive chart signals that defied the recent anti-inflationary rise in interest rates, which is usually a bearish fundamental factor.
 
Other Metals Lagged
Analysts also noted that gold's strength had not been confirmed by similarly sharp increases in silver and platinum prices.
The gold rally passed a milestone Monday when the heavily traded contract for April delivery moved above $430 an ounce, but confidence in the market then waned.
Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said gold historically has performed poorly in February, which might account for traders' reluctance to keep betting on higher prices. ''If history serves as a guide, I would be on my guard here,'' he said.
But Peter Cardillo of Josephthal & Company said uncertainty surrounding stock prices and the political upheaval in Eastern Europe could keep investors interested in gold.
 
Petroleum Prices Mixed
Petroleum futures turned in a mixed performance on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as the American Petroleum Institute issued its weekly inventory report that showed higher-than-expected supplies.
The institute reported an increase of 7.7 million barrels in United States stocks of crude oil, a rise of 4.7 million barrels in gasoline stocks and an increase of 4.5 million barrels in supplies of petroleum distillates, which include home heating oil.
Analysts said the report could prompt selling of futures today.
In trading yesterday, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents lower to 12 cents higher, with March at $22.51 a barrel; heating oil was 0.15 cent lower to 0.24 cent higher, with March at 56.19 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 1.08 cents lower to 1.2 cents higher, with March at 61.88 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: OPEC Chief Sees Demand Keeping Prices High

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Fewer oil shipments from the Soviet Union to Eastern Europe have led to higher demand for oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. That should keep world prices above $18 a barrel this year, the head of OPEC said today.
Although demand should slip modestly in the coming months, a sharp break in prices ''is not in the cards,'' even though OPEC production exceeds the limits the organization set in November for its 13 members, Subroto, OPEC's Secretary General, said in an interview.
Analysts have said that oil output in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, has declined by about 800,000 barrels a day, to about 11.5 million a day, in the last two years. $60 Billion Needed Dr. Subroto, the former oil minister of Indonesia and the chief spokesman for OPEC, was in Houston to speak at a conference of oil industry executives sponsored by Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass. He said that with worldwide oil demand rising faster, and the prospect of increased demand from growing economies in Eastern Europe within a few years, OPEC believes it must raise $60 billion to finance more production within five years. 
The analysts estimate that OPEC produced more than 23 million barrels a day last month, or a million barrels more than the daily ceiling of 22 million barrels that took effect on Jan. 1. The United Arab Emirates is the only nation producing far more than its quota, the analysts said.
Dr. Subroto said total production capacity within OPEC should be increased by as much as five million barrels a day, or by nearly 20 percent, by the mid-1990's. Some OPEC nations have operated at full capacity in recent years, and they risk losing billions in future revenues if they do not expand oil-export capacity soon. 27 Million Barrels The production capacity of OPEC is estimated at nearly 27 million barrels a day. Dr. Subroto said the organization's output should reach 28 million barrels a day by 1995.
Joseph A. Stanislaw, an expert on Middle East and European energy markets for Cambridge Energy, said commercial lenders and private oil companies in the West were the most logical sources of money for the OPEC's expansion plans.
He said he estimated the capital needs for the OPEC effort at $35 billion to $50 billion through the mid-1990's. A similar total would be needed to increase refining and transportation operations within OPEC nations, Dr. Stanislaw said.
Some money would come from revenues dervied from OPEC's oil exports, but as much as three-fourths of the total must be attracted from foreign sources, he said.
But many large oil companies are likely to be cautious in re-establishing ties with OPEC nations.
 
'Political Problems'
John S. Jennings, the managing director of the Shell Transport and Trading Company, a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said some OPEC nations could have ''tremendous political problems'' in inviting foreign financiers and oilfield operators back to their nations.
Commercial bankers are especially wary of financing oilfield projects in Iran and Iraq, where each side caused severe damage to the other during the eight-year war that ended in 1988.
Yasushi Kajiwara, the head of energy lending at the Industrial Bank of Japan, said commercial banks were urging the OPEC nations to pledge that refineries, pipelines, oil ports and other energy centers would not be attacked during future wars that might occur in the region.
Without the assurances, he said, new production would be limited in the future and global oil demand could push prices to $40 a barrel by 1995 and $60 by the year 2000.
OPEC oil prices averaged $19.41 a barrel in the fourth week of January, down from $20.40 a month earlier, but well above the minimum of $18 a barrel for the first half of 1990 that was set in November. ''We expect that it will slide a little bit more during the second quarter,'' Dr. Subroto said.
One of OPEC's largest producers, Iraq, recently agreed to ship oil to Hungary and Czechoslovakia, Dr. Subroto said. Iraq said for the first time last week that it would consider foreign investment to help raise its oil production. Iran has also held talks on beginning shipments, he said.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Envoy Besieged in Spying Inquiry Is Called Security Risk and Ousted

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Felix S. Bloch, the American diplomat who came under intense Federal investigation last year when officials said he was photographed with a Soviet spy, was told today that he was being dismissed because he is a national security risk, the State Department said.
The action came after six months in which Mr. Bloch was publicly identified as a suspected Soviet intelligence agent, besieged by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and reporters, and barred from his Washington office, but never charged with a crime.
Mr. Bloch has been on leave with pay from the State Department's bureau of European and Canadian affairs since June 22. Today, the department removed him from its payroll and said he would be dismissed in 30 days.
The State Department announcement leaves Mr. Bloch with the choice of accepting his dismissal, and implicitly conceding guilt, or contesting it without guaranteed access to details of the allegations that led to his ouster. Under Federal laws governing dismissal of employees suspected of being security risks, the State Department is required to submit a summary of charges ''stated as specifically as security considerations permit.'' 
Under the law Mr. Bloch can contest the decision through administrative hearings at the State Department, including an appeal to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. Should he fail, he would then have the option of taking the matter to Federal court. It was unclear today what Mr. Bloch would do. Mr. Bloch's lawyer, John M. Bray, said his client had no comment. Mr. Bloch did not answer the telephone at his home near downtown Washington.
 
Trail Growing Cold
The State Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the inquiry into allegations of espionage by Mr. Bloch remains active. Officials have conceded, however, that they so far lack the evidence to make a court case against their target and that his trail grows colder each day.
Federal officials denied that a motive in dismissing Mr. Bloch was the hope that the move would produce additional evidence of wrongdoing through administrative hearings, court battles or other steps he might take to contest the action. Dismissal is the strongest action that can be taken against Mr. Bloch short of filing criminal charges, which the available evidence does not support, law enforcement officials say.
It is ''farfetched indeed'' to think Mr. Bloch's dismissal is a Federal ploy to force the disclosure of new evidence against him, Michael Schatzow, a Baltimore lawyer who prosecuted John A. Walker, the master Soviet spy, said in an interview. Indeed, he said, the Government has abandoned similar proceedings in other cases to avoid disclosing classified evidence.
''In these proceedings the burden usually goes the other way,'' he said, meaning the Government must show that its actions are justified. ''Mr. Bloch obviously has a good lawyer. He's not going to stick his foot in his mouth now.''
 
An Eerie Composure
For the State Department, Mr. Bloch's dismissal was also dictated by financial considerations. Officials noted that Mr. Bloch receives an $80,000-a-year salary for a job he is barred from performing.
Through it all, the balding, 54-year-old bureaucrat has maintained an eerie composure, repeatedly declining opportunities to deny that he was a spy and challenging investigators to find enough evidence to prove otherwise.
A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, today refused to describe the specific allegations of wrongdoing that led to the decision to dismiss Mr. Bloch, saying those charges are confidential under privacy laws.
The Federal law covering Mr. Bloch's case allows the removal of employees ''in the interests of national security.'' An Administration official said today that the State Department had not previously used the law, and that its last known use, in 1983, was by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
State Department lawyers have been studying the agency's options under the law since at least last autumn, an Administration official said today.
''It's a pretty complicated legal issue because it involves balancing the national security and due process,'' the official said. ''We do feel like we moved promptly in terms of the work that had to be done, but cautiously.''
Mr. Baker decided last week to invoke the Federal law, and the agency's Under Secretary for Management, Ivan Selin, ordered the dismissal.
If Mr. Bloch is dismissed next month, the State Department would consider taking action under another law to reduce or eliminate his pension, the Administration official said.
Mr. Bloch was the second-ranking American diplomat in Vienna during much of the Reagan Administration. In that job, he effectively ran day-to-day embassy affairs in a city that is a center for sensitive arms negotiations and other strategic matters.
 
Charges Go Back to 70's
Since 1988, he had worked in a Washington office that deals with European economic relations and restrictions on technology exports to the East bloc.
American officials have said they believe that Mr. Bloch began spying for Moscow in the 1970's, when he was an officer at American embassies in West and East Berlin. But officials said he came under F.B.I. scrutiny only last spring, when he turned up in a secret videotape of a known Soviet agent whose European movements were being followed.
Mr. Bloch was immediately placed under heavy surveillance, and his automobile and telephone were wiretapped. Officials said the automobile wiretap later recorded Mr. Bloch telling his wife, Lucille, that he had accepted money from the Soviet Union.
Numerous news reports said the inquiry also turned up evidence that Mr. Bloch had spent large sums of money, well beyond the means of a mid-level diplomat, for a prostitute's services during much of his stay in Vienna.
The Soviet agent appears to have cryptically told Mr. Bloch in a telephone conversation last May that he was under surveillance by the F.B.I. Shortly after the tip, the State Department suspended Mr. Bloch.
Last July, reporters detected the heavy surveillance, and a horde of writers and photographers joined Federal agents in a round-the-clock siege of Mr. Bloch's home.

HEADLINE: Congress Approves $42 Million in Aid to Panama

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The House and Senate today approved a $42 million package of emergency aid for Panama that would also lift many trade sanctions that had been intended to press Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
The aid package was approved by a voice vote in both chambers and sent to the White House. It was the first step in a much broader aid proposal advanced by the Bush Administration to help Panama rebuild its economy after the American invasion and the damage inflicted by the Noriega Government and United States sanctions. There was little debate today. 
''We support the Administration's analysis of the urgency of the matter,'' said Representative Dante B. Fascell, the Florida Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
 
Criticism From House Speaker
Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, said that ''if this area of the world was important enough to risk and lose American lives, it is worth our capital'' to help restore democracy.
The measure also includes $10 million in aid ''to support the process of democratic transition'' in Eastern Europe, intended to reach that region before the flurry of elections expected this spring, congressional aides said.
Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, spoke with unusual force today of the Democrats' intent to keep pushing for more aid for Eastern Europe. ''The Administration had flat zero, zero dollars proposed to assist democratic elections in Eastern Europe,'' Mr. Foley said at his morning news conference.
''The Administration - and I am not trying to denigrate it - the Administration has $1 billion proposed for Panama and can't seem to muster anything like that for the rest of Eastern Europe,'' Mr. Foley said. ''This is not a time when we can assume that these democratic changes in Eastern Europe are permanent.''
The measure approved today restores to Panama many of the trade and aid privileges revoked by the United States because of General Noriega's failure to cooperate in the war against drugs. The Panamanian leader has been indicted in Florida on charges of drug trafficking.
 
Trade Privileges to Resume
Panama would be eligible, once again, for trade privileges under the Caribbean Basin Initiative, a United States program to stimulate the region's economy, as well as other international economic programs like loans from the Export-Import Bank. The measure also includes $32 million in direct, emergency aid and an additional $10 million in loan guarantees for the construction of low-income housing.
The action today is the first step in President Bush's proposal for a $1 billion package of grants, loans and other types of assistance for Panama.
Administration officials have testified that Panama's gross domestic product, which measures the output of goods and services, declined about 16 percent in the last two years, while unemployment rose to 25 percent.
While there was broad support for the Panamanian aid, some objections were expressed today.
Some members asserted that the aid for Panama was being transferred from money set aside for Africa; the Democratic leadership gave assurances that the money would be replaced later this year. Other members said they continued to have concerns about money laundering in Panama.
But a measure of the political popularity of the Panamanian invasion came on a seperate resolution commending the President and the American military and urging Mr. Bush ''to continue his efforts to foster democratic ideals in Panama and the establishment of a democratic government so long sought by the people of Panama.''
The measure passed by a vote of 389 to 26.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: TRADE;
Negotiations Are to Begin on Ending Restrictions Against Soviet Imports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The first round of talks on a trade agreement that could end nearly a half-century of American discrimination against Soviet imports will start on Monday in Washington, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, announced today.
Both Governments hope to conclude the talks before President Bush meets with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in June.
Moscow would like an end to the restrictions under the Jackson-Vanik law of 1974, which prevents the Soviet Union from receiving most favored nation status, or normal tariff treatment on imports from it, until it adopts an open emigration policy. Most favored nation status gives countries the benefits of tariff reductions that have been adopted since the 1930's. 
 
U.S. Seeking Soviet Commitments
American trade officials said the United States would also have some demands, seeking commitments by the Soviets on protection of patents, copyrights and other intellectual property, mechanics for settling commercial disputes, safeguards for preventing surges of cheap imports, and the right to have offices for American representatives in the Soviet Union.
Mrs. Hills announced the talks during testimony on trade matters before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. She said Yuriy N. Chumakov, a Soviet deputy foreign trade minister, would lead the Soviet delegation.
Mrs. Hills said she intended to keep pressure on Japan, South Korea and other trading partners to open markets to American exports, but apart from the Soviet trade announcement she made no major disclosures.
 
Hope for Market-Driven Economy
Through the negotiations, she stressed, the United States hopes to ''encourage economic reform'' within the Soviet Union as it moves toward a more market-driven economy.
A successful agreement, she also noted, will ''create opportunities'' for American business in the Soviet Union.
Congressional sensitivity over contents of the agreement and the process by which Congress will review it was evidenced by particularly close questioning of Mrs. Hills by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
Noting the importance of maintaining close consultations with Congress, he said that if the Nixon Administration had kept Congress better informed in the early 1970's while it was negotiating a trade agreement with Moscow, the Bush Administration would not now have to deal with the existing limitations on Soviet trade.
 
Effect of Jackson-Vanik Law
This was a reference to the Jackson-Vanik curbs, which Congress wrote into the Trade Act of 1974. The linkage to Soviet emigration policies caused Moscow in early 1975 to abort that trade pact, which had been under negotiation for two years.
Under Jackson-Vanik, tariffs on imports from the Soviet Union are as much as 10 times higher than they would be from most other countries. For American consumers, ending the curbs would mean, for example, $1.25 off the retail price of a bottle of vodka, which is one of the big Soviet exports to the United States.
The United States is considering granting Jackson-Vanik waivers on imports from Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria and East Germany. Hungary recently obtained a waiver. The curbs against Poland were lifted in 1987.
Senator Bentsen, the 1988 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, said he understood that ''there are those within the Administration who really want to limit consultations with this committee or Congress'' and ''I want to see the consultation requirement lived up to.''
Mrs. Hills insisted that ''there is no question in my mind that this Administration wants to consult.''
 
Congressional Review Problem
One problem is how the Congress is going to review the trade agreement following the so-called Chadha decision of the Supreme Court in 1983, which declared a legislative veto illegal.
Under Jackson-Vanik, approval of a trade agreement that restores most favored nation treatment would require a concurrent resolution - an act of Congress that is not signed by the President. The resolution would be subject to the approval of the Senate and the House.
But under Chadha, lawyers say, this procedure is probably unconstitutional because it could amount to a legislative veto.

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Urges 'Real World' View of China

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger asked Congress today to take a more tolerant view of China, saying it was ''less completely evil'' than it seemed in June, when the Chinese Army crushed the democracy movement in Beijing.
''China is not a benighted society from top to bottom,'' he told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in the Administration's most comprehensive defense of its policy toward China. ''The forces favoring reform have not disappeared.'' The mood of many senators was expressed by Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, who described the Chinese leaders as ''gangsters'' and said, ''There are many evil regimes in the world today, but none more deserves to be overthrown by its people than the one in Beijing.'' 
Senators Gordon Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, and Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, said Mr. Bush was so afraid of offending China's leaders that he seemed to treat China as a client state. Mr. Humphrey and Mr. Sarbanes both said Mr. Bush, a former chief of the United States mission in Beijing, seemed to have a lingering case of ''clientitis,'' an excessive tendency to defend the interests of the country where he served.
Members of Congress from both parties expressed fear that the United States response to China might embolden hardliners in the Soviet Union to believe that they could crack down on dissent without paying a longterm price in relations with Washington.
Mr. Eagleburger and President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, visited China in July and December. On the first trip, he said, China was told that ''the United States does not condone the appalling violence used to suppress the peaceful demonstrations, nor do we condone the repression that has followed.''
China's response to those admonitions was ''inscrutable,'' he said. ''They understood us, but there was no real reaction, other than, 'You tied the knot, you have to untie the knot.' ''
Mr. Eagleburger acknowledged that repression continued in China after the first visit. On the second trip, he recalled, he and Mr. Scowcroft told Chinese leaders ''how they could improve their relations with the United States.'' The results have been ''favorable,'' he said, noting that China lifted martial law in Beijing and released 573 people from detention.
But in response to questions, Mr. Eagleburger said there was no reason to expect that martial law would be lifted in Tibet. He said that he could not confirm reports from Beijing today that China would toughen restrictions on young people planning to study abroad, but that if such restrictions are enforced, that would represent ''a serious step backward.''
''Today, in the eyes of many foreign observers, China's leaders seem unable to do anything right,'' Mr. Eagleburger said. He asserted that ''we need a better balance between our fascination with the China of the early 1970's and today's mood of disappointment and hostility.''
''In the real world,'' he said, ''we need to see that China is less completely charming than the land of panda bears and the Great Wall and also less completely evil than a night in June when the 'goddess of democracy' was crushed by tanks in Tiananmen.''
Mr. Eagleburger said that President Bush's policy toward China would not ''lead to a rapid payoff.''
''This is a long-haul situation,'' he said. ''It will take a good bit of time. We are hopeful, but can certainly not guarantee that the process we are now following will, in fact, lead the Chinese Government toward reform and democratization, economic and political. I can't promise it.''
Mr. Eagleburger said that if the United States isolates China, it would play into the hands of Chinese officials who oppose democratic change.
''The process of isolating ourselves from the Chinese people, cutting off the contacts, reducing the dialogue back and forth, will lead to nothing more than an isolated China which returns to the bad old days of a very dictatorial, centralized system that really doesn't care what the rest of the world thinks,'' Mr. Eagleburger said.

HEADLINE: Security Tight for Jackson On Arrival in South Africa

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived in South Africa today for his first visit in 11 years and was immediately surrounded by some of the tightest police security ever given to a foreign visitor.
In the face of hostility toward the American civil rights leader's visit from conservative white groups, the police threw a security cordon around Jan Smuts Airport and checked all vehicles for weapons. When Mr. Jackson left the airport, flanked by a dozen uniformed police officers, there were cheers from a throng of black workers and a lone shout from an burly white man in his 30's, who jeered: ''Go home Jackson! You're supposed to be a man of God!'' A car filled with plainclothes officers, also whites, accompanied the American's entourage to a downtown Johannesburg hotel.
Concerns for Mr. Jackson's safety centered on threats from extreme right-wing white groups already enraged by the program of political relaxation announced last week by President F. W. de Klerk. The climate was not eased when Roelof F. Botha, the Foreign Minister, criticized the American on Tuesday. 
 
Timing of Visit Criticized
In remarks to reporters, Mr. Botha accused Mr. Jackson of saying different things about economic sanctions to the South African Ambassador to the United States than he has been saying publicly, and demanded that he ''make up his mind.'' Mr. Botha also said that the timing of the Jackson visit, ''in the middle of very important business'' for South Africa, was inopportune.
Mr. Jackson appeared anxious to ease tensions, saying at an airport news conference that he would be meeting with Mr. de Klerk and with other white leaders, as well as with blacks, and that he hoped during his visit to address ''the unfounded fears of whites'' about the dismantling of apartheid as well as what he called ''the pain of black people.''
Pressed by reporters to respond to Mr. Botha's criticisms, he declined. He noted that he was here ''on a Government visa'', and added: ''What I have to share with Mr. Botha I will share with him,'' at a meeting scheduled for Cape Town next week.
 
'Apartheid Is Sanctions'
Mr. Jackson avoided statements that the sanctions should be intensified, as he had been quoted as saying after Mr. de Klerk's announcements on Friday. Instead, he emphasized the prospect that sanctions will be lifted as racial laws are dismantled.
''Apartheid is sanctions,'' he said. ''For those who cannot vote, it is political sanctions; for those who cannot borrow money and grow economically, it is economic sanctions; for those victimized by the Group Areas Act, it is land sanctions. So sanctions beget sanctions. The real issue is to end apartheid, and the sanctions will leave.''
Among South African blacks, Mr. Jackson's visit has been widely greeted as the most important by any American political figure since Robert F. Kennedy visited here in 1966.
At the news conference, the American was flanked by Walter F. Sisulu, a recently freed leader of the African National Congress, the Rev. Frank Chikane of the South African Council of Churches, and the Rev. Allan Boesak, a major figure in the United Democratic Front. The three men are among of the country's most influential black leaders. Mr. Sisulu, who released last year after 26 years in prison, praised Mr. Jackson's ''courage and determination,'' and the two men dined together later at Mr. Sisulu's home in Soweto, the black satellite city outside Johannesburg.
 
Visa Denied in '88
Among conservative whites, hostility to Mr. Jackson dates to 1979 during his first visit here, when he was quoted as calling South Africa a ''terrorist dictatorship,'' and from his subsequent support for American economic sanctions. In 1988, during Mr. Jackson's run for the Democratic Presidential nomination, the Government refused him a visa for a visit. This time, a visa was issued for a 12-day visit after Mr. Jackson's application had been strongly supported by the South African Ambassador to Washington, Pieter J. Koornhof.
 
Visit With Mandela Scheduled
If a tentative itinerary circulated by the United States Embassy is followed, the highlight of the trip is likely to be a 90-minute visit with Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the African National Congress, at the Victor Verster Prison outside Cape Town on Monday.
At his news conference, Mr. Jackson appeared to take pains not to paint the government into a corner over the proposed meeting, saying that he had ''no commitment'' from the authorities that a meeting would be held. In any event, he said, he would prefer to see Mr. Mandela ''walking down the streets of Johannesburg'' after he has been released, as Mr. de Klerk promised last week.
In his comments on Mr. Klerk's decision to lift the bans on the African National Congress and on more than 30 other anti-apartheid groups, and to otherwise ease restraints on black political activity, Mr. Jackson said that Mr. de Klerk had ignited ''hope'' in South Africa and around the world.
But he urged the white leader to press forward to a complete end of apartheid. ''If the Government goes backwards, there will be chaos; if it stands still there will be tension; if it goes forward there will be a new and free and democratic South Africa,'' he said. ''In a very real sense, the greatest days for South Africa are beyond apartheid.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Renewing Border Detentions

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAYVIEW, Tex., Feb. 7

 BODY:
In a sharp policy reversal. the Government announced today that it would again start detaining Central Americans who cross the border illegally and then try to seek political asylum.
The detention policy was publicly abandoned just two weeks ago when Commissioner Gene McNary of the immigration service acknowledged that budget restraints were forcing the agency to release aliens from its detention facility here.
But after a rebel offensive in El Salvador late last year the tide of refugees has grown, prompting the renewal of the detention policy.
Mr. McNary toured six newly erected tents at a detention center here today and announced, ''The message we are now sending across Central America and around the world is, 'Just don't drop in on our doorstep without a just cause and a provable case of fear of persecution.' '' 
The renewed policy, he said, is similar to an initiative begun last Feb. 20 in which a tent city was erected here for several months to handle an influx of refugees. The number of detainees grew quickly to reach a maximum of about 3,600 in the spring but began to drop and is now about 1,000.
 
Border Crossings Increase
The number of Central Americans stopped while crossing the border in this area of South Texas had hovered around 800 a month through much of the summer and fall of last year. Then, after the rebel offensive, the number of people apprehended jumped to 1,203 in December and to 1,806 in January, according to immigration officals.
The detention center, situated near a rural crossroads about 20 miles northeast of Brownsville, is now prepared to handle up 2,500 people and the population could go to 10,000, Mr. McNary said.
Mr. McNary said he hoped to send a message to people seeking asylum that they face certain detention under conditions that ''won't be like the Ritz Carlton.''
Although he insisted, ''We are here to stay, make no mistake about it,'' the resources available to carry out the threat appear to be limited.
The Commissioner said about $11 million from the immigration service's budget had been set aside to finance the new detention effort. He said more emergency funds would be available later, but he did not specify what they would be.
Mr. McNary said he had not sought approval for the renewed detention policy from either the White House or the Department of Justice, the service's parent agency. He also said he had not secured any additional money to support the program. So far, he said no additional personnel had been sent to South Texas to carry out the new effort. But he promised that as many as 500 additional border patrol agents would be available if necessary.
Two weeks ago, the Immigration commissioner said in interviews that budget restraints had obliged him to order the population of the detention center here reduced to no more than 668 people. At the beginning of the year, the facility housed about 1,200 detainees, officials said.
 
Detention Up to Six Months
In order to meet the budgetary imperative, hundreds of Central Americans, some of whom had been detained for as long as six months, were suddenly released on their own recognizance. Many of those newly apprehended were held only a few days if they could show they had families in the United States.
The policy of releasing detainees ''has stopped as of today,'' Mr. McNary said at a news conference this afternoon in which he acknowledged that he was reversing tactics.
Robert Rubin, a lawyer with the San Francisco Lawyers' Committee for Urban Affairs, a group that has contested the immigration detention policies in several lawsuits, said, ''It is difficult to understand the sudden flip-flop in position now because everyone has known for several months that the number of refugees coming from Central America has been increasing in direct response to the increasing level of violence in El Salvador.''
Mr. Rubin said that the most recent wave of people seeking asylum began when the old detention policy was still in effect and well before Mr. McNary ordered the number of detainees reduced last month.
Mr. Rubin added, ''The I.N.S. needs to appreciate that the message of detention does not reach people who are fleeing violence.''
When the original detention policy was begun almost a year ago, the immigration service asserted that the great majority of the refugees were not fleeing political persecution but were seeking economic opportunities, so that they were frivolous rather than true candidates for asylum.
Foreigners who enter the country without submitting to inspection by an immigration officer are subject to detention and possible deportation if they can not prove they have the right to be the United States.
 
One-Day Adjudications Promised
In instituting the detention policy the immigration service promised that by adding hundreds of officials to the staff here it would be able to adjudicate an asylum claim in one day and then either deport the alien or grant asylum. But the process of determining whether individuals had a legitimate fear of persecution bogged down, until many refugees were detained for several months.
Mr. McNary said today that the service would again provide one-day processing, even though no additional agents were likely to be sent here for several weeks. Asked to explain how the refugees could be processed so quickly without additional officers or changes in procedures, Mr. McNary said, ''We are starting from a good blueprint.''
The immigration service's legal basis for the detention policy has come under attack in the court. In a ruling last July, Federal District Court Judge William Wayne Justice found that the frivolity standard was unjustly applied to six individual refugees. He is now considering a motion that the finding be extended to all refugees from El Salvador.

HEADLINE: Tougher Enforcing of Child Labor Laws Is Vowed

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
In the face of record levels of child labor law violations, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole today promised ''immediate action to step up enforcement'' of the laws, larger penalties for violations and a review of all regulations governing children who work.
''Our fines must exact a price or there will be no deterrence,'' Mrs. Dole said in a statement. ''This new strategy will leave no uncertainty about our commitment to enforce the law.''
Department officials said new changes in calculating violations could lead to a quintupling of fines, now often only a few hundred dollars. They also said they expected to take significant enforcement actions within a month. 
 
'Our Future,' Mrs. Dole Says
''The children of America are our future,'' Mrs. Dole said. ''The Department of Labor will do everything within its power to protect children against those who violate our child labor laws. The first step in this process is to reassess our fine structure and take immediate action to step up enforcement.''
Child advocates, who have been pressing the department to toughen enforcement for several years, welcomed the statement but noted that the department, constrained like others by the Federal budget, is not adding money or personnel to enforce the laws. Labor officials said they plan to improve use of existing resources.
''It's important that the department has set this new direction,'' said Linda F. Golodner, executive director of the National Consumers League and chairwoman of the Child Labor Advisory Committee, set up by the Labor Department. But she said much more was needed to stop the violations, especially in industries not covered by the laws.
 
'A Slap on the Wrist'
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, who has introduced legislation to raise penalties for labor law violations, saluted Mrs. Dole's move. ''This is an area that the Federal Government has neglected for a decade,'' he said. ''The Secretary's interest in the issue can only help.''
But he added: ''I still don't think the penalties are tough enough. Employers will see them as a slap on the wrist.''
Federal labor laws prohibit most paid work for children under 14 years old so as to protect them from commercial exploitation and keep them in school, and the laws set strict limits on how much children under 16 can work after school and on weekends. The laws also restrict children from using hazardous machinery, like slicing machines and trash compactors. Yet labor officials have found children operating such devices.
The Labor Department found a record number of children, 22,508, working in violation of the 52-year-old Fair Labor Standards Act last year. That is more than twice the number of 1982 and the highest since the law was enacted. Violations have risen, officials say, because of the low unemployment rates of the 1980's. Pressed to find workers, employers have been reaching deeper into the population.
Cases of illegal employment of children, some as young as 10 and 11 years old, have become commonplace in New York City's garment district, in fast-food chains and supermarkets, in migrant labor camps and in door-to-door candy sales.
 
First Step: Higher Penalties
In a speech today to the Child Labor Advisory Committee, William C. Brooks, Assistant Secretary for Employment Standards, elaborated on Mrs. Dole's announcement.
In the first step of the new policy, Mr. Brooks said, penalties would be raised in part by changing the procedures for assessing them. At present, an employer can be fined up to $1,000 for each child found working in violation of the laws, regardless of the number of regulations the child is found to be violating. With the change, the employer can be fined for each violation. This, Mr. Brooks said, could yield fines five times larger than those levied now.
In addition, he said, the new system will permit consideration of factors that may further increase the penalty, like when the employer is a repeat offender of the child labor provisions. If an employer is found to keep inadequate work records, Mr. Brooks said, he could be assessed another penalty.
''The bottom line,'' he said, ''is that penalties should not - must not - be an acceptable cost of doing business.''
He said Mrs. Dole planned to set up a working group to explore whether to beef up the department's enforcement practices and to consider revising the classification of jobs deemed hazardous for children. He said the group would also consider the child labor laws and regulations, many of which do not take sufficient account of chemicals and machinery developed since the the laws were enacted in 1930's.
And in cases of especially serious and repeated violations, Mr. Brooks said he would be prepared to go to the courts to seek injunctions against the practices.

GRAPHIC: photo: Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole yesterday announced a new strategy of stepped-up enforcement of child labor laws. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Amiable Idea Merchant Who Is Viewed as the Most-Feared Japan-Basher

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Enter Pat Choate's cinnabar-colored Victorian townhouse on Capitol Hill, and you are walking into the Orient. Utamaro woodblocks and a 17th-century painted screen line the gallery of the spare living room. A six-foot-square calligraphy on hammered silver frames the dining room table. A mural of Hokusai's ''Mount Fuji at Dawn'' graces the viewing area of the Japanese rock garden in the backyard.
So why is this bearded and bespectacled economist regarded as Washington's most-feared Japan-basher?
In September, Alfred A. Knopf will publish ''Agents of Influence,'' Mr. Choate's chronicling of the ways Japan shapes American trade and economic policies through contributing to Congressional, gubernatorial and mayoral campaigns, bankrolling think tanks and universities, planting stories in the press, and most of all, through the revolving door, hiring for big money former United States Government officials as lobbyists, lawyers and publicists. 
''This is a town where you can rent power and influence,'' says Mr. Choate, who is vice president of policy analysis for TRW Inc., a $7 billion military and industrial conglomerate. ''We have created a buccaneer class where public service is merely a sabbatical for lobbying and that lobbying has increased for foreign governments and foreign corporations. I'm using the Japanese because they're on the cutting edge.''
 
Variation on a Theme
Mr. Choate (whose name rhymes with boat) says his new book is nothing more than a variation on the theme he has explored for years, in books like ''America in Ruins'' and ''The High Flex Society,'' and in caucuses of the middle-of-the-road Democrats' Democratic Leadership Council and the centrist Republicans' House Wednesday Group: how to make American industry more vibrant and competitive in the new world economy.
Rumors about the book have disturbed Americans with Japanese connections and prompted Japanese officials to try to quash its publication.
A particularly heavy-handed pitch came during a visit to Tokyo last year by TRW's chairman, Joseph T. Gorman, when Matsudo Kuroda, the former vice minister of Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry and now a consultant to the New York-based Salomon Brothers, argued that if the book were published, it would severely damage U.S.-Japanese trade relations. TRW has substantial business dealings with Japan. Mr. Gorman was not swayed.
Mr. Choate is a mild-mannered, nice guy with clout, a contradiction in Washington where political capital is often accrued by self-promotion, leading with one's elbows and making enemies along the way.
 
Strategy on Ideas
But his dogged approach, a legacy from his childhood days picking cotton on his father's farm in Maypearl, Tex., masks a calculated strategy to feed his ideas into the system and watch them bubble up into legislation and policy. In the early 80's, he helped shape the short-lived debate on whether to bolster America's worn-out roads and dams and bridges. In the mid-decade, he made ''competitiveness'' the buzzword of the capital, resulting in Ronald Reagan's making it the centerpiece of his 1987 State of the Union Message and in some Democratic Presidential hopefuls centering their 1988 campaigns on it.
An idea merchant and a master of packaging and timing, Mr. Choate wields power by talking, writing and testifying nonstop. Armed with infinite patience and one of the richest Rolodexes in town, he sways lawmakers, lectures executives, tips off journalists, sits on task forces, attends institutional retreats, argues on talk shows and makes himself available to almost anyone who wants to hear his ideas on how the American economy is changing and how the country should adapt to an uncertain future.
Slightly overweight - he'd rather network over the lunch table than on the tennis court - he has expanded his wardrobe well beyond his uniform of three identical blue suits and white shirts of two years ago. A regular on ''Money Politics,'' a talk show aired on Sunday mornings on ABC's Washington affiliate, he has worked hard to improve his television persona. ''He has gone from an academic discursive style to a TV sound bite style,'' says Neal B. Freeman, the program's executive producer. ''We recently had him remove his glasses in the interest of esthetic appeal.''
 
Predicting What He Knows
He has also perfected the technique of using the show as a vehicle to make predictions that he knows will come true. In response to President Bush's capital gains initiative, for example, Mr. Choate said late last fall that Senate Democrats would find merit in a two-tiered capital gains tax plan. Last month, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who regularly receives advice from Mr. Choate, launched it as a policy inititiave.
In November, Mr. Choate predicted that Senator Jim Exon, the Nebraska Democrat, would send a letter to Carla Hills, the United States Trade Representative, chastising her for backing off from a semiconductor agreement during a recent trip to Japan. Mr. Choate admits that he had already seen the letter, and notes that he never predicts without permission.
For Ronald Morse, a Japan expert and fund raiser for the Library of Congress, Mr. Choate is a ''likeable guy, wholesome, like whole wheat bread.'' For C. Fred Bergsten, a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Carter Administration and head of the Institute for International Economics, though he is open about their differences, Mr. Choate is ''an extremely effective operator.''
But Dennis Whitfield, a partner with The Brock Group, an international trade and investment consulting firm, calls Mr. Choate misguided. ''He's a great idea man, very bright and very personable,'' says Mr. Whitfield. ''He just happens to be wrong.''
For Mr. Whitfield, the only way to attract the best talent into Government is through the revolving door. ''To get people of a high caliber you need people who have proven themselves in other fields,'' he says. ''And you can't prohibit them then from going back and making a living in the manner in which they were before.''
 
'Kind of McCarthyism' Seen
What others find troubling in Mr. Choate's thesis is that when he lumps together everyone who gets money from Japan he suggests a sort of anti-American conspiracy. ''The great danger of Pat's book is that it is going lead to a kind of McCathyism regarding Japan,'' says David D. Hale, chief economist for the Chicago-based Kemper Financial Services, who, like Mr. Choate, argues for much stricter controls on the revolving door. ''Clearly there are people on the take, but other people get their money because no one else is willing to fund their research on Japan.''
One of Mr. Choate's targets has been Mr. Bergsten's think tank, which has significant influence on trade policy attitudes. In a 1988 article that he calls an ''announcement'' of his forthcoming book, Mr. Choate argued that ''while the views of these institutes and scholars are genuinely held, significant foreign funding amplifies their particular perspectives and gives them a sharp competitive advantage in the idea marketplace.''
''I was shocked at his intellectual sloppiness because he knew better; the attack was unjustified,'' says Mr. Bergsten, who adds that his institute has historically received more money from TRW than from Japan, which is the source of less than 3 percent of the group's resources from Japanese nongovernmental sources.
Mr. Choate insists that ''Fred misinterpreted,'' adding, ''What I was saying was not that people change their views to get their money, but that they got their money because they change their views.''
It is not a line of argument that satisfies Mr. Bergsten. ''That's kind of a cute way to put it, but I very strongly object to is the innuendo,'' he says. ''Pat doesn't specifically say that Fred and his institute are influenced, but it's the innuendo, and it's damaging to everything I'm trying to do, including resisting influence.''
Others who agree with Mr. Choate that the revolving door needs more controls and better monitoring, fault him for singling out the Japanese for censure. They argue that there is no difference between the former Pentagon official who leaves public service to represent an American firm like TRW in its military contracts or one who works for a foreign interest. ''The problem is the unethical use of government position for personal gain,'' says Charles William Maynes, editor of Foreign Policy. ''The revolving door is a problem, but it's not a uniquely Japanese problem.''
 
Backlash Before Publication
The backlash against the new book has already begun. Some Japan boosters speculate that Mr. Choate has pulled punches by relying on some sources who have told stories and named names with the understanding that their own interests will be protected.
Mr. Choate, who strongly denies the imputation of plea bargaining, is in the enviable position of saying and writing what he wants while at the same time drawing a full-time salary for TRW. He left government in 1977, after serving in the Office of Management and Budget and the Commerce Department in both Republican and Democratic administrations, and since 1981 has operated as a one-man think tank from the conglomerate's office in Rosyln, Va.
Although TRW has two manufacturing plants and a business development office in Japan and a number of American-Japanese joint ventures in North America, he is not required to show his bosses an advance copy of his forthcoming book, which he says he has written in his spare time. Because his wife, Diane, a psychotherapist, is studying Jungian analysis in Zurich, he says he has the luxury of working at home alone.
Mr. Choate knows that he may risk friendships by naming names and detailing unsavory relationships in the book's Appendix A, an alphabetical Who's Who of Washington's Japan promoters, the interests they represent and what they were paid. But he is confident that because of the peculiar political culture of Washington, where alliances of the powerful survive because they have to, the furor will be short-lived.
''There are going to be a lot of people who will be very angry with me when the book comes out, and I will be very angry and then realize ultimately that a lot of the criticism has nothing to do with me,'' he says. ''But sooner or later, the next topic will come along and we can work together on that. So I'm not in great puddles of sweat about this, because I'll be a player long after this book is gone.''

HEADLINE: Senate Votes Bush Education Bill, With Plan for Teacher Standards

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The Senate today overwhelmingly approved President Bush's first major initiative in education. But in passing the measure, the lawmakers added a provision that the President opposes: money for an independent board that is working to develop a voluntary national teacher certification system.
By a vote of 92 to 8, the lawmakers approved the Educational Excellence Act, authorizing the spending of $586 million for the fiscal year 1991, which starts Oct. 1. The measure, first submitted to Congress by President Bush last spring, includes money to improve education in mathematics, science and engineering and money for elementary and secondary schools with large numbers of poor students that make significant progress in raising achievement levels. 
 
Money for Standards Board
The bill, introduced by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, authorized $25 million over three years for the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, an independent board created three years ago by the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy. Business executives have said they will match that amount.
The standards board plans to start offering certificates in 1993 to qualified teachers who make it through a rigorous evaluation process. The hope is that the ''board-certified'' teachers will ultimately upgrade teacher training and the profession.
The Administration has opposed providing money for the standards board. Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said at a hearing in July that the board should remain independent from the Federal Government.
The Senators who voted against the bill, all Republicans, were Jesse Helms of North Carolina; William Armstrong of Colorado, Jake Garn of Utah, Phil Gramm of Texas; Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire; James McClure; and Steve Symms of Idaho and Malcolm C. Wallop of Wyoming.
Passage of the measure is by no means assured in the House of Representatives, where some Democrats like Augustus Hawkins of California, who is chairman of the Committee on Education and Labor, object to spending $35 million on a magnet schools program intended to attract gifted students to enriched educational programs. Mr. Hawkins objects to magnet schools unless they are tied to racial desegregation efforts.

HEADLINE: The Third Russian Revolution;
And the U.S.S.R.'s Union. And Its Economy.

 BODY:
It was as though President Bush had proposed in his State of the Union speech to do away with America's two-party system, federalism and private property. Standing there in Moscow, Mikhail Gorbachev confidently proclaimed to the Central Committee of the Communist Party that the party's monopoly of power had to go. Not only that: central control of the Soviet Union from Moscow had to go. And not only that: state ownership of the means of production had to go. 
These are radical reforms, all right. To the old-line Communists, Mr. Gorbachev's radicalism is apostasy and heresy - an assault on, among other things, their power and privilege. But Mr. Gorbachev, who once resisted radical reform, knows they have no better idea of how to save the party, the union or the economy. A radical program is now realistic.
He is facing facts and insisting that policy adjust to them. But can he adjust it fast enough?
Fact No. 1: Few Soviet citizens continue to believe in Communism. Without that belief, the Communist Party's extraordinary power lacks justification. So does the power of the Soviet state.
Mr. Gorbachev's answer to this loss of legitimacy is elections. He's betting that old-line apparatchiks who oppose him won't pass the electoral test and will have to retire. If enough reformers win, they may renew the party. If not, the party's base will erode further, and Party Secretary Gorbachev will have to rely more on his authority as President Gorbachev to get his way.
But elections can legitimize more than his authority. In the Baltic republics, they will give nationalists the basis for demanding their own states.
Fact No. 2. The Soviet Union is less than the sum of its parts. Across the country, nationalists assertively distance themselves from Moscow.
Mr. Gorbachev wants to turn these nationalist pressures to his advantage by moving from union to loose federation. That means devolving political and economic authority to the republics and undermining the power of the apparatchik-dominated ministries in Moscow.
Even so, some republics, not satisfied with greater autonomy, may push to secede.
Fact No. 3. Reform, far from reviving the flagging economy, has deepened the decay. And the apparatchiks continue to resist change. Yet most citizens realize there's no turning back. They're receptive to more radical reform. Mr. Gorbachev has now pointed the way. He's introducing new forms of private property in some sectors of the economy to encourage entrepreneurs.
But this reform may be too narrow in scope and too hedged with restrictions to generate much economic growth. And it will spawn inequality before growth, leading those less favored to denounce privilege and economic experimentation.
Mr. Gorbachev seems to emerge from this week's transformations stronger. But even if his grip on the Kremlin is secure, his right to rule will, with faith in the party and Communism shaken, ultimately depend on the Soviet people. Only they can turn the reforms, however radical, into results.

HEADLINE: Baby Costs Plenty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In response to Laura B. Kennelly (letter, Jan. 31), who suggests that parents work to ''decorate their babies with expensive items'' and that children raised in such an environment will require therapy and special schools, we would like to say, ''Grow up!''
Many dual-income families work out of economic necessity. For those women who choose to work, we hope Ms. Kennelly respects their decision, just as we respect her decision to be a full-time mother with her baby supplies of borrowed clothing, used furniture, and hemmed-up sheets for bedding.
Your publication of such a letter, however, was offensive and hurtful. As young working parents living in New York City, we know how difficult and expensive a task it is to raise a baby. The expense cited by American Demographics magazine for a baby's first year of $5,774 is realistic, if not low. Believe us, it is a struggle to balance family and career and to find quality child care. We are doing the best we can and do not appreciate harsh judgments.
 
SUSAN LIPP
MITCHELL LIPP
 New York, Jan. 31, 1990

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
No End to the Threat

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
On the very day when Mikhail Gorbachev was arguing in a stormy Central Committee session for the Soviet Communist Party to begin sharing power with other political groups, what was President Bush's maladroit message to the world?
''Now, back to war,'' he told American troops during their maneuvers at Fort Irwin, Calif.
The President's hortatory remark was televised at the end of a speech that had interrupted a simulated tank war in Europe. Mr. Bush's presence on the field reflected his determination to maintain an enormous military budget, despite what he conceded were ''encouraging changes'' in what used to be the Communist world, and despite overwhelming domestic spending needs.
Nothing that's happened in Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union, Mr. Bush maintained at Fort Irwin in a new theme of his Administration, should ''lull us into a sense of complacency.'' 
Of course not, but when he himself - properly, I believe - praises Mr. Gorbachev's leadership and publicly hopes for the success of the Soviet President's reform program, are the American people really supposed to believe that the Gorbachev program may include a conventional invasion of Western Europe and/or a strategic attack on the U.S.?
That's what Marlin Fitzwater, the White House Press Secretary, seemed to suggest when he said the threat posed by Soviet nuclear forces had not diminished and despite lessening of tensions ''the United States must continue to maintain a robust and credible nuclear deterrent.''
Or is Mr. Bush warning that if Mr. Gorbachev is overthrown, his successors may launch an aggression? Either cold war notion asks Americans to discount new and old Soviet weaknesses:
* The loss of Eastern Europe, including East Germany and crippling the supposed strength of the Warsaw Pact.
* The surging internal unrest, from Lithuania to Azerbaijan, that undermines the 70-year Soviet regime and may turn back the calendar not just to World War II but to 1917.
* The pervasive economic and technological stagnation that impelled Mr. Gorbachev's effort to remake Soviet society.
If, despite Mr. Bush's so-called prudence, you believe that all these facts might at last diminish the fear of Soviet aggression that for 40 years has shaped U.S. foreign policy and military spending, Richard G. Darman offers another facile ''threat'':
''There are third parties now - non-superpowers,'' the budget director and this Administration's house intellectual told a television audience, ''who have ballistic missile capability.'' If the Russians aren't coming, folks, maybe somebody else is.
That, Mr. Darman said with a straight face, makes it imperative for the U.S. to spend more - in fact, $900 million more than last year - for the Star Wars missile defense, and to continue building the Stealth bomber ($500 million each). He did not name any ''third parties.''
Star Wars, moreover, is by now a certified non-starter, out of Buck Rogers by Rube Goldberg. Skeptics may well wonder, therefore, if the sickly U.S. education system and the nation's decaying infrastructure (to name only two domestic needs) are really being sacrificed to the 'threat' of North Korean missiles, or actually to Mr. Bush's fear of the Republican right wing.
As for the rest of the President's military budget, do not be misled by talk of ''spending cuts.'' In fact, military spending is going up, though not by as much as once was predicted. The total in fiscal 1991 will be $295 billion, which - though touted as a reduction of 2.6 percent in projected Pentagon spending power - represents an increase of about $5 billion in actual dollars over the current year. Proposed reductions, over all, are limited and ''fairly timid,'' said Les Aspin, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
The resulting military force, bristling as it still does with weapons systems and the ability to project U.S. power anywhere in the world, won't look timid in Moscow. The embattled Mr. Gorbachev will hardly see the helping hand Mr. Bush promised him, in a military budget rising in the face of what is undeniably the retreat and contraction of Soviet military power.
Worse, those in this country who lack jobs, shelter, education, health care and hope can take comfort only in the knowledge that, even with the Warsaw Pact in disarray, George Bush stands militant guard against third parties with missiles.

LENGTH: 977 words

HEADLINE: Polishing Image, Principal Bans Gold Teeth

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
A Brooklyn high school principal has banned decorative gold caps for teeth because he believes they do not convey the serious image his students need to be successful in the business world.
''You can't go to Wall Street with gold teeth or excessive gold jewelry,'' the principal, Frank Mickens, told an auditorium full of freshmen at Boys and Girls High School yesterday. ''You can be a drug dealer, you can be a prostitute, you can be a pimp.''
As the students reacted to the directive with loud cries of derision, Mr. Mickens said: ''I'm not playing. Don't tell me it's implanted in there.'' He said any student who did not want to comply with his ruling could transfer to another school. 
In banning gold caps on teeth, the principal at the school in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section advanced a national trend in which educators are asking students to leave their expensive clothes and jewelry at home. There are two reasons: In flaunting costly coats and strands of gold the students are vulnerable to crime. And, educators say, they are also learning to place more emphasis on material things than on academic achievement.
In poor neighborhoods in Chicago, Detroit and Los Angeles there has been an increase in robberies by young people willing to kill for clothes. Mr. Mickens, a tough, outspoken principal who directs a school of 3,500 students, said he believes that three years ago he became the first principal in New York City to ban excessive gold jewelry. He has also banned short skirts, personal tape players and shearling coats.
As far as he knows, he is the first New York principal to ban gold teeth. A spokesman for the Board of Education, Robert H. Terte, said that there is no dress code for New York pupils but that principals have broad authority to set rules. ''The standard is whether it's reasonable and necessary to maintain order and discipline in the schools,'' Mr. Terte said.
 
Incessant Hallway Patrol
The ban on gold teeth is simply the second phase of what Mr. Mickens calls his ''moral mission'' to impart values at 1700 Fulton Street, where he has been the principal for four years. The school sits amid an area infested with drugs and crime and was once regarded as one of the worst schools in New York.
Now, 70 percent of the seniors at Boys and Girls go on to higher education, and the halls are clean and quiet. Much of the success is credited to Mr. Mickens, who incessantly patrols the hallways barking orders, shaking the hands of honor students and cajoling others to try harder. He estimates that only about 100 students wear the gold caps, but he says they are 100 too many.
''In dealing with black and Hispanic young people, I teach them they have to be beyond reproach, people have to look at them and immediately know they are dealing with a good young person,'' said Mr. Mickens, who is black. ''We're on a campaign of self-esteem. It's my belief once a kid feels good about himself he won't need that gold.''
''He is a person setting kids in the right direction,'' said Obah-David Ward, president of the school's Parent, Teacher and Community Association. ''The parents concur in what he is doing.'' Mr. Ward agrees with Mr. Mickens that many parents are too intimidated by their own children to set limits on what they wear.
 
Reasons Are Cosmetic
''You have to look at the broader issue of what is happening to our children and our community,'' Mr. Ward said. ''You look at the troubling unemployment or the parents working two or three jobs and who just aren't there to see their children,'' he said. ''Our children are placing the accent on the wrong thing: the gold here and the gold there, the right shoes, the right dress. We want the emphasis to be on education.''
Most of the gold teeth are simply for cosmetic reasons, students say. The caps, which slip over one's real teeth, range in cost from $40 to over $100. Especially popular right now are gold caps over the two front teeth, sometimes etched with initials or dice or another emblem. Boys wear them more often than girls.
The students say the gold teeth may have first appeared in the mouths of drug dealers or others looking for ostentatious ways to show their wealth but are now simply a fad. Although some students said they believed the ban was an invasion of their privacy, others said they thought the principal had their safety in mind. Others thought gold teeth conveyed a ''tough'' image.
 
'I Like Gold, Period'
''I just like gold teeth,'' said Michael Foreman, 14 years old, who attended the freshman assembly yesterday. He has two in the front of his mouth, one etched with a crown, the other with a star. He said they each cost him $40. But he said he would follow Mr. Mickens's order.
''I've had these for four or five months, since school started,'' Michael said. ''I like gold, period. It's better than silver or anything else. My parents say in some ways gold brings a lot of trouble because people try to rob you.''
A freshman, Ebony Black, 14, said the issue was more one of safety than image. She said ''a lot of people are wondering where you got the money to pay for them. A lot of people think you have to be a drug dealer or something to get them, but you don't.''
Tyrone Johnson, a 17-year-old senior, said he thought many younger students failed to understand that in the mostly white society outside Bedford-Stuyvesant gold teeth are associated with a lack of education or an unwholesome life style.
''People don't take you as seriously,'' said Mr. Johnson, an honors students who has applied to three Ivy League schools. ''They think you're a joke.''
Erskine Tillery, a 16-year-old sophmore, said he would reluctantly give up the two gold caps on his front teeth because he will probably be safer from gold thieves.
He said solemnly, ''People will shoot you if they don't come out.''

HEADLINE: O'Neill's Budget Proposes Job Cuts and Borrowing

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed a stringent state budget today that would eliminate 2,000 jobs and borrow against reserve funds, but would not raise taxes.
The $7.2 billion budget, which Mr. O'Neill outlined to the General Assembly in a sometimes emotional speech that was widely seen as the opening salvo of his re-election campaign, would also pare about $600 million in spending at state agencies.
In addition the Governor held down the size of the budget by shifting hundreds of millions of dollars for expenses like housing assistance from the state's main account, the General Fund, to specialized funds that are not calculated as part of the budget.
 
Economic Gains Expected
The budget also is based on expected improvement in Connecticut's lagging economy. It predicts that revenue from the state's 8 percent sales tax will increase 5 percent in the fiscal year beginning July 1. 
Mr. O'Neill said that the employment cuts would be felt in longer lines for things like motor vehicle registration but that basic state commitments - especially aid to cities and towns - would remain intact.
Mr. O'Neill's Republican opponents in the legislature immediately attacked the shifts of budget accounts as a fraud that would would mask deeper budget problems and come back to haunt Connecticut as those special accounts were depleted.
 
'A Shell Game at Best'
''It's a shell game at best,'' said the State Republican Party chairman, Dick Foley.
Mr. O'Neill, who was presenting his 10th budget since taking office in 1980, told the packed audience of lawmakers, lobbyists and visitors in the ornate Hall of the House of Representatives that the budget was an honest one and that hard times had demanded choices.
Repeatedly rousing his audience with a shouted charge - ''Stand up for Connecticut!'' - Mr. O'Neill defended the budget transfers and said that shifted funds, while not counted in the budget total, were not being used inappropriately.
''In these difficult times, our budget must meet complex and sometimes conflicting demands,'' he said.
The dispute, on the opening day of the General Assembly session, resulted into two sharply differing accounts about exactly how much spending would grow in the fiscal year that begins July 1. Mr. O'Neill and other Democrats who control the Assembly said 4.5 percent - the lowest spending growth in 15 years. Republicans, calculating the off-budget shifts, said 8.9 percent.
For both groups, the analysis focused on what in Connecticut politics is one of the more sacred and explosive spending categories - aid to cities and towns. In Mr. O'Neill's budget, a special $215 million property tax relief fund, created in 1985 and scheduled under current law to be distributed to municipalities over 10 years, would essentially be drained to keep the present local grants intact.
The annual distribution of $42 million would be increased by $140 million primarily by mixing in budget items that are currently paid to the towns from the General Fund. Payments, for example, to compensate municipalities for loss of revenue on such tax-exempt properties as hospitals would be paid from the property tax fund.
 
Future Prospects Uncertain
''There's no magic - the budget would have been cut had we not had the resources of that fund,'' said Anthony V. Milano, the secretary of the Office of Policy and Management and Mr. O'Neill's chief budget officer. Asked whether using most of the relief fund this year would threaten the long-term promises to the towns, Mr. Milano said it could not yet be determined.
''These choices have to be made on an annual basis,'' he said of the local aid grants.
In addition to the property fund changes, three regulatory agencies that were formerly financed from the General Fund - the Hospitals and Health Care Commission, the Liquor Control Departnent Commission and the Worker's Compensation Commission, with combined budgets of about $8 million - would be removed from the General Fund under Mr. O'Neill's plan. Those agencies would finance their operations by requiring those it regulates to pay ''assessments.''
 
Borrowing and Bond Sales
A third category concerned budget items formerly in the General Fund that would instead be covered by borrowing and bond sales. About $65 million of those shifts were proposed in the budget, including $35 million for local school construction.
According to Gordon J. Frasinelli, the executive budget officer at the Office of Policy and Management, about half of all the state agencies and commissions in the state will get the same or less money this coming year than they did last year.
The winners, he said, include the Department of Correction, which is responsible for overseeing the state's huge prison expansion. Its appropriation will increase about 20 percent, to $420 million.
The Department of Income Maintenance, which distributes Medicaid payments and aid to the poor - and which has seen its own internal budget depleted by rising medical and welfare costs - will get an 11 percent increase to $1.7 billion. Still, the total is $100 million less than the department had requested.

HEADLINE: Man Suspected in 4 Slayings Dies in Shootout With Police

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DRYDEN, N.Y., Feb. 7

 BODY:
A man suspected of killing a family of four in their home in December was killed today in a shootout with state troopers. The man's mother was arrested and charged with murder in connection with the slayings.
The state police Superintendent, Thomas Constantine, identified the dead man as Anthony Turner, 33 years old. 
Mr. Turner's mother, 54-year-old Shirley Kinge, was arraigned tonight in Town Court in Dryden, a suburb of Ithaca, on four counts of second-degree murder and one count each of arson and criminal possession of stolen property. Town Justice Edwin Sweetland ordered her held without bail.
Mr. Turner's 2-year-old child was turned over to social workers by state troopers.
Superintendent Constantine said at a news conference this afternoon that Mr. Turner was sitting on a bed in his apartment holding a shotgun to his chin when the authorities entered the room.
The suspect turned toward the troopers and fired a single shot, Mr. Constantine said. The three troopers then returned the gunfire, he said.
The Superintendent said an autopsy was planned to determine whether Mr. Turner killed himself or was killed by the shots fired by the police.
 
Suspected for Week
The authorities carried a warrant charging Mr. Turner - also known as Michael Kinge - with four counts of second-degree murder in the Dec. 22, 1989, slayings of Warren Harris, 39; his wife, Dolores, 41, and their children, Shelby, 15, and Marc, 11, during an apparent robbery.
The state police said Mr. Turner had been a suspect for about a week, and neighbors said his apartment had been staked out since Friday. Mr. Turner, an unemployed maintenance worker, had a long criminal history in New York City, including convictions for burglary and theft with a deadly weapon.
 
Threat From Turner
After an arrest in 1982, he said he regretted that he did not ''shoot it out'' with the arresting officer, Superintendent Constantine said.
Superintendent Constantine said Mr. Turner might have known that he had become the focus of the Harris investigation. An unidentified associate of Mr. Turner told the police that Mr. Turner always had firearms with him and would shoot it out with the police if they tried to arrest him for the Harris murders and would kill as many officers as possible, the Superintendent said.
Maj. Robert J. Farrand said there were no other suspects at this time, although the investigation is continuing.
In December, the Harrises were tied up, shot in the back of the head and hours later doused with fuel and set afire in upstairs bedrooms at their home on a large wooded lot.
The bodies were discovered the next day as firefighters responded to a report of a fire at the Harris house.
 
Shot in Head
The police have said robbery appears the most likely motive for the killings. Mrs. Harris ran a country gift and antique store just a few yards from the house. Her husband was a sales director for an electronics distributor.
Three of the family members were found in one room, bound hand and foot and with pillowcases over their heads, Superintendent Constantine said. They had each been shot in the back of the head with a .22-caliber weapon.
Shelby Harris was found in a second bedroom. The police said she had been sexually assaulted and shot in the head.
On the day that the bodies were found, a man and woman used the Harrises' credit cards to buy clothing, electronics and diamonds at malls in suburban Syracuse and Auburn.
Clerks at those stores helped a police artist draw sketches of the people who used the cards.
