HEADLINE: Speech Invitation Divides Columbia

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Richard Griffin, who appears with the rap group Public Enemy as Professor Griff, is scheduled to deliver a speech at Columbia University next week. The invitation, from the Black Students Organization at Columbia, has upset other student groups, including Jewish organizations, because of anti-Semitic remarks he made last year.
No one has publicly demanded the cancellation of his talk, scheduled for Sunday evening in the Altschul Auditorium at the School of International Affairs. The leaders of the Black Students Organization said they had asked Mr. Griffin to speak on education in the year 2000, not his remarks about Jews. 
The student group issued the invitation because, it said, it considered Mr. Griffin an important force in black America. Members of the group maintain that they can sponsor his appearance whether or not they endorse his beliefs.
Mr. Griffin said yesterday that the remarks that sparked the controversy, which he made in an interview with The Washington Times, were taken out of their full context. ''If you look into the root meaning of the term,'' he said, ''a black man in America can never be anti-Semitic.''
But some students and administrators at Columbia contend that student funds, made available to the organization for Black History Month, should not be used to underwrite his appearance.
''Inviting him here was a mistake, and appropriating the money was a mistake,'' said the dean of Columbia College, Jack Greenberg. ''But it would be a bigger mistake to withdraw the money now. I don't think he should be thrown off campus. The best way to handle this is just leave him alone.''
 
Rule on Speech Cited
A student group that promotes campus events, the Board of Managers, withdrew $1,000 it had pledged for the Black Students Organization's programs this month. Leaders of the board said they set aside the money after the black students' group had told them about a speech by the writer Maya Angelou. The umbrella group said the black students did not tell them about Mr. Griffin until last week.
''Columbia has a disciplinary statute saying any speech that denigrates another because of race, religion or sexual orientation will be dealt with in the most severe manner,'' said the president of the Board of Managers, David Mlodinoff. ''I thought co-sponsorship of Griff would make me partially responsible.''
Another group, the Columbia College Student Council, decided on Monday not to rescind $9,000 that it had earmarked for the Black Students Organiation and the black history observances.
Mr. Griffin was billed as Public Enemy's ''minister of information'' last May when The Washington Times quoted him as saying that Jews were responsible for ''the majority of wickedness that goes on across the globe.''
Asked in a telephone interview last night what he had meant, Mr. Griffin said: ''There is wickedness that goes on across the globe. Certain atrocities done to black people, yes, Jews had hands in it and black Africans, they had their hands in it. Not only Jews but Gentiles, kings and queens.'' He said he was referring to ''the enslavement and the dehumanization of the black man and woman in America'' and to a Public Health Service program at the Tuskegee Institute that, from 1932 to 1972, withheld treament from syphilitic men. The purpose was to determine the natural course of the disease, regardless of the human cost.
Soon after the interview was published, the songwriter and main rapper for the group, Carlton Ridenhour, known as Chuck D, dismissed Mr. Griffin and announced that Public Enemy was disbanding.
 
'Speaking to His Own People'
''Griff is not anti-Semitic,'' Mr. Ridenhour said at the time. ''He hangs out with Falasha Jews from Ethiopia damn near every other month. His beef was with Israel and its involvement in South Africa, which hurts his people, black people. But you don't blame Jews for Israel. So I made him apologize, and he was demoted. Now he's speaking to his own people instead of the world.''
Public Enemy began appearing together again a few months later, and Mr. Griffin was given a different role, as the group's liaison aide to black neighborhoods and youth programs.
It was Public Enemy that performed ''Fight the Power'' in ''Do the Right Thing,'' the Spike Lee film. The song called Elvis Presley a racist.
More recently, Mr. Griffin has opened the group's shows by strutting in front of a ''security force,'' part of the group's retinue, in mock-military maneuvers. On Jan. 1, Mr. Griffin's routine included a speech in which he said that the AIDS epidemic had been propogated as an experiment by Moscow and Washington.
At Columbia, leaders of the Black Students Organization have defended their choice of Mr. Griffin as a speaker, saying that he and Public Enemy have a wide following.
''He's coming here to speak on education in the year 2000, about the black community to the black community, and we want to hear him on that,'' said the president of the group, Alethia Jones, a junior from Brooklyn. ''What the Board of Managers is doing is trying to exercise economic power over us, which is not fair and not justified.''
When asked whether the black students' organization approved of Mr. Griffin's comments about Jews, the chairman of the group's political committee, Hector Carter, told a student newspaper, The Federalist Paper: ''The B.S.O. is neutral on that. We want to hear what the man has to say. We're not saying, 'Yes, he's right,' or, 'No, he's wrong.' ''
Mr. Griffin said last night that he was willing to meet with Board of Managers officers. ''I have to break up the old relationship between blacks and Jews,'' he said. ''No more master and slave relationship, no more landlord and tenant, no more employee-employer relationship. We are mature. It's 1990 and we should get together at the bargaining table.''
The offer came three days after Jewish groups on campus met to plan a response to Mr. Griffin's appearance. More than 400 students jammed an auditorium in the basement of Butler Library, and 200 others waited outside.
 
Boycott Proposal From Dean
At the meeting, Dean Greenberg proposed that students boycott Mr. Griffin's speech. Then - after a member of the black students' group, Maurice Coleman, urged everyone to go to see Mr. Griffin for themselves - 100 members of the Black Students Organization filed out of the room. The Jewish chaplain at Columbia, Rabbi Charles Sheer, followed them into the corridor and urged them to return. But they did not.
Since then, three petitions protesting the speech have been drawn up, one by the Council of Jewish Organizations, one by the senior class and one by another group of students. More than 1,200 people have signed the Jewish organization's petition, and the group plans to run it as an advertisement in another campus newspaper, The Columbia Daily Spectator.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Is Sending Signals He Won't Run for Governor

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHEEKTOWAGA, N.Y., Feb. 7

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giuliani is sending strong signals that he will not be a Republican candidate for governor this year, even though he has started a traditional campaign warm-up: a series of speaking engagements throughout New York State.
''I'm not closing the door but I don't want to hold out any great hope that I will be running,'' Mr. Giuliani told editors at The Buffalo News on Tuesday.
And as he flew into the Buffalo area earlier in the day, he said in an interview: ''I've told Republican leaders that they should try to develop other candidates. I can't make a commitment to run as a full-time candidate now.'' 
Mr. Giuliani's words were backed by actions suitable for a politician who wants to keep his political prospects alive - possibly for a Senate candidacy in 1992 - without challenging one of the strongest Democrats in the country, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is expected to seek a third term.
 
'Vision of America'
Some Republicans had said Mr. Giuliani would deliver a speech highly critical of the Governor on Tuesday night at the annual Erie County Republican Dinner here. Republican State Committee researchers had provided him with five pages of economic statistics to use to attack Mr. Cuomo.
But after Mr. Giuliani's advisers told him that such a critical speech would be inappropriate for a noncandidate, he discarded the material, delivering instead a mild 30-minute address on what he called his ''vision of America and vision of New York in the year 2000.'' The speech drew applause from the 500 Republicans in attendance only once.
Mr. Giuliani's advisers say challenging Mr. Cuomo would be an enormous risk, and they concede that a defeat in the gubernatorial race so soon after Mr. Giuliani's unsuccessful mayoral campaign in New York City last year would probably end his brief electoral career. His campaign against David N. Dinkins was his first.
Mr. Giuliani has scheduled about 12 appearances outside New York City in the next six weeks. He said the purpose of the speaking tour was to help the Republican Party raise money and to ''develop a relationship with the party, learn issues and meet people.'' He said he would make a final decision on a gubernatorial candidacy after these appearances.
 
Would Need Bush's Help
If he were to run for governor, Mr. Giuliani said, he would need $10 million to $15 million, a huge sum that his advisers said could be raised only with the all-out help of President Bush, who would then be putting his own political credits on the line. The rationale for Mr. Bush's intervention would be to hobble Mr. Cuomo as a potential Presidential candidate in 1992.
The Republican State Committee, in its latest financial accounting reported last month, said it had less than $5,000 in its treasury despite the efforts of its new chairman, J. Patrick Barrett, a multimillionaire who has donated more than $100,000 of his own money to the committee.
Mr. Barrett said that he had a $6 million fund-raising goal this year but that the money would be used for operating costs and State Senate campaigns and only partly for the gubernatorial candidate.
Of Mr. Giuliani's gubernatorial intentions, Mr. Barrett, who did not attend the Republican gathering here, said in a telephone interview, ''I really don't know what Rudy thinks.'' But he said Mr. Giuliani was not following his advice that an early decision be made.
 
Congressman a Possibility
Mr. Barrett said he was looking to other candidates but named only one, Representative Bill Green of Manhattan, whose East Side district may be merged with that of Representative Ted Weiss of the West Side in the redrawing of Congressional district lines next year.
Mr. Barrett said another potential candidate, State Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan, was ''kind of untouchable because he's in the State Senate.'' Republicans are fearful of losing their last stronghold in the state, control of the Senate.
Another handicap for Mr. Giuliani is that he has apparently not resolved the problem of how a Republican who accepted the Liberal Party's endorsement, as he did in his mayoral campaign, and still counts the Liberal Party leader, Raymond B. Harding, as one of his confidants, can move rightward this year to be acceptable to the Conservative Party. He acknowledged that a Republican usually needs Conservative support to win a statewide contest.
The Conservative Party state chairman, Michael Long, said Mr. Giuliani's Liberal ties are ''a major hurdle.''

In spite of a series of such speaking engagements, Mr. Giuliani is sending strong signals that he will not run for governor this year. (The New York Times/Joe Traver)

HEADLINE: Other Furnishers Aren't Smiling

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
FROM all the talk of nesting and cocooning, one would think that the golden era of the home has arrived. Americans supposedly have given up their wild times on the town to eat take-out food in front of the television, ensconced in comfortable couches, feet solidly on the coffee table.
But it has not turned out that way. There is no boom in the home furnishings business. Companies like the Ralph Lauren Home Collection, whose sales rose 19 percent from 1988 to 1989, are the exception rather than the rule. 
The number of pieces of furniture sold in the United States last year fell by 1.5 percent from 1988, according to the American Association of Furniture Manufacturers. Other areas of the home furnishings industry, like appliances and carpeting, report that sales are down, flat or up only slightly. The percentage of income spent on furniture has fluctuated slightly but remained essentially flat, at roughly 1 percent of income, through the 1980's.
''The industry isn't faring well,'' said Donald A. Belgrad, president of Schnadig Corporation, a Chicago-based company that makes tables and upholstered furniture. ''You see all the electronics and maybe some futons on the floor.''
Jeffrey St. Clair, who studies trends for Retail Planning Associates in Columbus, Ohio, recently conducted in-depth market-research interviews with affluent consumers in the Washington area. He found that most wanted to spend their money creating interesting lives for themselves and their children, on things like entertainment and vacations.
''Feathering the nest,'' he said, ''did not come out as strongly as enriching their lives. They want to consume experiences.''
To help redirect their consumption, a new consortium of furniture makers, the Home Furnishings Council, will soon start an advertising campaign, with a first-year budget of about $7 million, that will try to stimulate home purchases by linking them to the quality of family life. The council plans to use the slogan, ''It All Begins at Home.''
Industry experts blame the current economic climate for disappointing sales. ''Consumers are bracing for a recession,'' said Wallace W. Epperson Jr., who studies the home furnishings market for Wheat First Securities in Richmond, Va. Personal savings are up, he said, and consumer debt is dropping.
A soft market for new-home construction may be hurting the sales of larger items. Unit sales of dishwashers, refrigerators and stoves are all expected to have fallen in 1989 when final figures are in, according to the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers in Chicago.
Those who are buying are decorating slowly because their basic housing costs are taking more of their income. ''You're seeing families furnish over a period of three or four years rather than in the first six months,'' said Greg Silverman, who studies home furnishings for Management Horizons in Dublin, Ohio, consultants to retailers.
Some companies, of course, are doing well, usually because they have clearly defined their style and simplified the decision-making process for the consumer. Often, they help consumers hurdle mental obstacles by making furniture available immediately and displaying it in room settings that make it easy to visualize the decorating possibilities.
IKEA, the large Swedish retailer, saw its sales in the United States grow 40 percent last year. Its four American stores offer a wide range of well-designed modern home furnishings for very low prices, yet are perceived as offering quality. Items are sold individually, but whole rooms are also displayed with a total pricetag. Merchandise, much of it ready-to-assemble, is sold warehouse style and can be carried out of the store.
This spring, IKEA U.S. Inc., which has stores in Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, is opening a 270,000 square-foot-store in Elizabeth, N.J., that will be its largest outside of Scandinavia.
Another thriving company that offers reasonably priced items perceived to offer quality is the Bombay Company, which sells reproductions of English antiques. The company's sales grew 49 percent from 1988 to 1989, and it added 52 stores in that time, for a total of 215.
While consumers like to see room displays, they also want to express individuality.
''For our parents, the concept of what was in and what was out was very important,'' said Raymond Chevallier, the 39-year-old vice president of marketing at F. Schumacher & Co. in New York, which sells expensive home textiles. ''There were very strong trends in color. Our generation is much less prone to lock step. Somebody can go to Conran's, and then specify a Schumacher damask.''
Generally, accessories are selling better than big-ticket items. Robert McElroy, manager for home furnishings at Bloomingdale's in New York, said sales of bed sheets costing more than $50 apiece have been exceptional. ''People do not balk at the price,'' he said. ''If they've got the money, they don't mind spending it.''
Sales of home textiles, a $14 billion market that includes things like curtains, drapes, towels and mattress pads, were up 2.9 percent in 1989 from 1988. But this growth was far below the previous year's increase of 7.1 percent, according to HFD, a weekly home furnishings newspaper in New York.
In all categories, Mr. McElroy said, consumers want products that will last. They are buying top-of-the-line sheets from Fieldcrest and Cannon, the Ralph Lauren Line, Christian Dior china and glasses, and crystal from Lalique, Baccarat and Waterford. For the kitchen, he said, they are buying well-known, professional-quality items like Cuisinart, Calphalon and All-Clad.
While many companies have been disappointed by recent sales, industry executives are confident that the maturing baby-boom generation will buy home furnishings in the 1990's.
''The consciousness of millions of people is being directed to the importance of the home,'' said Nathan S. Ancell, the founder and chairman emeritus of Ethan Allen, the big furniture maker with 300 stores. ''The interest in fixing up the home is going to substantially increase.''

HEADLINE: Robots Transform Coal Mining

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WANA, W.Va.

 BODY:
The four-inch carbide-steel claws of a screaming yellow robot tore relentlessly at the coal seam 1,000 feet below the surface, digging enough in 30 seconds to meet the electric needs of a typical suburban house for a year.
The robot's human master, old enough to remember when miners used picks and shovels and loaded coal into carts drawn by dogs, strolled beside, periodically pushing buttons on support equipment.
Coal mining, an unglamorous business known mostly for accidents and bitter strikes, is going high tech, and the resulting productivity gains are important for a nation that is using up its other fossil fuels.
The country's deposits of coal are expected to last more than a century, while oil reserves will last only 10 years at current rates of production, assuming no more oil is found. Gas reserves are also more limited than coal supplies. As oil and gas are used up, finding and extracting them become more expensive; by contrast, because of technical advances like the robot, the cost of digging coal is falling. Thus, over the long term, the price gap between coal and oil and gas will probably grow, and coal could become an even more important energy resource. 
 
A New Mining Method
The robot here, in the Consolidation Coal Company's Blacksville No. 2 mine, 700 to 1,400 feet under the Mason-Dixon line, is perhaps the most advanced in the country. It is but one recent improvement in a highly automated technique called longwall mining, in which coal is removed not by tunneling like a worm through an apple, leaving more of the target than is removed, but by methodically shuttling back and forth across the width of the deposit and devouring nearly everything.
Longwall mining has been around for decades but mine operators have recently made the technique far more efficient. The method can now extract about 75 percent of the available coal, compared with 50 percent for conventional mining, which is done largely with machines that dig tunnels. Moreover, the coal can be recovered far more inexpensively.
While coal has been hailed as the nation's energy savior since the 1973 Arab oil embargo, the cost of oil has not risen enough to make coal a good substitute beyond the power plant, where it is burned to produce electricity. Cutting the cost of coal production is a small step toward wider use. When costs justify it, coal can even substitute for gasoline.
 
Extensive Deposits
Already, coal is the nation's biggest indigenous energy source, and its role has been growing. It supplied more than 23.4 percent of all energy consumed in this country, up from 17.5 percent in 1973, the year of the first oil shock, and 19.1 percent in 1979. And it accounted for nearly one-third of all energy produced in this country last year, up from 22.5 percent in 1973. It is the main fuel used to make electricity, providing about 56 percent, and is also the nation's largest energy export by far.
But increased production of coal also raises intense environmental questions. The issues range from the speculative - like the extent of global warming caused by the burning of carbon-rich fuels like coal - to the spooky, like the collapse of land as robot miners pass beneath. The Government is spending more than $5 billion to find cleaner ways to use coal, and the coal companies have tried harder to ameliorate the effects of the collapse, called ''subsidence.''
Longwall mining is used wherever coal is present in thick, level seams deep under the ground. (Shallow deposits are often exploited by strip mining, in which the surface layers are scraped away and the coal is excavated from an open pit.) Embracing new technologies and sometimes developing technology on its own, Consolidation Coal, a subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, last year mined 55 million tons with 9,500 employees. Fifteen years earlier it took 23,000 workers to mine 55 million tons. A big part of the change was installing 22 longwall machines like the robot here.
Despite the loss of employment, the United Mine Workers union generally favors longwall mines. ''Back in the 1950's, John L. Lewis said it would be far better to have highly productive oprations that were able to pay our folks good wages and benefits than to have 600,000 shovelers living in poverty,'' said John Duray, a spokesman for the union.
 
Called Safer
Union officials say longwall mines are also inherently safer in their design, and the mines that can afford them are generally the bigger, better-managed ones.
Consol, as the company that operates this mine is known, is by far the biggest longwall operator.
In the longwall system at Blacksville 2, miners dig a tunnel the height of the coal seam, and in it they set up a row of floor-to-ceiling steel brackets to hold up the rock and soil above. Sheltered by the shields, the miners install a robot that runs back and forth on a track across the 750-foot-long wall of coal on the open side of the bracket. On each pass, a wheel 4 feet in diameter, studded with claws, chews up the coal in a space extending 3 feet high and 30 inches in front of it. The coal falls to a conveyor belt. At the end of the wall, the robot miner, called a shearer, reverses direction and makes a pass just below the first.
When the shearer has finished its second pass, devouring almost all of the six-foot height of the coal seam here, it moves 30 inches forward and starts again. Then, in a sequence worthy of a grade-B science fiction film, each of the 153 steel shields in the row takes it turn stepping forward into the space that the shearer just opened, to be in position for the shearer's next pass. As they step forward, the earth behind them collapses.
The longwall moves forward 17 to 20 feet per eight-hour shift, two or three shifts a day, until it has covered about a mile, over many months. Then, in a few hours, the equipment is moved to another track 750 feet long, and starts work again.
 
Fierce Competition
The process can help coal companies achieve enormous efficiencies. Competition among coal producers is vicious, and executives at Consol say they plan to meet it by increasing productivity 3 to 6 percent annually.
Setting up a modern mine can cost $100 million, and the chance of making a killing is very small. Unlike the price of oil, the price of coal has been fairly stable since the early 80's and is not likely to go anywhere soon; when inflation is taken into account, the price of coal is down by 44 percent since 1975.
The price varies according to the sulfur content and energy content of the coal. In September, the amount of coal required to make a kilowatt-hour of electricity cost only 54 percent as much as the oil needed for the same job, according to the National Coal Association.
Blacksville has two of Consol's 20 longwall machines. There are only about 100 longwall systems running in the 2,000 underground coal mines in the United States, but they produce about one-third the coal that comes from such mines, and some experts think that figure will rise to more than half by the end of the 90's.
About a third of the nation's coal comes from surface mining, mostly in the West. The other third comes from underground mines that use older technologies, either because their owners cannot afford longwall machines or because the coal deposits are unsuitable for them.
 
Further Refinements
Engineers are now working on additional refinements to longwall mining. For example, operators of the Blacksville 2 mine hope that even pushing the buttons to make the 153 shields step forward - now done by a human - will soon be taken over by the robot's computer brain.
Workers at this mine do not believe that this refinement will cut payrolls further because someone will be needed to watch the robots. At other mines, however, the prospect of installing a longwall machine brings dread because of the layoffs that will come with it.
High-tech changes are taking place at the surface, too. In a small factory at the mouth of the mine, the coal is washed in water and other liquids, removing some of the sulfur; it is then dried, crushed and sorted by size. Sometimes it is blended with coal from other mines.

HEADLINE: Bank Tests Its Formula in Texas

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
When John B. McCoy, chairman of the Banc One Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, talks about himself, he is apt to make self-effacing comments about how he has never (''well, hardly ever'') made a loan and how he was slow to see the opportunities of expanding into Texas.
But Mr. McCoy's modest descriptions of his abilities contain clues about how he helped lead Banc One to become one of the most successful banks in the country. By concentrating on consumer banking and lending to small businesses, as well innovatively applying computer technology, the company has produced 21 consecutive years of rising profits.
Enlarged by last week's acquistion of the Bright Savings Association in Dallas and last June's purchase of 20 banks formerly owned by MCorp of Austin, Tex., Banc One is now the nation's 13th-largest banking company. But it is entirely within Mr. McCoy's character that Banc One was not the first or most agressive bank-holding company to go after foundering institutions in Texas. 
 
'No Large Loans'
Mr. McCoy's lack of ambition to make a mark as a hot-shot lender with the fanciest deals for the largest clients has spared Banc One the troubles that other bankers have found in giving large loans to third world countries, real estate developers or to finance leveraged buyouts. ''We have no large loans,'' Mr. McCoy said, ''because any loan above $50 million has to be signed by me, and I don't make loans.''
When other Banc One executives suggested two years ago that there were opportunites in Texas, Mr. McCoy says he told them: ''We don't want to look in Texas. It just doesn't make sense.'' Eventually he agreed that ''looking is cheap.''
By the time he was convinced to buy the MCorp units, other banks, like the Chemical Banking Corporation and the First Interstate Bancorp, had already bought major Texas banks with many bad loans on unfavorable terms that have caused large losses at both companies.
These episodes should not suggest that Mr. McCoy is an overly cautious banker: He is merely one who has found a formula and is loath to abandon it. By sticking to what it does best, Banc One has consistenly earned far more profit per dollar of assets than other banks its size.
 
Some Unsuccessful Ventures
Not all Banc One's ventures have been successful. A 1979 attempt to develop in-home banking was a failure, as was an earlier program to install machines in grocery stores to verify customers' checks using their credit cards. But there were also successes, like its arrangement in 1977 to process Cash Management Accounts for Merrill Lynch & Company. This eventually led Banc One to become a major processor of credit card transactions for dozens of other banks and credit unions.
With the 100 new branches in Texas, however, it will be back to basics.
''Our plan in Texas is to develop the same retail banking that has worked so well in other states,'' Mr. McCoy said. ''There is a huge displacement of customers in Texas from savings and loans to banks. It's a market where consumers are not used to banking products that have been available in other parts of the country.''
Mr. McCoy sees no reason why MCorp's business-loan-oriented banks cannot learn to be consumer banks under Banc One. To speed the process, he is supporting legislation that would amend a Texas law to allow home-equity lending.
The Texas acquistion is the latest in a long string that has helped Banc One grow, even though Ohio is a slow-growth ''Rust Belt'' state with a declining population. Banc One is the parent company for more than 50 subsidiary banks, identified in signs as Bank One. The parent's name is spelled with a ''c'' because Ohio law limits the use of the word bank.
For many years, the acquisitions were limited to small, profitable banks in Ohio. While they did not mushroom in size, they almost inevitably became more profitable under Banc One. With the hiring in 1984 of William P. Boardman, a tall, silver-haired lawyer who handles acquisitons without guidance from high-priced investment bankers from Wall Street, the expansion accelerated outside Ohio.
 
Move Into Indiana
In 1986, Banc One bought the American Fletcher Corporation, the second-largest banking company in Indiana, with $4.1 billion in assets. In 1988, it bought the Marine Corporation, based in Milwaukee, with $4.3 billion in deposits. Just as it did with smaller banks, Banc One has improved profits at those banks by cutting costs and focusing more on small, high-interest-rate loans.
The Indiana bank, for example, had a reputation as a solid, profitable lender to businesses and had a client list of large companies. Its former chairman, Frank E. McKinney Jr., now president of Banc One, thought there was little chance of earning about $1.06 for every $100 of assets after the acquistion. But by 1988, two years later, Bank One Indiana was earning $1.59 for every $100 of assets.
While Banc One leaves decision-making in the hands of local banks, it handles many of their affairs where economies of scale make them suitable for centralization. Securities investments, for example, are handled in Columbus, while the Indiana bank handles processing of home mortgages. The contribution of the Texas bank may be as a corporate cash-management system.
 
A Booster of Texas
Mr. McCoy, 46 years old, whose father and grandfather were chairmen of Banc One or its predecessors, is too committed to civic improvements in his hometown of Columbus to denigrate Ohio. But he has become a booster of the Lone Star State, well aware that Dallas, Fort Worth and Houston combined are about equal to the entire Ohio banking market.
He also knows that MCorp was weakened in its fight for survival in the flagging economy of the oil state. For example, it had sold its credit card business, a key part of Banc One's business in other states, and had eliminated the division that maintained and built branch offices - another ingredient to successful expansion in the consumer market.
''We have no retail distribution network, no retail sales force and no retail products,'' George Meiling, Banc One's treasurer, said soon after the announcement of the MCorp acquisiton last year. ''Other than that, Texas is just great.''
But within hours after signing the MCorp deal, Mr. McCoy was talking about re-entering abandoned markets. A mass mailing offering credit cards to customers started within weeks and attracted responses from nearly 10 percent of the bank's customers.
 
Extraordinary Cost Savings
And while it is developing a consumer banking business, Banc One is benefiting from some extraordinary cost savings achieved by taking advantage of the ability to renegotiate terms of earlier MCorp contracts.
For example, Banc One renegoiated the lease of the Austin headquarters to $13 a square foot annually for 200,000 square feet, down from 690,000 square feet at $30 a foot. The contract with EDS Inc. to process savings, checking and other transactions was renegotiated to an annual cost of about $35 million, from $70 million under MCorp.
Banc One's vaunted system of financial management starts with the assumption, Mr. McCoy said, ''that everybody is bright and smart, but they just sometimes don't know what to do.'' While the central office in Columbus assiduously keeps its hands off the day-to-day decision-making at its subsidiary banks, it insists on prying into every detail of their financial performance.
Four times a month, every bank prepares forecasts for 12 months ahead. ''By the third day of the following month, we can spot deviations from the forecast,'' Mr. McCoy said.
Because every bank is required to follow the same definitions for expenses and revenues, the monthly figures are readily comparable. And the comparisons are not just for central office officials; executives at the individual banks are encouraged to share information with their colleagues.
''Lots of banks compare themselves with their peer group,'' said J. Douglas Adamson, former head of consumer banking at Bank One in Lafayette, Ind., and now director of the Bank Marketing Association, a trade group. ''But at Banc One, the peers are part of an exchange group, not competitors.''
 
Bankers Given 'Sisters'
To speed the learning process at the Texas bank - which Banc One expects eventually to divide into about 20 smaller banks - Texas bankers in various cities are being paired with a ''sister'' bank in the Midwest. At the top of the Texas bank, Thomas E. Hoaglin, president and an alumnus of Bank One of Dayton, Ohio, has been paired with Harvey R. Mitchell, chief executive officer, a veteran Texas banker who was previously vice chairman at the First Republicbank Corporation, Dallas.
But even with the example of Banc One's Midwestern success, James J. McDermott, a senior vice president at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a securities firm, warned that ''Texas will be the acid test.'' He said that, while Banc One ''comes from a competitive market in the Midwest, in Texas they are playing in the major leagues.''
Mr. McDermott noted that banks like the NCNB Corporation, which bought First Republicbank, and Chemical, which owns the Texas Commerce Bank, are very strong in the same retail banking business that has been Banc One's specialty but are still having problems.
In fact, moves by NCNB and Chemical so far show that they have much the same idea as Banc One - exploit the retail banking market by attracting deposits and making smaller loans while waiting for the rest of state's economy to improve.
Can Banc One be as successful in Texas as it has been in the Midwest? Many analysts and investors had their doubts when the acquisitions were made in Indiana and Wisconsin and when Banc One's stock price weakened. But its earnings since have made believers out of skeptics.
Banc One's stock price has fallen in recent months, like other banks', and probably is suffering because investors expect the company to pay for the Texas acquisitions by selling up to $200 million of new stock. Even so, the share price of around $30 is about 11 times its 1989 per share earnings, the highest of the 15 largest banking companies in the country.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
10-Year U.S. Notes Sell Well

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A better-than-expected turnout at the Treasury's quarterly auction of 10-year notes spurred a sharp turnaround in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities moved off their lows and closed higher for the day.
The Treasury received $23.9 billion in bids for the $10 billion in notes sold yesterday. That was the highest total on a 10-year note auction since the auction on Nov. 9, 1988.
Still, the welcome accorded the notes was not so strong as the bidding for the $10 billion of three-year notes offered Tuesday. Then, the Treasury received more than $34 billion in bids. 
 
Sharply Higher Yields
At yesterday's auction, the notes were sold at an average yield of 8.59 percent, up sharply from the average rate of 7.94 percent at the last 10-year note sale on Nov. 13. It is the highest yield on a 10-year issue since the May 10, 1989 sale, when bids on the securities produced an average yield of 9.18 percent.
After the Treasury announced the results of the auction the notes rallied, and by late yesterday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.50 percent.
''Everybody was so mesmerized with fear that they bid with a great deal of caution,'' said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank. ''Those cautious bids helped to allow the auction to go well.''
Traders said the bidding process was helped by big accounts that sold mortgage-backed securities to buy the new notes, by the Japanese and by individual investors. Still, traders estimated that about 30 percent of the issue remains on the books of primary dealers.
 
Participation of Japanese
Japanese firms are believed to have accounted for 20 to 25 percent of yesterday's auction, after taking an estimated 35 percent of the $10 billion auctioned on Tuesday.
Anxiety about who would buy the new notes - and at what price - was high before the 1 P.M. start of the auction.
Part of the worry stemmed from a big rise in yields on 10-year West German bonds, which moved above 8 percent for the first time since 1984 after Bonn said it intended speed the unification with East Germany by moving rapidly to create a single German currency.
Worries that rising foreign interest rates would siphon money from the Treasury auctions have been prevalent for weeks. But those concerns abated somewhat yesterday.
More impressive than the total ofbids, some analysts said, was the size of the non-competitive bid. In such a bid, the bidder offers to take the issue at whatever price and interest rate the average bid produces.
Individual investors and smaller commercial banks placed $565 million worth of non-competitive bids for the issue, the highest total in more than four years.
''The non-competitive bid is a good barometer for domestic demand,'' said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities Company International. ''That sort of interest generally surfaces at the end of bear markets, not in the middle of one.''
 
Chances for Today's Sale
Mr. Brusca said the reappearance of domestic investors gives today's auction of $10 billion worth of 30-year bonds ''the chance of being a pretty good one.''
Moreover, he said, ''since Japanese interest was fairly light at the 10-year, and the yen is stable, we could see much better interest from the Japanese.''
But others were not so sanguine. With a big rise in the Producer Price Index for January expected to be announced on Friday, some dealers said they did not expect demand for the new bonds to be strong.
''Whatever the Japanese don't take, the Street will be forced to hold,'' one government-bond trader said.
Late yesterday the bonds were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.50 percent.
On Tuesday a widely held view on Wall Street was that Japanese participation at the 30-year auction would be limited unless the bonds were yielding around 8 5/8 percent. Based on yesterday's price movements, reaching that level now seems unlikely, analysts said.
 
Secondary Market Turns
The auction results prompted a quick turnaround in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 95 17/32, up 13/32, to yield 8.54 percent. Before the auction results were announced, prices of the closely watched bond were down by about 3/8 of a point.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 97 5/ 32, up 5/32, to yield 8.44 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 18/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.36 percent.
Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.79 percent late yesterday, up a basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.74 percent. But one-year bill rates fell by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.57 percent.
In other developments, the State of Maryland offered $130 million of general obligation bonds at a competitive sale in the tax-exempt municipal bond market yesterday.
A bid from a group led by Chase Securities Inc. won the issue, which consists of serial bonds from 1993 to 2005. Yields on the securities range from 5.90 percent in 1993 to 6.80 percent in 2005.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Meanwhile, prices of most actively traded secondary municipal bond issues rose by 1/8 to 1/4 of a point, dealers said.
For the second straight session, there was no new-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market. Corporate traders said that prices of most issues in the secondary market rose by about 3/8 of a point.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
U.S. Acquisitions Surge in Europe

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
FROM Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner who bought Adidas, to United Parcel Service, which purchased parcel delivery services in seven countries, Americans were buying in Europe last year and buying more than ever.
Because of the headlines accorded the purchases of parts of Tiffany & Company and Rockfeller Center by the Japanese and the less noticed holdings by the British and the Dutch, many Americans may think of America being gobbled up by foreign investors.
But with a surge of purchases in the last six months of 1989, American companies led the world in snapping up companies in Europe, according to data collected by Translink's European Deal Review. Acquisitions by Americans, where prices were reported, totaled $15.2 billion, or 27.6 percent of the $50 billion total. Prices were reported for only 40 percent of the 185 American deals reported. 
And the Japanese were far behind, placing sixth with $1.63 billion, or 3.3 percent of the total. Following the United States were France ($10.65 billion), West Germany ($7.32 billion), Britain ($6.1 billion) and Italy ($1.85 billion).
The surge in acquisitions worldwide was a record, according to Translink, and it shows that American companies are positioning themselves for the projected economic union of Europe in 1992.
''It's all a response to 1992,'' said Edward M. Graham, professor of economics at the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University. ''Companies already in Europe are changing their strategy from country to country to Pan-European. And others, who are not there, are deciding they want to get in.''
Mr. Graham, who is working on a paper on the subject, said the surge by American companies was not a surprise, But he said he was comforted by the data because they are the first to confirm the impressions he had gained from anecdotal evidence and other statistics.
The market in a unified Europe will be almost as large as that of the United States, and with the recent developments in Eastern Europe it could be even larger. With the promise of strong economic growth and the possibility of lowering costs, a unified Europe has finally become a venture that American companies cannot ignore.
A sign that the purchases are more the part of longer-term strategy than a sudden opportunity is that about a third of the deals came in the last three months as the dollar was falling sharply against most European currencies.
''American companies are realizing that Europe is an opportunity that is moving very fast and is an opportunity that cannot be missed,'' added Mark Dixon, the editor of Translink's European Deal Review. ''They are acting sensibly for the first time in four years.''
But American companies are also moving a little out of fear. There is a perception that once 1992 arrives barriers may go up that could make it more difficult to get a foothold.
In their acquisitions last year, American companies were mostly interested in automotive concerns and food and food retailing businesses. The other major purchases were in printing and advertsing, oil and gas, electronics and chemicals and plastics.
Most of the purchases were made at the expense of the British, who were the No. 1 target worldwide. Of the total of $50 billion in worldwide deals, $22.9 billion, or 46 percent, were in Britain. Of the $15.2 billion in American purchases, $11.12 billion, or 73 percent, were in Britain, almost three times the total in 1988. Among the largest were Ford Motor's purchase of Jaguar for $2.27 billion, and Pepsico's $1.34 billion acquisition of two competing snack makers, Smiths and Walkers, from BSN S.A. in France.
Not all the deals were successful, although they are counted in the figures. Wasserstein, Perella and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company failed in their hostile bid for Gateway, the British food stores. They ended up with 40 percent at a cost of $1.35 billion, Translink said.
The surge of acquisitions in the second half of the year was dramatic, with the number of deals rising to 117, from 68 in the first half, and the value surging to $11.22 billion from $3.98 billion.
But this is not all good news. Mr. Graham points out that the Japanese figure is probably low because the Japanese have made larger investments in building new plants in Europe. In addition, he noted that while these figures show that the jump of foreign purchases in the United States is clearly just part of a global trend, the increase in recent years has been much larger in the United States than elsewhere.
And he is also worried about new protectionist trends. American companies now well established in Europe, like General Motors and Ford, he said, are apparently ready to support efforts aimed at limiting the import of Japanese cars, both from Japan and Japanese subsidiaries in the United States.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
For Citibank Official, An End and a Beginning

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
For William R. Rhodes of Citibank, yesterday was an end and a beginning. At the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, he joined officials from Mexico to sign an agreement to lower Mexico's $48.5 billion in debt with the more than 460 banks involved, winding up almost a year of tough negotiations that he led as co-chairman of the commerical bank advisory committee.
At the same time, Citibank announced his promotion to senior executive, international, a new job that will take him out of the day-to-day business of debt negotiations. But he assumed an overall responsibility for the bank's debt negotations besides his new responsibilities. 
Mr. Rhodes, 54 years old, was involved in most of the primary negotiations since the third world debt crisis began in 1982. Mr. Rhodes has been the chairman or co-chairman of bank negotiating committees for Argentina, Peru, Uruguay and Mexico. Brazil, Mexico and Argentina are the three largest debtors in the developing world.
In his new job, Mr. Rhodes will have broader international responsibilities that he said he would use to concentrate some on Eastern Europe. He visited Poland in December. He will also deal with the international financial insitutions, like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and the Washington officials whose policies affect Citibank's international business. He will report directly to John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, Citibank's parent company.
Mr. Rhodes will be replaced by Robert A. McCormack, 46, who has been a vice president and on Citibank's debt negotiating team since 1987. He will be chairman of the restructuring committee at Citibank. He joined Citibank in 1973 and has since worked in Venezuela, Jamaica, Panama and Puerto Rico and Singapore. He will report to Mr. Rhodes.
Mr. Rhodes, who joined Citibank after graduating from Brown University in 1957 and served in the Caribbean and Latin America, has been waiting for this change in assignments for some time. But he sounded a little reluctant to give up the daily combat of the third world debt crisis.
''I'll still be spending a lot of time on debt,'' he said at the signing ceremony. ''I'll still be very involved.''

HEADLINE: Technology Issues Set Pace As Dow Climbs 33.78 Points

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Strength across the board in technology issues propelled the stock market to a solid gain yesterday on sharply higher volume.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed by 33.78 points, to 2,640.09. Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declining ones, 941 to 567.
Turnover on the Big Board, which had been exceptionally slow the first two days of the week, jumped to 186.7 million shares, from 134.1 million shares on Tuesday and 131 million shares on Monday. 
''We are seeing a shift in market leadership away from consumer stocks to industrial production stocks,'' said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., the chief technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ''This was demonstrated yesterday by the performance of the technology issues.''
 
I.B.M. Up to $103.125
In the technology group, I.B.M. rose 2 1/8, to 103 1/8; Digital added 1 7/8, to 79 1/8; Compaq Computer climbed 4 3/4, to 86 1/8, and Motorola moved up by 1 3/8, to 58 5/8.
Stocks were broadly lower in early trading on concern about the reception for yesterday's and today's portion of the quarterly refinancing by the Treasury. That concern lessened as the session progressed, and it became apparent that participation was greater than expected at the auction of the 10-year notes yesterday, but worries about the auction of the 30-year bond today still kept a lid on any attempts at a sustained advance.
The traders said that about noon, a feeling among some institutions that the market was no longer worried about the auction lifted the Dow to a seven-point gain. The advance was doubled about a half-hour later, when bargain-hunting and some buying relating to futures came into play.
''Traders are beginning to abandon their concern with external uncertainties, including this week's Government financing and the course of interest rates,'' Mr. Peroni said. 8.59% Average Rate The second stage of the quarterly Treasury auction, $10 billion in 10-year notes, was well received, the traders said. The yield on the average discount rate at the auction was 8.59 percent, compared with the last 10-year note sale in November, which had an average rate of 7.94 percent.
Mr. Peroni said the stock market appeared to be diverging considerably from the ''dismal psychology'' that pulled it lower last month. ''This is creating a gradual rejuvenation of confidence in equities,'' he said.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose by 4.09 points, to 333.75, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 1.98 points, to 184.31.
Among individual issues on the Big Board, Halliburton jumped by 3 points, to 45 3/8, after the oilfield services company reported earnings for the fourth quarter that had been better than expected. They were at 41 cents a share, up from 11 cents a share in the previous year's quarter.
 
Norton a Big Loser
The Norton Company, a maker of abrasives and other products in Worchester, Mass., was the fifth-largest dollar loser, plunging 4 3/8, or 8.4 percent, to 48. The company said its stock sank in response lower-than-expected earnings of 49 cents a share for the quarter, before extraordinary gains, versus 73 cents a share in the 1988 period.
Gold stocks were weak for the second straight day, as the spot price of the precious metal fell on the Commodity Exchange in New York. ASA declined by 2 3/4, to 68 5/8; Hecla Mining slipped by 1/4, to 15, and Sunshine Mining was unchanged at 3 5/8.
Actively traded blue-chip stocks included A.T.& T., which was up by 3/8, to 39 7/8; Philip Morris, which gained 3/4, to 39, and General Electric, which rose by 5/8, to 62 5/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose by 1.61 points, to 356.35, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index gained 2.80 points, to 426.79.
Apple Computer dropped 1 1/2, to 33 1/4, in over-the-counter trading. A spokeswoman for the company, based in Cupertino, Calif., said that the sale of thousands of its MacIntosh computers to the Air Force, as a subcontrator for Honeywell Inc., was in jeopardy because bidding for the contract has been reopened.

HEADLINE: Some Influential Voices Urge Simpler Tax Code

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's top tax officials and the most influential Congressman on tax policy agreed today that aspects of the tax law are too complicated and need to be simplified.
Kenneth W. Gideon, Assistant Treasury Secretary for tax policy; Fred T. Goldberg Jr., the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, did not advocate specific changes in the tax code and they insisted that whatever changes were made should not violate the principles of the extensive overhaul of tax law enacted four years ago.
But Mr. Rostenkowski and the Administration officials acknowledged for the first time that they saw merit in the widespread complaints from interest groups and individual taxpayers that some elements of the 1986 law are unreasonably complex.
 
'A Troubling Legacy'
''The legislative frenzy of the past 10 years has left a troubling legacy of complexity, uncertainty and administrative burden on business and individual taxpayers and the I.R.S. itself,'' Mr. Goldberg said. 
Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, said his committee would undertake ''a formal, structured simplification study'' this year.
The Tax Reform Act of 1986 was the most comprehensive revision of the tax code since World War II. It lowered tax rates dramatically and ended scores of deductions, exemptions and other tax breaks.
With the changes, millions of low-income Americans were removed from the tax rolls and millions more became eligible to file a short form rather than the longer one with itemized deductions. In addition, most taxpayers must keep many fewer records than under the old system.
On the other hand, many businesses and some individuals, most of them wealthy, found themselves burdened by regulations neither they nor their accountants could fathom.
For example, there are hundreds of pages on measures intended to end tax shelters by disallowing deductions for ''passive losses,'' or losses from paper transactions.
James P. Holden, chairman of the tax section of the American Bar Association, told the committee of other ''areas of unnecessary complexity,'' including rules on dependency exemptions, personal interest deductions, pensions and fringe benefits, and foreign tax credits.
 
Under Pressure
The Ways and Means Committee members have faced heavy lobbying for changes in these areas, and lawmakers from both parties agreed today that some parts of the law were overly complicated.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the top Republican on the panel, said that last year was the first time that he was unable to prepare his own tax returns and had to seek outside help.
Representative Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat who is a strong supporter of the 1986 law, said, ''The system is so Byzantine that you can't get straight answers from two experts in the same room.''
But Mr. Rostenkowski warned his colleagues ''not to confuse simplification with efforts to substantively reopen tax reform.''
''My invitation for simplification proposals is not an invitation for the restoration of special benefits that were repealed after two grueling years of tax reform,'' he added.
 
Capital Gains Are Issue
The Administration officials agreed basically with that assessment, but they said they would continue to press for a lower capital gains tax rate.
Many Democrats believe a cut in the capital gains rate would undermine one of the basic principles of the 1986 changes, which was to tax all income at the same rate. ''If we move toward capital gains, we're going to resurrect the tax shelter industry,'' Representative Dorgan said. But Mr. Gideon said: ''Our system must adjust to take into account the changing nature of global competition. In order to remain competitive, incentives for savings and investment must be improved. While we must preserve the achievements of the 1986 act, it should not prevent us from adjusting the code to changing economic conditions.''

(The New York Times/Paul Hosefros)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Traders Focus on Marks; Gold Prices Drop in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher against major currencies in domestic trading as the West German mark continued to hold center stage.
Gold prices declined in the United States after moving mostly higher abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $418.10 an ounce, $3.20 lower than Tuesday's close. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $418.10 as of 4 P.M., down $2.60 from Tuesday's late bid. 
The dollar has been playing a supporting role to the mark lately because reforms in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are expected to benefit the West German economy, said Keith Raphael, second vice president of foreign exchange at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Meanwhile, negative sentiment toward the dollar has prevailed amid speculation that a softening United States economy will be accompanied by declines in interest rates. Lower rates would reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments, tending to curb demand for dollars.
But the dollar managed to gain against its foreign counterparts in what dealers described as a technical rebound. Overseas, the dollar turned in a mixed performance.
 
Moscow News Factored In
Dealers said developments in Moscow, with Soviet Communist Party leaders agreeing to give up their monopoly on power as proposed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had already been factored into foreign exchange markets.
A lack of market-moving news yesterday made dealers reluctant to trade heavily and kept the dollar within a narrow range.
In New York, the dollar ended at 145.60 yen, up from 145.245 yen on Tuesday. It ended the day at 1.6580 West German marks, up from 1.65605 marks on Tuesday and from the 1.6545 closing level yesterday in Europe. The pound gained, ending at $1.6960, compared with $1.7030 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late quotes, included: 1.4890 Swiss francs, up from 1.4763; 5.642 French francs, up from 5.64; 1,236.50 Italian lire, up from 1,233.50, and 1.19455 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18755.
Gold prices were mixed, while silver rose.
In London, gold rose to a late bid of $423 a troy ounce, from $420.85 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $422.25, from $420.75 bid late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.72 to close at a bid of $417.75 an ounce.
On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery ended at $5.311 a troy ounce, up from Tuesday's $5.306. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $5.38 an ounce, from $5.31 bid late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Notebook;
Balanced Race in Patrick Division

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
As the National Hockey League season finishes its third quarter and approaches the home stretch, its most closely contested pennant race is in the Patrick Division, where the most interesting club in that six-team group is the first-place Islanders.
By getting 50 of a possible 60 points in their last 30 games, the Islanders have moved from last place to first and have opened a 3-point lead over the Rangers and a 5-point lead over the Devils. Last-place Pittsburgh is only 9 points out of first. No division is nearly as balanced, but this is the biggest lead of the season for the Islanders, who have won three games in a row. 
If the season were to end today, Pat LaFontaine of the Islanders would be a top candidate for the Hart trophy as the most valuable player in the league. His coach, Al Arbour, would merit strong consideration as the coach of the year. Last season, the Islanders finished 20th in a 21-team league. Last autumn, most experts picked them to finish last in their division. They currently rank eighth in the league with 59 points.
LaFontaine, who scored three goals in Tuesday night's 8-7 overtime victory at Pittsburgh, has 47 goals to equal his career best. He remains 3 goals behind Brett Hull of St. Louis, who leads the league with 50.
During the Islanders' early-season slump, LaFontaine could be heard after games, in the locker room, assuring reporters and teammates that prosperity was just around the corner. In recent games, he can be seen speaking forcefully to groups of players before face-offs, instructing them on technique and strategy.
''It was his time to step up,'' Arbour said, ''and he has assumed the leadership role.''
The 57-year-old Arbour is the oldest coach in the league. Although Arbour shows flashes of his temper from time to time, he builds the psychological stability of a young team with a consistent personality.
''He is worth about a goal a game to that club,'' said a veteran N.H.L. official, who watched a recent game from the press box. ''He doesn't say much, but he always gets the message across.''
Certainly there are other candidates for the top awards. Among the very valuable players are Mark Messier of Edmonton, Hull of St. Louis, Ray Bourque of Boston, Mario Lemieux of Pittsburgh and Wayne Gretzky of Los Angeles.
Among the contending coaches are Doug Carpenter of Toronto, John Muckler of Edmonton, Mike Milbury of Boston, Rick Dudley of Buffalo, Bob Murdoch of Winnipeg and Mike Keenan of Chicago.
 
Plans for a New League
Dennis Murphy, the founder of the World Hockey Association of the 1970's, said yesterday that 50 people would attend meetings in Los Angeles tomorrow and Saturday to plan the launching of the Global Hockey League.
The league, with a North American division and a European Division, will begin play in November, Murphy said, with each team making two four-game road trips to the other continent.
Groups from Tampa, Fla.; Cleveland; Atlanta; San Diego; Phoenix; Albany, and Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, will be among the North Americans at the meeting, Murphy said. Among European sites Murphy has targeted are London, Stockholm and Dusseldorf, West Germany.
The league will eliminate the center red line (and the two-line offside pass over it), Murphy said, and will award penalty shots to teams victimized by high-sticking. Team owners must put up $2 million each, he said, to cover franchise fees and bonding.
Murphy said the changing political and economic climate in Europe would make the 1990's ''the best time in the world'' for North American-style sports business.
''But people have to understand that we're not all just a bunch of money-grabbers,'' Murphy said.
 
Difference of Opinion
Bob Goodenow, the lawyer selected to replace Alan Eagleson as executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, admits he represented management in 1982 and 1983 when it successfully battled union organizers at a company called Fire Fighter Sales & Service Company in Pittsburgh.
''I think I represented my client to the best of my abilities,'' Goodenow said. ''To me, this is old news.''
Frank Caputo, a retired business agent for Teamsters Local 249 in Pittsburgh, said in a letter to The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette on Monday that Goodenow is ''an opportunistic chameleon.''
''A group of 10 overworked and underpaid young men were trying to get off the bottom rung of the ladder,'' Caputo wrote, ''and Goodenow made the moral judgment that it was all right to accept pay and keep them on the bottom rung and knock them to the ground.''
Gerald Diduck, the Islanders defenseman who was a member of the players association's search committee, said Goodenow's experience would help the union.
''He knows what tactics management uses when planning a strike or a difficult negotiation,'' Diduck said. ''It's an asset.''

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Costs Can Go Downhill If Skiers Are Flexible

BYLINE: By Janet Nelson

 BODY:
rrAt the start of each ski season, skiers are greeted with the news that lift-ticket prices have gone up. Usually the amount of the increases is only a dollar or two, but over the years this has brought some single-day weekend tickets to $35 and $37 at Eastern ski areas.
At the same time that single-day weekend tickets have been going up, there has been a proliferation of discounts and special rates that substantially reduce the cost of a day's skiing.
''In recent years, we've seen more and more ski areas experimenting with different kinds of pricing structures for lift tickets,'' said Tom Meyers, marketing director for the Vermont Ski Areas Association. ''The basic one, of course, is the weekend/ midweek differential where midweek prices are usually 25 to 40 percent below the weekend prices. But recently, there are also more bargains for different times of the year, such as peak and holiday versus the regular-season rates, and early and late season discounts.'' 
Meyers sees this trend in ticket-price variations continuing and expanding to include parts of the day, hourly rates and even individual ride fees. These kinds of changes are becoming possible as new ticketing technology, using computers, bar codes and counting systems, is adopted by ski areas.
For now, though, skiers must study deals and packages to find the most economical way to go skiing. rrThere are a number of areas in the East that offer daily skiing for $20 or less on weekdays during nonholiday periods. One of the best bargains is found at Magic Mountain, Vt., with a $15 daily price, while two other Vermont resorts, Bromley and Haystack, have $20 tickets and Suicide Six has an $18.50 midweek ticket. Saddleback, Me., offers skiing for $18 on weekdays, and Big Squaw and Mount Abram have $15 tickets. In New Hampshire, Mount Sunapee and Dartmouth Skiway both have $20 midweek tickets. Cranmore has a $19 ticket. Ragged Mountain has a $17 ticket, King Ridge and Pat's Peak have $16 tickets and King Pine has a $15 ticket.
In the Catskills of New York, skiers can buy a Sampler Card (914-586-4655) for $10 that permits two skiers to ski for the price of one at nine areas - Holiday, Cortina, Bellearye, Ski Windham, Highmount, Deer Run, Big Vanilla, Hunter and Bobcat -making daily prices for two less than $20 each. At Hunter Mountain, the Sampler Card is good only on the beginners' mountain.
In New Hampshire, several ski areas also offer two-for-one deals. On Tuesdays, Mount Sunapee and Cannon offer twofers. Cannon's midweek ticket is $21. Bretton Wood has twofers on Wednesdays and Gunstock has them on Tuesdays and Wednesdays. The midweek ticket at those areas is $22.
Multiple-day lift tickets, available for two to seven days, are another means for skiers to realize substantial savings. While these discounts have traditionally been offered only for midweek periods, some areas are now venturing into discounts for two weekend days and long weekends.
Stratton, Vt., for instance, has a two-day adult weekend ticket for $60, which is $12 less than two separately purchased daily tickets. Magic and Bromley, Vt., have a $50 two-day weekend ticket that must be used at both areas on consecutive days. At Attitash, a two-day weekend ticket is $58, and a third day brings the price to $82. rrInterchangeable passes that offer skiing at several ski areas in a region or in a state not only give savings over normal lift-ticket prices (particularly for the highest-price ski areas in the packages), but also greater variety for every day of a vacation. This year, there are more of these multi-area, reciprocal passes than ever before.
Ski the White Mountains One Pass (603-745-8720) is good for midweek, nonholiday periods for five consecutive days at 10 ski areas. The price is $115 and when a parent purchases a One Pass, one child under 13 years of age skis free. Ski areas where the One Pass can be used are Attitash, Balsams/Wilderness, Black, Bretton Woods, Cannon, Cranmore, Loon, Tenney, Waterville Valley and Wildcat.
First Mountains of New Hampshire offers a seasonlong interchangeable pass good at King Ridge, Pat's Peak, Temple and Crotched, plus several ski touring centers. For $195, skiers get unlimited skiing at those areas and up to 20 lift tickets at Mount Sunapee.
The Ski 93 Midweek Mountain Pass (603-356-3171) lets skiers choose different New Hampshire areas for three out of four days or four out of five days or allows them to ski at one area for an entire midweek stay. The prices are $80 for adults and $60 for juniors for four days and $100 and $75 for five days. The ski areas in the program are Bretton Woods, Cannon, Loon, Tenney and Waterville Valley.
The Valley Pass for Mount Washington Valley (603-356-3171) is interchangeable for three midweek days at Attitash, Black, Cranmore and Wildcat. The price is $66 for adults and $33 for juniors.
In Vermont, Ski Vermont's Classics offers interchangeable tickets any day of the week, although holiday surcharges may apply at some resorts. The three-day ticket is $99 and the five-day ticket is $151 and they are good at Jay Peak, Sugarbush, Stowe, Smugglers' Notch and Bolton Valley.
