HEADLINE: Chill of Labor Impasse Threatens Baseball's Spring

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The wintertime hopes of baseball players and fans could be shattered today. The owners of baseball's 26 clubs will meet in Chicago and are expected to carry out their threat to postpone the opening of spring training.
Negotiators for the owners and the players' union have been unable to produce a new collective-bargaining agreement to replace the one that expired Dec. 31. The Player Relations Committee, the owners' labor arm, has said for the last month that if the two sides had no agreement of any sort by today's meeting training camps would not open as scheduled on Feb. 16.
On Wednesday, after the last bargaining session, Charles P. O'Connor, the owners' chief negotiator, referred to a memorandum sent to the clubs on Jan. 9, which said, ''Spring training camps may not be opened until the P.R.C. instructs you to do so.'' He then said that nothing had happened to prompt the owners to change their stance. 
Begun late in the 19th century as a warm-weather boot camp for out-of-shape players, spring training has in recent years become a growing industry that draws thousands of tourists and fills ball parks regularly. In Florida, home to 18 teams, it generates $330 million for the state economy. For fans, it is an early start on summer and a time when every team can be a champion.
The owners have shut down spring training twice before. They kept camps closed in 1973 until Feb. 26, the day after they agreed with the players on a new labor contract. In 1976, the camps remained shut until Bowie K. Kuhn, then the commissioner, ordered them opened March 17. In both cases, the season started on time.
The players have struck four times, twice late in spring training - in 1972 and 1980 - and twice during the regular season, for 50 days in 1981 and for two days in 1985. The 1972 strike delayed the start of the season by 10 days.
The current dispute stems from the owners' desire to implement a new salary system based on a revenue-sharing plan. The owners propose to give the players for salaries and benefits 48 percent of the income derived from ticket sales and radio and television rights. Income from those sources accounts for 82 percent of the owners' total revenue.
The money would be allocated for salaries in two basic ways.
Players who have been in the major leagues between one year and six years would be paid primarily on the basis of a statistically created scale tied to performance. Players with six years of service or more would be free agents, but their ability to sign with new teams would depend on the teams' payrolls. If a team were over a certain payroll level, it would not be able to sign free agents from other teams.
Under the old agreement, a player with less than three years' service negotiates the best deal he can with the club that holds his contract. A player with three to six years' service can submit his salary request to an arbitrator if he fails to reach agreement with his club. A player with six years' service is free to sign with the highest bidder.
 
Players' View of Proposal
The owners' negotiators have been unable to sell the players on any part of the new proposal. Scott Sanderson, a pitcher with the Oakland Athletics and a member of the players' negotiating team, explained the players' views in a telephone interview yesterday.
''The game, even by their admission at the bargaining table, has never been healthier than it is now,'' he said from Chicago. ''At such a time, to get the players to believe there is a need for a drastic change in the structure of baseball is going to be tough to do.
''Second, to propose that at a time when their recent track record has been one of collusion adds skepticism on our part. Third, to not have all the factual information that could support their proposal lends to the skepticism.''
Paul Molitor of the Milwaukee Brewers, the American League player representative, said the owners' collusion against free agents had prompted the players ''to look at this to see what their underlying motive might be.''
''You have to rebuild that trust before you ask us to make a major change,'' he said. ''They talk about partnership, but when they thought of this plan, their idea wasn't partnership; their idea was to do what was best for them. If a partnership came along the way, fine.''
The players mistrust the owners primarily because of their treatment of free agents after the 1985, 1986 and 1987 seasons. Two arbitrators found the owners had colluded in the first two instances; a decision is pending in the third.
Beyond that, the players are skeptical of the owners' motives because of past negotiations. In 1981, the owners' demand for a professional player as compensation for the loss of a free agent prompted the players' strike. Yet, four years later, in the next negotiation, the owners dropped the professional-compensation provision they had gained.
The owners' negotiators entered these talks with the stated intention of improving labor relations. Donald M. Fehr, the players' labor leader, has noted that the owners endorsed the Player Relations Committee's bargaining strategy last July 18, and that strategy included a lockout if no agreement was reached by the start of spring training.
''So I assume,'' Mr. Fehr said earlier this week, ''that what is about to happen is we're going to have a lockout to make labor relations better. It's an interesting theory. We'll see if it works.''
The lockout is the owners' way of being in control of the timing of a work stoppage. Mr. O'Connor, the Washington-based lawyer who is the Player Relations Committee's general counsel, has explained that the owners didn't want to get into the season and have the players strike, as they did in 1981 (on June 12) and 1985 (on Aug. 6).
An in-season strike would cost the owners television money, especially if it forced the cancellation of the All-Star Game in July or the post-season playoffs and World Series in October. The clubs begin a new four-year $1.06 billion television package this year.
 
Looking for 'Certainty'
The owners say they want the revenue-sharing plan because it would provide them with what Mr. O'Connor calls cost certainty. When negotiations in other industries end in agreement, Mr. O'Connor said, both sides know what the cost will be. Not so in baseball.
He has referred to the escalating player salaries that have reached record heights. Before this winter, no player had a contract that averaged $3 million a year. This winter, nine players signed such contracts.
In the pay-for-performance plan for players who have between one and six years' service in the major leagues, the 26 clubs would equally share all of the salaries. Those salaries would be determined by ranking the players in four groups and paying them based on time in the majors and statistics from the previous two seasons.
The owners' negotiators say that under the plan young players would receive higher salaries than they receive now in their second and third years in the majors. The players object to the plan because it would eliminate salary arbitration, multiyear contracts and guaranteed contracts for these players.
The players object to the payroll-level plan for free agents because it could restrict the mobility and thus the bargaining power of some free agents.
 
Players' Proposals
The focus on the revenue-sharing proposal has overshadowed the players' proposals.
Among other things, the players want to return the eligibility level for salary arbitration to two years from the three years that became the standard in the last agreement; they want the minimum salary raised from $68,000 to a figure between $100,000 and $125,000; they want rosters restored to a mandatory 25-man limit from the 24 the clubs have used the last few years, and they want collusion protection built into the agreement.
The owners' negotiators have said they would discuss the players' proposals only in the context of their revenue-sharing proposal.
The players say one reason they have difficulty with the owners' proposal is the owners' inability or unwillingness to answer what the players see as basic questions:
Will salaries under the plan be higher than at present, lower or the same? If the owners foresee problems with disparity between small- and large-market teams, when will those problems occur? How much money would it take to eliminate any economic disparity between those two groups?
The players also asked if the owners had studied the possibility of allocating joint revenues, like the national television money, in unequal proportions so smaller-market clubs would get more. The owners' negotiators said they had not.
Discussing the plan's potential effect on salaries, Mr. Fehr said: ''It's nearly impossible for us to believe it would produce more money. If it would and they wanted it, they would be trumpeting that all over the place.''
The proposal, he added, is ''very complex with tremendous implications.''
''It takes a lot of study and analysis that we now know their own economics experts were not fully conversant with,'' he said.
Because of what he said was the complexity of the issues and lack of answers, Mr. Fehr questioned the wisdom of a lockout.
But Mr. O'Connor said, ''I share the clubs' view that the deadline now from the standpoint of preserving this season, from the standpoint of keeping it an equal-level playing field between themselves and the union, is a wise judgment.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Accuses 2 Nynex Companies Of Overcharging and Fines Them

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The Government ordered the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday to pay a total of $1.4 million in fines for what it called an illegal scheme that inflated profits at the expense of customers.
The Federal Communications Commission said customers had been overcharged about $35 million between 1984 and 1988 by the two companies, which are owned by the Nynex Corporation.
The penalty is the largest ever imposed on a regulated telephone company and is the first involving accusations of a major abuse by one of the seven regional telephone holding companies.
Nynex was also ordered to return the $35 million. The commission said the money would not go directly to consumers but would be used to lower the fees that New York Telephone and New England Telephone charge long-distance companies. That would indirectly produce a very small drop in long-distance prices, the commission said. 
The commission said the two phone companies had bought equipment, services and supplies from another Nynex subsidiary at prices inflated by $118.5 million. About $35 million of the cost was passed on to customers through higher rates, it said.
 
Violated the Rules
The commission said such a transaction violated rules requiring that when a regulated telephone company buys from an affiliated company, the telephone company passes on to customers no more than the cost that would have resulted had the transaction been done with an outside company.
The rules were created to protect consumers and competing telephone concerns from anti-competitive practices by the seven regional telephone holding companies created in the breakup of the Bell System telephone monopoly six years ago. Nynex is one of the seven companies.
Ken Moran, chief of the accounting and audit division at the Federal Communications Commission, said the Government thought that the excess charges were intentional and that ''Nynex understood the rules and knew precisely what it was doing.''
But William C. Ferguson, Nynex's chairman, said the company did not intend to overcharge customers. He said the rules to which the commission referred do not apply to this case.
''My first and overriding concern is the good faith of each of our customers,'' he said in a statement. ''I want them to understand clearly that there has been no intention of overcharging.''
The commission imposed the maximum fine possible against the two telephone companies: $709,500 each, or $500 a day for each day of abuse that occurred within the last five years. The period before that falls outside the five-year statute of limitations. Congress recently increased such fines to $6,000 for each day of violation, the commission said.
The F.C.C. has no authority over local telephone bills, and yesterday's action will not affect such bills, the commission said. The commission said it would require New York Telephone and New England Telephone to lower by a total of $35 million the ''access fees'' they charge long-distance carriers like the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, MCI Communications and U S Sprint Communications. A.T.&T. is required to pass such savings on to consumers in the form of lower long-distance rates. In the past, MCI and Sprint have lowered their rates to remain competitive with A.T.&T.
 
Possibility of Appeal
Nynex has 30 days to appeal the commission's decision.Robert O'Brien, a Nynex spokesman, said the company planned to study the ruling and respond. Mr. O'Brien said the company thought it had fully complied with F.C.C. rules.
Mr. O'Brien said it was unclear whether the purchasing rules applied to Nynex's supplier. The rules were written in 1977 for transactions between Western Electric and the other companies in the Bell System that it supplied. It was not until 1987 that the F.C.C. wrote a rule applying the 1977 policy specifically to purchases from Nynex's supplier, the Nynex Material Enterprises Company, and similar operations of other regional Bell companies.
The commission said its findings were based on an audit of transactions between Nynex Material and both New York Telephone and New England Telephone.
Nynex Material, which has its main offices at 441 Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, was created in 1984 to centralize Nynex's purchasing requirements. It buys everything from paper clips and note pads to fiber-optic cable and computer switching equipment for Nynex's 12 operating companies. The division manages about $2 billion worth of contracts a year with about 6,200 vendors.
 
Seeking Looser Regulation
Yesterday's decision certainly will not help Nynex and the other regional Bell telephone companies in their attempt to persuade the Federal judge overseeing their operations to loosen restrictions and allow them to enter other businesses.
For Nynex, the ruling is yet another difficulty as it tries to recover from a six-month-long strike and win a major rate increase from the New York Public Service Commission. Nynex took an unexpected $325 million charge against earnings in the fourth quarter of 1989, giving it a $43.7 million net loss for the quarter.
The company has had difficulty controlling its costs, and its revenues have been hurt by a weak economy in the Northeast and heavy competition from fiber-optic telecommunications concerns that are attracting large business customers by offering private telephone networks.

HEADLINE: Brazil Aspires to Big League in More Than Soccer

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Touring the United States, Japan, Western Europe and the Soviet Union, Brazil's President-elect has carried to world leaders a determined message: Brazil wants to join the ranks of the first world in the 1990's.
''We want to stop being the leading country of the third world to join the group of the first world,'' the President-elect, Fernando Collor de Mello, said in Italy on Monday. On March 15, Mr. Collor is to be inaugurated as President of Brazil, which has the world's eighth largest market economy.
Wearing hand-tailored business suits, speaking four European languages and advocating fewer Government barriers and more foreign investment, Mr. Collor has made it clear that he intends to draw Latin America's largest nation into closer economic integration with the developed world. 
Celebrating this turn, Roberto Campos, an acerbic free-market Senator, wrote in a newspaper column here on Sunday, ''The time has arrived for us to make the choice for wealth - preferring to be the last member of the Jockey Club instead of the first member of the dance hall.''
 
Investors Turn Elsewhere
In the 1980's, Brazil lost appeal to foreign investors as the economy stagnated under weak political leadership, racing inflation, spreading Government controls and the third world's largest foreign debt. In the 1980's, the Pacific basin replaced Brazil as a magnet for foreign credit and investment. Today, many Brazilians fear that the new magnet is Eastern Europe.
Determined to promote ''the New Brazil,'' Mr. Collor embarked on Jan. 24 on a nine-nation, 20-day tour. By the time the trip ends on Tuesday, Mr. Collor hopes that his standing will be bolstered with two key audiences: Brazil's polarized electorate and Brazil's skeptical foreign investors and creditors.
For the domestic audience, Mr. Collor, a former newspaper executive, has pushed Brazil into the age of the photo opportunity.
In Tokyo, the President-elect, a former karate champion, donned his black belt and white togs and practiced exercises with Japanese karate instructors.
In Turin, cameras rolled again as the athletic Mr. Collor deftly bounced and dribbled a soccer ball on the field where Brazil's national team is to make its debut in the World Cup in June.
 
An Invitation From Bush
In addition, rubbing shoulders with the world's most powerful leaders undoubtedly has lent a statesmanlike image to Mr. Collor, who at 40 will be Brazil's youngest President.
While the world press largely ignored the trip, Brazil's television and magazine journalists breathlessly chronicled how President Bush invited Mr. Collor and his wife, Rosane, to the White House for an impromptu buffet dinner, and how President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union left his dacha for an 80-minute meeting with the President-elect.
Although no opinion polls have charted the effect at home, several Brazilians said in interviews that Mr. Collor's foreign tour is winning him support.
''I know two psychiatrists who voted Lula who are now telling me that Collor's trip is making them think again,'' a Rio hostess said at a dinner party on Tuesday night.
In December, in a polarized election campaign, Mr. Collor defeated Luis Inacio da Silva, a socialist widely known as Lula, by 53 percent to 47 percent of the vote. After the election, many of Mr. Collor's opponents were further antagonized when he rented a private jet and embarked on a 13-day vacation in Africa and Europe that was estimated to cost $350,000.
 
Rounding Up Supporters
But the current business trip, conducted on commercial airliners, seems to be helping the President-elect, whose party, the National Reconstruction Party, controls only 35 seats in the 560-member Congress.
Before leaving for New York, his first stop, Mr. Collor charged his designated Justice Minister, Bernardo Cabral, with the task of rounding up congressional support. Encouraged by a series of negotiations, Mr. Cabral has predicted that he will have stitched together a working majority alliance by the time Congress reconvenes on Feb. 15, two days after Mr. Collor's return here.
On the external front, Mr. Collor's lack of coverage in the general press has been compensated for by his blanket exposure to a highly specific, and highly influential, audience: Brazil's overseas investors and creditors. By the end of the tour, Mr. Collor will have met with the heads of state of the United States, Japan, the Soviet Union, West Germany, Italy, France, Britain, Portugal and Spain. In each country, hundreds of business leaders have heard him speak.
By next Tuesday, the business men and women responsible for decisions on at least 90 percent of Brazil's foreign investment and credit will have had a chance to size up Brazil's future President personally.
So far, the reviews have been largely favorable.
''It's encouraging to see a leader so young and so sure that the way out for Brazil is by adopting a market economy,'' Carla A. Hills, the United States special trade representative, said after having breakfast with Mr. Collor in Washington.
Summing up Mr. Collor's meetings with United States officials in Washington, Richard H. Melton, the American Ambassador here. said on Tuesday, ''We view his goals and policy objectives as being largely compatible with our own - reorienting Brazil toward the 'first world,' gradually opening Brazilian markets to foreign trade and investment and encouraging market-oriented solutions to Brazil's economic problems.''
 
More Free-Market Talk
Indeed, Mr. Collor has been preaching overseas a slightly sharper version of the free-market dogma that helped him win the presidency at home. Describing Brazilian-made cars as ''clunkers,'' he said in Bonn that the West German and the Japanese were welcome to open car factories in Brazil.
Describing Brazil's controls on computer imports and investment as xenophobia, Mr. Collor told Japanese businessmen that Brazil would open its computer market to foreign investment.
''Brazil cannot run the risk that the 1990's be another lost decade,'' he said in Tokyo.
A Collor supporter who represents an American bank here said of the President-elect: ''I hope he can bridge the gap between words and actions. Don't forget that only six months ago another Latin superstar was playing tennis with Bush.''
This ''superstar,'' President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina, has recently come under a cloud as his attempt at a free-market economic program unraveled into double-digit monthly inflation.

He joked with Prime Minister Michel Rocard of France after their meeting on Wednesday in Paris. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: End to Bush Observer Team's Role In Nicaraguan Vote Raises Debate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
A decision to disband an official American delegation that was to observe the Nicaraguan elections has intensified a political battle shaping up over the fairness of the campaign.
Senator Richard G. Lugar, co-chairman of President Bush's election-monitoring commission, announced on Wednesday that the bipartisan group, made up of 20 members of Congress, was disbanding because the Nicaraguan Government had denied visas to some of its members.
Nevertheless, the Feb. 25 elections will be closely monitored by hundreds of observers from Latin America, Europe, the United States and the United Nations. Among the groups applauding the preparations for the vote are missions led by former President Jimmy Carter and Elliot L. Richardson, who heads the United Nations group. 
President Daniel Ortega Saavedra is running for re-election against several candidates. Chief among them is Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, publisher of the main opposition daily La Prensa, who leads a coalition of opposition parties. The coalition, the National Opposition Union, includes parties ranging from right-wing conservatives to socialists and Communists.
 
Many U.S. Observers Anyway
The exclusion of Mr. Lugar's group will make it difficult but not impossible for Congress to accept the legitimacy of the vote. Along with the United Nations, the Organization of American States and the European Parliament are sending observers. Mr. Carter is leading a team that includes members of Congress from both parties.
If those groups conclude that the election is fair, Congress might accept the verdict. But the Bush Administration has already issued many statements declaring the elections biased, possibly to lay the groundwork for dismissing the results if Mr. Ortega wins.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, asserted that the exclusion of Mr. Bush's observer team, combined with accusations of Sandinista violence against opposition members and Sandinista efforts to delay the distribution of American aid to the opposition, raised doubts about the Sandinistas' commitment to free elections.
Managua told American officials months ago that it would not admit an official American observer team as long as Washington continued to finance the Nicaraguan guerrillas and enforce economic sanctions.
 
The Sandinista View
Paul S. Reichler, the Washington lawyer who has represented the Nicaraguan Government for more than a decade, said today that the Sandinistas would welcome members of Congress, including Mr. Lugar, as members of other observer delegations.
But he said, ''An official U.S. Government delegation is out of the question because the U.S. continues to finance the contras, who continue to make war in Nicaragua and have threatened to disrupt the electoral process.'' Mr. Reichler said there would be 1,000 foreign observers and 1,500 foreign journalists in Nicaragua for the elections.
The various observer delegations will not necessarily agree on the fairness of the elections, and some may be more critical than others, especially if the results are close. Allen Weinstein, president of the Center for Democracy, which has been monitoring the Nicaraguan campaign since March, said the missions organized by the United Nations, the O.A.S. and Mr. Carter ''accentuated the positive, while addressing the Sandinista Government directly on problems they observed.''
Mr. Weinstein, who observed elections in the Philippines in 1986 and in Panama last year, said Nicaragua had ''a mixed record'' in the campaign so far. ''Problems such as the intimidation of poll watchers have to be completely and fastidiously addressed in the weeks remaining before election day,'' he said.
 
Bipartisan Monitors
Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, Democrat of California, who was co-chairman of Mr. Bush's observer delegation, said, ''It looks from a distance as if the election in Nicaragua is likely to be a fairly free and open contest, perhaps because the Sandinistas believe they will win.''
''It would have been in the Sandinistas' own interest if our group could have visited Nicaragua and come back to the United States and vouched for the fairness of the elections,'' Mr. Beilenson said in an interview. ''I'm sorry they didn't let us in.''
Mr. Carter's observer team included these four members of Congress: Senators John C. Danforth of Missouri and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Representatives Doug Bereuter of Nebraska and Bill Richardson of New Mexico. Mr. Danforth and Mr. Bereuter are Republicans; Mr. Dodd and Mr. Richardson are Democrats.
Mr. Bush's delegation, appointed in November, included conservative Republicans like Senator John McCain of Arizona and Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, as well as liberal Democrats like Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan and Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Diplomacy;
Baker Meets in Moscow On Arms and Afghans

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d opened talks today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, by setting out a variety of arms control initiatives, as well as a new American proposal for solving the Afghan conflict.
Soviet and American working groups continued to meet late into the night, as the two sides tried to digest the latest American and Soviet technical suggestions for the negotiations on limiting conventional arms, long-range nuclear missiles and chemical weapons.
Negotiators are hoping to hammer out compromises on several key problems holding up the separate negotiations and then have those compromises completed tomorrow when Mr. Baker goes to the Kremlin to meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Both Soviet and American officials said the most pressing issues - how the Soviets intend to handle the rapidly moving process of German unification and how they will respond to President Bush's recent proposal that both nations slash their troop levels in Europe to 195,000 men - will also await the Baker-Gorbachev session. 
 
Offer on Najibullah
On Afghanistan, the Secretary of State laid out for the Soviets the Bush Administration's new position, officials said. He told them that Washington was prepared to drop its long-held demand that the Soviet-installed President, Najibullah, be removed before any negotiated settlement is possible.
Mr. Baker, aides said, still insisted that Mr. Najibullah must go, but said his removal could be part of gradual, phased transition process.
Asked for the Soviet reaction to the proposal, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said: ''The American side showed us its plan, but it did not take into account the situation in Kabul, the difficulties of the Najibullah Government. But as a whole there was agreement on both sides that it is necessary to look for new approaches. It can be said that the realistic approach is a dialogue of national reconciliation, with the participation of all Afghan sides in the dialogue.''
 
Report on Refugee Quota
On another issue, Mr. Gerasimov said the United States had told Moscow that it would accept up to 20,000 more Soviet emigrants a year as refugees.
''The U.S. side informed us that they are raising their quota this year to approximately 60,000 or 70,000,'' Mr. Gerasimov said. The United States now accepts 50,000 Soviet refugees a year.
But American officials in Washington said today that the Administration had not proposed an increase in the ceiling for the current fiscal year. Administration officials said 10,000 to 20,000 Soviet citizens could conceivably be admitted to the United States outside the refugee program.
While American officials insisted that today's talks were not affected in any way by the preoccupation of senior Soviet officials with the outcome of their latest Communist Party meeting, in which party leaders agreed to relinquish their monopoly on power, there was a palpable difference in atmosphere between the opening of this Baker-Shevardnadze meeting and the last one, held in Moscow in May.
When Mr. Baker met with Mr. Shevardnadze in May, there was a sense that their talks could have a major impact on the course of international events. At today's opening, which took place against the backdrop of the Soviet party meeting and the collapse of Communist power in much of Eastern Europe, the ambiance seemed rather subdued and emotionally flat.
 
U.S.-Soviet Agenda Dwarfed
The contast seemed to reflect the fact that so many aspects of the traditional Soviet-American agenda have been dwarfed, and in some cases rendered almost irrelevant, by the changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union in the last six months.
For instance, the original motivation for this particular meeting was to overcome many remaining obstacles to a strategic arms limitation treaty so Presidents Bush and Gorbachev would be able to sign it at their June summit meeting in Washington.
But the more immediate issues now dominating the agenda in Europe are ones that the American-Soviet dialogue alone can only marginally influence -the reunification of Germany and the disintegration of the Soviet bloc.
Baker aides said Mr. Shevardnadze had devoted most of last night's three-hour meeting with the Secretary to explaining the results of the party session and Mr. Gorbachev's general plans on the domestic front.
The aides quoted Mr. Shevardnadze as telling Mr. Baker that it had become clear that political change in the Soviet Union was outrunning economic change and therefore some far-reaching economic liberalization was going to be called for in the near future.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The President;
What Is Bush Up To?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the leader of the Democratic majority in the House, said today that ''Americans are asking one question: 'Why is President Bush beating plowshares into swords?' ''
Mr. Gephardt was making a partisan gibe, of course, and by no means all Americans would agree with his characterization of Mr. Bush's performance this week. But to many in Washington, at least, much of the President's activity has seemed seriously, sometimes almost surrealistically, out of sync.
This week, while the Communist Party of the Soviet Union voted to give up its constitutional monopoly on power, while evidence accumulated that the Soviet Union is threatened with rapid dissolution, while West Germany's leaders were working toward uniting its currency (and thus its economy) with that of East Germany, while the Pentagon was saying the Soviet Union no longer constitutes a danger in the Persian Gulf - while all those signs of an ebbing Soviet threat were coming in, Mr. Bush was sending out cold war symbols. 
There he was on Monday, watching American soldiers fight ''Soviet'' tanks in war games at Fort Irwin, Calif. There he was today at Offutt Air Force Base outside Omaha, wearing a leather bomber jacket as he clambered into a B-1 bomber and inspected a B-52 - a pair of lethal machines whose primary mission is to attack the Soviet Union. Is the Bridge Secure? It was all quite deliberate, of course. In this day of image politics, Presidents do not offer up pictures like those by chance, especially not Presidents like Mr. Bush, the man who so skillfully appropriated the American flag as his campaign symbol.
Furthermore, Mr. Bush has made his message explicit. He is loath to walk too quickly across ''a bridge that can lead us from seemingly endless conflict to the promise of a lasting peace,'' he said in San Francisco on Wednesday, before he is certain that ''the bridge is secure.''
But an accomplished politician like the President, who has shown more than once that he is cannier and more calculating than he seems, must surely know, key members of both parties have been saying, that there isn't much real public support for continued huge military spending, and that every fresh sign of Soviet weakness tends to erode even that minimal support.
Mr. Bush has freely acknowledged that he faces a tough selling job. So why has he sent Congress a $295.1 billion 1991 budget for the Pentagon, 1.3 percent above the current one? Why does he keep pushing the Strategic Defense Initiative, running the risk of ridicule by suggesting that if it isn't needed to protect the country against the Russians, it might be needed to block missiles launched by the Iranians or the Libyans or the narcotics barons?
 
Personality, Politics, History
It's a puzzle to which few here pretend to have the answer. But most Presidents act as they do on big issues for several reasons, and this one's actions would seem to grow out of his personality, his political calculations and his sense of history.
White House officials deny, as they would be expected to, that there is any politics at all in the way the President is reacting to headlong change.
No doubt, Mr. Bush's innate caution is one element in the equation, especially at a moment when, as he acknowledged in his speech to the Commonwealth Club, ''the world is moving too fast to forecast'' what is coming next.
No doubt, like most leaders, he finds it uncomfortable to execute sharp turns away from policies that have been followed by his predecessors - in this case, as he also said in San Francisco, from Harry S. Truman to Ronald Reagan. That is one reason why policies almost always outlive the circumstances that gave rise to their adoption.
 
Delight in Military Gear
Perhaps he gets a certain thrill, as an old World War II aviator, from the sophisticated and fascinating modern weapons that technology has made possible. He is not the first President to delight in putting on military gear, as he did at least twice this week, and posing for television. Even his rival of two years ago, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, made a feckless, now-famous attempt to play the game by donning a tank crewman's helmet for the cameras.
But many think that Mr. Bush has an overall political scheme, too.
He has chosen to provide for two manned bombers and two long-range mobile missile systems, while proposing to close or scale down a large number of military bases in the United States, because that puts the Democrats in a box. Most of the affected bases, not by accident, are in areas represented by Democrats. If the Democrats go along, they weaken themselves with voters more concerned about jobs than high strategy; if they protest, they look like hypocrites, eager to cut all military spending eexcept where it hurts them.
''Longstanding critics of defense spending should not turn around and block the closing of a base in their home district,'' he said this week, lest anyone should have missed the point.
 
Gesture to Conservatives
At the same time, the emphasis on modernizing strategic weapons is seen as a gesture to the conservatives in his party whom Mr. Bush has so often taken pains to woo, largely because he knows they suspect him of being a closet liberal. A middle-of-the-road Republican Senator commented the other day, apropos not only of the budget request but also of the bellicose imagery:
''It's a lot of pantomime, designed to placate our right-wingers the same way his gentle words about education and the environment are meant to reassure the moderates. He knows he'll never get all the weapons he's asked for, but he figures that they'll cut whatever list he sends up here anyway, so he may as well start high and work down.''
Most of the Democrats in Congress do seem intent on whittling down the President's requests. No sooner had he proposed to cut American troop strength in Central Europe to 195,000, a figure far below any he had ever entertained publicly before, than he was being pressed to cut many more.
But whatever spin he applies to things, Mr. Bush is storing up trouble for himself by pressing for so large a military budget at a time when the main reason the American people were willing to be heavily taxed to buy weapons - their fear of attack from the Soviet Union - appears to be evaporating.
''I'm absolutely convinced that he can't sustain anything resembling this level of spending this year,'' Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the leader of the Democratic majority in the Senate, said in an interview this week. ''We don't need two manned bombers, we don't need lots of things that he has proposed, and when we finish with the budget, the money will not be there.''
 
Drastic Cuts Are Seen
Although he was unwilling to specify an figure of his own, pending the conclusion of hearings on the present shape of Soviet policy and the appropriate American response, Mr. Mitchell predicted that spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative would be ''drastically reduced,'' that either the MX mobile missile or the Midgetman missile or both would be eliminated, that several aircraft carrier groups would be cut and that far fewer B-1 Stealth bombers, if any, would be authorized.
After hearings presided over by Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, Mr. Mitchell plans to try to line up most of his party behind an alternate military budget. He acknowledges that some Democratic conservatives might be unwilling to go along, but he expects to win some Republican backing. The target date, he said, is late April. As things now stand, Mr. Bush seems unlikely to prevail in the battle that will ensue. But perhaps time will be on his side. By the time a final vote is taken, events may have made the future clearer and compromise may be possible.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;
East Germany Agrees to Pay Reparations to the Jewish Victims of the Nazis

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
East Germany, which has long refused to accept responsibility for the crimes of the Nazis against the Jews, has for the first time agreed to pay reparations to Jewish victims, the World Jewish Congress said yesterday.
In a statement released at the Manhattan headquarters of the congress, Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany said his Government recognized ''the responsibility of the entire German people for the past'' and stood ready to ''provide material support'' for those who were persecuted.
West Germany made a similar declaration in 1951 and has since paid an estimated $37 billion in reparations to Israel, Jewish organizations and individual Jewish claimants.
Some 170,000 victims of the Nazis still receive regular checks from the West Germans. Mr. Modrow's letter, sent to Edgar M. Bronfman, the president of the congress, did not say how much money would be available by the East Germans. 
 
Negotiations on Amount
The amount is expected to be determined in negotiations with Israel and the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, the same two groups that negotiated the reparations agreement with West Germany almost 40 years ago.
The willingness of East Germany to negotiate is expected to open the way for that country to establish diplomatic relations with Israel.
East Germany has long maintained that it is in no way heir to the crimes of the Third Reich, and that its Communist leadership, long imprisoned by Hitler, fought and helped defeat the Nazis.
Jewish groups have worked hard over the years to get East Germany to accept some responsiblity. The issue was discussed in the 1974 negotiations that led to the establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and East Germany. Talks between Jewish organizations and the East Germans were begun at that time and have continued intermittently.
 
Collapse of the Communists
It is not clear whether Mr. Modrow's letter is the result of those sporadic talks or of the collapse of Communist dominance in East Germany. Mr. Modrow came to power last year after the fall of Erich Honecker. Under the Nazis, Mr. Honecker spent long years in concentration camps.
Heads of Jewish organizations were cautious in their reaction yesterday. Mr. Bronfman called Mr. Modrow's letter ''an important first step.'' Rabbi Israel Miller, the president of the Jewish claims organization, said, ''I hope that his deeds match his words.''
Philip M. Klutznick, chairman of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture, which administers West German reparations to help rebuild Jewish life in Europe, said such a move by the East Germans was ''only just.''
He added, ''This is a debt that can never be fully repaid.''
Mr. Modrow's letter also dealt with the fear of resurgent anti-Semitism and nationalism in his country. ''The German Democratic Republic stands unalterably by its duty to do everything against racism, Nazism, anti-Semitism and hatred among peoples, so that in the future war and Fascism will never again start from German soil, but only peace and understanding among people.''
 
West Germany's Impoverishment
It is also unclear how East Germany, which is in economic difficulty, could afford substantial reparations.
But Rabbi Miller said West Germany was impoverished after the war and was nevertheless able to pay $1 billion in reparations to Israel in the form of commodities and manufactured goods like German automobiles. He suggested that East Germany might be able to do the same.
The reparations that Israel received were for the cost of resettlement of European refugees in Israel. At the time of the negotiations over the amount to be paid to Israel, the West German Government said it was ready to assume two-thirds of the cost, arguing that the balance should be paid by East Germany. Following that logic, the East German share for Israel would be more than $300 million.
In addition to the Israeli portion, reparations for individuals and Jewish organizations will be subject to negotiations. Experts could not put a dollar amount on that yesterday.
Along with the 170,000 survivors receiving stipends, thousands of others who have come to the West in recent months from the Soviet Union as the result of the turmoil in Eastern Europe are also expected to apply.
The details of how such funds will be distributed are expected to be worked out in the negotiations. In East Berlin, Dr. Peter Kirchner, the head of a small Jewish group in East Berlin, welcomed the Modrow statement. ''The most important thing is that it's final, that it says, Yes, the G.D.R. fully recognizes its share of guilt, and also that the G.D.R. feels itself bound by this responsibility,'' he said.
 
Modrow's Wish
He said Mr. Modrow's interim government evidently wanted to declare itself on the subject before it was replaced in March by a democratically elected government.
In New York, Rabbi Miller, said he believed that the change to a democratic system was the ''determining factor'' in Mr. Modrow's declaration. Rabbi Miller said he neogtiated the issue of reparations with Mr. Honecker two years ago. ''We were getting no place with Honecker,'' he said.
The Modrow Government has begun talks with Israeli representatives about opening diplomatic relations between the countries. Last week, negotiators for both countries met in Copenhagen. An Israeli statement said relations with East Germany were linked to ''the question of the acceptance by the G.D.R. of its share in the moral and historical responsibility for crimes perpetrated by Germans against Jews during the Nazi regime.''

HEADLINE: Genteel Charleston Shakes Off Hugo And Starts Hurrying Toward Spring

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C.

 BODY:
On a visit to Charleston in 1880, Oscar Wilde and his host strolled through town just after dusk. The Irish author and wit remarked on the beauty of the moon rising over the harbor and the city.
''You should have seen it before the war,'' his host is said to have responded wistfully.
In a city that is synonymous with a gentility associated with the Colonial and antebellum South, that response was once typical of its Charleston-centered world view. When Charleston has been beset by often chaotic and impersonal accidents of history like hurricanes and wars, the city's residents have had an apoplectic tendency to take them personally. 
Preservationists here still speak of Charleston as an ''accreting city'' - one that in its 320 years has been lovingly layered by the passage of time, acquiring not only a variety of distinctive architectural styles but also a certainty about the order of things that has intensified its glow.
 
A Lack of Wistfulness
''But I don't see any of that same sick wistfulness after Hurricane Hugo,'' said Connie Wyrick, a spokeswoman for the Historic Charleston Foundation. ''We're so far past that, and the idea now is to protect this patrimony and move forward.''
It has been more than four months since Hurricane Hugo struck Charleston, and the city is mending. Cosmetic repairs have returned the basics of most of the city's historic buildings and homes to what they were before the hurricane, which struck Sept. 21-22.
Preservationists say that what has not been restored, and in some cases cannot be replaced, are many of Charleston's ancient oaks and such subtle architectural touches as decorative cast-iron pieces and the pressed-tin moldings that adorned cornices.
Moreover, many of Charleston's pampered English gardens are a wreck, and gardeners must wait for early spring to see what remains of the languid crepe myrtle, and the colorful azalea and magnolia. And behind many of the repaired facades, homeowners are still coping with the lingering effects of moisture and other storm damage that takes longer to emerge.
 
Two Damage Assessments
Two reports released recently sought to calculate what has already been lost.
In one report, a draft of a study by the National Trust for Historic Preservation of the hurricane's impact on ''cultural and historic resources'' in North Carolina and South Carolina, damage was estimated at $250 million. In Charleston alone, the report said, more than 2,000 historic structures were damaged.
In the other report, a National Parks Service survey of the 135 buildings in Charleston deemed to be of the greatest historical and architectural significance found that none had been completely lost. But damage to these buildings, ranging from severe structural problems to minor roof damage, was estimated at $10.5 million.
While such reports put the city's situation in some perspective, officials here fear that they may keep tourists away. And that could be devastating to the city, which attracts about three million visitors a year, worth about $400 million to its economy.
 
Very Little Major Damage
''Putting the figures aside,'' said Mayor Joseph Riley. ''the point is that the worst fury of the hurricane hit about 25 miles from the historic district and so, while no building was spared some damage, very little of the damage was major. What we have is a tremendous paint-up, fix-up, tidy-up and repair job, and the first-time visitor couldn't even tell that we had a hurricane.''
Thomas Savage, curator of the Historic Charleston Foundation, said: ''People who visit will not be dumbfounded by the storm damage because the facades are here. The silhouettes of some of the textbook examples of historic architecture are intact.''
Mr. Savage said the foundation was going ahead with its annual spring Festival of Houses and Gardens, which is scheduled for March 22 through April 21. One hundred homes will be featured in tours, he said, and things like roof and plaster damage will not stop the tours ''because that just happens to be the way we are living now.''
J. Jackson Walter, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, praised Charlestonians and particularly Mayor Riley for ''having correct values when it comes to preservation.'' He said there was no mad rush to demolish damaged buildings in Charleston as he said was the case with the National Trust in San Francisco after the earthquake there less than a month later.
 
Praise for City Leadership
''There was no Joe Riley in San Francisco,'' he said. ''Here you had a city leadership that was instantly and strongly aligned toward restoration and conservation.''
But even in a city that is sensitive to the needs of preservation, there have been problems, said Connie Wyrick, a spokeswoman for the Historic Charleston Foundation. Some of the problems centered on the Federal Emergency Management Agency's guidelines for grants for repairs.
In many cases the Federal agency uses formulas that represent standard costs nationally, and such formulas do not apply to restoration of older buildings, Mayor Riley said.
Even though the percentage of homeowners in the city's historic district was high, many of them moved quickly to settle with insurance adjusters, only to have other structural or related damage show up later. Still others chose to get quick repair jobs to damaged masonry and roofs from the army of out-of-town and often unlicensed workers that descended on the city after the storm. And the results of such haste show, some homeowners say.
 
Need for Skilled Craftsmen
''I'm convinced that some of these so-called contractors were ax murderers the week before they showed up here,'' said Mr. Savage, pointing to sloppy roofing jobs and brick work. ''There were good workmen who came in, but this city's preeminence as a preservation city is belied by the fact we just didn't have the skilled craftsmen here to do some of the work.''
For many, the storm damage provided motivation for them to learn more about their homes. For example, Phillip Middleton, a lawyer who lives in a home that was built in 1783, the mystery was how to repair the slate roof damaged when a chimney toppled.
After calling the British Embassy and making several trans-Atlantic telephone calls, Mr. Middleton was able to identify the quarry that supplied all of the purplish slate intended for crown colony buildings in the 18th century, and arranged for a representative of the company to come to Charleston to advise and supply homeowners.
''When he said the quarry had been active and operating since the 12th century, even Charlestonians were impressed,'' Ms. Wyrick said.

HEADLINE: Appeals Court Rules A.M.A. Acted Against Chiropractors

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court has upheld a 1987 ruling that the American Medical Association violated antitrust laws by trying to destroy the chiropractic profession.
On Wednesday, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed the finding of Federal District Judge Susan Getzendanner, who barred the medical association from boycotting chiropractors, whose treatment is manipulation focusing on the spine.
George McAndrews, a lawyer for the chiropractors, said the rights they want include ''fair treatment by tax-supported institutions, hospitals, insurance plans, H.M.O.'s and other groups that have burdened those patients with anticompetitive barriers.'' 
A.M.A. policy, the plaintiffs charge, has prevented doctors from referring patients to chiropractors or taking referrals from them. The doctors were accused of preventing chiropractors from treating patients at hospitals controlled by medical doctors.
 
Association's Curbs Enjoined
On Sept. 25, 1987, Judge Getzendanner, who has since retired, permanently enjoined the A.M.A. from ''restricting, regulating or impeding'' its 275,000 members or hospitals where they work from associating with chiropractors. Earlier she found a conspiracy ''to contain and eliminate the chiropractic profession.''
A three-judge appellate panel ruled that Judge Getzendanner had reached a ''reasonable'' decision. The panelists were Judges David Manion, Harlington Wood Jr. and Kenneth Ripple.
She ''found a cognizable danger of recurrent violations, was unimpressed with the A.M.A.'s expressed intent to comply with antitrust laws, was unpersuaded by the effectiveness of the A.M.A.'s discontinuance of its boycott and properly considered the systematic and long-term nature of the boycott,'' the appeals panel said.
 
Internal Amendment Is Directed
Judge Getzendanner also directed the A.M.A. to publish a copy of her order in the Journal of the American Medical Association and mail all of its members and employees copies.
She also required that the association amend its Current Opinions of the Council on Ethical and Judicial Affairs, guidelines on ethical behavior to reflect that it is ethical to associate with chiropractors.
The lawsuit, filed in 1977 by four chiropractors, did not seek money damages but challenged the medical doctors' refusal to acknowledge chiropractors' professional abilities.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 10, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article by The Associated Press yesterday about an antitrust ruling against the American Medical Association for its boycott of chiropractors described the Federal appeals court's opinion incompletely in some copies. The opinion, by the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, said the A.M.A. had economic motives but was acting mostly out of concern about scientific methods in patient care.

HEADLINE: For Nebraska Governor, a Hard Path

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROKEBY, Neb., Feb. 7

 BODY:
She is ''just plain Kay,'' Nebraska's Governor told students in a rural two-room schoolhouse here, but that is not a view that is very widely held.
Gov. Kay A. Orr, the pride of Republicans across the country and a target of Democrats here at home, was pursuing what she says is one of the most pleasurable privileges of her office, visiting public schools around the state.
But on the visits today, as she tackled questions that would have done justice to a news conference in the state capital of Lincoln, not too far away, the topics made it clear why Mrs. Orr, a Republican officeholder in a Republican state, is a beleaguered candidate as she prepares to seek re-election.
A lot of Nebraskans think she has broken faith with them when she merely made a mistake, she told a student who asked her about a change in tax policy that resulted in a tax increase that she said was unintended. One of her pledges in her first campaign was that she would not raise taxes. 
 
Erosion of Poll Standing
The Governor is trying to reverse an erosion in her standing in opinion polls over the last two years. The effort is expected to be bolstered by a fund-raising visit to Omaha on Thursday by President Bush. Support for her campaign has also come from recent visits by Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, and by Jack F. Kemp, Mr. Bush's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
In December 1987, at her highest point in opinion polls conducted by The Omaha World-Herald, 60 percent of Nebraskans interviewed said they approved of the job she was doing as Governor and 25 percent disapproved. By the following March, that rating had fallen to 48 percent approval while 38 percent disapproved.
Since then, her approval rating in the poll has never again topped 50 percent. The latest poll, in December, based on interviews with 615 adults in the state, gave her an approval rating of 47 percent and disapproval of 46 percent, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Those polling results are apparently one element that has encouraged several Democrats to weigh candidacies for the primaries, to be held May 8. So far they include Bill Harris, Mayor of Lincoln; Bill Hoppner, former chief of staff to her predecessor, Bob Kerrey, now a United States Senator; Ben Nelson, an Omaha lawyer, and Mike Boyle, a former Mayor of Omaha. As yet Mrs. Orr has no opponent in the Republican primary. Concern Within the G.O.P. The polls have also stirred concern among national Republicans, who have been able to point to Mrs. Orr as the first Republican woman to be elected Governor of any state, as well as a determination to help keep her in office.
The shadow of the campaign was evident in today's schoolhouse questions and answers.
It was a question from a boy, ''Why did you raise our taxes?'' that gave Mrs. Orr a chance to explain, by inference, her slippage in the polls. That slippage followed a change the Governor pushed through the Legislature in 1987, decoupling state income taxes from the Federal tax system and setting new rate schedules for state taxpayers.
She had run for Governor pledging no tax increases and, she often explains, the change she urged was intended neither to raise nor to lower taxes. As it worked out, however, it raised taxes at many income levels. And, she acknowledges, it has alienated many voters despite the fact that she has successfully sponsored corrective legislation.
''I'm going to be explaining that'' throughout the campaign, Mrs. Orr told the students. ''Folks thought I had raised their taxes, and they were very angry about that.''
The Governor's ''just plain Kay'' remark came in answer to a question, ''What's your real name?'' ''It's not short for Katherine or anything else,'' she said. ''It's just plain Kay.''
When a girl asked about how Mrs. Orr was helping the homeless, the Governor took the opportunity to praise the child, saying, ''That shows you are very sensitive.'' The Governor also took the opportunity to allude to legislation that she regards as one of her triumphs, providing for tax benefits for companies that create job opportunities, saying that ''a healthy economy is one of the ways'' to solve the problems that lead to homelessness.
 
Economic Gains Cited
According to her figures, the results so far are 23,000 new and prospective jobs and a jobless rate that has fallen to 2.7 percent, from 5.5 percent when she took office in January 1987. More neutral commentary gives her considerable credit for the program but puts the figure at closer to 11,000 jobs created so far.
Some of Mrs. Orr's opponents like to picture her as a tough, hard-edged politician, and some have made sarcastic allusions to the fact that she appeared with a 20-month-old grandson on her 51st birthday on Jan. 2 when she announced her decision to run for re-election. Some have speculated that the appearance with her grandchild was a calculated device to demonstrate warmth - a theory that clearly angers her.
''I am also a wife, a mother and a grandmother,'' she said as she described her job to the children. And besides her two children, she continued, she has ''two dogs, two cats and a horse.''
She addressed such criticism another way in a conversation between visits to the two schools. Mrs. Orr warned, ''It's going to be a dirty campaign.''
''They are wrong,'' she said, referring to her critics. ''I am strong, but people who know me know there's no sham.''

HEADLINE: Darman and Moynihan Joust Over Social Security

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, faced off over Social Security today for the first time in a public forum.
By the time the hearing of the Senate Finance Committee was over, it appeared that neither Senator Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security tax nor the Bush Administration's plan to use the surplus in Social Security revenues to begin paying off the Federal debt in five years had enough support to become law.
But the Social Security issue has created so much controversy that some changes may be inevitable.
Senator Moynihan's proposal, which would reduce Government income by more than $60 billion over the next two years, has gained little backing among his fellow Democrats. It may have been dealt a fatal blow today when Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the chairman of the Finance Committee, said he could not support it. 
 
'Many Mutations' Are Seen
''That much loss of revenue would cause serious problems for the economy,'' Senator Bentsen told reporters. But the Texas Democrat quickly added that ''many mutations'' of the Moynihan plan were floating about and that he might favor one or more of them.
The Administration's plan, which would allow the surplus in Social Security funds to continue to cover general Government operating expenses through 1995, has almost no support among Democrats, and many Republicans have broken ranks with the White House.
But Mr. Darman said the Administration was not wedded to the specific proposal and was willing to consider others.
Adding to the prospects that changes in the system are in the offing, Democratic leaders from the Senate and House have been meeting to work out a Social Security alternative the party can support. So far, they have been unable to agree on one.
 
A Scarcity of Sparks
The confrontation between Mr. Moynihan, a New York Democrat, and Mr. Darman caused fewer sparks than might have been expected from two of the most nimble minds in Washington, in part because both have made their cases so many times recently.
Mr. Moynihan maintained, as he has for weeks, that it was unfair to collect from workers Social Security taxes meant to finance their retirement, and use the money to cover part of the budget deficit caused by the Government's failure to collect as much in other taxes as it spends for day-to-day expenses. The billions of dollars in revenue that would be lost by his proposal, he declared, would be ''no great sum to make up.'' He suggested that much of it could be offset by deeper cuts in military spending.
Mr. Darman argued that the Moynihan plan risked ''fiscal policy havoc'' by substantially increasing the budget deficit. He suggested that the Senator ''seems to give up on the problem, just when the political system is preparing to deal with it.''
 
Agreement on Problem
While the solutions are in dispute, the ''problem'' to which Mr. Darman referred is recognized by politicians of both parties. It is this:
The Government over all is running a sizable budget deficit. Meanwhile, the Social Security system is collecting an increasing amount more each year in payroll taxes than it is paying out in retirement, disability and survivors' benefits. The excess in this fiscal year is $66 billion. The total Federal deficit, according to the calculation of the Congressional Budget Office, is expected to be $138 billion. But if Social Security is taken out of the calculation, the deficit would be put at $204 billion.
The Social Security surplus is a result of the schedule of payroll tax increases enacted in 1983. The purpose of the increases was twofold: to insure solvency in the system in the short run and to build up a reserve to guarantee that pensions could be paid to members of the baby-boom generation when they retire early in the next century. Workers and their employers now pay 7.65 percent each, 6.2 percent for Social Security and 1.45 percent for Medicare, up to a maximum of $3,924 a year.
The Social Security surplus, however, grew much faster than anticipated because the economy did better than expected. The overall budget deficit, caused by lower taxes, higher military spending and the failure to cut spending for domestic programs, also grew more than expected.
 
A Collection of I.O.U.'s
Under law, the Social Security surplus is paid into a trust fund and is used to buy Treasury securities. If there were no budget deficit, the investment of Social Security funds in Treasury securities would mean the Government would have to borrow less from the public, allowing more private money to be invested in plants, equipment and other productive enterprises.
When the budget is in deficit, the money the Treasury gets from selling the securities to the Social Security system is spent for general expenses, from paperweights to warships.
But even when no budget deficit exists, the trust fund is nothing but a collection of i.o.u.'s. When the Treasury securities come due, the Government must tax or borrow enough to repay them. The reserve is merely a Government promise to do that in the next century to pay retirement benefits.
The theory behind building a Social Security surplus was that it would stimulate enough private investment that the economy would grow. The increased standard of living that would result would make it easier for workers in the next century to pay for the retirement of the baby-boomers.
Senator Moynihan maintains that since the money is not now being used to improve the economy, the tax increases ought to be reversed. The Administration's plan is to continue to cut the deficit gradually until it reaches zero in 1995 and to earmark the surplus after that for debt reduction.

HEADLINE: Adversaries at the Table: The Labor Negotiators

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Like players, they have distinctive styles. Like owners, they have distinctive interests.
But Donald M. Fehr, the executive director of the baseball players' union, and Charles P. O'Connor, the executive director of the club owners' labor team, probably have more in common with each other than with the men who preceded them in the economic wars that revolutionized baseball over the last 20 years. Both are lawyers who have spent their careers in labor relations, both are somewhat professional and cool in manner, both are known as negotiators and not as warriors. 
They are also confronting each other in the talks on a new basic agreement for major league baseball. And they should make more baseball news than any of the players and clubs they represent if the spring training camps are kept closed until the two lawyers reach some sort of agreement or understanding.
 
Worked with Miller
Fehr has been there before. He was there as an associate of Marvin Miller in 1976 when the players shattered the century-old assumption that they belonged to the teams that hired them, and he was there during the next decade when the players consolidated their free-agent revolution. Now he is their leader as the players try to retain the clout that has made them entrepreneurs with salaries soaring past $3 million a year.
O'Connor is new to the scene, at least as a visible member of the cast. He is a Washington lawyer who worked on the sidelines for the last two years as an outside labor counsel to the Player Relations Committee, the owners' bargaining arm. Then, like a late replacement for the starting pitcher, he got the call when Barry Rona resigned as director of the committee last November on the eve of the start of negotiations.
''He's reserved and not flamboyant, but he is witty and he has a good sense of humor,'' said Rich Levin of the commissioner's office. ''But he is a tough guy deep down, and he's not afraid of confrontations. Barry was more of a down-home sort; Chuck is more formal. I guess you'd say he is lawyerlike in his manner.''
O'Connor was born in Boston 49 years ago and grew up cheering for the Red Sox. He graduated from Holy Cross in 1963 and from the Boston College Law School in 1966, and he had no doubt what he wanted to do, even when he was working as a bricklayer: he wanted to be a labor lawyer. Started With N.L.R.B. He got his start in the general counsel's office of the National Labor Relations Board in Washington. Then, 21 years ago, he joined the Washington law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Three years later, he became a partner.
He got into baseball somewhat by chance in 1981, the year the players went on strike for 50 days and the big leagues were shut down for two months. He was asked to work on a project for Anheuser-Busch, which owns the St. Louis Cardinals, and after that he divided his baseball loyalty between the Red Sox and the Cardinals.
He is a formidable figure at 6 feet 3 inches and more than 200 pounds. He and his wife, Linda, have four children. And, although not well known in baseball, he is unmistakably the architect of the owners' radical proposal for revenue-sharing among the clubs and a statistical formula for setting salaries for players who have been in the big leagues between one and six years.
He is also the latest in a line of management negotiators that included John Gaherin, who once represented New York's newspapers in labor troubles; Ray Grebey, once the labor trouble-shooter for General Electric, and Lee MacPhail, the former president of the American League, who served as a ''healing'' choice in the increasingly turbulent relations between the clubs and the players.
 
Into Labor Law Early
The man across the table from O'Connor these days, Fehr, was born 41 years ago in Indiana, the son of a businessman. He grew up in Prairie Village, Kan., earned his bachelor's degree at Indiana University and his law degree in 1973 at the University of Missouri. He also got into labor law early, and stayed.
He started as a law clerk for Judge Elmo Hunter of the United States District Court in Kansas City, Mo., then joined the Kansas City law firm of Jolley, Moran, Walsh, Hager & Gordon. He was there when the landmark case of Andy Messersmith was tried in Federal court in Kansas City in 1975, and the firm was selected as the local representative of the Major League Baseball Players' Association for the trial. Messersmith was suing for the right to become a free agent, and won.
The next year, Fehr joined the players' union full time as general counsel when Richard Moss left, and worked closely with Miller, who was the strategist of the players' revolution and the executive director of their union. When Miller retired in 1983, the union named a Federal mediator, Kenneth Moffett, as his replacement. But he was dismissed in November that year, and Fehr took charge.
 
Not a Warrior or Orator
Fehr is a studied, smooth-faced man of medium height who once rooted for the Kansas City Royals and later the Yankees. He and his wife, Stephanie, have four children. He doesn't resemble Miller as a warrior or orator, and in fact was characterized last year by his mentor in these words:
''He's not as aggressive as he should be with people who lie and cheat. It shows he lacks the background of a trade unionist. It shows a lawyer's mentality.''
''I don't mean Don's wrong,'' Miller said. ''But he and I have different standards in labor-management relationships.''
Miller was asked this week if his successor was confrontational enough, and he said: ''This is no time to be second-guessing anybody. The situation is confrontational now.''

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Superczar

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Just before his fatal heart attack, Andrei Sakharov went before the Soviet Parliament to plead for an end to the monopoly power of the Communist Party; Mikhail Gorbachev shut him up and cut him off.
Now that multiparty dream is becoming a reality. With the simple presentation to voters of a choice between opposing candidates, the dead hand of Leninist totalitarianism will be lifted. The honoring of opposition is the beginning of political freedom. 
Sakharov and some of his reform group had a second goal: to break the monopoly of Government ownership, permitting private property and free markets to generate national wealth.
That thrust for economic freedom was blunted by the Politburo only six weeks ago, as Mr. Gorbachev agreed with Communist ideologues and apparatchiks to try a form of perestroika that did not give up central control. Such strangling ''democratic centralism'' was again endorsed by the plenum, but a law permitting the privatization of some property is also on the agenda - a little, and late.
Sakharov, almost alone, dared to offer a third goal: to make it impossible in the Soviet Union for any ruler to have too much power. Of what use would a multiparty system and a market economy be if their very existence depended on the whim of one man?
Benevolent despotism exists in Moscow; Sakharov's main concern remains valid. The fever of democracy, the fierce (but secret) debate about direction, the first assemblage of a huge crowd in Red Square in 70 years - all these thrilling, historic events are taking place concurrent with the consolidation of power in a single pair of hands.
''The Party's Over,'' cry the Western headlines - as if the crumbling of Communist Party monopoly guaranteed lusty political competition for the job of national leader.
On the contrary, the coming fractionalization of the party will remove the last challenge to one-man control of the Government. Centralization of authority has not been defeated; the center of power has simply moved across the hall.
Mikhail Gorbachev now has more power than any czar, more of a personality cult than Stalin. He has undermined the corrupt party and created his own Government hierarchy in which only the president need not stand for election. Hello, Superczar.
Should we rejoice at the results of the Moscow plenum? Of course: it was one more manifestation of the victory of capitalism over Communism, a triumph already made plain everywhere by the difference in living standards of free and unfree peoples.
Should we admire the manipulations of the most daring opportunist of our century? Pursued by the wolves of depression and dissension, he has tossed the nations of Eastern Europe from the Soviet sled, and further unburdened himself of heavy Leninist doctrine.
That's admirable, but it's not enough; the wolves are catching up. He has to toss over the heavy arms spending that bogged him down originally, let the Baltic nations slip away to long-deserved independence, and kick weighty Cuba and arms-addicted Syria off the sled.
Without those wolves of necessity at his heels, Mr. Gorbachev would not have felt the urge to spin off the satellites, to demobilize some troops, to attack the Communist Party or introduce the ownership law.
None of that was part of his plan, as his early writing, five years of blunders and recent flip-flops made clear. Improvising brilliantly, the superczar is at last moving toward a multiparty system at home, but democracy cannot be dictated; one-man rule, no matter how benevolent the despot, is no better than one-party rule.
The ability of a crowd to gather in Red Square is just as historic as the secret vote in the meeting hall; that was televised and will be contagious.
Soon we will see more crowds, protest parades, strike-supporting demonstrations. Many will be shouting their anger at food shortages and joblessness, others at ethnic scapegoats, but enough will be demanding more say in their own lives.
President Bush is said to be considering a higher-profile envoy to Moscow, like his fellow Texan Robert Strauss. He should choose that sort of direct dealer who can speak frankly about democracy.
For political freedom, you need a vigorous, organized opposition; for economic salvation, you need private property and free markets; for world cooperation, you need to withdraw your troops from Eastern Europe and free the Baltic nations; for legitimacy, you must make it possible for the people to choose their leaders and have the right to vote them out. Most especially including the President.
