HEADLINE: Region Grapples With Sluggish Sales-Tax Revenues

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Like seers pondering the auguries, economists and government officials in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey are sifting through sales-tax receipts for a vision of the region's future.
Their predictions - how much people will spend and thus how much tax money will come in - have always been crucial to the budget process that occupies all three state governments around this time of year. And until recently the job was not difficult. In Connecticut, for example, sales-tax collections - the main source of revenue in the state - rose by a steady 5 percent or more in every year except one from 1971 to 1988. 
But all that has ended over the last few years, with an unexpected slowing of sales-tax collections in the Northeast from Massachusetts to New Jersey. The collections have continued to grow but at a sharply slower rate - about 3 percent to 5 percent a year across the region compared with almost three times that rate in the mid-1980's. As a result, statehouses are searching for new tax-collection formulas, and some tax experts are seeing changes that go beyond a temporary economic slowdown.
 
'Already Bought the House'
''A part of the population is maturing, and they've already bought the house, they've got the VCR, they've got three televisions and they haven't worn out yet,'' said Dr. Richard L. Kaluzny, chief of the office of tax analysis at the division of taxation in New Jersey, where sales-tax revenues are expected to grow by only 3 percent this year, compared with 11 percent or more through the mid-1980's. ''My suspicion is that this has a lot more to do with demographics than we realize.''
The downturn in sales-tax growth has coincided with an increase in the national savings rate, and some experts say this is one sign among several that lower tax collections - and perhaps a long-term slower growth rate for state spending - may become a permanent budgetary reality in the 1990's.
''Sales taxes are like stock prices - an instantaneous expression of what's going on,'' said Irwin L. Kellner, the chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York. ''Elected officials should sit up and take notice.''
State budget officials, who must ultimately make revenue-growth predictions, said however, that with so much of the sales-tax equation depending on the mood of consumers - whether they are optimistic about the future and buying goods or pessimistic and saving money - predicting slower tax-collection rates and cutting state services in anticipation of such declines could be self-fulfilling; they would send an even stronger message to consumers that times are hard, the officials said, and consumers in turn would buy less.
 
An Optimistic Prediction
In Connecticut, for example, budget officials on Wednesday released what they immediately conceded was an optimistic prediction of 5 percent growth in sales-tax revenues for the year that begins on July 1, and said they believed that pent-up demand would provide part of the fuel.
The projected increase, which Mr. Kellner and several other economists rejected as unrealistically high, would follow a year in which sales-tax collections actually fell in Connecticut for the first time in recent memory. Although state budget officials said the dollar totals did increase during the year, it was only because the sales-tax rate went up last July 1, from 7.5 percent to 8 percent.
New Jersey's sales tax is 6 percent. In New York, the state collects a 4 percent sales tax and local sales taxes vary, although most are between 3 and 4 percent.
Dr. Kaluzny in New Jersey said that another problem in predicting sales-tax revenues accurately is that ''nobody wants to believe it'' when a grim revenue forecast is made. If the prediction is wrong, he said, painful cuts in state services may have been made unneccessarily. If the prediction is right, solving the problem will have at least been postponed until the next budget.
Dr. Kaluzny said he beleived that sales-tax revenues would rise about 3 percent in New Jersey in the next year. Gov. Jim Florio will present his budget and sales-tax projection to the Assembly next month.
 
Exemptions Aggravate Problem
''Who goes to the dentist to get preventive root-canal surgery?'' he said. ''You tend not to want to do it.'' What may have also aggravated the prediction problem, at least in Connecticut, are the sales-tax exemptions that were passed into law in the mid-1980's, when revenues were rising rapidly and the money was not needed. The new laws, intended to make the sales-tax fall less heavily on the poor, made any item of clothing under $75 exempt from the tax, as well as any meal costing under $2.
The result was to make the tax base depend even more on consumers' buying higher-priced merchandise, usually the items that consumers could put off buying if need be.
''The regular purchases, the things you buy in good times or bad, have been taken out,'' said Richard H. Mattoon, an economist for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, a business-lobby group.
But there are also efforts to broaden the types of transactions covered by the sales tax. In New York, for example, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo - who has also predicted a 5 percent sales-tax growth rate for the next year - proposed a new law last month that would generate $45 million in new revenue by taxing people on the value of their used cars. Under current law, when a car owner trades in his vehicle for a new one, the value of the trade-in is deducted from the price of the new car when the sales tax is calculated.
Last year, the Connecticut General Assembly also extended the state sales tax to cover many services like payments to gardeners or accountants, and repealed the sales-tax exemption for low-cost meals.
Ultimately, however, most economists said that a key source of the sales-tax downturn - the fact that people are not buying, building or furnishing as many houses as they were a few years ago - would persist for the time being regardless of what the states do. And Mr. Kellner at Manufacturers Hanover said he thought that any turnaround in sales-tax revenues was unlikely for perhaps 18 months, not soon enough to help the state budgets that will become law over the next few months.
But Connecticut officials believe the rebound will come in time to save them.
''We do not believe 5 percent is an unrealistic goal,'' said Connecticut's chief budget officer, Anthony V. Milano, the secretary of the Office of Policy and Management.

HEADLINE: Noise Rules for New Nightclubs Approved

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
The Board of Estimate approved a mixed bag of rules yesterday that it said would strike a balance between New York's often noisy nightclubs and their neighbors who seek peace and quiet.
When the regulations were first proposed by the City Planning Commission last summer, it was thought that they might fundamentally change night life in New York City. But the rules adopted by the Board of Estimate are far less restrictive than the original offerings and apply only to new nightclubs, not existing ones.
Originally, the commission had proposed earlier closing times for new clubs in commercial and residential areas unless they obtained a special permit, but it dropped this after encountering strong objections. Clubs can now stay open until 4 A.M. Cabaret Group May Sue Still, the new regulations displeased the New York Cabaret Association, which said they would discourage the opening of new clubs and adversely affect the night life and economy in New York City. A lawyer for the association, Robert S. Bookman, said there would likely be a lawsuit challenging some provisions. 
Among the new regulations is one that will generally require new large clubs planned for certain areas, like TriBeCa, SoHo and the Flatiron district of Manhattan, to meet specified conditions, and to obtain a special city permit.
To grant a new club a special permit, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals would have to find, among other things, that the proposed club would not impair the character of the surrounding area and that it would not cause undue congestion in local streets.
Small jazz clubs and other establishments with musical entertainment, but no dancing, and with a capacity of no more than 200 patrons, will not be required to obtain special permits.
Other small clubs with non-musical entertainment - like comedy clubs or poetry clubs will need a permit to open in some areas, largely in boroughs other than Manhattan.
New dance clubs and certain other establishments with a capacity of more than 200 patrons will, for the most part, be required to locate their entrances at least 100 feet from the nearest residential district.
 
Insuring 'Good Neighbors'
They will also be required to provide at least four square feet of indoor waiting space for each patron they can accommodate - a provision intended to prevent, at least at new clubs, long lines of patrons waiting outside the establishments.
Sandy Hornick, zoning director of the Department of Planning, said those requirements would make sure that the new clubs ''will be good neighbors.''
Residents of some neighborhoods where there are highly popular discos have complained that the waiting crowds are often boisterous, cause vandalism, and generally adversely affect their areas.
Because a previous city law that set a limit of three musicians at a time on stage in many of the city's small clubs and cabarets was declared unconstitutional by a State Supreme Court justice in 1988, the new regulations specified no limits for such clubs. But it said those clubs cannot have a cover charge or have specified show times.
 
Opposed by Golden
Planning officials said that the regulations should encourage more small clubs to open.
The lone Board of Estimate member to vote against the regulations, Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, said in a statement read by a representative, that the new zoning would have no effect on existing ''bad neighbor'' discos and clubs and ''are just too seriously flawed'' in other respects.
But Ruth W. Messinger, the Borough President of Manhattan, in voting for the amended zoning proposals, said the new regulations strike ''a proper balance between community concerns and a recognition of the importance of New York's dynamic night life.''
She said she was confident they would ''preserve both New York's worldwide reputation as an entertainment capital'' and the desire of many communities for ''peace and quiet.''

HEADLINE: 2 Gang Members Slain in Chinatown Restaurant

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
A clash between rival Vietnamese and Chinese gang members in Chinatown early yesterday left two young men dead and three people wounded, the authorities said.
The police identified the suspected assailants as members of the Canal Street Boys, which they said was the latest name adopted by a gang of ethnic Chinese from Vietnam.
The two youths who were killed were identified by the police as Peter Wng, 20 years old, and Dak Leong, 19. Both were said to be members of the Chinese gang known as the Ghost Shadows. 
 
A Heated Turf Feud
The authorities said the attack appeared to be the latest chapter in a turf feud between the relatively new gangs like the Canal Street Boys, and the older established Chinatown gangs, like the Ghost Shadows.
The police said the Canal Street Boys, who have been operating mostly on Canal Street for the last two years, have been involved in extortion, robberies and several homicides.
The latest incident began at 3:50 A.M., the police said, when a group entered Winnie's Bar and Restaurant, at 104 Bayard Street in Chinatown, and opened fire. Mr. Wong was pronounced dead at the scene, and Mr. Leong died on arrival at Bellevue Hospital Center.
A police spokesman, Det. Joseph McConville, said two people were wounded inside the restaurant. He identified them as Robert Shu, 27, shot in the groin, and Theresa Lau, 21, shot once in the left upper arm. Other police sources said that neither Mr. Shu nor Ms. Lau was known to be a gang member. Ms. Lau is a student at New York University.
A police officer parked in front of Police Headquarters heard the shots and chased a man with a gun who ran from the restaurant, the Chief of Detectives, Joseph R. Borrelli said. The officer, who was not identified, shot the suspect, Qui Tram, 23, in the left shoulder and arm, the police said. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital and was listed in stable condition last night. The police had not charged Mr. Tram as of last night.
''I heard some people shooting and the noise woke me up,'' said Sebastian Rueda, a 41-year-old unemployed and homeless carpenter, who has been camping out in the pavilion at Columbus Park just opposite Winnie's. He said there were often loud late night brawls in the place, but ''this time was different.''

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Bogosian Illuminates Life in the City

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
It's not news that Eric Bogosian is a great talent, a chameleon actor and penetrating social observer whose one-man shows have staked out their own mean streets in the crowded 1980's theatrical territory inhabited by Lily Tomlin, Spalding Gray, Whoopi Goldberg and so many others, from stand-up comedians to sit-down performance artists. Nor will it be news that ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll,'' Mr. Bogosian's new show at the Orpheum, follows the format of such preceding recitals as ''Fun House'' and ''Drinking in America.'' Once again the actor appears in black jeans, sneakers and white shirt to take the audience on a nonstop 90-minute tour through the mental states of men who live in these United States.
But there is news at ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll,'' and it is this: with this brilliant show, his funniest and scariest yet, Mr. Bogosian has crossed the line that separates an exciting artist from a culture hero. What Lenny Bruce was to the 1950's, Bob Dylan to the 1960's, Woody Allen to the 1970's - that's what Eric Bogosian is to this frightening moment of drift in our history. With the possible exception of Spike Lee, I know of no one else like him in pop culture right now. He knows which way the wind is blowing, and in ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll,'' those icy currents smack you right in the face. 
The show opens just as the day does for so many in the audience. A gimpy, insistent subway panhandler ''just released from Rikers Island'' announces to the captive straphangers: ''This is the situation - I need your money.'' What follows is a riotous amalgam of the familiar spiels, and Mr. Bogosian, his large green eyes glazed, leaves little doubt that the reformed junkie pleading for spare change is still on drugs. But should the beggar's needs be dismissed because he's lying? Not necessarily. As the man drones on, attempting to flatter his potential benefactors by recycling the jargon he's picked up in a lifetime of contact with the city's social and penal bureaucracies, Mr. Bogosian subtly but even more corrosively indicts the system that greases the skids and blights hope for those who need help. ''Underneath it all,'' says the subway beggar, ''we're exactly the same.''
Mr. Bogosian's next character - a fatuous, aging English rock star plugging his wares on a talk show -would seem to belie that statement. The musician is an anti-drug crusader who has joined forces with such other public moralists as Dan and Marilyn Quayle. (''She's hot - she's very hot!,'' the rocker assures his skeptical young fans about the Second Lady). But as he takes deep drags on his cigarette and glamorizes his own drug past in every show-biz reminiscence, it's clear that the rock star is as much of a con artist as the subway hustler; only the size of the stakes has changed.
By the time he gets around to pitching his favorite cause, the Amazonian Indians - a charity that seems to be inspired more by the rock star's egomania and unacknowledged racism than by the needs of the third world poor -Mr. Bogosian has come full circle. With only two characters, he has mapped out the entire international cycle of drug dependency, official hypocrisy and economic exploitation that leaves the homeless locked in subterranean hell and the coked-up rich in Hollywood heaven, with everyone else, especially the young, battling the fallout in between.
In the roughly one dozen bits that follow, Mr. Bogosian fills in more and more of the bleak Western landscape of 1990. A raving, phlegm-spewing old man delivers an obsessive but persuasive exegesis of the industrial age's death cycle, the pollution patterns that turn cities into ''human septic tanks'' and oceans into ''giant vats of oil and garbage and dead animals.'' Yet the monologue is not an environmentalist's boilerplate but rather a baroque fantasy, part Twain and part Ben Jonson, in which the narrative sweep takes in everyone from urinating outdoorsmen to well-heeled passengers vomiting caviar and pate on an ocean cruise.
Just as far-reaching is the chilling soliloquy that concludes the evening. An unreconstructed 1960's dropout sits cross-legged at stage edge to make the case that the United States is already an ''occupied country'' run by computers, whether fax machines or supermarket checkout stations, that plot against people all night by jabbering to one another in indecipherable languages. With the aid of television's power to deliver subliminal messages, the machines may already be in charge. How else, the man reasonably asks, can one explain the proliferation of microwave ovens - a superfluous, television-hawked appliance whose only logical use may be to fry the nation's households en masse when the computers stage their coup?
This is paranoia, of course, but like the paranoia in a Hitchcock movie, it's a little too close for comfort. And by inhabiting his characters instead of condescending to them, Mr. Bogosian doesn't allow anyone a safe distance from his less philosophical men, like the Mametesque entrepreneur who uses each of four phone lines (and an intercom) to betray a different business associate or loved one, or the self-made exponent of ''the good life'' showing off his new Olympic-size swimming pool with a pride inextricably bound to a fear of death, or the violent criminal who admiringly likens George Bush to Batman.
Mr. Bogosian's unflaggingly intense impersonations, directed by Jo Bonney on a simple but evocative set designed by John Arnone, are flawless; he doesn't need costume or makeup changes to give each character a distinct face, voice and posture. And as always, Mr. Bogosian is a hilarious wit: there is one line after another, not too many repeatable here, that you will quote to friends. He is also a born storyteller with perfect pitch for the voices of various ethnic, racial and economic backgrounds. A monologue in which an Italian-American hoodlum describes ''the best night I ever had in my life'' - a pornographic tale of urban mayhem in which he and his drugged pals lay waste to a McDonald's as well as to themselves - is too riveting to dismiss as revolting.
Yet Mr. Bogosian isn't a documentarian, an X-rated Studs Terkel running a tape recorder. And he isn't a public scold of either the left or right, setting political agendas. His sketches don't end with neat moral codas but trail off, like distant radio stations vanishing into the night on a dark highway. The highly original writing in ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll'' is realer than journalism - and more frightening - and its depth helps boost Mr. Bogosian to a new plateau.
This show is much more of a piece than ''Talk Radio,'' his one attempt to collaborate with other actors in a more conventional play. Though the characters don't share scenes, they do share a coherently depicted (if incoherent) civilization (if that's the word for it) where homelessness, guilt and an addictive desire to feel ''wonderful'' (a state attained with drugs, power, money or sex) are ubiquitous. The characters we don't see - the abused secretary, the obsequious talk-show host, the tense subway passengers - are often as vivid as the men who do parade across the stage.
The canvas is far broader than the title and quirky cast of characters suggest. Leaving the show, one is struck not so much by the uncanny resemblance between the real-life beggars outside the theater and the fictional ones of Mr. Bogosian's impersonations as by the way ''Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll'' as a whole forces the audience to examine its own roles in the larger drama that, however unwillingly, it shares daily with the dispossessed.
The last of Mr. Bogosian's characters argues that the homeless are threatening not just because they evoke suffering and guilt but also because they represent revolt and freedom. They are the people who have been ''thrown out of their cages,'' he says, because they refused to do ''what they're supposed to do.'' At this remarkable historical moment, people all over the world are being thrown out of their cages, and among American writers for the theater, Mr. Bogosian is the first to see his own society as part of the big picture. Using every powerful means available to a theater artist, he shakes the cages of a complacent country engulfed by homelessness to ask just exactly who, if anyone, is at home.
 
IS THAT ALL THERE IS? - SEX, DRUGS, ROCK & ROLL, written and performed by Eric Bogosian; directed by Jo Bonney; set design by John Arnone; lighting by Jan Kroeze; sound by Jan Nebozenko; production stage manager, Pat Sosnow; produced in association with Ethel Bayer and William Suter. Presented by Frederick Zollo and Robert Cole, in association with 126 Second Avenue Corporation and Sine/D'Addario Ltd. At the Orpheum Theater, 126 Second Avenue, at Eighth Street.

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES

BYLINE: By Lawrence Van Gelder

 BODY:

A Lesson in Love
''I tell you that Turgenev has written this book as a kind of warning to young people,'' Jerzy Skolimowski was saying.
The Polish-born film maker was explaining how he had become gripped years ago by the Russian author's novel ''Torrents of Spring'' and had, at last, been able to turn it into his latest film, opening today.
''I read it a very long time ago, when I was in school in Poland,'' said Mr. Skolimowski, who has been living for the last five years in Santa Monica, Calif. ''And that was a time when we had Stalinism blooming, in the early 50's; and our contact with real literature was limited. And what we had to read were Social Realism books of that period. Very few classics were allowed. Among them, fortunately, was Turgenev, whose works I read early and liked very much.'' 
''Not only this,'' Mr. Skolimowski said of ''Torrents of Spring,'' ''but 'Fathers and Sons.' Those were my favorite books at the time.''
After many years, Mr. Skolimowski happened to mention his interest to Jeremy Thomas, the producer of the Academy Award-winning ''Last Emperor,'' among other films, while the two were working on Mr. Skolimowski's memorable 1979 film, ''The Shout.''
About a year ago, Mr. Thomas heard that the Italian producer Angelo Rizzoli was planning a film of ''Torrents of Spring,'' and mentioned Mr. Skolimowski's interest. And that was how Mr. Skolimowski eventually found himself on location in Venice, Rome and Prague (the latter standing in for the central Germany of 150 years ago), with a cast led by Timothy Hutton, Valeria Golino (who played Tom Cruise's girlfriend in ''Rain Man'') and Nastassja Kinski.
Mr. Hutton portrays a young Russian aristocrat, who, during a brief stopover in a quiet German town during a journey home, falls in love with a pastry-shop owner's daughter, played by Miss Golino. But within a short time of declaring his love, he finds himself enraptured and seduced by the wanton Russian woman played by Miss Kinski, with devastating consequences.
''This,'' Mr. Skolimowski said, ''is the story of the very first love of a young man who kind of jumps into it, like an empty pool, and only 48 hours later realizes that there are other women and that he can easily be attracted to them as well.''
Mr. Skolimowski says he sees ''Torrents'' as a cautionary tale, adding, ''Be careful with the recognition of what love is and what it is not.''
In recent months, he has been a frequent visitor to Warsaw, applying his vote and prestige to the first open elections in 40 years and their rebuke to the Communist Government.
Mr. Skolimowski said it was difficult to predict what effect the liberalization sweeping Eastern Europe might have on Polish film making, ''because it's all in chaos.''
''But,'' he said, ''I believe there is a strong indication that people will have enough patience and good will to go through the difficult times. Probably this year will be the most difficult to get through. But once the whole country gets into the new economy, I believe everything will start to be different and will be blooming.
''Poles are rather talented and dedicated people, and I believe once they taste freedom - not only political but the freedom of the economy -I believe it's going to work.''
Referring to film making, he said: ''What is clear is that there won't be any political contributions anymore. Several of the creators under the Communist regime were just paying tribute to the authorities, and some of the stuff they were making was really rubbish. So that will never happen again.
''On the other hand, the healthy competition between talented artists may create a kind of stimulation. There won't be so much sponsorship from the Government. Everyone will have to be dealing with his own economic problems.
''I believe film production will become more Western.''
Mr. Skolimowski said that when the time arrives for production of his next film, perhaps he will seek some Polish participation. ''I'm willing to take a chance,'' he said. ''That would be another patriotic act.''
 
Berlin Film Festival
Oliver Stone's ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' starring Tom Cruise as the paraplegic Vietnam veteran Ron Kovic, is to be screened on both sides of the Berlin wall during the Berlin Film Festival this month. The West German showing is scheduled for Feb. 17; the East German, the next day.
 
Costner, Revolutionary
Kevin Costner is to star for Orion Pictures in a film about the life of Michael Collins (1890-1922), the Irish revolutionary leader who led the battle for independence from British rule that resulted in the founding of the Irish Free State before he was assassinated by Sinn Fein irregulars. Filming is to begin in September.

A retrospective devoted to Merchant Ivory Productions is to begin next Friday at the Angelika Film Center and run through March 2. Between start and finish, 15 films are to be shown, beginning with ''Shakespeare Wallah'' and including ''Maurice,'' ''The Europeans,'' ''A Room With a View'' and ''The Bostonians.''

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Middle-Aged and Not Quite Middle Class

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
Stanley and Iris are not the sorts of characters one often meets in movies these days. They're not exactly high-profile types. There are no extraterrestrials in their lives, no vice cops and not much of anything that could pass for comedy of the thigh-slapping kind.
They may go to movies, but not with any regularity. If they have the time, they probably prefer watching television. Neither one yet owns a VCR. 
Stanley and Iris are both over 40. They are members of the working class in a society in which many blue-collar workers, though not Stanley and Iris, earn as much as if not more than people who call themselves middle class.
Stanley is a cook in the canteen of the Nevins & Davis Bakery, where Iris is a cake icer on the assembly line. He's a loner who lives with his old father and putters around inventing things.
Iris, a recent widow with two children, shares her already cluttered house with her sister and unemployed brother-in-law. Her money is hard earned, which is why she is so outraged when her purse is snatched on the bus as she's riding home from work.
Stanley comes to the rescue, but too late. The thief makes off with her paycheck. When Iris calms down, she thanks Stanley. ''Lucky you were on the bus.''
''I don't usually take the bus,'' says Stanley with nutty cheerfulness. ''My bike was stolen.''
In this way Stanley (Robert De Niro) and Iris (Jane Fonda) meet, beginning an uncommon love story about a pair of keenly observed, seemingly commonplace people.
Stanley and Iris inhabit a world so seldom acknowledged by movie makers that in Martin Ritt's ''Stanley and Iris,'' it seems as arcane as fin de siecle Paris. In fact, it's end-of-the-20th-century New England factory town.
The movie is going to be a hard sell for most of today's audiences. That will be too bad, though probably understandable. There's no easy way to describe ''Stanley and Iris'' without making it sound too noble and worthy to be much fun. Here is a ''good work'' in which two of our most high-powered film stars more or less pare down their public personalities to fit into a world that most Americans never see, even those who live out their lives in it.
Yet ''Stanley and Iris'' does not condescend. It's as honest and direct and entertaining as the considerable talents of everyone involved can make it. Not the least of these talents are Harriet Frank Jr. and Irving Ravetch, the writers whose eight collaborations with Mr. Ritt began with ''The Long, Hot Summer'' and include ''Hud'' and ''Norma Rae.''
Like ''Norma Rae,'' as well as ''The Molly Maguires'' and ''The Front,'' also directed by Mr. Ritt, ''Stanley and Iris'' represents a kind of committed film making that has been generally out of favor for some years. At least in part, this has been because the commitment is so often a substitute for content as well as style.
Now, in this era of music-video movie making, Mr. Ritt stands almost alone as an unembarrassed social realist and a movie maker of conscience.
''Stanley and Iris'' is not as shapely and smoothly turned as the Oscar-winning ''Norma Rae,'' which managed to celebrate unionism at a time when union busting was becoming as fashionable as conspicuous consumption. The focus of ''Stanley and Iris'' is much shorter and its concerns, to most movie audiences, even more esoteric.
Stanley, played by Mr. De Niro with great good humor and damaged feeling, is illiterate. He has somehow been able to get through life, so far, without learning how to read and write.
When he was growing up, he traveled around the country with his salesman father, never quite settling in one place long enough to receive a basic education. When, finally, they did settle, Stanley felt he was too old to go through the humiliation of first grade.
Until he meets Iris, Stanley has accommodated his disadvantage by limiting his contacts with the world, living in self-imposed isolation. ''You ask yourself,'' he says at one point, '' 'Do I have a name if I can't write it?' '' He has developed the wiliness of a thief in his stratagems to avoid exposure. Not until the practical, tough-skinned, frankly sexual Iris comes along does he find the nerve to face the facts.
''Stanley and Iris'' demands a certain effort to suspend disbelief. One might have thought that he could have learned how to sign a reasonable facsimile of his name in all these years. Yet Iris's education of Stanley Cox is both moving and funny. As long as the film sticks to this affirmative action (in which, of course, the teacher is also taught by her pupil), the movie works beautifully.
Miss Fonda's increasingly rich resources as an actress are evident in abundance here. They even overcome one's awareness that just beneath Iris's frumpy clothes, there is a firm, perfectly molded body that has become a multi-million-dollar industry. Her Iris is believable without being a type, or a census statistic. She's a singular woman of guts, common sense and freely acknowledged passion. She's idealized, but within acceptable limits.
The members of the supporting cast are equally good, including Swoosie Kurtz, as Iris's sister, Martha Plimpton and Harley Cross, as her children, and, in particular, Feodor Chaliapin, as Stanley's father, a very old man, who, while awaiting death with impassive dignity, allows his son to cut his hair.
Warning: The movie ends badly with a sequence that is so false that it almost gives the lie to all that has preceded it. It's not unlike a facelift that leaves the patient wearing a permanently unconvincing grin.
''Stanley and Iris,'' which has been rated PG-13 (''Special Parental Guidance Suggested for Those Younger Than 13''), has some vulgar language and scenes of family discord that could upset very young children.
 
READING, WRITING AND ROMANCE - STANLEY AND IRIS, directed by Martin Ritt; screenplay by Harriet Frank Jr. and Irving Ravetch; director of photography, Donald McAlpine; edited by Sidney Levin; music by John Williams; production designer, Joel Schiller; produced by Arlene Sellers and Alex Winitsky; released by M-G-M. Running time: 105 minutes. This film is rated PG-13.

LENGTH: 1928 words

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Clothes From the Turn of a Different Century

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
Clothes may make the man or the woman, but they can also make history tantalizingly real, telling tales of the social, economic and political milieus that produced them. At the moment, two exhibitions that focus on French attire of the late 18th and early 19th centuries allow clothes to do just this, although by quite different routes.
At the Fashion Institute of Technology - and organized in collaboration with the Kyoto Costume Institute of Kyoto, Japan - there is the exhibition ''Ancien Regime (Revolution in Fashion),'' a tautly beautiful show that casts an unfrivolous modernist eye on the frivolities of late Rococo dress. Moving forward in time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has ''The Age of Napoleon: Costume From Revolution to Empire, 1789-1815,'' an exhibition that opts for the sensory overload of the mise en scene, surrounding clothes with furniture, art, jewelry, weapons and even the Emperor's campaign tent.
Despite their differences, these shows go together like hand and glove or, more exactly, like cause and effect. The event they hinge on is the French Revolution, whose upheaval, among many other things, dramatically affected both contemporary dress and the fortunes of France's luxury industries, especially the textile fabriques or factories of Lyons. 
''Ancien Regime'' concentrates on the sumptuous gowns and three-piece suits of the Bourbon court, garments often made of silks, silk satins and brocades produced on the looms of Lyons. These costumes are in excellent condition: their subtle colors seem unfaded, their embroideries and laces might be brand new. At the Fashion Institute, these costumes are isolated, deservedly, like rare objets d'art, displayed on plain mannequins in plain white galleries with very little in the way of explanatory wall texts.
Nonetheless, as with a visit to Versailles, these garments speak volumes about the roots of the revolution. They also evoke a world of strict dress codes, highly skilled artisans, ordeal by undergarment and surface refinement that is nearly beyond the comprehension of the modern mind - even the minds of the most incorrigible fashion victims or ''Dangerous Liaisons'' fanatics.
On the walls, enlargements of engravings from Diderot's Encyclopedia, which catalogued the arts and industries of France for the first time, diagram the patterns, tools and techniques that produced lace, shoes, gloves, fans, wigs and buttons - in short, the vast repertory of essential accessories. Vitrines display shoes and stomachers, and hair-powdering carrots of turned wood. One display brings to light the corsets, boned bodices and hooped rattan paniers that turned women into unnaturally curved and billowing sculptures.
Best of all, of course, are the clothes themselves, illuminated by succinctly detailed labels that have an unexpected poetry of their own. Reading such descriptive phrases as ''Lyons silk cannele flower brocade decorated with blond lace and wire chenille and floss silk flowers'' or ''Spitalfields silk brocade with classically inspired ruins, vegetation and trophies,'' or ''silk painted in China'' provides pleasures similar to the passive reading of cooking recipes. Except that here the feasts are complete and delectably present.
''The Age of Napoleon'' picks up where the Fashion Institute exhibition leaves off, showing how, in the wake of the revolution, clothing became a way for citizens to express political allegiances. Parisians immediately began to dress more modestly to distance themselves from the reviled aristocracy. The boxy red carmagnole jacket and sans-culottes worn by revolutionaries in the early years of the revolution are here, as well as tricolor stockings and, yes, guillotine earrings, unexpected bits of pre-industrial kitsch. But classical antiquity, a political ideal, soon became a fashion trend. Men wore capes that resembled the togas of Rome. The loose, high-waisted Empire gown, which freed the female body from corset and panier, was also intended to suggest the Greek or Roman goddesses.
In place of esthetic focus and sense of clothes-for-art's-sake, this exhibition has a panoramic sweep, built upon constantly changing groups of artifacts and myriad details. It moves from everyday clothes of the bourgeoisie to court dress to ecclesiastical garments to military uniforms, presenting a blur of visual and historical information that the show's excellent catalogue helps to slow down, but does not entirely dispel.
Visually, one of the Napoleon show's most engaging aspects is the swift and extensively represented evolution of the simple Empire gown, from a garment made of printed cotton to a diaphanous flow of thin white muslin popularized by the Empress Josephine, to its apotheosis in the silk court dresses with their heavy bejeweled and embroidered trains. Like much else in this exhibition, the gowns offer proof of how Napoleon brought French life full circle as he proceeded from First Consul to Consul for Life to Emperor, instituting a code for court dress as sumptuous as the one that the revolution had overturned, and putting the Lyons fabriques back in business.
''Ancien Regime (Revolution in Fashion)'' can be seen at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street, through Feb. 17. ''The Age of Napoleon: Costume From Revolution to Empire, 1789-1815'' remains at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through April 15.
 
Gerhard Richter: New Paintings
Marian Goodman Gallery
24 West 57th Street
Sperone Westwater
142 Greene Street
Both shows through Feb. 24
In his latest show of artistic strength, the West German Gerhard Richter continues to pit abstraction against representation, painting against photography, and pure physical paint against poetic emanation. More than ever, Mr. Richter is a brilliant tactician of the painted surface, a cool-handed mechanic whose work burns with a kind of heatless passion that is both seductive and off-putting. Like Jackson Pollock, he has evolved a no-hands, no-brush surface treatment, a method in which chance and consummate control seem to mingle effortlessly, forging an increasing visual density and power. Like the young Frank Stella, he taunts the viewer with the possibility that what you see is what you see, period.
In the past, Mr. Richter has specialized in a deep, illusionistic space and tilting diagonal brushstrokes, creating works that seemed to freeze-dry Abstract Expressionist flamboyance while also suggesting giant photographic details of a silent underwater world. Now the artist is sticking more and more to the flat of the canvas and favoring fewer colors, most prominently black and white, over the brighter, fuller spectrum of previous years.
But many of his characteristic dualities remain in place. Three small realist images - one at Goodman and two at Sperone - are on hand, signaling Mr. Richter's larger conceptual program, specifically his refusal to choose between styles. Without the realist asides, some of the smaller abstract paintings in both shows might simply look like the best lyrical abstraction ever made.
Still, the obsession with pure paint has its undeniable fascinations. The flat horizontal and vertical pulls of paint that dominate these luminous works, usually applied with big sheets of plastic, show the skin of paint stretched literally to the breaking point. And break it does, creating surfaces riddled with little gaps and fissures and enticing glimpses of earlier layers and other colors.
As usual, the effect is at once synthetic and surprisingly naturalistic. The blurred light and implied speed of these surfaces can suggest giant pieces of film passing before the eyes. Especially in two large works shown side by side at Sperone, this film seems to be burned around the edges. But these pocked, shimmering surfaces also suggest watery reflections, or surfaces of slowly melting ice - an association that presents itself even before one learns that several works are in fact titled ''Ice'' in German.
Some of the large paintings in these shows - especially a dark, looming trio of enormous double-canvas works at Goodman named after winter months - may be among the best paintings Mr. Richter has ever made. But it's hard to say. His paintings are always visually impressive, but they are also plagued by a certain sameness and a sense of nearly mass production.
At the same time, this kind of ambivalent response may be what the artist is after. Ultimately, he is a painter who refuses to commit himself absolutely to his medium, who pits the congested, eye-filling uniqueness of each canvas against its redundancy, just as he plays the continuation of painting against the possibility that painting is dead.
 
Lois Dodd
Fischbach Gallery
24 West 57th Street
Through Feb. 28
This small exhibition of small paintings by the realist Lois Dodd attests to a devotion to the nocturne that goes back some 15 years and that has served the artist well. Nighttime depiction of light, whether man-made or natural, is the constant here. Also constant is a dry, casually laid-on paint surface that conveys a distinct impression of images pinned down in a hurry, before the moon shifted behind a cloud, or the people in the house across the way turned off their living-room light. A patch of green lawn caught in lamplight, moonlight eking its way through leaves, the low-lying sparkle of a town on the horizon, the soft, slivery slope of a dirt road - these are among the best images of a good show.
 
'Shaker ''Gift'' Drawings From Hancock Shaker Village'
Hirschl & Adler Folk
851 Madison Avenue (near 70th Street)
Through Feb. 17
In this exhibition, all 24 ''gift'' drawings in the collection of the Hancock Shaker Village in Pittsfield, Mass., pay a rare visit to New York City. In most of them, schematic yet accurately detailed trees and gardens prevail, rendered in light watercolor tones and spreading across the paper in linear trellises. Made mostly by women as gifts to other Shakers, these drawings speak of heavenly visions while celebrating the beauty and order of nature. They also point out an unexpectedly decorative if consistently modest side to the famous Shaker austerity.
 
'Heads'
Coup de Grace Gallery
579 Broadway (near Prince Street)
Through tomorrow
This group show brings together the work of four relatively unknown artists whose primary image is the human face or head and whose primary desire seems to be a haunting, unsettling effect.
The faces in Mauro Altamura's photographs have a ghostly speed and immateriality, although their blurred grimaces rely too much on effects that Francis Bacon and Arnulf Rainer have already made familiar. Thomas Micchelli's small blue paintings of faces with bright red head wounds owe a similar debt to Leon Golub, although these works are not without impact.
Adam Simon's treatment of what might be called the ''have a good day'' face consists of two dots and a curved line on small monochrome canvases that are topped off with the phrase ''Missing.'' This image of empty-headedness is the show's one light note.
The exhibition's standouts are the small, eerie self-portraits of a photographer, John Brill, which present the artist's face and bald head in a range of scales and unfocused spaces, all vaguely aqueous, all of this world and not. In this manner, the artist minimizes his distinguishing characteristics, assuming the role of everyman while creating an atmosphere in which the pain and the comfort of self-knowledge seem equally present.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Lukewarm Ending for Auctions

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Investors gave the final portion of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions a tepid welcome yesterday, but even that was enough to push prices of notes and bonds higher.
At the auction, the Treasury sold $10 billion of 30-year bonds at an average yield of 8.50 percent, up from a yield of 7.87 percent at the last 30-year bond auction in November.
The size and range of the bids suggest that demand for the issue was not strong. A total of $18.4 billion worth of bids was received, about $2 billion less than had been bid at past auctions when the Treasury sold comparable amounts of bonds. 
 
Larger Bid Spread
The bids ranged from a low of 8.48 percent to a high of 8.53 percent. The difference between high and low bids at most Treasury auctions is seldom greater than one or two basis points, or hundredths of a point.
''By standard criteria, this was not a good auction,'' said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides analysis on the credit and foreign exchange markets. ''But the fact that the bond came with a coupon of 8.50 percent is the key. If the yield had been a basis point lower, the coupon would have been 8 3/8 percent, and the market's reaction would have been much different.''
Prices, which moved higher before bids on the bonds were placed at 1 P.M., sagged just after the results were released. But recognition that the bond carries an 8.50 percent coupon, coupled with reports that the Bank of Japan would not raise interest rates following important legislative elections on Feb. 18, encouraged dealers to buy securities.
Fears of higher rates in Japan, which might siphon funds from the United States credit markets, have been widespread.
 
Some Bright Spots
The refunding auction, the last of three held this week, provided some bright spots, particularly the healthy demand from individual investors.
Non-competitive bids, a good gauge of private demand, amounted to $955.9 million, nearly three times as large as at the November sale. In such a bid, the bidder offers to take the issue at whatever price and interest rate the average bid produces.
''We saw a lot of customer business,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Goverment Securities. ''They were buying everything, including the 10-year notes auctioned on Wednesday, as well as the bonds. In some sense the auction was a professional bid, but it was to replace paper that went away earlier.''
Reflecting the post-auction demand, the new bonds were offered late yesterday on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.44 percent.
 
Healthy Japanese Buying
As expected, Japanese firms made healthy but not huge bids for the bonds. Market analysts estimated that the big four Japanese firms -Daiwa, Nikko, Nomura and Yamaichi - placed $3 billion worth of bids. Few of the bids were placed for clients in Japan, said analysts, who said the firms were seeking the bonds for their own trading accounts.
After the auction, prices of secondary Treasury issues pulled back, then moved higher. By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 96 1/8, up more than half a point on the day, to yield 8.48 percent.
Prices of the issues auctioned earlier this week by the Treasury also moved higher. In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes sold Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.42 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent three-year notes auctioned Tuesday were offered at a price to yield 8.32 percent in when-issued trading.
Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.79 percent late yesterday, up a basis point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.72 percent.
 
A Shift in Focus
With the refunding auctions behind them, market participants are likely to shift their focus back to developments in the economy.
The return to more fundamental concerns will begin today, when the Government is expected to release its Producer Price Index for January.
The data, a measure of inflation, are expected to show that prices increased significantly in the month, almost entirely because of weather-related increases in food and energy prices.
Most analysts anticipate that the overall Producer Price Index rose by 1.2 percent last month. However, excluding food and energy, economists are forecasting that the index rose by a much more modest two-tenths of 1 percent.
''The producer price numbers are already reflected in the credit markets,'' said James Fralick, a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''But if the market were to see the producer price numbers, excluding food and energy, go up by four-tenths of a percentage point or more, it would not behave very well.''
 
Help for Secondary Markets
The rise in Treasury prices helped the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds.
Corporate traders said prices of most issues rose by about one-quarter of a point. Prices of actively traded municipal bonds improved three-eighths to half a point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Jan. 29. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC WATCH;
Monetary Union: Would It Help?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
For East and West Germany, monetary union would be a leap into the unknown, say Western economists who were caught off guard by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's call to begin negotiations on monetary integration as early as next week. The cushion on landing would depend on the terms of the union, the adaptability of East German enterprises and the confidence of West German investors.
What does seem clear - and what apparently set off the rush to judgment - is that the East German economy is doomed to decline without monetary union.
Last month alone 58,000 East Germans crossed the border in search of a better life, hobbling East German production and straining West Germany's welfare services. Since Bonn is already bearing much of the burden of East Germany's collapse by accepting unlimited immigration, analysts argue, the added risk of assuming effective control of an integrated German economy is modest. Indeed, economic theory suggests that the marriage would be smooth and prosperous. 
 
Keeping the Shelves Stocked
Monetary union - the adoption of a common currency - is generally seen as the last stage of political and economic integration. But in the case of Germany, events seem to be forcing policy makers to put the economic cart before the political horse. East Germany, long the most prosperous of the centrally planned Eastern European economies, is reeling from the collapse of central authority and the flight of young workers.
''The question now,'' says Jan Vanous of the PlanEcon consulting firm in Washington, ''is whether East Germany can maintain enough stability to keep groceries on the shelves.''
And in the view of many West German officials, the only way to avert chaos - and subsequent mass migration westward - is to commit the two Germanys now to speedy economic unification.
Just how this union might be put together is fuzzy; there are no precedents for comparison. But Western economists, like Jeffrey Sachs at Harvard, believe the practical choices are limited.
East German individuals, enterprises and banks would trade their domestic currency and bank account balances to the West German Bundesbank for West German marks at an exchange rate fixed in advance. Restrictions on movements of capital across the border would be eliminated, making it possible for East Germans to bank freely in the West and for West Germans to invest freely in the East. All financial transactions would be denominated in West German marks.
''The catch to monetary union,'' Mr. Vanous says, ''is that you lose control over macromanagement.''
East Germany, the weaker partner, would effectively lose its economic sovereignty, retaining roughly the same authority over its economic destiny as, say, the state of Illinois.
The East German central bank would have to cede its power to issue currency or create bank balances to pay its bills; otherwise, the West German Bundesbank would be unable to control the total supply of money. And the East German Government would have to eliminate the subsidies that now hold the prices of consumer staples far below production cost. Otherwise, Mr. Sachs points out, ''all the food would disappear to the West.''
But there would be an immediate payoff. A formal commitment to economic integration would slow the brain drain from East Germany, and relieve the pressure on West Germany's housing and welfare budgets. And with money freely convertible into other currencies, foreigners could be confident that they could repatriate business profits. That, presumably, would attract desperately needed capital and technology from West Germany and the rest of the industrialized West.
A key to smooth transition, notes the Columbia University economist Jagdash Bhagwati, is the choice of the right exchange rate. If the East German currency is overvalued - if East German wages are set high when first translated into West German marks - East German goods will not be competitive. And while wages and prices would presumably adjust fairly quickly to more realistic levels, the initial effect would be more unemployment in East Germany and more emigration.
On the other hand, Mr. Vanous points out, if the exchange rate of East German currency is set very low - say, 5 East German marks or more for each West German mark -families will see their savings disappear. He estimates that East Germans hold roughly 180 billion East German marks in currency and bank accounts. Thus the choice of, say, a 4-to-1 exchange rate rather than a 3-to-1 exchange rate would cost East Germans about 15 billion West German marks, or about $9 billion - no small change for a nation of 16 million people living in what amounts to shabby gentility.
 
Luring Investors
The best approach, Mr. Vanous believes, would be to err on the side of undervaluation, initially making it immensely attractive for outsiders to invest in East Germany. East Germans with savings might be compensated with stock in public enterprises that the Government sells - or simply by the prospect of a freer, more prosperous life in a newly integrated German economy.
But according to the theory of ''optimal currency areas,'' pioneered by the Columbia University economist Robert Mundell in the 1960's, the long-term success of currency integration turns on more fundamental issues. Over time, differences in dozens of factors ranging from education to the environment to government regulation make some areas more attractive to business and some less attractive. If these economic regions are in different countries, changes in the currency exchange rate can compensate for changes in the competitiveness of business in each country. But in regions with the single currency, capital and labor must move from place to place in order to offset the changes and prevent the less competitive regions from becoming chronically depressed.
What will matter most 10 or 20 years from now, Mr. Sachs argues, is whether Germans have the right and inclination to move themselves and their capital to the regions of Germany that value them most. And by that measure, Mr. Sachs says, Germany with its one language and relatively uniform urban culture is far closer to an ''optimal currency area'' than, say, the United States or the Soviet Union.
Plainly, there are risks to monetary union. For East Germany, there is the risk it will cede control of its economy without sufficient return in jobs or income. For West Germany there is the risk that it will be forced to bear the costs of supporting a backward regional economy through a long and painful transition.
But as Mr. Bhagwati points out, ''there is no longer a negative side to economic integration.'' Even without monetary union, West Germany's open-border policy guarantees that it will bear much of the cost of East Germany's failure. With union, there is at least a reasonable chance that the flow of refugees will stop and that both parts of Germany will prosper.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Grew 6% in 1989

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Americans took out $4.91 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in December, pushing total consumer debt up 6 percent in 1989, the Federal Reserve said today.
The Fed said consumer credit in December advanced at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.3 percent, up from November's revised 7.8 percent increase. The November gain had initially been reported at 7.2 percent. 
But in both months, consumer debt rose to its highest level since February 1989, when it increased $5.38 billion. Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages.
 
Spending Is 'Not Collapsing'
While credit was up 6 percent for the year, it still was a modest increase, said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group in Washington. Debt rose 8.5 percent in 1988, and it increased 7.5 percent in 1987.
''It shows that consumer spending continues to grow modestly,'' she said. ''It's not collapsing,'' despite the sluggish economy.
The category of debt that includes credit cards jumped 24.5 percent in the month, which includes the bulk of holiday shopping. The increase was 17.5 percent in November.
Total credit card debt outstanding rose $4.06 billion at an annual rate in December, compared with a $2.86 billion increase in November.
Ms. Shaber said that while unit sales were good during the holiday season, profits for many retailers were off because of discounting.
Auto loans rose 1.1 percent, to $259 million at an annual rate, down from 1.9 percent in November. Auto loans posted a 4.1 percent increase in October, but sales tapered off at the end of the year.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate slowed to a 3.3 percent increase, to $557 million, in December, after rising 10 percent in November.
Mobile home debt outstanding rose 1.9 percent, to $35 million, in December. These debts had declined for seven consecutive months until a one-month gain in September.
The various changes left consumer debt at the end of December totaling $717.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Ford Settles A Mexican Walkout

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it had resolved some of its labor problems in Mexico by reaching a tentative contract agreement with workers at an engine plant in Chihuahua.
Separately, Ford said it was continuing to send termination notices to about 2,400 Mexican workers at its assembly plant in Cuautitlan, near Mexico City. And the No. 2 American auto maker said it was in negotiations with workers at its Hermosillo plant, where the labor contract expires on Feb. 28. 
A Ford spokesman, Al Chambers, said that the situations at the three plants were not related and that the company was confident that it could reach contract agreements.
 
Important Subcompacts
Ford's biggest worry may be the Hermosillo plant, where it is preparing to begin production in April of a redesigned line of subcompact cars, the Mercury Tracer and Ford Escort. The Tracer and Escort, which were developed with the Mazda Motor Corporation, are an important element of Ford's strategy for the 1990's.
Ford needs the highly fuel-efficient models to raise its overall corporate average fuel economy and meet higher Federal standards for 1990 models. Moreover, since the Tracer and Escort are new models, any interuption of production could have a devastating effect on their important introductory phase, when the company spends a great deal on promotion.
Still, Mr. Chambers said, ''we are quietly confident'' of reaching a successful conclusion to contract talks in Hermosillo.
Mr. Chambers declined to disclose the pay of Ford workers in Mexico.
In Cuautitlan, Mr. Chambers said, the company had begun to hire workers to replace those who were dismissed. Under Mexican law, any worker with more than three unexcused absences in a month can be legally discharged.
About two-thirds of the 3,700-member work force occupied the Cuautitlan plant last month after an intra-union dispute resulted in a shooting in which seven workers were injured and one killed. Mexican police peacefully removed the occupying workers on Jan. 22, Ford said, and many of those who had been in the plant did not return to work after that.
The Cuautitlan plant assembles six Ford car and truck models for the Mexican market.
Much of the labor unrest in Mexico stems from rapid inflation, Mr. Chambers said, adding that the value of the peso has dropped from about four pesos to the United States dollar in 1981 to about 2,700 currently.
The tentative labor agreement in Chihuahua resulted in a 27 percent increase in wages and benefits. In the last week of January, workers left their jobs because there was no contract, the spokesman said. The plant produces engines for Ford Tempo, which is sold in the United States and Mexico, and the Topaz, which is sold in Mexico.

HEADLINE: New York Times Company Reports 4th-Quarter Loss

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
The New York Times Company yesterday reported a loss of $19 million in the fourth quarter, compared with net income of $50.4 million, or 64 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988.
Revenues in the quarter rose 4.5 percent, to $470.2 million, from $450 million a year earlier.
For all of 1989, net income rose 29.2 percent, to a record $266.6 million, or $3.39 a share, compared with $167.7 million, or $2.08 a share, in 1988. The earnings included an after-tax gain of $193.3 million, or $2.46 a share, from the sale of the company's cable television system in August. 
Revenues rose 4.1 percent, to $1.77 billion from $1.7 billion.
The company's continuing operations, which include newspapers, magazines, broadcasting and information services and forest products, produced a loss of $19 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a profit of $48.5 million a year earlier. For the year, income from these operations declined 57.6 percent, to $68.2 million, or 87 cents a share, from $161 million, or $2 a share, in 1988.
 
In Line With Expectations
That was in line with estimates by the company and industry analysts. Times stock closed yesterday at $24.375, unchanged, in trading on the American Stock Exchange.
The company said the decline in its operations for the quarter and the year was primarily attributable to the weakness of the New York region's economy, which affected advertising linage at The New York Times.
The company said income from continuing operations was also reduced by three factors:
* A charge of 57 cents a share in the fourth quarter that reflected the reduced value of the company's investment in the Forest Products Group, as well as for some costs associated with voluntary staff reductions at The New York Times.
* A reduction of 11 cents a share in the fourth quarter and 18 cents a share for the year resulting from organizatonal changes after the acquisitions of McCall's, Golf World (U.S.) and Sailing World magazines.
* A charge of 3 cents a share in the fourth quarter resulting from a settlement of litigation involving home delivery dealers.
Were it not for those factors, the company said, earnings from continuing operations would have been 47 cents a share in the fourth quarter and $1.65 a share for 1989.
John Reidy, a media analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said: ''The earnings were in line with expectations. They promised us some write-offs in December. Like other papers in the Northeast, retail advertising remains in a slump, and now the help-wanted area of the classified part of the business is in trouble.''
 
Chairman's Outlook
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman and chief executive, said earnings from continuing operations in 1990 were expected to exceed the 87 cents a share reported for 1989.
At the newspaper group, which includes The New York Times, 35 smaller newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune, operating profit in the fourth quarter fell 63 percent, to $25.1 million, from $68.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenues rose 2.2 percent, to $375.2 million, from $367.3 million.
For the year, operating profit for the newspaper group fell 21 percent, to $182.9 million, from $231.5 million in 1988, as revenues rose 1.4 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.38 billion.

HEADLINE: Bearish Mood Is Overtaking Stock Investors, Study Says

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
Investor sentiment has reached its most pessimistic level since June 1982, just before the start of the 1980's bull market, according to a weekly study that is closely watched by Wall Street.
This bleak outlook reflects a sharp reversal from the mood reported in mid-December, when the majority of professional investors were optimistic about stock prices.
The shift in investor mood came about because of the sudden, unexpected increase in interest rates in the United States and abroad, analysts said. ''The expectations were very high for lower interest rates,'' said Michael H. Sherman, chief investment strategist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. 
 
More Bad News Expected
In addition to the rise in rates, investors have been nervously waiting for more bad news, said Michael Burke, editor of Investors Intelligence, a New Rochelle, N.Y., advisory service that publishes the weekly survey of investor sentiment as culled from investment newsletters.
Mr. Burke's latest report, which covers the period ended last Friday, found that only 29.9 percent of the almost 130 investment newsletters it studied were bullish on the stock market, while 57.3 percent of them were bearish. By contrast, in December, 57 percent of the advisers were bullish about the market.
Such current widespread pessimism could explain the stock market rise of more than 38 points in the last two days, professional investors say. In the perverse ways of Wall Street, overwhelming bearishness is often viewed as good news, just as widespread optimism often accompanies market peaks.
This is true because when market prices are depressed and the mood is negative, often bargain hunters step in and push prices higher. On the other hand when prices are high some investors believe there are few buyers around and subsequently prices begin to fall.
Indeed, many money managers use the sentiment figures as a contrarian indicator for stock prices. And when the number of bullish advisers drops to its current level they say that stock prices generally bounce upward.
''When you get under 30 percent for the bullish side, you probably have a rally coming,'' said David N. Dreman, founder of Dreman Value Management, a New York money management firm.
 
Lack of Conviction
The extreme shift in the sentiment numbers over such a short period of time indicates a lack of conviction by investors, said Byron R. Wien, investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, who recently wrote a report entitled ''The Last Remaining Bull Speaks Out.''
Despite the abrupt change in sentiment, many money managers do not expect stock prices, which have fallen about 6 percent since the beginning of the year, to stage a broad rebound.
The increase in interest rates has made returns from fixed-income securities competitive with those available from stocks. Profits of many companies are expected to weaken this year. And with the weakness in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market, investors are re-evaluating the prices of securities in an environment that has fewer takeover battles.
In fact, many professionals believe that market averages like the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 could fall even lower this year.
 
'This Is a Sucker Rally'
As a result, some large institutional money managers are not yet spending their cash in the stock market. ''We think this is a sucker rally,'' said Timothy G. Dalton, president of Dillon, Read Capital Management.
Many money managers have also been despondent because most stocks are performing more poorly than the popular market averages. The performance of the large, blue-chip companies that make up the Dow has overshadowed weakness in the broader market since last August. ''The averages are not indicative of what's going on,'' said Harvey P. Eisen, president of Sun America Asset Management, the investment subsidiary of Broad Inc. ''It's been real, real hard to have stocks that go up.''

HEADLINE: Stock Prices End Mixed; Dow Up 4.28

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks turned in a narrowly mixed performance yesterday after a seesaw session in which the Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.28 points, to 2,644.37.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines, 768 to 696. Volume on the Big Board contracted to 176.2 million shares, from 186.7 million on Wednesday. 
Although the Dow finished slightly ahead, broader indicators faltered. The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.22 point, to 184.09, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged 0.79 point lower, to 332.9.
In early trading, the Dow had climbed 25 points, buoyed by investors' perceptions that the Treasury refunding auction, in which it was offering $10 billion of 30-year bonds, was going well.
But toward the end of the session, reports circulated that Japanese participation in the final day of the auction was not what had been expected. Traders said this talk precipitated a broad retreat that pushed the Dow to about a 7-point deficit.
 
Sign of Good Demand
By late in the day, however, the 30-year bond had an average yield of 8.45 percent, compared with a yield of 8.50 percent at the time of the auction. That reflected good investor demand and led to a late recovery for stocks. The 10-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were trading at a price yesterday to yield 8.42 percent.
''The concern that higher foreign interest rates would siphon money from the Treasury refunding abated,'' said Bernard Spilko, senior vice president of the Zurich-based Bank Julius Baer. ''Investors will now focus on the potential for softer economic data reports that may result in lower interest rates later this year.''
This morning, the Government will release the Producer Price Index for January, which is expected to show a sharp rise because of weather-related factors.
Among individual issues yesterday, Varity Corporation, a Toronto-based farm machinery and auto parts maker, was the most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange, dipping 1/8, to 3 1/4, on a volume of 2.4 million shares. The company said it knew of no developments to account for the activity.
Bank of New England dipped 5/8, to 5 1/4. It said that it had entered into a revised agreement to sell its leasing operations and $500 million of its lease portfolio to the Bank of Tokyo for a premium of $92.5 million.
 
Drop for Rykoff-Sexton
Rykoff-Sexton plunged 5 points, to 16 7/8. The distributor to the food service industry said it expected earnings for its third fiscal quarter ended Jan. 27 to be less than the 5 cents a share it had predicted. In the three months a year earlier, the company earned 38 cents a share.
Glamour issues that had an active day included A.T.& T., up 3/8, to 40 1/4, and Philip Morris, up 3/8, to 39 3/8.
Technology stocks were mixed after helping lift the market on Wednesday. I.B.M. slipped 3/8, to 102 3/4, in active trading, and Compaq Computer dropped 1, to 85 1/8. On the other hand, Motorola edged up 1/4, to 58 7/8, and Digital Equipment added 5/8, to 79 3/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.33 points, to 357.68, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index tacked on 0.53, to 427.32.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Some Gains As Rally in Mark Falters

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday as the soaring West German mark lost ground because of profit taking and concerns about the effects of a possible monetary union between the two German states.
Ronald H. Holzer, chief currency dealer for the Harris Trust Company in Chicago, said the dollar remained under the sway of the mark in foreign exchange because recent political changes in East Germany and the Soviet Union were expected to benefit the West German economy.
But profit taking and concerns about the implications of a proposal by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to unify the two German monetary systems pushed the mark lower yesterday, dealers said. That, in turn, helped support the dollar, they said. 
Fear that taking over East Germany's nearly bankrupt system would endanger the West German economy also helped drive down prices of West German bonds yesterday for the third straight day.
The dollar traded at 1.6665 marks in New York, up from 1.6580 Wednesday, and at 1.68872 marks in Europe, up from 1.6545.
In New York, the dollar fell to 145.32 yen in New York, from 145.60 late Wednesday.
The dollar was stronger against the British pound. Sterling cost $1.69435 in New York, down from $1.6960.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.4890 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6660 French francs, up from 5.6420; 1,240.25 Italian lire, up from 1,236.50, and 1.19465 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19455.
Gold prices rose slightly after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed at $418.60 an ounce, up 50 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold of $418.70, up 60 cents.
Gold fell in London to $417.75, from $423, and in Zurich, to $417.75, from $422.25.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $418.15, down from $419.65.
Silver prices were mixed. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $5.324 an ounce, up from $5.311. Silver fell in London to $5.32, from $5.38.
