HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Soviet Consumers Face Cutback In Meat as Feed Grain Runs Out

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Dispirited Soviet consumers face a cutback in meat production because the country has run out of grain to feed its cattle, the Government's chief food official says in remarks published today.
The prospect of reduced meat supplies threatens to add pressure on a Communist Party already weakened by internal dissent and public discontent.
Vladilen V. Nikitin, chairman of the State Commission for Food and Procurement, told the Communist Party Central Committee on Wednesday that the state had reduced feed allocations to all republics because grain deliveries had sharply fallen and the country could not afford to buy more abroad.
 
'There Is No Grain'
''This is the situation today: there is no grain,'' he said, according to a transcript printed today in Pravda. ''To act properly, I am left with only one decision: to cut deliveries of a certain amount of meat. There is no grain because there is no money.'' 
Other speakers at the party meeting said meat-producing regions were refusing to deliver their products to the central Government for distribution, hoarding meat instead to prevent local consumer revolts.
Yegor K. Ligachev, the Politburo member answerable for agriculture, disclosed that many industrial centers were suffering ''serious difficulties'' with meat supplies because producers had defied delivery orders.
 
A Blow to Gorbachev
Shortages of food and other consumer goods have been a major source of pessimism about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic program, and have fueled recent uprisings against local party leaders in several cities across Russia and the Ukraine.
The day that Mr. Nikitin delivered his report to the party, residents of the coal-mining city of Donetsk massed in the streets to demand removal of the entire local party leadership after local television reporters discovered a warehouse storing scarce imported food.
Over the last six weeks, party officials in Volgograd, Vladivostok, Sverdlovsk, Tyumen, Ufa and other province centers have resigned at the demand of crowds angered by official privileges and consumer shortages.
To some extent the protests play into the hands of President Gorbachev, because they have led to the replacement of old-guard Communist officials with putative party reformers. But journalists in some of those cities said the protests sometimes included blanket condemnations of the Communist Party.
On Saturday an alliance of Communist Party insurgents, hoping to exploit popular unrest in support of more far-reaching political and economic changes, has scheduled a meeting to discuss breaking away from the party. While much of the world was enraptured by the Central Committee's decision this week to end the party's monopoly on power and to open the way for multiparty politics, critics said the moves did not go far enough in loosening the Communist grip.
Next week a broader group, including opposition members of the Soviet Parliament, leaders of coal mine strikes last summer and independent voters groups, has scheduled a meeting to demand a round-table dialogue with Communist Party leaders similar to the discussions that brought opposition figures into the governments of Eastern Europe.
Many Communist insurgents say a split of the Communist Party into two parts, one with an orientation comparable to European social democrats, was the most likely route to establishment of real political competition here.
The disclosures about the worsening meat situation came after party leaders from the Ukraine, the country's breadbasket, complained that their feed allotments for 1990 had been slashed by one fourth.
 
Meat Rationed in Some Places
Meat is already rationed in some parts of the country, and the availability of inexpensive meat is one of the Soviet Union's most sensitive economic indicators.
Although the country reported a good grain harvest of 211 million tons last year, the state procurements dropped to 59 million tons, the lowest since 1984 and a third below what was planned.
Deliveries of this grain, which Moscow distributes to the republics, was apparently hampered by fuel shortages and transportation problems, as well as by hoarding in localities.
The current shortage apparently also reflects a reluctance to spend scarce foreign currency on increased purchases of Western corn and feed grains, which are crucial to the Soviet livestock industry.
The country imported 36 million tons of grain last year, but has recently had trouble meeting its foreign payments.
 
Pig and Poultry Farms Hit
Vitaly A. Masol, the Prime Minister of the Ukraine, said the 25 percent cut in concentrated feed would hit hard at the republic's pig and poultry farms, which depend on state supplies.
''Tomorrow the country will be without eggs, because these are state enterprises, and without meat,'' he said.
''And we are approaching a congress,'' he added, suggesting that food shortages would stir public unrest going into the nationwide Communist Party congress this summer.
Vladimir A. Ivashko, the Ukrainian party leader, added that the economy as a whole had continued in a sharp decline.
''As far as I know, throughout the country in January there was no growth at all, but a big minus,'' he said, evidently referring to figures for industrial production.
Jan J. Vagris, the party leader in the Baltic republic of Latvia, said his republic's allotment had been slashed 40 percent, which he suggested was a deliberate warning in the face of Latvia's moves toward independence.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Can Be a Fate Worse Than Liquidation;
Rehabilitation the Goal

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Bankruptcy Is Better in America'' (Business Day, Jan. 23) is a welcome addition to news media treatment of this important subject. I believe the public has been ill served by the tone of articles that state or at least suggest that financially distressed companies are in that condition because of mismanagement or worse and that those that seek the protection of the Bankruptcy Code too often improperly avoid or delay the payment of creditors' claims.
A recent article in a Bridgeport, Conn., newspaper, professing concern for employees and creditors, argued that a corporation should not be permitted to avail itself of the ''so-called reorganizaton procedures'' under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, unless there was an emergency, and in the absence of such, the bankruptcy should ''be recognized as a fraud.'' To protect against such abuse, it was suggested that ''Bankruptcy judges could demand that managements filing under Chapter 11 immediately show what the emergency is that justifies automatic stays of all their obligations. Unless such evidence comes with the filing or within days thereafter, the stay could be tossed out by the court.'' 
Of course, that prescription would more likely kill than protect the perceived victims of the assumed fraud.
As you point out, it is a principal goal of bankruptcy law to promote the rehabilitation of economically distressed companies. If a company had to wait until its financial condition was in a state of emergency, it is not likely that it would be able to borrow necessary funds to save itself and the jobs of its employees.
As you note, banks and other lenders are given a priority under the Bankruptcy Code to encourage them to inject new capital into the distressed company. They lend to the extent that they have confidence that rehabilitation has a reasonable prospect for success and believe that they will do better than if the company is forced to liquidate. To provide a statutory basis for lender confidence, the Bankruptcy Code requires adequate protection of secured creditors' interests.
At least initially, the law permits management to remain in control, so that during an exclusive period, which may be shortened or extended, a plan may be proposed for the payment of creditors' claims. As a counterbalance, the code also provides for the appointment of a trustee, conversion to Chapter 7 for liquidation or dismissal, if any of those changes are shown to be in the best interest of creditors and the bankruptcy estate.
Since a successful rehabilitation will often save jobs, preserve the company as a provider of goods and services and continue it on the tax rolls, an early push for liquidation is in most cases, but not all, inappropriate. It is to be hoped that your article will generate a higher level of understanding, especially in a time when record numbers of bankruptcy filings are predicted.
 
ALAN H. W. SHIFF
United States Bankruptcy Judge
District of Connecticut
 Bridgeport, Conn., Jan. 24, 1990

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 Daniel P. Kearney resigned as president and chief executive of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the savings and loan bailout, in what was seen as another sign that the $159 billion program to clean up the thrift industry is faltering. In departing, he said he had not been given sufficient authority to carry out his duties effectively. [Page 33.] Producer prices soared 1.8 percent in January, the biggest rise in more than 15 years, the Labor Department reported. But while the increase was markedly more than most analysts anticipated, economists were quick to point out that when energy and food are excluded, the index for finished goods edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the best performance since July. [33.] Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their December meeting on a further easing of their high-interest-rate policies. [37.] 
 
 
 
Companies
 Young & Rubicam pleaded guilty and agreed to pay $500,000 to settle the charge that it had engaged in a conspiracy to bribe foreign officials to obtain and hold the Jamaican Government's tourism account. Other charges against Y.&R. under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act were dropped. Charges of racketeering and bribery were also dropped against one present and one former executive of the advertising agency. [33.] Marine Midland Banks announced a loss of $119.9 million in the fourth quarter, because of problems with commercial real estate loans in the U.S. The loss reduced the bank's total profit for 1989 to $13.9 million, down from $160.5 million in 1988. [36.] Disney said it would no longer allow commercials for products or services to be shown at theaters in this country, with its Touchstone, Hollywood Pictures and Disney releases. It is not yet clear whether other studios will follow Disney's lead. [33.] RJR Nabisco postponed a $1.25 billion ''junk bond'' offering. Rumors about the postponement, which was not announced but was confirmed late in the trading day, filtered through the market, adding to already-heavy selling pressure. [33.] Toyota introduced a mini-van that features some unusual solutions to problems of improving stability and cargo space. [35.] Bond Corporation Holdings failed to persuade a court to free its Australian breweries from receivership. [35.] G.M.'s experimental electric car has attracted great interest, the company said. Recommendations are expected within three months from a team studying the feasibility of producing it. [35.] The College Football Association agreed to smaller television contracts with ABC and ESPN that reflected the University of Notre Dame's decision to drop out of the agreements. [36.]
 
 
 
Markets
 The Dow Jones industrial average edged up by 3.83 points, to 2,648.20, with advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange leading declining ones by 826 to 667. For the week, the Dow gained 45.50 points, or 1.7 percent. [41.] Treasury securities prices soared as investors, encouraged by the report on producer prices, rushed to lock in yields. [41.] Coffee futures prices rose to five-month highs on concern over a possible squeeze on supplies. [42.] The dollar was mixed in light trading while the mark eased a bit and gold fell. [42.]

 Biotechnology companies complain that foreign concerns can circumvent U.S. patents by taking patented ingredients offshore to make drugs they can sell with impunity in the U.S. Patents. SECTION: Section 1; Page 33, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1761 words

HEADLINE: RESIGNATION AT SAVINGS AGENCY

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The chief executive of the agency that oversees the Government's savings and loan bailout resigned today in what was seen as another sign that the multibillion-dollar White House program to clean up the industry is faltering.
In departing as president and chief executive of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, Daniel P. Kearney said he had not been given sufficient authority to do his job effectively.
The bailout program, signed by President Bush in August, authorized regulators to spend $159 billion over 10 years to shut or sell more than 500 insolvent savings institutions whose troubles - from lax regulation, excessive risk-taking and the collapse of the energy economy of the Southwest - created the costliest financial crisis since the Depression. The bailout also made sweeping changes in the regulation of the industry, including creating both the Resolution Trust Corporation and the Oversight Board to supervise the disposition of the troubled institutions and their assets.
 
Signs of Higher Costs
 Regulators and banking specialists pointed today, however, to serious problems with the bailout that are already increasing the ultimate cost of cleaning up the savings and loan industry. They cited bureaucratic infighting, a slow pace in the number of deals struck with would-be buyers, weak real estate markets in the Northeast and other areas and a serious lack of bidders for the hundreds of insolvent institutions throughout the country. 
As these insolvent and money-losing institutions continue to operate, losses are mounting at a rate of $6 million a day, regulators say. Because of delay, regulatory bickering and uncertainty, the total cost of the plan, some financial experts say may eventually pass the $200 billion mark.
 
Treasury Interference Cited
 ''Kearney's resignation underscores that the bailout legislation is not being implemented as people had hoped,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, adding that he understood that unnecessary interference by top members of the Treasury Department was principally responsible for the departure.
''I do think that George Bush better watch out,'' Mr. Guenther continued. ''The savings and loan problem is creeping closer and closer to his door again. Congress now can go on the offensive legitimately.''
Although Mr. Kearney did not specifically name the Treasury as the primary source of conflict, Government officials and regulators said that almost from his arrival he struggled with top Treasury officials over whether he would have any major say in the formation of policy.
In a hastily convened meeting this afternoon, the Oversight Board chose William Taylor as the acting president to take over the duties of Mr. Kearney, who is stepping down immediately. Mr. Taylor is now head of the Federal Reserve Board's division of bank supervision and one of the most respected bank regulators.
But banking experts said they doubted he would take the job permanently because he has reportedly already rejected an offer to become the next director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the Federal agency that regulates the savings and loan industry. That job is now held by M. Danny Wall, who has resigned but is staying until a replacement is named.
 
Meeting With Brady
 Officials said that Mr. Kearney first made it known that he was about to resign at a luncheon meeting on Thursday with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, during which he complained of a requirement that he clear almost all of his public comments, press releases and other statements with the Treasury.
Government officials said Mr. Brady, who is chairman of the Oversight Board, did not strongly urge Mr. Kearney to stay, nor promise him more latitude. Other regulators, however, reportedly did encourage him to stay on, including both Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and a member of the Oversight Board, and L. William Seidman, chairman of both the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which oversees the nation's banks, and Resolution Trust.
But Government officials said today that Mr. Kearney felt he lacked sufficient support from the Treasury to continue.
Treasury officials, while saying they regretted Mr. Kearney's departure, said they also felt it was important that the president of the Oversight Board realize he was acting on orders from the Administration, rather than as an independent banking regulator.
 
A List of Grievances
Mr. Kearney said in a statement that he felt both sides misunderstood each other on the scope of the powers vested with the Oversight Board chief executive. Regulators said Mr. Kearney complained that he was essentially being micromanaged by Treasury officials and felt he had no decision-making authority.
His departure will be a loss for the Government, regulators and bankers said. Mr. Kearney had been a mortgage finance specialist in Boston before coming to the Oversight Board but is more prominently known for his work as a partner at the investment house Salomon Brothers, where he helped develop the firm's mortgage-backed securities operation before he left in 1988. He is considered a first-rate manager by the financial community, with extensive experience in real estate and intimate knowledge of the nation's capital markets, which made him almost ideal for the huge job of watching over the bailout.
''People of his caliber in the financial arena are not often attracted to public service, and he was uniquely suited for the job,'' said Eric I. Hemel, a former official of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and now a securities analyst for the First Boston Corporation.
Wall Street bankers and members of Congress said the departure of Mr. Kearney, while obviously delaying the bailout, manifests the structural problems of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which has day-to-day responsibility for managing the bailout, and its Oversight Board, which sets broad policies and approves spending plans.
Both the agency and its board are intended to give the White House ultimate control over how bailout money will be spent. Besides the Treasury Secretary, as chairman, and the Fed chairman, the board includes the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and two other private-sector members appointed by the President.
''It shows that the problems in the regulatory structure are more severe than most people realized,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat from Brooklyn. ''Everyone thought that initially there would be some infighting and then it would be straightened out, but that hasn't happened.''
What concerns experts most is that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is given management responsibilities for Resolution Trust but not ultimate decision-making authority. That rests with the Oversight Board.
 
Inefficient, Costly and Slow
 Mr. Seidman, as chairman of both the F.D.I.C. and Resolution Trust, has repeatedly said this bureaucratic structure is inefficient, costly and slow.
The Treasury has argued that since the bailout involves billions of dollars in taxpayer money, the White House, through the Treasury Department, needs to have ultimate authority over how the money is spent.
Representative Bruce Vento, Democrat from Minnesota, said the Kearney resignation ''only serves to confirm what I have said for the past six weeks - that the Oversight Board should be abolished.''
Members of Congress are also criticizing the White House for what they see as a lack of seriousness about the bailout. They note that the Administration has not filled the two seats on the Oversight Board to be appointed by the President, one vacant seat on the F.D.I.C. and a number of others.
 
10 Positions Vacant
 Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, listed 10 positions relating to the bailout that are vacant.
The White House did announce one trust corporation appointment today, saying it had chosen John J. Adair, now with the General Accounting Office, to be its inspector general.
Wall Street lawyers also say the bidding process for hundreds of troubled savings institutions under the control of Resolution Trust had become so inefficient and costly that clients with deep pockets, primarily commercial banks, are retreating.
''There are simply no buyers for the sick S.&L.'s,'' said Rodgin Cohen, a partner at the New York firm of Sullivan & Cromwell.
Mr. Cohen said that for the most part bankers are interested in weakened savings and loans that have not yet been taken over by the Government. He noted that when an institution is taken over, its value can drop by almost 20 percent overnight as the best corporate borrowers and many small depositors flee.
 
Little Value to Bankers
 What is left then, he said, are savings associations with bad assets, troubled borrowers and high-priced deposits that offer little value to bankers seeking to enlarge their branch networks through geographic diversification and increase the number of small, stable depositors.
But he said that the trust agency would not make any deals for institutions before they have been under its control for months, and that by that time there is little economic viability to most of these institutions.
He said that while banks were willing to pay a premium equal to 6 percent of deposits for a healthy branch network, the trust agency had only been able to get bids of less than 1 percent for its institutions.
Mr. Cohen added that he had one client who had offered to buy a large savings institution that was obviously headed for Government seizure, but the trust agency rejected the offer.
William Isaac, former chairman of the F.D.I.C. and now head of his own consulting firm, the Secura Group, agreed with Mr. Cohen, saying that the types of deals being offered by Resolution Trust are uneconomical for his clients.
 
Little Time to Assess Assets
 He said the Oversight Board had set policies that give bankers little time to assess the condition of real estate loans they acquire with an institution.
He added that much of the problem stemmed from the multiple layers of authority between Resolution Trust and its Oversight Board.
''The existence of the Oversight Board diffuses responsibility,'' he said. ''There is no one to blame because it is a committee. It allows the Treasury to blame the F.D.I.C. and the F.D.I.C. to blame the Treasury, the Fed to duck responsibility and all of them to blame the Congress.''

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Post 1.8% Jump

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Reflecting December's exceptionally harsh weather, producer prices soared 1.8 percent in January, the biggest rise in more than 15 years, the Labor Department reported today.
But while the increase was markedly more than most analysts anticipated, the categories responsible for practically all of the rise - energy and food - were no surprise at all. Indeed, economists were quick to point out that when energy and food are excluded, the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the smallest increase since July.
''It looks a lot worse than it really is,'' Edward F. McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said of today's figures. The numbers actually present ''a pretty good report,'' he concluded. 
 
Markets React Well
The markets took today's figures in stride, with interest rates moving down a bit. The credit market was buoyed, traders said, both by the sign of low underlying inflation and by the Treasury's success this week in attracting foreign buyers for its securities offerings. In the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.83 points, to 2,648.20. [Page 41.] Both food and energy, displaying even more than their usual volatility, posted sharply higher prices as frigid weather in late December raised demand and prices for heating fuels and drastically reduced supplies of certain foods in January.
Like the finished-goods index, which tracks the prices received by producers for commodities sold to the final individual or business user, two related indexes showed similarly negligible increases when energy and food were excluded.
 
Two Small Increases
A rise of one-tenth of 1 percent was posted in the index covering prices received by producers at the intermediate stage of production, which includes semifinished items that require further processing or completed items used as parts of other products. The crude-goods index, which measures prices of items entering the production chain for the first time, was up two-tenths of 1 percent.
As an example of the types of goods in the indexes, wheat would be a crude good, flour an intermediate good and bread a finished product.
Analysts generally characterized the January price burst as a temporary phenomenon that might have some lingering effects but is not a sign of a general acceleration in prices.
''Over all, the numbers suggest that inflationary pressures in the United States continue to be moderate,'' said Brian S. Wesbury of Stotler Economics in Chicago. There's clearly no imminent risk of an inflationary surge, he said, and the Federal Reserve is most unlikely to read the January results as requiring tighter credit.
 
Energy Costs Surge
The rise in the finished-goods index, the most widely followed of the three producer indexes, was dominated by a 13.6 percent jump in energy. The price of home heating oil climbed 25.3 percent, natural gas rose 3.2 percent and gasoline - reflecting the refiners' emphasis on producing more heating oil and less gasoline from each barrel - jumped 16.7 percent.
The rise in food prices, 2.1 percent, was less severe, but included a huge 58 percent leap for fresh and dried vegetables. There was a 12.5 percent jump in the price of eggs, bringing the increase for eggs since January 1989 to 45.2 percent. Prices about doubled last month for tomatoes, lettuce, cabbage, snap beans and dried beans.
The 13.6 percent jump in energy last month was the biggest since the department started that series in 1974. Fresh and dried vegetables had never risen as much as 58 percent in a month since tabulation began in 1967. Over all, the rise in food was the steepest in six years, the department said.
Prices also rose for fish, soft drinks, fresh and processed fruits and bakery products, but there were declines for chicken, turkey, pasta and coffee.
 
Some Prices Fell
Partly offsetting the increases in food and energy were lower prices for cars and light trucks - reflecting fresh incentive programs. Price declines accelerated for tires and tubes. Tobacco prices, as expected, turned down after a sharp year-end increase.
Although it is widely agreed that the January price surge will be reversed, not all of the change is expected to occur quickly. ''The wild card,'' observed Richard B. Berner, a top economist at Salomon Brothers, ''is how fast they come down.''
The price of fresh tomatoes, for example, could tumble as new crops reach the market, but for processed tomatoes the January price jump could be working through the distribution channels for months. And, as with some foods, last month's surge in energy prices has been built into the cost structure of innumerable products.
Analysts expect that the increase in the Consumer Price Index for January will approach 1 percent when it is reported on Feb. 21. The consumer index, unlike the producer index, includes imported goods and a broad array of services. Prices at the various producer price levels eventually influence retail prices but with widely varying degrees and time lags.
 
Offsetting Factors
At the intermediate stage of production, where prices last month jumped 1.2 percent, there was no change when energy was excluded. Energy rose 8.8 percent, including a nearly 50 percent jump for liquefied petroleum gas. Sharp drops for several nondurable manufacturing materials, like industrial chemicals, plastic resins and paperboard, were balanced by increases for various manufacturing and construction components. Among the latter showing big increases were aircraft engines and auxiliary equipment, motor vehicle parts, bearings and engines.
Among crude goods, the overall increase was 2.4 percent, with energy up 5 percent and foods and feeds up 1 percent, the report said.
The finished-goods index now stands 17.5 percent above its 1982 base of 100, and 5.8 percent above the January 1989 level.
The January report also updated seasonal factors for the various indexes, which resulted in relatively small changes from earlier published calculations. In finished goods, for example, the increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent that was initially reported for December was revised to a six-tenths increase and November's one-tenth decline was changed to a one-tenth increase.

HEADLINE: Fed Decision Is Disclosed On Easing Interest Rates

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their December meeting on a further easing of their high-interest-rate policies because of the sluggish economy, according to minutes released today.
Two days after the Dec. 18-19 meeting, the Federal funds rate dropped from 8.5 percent to 8.25 percent, the sixth decline of one-quarter of a percentage point since the rate peaked at 9.75 percent in June.
Federal funds, the interest banks charge one another for overnight loans, is the primary lever the Fed uses to control short-term interest rates. It has not been adjusted since Dec. 21. 
 
Attacking Inflation
The central bank had kept interest rates relatively high for more than a year as it sought to decrease inflation by slowing the economy.
The gross national product, the total output of goods and services, declined from third-quarter growth of 3 percent to just five-tenths of 1 percent in the last three months of 1989. Some Government officials and business leaders have urged the Fed to loosen its grip further to stimulate economic activity.
The Federal Open Market Committee, as the policy-making body is known, met again Tuesday and Wednesday to review monetary policy. The minutes of that meeting will be released next month. The committee holds closed meetings eight times a year to formulate monetary policy and confers by telephone as needed.
It is made up of the 7 Federal Reserve Board members and 5 of the 12 presidents of the Fed district banks.
 
Risk Called High
The minutes of the December meeting said, ''A majority indicated that on balance they viewed the risks of a shortfall in economic activity as sufficiently high to justify an immediate move to slightly easier reserve conditions, and one member expressed a preference for somewhat greater easing.''
Members who wanted policy to remain unchanged ''were concerned that further easing might overcompensate for current weaknesses in the economy at the cost of delaying progress toward price stability,'' the minutes said.
In the end, the vote to ease was 9 to 2. Dissenting were Wayne D. Angell and Thomas C. Melzer. One board governorship is vacant.
 
Manufacturing Sluggish
In arriving at their decision, committee members reviewed information suggesting that economic activity was expanding slowly in the fourth quarter, with sluggishness ''especially evident in the manufacturing sector,'' the minutes said. ''By contrast, growth of the service sector appeared to be well sustained and overall construction activity seemed relatively firm.''
A Fed staff projection, however, suggested that the economy would continue to slow over the next several quarters, although it would rebound in the first quarter from the effects of fourth-quarter strikes and natural disasters.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed While Mark Eases a Bit and Gold Falls

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday against other leading currencies in light trading. The West German mark lost some of its value.
Gold prices fell in domestic and overseas dealing. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $416.10 an ounce, down $2.60 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold at $415.75 as of 4 P.M., Eastern standard time, compared with a late bid of $418.70 on Thursday. 
Currency dealers said the dollar traded within a narrow range for most of day as trading grew light with the approach of the weekend.
Like most other financial markets, the foreign exchange markets seemed to take in stride a 1.8 percent increase in the Producer Price Index for January. Economists noted that a severe cold snap in December raised the wholesale inflation reading. Excluding food and energy, the index rose just one-tenth of a percent.
Enthusiasm to invest heavily in marks has been tempered in recent days by news that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany favors uniting the two Germanys with a common currency.
Dealers who had been buying marks aggressively, assuming that the West German economy would benefit from the reforms in Eastern Europe, adopted a more cautious approach amid uncertainty about the results of a possible merging of East and West Germany's currencies.
Still, trading of dollars continued to be secondary to that of marks, British pounds, Japanese yen and Swiss francs.
The dollar traded at 1.6680 marks late in New York, up from 1.6665 on Thursday and above the 1.6750 marks at the close of European trading.
In London, a British pound cost $1.6930 late yesterday, more expensive than the late bid of $1.6885 on Thursday. The pound also strengthened in New York, where a pound was quoted at $1.6955 late in the day, compared with $1.69435 on Thursday.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 144.72 yen, from 145.50 late Thursday. Later, in London, the dollar traded higher at 145.20 yen, but it ran out of momentum in New York and closed at 144.725 yen, down from 145.315 yen Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's, included: 1.4915 Swiss francs, up from 1.4890; 5.672 French francs, up from 5.6660; 1,241.25 Italian lire, up from 1,240.25, and 1.20025 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19465.

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
Melinte Gains a Mile Record and $100,000

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 9

 BODY:
The people who staged the Vitalis/Meadowlands Invitational track meet tonight offered a total of $250,000 in bonuses for runners breaking world indoor records in three races.
They paid $100,000 to Doina Melinte of Romania for setting a record of 4 minutes 17.13 seconds in the women's mile. They saved $100,000 in the men's mile, although Peter Elliott's winning time of 3:52.02 was the seventh fastest in indoor history. They saved the $50,000 they offered in the men's 600 yards when the race turned into a bumping and falling fiasco. 
For the 12,161 spectators at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the best performance was Melinte's. The willowy 33-year-old Romanian won the 800-meter gold medal in the 1984 Olympics. She set a world indoor record of 4:18.86 for the mile in this meet last year.
 
Quick Early Pace
This time, for the first half-mile, she followed a good pace by Brit McRoberts Lind-Peterson. She pulled away from there and beat second-place Alisa Harvey by 90 yards, a little more than a half-lap of the 176-yard banked-board track.
Melinte passed the 1,500-meter mark in 4:00.27, breaking the 10-year-old world indoor record of 4:00.8 set by Mary Decker Slaney.
Melinte left the arena clutching her oversized check.
''I'm not sure what I'm going to do with the money,'' she said through a translator. ''But I'm not worried about it.'' Elliott said he was not worried about the money, either, although in his case he did not win any.
''I didn't come here to win a $100,000 purse,'' he said. ''I came here to break the record.'' #40-Yard Margin The 27-year-old Englishman gave it a good shot. He followed Ray Brown's crisp pace of 55.3 seconds for the quarter-mile and 1:53 for the half-mile.
When Brown dropped out with four laps left in the 10-lap race, Elliott was on his own. He slowed to 2:53 for three-quarters of a mile and beat Marcus O'Sullivan, the 1988 and 1898 winner, by 40 yards.
So Eamonn Coghlan's 1983 time here of 3:49.78 survived as the world indoor record. Elliott said he might have run faster if Mike Stahr had not got between Brown and Elliott for the first two laps.
''I thought everyone knew what we were trying to do,'' Elliott said sharply.
 
Strong Field in the 600
One of the enduring records in indoor track is Martin McGrady's 1970 time of 1:07.6 for 600 yards. In Butch Reynolds, Danny Harris, Antonio McKay and Ian Morris, the 600 here had four runners capable of winning the race and perhaps threatening the record.
As it turned out, all they threatened was one another. As they entered the first turn of the last lap, McKay was leading on the inside and Morris was moving up alongside him on the outside.
McKay was running perhaps a foot out from the inside of the track. Harris tried to get through that narrow hole. He bumped McKay, who lost his balance and fell. As McKay fell, he bumped Morris, who also fell.
That left only Harris and Reynolds. Harris finished 8 feet ahead of Reynolds in 1:09.98, far from the record. It was also far from a victory. The officials disqualified Harris for the bumping incident, so Reynolds (1:10.36) became the winner and the only finisher.
''I was pretty mad at Danny,'' McKay said. ''But then I went up to him at the end and said, 'Those things happen indoors.' ''
''Antonio was upset the way the race turned out, and so was I,'' Harris said. ''I don't want the best guys laid out on the floor. The only question was whether four big guys like us could stay out of each other's way. We couldn't.''
Doug Padilla was hoping to break the 17-year-old world indoor record of 7:39.2 in the men's 3,000 meters. But he hung back until the last two laps and settled for a 35-meter victory in 7:43.69, his best clocking ever indoors. He said economics might have made him run faster.
''There were too many good people in the race to try to go for a good time,'' he said. ''If there had been $100,000 at stake, maybe I would have run differently.''
 
Repeaters Add Titles
Padilla won his race here for the fifth time in eight years. Diane Dixon (53.59 seconds) captured the women's 400 meters for the fifth successive year and the seventh time in eight years. Joetta Clark (2:03.44) took the women's 800 meters for the fifth time in 12 years, going back to her high school days in Maplewood, N.J.
There were world indoor records for masters (age 40 or older) by 42-year-old Dave Stewart of Ottawa and 40-year-old Jim King of San Diego. Stewart won the masters mile in 4:15.47, and King the masters 400 meters in 50.64 seconds.
Roger Kingdom, the world's best high hurdler, won for the first time ever in a major New York metropolitan-area meet indoors, taking the men's 55-meter hurdles in 7.00 seconds.
Tony Dees finished second to Kingdom, and 10 minutes later, Dees won the 55-yard dash by inches in 6.16 seconds. LaVonna Martin won the women's 55-meter hurdles in 7.45 seconds, beating Jackie Joyner-Kersee for the third time in eight days.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
In Today's Housing Market, Is It Better to Buy or Rent?

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The decision to own or to rent a home has traditionally been based on three elements: cost, personal preference and investment. But the recent decline in house and apartment prices has made a such an investment less of a sure thing and has helped to convert many potential buyers into renters, if only temporarily.
In addition, buyers in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area face a problem that those in many other parts of the country do not confront: the median family income is far less than the income needed to buy a median-priced home.
For example, the median income in the New York metropolitan area is about $30,000, while the income needed to buy a median-priced house is around $63,000. The median price of an existing single-family house in New York last year was $183,400, according to the National Association of Realtors. 
A similar situation exists in the San Francisco Bay Area, where the median price is $260,600, and the Los Angeles area, where the median is $215,500. In contrast, the Midwest has the most affordable housing markets in the nation: the median family income in cities like Cleveland and Detroit is more than adequate to acquire a median-priced home - $75,300 in Cleveland and $73,700 in Detroit. The national median price for a house in 1989 was $93,100.
The general guideline for calculating housing affordability is that families should plan on spending at least two-and-a-half times their annual gross incomes. Thus, a family with an income of $75,000 can afford a house costing about $190,000.
The inability of many people to pay the high home prices now required shows no signs of easing any time soon, particularly in the Northeast. Neither does the current soft housing market, which, in many areas, is offering a static or negative return. As a result, this is likely to be a year in which the number of rentals exceeds their normal pattern and sales fall below the levels reached in the 1980's.
''There's not going to be any appreciation this year,'' said Harve Kevenides, a consultant at the Metropolitan Analysis and Forecasting Corporation in Red Bank, N.J. ''The real rate of appreciation will be negative or stable in 1990.''
 
 In the Near Term
 ''If one considers the purchase as purely an investment, any property purchased from 1986 or 1987 onward does not receive a sufficient return to cover the cash outlay,'' said Nancy Packes, the president of the Feathered Nest, a Manhattan real-estate brokerage firm. ''The perception is that there is no more appreciation to be gotten from residential real estate in the near term.''
Other real-estate experts have a different view of housing as an investment. ''We expect that homes will at least hold value and probably increase more rapidly than general price inflation over the next 10 years,'' said H. James Brown, the director of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University. ''And rents will steadily rise over the next decade.''
Lomas Mortgage U.S.A., a Dallas financial-services company that studies the cost of housing, reports that the average American household lacks the necessary income for a mortgage. This is true across the country, even though many lenders now allow borrowers to spend about a third of their income on housing, up from a quarter in earlier years.
''Housing costs are rising faster than incomes,'' said Paul M. Low, the company's president. He said that the average home with a conventional mortgage cost 8.4 percent more in 1989 than in '88, while household income rose by only 4.8 percent.
''On a cash-flow basis, forgetting taxes, you can rent for about half the cost of buying,'' said Kenneth Rosen, the director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the University of California at Berkeley. ''And the tax benefits of owning have been reduced by tax reform.'' But homeowners still can deduct mortgage interest and most property taxes, a considerable savings in regions where property taxes are high.
One important determination in deciding whether to buy or rent: Would you be better off investing your money in a house over a period of time or investing the down payment and saving any difference?
''The markets today may lead you to rent,'' said Susan Wachter, an economist at the Wharton Real Estate Center of the University of Pennsylvania. ''But your costs tend to be stable when you own, and that's a main motivator to home ownership.''
 
 
 FIGURING OUT THE DIFFERENCE
 The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics suggests that consumers make these calculations to help them decide whether to buy or rent housing.
 1. Write down the purchase price and financing terms for the house or apartment. Include the down payment, closing costs and points.
 2. Estimate your gross monthly shelter costs as a homeowner, including utilities, maintenance and repairs.
 3. Figure out your net monthly outlay, computing the tax savings by deducting mortgage interest and property taxes.
 4. Project what the proceeds would be from selling the property after, say, 5, 10 or 20 years. Some experts say a 4.5 percent annual gain should be projected for the next 10 years.
 5. What will your total rent be for the same period? And if you invested the money you would spend on a down payment, closing costs and points, what would your return be? Today an investor might reasonably expect to get a return of about 8 percent on Treasury bonds, 6 percent on municipal bonds and 6 to 8 percent on stocks.
 6. Compare the two sets of figures.

HEADLINE: Iran Reaffirms Rushdie Death Threat

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Iran's supreme religious leader said today that a decree calling for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie, issued by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini a year ago, remained in force.
In a sermon marking the 11th anniversary of the Iranian revolution, the religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said, ''Imam Khomeini's decree about the author of the blasphemous book 'The Satanic Verses' remains in force and must be carried out.'' Ayatollah Khamenei's remarks were reported by the Teheran radio and monitored by Reuters. 
Ayatollah Khomeini, who died last June, issued a religious decree early last year ruling that the Indian-born Mr. Rushdie blasphemed Islam in his novel and should die for it. He called on faithful Muslims to carry out the death sentence as a religious duty.
Mr. Rushdie, who maintains that his novel is merely a whimsical tale that in no way attacks Islam, has been in hiding and under police protection in Britain for a year.
While the book was widely condemned by Muslim countries and religious authorities as an insult to Islam, many influential Muslim authorities differed with this opinion, saying there was nothing in Islam that sanctions a death sentence in such a case.
 
Contradictory Signals
But Ayatollah Khamenei, who served two terms as Iran's President before taking his position as spiritual guide, renewed this appeal today, saying, ''Mercenary hands which try to diminish Islam by cultural plots like writing blasphemous books must know that they are wrong and these plots will hurt only themselves.''
The Iranian leader's assertions came at a time of contradictory signals about Iran's attitude on American hostages held by pro-Iranian Lebanese militants in Beirut and its desire to improve Iranian political and economic relations with the West.
On Thursday the United States renewed a warning that terrorist actions inspired by Iran may be planned against American interests and denied that any high-level talks about the release of American hostages are being held with Iran, as reported by French and Kuwaiti newspapers.
 
Warning on Terrorism
A State Department official, Richard A. Boucher, said on Thursday that a high level of activity by operatives of the pro-Iranian Party of God, which began in December, continued to present a clear danger to American citizens and installations, adding that ''terrorists may now be planning an operation against U.S. interests in Western Europe, which may be timed for on or about Feb. 11.''
That is the day in 1979 when the Iranian Army surrendered to the revolutionary forces led by Ayatollah Khomeini, and it is celebrated as the day of the triumph of the Iranian revolution against the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who died in 1980.
 
SUPPORT FOR RUSHDIE
LONDON, Feb. 9 (Special to The New York Times) Prominent writers are to issue a statement on Sunday in newspapers around the world pledging support for Salman Rushdie, the Press Association reported today.
Britain's domestic news agency said the International Committee for the Defense of Salman Rushdie and His Publishers succeeded in having more than 160 authors sign the statement, including Arthur Miller, Harold Pinter, William Golding, Allen Ginsberg, Catherine Cookson and Edna O'Brien.
Their support was reportedly gained in less than a week, and more names were added as outrage over the latest announcement in Teheran spread through the literary world.

HEADLINE: Drug-Shooting Casualty Inspires a City to Resist

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 5

 BODY:
Last weekend, volunteers from a local drug rehabilitation program patched and painted the 35 bullet holes in a pink and white stucco bungalow on Westminister Avenue here, where 60-year-old C. W. Roddy was wounded slightly by gunfire on New Year's Eve.
While the painters worked at Mrs. Roddy's house, two deputies and a sergeant on loan from the county sheriff's department helped patrol this crime-ridden city, which cannot afford enough police officers to contain the spread of drugs on its streets.
Meanwhile, county and city officials set aside their jurisdictional squabbles and carried a $5.1 million grant proposal to Washington, seeking money for law enforcement, drug rehabilitation and educational programs for this largely black community of 18,500 residents, 40 miles south of San Francisco, where one in five are unemployed and one in 10 are in prison.
In these and other ways, things have changed in East Palo Alto since Mrs. Roddy's shooting, presumed by the police to be a result of her hectoring the drug dealers on her block. The attack on her home and her refusal to be bullied into silence have outraged and inspired the community as never before, and sparked new government action. 
 
Sense of Optimism Voiced
''I've seen so much negativism in this city,'' said Mrs. Roddy, a retired telephone company service representative. ''Maybe what happened to me has given people the strength to speak out. I know God spared me for some reason and maybe it's to bring unity to East Palo Alto.''
Only by the loosest definition is Mrs. Roddy a ''drug crusader,'' as she has been called in local news accounts of the shooting. Like many of the older people who have lived in East Palo Alto for decades, she has seen her community deteriorate. Angry and frustrated, she harangued the dealers, noted the license numbers of cars cruising the street to buy or sell drugs and begged city officials for more police protection.
''She wanted something simple and basic,'' said Sgt. Ron Sibley of the East Palo Alto police department, which handles more complaints per officer than any force in the Bay Area. ''She wanted to come in and out of her driveway without being harassed. She wanted to sleep at night without hearing gunfire.''
Perhaps it is Mrs. Roddy's very ordinariness that has prompted all the attention. ''Here's an average citizen, in her own home, within inches of being killed,'' said Tom Nolan of the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors. ''People have the sense that things are totally out of control if this can happen.''
 
City Drive for Outside Help
Mr. Nolan is a leader in the recent effort to bring outside assistance to this troubled city. The city voted to incorporate in 1983, despite warnings that the paltry tax base would not support services. That bitterly contested incorporation vote was upheld by the Supreme Court in 1987, but the long legal battle cost the city money it could ill afford.
Just as the city was going broke, crack exploded on its grimy streets, just a few blocks from the million-dollar mansions of Palo Alto and the lush campus of Stanford University. More than half the city's $5 million budget now goes for police services, but it is not nearly enough. In 1989, there were 17 homicides, for a rate of 101 per 100,000 people, more than 10 times the national rate.
Among the homicides in 1988 was the slaying of a 26-year-old police officer, just six weeks out of the academy. In the wake of that slaying, several nearby cities and the California Highway Patrol lent officers to East Palo Alto for a few months. The results were impressive, with police calls down 50 percent and no homicides or shootings. But the cities of Palo Alto, Menlo Park and Redwood City, whose residents come here to buy drugs, could not send their officers here indefinitely.
The county, on the other hand, had resources to spare, but was at loggerheads with the city of East Palo Alto, which was wary of outsiders who might challenge the newfound autonomy. ''When you're trying to become an independent entity, it's difficult to accept help because it feels like failure,'' said State Senator Rebecca Morgan, a Republican from nearby Los Altos Hills. $500,000 From the County Senator Morgan was instrumental in bringing the two governments together. As a result, San Mateo County will give the city $500,000, which must be used for five more officers in East Palo Alto over the next two years. While the new officers are being recruited and trained, the county has lent the city several deputy sheriffs and sergeants, three each shift, nearly doubling the uniformed presence.
There is also a new neighborhood organization on Mrs. Roddy's block, Citizens United Against Drugs. The group's president, Jody Lee, is the mother of two dealers, among those at odds with Mrs. Roddy. Mrs. Lee said she hopes her sons ''will see me doing this and try to get their lives together.''
Mrs. Roddy seems particularly moved by Mrs. Lee's militancy. ''The day she came over to our side was a joyous day for me,'' Mrs. Roddy said. ''It's the beginning of unity.'' The outside of Mrs. Roddy's house no longer bears the scars of the shooting, but other marks endure, like the gash in a wooden coffee table in the living room and a shattered quilting frame in the garage. Her 1970 Pontiac is still in the shop, rammed while parked on the driveway in a separate attack on Jan. 10. In a third attack on Jan. 11, two makeshift Molotov cocktails were hurled at the house, but did not explode.
Mrs. Roddy's 37-year-old son, Darnell, remains jumpy, rushing every few minutes to look out the picture window, with its new glass panes.
''Darnell, what is the matter?'' Mrs. Roddy asked, blandly.
''It's too noisy out there,'' he snapped.
Mrs. Roddy maintains she is not nervous. ''I've never really been frightened,'' she said. ''I've been angry, livid, upset with the apathy of the people of East Palo Alto. But, I'm not afraid to die. I try to live my life daily like it was my last. When it's time to go, it's time to go.''

HEADLINE: Florida Airport in Race With Growth

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla.

 BODY:
The ponds, palm trees and other oasis-like amenities of Orlando International Airport are under siege. Thousands of construction workers, hundreds of trucks with tons of dirt and concrete, and 45,000 passengers pour in and out of the airport every day.
The airport in central Florida has been praised in the travel industry for successfully handling a huge increase in traffic since the airline industry was deregulated in 1979. Others, like those serving New York City and Chicago, have suffered a form of gridlock. 
Now Orlando continues to shatter all projections. When it was designated an international airport in 1981, it had about 6 million passengers. Last year it handled more than 17.2 million, an increase of 187 percent, making it the fastest-growing major airport in the country.
A third terminal is to open in June, increasing the number of gates to 74 from 50. Airport officials expect to break ground for a fourth terminal soon. Orlando has opened a third runway and is almost doubling the size of its central terminal, adding a 450-room hotel and more ticket counters and baggage-claim areas.
 
A New Surge Lies Ahead
Orlando is expecting a surge of new passengers, once all the construction is done. ''Our domestic growth has been held back because we have no more space, no more places to park aircraft,'' said John Wyckoff, executive director of the Greater Orlando Aviation Authority, which runs the airport.
Mr. Wyckoff says international and cargo flights will have the greatest growth. Orlando is being watched by the travel industry and by other airport operators for its aggressive and successful campaign to attract international carriers - a goal of many mid-sized airports.
''Orlando has succeeded in getting more of its share,'' said Terry P. Parent, the marketing director at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport. ''They have been quite aggressive; they have done a good job of promoting their assets and defining their market.''
 
Lure of the Theme Parks
Last year Orlando reported that it handled 1.5 million international passengers, up 102 percent from 742,786 in 1988. In the last year, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines started nonstop service twice a week between Orlando and Amsterdam and Delta began flying five times a week between Orlando and Frankfurt.
A big lure is Orlando's theme parks and attractions, primarily the three Disney theme parks on 6,600 acres.
''We planned our trip for six months,'' said Hidao Masumoto, an economist from Sao Paulo, Brazil, who spent two weeks and about $8,000 touring Disney World and nearby attractions with his wife, Rosa, and two children, Renato, 17, and Cinthia, 15. ''The children wanted to come.''
Pat and Carol Brennan from Peterborough, Ontario, spent nine days at Disney World, primarily at the Epcot theme park, with their daughters Amy, 13, and Angie, 10. ''We wanted to see Disney again before the kids got too old for it,'' Mrs. Brennan said. ''We love it.''
 
At Mercy of Money Managers
Disney officials report a dramatic increase in foreign tourists, and they attribute much of the rise to relative weakness of the dollar. ''We've stepped up our marketing efforts and we'll take some of the credit,'' said Thomas Elrod, senior vice president of marketing of Walt Disney Attractions. ''But in many ways we are at the mercy of the money managers of the world.''
One sign of the increase in long-distance visitors: the Disney organization says that when it opened in 1971, 20 percent of its visitors arrived by air; today, 50 percent fly.
For the last few years, more overseas tourists have been flying directly into Orlando. ''For the longest time, route maps showed Miami-Disney World,'' said Carolyn M. Fennell, director of community relations at the Greater Orlando Aviation Authority. ''We fought to have that changed, and now we are rightly getting what was our niche.''
Since scheduled international service began in 1984, five international carriers started nonstop service into Orlando from South America, Iceland, Europe and the United Kingdom. Additional charter service links Canada and Brazil.
 
The Change for the City
When Walt Disney World opened in 1971, the City of Orlando transformed itself from an agricultural community to a worldwide tourist stop. Orlando now has more hotel rooms - 68,000 last year - than Los Angeles, with 67,500 rooms, Chicago, with 64,300 or, New York, with 62,500.
Today, Orlando is said to be outpacing other Florida communities and the nation in economic growth. Business leaders here see a symbiotic relationship between the economy and the airport.
Rick Tesch, president of the Economic Development Commission of Mid-Florida, compared the relationship to the age-old question of the chicken and the egg. ''In our case there is no question,'' he said. ''The tourism industry was the egg, It has been the catalyst for the development of the transportation infrastructure that business needs.''
The airport, originally a small corner of an old Air Force base, with two Quonset huts serving as terminals, was started mostly to serve tourists, who made up 90 percent of its passengers. Today, tourists are close to 50 percent of the passengers.
 
The Problem of Parking Cars
Business travelers, especially those headed for the Kennedy Space Center, quickly forced the airport to make some changes. It had very little parking space because tourists then generally took cabs, buses or rented cars to their hotels. Now the airport has two new six-story parking garages with 10,000 spaces.
The growth of the business market is expected to continue, especially as Disney and Universal promote and expand their nearby movie studios and theme parks. The Disney-M.G.M. studio opened last year, while Universal Studios Florida is scheduled to open its attractions in May.
''People throughout the world love the movie business,'' said Randy A. Garfield, executive vice president of marketing at Universal Studios Florida. ''The international travelers just crave this.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Orlando International Airport is expanding to meet rapid growth and construction is under way on a new terminal that is scheduled to open in June. Last year, the airport handled more than 17 million passengers. (The New York Times/Gary Bogdon); Map of Orlando showing location of Orlando International Airport

HEADLINE: AIDS and the Fashion World: Industry Fears for Its Health

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:
Like an advancing shadow, AIDS has touched the lives of nearly everyone in the fashion industry.
Beyond the designers who have died, the visual display departments that have been decimated and the sample rooms that have been disrupted, there is the loss of countless unseen people who are the pulse of New York's second-largest industry: the stylists, illustrators, showroom assistants, makeup artists and hairdressers who not only capture the spirit of fashion but sometimes lead it.
''Health has become the most important thing in fashion, more important than the cut of the clothes,'' said Virginia Estrada, the sister of Angel Estrada, a New York designer who died of AIDS last year.
 
Investors Are Wary
Fashion executives find it difficult to quantify the costs of the crisis, which has caused designer labels to falter and smaller houses to die, absenteeism and insurance premiums to rise, and venture capitalists to shy away. In an already risky business, ''key man'' insurance policies are being sought with a new rigor, and there are even intimations that investors think female designers represent one less risk. 
But many said the greatest casualty has been creativity. At a time when the apparel business needs new direction to bolster the flagging retail sector, important young designers have died. Future stars who might replace them have found it difficult to find backers, especially if they are young and male.
Successful fashions, especially women's fashions, are a key element in the profit margins of retailers. For this reason, AIDS, which has well-documented medical and social implications, could also have business effects that will be felt throughout the economy.
''It ends up being a part of everybody, one way or another,'' said Patricia Pastor, a former Perry Ellis assistant who assumed his design responsibilities for two seasons after he died. ''We all dress. If this entire industry is being weakened by something, it's going to filter down to all of us.''
An estimate of the number of AIDS cases in the fashion industry is difficult to obtain - partly out of concern about obtaining health insurance. But it is more difficult to find anyone in the fashion industry who has not been affected by the disease.
''How are your T cells?'' has become part of the daily discourse, like the weather and what styles are selling. T-4 lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell, are one marker for the degree of infection by AIDS.
''In this industry, it surrounds you,'' said a fashion executive. ''It creates a kind of claustrophobic feeling.''
Recently, a group of Japanese investors asked the designer Carmelo Pomodoro for a list of five designers he thought would have a significant impact in the 1990's.
''I gave them a list with three women and two men,'' Mr. Pomodoro said. ''When they got back to me, they said they were not interested in the men, because of the AIDS factor.''
 
'Decade of the Woman Designer'
Rebecca Moses, a New York designer, said she had been approached by many investors - Japanese, European and American - since she restarted her fashion business last year. A few considered it a plus that she was a woman.
''They're really interested in investing in women,'' Ms. Moses said. ''It's absurd, but it's a phenomenon of the business.''
The long-term consequences of such a shift in investment are uncertain. Fashion, a highly entrepreneurial enterprise, depends on the odd and the new.
''It will have an enormous impact,'' said Alan Millstein, an analyst and publisher of a fashion industry newsletter. ''The actual AIDS numbers may not be very large, but the industry doesn't have that many design firms. The 90's could be the decade of the woman designer.''
 
The Investors Ask: Is a Designer Insurable?
 The prevailing problem in the fashion world today is insurability, said Andrew Jassin, a director of the Marketing Management Group, a garment center company that consults with investors about financing apparel companies.
''They will ask if a designer is insurable if they're going to make a deal,'' Mr. Jassin said. Industry executives expressed concern that such insurance policies, known as ''key man'' policies, a form of life insurance in which the beneficiaries are the investors or partners instead of spouses or family, may lead to discriminatory screening of designers and executives.
Joseph Abboud, a men's wear designer, said he was tested for AIDS 18 months ago when he applied for key-man insurance. It was part of the process in concluding a 20-year contract with Gruppo GFT, the manufacturer and financial backer of his clothing line. The arrangement, like many top management contracts, was contingent on the insurance policy.
''I had to take extensive medical tests and sign a release to be tested for AIDS,'' Mr. Abboud said.
Todd Oldham, a designer of women's wear, said he was tested before concluding negotiations with various potential investors. He now designs for Onward Kashiyama, a Japanese company.
''Before we landed Kashiyama, we had negotiations with other backers,'' Mr. Oldham said. ''I've taken the AIDS test four times now. They say it's for insurance, but they don't want their money to drop dead in 10 years. It's heartless, but business is business.''
Insurance executives said it is common practice in New York State for anyone, male or female, to be tested for AIDS when applying for life insurance worth more than $50,000. But Gerald Shaw, president of Oscar de la Renta, said that in his experience a medical examination before a garment center arrangement is concluded is highly unusual.
''I'm amazed to hear of it,'' said Mr. Shaw, whose father, Ben Shaw, financed many fashion houses. ''Key-man policies have been around forever. But I can't imagine someone taking a test as part of a preliminary negotiation.''
At the least, the insurance risks in fashion companies have made it more difficult and costly to be insured. Since in New York State companies with fewer than 10 employees can be required to submit to individual examinations to obtain group health policies, small concerns may not be able to get insurance at all.
Ron Cohen, an insurance broker specializing in garment center companies, said these were among the businesses that health insurers were shunning. ''What's happened now is the insurance industry has sufficient statistical information to prove to themselves that certain businesses have higher claims activity,'' Mr. Cohen said.
Mark Scherzer, a partner in the New York law firm of Scherzer & Palella, which specializes in insurance cases on the behalf of the insured, said: ''A fair number of my clients with AIDS have been in the fashion industry. Some have been told by their health insurance companies that their AIDS was a pre-existing condition. I've also consulted with people who thought they were going into business deals, but decided not to go ahead with them because they knew they would test HIV positive. It seems likely that's a very frequent occurrence.''
 
When a Designer Dies: Talent Isn't Replaceable
 Companies that have lost their head designers have met with varying degrees of success. Tracy Mills Couture, basically a one-man show, folded immediately after the death of its designer, Mr. Mills.
The outlook for the company founded by Mr. Estrada is better. When he died, his sister, Virginia, a sculptor and jewelry designer who had played a designing role in several of his collections, assumed the design responsibilities. But the business had to be changed.
''Everything had to be rethought when Angel died,'' Ms. Estrada said. The company, which had focused on custom-made evening dresses, will produce a sportswear line for this fall. It has also entered a licensing arrangement with a Japanese company, Kindwear, to make clothing in Japan.
''Talent is not replaceable,'' said Laurie Mallet, the president of WilliWear Limited, a company she founded with the designer Willi Smith, who died of AIDS in 1987. Without a designer to make news, Ms. Mallet opened a WilliWear retail store on Fifth Avenue at 19th Street to keep the name visible. Wholesale volume of the women's clothing plummeted. Sales of the men's wear continued to grow.
''It has taken me two years to find a designer with the energy and spirit that Willi had,'' Ms. Mallet said. She recently hired Andre Walker to design WilliWear for women. His first collection will be shown in New York in April.
At Perry Ellis International, first the president, Laughlin Barker, died of AIDS. Then Mr. Ellis himself died.
Despite the turmoil, some Perry Ellis licenses have had strong sales. ''From a business standpoint life goes on and it flourishes,'' said Claudia Thomas, the president of the company. ''We've been devastated by AIDS, savaged by it. On the other hand, we've had increases of 35 percent per annum for the last two years in our licensing income.''
The company hired Marc Jacobs, a resourceful young designer, and Robert Duffy, president of Perry Ellis Sportswear, to rejuvenate the business.
 
For Retailers, Too, It's a Major Problem
 High-fashion retailers have also been affected.
Ira Neimark, chairman of Bergdorf Goodman, said the store had lost at least five employees to the disease in the last five years. Bergdorf's employs about 1,000 people.
''The impact is significant,'' Mr. Neimark said.
Marvin S. Traub, the chairman of Bloomingdale's, has said that employees with AIDS have jobs as long as they are able to work. Lester Gribetz, the store's vice chairman, said, ''In Bloomingdale's we have business people who have tested positive for the disease, and that's a major problem.'' Among them are least two executives in his division, he said.
Visual merchandising, which includes window dressing and displays at stores, has been particularly hard hit.
''For a time last year, it seemed like we were going to funerals every week,'' said Richard L. Stolls, the president of Trimco, a supplier of display materials. ''In the beginning, it was hitting the lower echelon, and it was kind of hush-hush. Then we lost some major contributors to the industry.''
He cited Colin Birch, senior vice president for visual display at Bloomingdale's, and Robert Benzio, vice president for visual presentation at Saks Fifth Avenue.
''They were innovators, creators, extremely talented people,'' Mr. Stolls said. ''From an emotional standpoint it's difficult. You have customers you start relationships with, and then you have to start all over again.''
Mr. Stolls said his company's group insurance rates have soared. ''They've gone up tremendously,'' he said. ''We've changed companies several times in the last few years.''
 
'I Live With It. I Work With It.'
 AIDS is antithetical to everything the image-conscious fashion business stands for: beauty, youth, fitness, vitality, success and well being. And it undercuts one of the eternal lures of beautiful clothes: sex.
In the beginning, AIDS was shrouded in secrecy and denial. Now, coping with its sinister presence has become a fact of daily life in the fashion world.
''We're used to our grandparents or elderly people dying,'' said Ms. Pastor, the former Perry Ellis designer. ''All of a sudden, we've been faced with the death of our contemporaries, our co-workers. The effect in the workplace when someone has AIDS is psychologically very devastating.''
On the job it can mean looking and feeling great one day, and being in the hospital the next.
''I spend an inordinate amount of time and effort staying well,'' said a fashion publicist who has AIDS. He preferred to be identified, but his supervisors insisted that he not be.
''I live with it,'' the publicist said. ''I work with it. I arrange to have less stress. I feel guilty when I'm not pulling my weight.''
Arthur Fitting, the co-founder of New York Sport, a sportswear company, closed his business last year, partly because his partner had contracted AIDS. Mr. Fitting, who is a registered nurse, now works for Unity Health Care, a company that provides ambulatory AIDS treatment.
''The stress of starting a new company had a tremendous impact on my partner's health,'' Mr. Fitting said. ''Start-up costs, cash flow, the pace of the seasons - you can't be fighting for your life and have all that on your shoulders.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: The fashion industry has been deeply affected by the loss of young designers to AIDS. Virginia Estrada, a jewelry designer whose brother died last year, has taken over his work at the company he founded. (NYT/Don Hogan Charles) (pg. 42)
