HEADLINE: As Jerusalem Labors to Settle Soviet Jews, Native Israelis Slip Quietly Away

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLON, Israel, Feb. 7

 BODY:
At times it seemed a futile exercise. But for weeks on end Mordechai Glick and a few other volunteers showed up outside the United States Embassy each morning at dawn and handed leaflets to Israelis waiting in long lines outside the visa office.
''This Is Home!'' said the boldface headline. The text went on to add, ''You know deep in your hearts that only in Israel do you have a future as Jews.'' At the bottom, the leaflet was signed, ''The Organization to Stop Emigration From Israel.''
Mr. Glick said that as he handed the little blue papers to each of the visa applicants, ''all of them read it.'' 
''They were interested,'' he said, adding that ''some of them folded the papers into their passports'' but that not one person stepped out of line.
That was last summer. And in the months since then, most of the association's volunteers have stopped their work for the cause, trying to stop the steady stream of Israeli citizens who give up on their country, pack their belongings and move abroad, most often to the United States.
 
Outward Flow Ignored
As Mr. Glick and the others tell it, the huge wave of Soviet immigrants now pouring into Israel has so captured the Government's interest that it pays no attention to what the critics see as the larger problem of emigration, or, as it is called here, ''yerida,'' a Hebrew word meaning ''to go down.''
''No one's interested anymore,'' said Sipi Kichler, a teacher still active in the cause. ''Now the whole story is aliyah,'' or going up, as in moving to Israel.
But as Israel grows wholly preoccupied with absorbing a mass of Soviet immigrants - teaching them Hebrew, retraining them for jobs, finding them homes and settling them into Israeli society, all at great cost - far more Israelis who already have job skills, homes and deep familiarity with all aspects of life here are leaving.
''How can we as a country invest so much in these people, our citizens, and let them go?'' Mr. Glick asked. ''How can we survive if we do that? The state of Israel should be dealing with the yordim, those who flee, not just aliyah.'' #15,000 Moved Away Government statistics show that 12,923 Soviet Jews moved to Israel in 1989. But at the same time a Government estimate shows that about 15,000 Israelis packed their belongings and moved away. That figure does not count the many others who left the country on tourist visas with a vague intention to return one day. Many thousands of those people are not expected ever to come back.
For Israelis, the problem is not just the loss of skilled workers and Jewish citizens, already far outnumbered by Arabs in the region. The problem of yerida touches Israel's soul.
This state was founded to be the home for all the world's Jews, and Israelis find it troubling enough that most Jews choose not to move here. If thousands of Jews already here give up and move away, to many Israelis that is an an even more eloquent statement that the state has failed to be a successful Jewish homeland.
It may be that because of the psychological problem, as much as anything else, the Government chooses to ignore the problem. Thinking about the yerida problem makes Israelis uncomfortable. And to slow or stop emigration, Israel would have to lower inflation, lessen unemployment, provide more and cheaper housing, reduce military service and generally improve the quality of life, tasks not easily accomplished.
 
Office Closed Last Year
Until last year, the Absorption Ministry did have an office whose employees worked to discourage emigration. But it was closed last year, as the ministry and the rest of the Government struggled to cope with the heavy weight of Soviet immigration.
''We don't have the time to deal with it, we don't have the money to deal with it anymore,'' said Ida Ben Shitrit, the Absorption Ministry spokesman.
Large-scale emigration has plagued the people of the region for many thousands of years. Living here has always been difficult; the word yordim is derived from the flight of Jews who ''went down'' to Egypt for food and work several thousand years ago.
In the late 19th and early 20th century many of the European Jews who set up religious settlements in Palestine gave up after a few months and returned home, often hungry and diseased.
 
Beginning in the mid-1970's
Emigration abated in the state's first years. But since the mid-1970's, after repeated wars, economic problems and political strife took the luster off Israel's robust, pionering spirit, thousands of Israel's citizens began to leave.
The emigration association estimates that 650,000 Jewish citizens have left since the state was founded, an enormous number considering that Israel's Jewish population is about 3.7 million.
The Absorption Ministry says that estimate is exaggerated; really, only about 365,000 Jews have left, Yitzhak Peretz, the Absorption Minister, said. But in truth no one knows for sure because at any given time tens of thousands of Israelis are abroad for extended periods studying, working or visiting relatives who have already left. No one knows how many of those people will come back.
But Mr. Glick said the anecdotal evidence of emigration is staggering. 'Packing to Move' to the U.S. ''I'm a locksmith, and I'm in a hundred homes a week,'' he said. ''I can't even tell you how many people I see who are packing to move to the United States.''
He and Mrs. Kichler are Holocaust survivors. And it is this experience that makes them and thousands of others in the nation's older generation committed Zionists. They suffered in other countries and now cannot conceive of living anywhere else.
''The Holocaust tells us this is the only country for the Jews,'' Mrs. Kichler said.
Most of the people who are leaving, on the other hand, are younger native-born Israelis, or sabras, who know little of anti-Semitism or life as a minority in another state. They see themselves merely as Israelis, not Zionists.
''The new generation says, 'The fact that I was born here doesn't mean I have to die here,' '' said Rina Bar Tal, the longtime head of the emigration association.
 
Not Usually Impressed
Typically, all these sabras know of life in the West is that the people who live there appear to be wealthier, less troubled. As a result, Mr. Glick says he often lectures groups of young soldiers who are about to be discharged from the army, explaining to them ''what life was like for me abroad.'' But the young men and women usually are not impressed.
''The problem with the sabras,'' he said, ''is that they are naive. They don't know what can happen to them when they go abroad. They don't understand that there are people out there who hate the Jews.
''I explain this to them, but they tell me: 'Fine, but no one here is taking care of us. There are no jobs for us, no places to live. No places for us in the universities. And now all the new immigrants are coming, and they are going to get all the jobs.' ''
What Mr. Glick, Mrs. Kichler and the others want is Government programs to help Israeli young people find jobs and housing before they throw up their hands in despair and leave.
 
'An Israeli G.I. Bill'
''What we need is an Israeli G.I. bill,'' Mrs. Bar Tal said. ''Something to help them with jobs, education, housing.''
Michael Kleiner, chairman of the Parliament's immigration and absortion committee, shakes his head at that idea.
He said: ''We hear that sentiment all the time: 'My boy is leaving the army; he has served his country. Why can't he get some of these benefits the new immigrants are getting?' That kind of reasoning comes from a lack of economic understanding.''
But Uri Gordon, head of the absorption committee for the Jewish Agency, the quasi-governmental agency deeply involved in immigration issues, tends to agree with Mr. Glick and the others. ''My Government has to do everything it can so the young generation does not continue running from the country,'' he said. ''This has become a crucial subject, and we are not doing enough to fight it.''
Sadness and resignation in his voice, Mr. Glick acknowledged: ''We have lots of problems in this country. Very difficult problems. This particular issue makes people uncomfortable. So it just gets left aside.''

CORRECTION-DATE: February 18, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption last Sunday with an article about efforts to stop emigration from Israel characterized Mordechai Glick incorrectly. He is a member of the Organization to Stop Emigration From Israel but is not its head. The caption also misidentified the setting. It was Mr. Glick's home, not his office.

HEADLINE: KENYA WILL ALTER PLANNED HIGH-RISE

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Under pressure from the World Bank and from the United States and Japan, the Kenyan Government has decided to scale back plans for a $200 million 60-story tower that would have been the tallest commercial structure in Africa.
The Government, which had also been criticized by environmentalists for planning the building for the site of a popular downtown park, told a World Bank meeting in London last month that the tower would be modified, probably to 30 stories.
The office building and an accompanying hotel and conference center would be subject to further feasibility studies and would go ahead only in phases and in consultation with donor countries, Kenyan officials said. 
The tower, which was to feature a larger-than-life statue of President Daniel arap Moi, was to be financed by publicly guaranteed loans. Western donors complained that Kenya could not afford such loans because its economy, while stronger than many in Africa, was still strained, particularly given the dramatic fall in coffee prices.
 
Violation of Debt Agreement
Donors pointed out that the loan for the building, together with loans Kenya was seeking for an oil pipeline, a sugar project and equipment for Kenya Airways, would leave the country with more than $400 million in external debt.
Such a level would break an understanding with the International Monetary Fund that the Government would limit such debt to $100 million.
The Kenyan Government was also informed by Western diplomats, particularly from the United States and Japan, that the breaking of the I.M.F. agreement could lead Western donors to cut economic aid to Kenya. When the United States announced last month that it was forgiving part of Kenya's debt to Washington, the new United States Ambassador here, Smith Hempstone, said the entire debt would be written off only if Kenya kept its economic house in order.
Charles Mbinyo, the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Finance, who informed the World Bank meeting of Kenya's decision to modify the project, was quoted in a local paper here as saying the Government had never made a firm decision to go ahead with the tower. His remarks seemed to indicate that the Government was trying to find a diplomatic way of putting the project, which dominated the news here for several months, on the back burner.
Kenya until recently was considered a model in Africa for keeping its commercial loans to a manageable level, diplomats said.
 
Many Complaints in Kenya
The tower drew an unusual stream of criticism from Kenyans, who are often reluctant to publicly question officially sanctioned projects, especially ones so identified with the sole political party, the Kenya African National Union. The building was to be the headquarters of the party and its newspaper and television station.
Letters to newspapers deplored losing the park for lunchtime leisure. Kenyan architects advertised in one newspaper against the project's location. One architect estimated that shadows cast by the tall building would start falling over sunny streets by 2 P.M.
The dissent was led by Prof. Wangari Maathai, the leader of an environmental group called the Green Belt Movement, who came under attack from leading politicians, including President Moi, for suggesting that the building could be located elsewhere.
The attacks on Professor Maathai seemed to show the limits of allowable opposition in this one-party nation.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
American Visas for Scientists From the East Are Said to Be Lagging

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Despite the crumbling of cold war barriers, the granting of American visas to Soviet and East European scientists remains mired in red tape, depriving the nation of sorely needed talent, American scientists contend.
Many scientists and Government officials say United States visa policies affecting scientific exchanges are at least as restrictive, and in some cases more so, than they were before the political liberalization begun by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
The complaints are being made even though State Department figures show that the number of Soviet scientists being granted J-class visas, the type usually given to those coming to conduct research or teach at American institutions, increased from 104 in 1985 to more than 1,000 in 1989.
 
Proportion Said to Be Unchanged
The critics of the policy say the increase resulted not from any easing of American regulations but because Soviet travel restrictions have been greatly liberalized and far more Soviet scientists are applying for United States visas. The proportion being admitted is basically unchanged, they said, and should be far higher. 
A spokesman for the State Department said it does not maintain records of how many Soviet scientists apply for visas each year, but only the number who actually receive them. Nor could the department give overall figures on visas sought by or issued to Eastern European scientists.
Experts on American immigration agreed in interviews that the lack of change in visa policies stems more from inertia than any intentional continuation of an anti-Soviet policy.
Several officials of the State Department and intelligence agencies said in interviews that the legal regulations governing visas for Soviet and East European scientists need to be overhauled.
''Believe me, a lot of us in government sympathize with the complaints by scientists,'' one said. ''The problem is that things have moved so fast in Moscow and the other former Soviet-bloc capitals that all governments, including our own, were caught by surprise. We're playing catchup.''
Critics of the situation said an initiative by Congress was essential to changing what they regard as an overly restrictive system.
 
More Dependent on Foreigners
American science, particularly physics and mathematics, is increasingly dependent on the participation of foreign scientists and graduate students.
''Roughly half of America's graduate physics students are foreign, and a large proportion of them in recent years have been Chinese,'' said Dr. Robert L. Park, director of the Washington office of the American Physical Society. But the flow of Chinese students and scientists to this country virtually halted after Peking's violent repression of a drive for political change last year.
''A lot of those students end up staying in the United States for long periods of time, or even permanently,'' Dr. Park said. ''Without the flow from China we have to get physicists elsewhere, and the Soviet Union, which has a superb system of scientific education, is a logical alternative.''
Under the current regulations, an intelligence board called the Committee on Exchanges, or Comex, a branch of the Technology Transfer Intelligence Committee, examines visa applications from Soviet-bloc scientists and makes recommendations. Members of Comex include representatives of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency and the Departments of State, Justice and Commerce.
The main criterion for Comex's recommendations is national security. In general, the object is to prevent secret and ''sensitive'' technology, which is not always classified as secret, from becoming available to Moscow and its allies. But American immigration policies also play a role, especially in excluding visa applicants whose motives are deemed to be purely economic.
That is why 50 percent of the applications from Poland are rejected, said a State Department official, who requested that his name be withheld. Calamitous economic conditions in Poland are prompting a large flow of ''economic refugees'' seeking to enter the United States, not all of whom are authentic scientists, he said.
 
Applicants Are Discouraged
This has discouraged and angered many applicants. In a letter in the January issue of Physics Today, a magazine published by the American Institute of Physics, five Polish physicists complained of ''a strange contradiction between the words of the present American administration and its deeds in handling visa applications for Polish scientists invited to visit American universities.''
The scientists, representing Poland's Institute for Theoretical Physics and the Polish Academy of Sciences, said long delays in the granting of American visas were making it impossible to plan trips, and that visas ''were a lot easier to get five or ten years ago, when Poland could have been treated with much more suspicion than now.''
One case that has sharply focused scientists' attention on United States visa policies involves Dr. Sergei Esipov, a Soviet physicist who was invited to teach at Syracuse University only to have his application denied in December because of an unfavorable recommendation by Comex.
Goodwin Cooke, vice president of Syracuse, said the visa was denied because some technologically ''sensitive'' research is conducted there, to which Comex suspected Dr. Esipov might have access. Mr. Cooke, a former United States career diplomat, said, ''It is preposterous that American universities and American industry should be denied opportunities which others will exploit because of this cold- war process.''
James Dearlove, executive secretary of Comex, referred a telephone request for comment to the Central Intelligence Agency, which said the deliberations of Comex were classified.
In the view of Dr. Glenn Schweitzer, director of Soviet and East European affairs of the National Academy of Sciences, the problem is not that Soviet scientists as a class are unwelcome, but that the administrative screening system is overloaded and lags badly in processing visa applications.
 
'Clogging' of System Is Blamed
''The United States is now issuing about 100,000 visas to Soviet business and professional visitors each year, and the number of Soviet scientists applying for visas is increasing rapidly,'' he said. ''Cases like that of Esipov at Syracuse are not terribly common. The bulk of the problem is the clogging of the administrative system. We're concerned that worries over the transfer of technology to the Soviets should not unnecessarily inhibit scientific communication between us. The need for such communication has become greater than ever.''
Dr. Grayson Sher, manager of the Soviet exchange program at the National Science Foundation, agreed. ''The number of Soviet scientists who want to travel is increasing, and despite change in international relations brought about by glasnost, the granting of American visas has not eased,'' Dr. Shjer said.
''Reviewing each of these cases is time-consuming,'' an intelligence official said, speaking on condition that his name and affiliation be witheld. ''But the present Comex procedure, in which representatives of the intelligence community and other concerned agencies sit down together to talk things out and reach a collective decision, is far better than the way things were done in the past.''
Another official said that a problem Comex often has to confront is a lack of information. When Comex deems a visa applicant a potential conduit of sensitive technology to Moscow, the committee needs extra background information about the applicant to reach a decision, an informant said. When such information is lacking, the committee is more likely to reject the application.
But this explanation does not satisfy critics of the system.
''Simply stated, the old rules are depriving us of scientific brains and commercial advantages,'' Mr. Cooke said. ''Things there have changed, and it's high time Congress got around to changing our own rules. We are living in a new world.''

HEADLINE: Southeast Asia Is Now No. 1 Source of U.S. Heroin

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Golden Triangle of Southeast Asia, whose flow of drugs the United States has been trying to control for 25 years, is once again the single-largest source of heroin coming into America, with production levels rising sharply.
In 1987, only 18 percent of the heroin in the United States originated in Southeast Asia; today the figure is at least 45 percent. Six years ago, 5 percent of the heroin in New York City was Southeast Asian; today, according to the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, the figure is 80 percent.
The increase is a result of many factors, Western diplomats and law-enforcement officials say, ranging from unrest in Myanmar, formerly Burma, to a decision by some drug smugglers to bypass Latin America, which has gotten increasing attention from governmental authorities, and seek safer routes.
The changing patterns of heroin supply have brought new and unwanted attention to Thailand as the main smuggling and shipment center for heroin from the Golden Triangle, where Myanmar, Laos and Thailand meet. 
 
Thai Economy Booms
Although Thailand is praised by Western diplomats for having sharply reduced the amount of opium-poppy cultivation on its territory, the rapidly developing communications and transport systems of it booming economy are also being used for shipping the increasing amounts of heroin being produced in Laos and Myanmar to Europe and America. The large growth in Thai exports and in tourism here provides more options for smuggling, ranging from individual couriers to large shipments hidden deep in legitimate exports moving through containerized ports.
The amount of money at stake, Western diplomats and Thai officials say, makes the problem of corruption among Thai police, army and customs officials, none of whom are paid very well, a growing concern even for a well-intentioned Thai Government that cooperates with Western law-enforcement authorities.
Thai sensitivity to public suggestions of corruption and complicity is very high, but the tone of even private discussions about drugs between American and Thai officials is becoming more ''forthright'' and ''even, at times, angry,'' Western diplomats say, despite extensive cooperation between the two Governments.
''We're trying to get across to the Thais that drugs are an international problem and that Thailand is a target, too,'' a diplomat said. $3 Million in Anti-Drug Aid Despite the increased flow of heroin from the region, the United States provides only $3 million a year in anti-drug aid to Thailand, down from $3.5 million in the 1989 fiscal year. The request for the 1991 fiscal year is $4 million. The money is used to help Thailand install computerized immigration checks, support raids on opium refineries and opium-crop eradication, help a crop-substitution program and finance some drug-treatment centers.
Given that less than 2 percent of the region's opium is grown in Thailand but that most of it is shipped from here, the aid is being focused more on improving customs checks and police training.
The major increase in opium cultivation is taking place in Myanmar and Laos, two of the world's most isolated countries. The Laotian Government, which the United States has in the past accused of involvement in drug production, agreed only last month to start a crop-substitution program, with an initial American commitment of some $200,000 in aid.
A $6 million- to $8 million-a-year program to aid Myanmar's military Government in crop eradication was suspended along with all other American aid and loans in September 1988, after a bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. That aid was in part siphoned to other military uses and only held down the rate of increase in opium production.
But some members of Congress, like Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, argue that with opium cultivation in Myanmar ''out of control,'' the aid should now be renewed, despite objections to the regime on human-rights grounds and some evidence that the Burmese Government is itself involved in the drug trade to boost its tiny foreign-currency reserves.
 
Productions Rising Sharply
Western experts say that depending on the growing season, which runs through March, at least 2,600 metric tons of raw opium will be produced in the Golden Triangle and perhaps as much as 3,000 tons, producing 300 tons of heroin. Even the lower figure represents an increase of 44 percent over two years ago, much of it coming from Myanmar.
Western experts estimate that about 2,200 to 2,600 tons of opium will be produced this year in Myanmar, compared with 2,000 tons last year and about 1,600 in 1988. Thailand will produce about 50 tons, about the same as the last two years, but only a third of the 150 tons produced in 1970.
The estimated figure this year for Laos is between 300 and 400 tons. Last year, the estimate was between 200 and 300 tons, and the year before that, between 100 and 200 tons. But Western experts say no one really knows for sure.
With the increase in heroin production, Thailand's role of regional entrepot is drawing more criticism.
 
Concern in Congress
Last month, a delegation of congressmen led by Representative Rangel, chairman of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said here that Congress was ''concerned about the explosion of opium and heroin coming through Thailand.'' He said, ''We are losing the war on heroin, and we are losing this war in Southeast Asia.''
Representative James F. Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, said Thailand risked becoming ''stigmatized'' internationally as a major drug center, like Colombia. Like Colombia, too, he said, Thailand also risked becoming a further focus for well-armed and well-financed drug syndicates that might threaten the stability of the state.
The reaction from a Government spokesman, Likhit Hongladarom, was both sharp and defensive. Members of Congress would do better advising the American Government on how to cut demand for drugs than seeking to discredit Thailand, Mr. Likhit said.
''To avoid disrupting bilateral cooperation on narcotics,'' he said, ''we hope the U.S. Government will come up with a more friendly and constructive way to enhance our joint efforts in controlling the drug situation.''
 
U.S. Indicts Thai General
While the Thais will act swiftly when presented with a case against an official built by a foreign government, diplomats say, few prosecutions are developed domestically.
Last July, an American grand jury indicted Maj. Gen. Vech Pechborom of the Thai police on four counts of heroin trafficking, alleging that he allowed heroin to move through Don Muang Airport here. General Vech has been suspended while the Thai police investigate, a process that is nearing completion, officials say.
''The Thais have been very cooperative on this one,'' a Western diplomat said, adding that they had rejected opportunities to drop the case or to reassign investigators challenged by General Vech.
But officials from Singapore and Malaysia, which have harsh laws against drug trafficking and use, complain that the Thais will not extradite any Thai national. Nor does the American-Thai extradition treaty allow the extradition of Thais.
Thailand also lacks a narcotics conspiracy law, making prosecutions difficult against anyone higher than a courier actually caught with drugs, and does not allow the seizure of assets garned from drug trafficking, two prime complaints made by American and other Western officials.
Lieut. Gen. Chavalit Yodmani, director of Thailand's Office of Narcotics Control Board, says such laws are coming after a draft receives a proper interdepartmental and Cabinet review. He stresses the new efforts being made to disrupt international trafficking, with a significant increase in the amount of heroin seized in 1988, the continued replacement of opium poppies by more profitable crops in Thailand, and a new drug rehabilitation program.
 
Arrests Called Ineffective
But according to the United States Government's ''International Narcotics and Controlled Substances Review,'' the amount of heroin production and refining in Thailand itself has been increasing, unmatched by ''corresponding interdiction success'' by the Thais, with the largest part of narcotics arrests made for possession and consumption. From January to May of 1989, the percentage of those arrested for production, trafficking or export of narcotics was less than 8 percent. In addition, the review says, ''corruption and lack of a conspiracy law hinder effective enforcement.''
In addition to the heroin from Southeast Asia, the illegal drug market in the United States imports heroin from Southwest Asia, mainly from production areas in Iran, Iraq and Afganistan, and from Mexico.
Federal studies indicate that there are nearly a half million heroin users in the United States and about six million cocaine users.
The sharp increase in the supply of heroin, combined with excellent quality, has meant both a small drop in price and a large increase in the purity of the drug bought on American streets, resulting in more deaths from overdoses. Western experts also say a combination of heroin with crack cocaine is becoming increasingly popular among American drug users, easing the depression that normally follows a crack cocaine high. Drug users are also combining heroin with amphetamines.
''The focus in America is on cocaine,'' a senior Western diplomat said. ''But more heroin is coming in, and it's killing people, too.''

HEADLINE: No Perrier? A Status Bubble Bursts

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

 BODY:
Page Lee, a 27-year-old aerobics instructor at the Body Bank in Washington, felt this way: ''I am really bummed!''
On the other hand, George Tyson, a shopper at Rice Food Market in Houston, felt this way: ''Anything with a name I can't pronounce, I don't drink.''
Restaurants and stores all across America packed up their Perrier yesterday after 72 million bottles of the fashionable water were recalled when benzene was discovered in some samples. And the country seemed to divide into two sorts of people: those who mourned and those who gloated.
There was much discussion of how America would survive the great Perrier drought, which a company official in Connecticut said would last two to three months. 
 
Tony Little Green Bottles
''An entire class of people have just had their weekends ruined,'' said John Buckley, a Republican consultant in Washington, who was interviewed while grumpily clearing six pear-shaped green bottles from his refrigerator.
Wendy Wasserstein, the New York playwright, exclaimed upon hearing the news: ''Oh, this is terrible! It's the end of an era. We'll all have to go back to Scotch.''
The news hit with a shock because Perrier has become more than a mere product in the American marketplace. The tony little green bottles of French sparkling water, which sell for up to $3.50 in restaurants, have become the most vivid symbol of the status-minded and health-conscious lifestyle of the baby boom generation.
 
End 'With a Bubble'
It was not exactly the end of history for the yuppie set, who had helped turn ''nature's soft drink'' into a multimillion dollar fad, but it was close.
''Whoever thought the yuppie era would end not with a bang but with a bubble?'' marveled Christopher Buckley, a magazine editor and John Buckley's cousin.
Those who were not mourning included Scott Brannon, the manager of Buck's Underground restaurant in Atlanta who proudly counted himself and his customers in the column of Americans who would not suffer pangs of Perrier withdrawal.
''Frankly,'' he said, ''our clientele is more the beer-in-a-long-necked-bottle type.''
Bo Petersen, a resident of Dallas, N.C., echoed many others interviewed when he said he had been suspicious all along of a product that looked and tasted like water but cost as much as a drink of alcohol. ''You might have known this would happen when it started bubbling,'' he said. ''I wouldn't drink the stuff myself.''
In California, there was also gloating, with many of the trend-setting residents of Los Angeles explaining that they had long since given up on Perrier, since it was considered too common.
''It hasn't been hip for a while,'' said Daniel Huntoon, the manager of Hugo's Restaurant, where celebrities can often be seen sipping bottled water. ''We serve Ramlosa instead because it's a smaller bottle with less water for the same price, so we make even more money than with Perrier.''
 
Capping a Series of Indignities
In Washington, young professionals complained that the recall capped a series of indignities they have suffered over the past few years. It seemed that every trend they adopted turned into a cliche and every attempt to live pure, healthy lives was sabotaged by some new health scare.
Fred Khedouri, an investment banker in the capital, agreed, ''I have a vision of hands reaching out for a cocktail but frozen at mid-grasp, seized with a new fear.''
Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said he had been worried about fluoride in tap water and had just decided to start consuming Perrier but now was nervously waiting to see what would happen with the bottled water. ''Personally, I am not going to be satisfied until thousands of rats have consumed millions of bottles of Perrier and survived.''
As yuppies poured their Perrier down the drain and debated the merits of Pellegrino water versus Ramlosa, they wondered whether the recall might be a defining moment. Would they finally learn that life, despite all attempts to control it, can never be risk-free? Would image and status cease to be of such overriding importance in their lives?
''Those who live by the image perish by the image,'' warned Michael Kinsley, the columnist and television commentator. ''At this rate, in another month, we'll be back to burgers, fries and a Coke.''
Those who were mourning the news of the possible contamination of Perrier included Sally Quinn, the journalist and novelist who was planning a Saturday night Valentine's party at her Georgetown home. ''I am sitting here staring at a case of Perrier and wondering if I lie and tell the guests that it's Saratoga water,'' she mused, before the party started. ''I think the answer is yes.''
Not everyone credited the new health threat. For instance, Bruce Ames, a professor of biochemistry at the University of California at Berkeley who is an expert in toxins, argued that ''we have to stop getting completely hysterical about all these hypothetical risks.''
But for many people in a generation that has focused on fitness and health, the news was discouraging and reminiscent of a scene in the Woody Allen movie, ''Sleeper.'' When Mr. Allen's character suddenly finds himself 200 years in the future, scientists explain to him that they have learned that life-preserving properties are not found in wheat germ, organic honey and tiger's milk, as previously thought, but in deep fat, steak, cream pies and hot fudge.
 
What Are We Supposed to Do?'
''First they tell us mother's milk causes cancer,'' fretted Jonathan Pizer, a resident of Chicago's north side. ''Then they tell us oat bran really doesn't reduce cholesterol. Now they tell us Perrier contains benzene. What are we supposed to do?
''It's Reagan's fault,'' Mr. Pizer added. ''I don't know how, but it is.''
Aside from any possible health risks, however, some people took the recall as a sign that, as Gertrude Stein once observed, affectations can be dangerous.
Fritz Streiff, the maitre d'hotel at Chez Panisse in Berkeley, said he was going to begin to rid his restaurant of Levissima, Evian, Crystal Geyser and Perrier. ''We've been looking forward to eliminating imported bottle water from our menu for some time because of its pretention,'' he said. ''It seems to me that moving water from one continent to another is one of the sillier things we do. Nothing's safe. We're better off having local water.''
If the French brand was already considered passe on the West Coast, superseded by Swedish and Italian rivals, it was had still been reigning supreme in the East.
Damien Palladino, the manager of the Palm Restaurant in Washington, where bottles of Perrier are kept on every table, was shocked to hear the recall news this afternoon from a reporter. ''Oh, gosh, maybe I should give Perrier a call,'' he said, as he went to retrieve the outstanding bottles from lunch tables.
Bruce Snyder, the vice president of Manhattan's 21 Club, called it ''by far'' the most popular bottled water with his customers, who like to mix it with bourbon or Scotch.
''They'll probably drink another bottled water now, but I'll drink good old New York water as I always have,'' the 21 executive said proudly.
At Tavern on the Green, Arthur Greenan, the restaurant director, said customers who insisted would continue to be served Perrier. ''But the staff,'' he said, ''has been instructed to suggest an alternative.''

 BODY:

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Legacy From Photography's Mount Olympus

BYLINE: By Andy Grundberg

 BODY:
Of the score or more museum exhibitions organized in ob-servance of 150 years of photography, none has been more eagerly awaited than ''Photography Until Now,'' which opens next Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art. The anticipation is partly a matter of timing, since ''Photography Until Now'' is the last of the sesquicentennial shows to make an appearance. But it is also a reflection of the stature of the show's curator, John Szarkowski.
Mr. Szarkowski has been the director of the museum's department of photography for the last 28 years, and his influence on postwar American photography has been so profound as to be incalculable. His exhibitions, of photographers as diverse as Eugene Atget and Diane Arbus, have revised the photographic canon. His books, notably ''The Photographer's Eye'' (1966) and ''Looking at Photographs'' (1973), have enabled an ever expanding audience to see photographs as objects of delectation and wonder. Because of his refined eye and polished writing style, the Museum of Modern Art has been the Mount Olympus of the art of photography for most of his tenure. 
Today, at the age of 64, he is the most senior of the museum's department directors and one of the few on the staff to have worked under Alfred Barr, the museum's founding director. It is widely expected that he will retire soon, although he will not comment on the subject. But there is little doubt that his long career is now winding down, and the scope and conviction of ''Photography Until Now'' suggest that it may well be the crowning jewel of his legacy.
Unlike the most heralded photography surveys that appeared in American museums in 1989, ''Photography Until Now'' did not issue from a committee of curators. It is clearly the product of a single intelligence, one that has spent decades mulling over ways to best organize and explicate the photographic tradition.
The exhibition and the 343-page book that accompanies it were organized around one basic premise: that technology has been a motivating force in the development of the pictorial possibilities of photography. Mr. Szarkowski does not go so far as to suggest that technology determines the difference between, say, Edouard-Denis Baldus's view of the Pont du Gard in mid-19th-century France, taken with a glass negative, and William Wegman's diptych of his dog Man Ray, made with a 20-by-24-inch Polaroid camera in 1982. (Both works appear in the show.) But he does say, in the book's introduction, that he has ''attempted . . . to sketch out a history of photographic pictures, organized according to patterns of technological change.
''The word technology here refers not only to the chemical and optical issues often thought of as constituting photographic craft,'' he continues, ''but to methods of distribution of photographic imagery, economic constraints, and professional structures.''
In an interview conducted in his office early this month, he said that the notion of doing a history of photography first occurred to him 15 to 20 years ago, as a result of conversations he had with the art historian Beaumont Newhall. Mr. Newhall, who was the museum's first photography curator, wrote what has become the standard English-language history of photography, ''The History of Photography From 1839 to the Present.''
In Mr. Szarkowski's eyes, the Newhall history and all subsequent histories that have been modeled on it lack a consistent underlying theory that would account for the medium's development. He notes that Mr. Newhall's pioneering work is ''one of the great achievements in 20th-century art history,'' but adds, ''If you took me to a torture room, I'd have to say it has too many chapters, and they are too discrete. His chapter 'Documentary Photography' doesn't really touch on the one called 'Straight Photography.' ''
While there are 16 chapters in the fifth edition of Mr. Newhall's book, Mr. Szarkowski has been content with seven. They range from ''Before Photography,'' which recounts the invention of the camera obscura and Renaissance perspective, to ''After the Magazines,'' which contains the curator's views on photography as recent as Nicholas Nixon's 1988 portrait of a man with AIDS.
The common thread that connects Mr. Nixon's picture with an 1850 daguerreotype, Mr. Szarkowski argues, is their dependence on technology. ''The one thing everybody is affected by is the nature of the mechanical conditions,'' he said. Even self-consciously artistic photographers like Alfred Stieglitz and Paul Strand, he believes, did not ignore the technology of their time. They rebelled against the growing domain of photomechanical reproduction, he says, by producing pictures that defied the halftone processes then available.
''I'm not trying to tell the history of photographic technology,'' he added. ''I'm trying to tell the story of photographic pictures. But as an organizing principle it allows you to talk about all photographers at once.'' The show's 275-odd pictures include anonymous portraits, advertising images and scientific documents as well as canonical works by well-known art photographers. To the curator, ''it's all one piece of cloth.''
To those acquainted with Mr. Szarkowski's exhibition record, his organizing principle may seem to be merely a confirmation of his lifelong conviction that the art of photography is fundamentally different from other means of making images. (Indeed, he once wrote an article for this newspaper titled ''A Different Kind of Art.'') His thesis, one could say, is a restatement in historical terms of his belief that photography's status as an art rests with its distinct formal qualities.
This belief was first spelled out in his 1966 book ''The Photographer's Eye,'' which has proved to be immensely useful as a primer for appreciating photographs. In words that still ring with conviction, Mr. Szarkowski enunciated his belief that photography is ontologically distinct: ''The invention of photography provided a radically new picture-making process - a process based not on synthesis but on selection. The difference was a basic one. Paintings were made . . . but photographs, as the man on the street put it, were taken.''
The rest of ''The Photographer's Eye'' is divided into sections called ''The Thing Itself,'' ''The Detail,'' ''The Frame,'' ''Time'' and ''Vantage Point'' - precisely those aspects of photography that, in Mr. Szarkowski's view, make it unique.
During the last 10 years, this view has come under increasing attack. Photographers who have sought to connect their work to issues of concern to painters and sculptors, and artists who have come to photography from outside its historical traditions, disavow Mr. Szarkowski's insistence on photography's individuality. Many young scholars and critics argue that photography's real importance is a matter of its social functions and representations, not of any inherent qualities individual photographs may possess.
The conflict between these views and Mr. Szarkowski's is fundamental, and it no doubt explains why the curator remains lukewarm at best toward much recent vanguard art that employs photography. He even admits to being baffled by the term post-modernism; in an interview with Carol Squiers in the February issue of Elle, he remarks that it ''must mean a great deal more than what I understand it to mean.''
Mr. Szarkowski's understanding of post-modernist uses of photography may be greater than he lets on. ''Photography Until Now'' includes the work of Robert Cumming, Cindy Sherman and William Wegman, but his ambivolence has made the Museum of Modern Art less of a force in photography today than it was in the 1960's and course; critics of the museum have complained for years that the institution has lost touch with the vanguard of painting and sculpture as well.
Unlike Mr. Newhall's history, ''Photography Until Now'' does not seem to culminate in the present, and there is little sense of progress in its closing chapter. ''I think there is a lot of uncertainty and angst in photography today,'' Mr. Szarkowski said, noting that he sometimes wishes he could have been a photographer in the late 19th century. ''But there is also a lot of vitality and talent.''
He does not believe that television has altered late-20th-century photography in the same way that halftone printing did in the late 19th century. ''What's good in television relates to movies, to theater. It relates to a different series of precedents, not to what we think of as picture making,'' he said. This puts him squarely at odds with critics who believe that television and photography have worked together to create a ''simulacrum,'' or hollow model of reality - a view that is expressed in ''Image World: Art and Media Culture,'' the Whitney Museum of American Art's somewhat jaundiced tribute to photography, which closes next Sunday.
In the final analysis, however, curators are mainly measured by their exhibition records, and by this standard Mr. Szarkowski must be accorded a place alongside Alfred Barr. Among his most important and best-known shows are ''New Documents'' (1967), which introduced Diane Arbus, Lee Friedlander and Garry Winogrand; the Arbus retrospective of 1972; ''From the Picture Press'' (1973); ''William Eggleston'' (1976), and ''The Work of Atget,'' which appeared in four parts from 1981 to 1985. A few of his efforts have falled short of their ambitions, notably the 1978 show ''Mirrors and Windows: American Photography Since 1960,'' but on balance his exhibitions have been conceived and executed with uncommon skill.
Mr. Szarkowski was a 35-year-old photographer with two Guggenheim fellowships under his belt when he was hired to take Edward Steichen's place at the Modern in 1962. Today, he looks back fondly at his early days at the museum. ''It was fun then,'' he said. ''You could do two one-man shows a year, and most of them had never been done before.'' Now, he remarked, almost all major photographers have had at least one museum exhibition devoted to their work, so the challenges are different.
Observers inside and outside the museum speculate that the person most likely to succeed Mr. Szarkowski is Peter Galassi, a curator in the photography department. (According to museum procedures, Mr. Szarkowski's successor will be chosen by a search committee to be named when he retires.) Mr. Galassi, 38, has the proper credentials: he studied art history at Columbia under Kirk Varnedoe, now the director of the museum's department of painting and sculpture, and he has organized two exhibitions with provocative art-historical implications: ''Before Photography'' and ''Henri Cartier-Bresson: The Early Work.'' In ''Before Photography,'' Mr. Galassi argued that the visual appearance of 19th-century photographs was anticipated by paintings; in the Cartier-Bresson show he contended that the French photographer's best work had its roots in Surrealism, not photojournalism.
If Mr. Galassi's ideas about the medium's nature and its past do not precisely coincide with Mr. Szarkowski's, his ambitious curatorial style may. What remains to been seen is whether any inheritor of the photography world's most prestigious post can match Mr. Szarkowski's eye for pictures and his instinct for spotting young talents like Arbus, Eggleston, Friedlander and Winogrand.
 
 
THINKING IN NUANCES
 John Szarkowski's influence as a curator has been considerably enhanced by his writing talents. His cadenced, mellifluous prose complements the nuanced, metaphoric quality of his thinking, as these excerpts from ''Photography Until Now'' suggest. On the medium's origins: ''It would be simple enough . . . to trace the long line of optical and chemical observations and experiments that provided the technical basis on which the inventors of photography depended. The more difficult question is: from where, and how, did the idea evolve that one might catch a picture in a net, as one might catch not only the butterfly but the piece of sky in which it flew?'' On the multiplicity of photography's inventors: ''There were other inventors and possible inventors and would-be inventors whose names at least we know, and sometimes more. And the experimenters whose names we do not know might make an even longer list, and they also may have undermined their health, squandered their fortunes, neglected their families, and compromised their ethical principles to bring into existence this interesting new tool, even though it now seems unlikely that anyone could have held it back.''
On the state of photography today:
'' . . . only a generation earlier photographers still thought they had a privileged access to truth and thus to power. Not many years ago this perception was proven false, but perhaps it was false before it was proven so. Perhaps nothing of consequence was lost - only an illusion.''

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
The Lure of Fordism, Jazz and 'Americanismus'

BYLINE: by Michael Kimmelman

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
''Envisioning America'' at Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum may be the latest foray into the subject of art and American popular culture, but the works of Barbara Kruger, Jeff Koons, Cindy Sherman and Laurie Anderson are nowhere to be found. Andy Warhol's name is never evoked.
This is a show about art and American politics but Hans Haacke isn't here, and neither, for that matter, are the Guerrilla Girls or Gran Fury. It is a show that deals with such issues as capitalist expansionism, racism and jingoistic fears of being overrun by a foreign economic and technological power, but Japan certainly never crossed the minds of the artists whose drawings, prints and photographs are on view. 
''Envisioning America'' is, in fact, about the art of Germany between 1915 and 1933, but it may be difficult for some visitors to pass through this perceptive and well-selected show without at least briefly musing on how strong are some of the ties between the works here and the works of such contemporary artists as Ms. Kruger, Mr. Haacke and Ms. Sherman.
This was hardly the exhibition's goal, of course. Beeke Sell Tower of the Goethe-Institut in Boston, with the assistance of Peter Nisbet, curator of the Busch-Reisinger Museum at Harvard, has assembled from public and private collections throughout Europe and the United States some 65 works by artists like George Grosz, Otto Dix, Max Beckmann and Josef Albers. She has chosen to focus on four themes that were of particular concern to these artists - the Wild West, the metropolis, politics and popular culture.
Evidently, America was not a country that German artists of the early 20th century had experienced first hand (Grosz moved to the United States only after the period covered by this show) but one they imagined from afar, a culture filtered through movies, magazines and books. America became for them a symbol of opportunity and modernity but also of greed, a country that could produce Chaplin, James Fenimore Cooper and Henry Ford as well as lynch mobs and gangsters. It was, in other words, a myth of shifting and contradictory dimensions.
Grosz and his Dadaist colleagues drew particular inspiration from advertisements and the mass media, and they conceived of their appropriations from American popular culture as assaults on so-called high art and on the bourgeois society that supported it.
They published Neue Jugend, a short-lived journal that appeared in 1917 and extolled the virtues of ''Americanismus'' by borrowing from American newspaper and magazine designs. They devoured Cooper's novels about the Wild West and attended every western that made its way into Berlin's movie houses. The images in these films of a vast and still untamed country appealed so strongly to Grosz, Rudolf Schlichter and several of their colleagues that they even took to dressing up in the guises of gold prospectors, cowboys and Indians. Germany represented a cramped and decaying civilization. The America they saw on the screen seemed to hold out endless possibility.
Which is not to say that they admired America unconditionally. Long before the invention of MTV, the tempo of American life was recognized and depicted by German artists as frantic and fragmentary. When Hannah Hoch constructed a collage in 1920 entitled ''Cut With a Kitchen Knife Through the Last Weimar Beer-Belly Epoch of Germany,'' she mixed German and American images in a furious, helter-skelter fashion that approximated a ragtime beat. When Grosz designed his lithograph ''Self-Portrait (for Charlie Chaplin)'' in 1919 he imagined an Americanized world that was a claustrophic jumble of strippers, boxers, cigar stands and smokestacks.
Particularly after World War I and with the role played by American businesses in the process of German restructuring, artists divided strongly on the issue of Americanism. To artists on the Left, especially, the United States embodied capitalism and mechanization in all its lowest manifestations. John Heartfield's dustjacket design of Upton Sinclair's book ''100 Percent,'' for instance, juxtaposed magazine photographs of the Ku Klux Klan with an image of a policeman hauling a worker to jail. Gerd Arntz focused on life in the American factory, where he imagined men were made to approximate machines. His ''Things American'' of 1924 featured a faceless chorus line near a hanged black man and what may be a speeding automobile. Grosz, for his part, moved from mixed admiration to occasionally outright hostility in his attitude toward America, as is suggested by a satirical depiction from around 1924 of a smug businessman before an American flag, entitled ''Soon Europe Will Be a Suburb of New York.'' News of the executions in 1927 of the anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti stirred Grosz to produce what may be his most melodramatic drawing, in which a bloodstained Statue of Liberty holds aloft an electric chair in place of the torch.
German artists, it must be said, were by no means above making racist asides in their works toward black musicians and minstrel singers. And there was, in their equation of Americanism with exoticism, a sense that the United States was a country of primitive peoples.
Yet even during the 20's and early 30's, aspects of American life continued to hold for German artists of all political persuasions an unmistakable allure. America may have been considered the cause of what came to be known derogatorily as Fordism, but it was also home to jazz. Perhaps no object symbolized contemporaneity more than the saxophone. Grosz and Dix and Paul Klee all saw in nightclubs and ragtime bands the most perfect embodiment of what Ms. Tower calls America's ''otherness.''
''Jazz,'' she concludes in the catalogue, ''was metaphorically burdened with all the ills of an America that seemed too fast, too mechanized, too uncultured, too alien to European minds. Conversely, it served as a manifesto of modernity and progress, especially among the young members of the postwar avant-garde.''
This point was obviously not lost on the Nazis, who chose to illustrate the cover of a 1938 catalogue of what they considered degenerate music with an image of a black saxophonist wearing a Star of David on his chest. Debates today over the influence of popular culture on art seem tame by comparison. In any case, as ''Envisioning America'' makes clear, they are nothing new.
The exhibition remains at Harvard through March 18. It will be at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art's Robert Gore Rifkind Center for German Expressionist Studies from April 19 to June 24.

HEADLINE: Bill Simon's Audacious S. & L. Gamble

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
William E. Simon has a problem, and true to the former Treasury Secretary's reputation, he has a rather audacious solution.
Honfed Bank of Honolulu, one of the savings and loans owned by the investment group Mr. Simon leads, needs a big injection of capital to meet the Government's strict new financial standards.
Mr. Simon's plan for dealing with the shortfall is one that no other institution in Honfed's condition could hope to pull off. He wants to raise the money from public investors willing to trade the considerable risks of the savings business for the chance to get in on a deal with him.
''Never before has the individual investor had the opportunity to invest alongside William E. Simon in a widely distributed public transaction,'' trumpets a promotional brochure prepared for the Honfed deal by the Wall Street firm of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. 
That Mr. Simon would even attempt a public offering astounds many analysts. Honfed, while profitable, is technically insolvent under the Government's new rules, although Mr. Simon's associates prefer the phrase ''capital deficient.'' And this being an era in which savings and loan failures and taxpayer bailouts dominate the headlines, Wall Street of late has not been willing to invest in any but the handful of most profitable savings institutions.
''The Simon name aside, the capital markets have been closed to marginal savings and loans, and my sense is that the Street is not going to be wildly enthusiastic about this,'' said Bert Ely, a savings and loan consultant based in Alexandria, Va.
Still, there is an undeniable appeal to the offer. Mr. Simon's investment record, extending back to the leveraged buyout of Gibson Greeting Cards, in which he turned $330,000 of his own money into a $70 million profit in 1984, is the stuff of legend.
Just last week, Mr. Simon agreed to sell First Interstate Bank of Hawaii, another piece of his nascent financial-services empire, in a deal that should allow him to pocket a profit of more than $20 million on a one-year investment of $15 million. Moreover, there are preliminary signs that Honfed could reap some big profits on its real estate holdings, helping its financial condition and allowing it to scale back the size of the public offering.
Mr. Simon declined to discuss Honfed while its offering is being reviewed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But, not surprisingly for a man who has never lacked confidence in his decisions, he expressed satisfaction with his investments in the savings and loan business, reiterated his faith in the industry's long-term prospects and dismissed the criticisms of those who do not look beyond the industry's current travails.
 
Raising Eyebrows
 ''People are slow in coming around to this kind of thinking,'' Mr. Simon said. ''It's the fellow at the head of the pack that people always raise their eyebrows about.''
People have always raised their eyebrows about Bill Simon. Despite the protests of friends and colleagues who admire his wit, charm and generosity, he has long been tagged as arrogant, impatient and ruthless, whether in exercising power in Washington or in adding to a fortune that Forbes magazine estimated last year at $300 million. His success over the last decade has brought carping, some of it no doubt the product of jealousy, that he gets too much credit for deals engineered by others or that his deals minimize his own risk while putting it squarely on others.
If nothing else, the Honfed situation may be the stiffest test yet of the Simon mystique. Mr. Simon's strategy for dealing with Honfed provides a look at how his current ventures operate and how he and his partners are trying to cope with the rapidly changing regulatory environment.
As one of a number of troubled savings institutions acquired in recent years with direct or indirect Government assistance by some of the nation's most sophisticated financiers, including Ronald O. Perelman and Robert M. Bass, Honfed also could eventually be another test of whether Federal regulators gave away too much to lure well-heeled owners into the industry.
That question was raised with new intensity earlier this month when the California-based American Savings Bank, acquired by the Bass Group with well over $1 billion in Government aid, reported record earnings of $214 million for 1989.
For now, it is far too early to speak of Mr. Simon cashing in with Honfed, Hawaii's largest savings and loan company. Indeed, his plans to wean Honfed back to health have been complicated by the sweeping legislation to reform the savings and loan industry passed by Congress last summer.
The Government, for example, has effectively rescinded an earlier agreement that exempted the institution from having to meet its capital requirements for several more years. The bottom line: the turnaround that the group hoped to accomplish over a 10-year period following its acquisition of Honfed in 1986 now must be completed in about half that time.
Meanwhile, Honfed's core earnings - those derived from the basic business of taking deposits and making home loans - remain weak.
Honfed was the first acquisition in Mr. Simon's plan to build a network of savings institutions, banks and other investment ventures around his grand if somewhat hazy notion of the Pacific Rim as the next great economic opportunity.
Along with outside investors, Mr. Simon's group is developing $800 million of commercial, residential and industrial property around the country. It has also set up small ''junk bond'' and venture capital funds and considered a host of corporate acquisitions outside banking.
 
Other Properties
 The group also owns a second small commercial bank, World Trade Bank of Los Angeles, in addition to First Interstate of Hawaii, which in the deal announced last week will be sold to the parent of the First Hawaiian Bank for at least $119 million.
And it owns two savings and loan companies besides Honfed. Two years ago it acquired Western Federal Savings and Loan, a healthy institution based in Los Angeles. At the same time, it accepted Government assistance to acquire Bell Savings, an insolvent institution in California, and then merged Bell into Western Federal. The group also acquired Southern California Savings and Loan, another formerly insolvent institution that is slowly returning to health.
The 62-year-old Mr. Simon, who has always prided himself on staying ahead of the investment pack, was one of the first to view insolvent savings institutions, acquired with some form of direct or indirect Government aid, as an appealing investment.
Mr. Simon got out of the leveraged buyout game in 1985 when he became convinced that the market was overheated and that the deals being offered to him no longer made economic sense. Spurred by friends and business contacts throughout Asia and Australia, he decided to develop a pipeline for Pacific Rim capital to flow into a variety of investments.
Working with Gerald L. Parsky, a Los Angeles lawyer who had been a top aide throughout Mr. Simon's years in Washington, he concluded that there were considerable values to be found in real estate and financial institutions. With Mr. Parsky as an equal partner, Mr. Simon formed WSGP International, an investment vehicle for them and a few close associates.
Mr. Simon plays the role of master strategist, puts up his own money for deals and opens doors to outside investors. Mr. Parsky is in charge of day-to-day operations and is the team's primary dealmaker and negotiator. To provide added clout and experience in the savings and loan business, the group brought in Preston Martin, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve and one-time chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, then the primary regulator of the savings industry.
When the group bought Honfed, called Honolulu Federal Savings and Loan at the time, they got an institution that had hit on hard times in the mid-1980's because of troubled real estate investments and loans.
As part of its acquisition deal with Mr. Simon's group, the Government agreed to write down the value of Honfed's real estate holdings by $107 million, effectively insuring that the new owners would not have to suffer losses when they eventually sold the real estate. In fact, the concession gave the investors a good chance of profiting if the market came back.
In addition, the Government agreed that Honfed could operate for 10 years without meeting the requirements for capital strength in effect at the time as long as it met certain other thresholds for stability. (That agreement, however, is no longer being honored by regulators.) In return, Mr. Simon's group injected $17.7 million of its own money as new capital and arranged for a $40 million junk bond offering to bolster the institution's capital even further.
Mr. Simon and Mr. Parsky believed that members of their group could offer expertise to the institution as well as capital. For example, Larry B. Thrall, a longtime real estate developer, was put in charge of selling Honfed's property, disposing of most of the holdings at significant profits.
To a certain degree, the Simon group's efforts have paid off. Honfed has posted profits each year since the acquisition - $15.5 million in 1987, $9.5 million in 1988 and $4.2 million through nine months of last year. But nearly all of the profits so far have come from real estate sales rather than sustainable core earnings.
The company's efforts so far to remedy that shortcoming have moved slowly. Honfed is making more mortgage loans, and has grown in size from $2.1 billion in assets at the end of 1987 to $3.1 billion last year. But because of the negative publicity surrounding the savings industry in general and the lingering questions among customers about Honfed's health in particular, the institution has had trouble attracting and keeping low-cost retail deposits. As a result, the company has started offering higher rates to attract ''jumbo'' deposits of $100,000 or more.
Honfed wants to reduce its reliance on expensive deposits by acquiring the 18 Hawaiian branches of First Nationwide Bank, the savings and loan company owned by the Ford Motor Company, for $11 million.
But, in another indication of how the Government's strict new rules have complicated Honfed's plans, Federal regulators will not allow Honfed to go ahead with the First Nationwide deal until it brings itself into compliance with the new capital requirements. As of Sept. 30, the most recent date for which figures are available, Honfed needed $73 million in new capital to reach the requirement for the most basic level of capital, known as tangible capital.
 
Question of Trust
 The public offering of preferred stock, should it succeed, would take care of the capital shortfall. Honfed is seeking to raise at least $90 million.
Whether the offering flies with investors will depend partly on the interest rate offered on the preferred stock, which has not yet been set. But it will also depend to a large extent on whether investors trust that Mr. Simon and his team can manage the risks of running even a well-capitalized savings institution.
Mr. Simon has some persuasive arguments in his favor. A recent appraisal of Honfed's real estate valued it at $68 million more than the value on the institution's books, suggesting that significant profits can still be reaped from property sales. Moreover, Honfed has actually received offers on two pieces of property for prices that would yield gains $30 million higher than the appraisals. If things go just right on the real estate deals, Honfed could conceivably even drop the public offering and raise a smaller pool of money from private investors who have backed some of the group's past deals.
Perhaps more important for investors, there are signs that Honfed, if it can be recapitalized and made consistently profitable, would become a logical takeover candidate, raising the possibility of big profits from any sale.
 
Period of Consolidation
 Indeed, the financial services industry in Hawaii is going through a period of consolidation. The proposed sale of Mr. Simon's First Interstate Bank to the First Hawaii Bank is not the only evidence of that. The state's largest bank, the Bank of Hawaii, agreed recently to acquire the state's second-largest savings institution, First Federal Savings, for a sizable premium over its book value.
Mr. Simon's other savings institutions, meanwhile, are in somewhat better shape. Western Federal is profitable, and while slightly undercapitalized, should soon be able to meet the Government's requirements. Southern California Savings needs $30 million in additional capital. But the institution is steadily becoming more profitable.
For his part, Mr. Simon keeps spreading the word that savings and loans are not the sinkhole that the conventional wisdom holds them to be, and he has gained some converts. His group has already persuaded one pension fund, the Los Angeles County Employees Retirement Association, to commit $150 million to a fund that will make acquisitions of small, healthy institutions.
''Core earnings have to be raised in several of our institutions, but basically they're fine,'' Mr. Simon said. ''As of right now I'm pleased with everything we own and I'm confident that significant profits will be made from owning them.''
 
 
MR. SIMON'S EQUAL PARTNER
The headlines say Bill Simon. But Mr. Simon has always worked closely with others who deserve at least equal credit for his successes. And in his current endeavor, his primary partner is Gerald L. Parsky, a longtime friend and associate who is largely responsible for running the operation.
Mr. Parsky is an equal partner with Mr. Simon in WSGP International, the merchant bank that serves as the parent company for all of their ventures. An energetic, affable 47-year-old whom Mr. Simon describes as his best friend, Mr. Parsky oversees their farflung investments from WSGP's headquarters in Los Angeles while Mr. Simon works primarily in New Jersey, where he lives.
''He and I have a complete understanding of each other,'' Mr. Parsky said. ''That's the reason he can be on his boat or on safari in Africa and know that things are being taken care of.''
Mr. Parsky graduated from Princeton University and the University of Virginia Law School. He went to the Treasury Department in 1971. By 1974, at the age of 30, Mr. Parsky found himself serving Mr. Simon, who was then the Treasury Secretary, as an Assistant Secretary, the youngest person ever to hold that post.
When the Ford Administration ended, Mr. Parsky considered going into business with Mr. Simon, but decided that he wanted to make a mark for himself on his own. So he joined the Los Angeles law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, where by the mid-1980's he had risen to senior partner.
In 1985, when Mr. Simon again proposed going into business together, Mr. Parsky agreed. Today, he somehow manages to juggle his responsibilities at the law firm with running WSGP.
''Bill has a wonderful ability to sense markets and opportunities,'' Mr. Parsky said. ''But he would be the first to admit that there are times when he is impatient getting from point A to point B. I'm a little more patient.''
 

SAFARIS AND SAILING
At age 62, Bill Simon says he still feels young, and he is certainly enjoying life. He recently returned from a safari in Africa, he spends considerable time sailing his yacht and he combines his frenetic business life with a welter of charitable and social obligations.
He gives his time and money to such diverse organizations as the University of Rochester, which renamed its business school after him several years ago in return for a large contribution, and Covenant House, the shelter for runaway children in New York that is enduring an investigation into alleged sexual misconduct by its founder.
While he never shirks the limelight, he has always been mystified by the attention and criticism his business activities and his volatile personality have drawn. He says he has never believed in the legend of his own investment prowess, preferring to think of himself as a canny businessman blessed with smart partners.
''It's as if making money had become pejorative,'' he once said. ''Big is bad and all that. But I am what I am and I'm not ashamed of it.''
