PUB-DATE: February 11, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1924 words

HEADLINE: Why Foreign Presence at Treasury Auctions Is Overrated

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Four times a year, the Treasury Department sells billions of dollars in notes and bonds to raise money to finance the budget deficit. Before each auction, the cry goes out that the securities could be hard to sell because the Japanese may be reluctant buyers, either because they are annoyed with Americans or are attracted to better investments elsewhere. And four times a year, the handwringing turns out to be unwarranted.
That was very evident last week at the Treasury Department's auction of $30 billion in long-term securities. The four major Japanese brokerage houses - Daiwa, Nomura, Yamaichi and Nikko - offered to buy their usual 30 percent and, just in case they faltered, cash-rich American investors turned out in strength as eager buyers. The Treasury's auctions, in fact, often run counter to the prevailing view that Americans have wastefully spent more money than they possess and therefore must rely on foreigners to help cover the shortfall. The budget deficit has become the symbol of that shortfall. 
Despite the handwringing over the Japanese, many economists say foreigners have no choice but to participate in the Treasury auctions. If they did not, they would end up hurting themselves more than the United States. And even if foreign lenders - and in particular the Japanese, who are the biggest outside buyers of Treasury securities - didn't show up, Americans have enough idle cash in their bank accounts to have purchased all $30 billion in 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities auctioned last week. The only question, just before the auction, was how high interest rates might have to go to get Americans to do all the buying, without Japanese help. The answer from many experts was that the pre-auction rates of 8.5 percent or so on 10-year notes and 30-year bonds were high enough. Indeed, the American interest made the bidding at last week unusually heavy, experts say. Between $1.80 and $3 was offered for each dollar of securities auctioned.
Such strong interest in buying Treasury securities reflected the fact that Americans are flush with lending power, in large part because a weak economy has reduced demand for loans to finance commercial investment. Data assembled by Salomon Brothers and by Henry Kaufman, an economic consultant, show that business borrowing - corporate bonds, high-risk ''junk bonds,'' bank loans and commercial paper sales - have fallen to $9 billion in January, from $20 billion a month on average in 1989. Consumer borrowing is also softening.
''The demand for credit in the United States is clearly slowing,'' Mr. Kaufman said. Still, even if Americans did not have the wherewithal to finance their own spending, the Japanese - and the Europeans, for that matter - would have found themselves constrained to purchase Treasuries. They have accumulated billions of surplus dollars from the sale of their exports to Americans.
Their only alternative to investing the surplus money within the United States is to convert it into Japanese yen or West German marks. But that would drive down the value of the dollar and, in turn, the value of their growing American assets.
Suddenly, a German-owned company such as Hoechst Celanese would be forced to reduce the value in marks of its textile fiber factories in the American South. And Rockefeller Center, purchased by Japan's Mitsubishi Estate Company, would be worth fewer yen. The landmark was recently acquired for $840 million, or 119 billion yen, when the dollar was worth about 142 yen, but would be worth only 100.8 billion yen if the dollar fell to, say, 120 yen.
''To say that the rest of the world may stop lending to us is to misdescribe that situation,'' Francis M. Bator, an economist at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, wrote recently in Foreign Affairs. ''Literally, it cannot. As long as it sells to us more than it buys from us, it is stuck with lending back to us the excess dollars.''
So why all the fuss by Wall Street analysts and the media over Japanese intentions? Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate in economics, says they are simply perpetuating a myth. David R. Jones, senior economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a bond brokerage house, says the reasons are mostly psychological and political. ''I guess in some sense there is this perception that this Japanese money can't stay here forever, and the next auction is the one where we are going to lose it,'' he said. ''It is a real fear.''
That concern was greater than usual before last week's three-day auction, which concluded on Thursday. Interest rates on Japanese and West German bonds, which compete for the same pool of capital as American securities, have risen sharply. While the 10-year United States Treasury note, for example, now yields 8.3 percent, the similar German security has risen more than one percentage point since Christmas, to 7.9 percent. The Japanese 10-year bond is up a similar amount, to 6.3 percent.
Such sharp increases raised concern that the worldwide pool of savings - European, Japanese and American - might be drawn away from this country. That prospect helped push up the interest rates on United States Treasury securities. The 10-year Treasury note, for example, rose from less than 8 percent at Christmas. ''A big factor in this sharp rise was fear that the Japanese would not participate in the Treasury auction,'' said Sam Nakagama, of Nakagama & Wallace, a Wall Street investment firm.
But other factors besides comparative interest rates affect investment decisions. A major one is whether inflation will eat away at interest payments. Wall Street's views change constantly, but some current thinking maintains that inflation may be peaking in America while it rises in Germany and in Japan, making United States securities even more attractive.
If that weren't enough to ease the fears over Japanese intentions, the mechanics of the auction itself should have been. Neither the Japanese nor the American brokerage houses bidding at these auctions retain much of what they buy. Seeking quick profits, they resell most of their new holdings as fast as possible to all comers, regardless of nationality. Daiwa Securities America Inc., for example, purchased $900 million worth of 10-year notes on Wednesday and quickly resold between $300 million and $400 million of them to Americans, according to William Brachfeld, Daiwa's executive vice president.
The goal of this trading is not to preserve for Japanese investors the 30 percent share of the Treasury securities purchased by the four Japanese trading houses, but to resell, say, a $100 bond purchased at a discount of perhaps $99, for $99.12 or $99.24. Strong demand last week made such profits possible.
Because of this trading, it is difficult to assess the participation of the Japanese or any other investors. For instance, Salomon Brothers, a major American bidder at the Treasury auction, resells securities to the Japanese. And those Treasury securities that are resold to Japanese back home often end up in the hands of Tokyo bond dealers who resell them internationally, said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa.
''I think there is a lot of malarkey out there about what is going on and what is not going on,'' said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities Inc. ''At any one moment, we simply never know how much of the securities we acquire are in Japanese hands or in foreign hands.''
Notwithstanding all the shuffling, some foreigners do end up holding Treasury securities over the long term. Mr. Brachfeld estimates that about $1.2 billion of the $10 billion in 10-year notes auctioned Wednesday will find a home with a Japanese household or corporation. (The 10-year note is the most popular Treasury issue among Japanese.) That pattern roughly mirrors the percent of all United States Treasury securities held by foreigners, which has remained almost unchanged through the 1980's despite the concern over foreign participation in the quarterly auctions. Of the $3.47 trillion in outstanding Government securities at the end of last year's third quarter, foreigners held $384.6 billion, or 11.1 percent, the Federal Reserve reports. That is up only slightly from 10 percent in 1983. The British were the big foreign investors at Treasury auctions in the early 1980's, but the Japanese have been since 1985.
Rather than worry about whether the Japanese, the British, the Germans or any other foreign buyers will continue to purchase Treasury securities, helping to finance the budget deficit, the real issue is actually whether the United States is becoming too dependent on foreign holdings of all its financial assets - stocks, corporate bonds, Government securities, corporate commercial paper, some bank deposits and the like.
The nation's pool of these assets totaled $9.7 trillion as of last September, with foreign holdings accounting for $748.1 billion, or 7.7 percent. That is almost double the 4.3 percent in 1983, but still a small enough sum to disappear without much notice if these foreign holdings were liquidated slowly, over a period of several years, said Russell Scholl, a Commerce Department economist.
''If foreigners tried to pull out their money quickly, they would have no trouble creating a disaster,'' Mr. Scholl said. ''The motive might be to hurt the United States, but the Japanese and the Europeans would end up also shooting themselves in the foot.''
 
 
GAUGING THE EFFECT OF A JAPANESE 'STRIKE'
 
Once, in 1987, the Japanese almost did pull out of American Treasury securities. The Reagan and Nakasone Administrations were feuding over Fujitsu Ltd.'s attempt to purchase the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, and the American Government had accused Japan of dumping computer chips in the United States at unfairly low prices.
The reaction came in the spring, when many private Japanese investors halted new purchases of Treasury notes and bonds, funneling money instead into Japan.
But the Japanese Government stepped in at the auctions. The Bank of Japan purchased dollars from its reluctant citizens and invested them in Treasury securities, almost offsetting the shortfall created by the private sector, which stayed mostly on the sidelines until fall. As a result, foreign holdings of all Treasuries fell to 9.7 percent in 1987, the lowest level of the past seven years, but still only slightly below the annual average of 10.1 percent for that period.
Nicholas Sargen, vice president for bond research at Salomon Brothers, believes the ''strike'' added perhaps one percentage point to long-term rates; others say perhaps 2 percentage points. But a couple of factors complicated the measuring process. While private Japanese investors prefer long-term securities, the Bank of Japan purchased mostly short-term Treasury bills, which should have dampened short-term rates.
But a counterforce was at work: the Federal Reserve, led by Paul Volcker, was raising American interest rates to curb inflation - and both short- and long-term rates responded to the Fed's efforts.
Whatever the pressures, the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 7.81 percent in late March of 1987, from 7.45 percent early in the month, and then rose steadily to a 10.2 percent on Oct. 16, the eve of the stock market crash. ''The 1987 experience would certainly say that there could be upward pressure on interest rates if the Japanese pulled back,'' said David R. Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston, a bond brokerage house. ''But the magnitudes are hard to pin down.''

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Camden Zero-Coupon Quandary

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Underwriters and lawyers agree that the Camden County Municipal Utility Authority bond issue now being marketed to investors across the country is one of the most unusual refinancing deals the tax-exempt market has seen in years.
But they agree on little else about the New Jersey county's offering, which is being sold at a time when the interest-rate climate has made refinancing issues of any sort relatively rare . Is the Camden issue, as its defenders say, an ingenious innovation that can help hard-pressed communities ease their debt-service costs? Or is it, as some critics charge, a deal that creeps so close to the edge of Federal tax rules that it will bring a backlash of new regulations from Washington?
The legal debate comes down to this: How much interest income is the Camden authority permitted to earn on the revenues that it will free up as a result of having refinanced its pre-existing debt? 
Just as homeowners may take advantage of lower interest rates to refinance their mortgages and cut their monthly payments, the authority is trying to reduce its debt service costs by selling $115.8 million in new bonds, called the 1990A Series, and setting the money aside to pay debt service on older, more expensive bonds sold in 1987. (In addition, it has raised $121.7 million in 1990B Series bonds to replace some short-term notes, a straightforward transaction of little interest to bond lawyers.) There is no dispute over how much interest the authority can earn on the money it is setting aside to service its earlier debt. Washington has stringent rules to prevent municipalities from reaping arbitrage profits by raising money at low tax-exempt rates and investing it at higher rates. Under these anti-arbitrage rules, an agency that sells 7 percent municipal bonds today cannot earn more than 7 percent interest on those escrowed funds. Doing otherwise could endanger the bonds' tax-exempt status.
But in the Camden issue, designed by investment bankers at Butcher & Singer in Philadelphia and First Fidelity Bank in Newark the authority has sold zero-coupon bonds that require no debt service at all until 1998. (Zero-coupon bonds pay no annual interest, but are sold at prices substantially below their face value, so that the investor profits from the difference between the purchase price and the final maturity value.) As required, the authority will invest the 1990A Series proceeds in an escrow account - let's call it Account A - with a yield matching that on the newly sold bonds. It will use that fund to pay the debt service on the old 1987 bonds for the next seven years.
But - and this is the ''but'' that worries some lawyers - the authority also plans to deposit all the general sewer-system revenues it otherwise would have spent to pay debt service on the 1987 bonds into a new investment fund - call it Account B. And the money in Account B is invested at a yield higher than that on the 1990A bonds.
Come 1997, the first date on which the old 1987 bonds can be redeemed, the authority has the option of using Account B to pay off those bonds or to build part of its still-incomplete sewer system. Is the arrangement a good one? George Tuttle, the First Fidelity investment banker who worked with Butcher & Singer on the deal, defends it as ''an efficient structure that saves the authority $9 million. The way you handle the tax issues is to make sure you have the highest quality legal advice, and that's what we did.''
But the normally polite bond counsel community, the lawyers who review municipal bonds to insure that they qualify as tax-exempt investments, is deeply divided on the question. ''We have put in enough controls to satisfy us and, I think, to satisfy others,'' said Matthew Lewin, a partner at Chapman & Cutler, in Chicago, which has reviewed and approved the Camden structure. ''But, yes, there are a significant number who would not share our opinion.''
Underwriters at a few large Wall Street firms report privately that their own bond lawyers have doubts about the approach, , which Mr. Lewin attributed to their unfamiliarity with the specifics of the deal.
The complex refinancing approach and the exclusive reliance on zero-coupon bonds make the Camden issue ''the kind of deal that investment bankers will put into their files for future reference,'' said Kurt van Kuller, a managing director of Lebenthal & Company in New York. But his own impressions? ''Well, frankly,'' he said, ''it seems very squirrely to me.''
In his view, the authority's Account B bears a strong resemblance to invested sinking funds, a once-popular bond financing technique that fell into disuse when the Federal rules against excess arbitrage were strengthened in 1978.
''The lawyer says that this does not have the 'excess arbitrage' features of invested sinking funds,'' said Mr. van Kuller. ''But if I were a large institutional investor, I'd have a legal staff on retainer working with me to check into these issues. . . . and that's expensive.''
But the real cost of this financial innovation goes far beyond legal fees, warned Sam Katz, the co-chief executive at Public Financial Management in Philadelphia, a large public finance advisory firm. ''We're entering a period when the Congress and the Internal Revenue Service seem inclined to correct some of the public finance problems caused by their past overzealousness,'' Mr. Katz said. ''When people push the envelope to the very limit, it portrays our industry as one that is unprepared to live within the rules.'' And that, he said, ultimately could saddle all public borrowers with new rules that would make it more cumbersome and expensive for everyone to finance essential public projects.
Despite these worries, the Camden deal has come to market at a time when zero-coupon bonds are both extremely scarce and increasingly popular among people planning for retirement, say, or college tuition bills.
But Mr. van Kuller said he would not be surprised if, given the questions surrounding the structure, the price on the bonds dropped a bit to produce a higher yield for buyers. ''The market doesn't always solve these problems,'' he said. ''But it always adjusts to them.''
 
DESPITE CORPORATE PROGRESS, A STOCK STILL SLEEPS
 
The stock market, jittery about the ''junk bond'' market and all the companies that borrow there, paid little attention last week when the Kroger Company announced that it had ended 1989 with less debt and lower interest rates. Kroger's stock closed the week up just a few cents, at $13.50.
At that price, the stock looks like a bargain to some analysts. Charles E. Cerankosky of Prescott Ball & Turben in Cleveland notes that the company's improved financial prospects are already reflected in the prices of its junk bonds. ''Obviously the bond market sees an excellent investment here,'' he said.
Edward Comeau, a food industry analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, said the stock's problem is probably rooted in the market's current intolerance for debt. Given that mood, and tighter food industry margins this year, he is not recommending the shares right now. But, he said, patient investors could find that the shares have ''good upside potential.''

HEADLINE: Business Diary/February 4-9

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
The Rush Toward a Single Mark
 
East and West Germany are hurtling toward monetary union. Not even the opposition of West Germany's central Bundesbank or East Germany's elections March 18 appear likely to block a speedy agreement. On Tuesday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany called for immediate talks; the very next day, his Cabinet set up a unity committee. Karl Otto Pohl, president of the Bundesbank, said the rush to a single currency would wound the West German economy without substantially aiding East Germany. The central bank usually has final say on monetary matters. But East Germany's economic decline has been so rapid, with such a vast exodus to the West, said Norbert Walter, senior economist for Deutsche Bank A.G., that ''this time, the bank will lose.
 
*
 
Setting the exchange rate would be the most crucial decision for East and West German officials if they try to unify the currencies. The official rate is one to one, the unofficial rate is six West German marks to one East German mark. Valuing the West German mark too high would destroy the worth of East German savings. But over-pricing the East German mark would keep the country's wages and goods from being competitive. East German unemployment and emigration would continue, and a lack of investment from the West would result. 
 
 
The Communist Fairy Tale
 
Soviet Communist Party leaders agreed on Wednesday to surrender their monopoly of power and acknowledged that the nation and its economy had been grievously mismanaged. The Communists had constantly invoked Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels to justify their rule. But Marx and Engels themselves wrote that Russia was one of the last places where they expected a revolution to lead straight to successful socialism. They did root for revolutionaries everywhere, and predicted a peasant revolt in Russia. But Engels in particular attacked ''the illusion that it will be possible to guide this revolution into a smooth, constitutional channel.'' When Pyotr Tkachov, a Russian revolutionary, said the Russians were ''the chosen people of socialism,'' Engels ridiculed his claim as a ''fairy tale'' and ''sheer bounce.''
 
 
No Trade Deficit in Tourists
 
The United States has found one import that actually eases the trade deficit: foreign travelers. Last year, for the first time, foreign visitors spent more in the United States than Americans spent abroad. The Commerce Department expects the surplus to grow from $450 million last year to $1.5 billion this year and more in the future. Don Wynegar, the Department's research director for tourism and travel, said the weak dollar and strengthening economies abroad allow more foreigners to vist the United States.
 
 
ressure on Panama
 
Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega may be out of Panama, but its new Government is resisting United States pressure to tighten banking laws that have made it a drug-profit haven. Many senior Panamanian officials, though never accused of laundering money themselves, have had strong ties to corrupt banks. One-Way Soviet Trade United States trade with the Soviet Union is likely to increase dramatically. But most of the traffic will be one-way, with United States exports rising much more than imports. An Administration official said last week that he expected trade to increase from $2 billion or $3 billion annually to at least $10 billion in about three years. Talks to end American discrimination against Soviet imports begin Monday. But imports are unlikely to rise because Soviet oil and platinum already come in with normal tariffs. The Soviet Union is likely to increase imports of United States consumer items, food-processing equipnment and medical supplies. Lower trade barriers will bring United States consumers one payoff: $1.25 less for a bottle of vodka.
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
 Relief Over 'High' Inflation
 
Seldom has such a huge jump in the Producer Price Index left the economists so relieved. January's 1.8 percent jump was the largest in 15 years. But the core inflation rate, without food and fuel, rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, the best performance since July. A cold December resulted in a record 13.6 percent increase in energy prices, and food rose 2.1 percent. ''It's clear we have a seasonal problem, and that's likely to subside after a month or two,'' said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. He said the Federal Reserve Board has achieved its goal of lowering wholesale inflation and might ease credit during the second quarter.
 
 
$30 Billion Success Story
 
The success of the Treasury Department's quarterly auctions last week aroused investors to bid up prices for Government securities on Friday. Yields had risen in anticipation that investors would be reluctant to bid during the three-day, $30 billion sales. On Friday, investors rushed to lock in yields, driving the rate on the 8.5 percent 30-year bond auctioned the day before to 8.33 percent.
 
 
Bailing Out of the Bailout
 
The head of the agency overseeing the savings and loan bailout resigned Friday. Daniel P. Kearney said he was leaving as president of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Company because he had not won enough authority to carry out his duties. His departure raised doubts about the progress of the Bush plan to clean up the industry.
 
*
 
 Bartenders, artists, oil drillers and dentists, beware. All are among dozens of occupations quietly blacklisted by health insurers. Congress and the President are at work on bills to expand access to health insurance.
 
 
 
COMNPANIES
 
The Home Field Advantage
 
Notre Dame's football team aims to score as much off the field as on come 1991. The university said Monday it had cut a five-year deal for NBC to broadcast all its home games for at least $1 million each. Now, several other schools say they also might seek their fortunes by breaking with the College Football Association, which recently signed a $210 million, five-year contract with ABC. Special Situations in the QuarterEveryday low pricing has yet to yield much more everyday profit at Sears, Roebuck & Company. Fourth-quarter operating income, reported last week, was up only 1.4 percent to $817.7 million. Net income rose more than fivefold to $602.1 million, primarily because Sears had taken a $712.4 million charge in the fourth quarter of 1988 for the new pricing policy.
 
*
Eastern Airlines sold its shuttle and sold its Latin American routes, but still has heavy losses. As a result, its parent company, the Texas Air Corporation, lost $362.8 million in the fourth quarter, after a $224.4 million loss a year earlier.
 
*
 
Salomon Inc. is best known as a securities firm, but its Phibro Energy subsidiary carried the company through the fourth quarter last year. The securities business made just $1 million, while the energy unit earned enough to earn the company $68 million - in contrast to a $38 million.
 
*
 
The Eastman Kodak Company blamed reorganization costs for a $60 million fourth-quarter loss.
 
 
Accounting for Shamu
 
To Sea World visitors, Shamu looks like a killer whale. To Anheuser-Busch accountants, she looks like a depreciable asset. Busch acquired about 15 whales when it bought five Sea World aquarium parks from Harcourt Brace Jovanovitch Inc. last year. Harcourt's accountants considered Shamu and her companions long-lived if not immortal; they were was going to stay on Harcourt's books at the same value year after year. The Busch accountants, however, figured out a whale's lifespan, and as the years dwindle, so will a killer's value.
 
 
Speaking of Sales . . .
 
You bought the clothes, now buy the stores: Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field & Company were put up for sale last week. B.A.T. Industries, the stores' London-based parent, wants more than $1 billion for each to help defend against Sir James Goldsmith's hostile takeover bid.
 
 
A Plea and a Set of Fines
 
 Young & Rubicam Inc., one of the nation's largest advertising agencies, pleaded guilty Friday to a single charge of taking part in a conspiracy to bribe foreign officials in winning the Jamaican tourism account. The agency agreed to pay a $500,000 fine. In return, the Government agreed to drop other charges.
 
*
 
The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday ordered two Nynex Corporation subsidiaries to pay $1.4 million in fines, comprising the largest penalty ever imposed on a regulated telephone company. The commission said the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone Company had illegally inflated profits at the expense of customers.

HEADLINE: All About/The Tire Industry;
Decreasing Demand and Global Competition Propel Consolidation

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio

 BODY:
A decade ago, a dozen major tire manufacturers, half of them American, vied for world leadership. Today, just six giant companies, one in the process of formation, are dominant. The only one based in America is the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
Consolidation has come about because of slackening demand and global competition. With long-lasting radials accounting for 93 percent of new tires, motorists buy fewer replacements. Weak demand has forced companies to invade one another's territories. And as the auto industry becomes more global, auto makers favor huge tire companies that can fill their needs anywhere. 
In the last five years, foreign companies have bought out most of the best-known American labels, including Firestone and Armstrong. The agreement five months ago by Groupe Michelin of France to buy the Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company will create the world's largest tire maker - if, as expected, American antitrust regulators approve. In the United States, aside from Goodyear, only the smaller Cooper Tire Company remains independent.
Goodyear, the leader for decades, is contending for second place with the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan, which two years ago bought Firestone. Next come West German Continental A.G., which bought General Tire; Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy (Armstrong), and the Sumitomo Tire and Rubber Company of Japan (Dunlop). Two smaller Japanese makers, the Yokohama Rubber Company and the Toyo Tire and Rubber Company, are both concentrated in the Far East.
Consolidation has intensified competition to cut production costs and increase quality. The industry has become surprisingly high-tech, spending more than $1 billion on research and development last year, up by one-third from five years ago.

 
The Research
 
Now It's Microchips Instead of Road Tests
At Goodyear's vast research and development center in Akron, the rubber meets the microchip before it meets the road. Rows of technicians at computer work stations design tires. They test them with programs that seem like video games. On screen, cars whip through courses with potholes, ice slicks and hairpin turns. A decade ago, designing a tire for a new automobile model required testing 200 to 300 tires. Today, it takes about 65. ''In the last few years, tire designing has moved from an empirical art to a science, because of the computer,'' said F. Vincent Prus, Goodyear's executive vice president for research and development.
The major tire companies are spending freely on research and development. They are buying computers to test tire durability, traction, fuel efficiency, compatibility with new car designs and even noise. Analysts consider Goodyear the research leader. The company spent $300 million on research and development last year, or 3.5 percent of revenues - up from 2.5 percent five years ago.
Companies are also using research to cut costs, especially for original equipment, the tires that auto makers buy for new cars. Although original equipment sales account for just a quarter of production, nearly 70 percent of consumers replace their tires with the brand that came with the car. Since auto companies want a distinctive tire design for each new model, tire makers are striving to develop lines more quickly. Goodyear says computer-aided design helped cut development time from 117 weeks in 1980 to 65 weeks last year. The goal: 20 to 25 weeks by 1995.
 
 
The Chemistry
 
Exotic Synthetics Mean More Mileage
 Tire company executives say the public believes their jobs are no more complicated than pouring molten rubber into molds. ''Outside of the industry, I don't think anyone really understands how much effort goes into making a tire,'' said Frederic J. Kovac, Goodyear's vice president for technology. Tires are actually built, not molded, from a combination of natural and synthetic rubber wrapped around polyester and steel.
Rubber chemistry has become much more complex since the day 151 years ago when Charles Goodyear invented strong, vulcanized rubber by accidentally dropping sulfur and crude rubber onto his stove. Tire company chemists now stir up exotic synthetic rubbers to improve traction on wet streets without sacrificing fuel efficiency.
Steel belts - actually steel and polyester woven into a tough fabric - have been improved as well. The average radial tire lasts 50,000 miles; the average bias tire of 20 years ago lasted 18,000 to 20,000 miles. James A. Thiese, director of passenger and light truck tire development for Firestone, credits the work of the chemists: ''That's what now allows a tire to perform with the same efficiency in 20 degree-below-zero weather as it does in 95-degree heat.''
 
 
The Auction Block
 
Pirelli Looks Like The Next Takeover
 As huge as the world's six major tire makers may be - each with billions in sales - further consolidation could be coming. ''I fully expect that there will be what we call marriages of the elephants in the industry,'' said Wilhelm Borgmann, vice chairman of Continental. The companies face increasing pressure to raise research spending and spread their factories and sales forces across several continents.
Analysts say the most vulnerable major company might be Pirelli, one of the best-known names in Italian industry. Despite its purchase of Armstrong, Pirelli, with revenues of $3.3 billion last year, is only a third the size of Michelin. Pirelli has no significantpresence in Japan and ranks no better than second in any European country except Italy.
Acquiring Pirelli would would require the blessings of both the Pirelli family, which holds a 5.3 percent stake, and the leading Italian industrialists who control 57 percent. But matchmakers abound.
''A Goodyear-Pirelli merger would make sense in many ways, especially from Pirelli's viewpoint,'' said Dennis M. Byrne, a professor of economics at the University of Akron.
Harry W. Millis, an analyst at McDonald & Company in Cleveland, matches Pirelli, which is strongest in southern Europe, and Continental, stronger in the north. And he plans to maintain his merger watch. ''It's not certain who will acquire whom, but it's pretty clear that the consolidation is not over yet,'' Mr. Millis said.
 
 
RUNNING DESPITE A FLAT
For years, the ''run-flat'' tire promised to be one of the industry's greatest innovations: a tire that could run firmly on its rim after the air had leaked out. But by the time Continental A.G. of West Germany announced last year that it had developed the first one, the industry yawned. Analysts explain that consumers are less concerned about driving on flat tires since improved steel reinforcement has made flats less likely. Auto makers - who once wanted to cut weight and increase fuel mileage by eliminating the spare - appear less conservation-minded. ''No one among the auto companies seems to be all that concerned about sqeezing out a little bit more weight right now, at least in that form,'' said Harry W. Millis, an analyst with McDonald & Company.
The Continental run-flat tire can ride 200 miles after losing air. The tires are mounted on rims that have broad steel wheels sitting inside the rubber. A set of run-flats is slightly heavier than normal tires, but lighter than four tires and a spare.
No other tire maker is about to market run-flats. But Continental expects strong demand, starting with the makers of luxury cars. ''We're working with original equipment manufacturers to get the project going,'' said Wilhelm Borgmann, the company's vice chairman, pausing for effect. ''Mercedes will be first.''

SECTION: Section 3; Page 16, Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Cool Judgment, Hot Results

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Ken Oberman, manager of Oppenheimer & Company's Global Fund, keeps several cartoons taped near the computer in his crowded New York City office. One depicts the late Andrei Sakharhov as a diminutive figure on one end of a seesaw upending a massive stone monument of Stalin. Another shows Lech Walesa and asks: How many Poles does it take to change the world? (Answer: One.) But the shifting international scene provides more than just wry humor for the 59-year-old Mr. Oberman. The lessons he draws from it have paid off handsomely over the years.
His growth-oriented fund was last year's big winner among global funds. It was up 35 percent, against a 17 percent gain in Morgan Stanley's Capital International World Index, which measures equity performance of companies in Europe, the Far East, Australia and New Zealand. Over five years, it beat the index, too, and in the last 10 years, ''Oppenheimer Global has been the No. 1 global fund,'' in performance, said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services. In that period, Mr. Oberman matched the Morgan Stanley index and beat all equity growth and global funds. 
''Most money managers don't beat the market averages most of the time,'' said Spero L. Kripotos, vice chairman of CDA Investment Technologies Inc., a financial services firm in Rockville, Md. Added Mr. Lipper Mr. Oberman ''is one of the most thoughtful managers in the mutual fund business.''
A former student of economic history, Mr. Oberman is a self-proclaimed ''oddball'' among international money managers. He reads Abraham Lincoln, not ''Liar's Poker.'' He doesn't travel much for business, nor does he try to go after the hottest international markets or the trendiest stocks.
''Making the first money is easy,'' said Mr. Oberman, who has been picking stocks or managing money for the last 27 years and managing Oppenheimer Global since the early 1980's. ''The real question is picking companies with long-term potential. That takes time.'' ''There aren't any secrets,'' he added. But there are strategies. He seeks out undervalued issues around the world, and then tries to double or triple his money over three to five years. To limit the differences in accounting and tax policies among nations, he evaluates stocks by looking at cash flow from current operations after accounting for taxes.
Most international money managers look at the world on a country-by-country basis, and now, of course, they are hot on Eastern Europe. But Mr. Oberman hasn't bought a ticket to Budapest. He invested in West Germany long before the Berlin Wall crumbled. And with one-third of his portfolio in Scandinavian stocks, his fund, in jest, has been called the ''Fjord Fund.'' His theory: There is little payoff in chasing new markets. ''Change is constant,'' he says.
Rather, he looks for stocks that fit what he calls his ''themes.'' While those themes keep shifting to account for new developments, some - like health care - have been on his list since the early 1960's. His favorite stocks, of course, overlap categories.
Besides health care, the themes that he thinks will yield superior growth in this decade are energy, Europe 1992, perestroika, specialized communications, capital goods and the environment. ''It's easy to talk about technologies but that can be changed overnight,'' he says. ''But the question of ecology is a question we'll be dealing with until we kill or save ourselves.''
He has one more category, called ''hobgoblin,'' from the Ralph Waldo Emerson line that reads, ''A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds.'' The hobgoblin sector enables Mr. Oberman to maneuver in case he sees a company he likes that doesn't fit into one of his themes.
His current hobgoblin holding is Bombardier Inc., the Canadian transportation company. He says he likes it because it is diversified within the transportation industry and because its two aircraft manufacturing companies are performing well.
What was his biggest triumph? Buying into D.D.L., the Danish holding company that owns more than a quarter of the Scandinavian Airline System. In 1982, Mr. Oberman read the earnings forecast of S.A.S.'s president and realized that D.D.L.'s stock was selling at one-half of projected earnings instead of what he thought should have been five times earnings. He sold the stock six years later at 22 times his investment. And that, he said, was also his biggest mistake: D.D.L.'s price has almost tripled since then.
The fund's largest holding is a Swiss company, Brown Boveri, which joined forces with ASEA, of Sweden, to become the world's largest electric equipment manufacturer. The company touches on four Oberman themes: capital goods; Europe 1992 (it builds locomotives for European railways), energy (it produces hydroelectric systems) and perestroika (it owns a majority stake in a big Polish electrical equipment company).
Looking forward, he believes the hottest market of the 1990's will be West Germany, where he likes Mannesmann, a tool and heavy-equipment company; M.A.N., a truck maker, and Schiess, a machine tool company.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Funds Should Flex Their Muscle

BYLINE: By JAY W. LORSCH; Jay W. Lorsch, a professor at the Harvard Business School, is co-author of ''Pawns or Potentates: The Reality of America's Corporate Boards.''

 BODY:
Last month, two of the nation's largest pension funds took the unprecedented step of trying to confront the corporate lion in his den. Worried about the long decline in the fortunes of the General Motors Corporation, the heads of the California and New York public employees' pension funds wrote to G.M.'s directors and asked how a successor would be selected when Roger Smith, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, retires this year. These two pension funds, which have major investments in G.M., urged the directors to mount a broad search and asked to be consulted as goals were formulated for the new chairman and chief executive. 
G.M.'s first response to the requests was a polite rebuff. This is not surprising in view of our recent study of outside directors in America's largest public companies, which indicated that the real king of the corporate jungle is the chairman and chief executive - the same person in 83 percent of the companies studied. If the G.M. directors are like their peers on other boards - and I suspect they are - they lack real power, compared with management, to implement major changes. This power imbalance has created an unwritten code of conduct that undermines directors in wielding their influence, which stems in large measure from their numerical superiority. Despite the fact that they outnumber the chairman/chief executive, directors who criticize or openly challenge the ideas of this officer do so at the risk of being expelled from the group, as Ross Perot was at G.M. three years ago. Furthermore, discussing important issues in the absence of the chairman/chief executive is considered bad form, as is any attempt of a director to assume a leadership role. These good manners, however, often lead to bad management, since they hamper directors in assessing the performance of the company and the chairman/chief executive. Unable to unite as a group, outside directors do not challenge management or initiate changes in corporate direction in an effective and timely manner.
Another taboo for directors is open discussion of their objectives. And many of them are confused about the changing laws governing their responsibilities. They feel a conflict between their understanding of their legal obligation to maximize shareholder value and their personal concern for the company's long-term welfare.
The confusion is heightened by the fact that in most companies a majority of shares is owned by institutions. Directors believe that unlike the New York and California pension funds that wrote to G.M., many institutional investors are playing financial games - buying shares one day and selling them the next - with no interest in a company's long-term prospects. This, and the stock market's casino mentality, makes it hard for directors to define shareholder interest.
The status quo must change - and can change - so boards have the power to govern. One action, which has so far been unpalatable to many business leaders, is to separate the positions of chief executive and chairman of the board. Such a step would give boards the independent leadership to act quickly and decisively (especially when the chairman/chief executive is part of the problem), to deal better with sudden crises, and to address festering issues before they become serious. When then-chief executive Ross Johnson attempted a leveraged buyout at RJR Nabisco Inc. in the fall of 1988, for example, the chairman of the company, Charles Hugel, quickly organized the board, which rejected the bid.
A more modest step, and one that the chairman/chief executive might find more palatable, would be for outside directors to elect a ''principal director'' from their group, who would step forward only if the chairman/chief executive were incapacitated or if the directors thought the chairman/chief executive were incapable of providing the necessary leadership.
Responsibility for improved corporate governance also lies with state and Federal policy makers, who need to recognize that further thought and action is needed to provide a constructive framework for the 1990's. Unless markets and laws consistently encourage managers and directors to focus on long-term corporate health, rather than just short-term profits, American companies are doomed to a diminished position in the world economy.
Institutional investors, like the pension funds in California and New York, are correct to be concerned about the fate of America's great companies. The answer, however, is not for them to become directly involved in governance, but to join in creating stronger boards.

HEADLINE: Currency;
The Dollar Slips a Little More

 BODY:
The dollar lost more ground last week as the West German mark rose because of euphoria over the sudden acceleration of negotiations for a common currency for East and West Germany. The current wor ries about higher interest rates and a slumping bond market in West Germany should only weaken the mark temporarily. The Canadian dollar continued to tumble, finishing the week at 83.2 cents against the American dollar, its lowest level since the summer. The Bank of Canada, which set off the decline by signaling a month ago that it would ease interest rates because inflation had come down, stepped in to give the dollar a boost by lifting its key interest rate to 12.79 percent, the highest level since 1984.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1532 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How Latin America's Economies Look After a Decade's Decline

 BODY:
AFTER a decade in which average incomes fell while foreign debt and inflation soared, Latin America remains in deep economic crisis. The future of its new democracies may well rest on the ability of civilian leaders to improve living standards in the 1990's as they try to modernize their economies in the face of enormous obstacles.
The crisis, which began in the 1980's when interest rates shot up and prices for export commodities fell, is continuing even though some countries in recent months have managed to earn more from exports and thus improve their trade balances. Forces working against advancement include high inflation, which forces some countries to take steps that limit growth, and high debt burdens, which cut into the amount of money that might be available for new investment. Hopes that the United States would deliver substantial relief from the debt burden through a plan announced last year by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady have dimmed. Even though interest payments may be eased and some principal may be reduced, new banking regulations have made it less attractive for international banks to extend new loans.
Here is a look at the economies of some important Latin American countries. 
 
MEXICO
Swapping Debt for Hope
Under President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who took office on Dec. 1, 1988, the country has begun a turnaround from the stagnation and contraction that began in 1981, when Mexico's oil boom collapsed. Last year inflation, which reached 160 percent in 1987, was brought down to just under 20 percent, and for the first time in 10 years the economy expanded more rapidly - at 3 percent -than did the population.
Mexico has also been reducing its foreign debt. From a 1987 high of $107 billion, the total declined by about 10 percent even before a debt reduction agreement was signed on Feb. 4 with the country's commercial bank creditors. Finance Minister Pedro Aspe has estimated that the agreement has cut the debt to $80 billion.
Still, Mr. Salinas faces difficulties in his efforts to modernize the Mexican economy with such measures as trying to sell state-owned airlines, utilities and food companies - steps intended to reduce the national budget deficit and make the enterprises more competitive. One problem is that tariff reductions, also supposed to force domestic producers to become more competitive, have for the moment helped to push up imports instead; this has worsened Mexico's foreign trade balance and eaten into reserves. In addition, a hoped-for boom in foreign investment has not materialized. Some analysts say that if such trends continue, Mexico could be forced back to the negotiating table with its bank creditors.
 
ARGENTINA
Big Promises
Argentina is battling inflation, which totaled nearly 3,700 percent in 1989, while struggling to reorganize an economy marked by low productivity, corruption, a bloated public payroll, the flight of capital, large deficits and endemic tax evasion. President Carlos Saul Menem took office in July having promised an ambitious modernization. But his plans to privatize state companies, reform the tax code and bring order to the financial system carry with them the discipline of a strict austerity that is only beginning. Efforts to keep wages in check are threatened by resistance from labor unions, and efforts to control inflation by swapping short-term savings certificates for long-term bonds have eliminated the public's willingness to lend money to the Government.
In a departure from Argentine tradition, two television channels were sold to private interests. But privatization and deregulation in other areas, such as the selling of an unprofitable telephone company and railroads, will be tougher and slower. Argentina is trying to attract more foreign investors, but without much success. The outlook for the major export, grain, seems good, but the prospects for diversifying exports are mixed. While Argentina has a promising future as a wood, cellulose and paper producer, its chances with other manufactured goods are hampered because most industry is accustomed to producing overpriced second-rate goods for a protected internal market.
The foreign debt of about $65 billion is the third highest in the region; Argentina has paid no interest on the long-term portion for nearly two years and has no immediate prospects of doing so. Instead, it is desperately seeking new loans and credits from the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and the United States to stabilize the foreign exchange rate.
 
CHILE
Austerity's Payoff
Chile is reaping the benefits of tough austerity and free-market changes imposed in the mid-1970's by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who is to cede power in March to an elected President, Patricio Aylwin. Mr. Aylwin will inherit a deficit-free Government and an economy that has had five years of strong growth. Exports are surging as a result of diversification into fruit, fishing and forestry, and of relatively high prices for copper, Chile's most lucrative product.
The foreign debt, which in 1987 approached $21 billion, has been cut to about $17 billion; reserves bought back some of the principal at discount, and interest payments are on schedule. Chile expects to return to voluntary credit markets next year.
There is evidence that the poor and lower middle class have not benefited as much from the growth as the rich. A challenge for Mr. Aylwin will be narrowing that difference without hurting the economy.
 
BRAZIL
Enormous Debt
With Latin America's largest economy, Brazil is beginning the 1990's with elephantine problems - an inflation rate of 1,765 percent for 1989, economic growth that barely keeps up with population growth and a foreign debt of $110 billion, the largest in the third world. The Government stopped paying interest on the debt last July, and, as one result, received only half of expected foreign credit. The United States Export-Import Bank has demoted Brazil to the bank's riskiest loan category.
Fernando Collor de Mello, who takes office on March 15 as Brazil's first popularly elected President since the early 1960's, won on a platform of support for free markets, privatization, foreign investment, antitrust legislation, prison terms for tax cheats and generous debt relief. Business leaders are enthusiastic.
 
VENEZUELA
The Price of Change
Venezuela, Latin America's largest oil exporter after Mexico, is struggling to recover from deep recession; in 1989, the gross domestic product plunged 8 percent. President Carlos Andres Perez largely created the recession with a drive to reshape the state-dominated economy along free-market lines. He has cut subsidies and tariffs, encouraged foreign investment, put state companies up for sale and started talks on debt relief with foreign bankers. One goal is to lure back an estimated $60 billion in capital that has been sent abroad.
The austerity required to carry out the changes set off riots in Caracas a year ago in which about 300 people died. An inflation rate of 80 percent also contributed to a poor showing of Mr. Perez's party in 1989 elections. Mr. Perez has sought to soften the blow by creating public works programs and unemployment insurance. A recent rise in oil prices has provided some relief.
 
ANDEAN NATIONS
Terror Raids the Markets
Terrorism and investor nervousness hobbled growth in 1989 in Colombia and Peru, the two largest economies of the Andes.
Colombia, where inflation has traditionally been low and the foreign debt manageable, is suffering from a war by cocaine traffickers against the Government. The violence has provoked flights of capital and professionals. While the world focused on the country's cocaine exports, Colombians complained that their legitimate exports -coffee, flowers and bananas - were being hurt by higher tariffs and lower prices. In addition, leftist groups have been attacking coal mines and oil pipelines.
Peru rivaled Argentina for the continent's worst economic indicators of 1989: 2,775 percent inflation and a 10 percent drop in growth. Investors have been frightened off as Peru struggles against leftist guerrillas. As in Brazil, many people are betting on a free-market advocate: Mario Vargas Llosa, who leads all opinion polls as the April presidential election approaches. He proposes radical changes and has vowed to reduce inflation in his first year in office to 10 percent by cutting public spending and by selling off state enterprises.
Avoiding the wild swings of their neighbors, Ecuador and Bolivia experienced social peace, and modest growth and inflation in 1989. They have joined, to differing degrees, in Latin America's drive for private enterprise. But for both, real growth will continue to depend largely on prices for mineral exports - tin in Bolivia and oil in Ecuador. Bolivia, where consumer prices rose 8,170 percent in 1985, has tamed inflation - it was 16 percent last year - but at a huge cost. Public spending was drastically cut and government services reduced, and most state-run tin mines, which had been operating at a loss, were closed. Private mines were allowed to remain open.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 835 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
On Drugs, Bush Aims for a Meeting of the Minds, at Least

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF all goes according to plan, President Bush will fly to Colombia this week and join the leaders of that country, Peru and Bolivia in forming an alliance to wage the war on drugs. But the session is unlikely to resolve deep-seated differences between the United States and the Latin countries.
The United States, a huge consumer of illicit drugs, emphasizes law enforcement: the destruction of coca and marijuana crops and the interdiction of narcotics before they enter this country.
Colombia, Bolivia and Peru will emphasize their need for economic assistance not only to combat drug traffickers, but also to provide alternative employment for the many people who depend on the cocaine economy. 
The basic elements of the agreement to be signed this week in Cartagena, the Colombian resort city, were worked out last month in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, by officials from the four countries.
Mr. Bush and the three other Presidents - Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia, Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia Perez of Peru - will agree to exchange information and cooperate in the investigation and prosecution of narcotics cases. But Bush Administration officials say the spirit of cooperation will be more important than the text of any agreement.
The draft agreement addresses many of the Andean countries' concerns by promising increased aid for crop substitution and job creation. But it remains for Mr. Bush to overcome the bitterness that lingers over the United States invasion of Panama in December.
Colombian protests have already forced the Administration to put off plans to deploy an aircraft carrier near the coast of Colombia to intercept drug shipments. In addition, Mr. Garcia originally threatened to stay away from the meeting to protest the invasion. Now he plans to go, having been reassured by Mr. Bush's promise last month that the invasion force would be withdrawn from Panama ''well before the end of February.'' So even as he offers to lead an international war on drugs, Mr. Bush will try to avoid doing anything in Colombia that might stir nationalist resentment.
The conference itself will last less than six hours. American officials say it symbolizes the Bush Administration's commitment to work closely with the three Andean countries, which produce the raw materials for most cocaine smuggled into the United States.
Whatever that commitment, the Andean countries have deep concerns of their own that they intend to raise.
 
Harvesters and Gunmen
Patricia Ardila of the Panos Institute, a private group in Europe and the United States that studies third world environmental and economic issues, estimates that 1.5 million people in Peru, Bolivia and Colombia benefit from the cocaine economy as farmers, hired hands, harvesters, refiners, middlemen, transporters, buyers and gunmen.
''Countries such as Bolivia must receive substantial development assistance,'' said Carlos E. Delius, who served as the Bolivian Ambassador to the United States in 1988 and 1989. ''It is foolish to expect any government to win this war if its only mission is to rip up coca bushes.''
The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which oversees government operations, said in a report last week that the United States has often failed to coordinate antidrug efforts and economic policy in the Andean region. ''As eradication and interdiction efforts succeed,'' it said, ''hundreds of thousands of subsistence-level peasants will have to find another way of earning their living. If there is nothing in place to assist them, they are likely to become prime candidates for insurgent groups.''
In Peru, that has been happening for some time. ''Eradication efforts have driven the coca growers into the arms'' of Maoist guerrillas ''who have adeptly exploited the fact that this U.S.-inspired program threatens the peasants' existence in a time of extreme economic hardship,'' the report said. Peru's Ambassador to the United States, Cesar G. Atala, said it might make sense for the United States and Western Europe to establish a fund to buy up and destroy coca produced in the Andean nations.
American officials say President Barco of Colombia will appeal to Mr. Bush to support negotiations on a new agreement to regulate the prices of coffee, a vital legitimate crop for Colombia. Bogota's Ambassador to Washington, Victor Mosquera Chaux, said the breakdown last year of an international agreement that regulated coffee prices caused those prices to plummet, costing Colombia $500 million a year.
The Andean countries may also ask Mr. Bush to support debt relief. Bolivia and Colombia paid the United States more in interest and principal on their debt than they received in antidrug assistance in 1988. Since then, Washington has increased aid for military equipment and training to fight drug traffic. State Department officials say the United States will provide a total of $2 billion in military, economic and law-enforcement assistance in the next five years.

LENGTH: 903 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Taxes Give the Democrats One More Identity Problem

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposed cutting the Social Security tax, some party consultants seized on the idea as a brilliant political weapon. Here was a Democratic tax cut for the 1990's that was fairer than the Republican tax cuts of the 1980's. At the same time, the proposal revealed two facts of Republican fiscal policy: that cuts in the progressive income tax had effectively been paid for by increases in the regressive payroll tax, and that the proceeds were being spent like any other revenues rather than being socked away.
Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill got together last week to consider how to handle this political opportunity Mr. Moynihan had handed them. But soon they were devoured by concerns. They worried about the loss of revenue and the deficit. They feared that Republicans would use the plan to paint Democrats as a threat to Social Security - exactly as Democrats did to Republicans during the Reagan years. 
Senator George S. Mitchell, the majority leader, closed the strategy session by saying there was agreement on two points. ''One, we ought to act in concert,'' he said. ''Two, we can't agree on what we should do.''
The Democrats are indeed more united than they have been in a long time behind the idea that they must pull together to define who they are. There is general agreement that the Democrats must re-establish themselves as the party of working people, which can responsibly manage the economy while improving the quality of life. Then they must get the message across to voters.
Oddly enough, part of the party's problem is its firm hold on Congress. A decade ago, when Republicans were out of power in Washington, they were really out of power. The voices of Republicanism, exemplified by Ronald Reagan, spoke without worrying that their view would be muddled by a confusing message from Capitol Hill or challenged by realities.
The Democrats are trying to use their stronghold on Capitol Hill to broadcast a message to the nation. So far, the results are at best mixed, as the intra-party struggles over cutting both Social Security and capital gains taxes make clear.
So far, no prominent Democrat on Capitol Hill has joined Mr. Moynihan's call for a reduction in Social Security taxes. They agree the tax is regressive. They agree it is being used to conceal the deficit. But the Democratic leaders say only that they are thinking about the situation. Two Democratic barons of Congress, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, announced their opposition to the Moynihan plan.
 
Defections in the House
The capital gains issue was a mirror image of this debate. The leadership, after some confusion, came out firmly against a cut in the capital gains tax. But enough rank-and-file Democrats defected to push the cut through the House last year. Some reduction will probably pass both houses this year.
The Democratic Congress cutting capital gains taxes, a cut which would benefit the wealthy? The Democratic Congress brushing off a plan to cut Social Security taxes, a cut which would benefit working Americans?
What is a Democrat, anyway? Once perceived as the party of compassion and progress, Democrats are now considered by many Americans as a fragmented bunch whose policies are likely to produce (if they produce anything at all) too much spending on the poor and too many burdens on working people.
To understand and do something about their image problem, the Democrats have conducted opinion polls and started meetings to discuss the problems.
''For the first time that I am aware of, there is an aggressive, real, genuine get-in-a-room-and-let's-talk-and-let's-plan-and-let's-research effort on their part to work their way out of it,'' said an interested observer, Eddie Mahe, a Republican consultant.
Indeed, after nearly a generation of trying to blur the differences they have with the Republicans, the Democrats are looking for ways to highlight them.
In 1989, they found one: a woman's right to abortion. Their support of it helped Democratic candidates substantially. But now the Democrats need more. Their experts see economics and domestic problems like drugs and the environment as their big ticket.
 
'You Can't Use the Hill'
Some experts say efforts to advertise a party line from Congress are doomed. ''You can't use the Hill,'' said Curtis Gans, an election expert in Washington. ''A Hill-generated program will be subjected to the difficulties of the committee system.'' That can elevate regional over national interests and personal over party politics.
Mr. Gans says the Democratic Party's best approach would be to work outside Congress. Writing recently in Social Policy magazine, he said the party should follow the example of two former chairmen, Stephen A. Mitchell and Paul Butler, who led the way for a Democratic resurgence in 1958 and 1960. Their strategy, Mr. Gans said, was to establish a council of prominent Democrats ''to hone and define a party message.'' Former President Harry S. Truman, several governors, Senators and House members took part. They called for a higher minimum wage, stronger civil rights legislation, Federal scholarships for college students and more liberal immigration laws.
The Democrats won 61 seats in Congress in 1958. In 1960, they won back the White House.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Charms of the U.S.A. Are Selling Well

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS

 BODY:
THE host of Walt Disney World's Super Star Television attraction recently wandered through the crowd of visitors to the Florida theme park, asking the standard question: ''Where are you from?''
The responses - Brazil, Sweden, Canada, Great Britain - provided a good example of what is happening in the country's $350 billion travel industry: tourism in the United States has an increasingly foreign flavor.
The trend was further demonstrated in Washington last week at an international conference sponsored by the United States Travel and Tourism Administration, an arm of the Commerce Department. Representatives of 31 states, 39 cities and dozens of travel companies and attractions gathered to discuss how to attract more foreign visitors. 
''We have to find a way to make the United States more user friendly,'' said Rockwell A. Schnabel, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Travel and Tourism. ''We can be very intimidating, we are a huge country, and we speak English and not much more.''
Fueled by the weak dollar, international tourism hit record levels in 1989, when 38.3 million people - up from 1988's 34.2 million in 1988 -came to the United States. About 70 percent of those visits were for leisure and vacation.
Even in New York City, which suffered a decline in tourism last year, the number of people arriving on international flights rose slightly.
The foreign visitors spent $43 billion, compared with the $42.6 billion spent by Americans traveling overseas. The difference was in the United States' favor for the first time, and the surplus is expected to triple this year, the Commerce Department said, to $1.48 billion.
Tourism, in fact, became the nation's largest export industry last year, the department said. Furthermore, according to the department's economic projections, the number of travelers from abroad will increase 75 percent by the end of the decade.
With that prospect, states and cities are trying to sell themselves overseas. For some - New York, California, Florida, for example - the task is relatively easy. But increasingly, many travelers are bypassing large cities, including New York, for other parts of the country.
When South Carolina started its overseas marketing efforts 11 years ago, ''many people thought we were insane,'' said Robert G. Liming, director of the division of tourism of the state's Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism. ''But now,'' he said, ''with the increased competition, we've had a real competitive advantage.''
South Carolina promotes its warm weather and its beaches to German and British companies that arrange package tours.
''We know we are not going to get 500,000 West Germans to come to South Carolina when they don't even know where it is,'' Mr. Liming said. ''We are after the fourth- and fifth-time visitor who is looking for something different.''
It is a realistic strategy. Frans W. de Ridder, managing director of Meier's Weltreisen, a large West German tour operator, said his customers generally want to see what they have heard of the most.
''It is very difficult for us to put a museum in Oklahoma in one of our brochures,'' he said. ''For the not-so-popular destinations, I only see a chance if they get involved in the promotion and marketing of their areas.''
 
Other countries, such as the
Eastern European nations, are likely to be increasingly popular destinations. But some tourism officials said the opening of Eastern Europe should also mean new visitors for the United States. Antonio Enriquez Savignac, the secretary general of the World Tourism Organization, representing many national governments, said at the tourism conference that only 2 percent of the 400 million people in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union left their countries last year.
 
The Top States
The Commerce Department said that in 1989 six states and the District of Columbia captured more than half the international visitors. California, New York, Florida, Hawaii, Texas and Nevada attracted 17 million people last year.
But seven other states had the greatest increases in foreign visitors from 1985 to 1989: the rise in New Mexico was 266 percent; South Dakota, 266 percent; Utah, 254 percent; Arizona, 205 percent; Tennessee, 190 percent, and Alabama and Iowa, 175 percent.
In Iowa, the increase - to 100,000 visitors last year - has not gone unnoticed. David K. Reynolds, administrator of the Iowa division of tourism, said the state's recent decision to legalize gambling on old-style riverboats ''is going to help every program that we have.''
Whether the increases continue, in Iowa or the rest of the country, depends in part on the strength of the dollar. But that is not the only factor.
''The growth in tourism to the United States is closely related to the overcapacity of airline seats,'' said Mr. de Ridder. Since 1988, a spurt in growth of international service by both domestic and foreign airlines has left some flights with empty seats, he said, giving airlines increased incentive to offer tour operators discounted fares.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
It's Connecticut's Turn to Find Out About Hard Times

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
THROUGH the roaring 1980's, as Connecticut caught up with and then surpassed Alaska as the richest state in the nation in personal income, it began to seem to many people both inside and outside the state that things here had somehow turned to gold. There was virtually no unemployment, taxes were more likely to go down than up, and growth outstripped the national average for years.
But now the perceptions and expectations are coming in for a jarring test. The growth has stalled and the buoyant confidence of years past has been replaced by concerns about a housing glut, a government budget crisis and business bankruptcy. The implications of the change - both economic and psychological - are now working themselves out. 
''If you're driving 75 miles an hour and suddenly you slow to 45 miles an hour, the transition is a rattling one,'' said Nicholas S. Perna, the chief economist for Connecticut National Bank, the state's largest bank. ''You don't know whether you're coming to a dead stop or not. That's what's going on in Connecticut.''
Some economists, including Mr. Perna, believe the state will avoid the ravages of widespread unemployment, which would represent a true recession. Connecticut has a 3.8 percent unemployment rate, more than a percentage point below the national average. But few economists or public officials anticipate any return to the gold-rush days. Most said that residents will simply have to adjust to an era of much slower economic growth that could extend well into the 1990's.
And with the elections this November for every state office from Governor to the General Assembly, many politicians believe the stage has been set for an expression of just how voters feel about the adjustment they have been asked to make. For incumbents like Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat who began his re-election campaign last week in the face of polls showing his popularity at the lowest ebb of his nine years in office, the tidings seem grim. On Wednesday, Mr. O'Neill asked the General Assembly for $600 million in spending cuts to achieve a $7.2 billion budget and for the elimination of more than 2,000 state jobs by the middle of next year. He said that half of all the state agencies would receive the same or less money in the fiscal year that begins July 1 than they received this year, and that nearly $300 million would have to be taken from special state savings accounts or raised by additional borrowing to keep services as they are now.
 
No Pointing With Pride
Only a few programs, notably those of the Department of Correction, which is responsible for Connecticut's huge prison expansion, would get significantly more money. For legislators concerned about their own re-election chances, little in the budget could be taken back to voters and trumpeted as good news.
The political director of Mr. O'Neill's own party, State Representative Jonathan Pelto, has said he believes that the voters are in the mood to throw out incumbents, and that Democrats who have dominated state politics here for most of the last 30 years could take the greater fall simply because they are in power and the Republicans are not.
The municipal elections last fall were a portent, Mr. Pelto said. More incumbent mayors and other top officials were voted out of office -about equally from both parties -than in any local election in modern times.
Some experts say that Connecticut residents are in fact already expressing their pessimism about the future by spending less money and putting off major purchases. Declines in spending have wide repercussions in Connecticut because the government relies so heavily on sales taxes for its funds.
Unlike New Jersey or New York, for example, which have also seen declines in sales taxes and other revenues over the last several years, Connecticut has no personal income tax. It has to support nearly 40 percent of its budget from an 8 percent sales tax, the highest state rate in the nation. New York, by contrast, receives only about 20 percent of its budget from its 4 percent sales tax, and allows municipalities to add on local sales taxes; New York City, for instance, has a combined 8.25 percent sales tax.
In Connecticut, lower sales tax collections have in turn hurt the state budget and made the overall economic picture appear even more grim than it really is, some economists say. Tax revenues are down $45 million from the expected amount this year even with an increase in the tax rate last July from 7.5 percent to 8 percent.
And when the news about the state budget is bad, officials say, the vicious circle is completed when residents decide to put off purchases of cars and other big-ticket items in case things get even worse. For politicians and budget planners, it is an environment that leaves little room for error.
''The nice thing about rapid growth is that it covers all your mistakes,'' Mr. Perna said. ''You don't have to worry too much and things turn out fine. We're going from a period of extremely rapid growth where everything turned to gold, to slow growth where it will not be as easy.''
