HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
A Rash of Thoughtful Best Sellers Has Made Publishers Think, Too

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
HARPER & ROW almost seemed to be asking to lose money last year when it published ''The Other Path'' by Hernando de Soto, and it would seem to have been asking to lose even more when it recently reprinted the book in paperback. Written by a Peruvian businessman, the book is a detailed examination of the black market in Lima, with lessons about wealth and poverty in Latin America.
As far as many people in publishing are concerned, there could be no more certain prescription for disaster than a book combining economics and third world affairs. Though it sold well in Latin America, publishers have learned that discussions of regional issues rarely do well in the United States market. 
But with a number of serious books on subjects ranging from educational reform to the nature of consciousness riding the best-seller lists week after week, publishers once again seem willing to take chances on what might be called idea books, hoping to discover the writer who will become the next Allan Bloom.
''I had a deep-seated hunch that what Mr. de Soto said was so new and so fresh, a lot of people would want to know about it,'' said Hugh Van Dusen, the editor who bought the book at an auction for what he described as ''more money than you would think.''
As it turned out, ''The Other Path'' was not a big hit, but it has sold a respectable 10,000 or more copies in hardcover. And now that it is on reading lists at several American universities, it is likely to have a long paperback life. Mr. Van Dusen said he still thinks Harper & Row can make money from it in the long run.
In recent years, critics have predicted that the wave of mergers and acquisitions in the book industry would turn distinguished names in publishing into little more than corporate profit centers, catering to the mass markets as they kept a sharper eye on the bottom line. By now, books like Mr. de Soto's weren't supposed to stand a chance.
In the past, publishers often printed books they considered deserving, whether or not they seemed profitable. They considered it their obligation as publishers. But now a perception is growing that books that once would have stagnated on what is euphemistically called the ''mid list'' might have a chance of making money.
Throughout history there have been surprise best sellers. But in the last few years, a steady stream of books by academics have competed with the likes of Stephen King: Mr. Bloom's 1987 book, ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' followed by ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers'' by Paul Kennedy, ''Cultural Literacy'' by E. D. Hirsch Jr. and ''Innumeracy'' by John Allen Paulos.
 
Scholarly Advances
Hoping to compete with their colleagues, professors who once turned automatically to a university press to publish their latest musings are now likely to send their proposals to Simon & Schuster, for example, and Random House. Mr. Paulos, a Temple University mathematics professor, sold ''Innumeracy'' through an agent to Hill & Wang, a division of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, for a $27,500 advance. After a first printing of 10,000, it sold more than 100,000 hardcover copies.
For publishers, these books can be a bargain. While it might take an advance of six or seven figures to attract a well-known author, books by unknown academics still generally come cheap. Advances of $10,000 to $15,000 are typical.
University presses continue to publish the bulk of monographs and scholarly books. Some like ''Battle Cry of Freedom'' by James H. McPherson and ''The Emperor's New Mind'' by Roger Penrose, both by Oxford University Press, have become best sellers.
And, as in the past, mainstream publishers maintain at least a minor commitment to serious nonfiction books that, at best, will make money over the long haul. Several commercial publishers maintain divisions like Hill & Wang whose fare often competes with university presses: at Macmillan, it is The Free Press, Harper & Row has Basic Books, and Random House's division is Pantheon.
''There continues to be a significant market for serious and enduring books,'' said Steve Wasserman, the executive editor of Doubleday, who was recently hired by Random House to run Times Books, which specializes in nonfiction. Before coming to Doubleday, Mr. Wasserman was publisher of Hill & Wang.
What is often overlooked, Mr. Wasserman said, is that the best-seller lists only chart how quickly current titles are moving from the stores. ''They do not record the steady sale of books, and many distinguished books over time far outsell the current best sellers,'' he said.
Who knows which unknown authors might join that distinguished club? The catalogues for this spring tell of hundreds of books that don't fall into the categories of commercial fiction or fad diets - the kind of fare that pulls readers into shopping mall bookstores.
The titles include ''Galileo's Children: Scientific Discovery vs. the Power of the State'' by George Bailey (Little, Brown & Company), ''Rudeness and Civility: Manners in Nineteenth-Century Urban America'' by John F. Kasson (Hill & Wang) and ''A Passion For Justice: Emotions and the Origins of the Social Contract'' by Robert C. Solomon (Addison Wesley).
Whatever the fate of such books, unlike so many other spring titles, they are not being published because they offer a quick, easy read.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Bush Would Wait For a Weatherman

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
IN predicting the future, much of what is proclaimed as science must ultimately be taken as a matter of faith. A problem that continues to confront the Bush Administration is how fervently it should believe in the dangers of the greenhouse effect - and how high a price the country should pay to forestall them.
Last week, British scientists reported that 1989 was the fifth-warmest year in the nearly 100 years that reliable records have been kept. Coming after a decade of record-breaking years - including 1988, the hottest recorded - the report will be taken by some as more evidence that an accumulation of carbon dioxide and other byproducts of civilization is making the earth steadily warmer, harkening disruptive changes in weather and calamities like melting polar ice caps. 
But proving a link between the recent warming and atmospheric pollution has been impossible. In the long term, meteorological models are no better than econometric ones. While no one disputes that carbon dioxide buildup causes global warming, the questions of how much and when are as uncertain as 1999's interest rates.
Last week, when President Bush addressed a meeting of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, an international body formed to study the problem, he disappointed environmentalists with his cautious stance. Though he renewed his call for some kind of international action, he avoided specifics and made it clear that economic interests would have to be taken as seriously as environmental ones. What is needed, he said, is an ''international bargain, a convergence between global environmental policy and global economic policy, where both perspectives benefit and neither is compromised.''
According to computer simulations, the greenhouse effect could raise the earth's temperature by several degrees during the next century. But complex systems like weather defy science's attempts to simulate them. With the skein of causes and effects so hard to untangle, the question of what to do about global warming comes down to politics.
Mr. Bush's speech last week was edited by John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. Last Sunday on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' Mr. Sununu said he was trying to counter ''a little tendency by some of the faceless bureaucrats on the environmental side to try and create a policy in this country that cuts off our use of coal, oil and natural gas.''
Not all the bureaucrats are faceless by choice. William K. Reilly, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, wanted the United States to take a strong stand at a meeting on global warming last fall in the Netherlands. But he was reined in by Mr. Sununu and others. Ultimately, the United States, joined by Japan and the Soviet Union, quashed a proposal by Western European countries that would cut carbon dioxide emissions 20 percent by 2005. The wording that was finally substituted called for reductions ''as soon as possible.''
 
Political Tradeoffs
The political side of the problem promises to become even more pronounced in August when the group that met last week in Washington issues a final report, which is expected to form the basis for international negotiations. The biggest emitters of carbon dioxide - the United States is the worst offender -also have the most to lose economically from stricter pollution controls. Costs would also be high for third world countries, whose leaders continue to argue that they should be compensated for the costs of developing along cleaner paths than their richer predecessors had to follow.
Figuring out how to balance all these countervailing forces could be as difficult a task as sorting out the maddeningly complex interactions in the climatic models.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 24, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 565 words

HEADLINE: What Homeless Beggars Must Keep Telling Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Riders' Rights, Beggars' Rights'' (editorial, Jan. 31), your criticism of Judge Leonard Sand's decision recognizing that begging in the New York City subway system is constitutionally protected speech, you have succumbed to the same dangerous tendencies to generalization and fuzzy thinking that characterize most public reactions against the ruling.
To reduce the public hysteria on this issue, everyone needs to know that begging in the subway system is still strictly regulated. Solidly in place and ready to be enforced, even after the Federal court's decision, are rules prohibiting begging on a subway car, within 25 feet of a token booth, at any site that interferes with the flow of passengers (entrances to, exits from stairways, escalators, elevators), in a manner that might cause harm or injury to anyone, in a way that is likely to annoy, alarm or inconvenience another person and in a host of other circumstances and situations. 
These rules, which the homeless plaintiffs never sought to challenge, can easily be enforced by the transit police. It is inappropriate to blame the beggars if the rules are not enforced.
Given the economic and political landscape of New York today, begging cannot be understood as anything but vital political speech. Every time a destitute person asks for change or extends a cup, he or she conveys the uncomfortable, disturbing idea that in the midst of staggering wealth there live people who lack the means to live. If we silence the beggar by pushing him off the subways, we cut off one of his most effective channels of communication.
Your lament on behalf of subway riders about the role this ruling will play in hindering the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's campaign to increase ridership and safety ignores that begging and the homeless apparently are not major concerns of those who use the subway. In a recent marketing survey the M.T.A. asked 996 riders to identify the three most important problems in the subways. They ranked presence of the homeless sixth of six categories, trailing reliability and frequency of trains, crime and safety, dirt, crowding and miscellaneous. Only 19 percent cited the homeless as one of the top three problems, only 5 percent as the most important problem.
Finally, you deflect attention from the real public policy issue here, which is that poor people beg because of inadequate alternatives. Why has the government (Federal, state or city) not created incentives to recapture the 1.5 million manufacturing jobs this country has lost in the last 10 years? Why doesn't the Federal Government restore the $25 billion cut from the annual low-income housing budget in the last eight years? Why do we accept a state public assistance grant for the homeless living in shelters of $1.50 a day (for which each recipient must work 20 hours a week)?
Those who try to help the destitute in their struggle to survive would rather spend time, energy and money working to end homelessness and hunger than fighting legal battles to protect their clients' right to humiliate themselves by asking for spare change.
 
DOUGLAS H. LASDON
PATRICK J. HORVATH
GEOFFREY POTTER
 New York, Feb. 6, 1990
 
The writers are, respectively, executive director and staff lawyer for the Legal Action Center for the Homeless (which brought the lawsuit) and a cooperating lawyer.

HEADLINE: You Don't Move American Landmarks Like Yankee Stadium;
Bad Idea for the Bronx

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The plan by Fernando Ferrer, Bronx Borough President, to build a new stadium for the Yankees is unfortunate for residents of the Bronx and all New Yorkers.
In the last 15 years, the Bronx has become an international symbol of urban decay. Entire neighborhoods, once considered very desirable places to live, have been abandoned and in many cases burned to the ground. The downtown area around Yankee Stadium and the Grand Concourse is a mere shadow of what it was.
This area, marred by years of neglect, remains the urban core of this once great borough. Increasingly, urban renewal projects are bringing the area back. The rows of Art Deco apartment houses along the truly grand Grand Concourse, the Supreme Court building and Yankee Stadium combine to create a neighborhood full of vitality and beauty.
Moving Yankee Stadium to the proposed new site would increase automobile access and decrease accessibility by public transportation. More important, however, it would be a serious blow to urban renewal in the downtown area. The crowds drawn by the Yankees help support a host of merchants dependent on them.
Yankee Stadium could be renovated and enclosed, and better parking facilities could be developed. These improvements would benefit the Yankees, as well as Yankee fans, while continuing urban renewal.
If Mr. Ferrer is interested in bringing the Bronx back to the glorious position it once enjoyed, he would be well advised to abandon his plan to move the stadium.
 
MAX BOLSTAD
 New York, Jan. 29, 1990

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
How Americans Can Help

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev stood at the chasm and carefully took a historic step back from destruction.
After four years of refusal, Mr. Gorbachev joined the tide against the monopoly power of the Soviet Communist Party. He decided that to keep swimming against it would soon drown him, the party and the nation, so wretched is the rule of the party he leads and so total its failure.
But the chasm remains. Respect for the decision to move toward life, the sign of a strong and healthy mind, does not change the plain fact that it must be crossed. 
Should Americans try to help build a bridge across it? The question has taken on a new political and moral importance after Mr. Gorbachev's pronouncements, which could give political choice to the Soviet people but at the same time make his own power greater than ever.
To say it fast: The Soviet Union is as near collapse as a country can be without exploding into total revolution.
Economically, this huge continental nation becomes hungrier, shabbier and colder week by week. It is barely third world.
Politically, the colonial empire that czars and commissars called a single nation is moving rapidly toward its destiny - fragmentation. That would be a blessing, if the national and ethnic hatreds and bigotries accumulated under colonialism allowed it to happen without pogrom and massacre.
What's more, the coming collapse of the entire Soviet Communist system leaves the people without any plan for a government of the future. Mr. Gorbachev's hodgepodge, halfway-house perestroika is already another synonym for failure.
Yes, Americans can help build the bridge across chaos to tomorrow but only in special American ways, quite other than soda and hamburgers.
Here is one way: Broaden and take part in the kind of work American human rights groups have been doing for a long, difficult time.
Day after dark day, these groups kept in touch with Soviet freedom fighters and spread the word of the struggle. They gave those imprisoned the only gift of value - the ceaseless struggle for their liberation.
These American groups helped the dissidents create an essential for freedom: the international awareness of the Communist tyranny and the fact that the fight against it was going on behind the homeland walls.
With the goal of Soviet freedom coming closer, it would be a tragedy if Americans now walked away from the Soviet citizens and movements that have been fighting for years and concentrated exclusively on Soviet officialdom.
The longtime freedom fighters need attention and help - and not simply for moral or emotional reasons, which are important enough.
The struggle for Soviet freedom is still in its early stages. The veteran dissidents, not the officials, are the least likely to give up. And they are the most likely to warn against dangers, including accretions of power by Mr. Gorbachev or anyone else.
Many American groups are helping the Soviet democracy movement. In doing so they help all Soviet people. I list the following four as thanks for their help in keeping me informed:
Helsinki Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York 10017; Freedom House, 48 East 21st Street, New York 10010; International League for Human Rights, 432 Park Avenue South, New York 10016, and the Center for Democracy in the U.S.S.R., 358 West 30th Street, New York 10001.
They do a lot more for the cause of Soviet freedom than oceans of Pepsi and mountains of Big Macs. So do Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, accurate, trusted, invaluable. Another bridge builder: Hugely expanded contacts between American groups and the Soviet ''informals,'' the scores of thousands of Soviet clubs, unions and cultural organizations that sprouted in the soil of hope.
Some will blossom into local parties if democracy is allowed to grow in the Soviet Union. Thousands of others will turn into the cultural, political or special-interest associations that grow roots for political parties.
From American unions, political and religious groups, universities and professional societies they need fax machines, computers, copiers - and the fresh air of foreign contact. That has been a crime under Communism.
The degree to which it is allowed now by Mr. Gorbachev and demanded by the West will have a lot to do with speeding the inevitable end of the entire Communist system.
That, of course, is the only guarantee that the promise of choice becomes the reality of choice, which is the single bridge across the chasm.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: Seeing the Shuttle Up Close

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ; JEFFREY SCHMALZ is the deputy national editor of The Times.

 BODY:
WHATEVER the event, from a football game to a Presidential inauguration, the ideal vantage point is often television. Americans have grown accustomed to thinking of it as the best seat in the house, preferable to actually being there.
But there are some events that television does not even come close to capturing, and one of them is at Cape Canaveral, Fla.: the launching of a space shuttle. For each blastoff, at least 15,000 people - and occasionally more than 500,000 - cram the beaches and roadways around the Kennedy Space Center, some standing on the hoods of their automobiles, most usually not cheering but reverentially silent.
And many are taken aback at how different a launching is in reality, compared with television. Nothing has prepared them for the deep, crackling rumble; for the waves of vibration; for the intensity of the white light of flame that lifts the rocket skyward; for the thrill of being there. 
As the shuttle program completes its recovery from the January 1986 Challenger disaster, the launch schedule is growing, and with it the opportunity for spectators to come and see a bit of history. For the rest of this year, eight launchings are scheduled. Eight are planned for 1991, 12 for 1992, 13 for 1993, 11 for 1994, 11 for 1995 and 10 for 1996.
Planning a trip to the east coast of Florida to view a launch is a bit tricky: as a result of inclement weather or technical malfunctions, delays of a few days are common. To be safe, visitors should plan to be in the area for at least two days beyond the scheduled launch date.
But a family on a week's vacation that is willing to be a bit flexible and listen to news reports on launch status can work out a fairly smooth trip. If visitors hear that a launch is put off 24 hours or so, for example, they can spend the day instead touring the Kennedy Space Center exhibitions or one of the nearby beaches or attractions that make up what economic developers and tourism officials now like to call the Space Coast.
For most tourists, a trip to view a launch begins with arrival at Orlando International Airport, which is about 50 miles, or an hour's drive, west of Cape Canaveral. The Orlando area, one of the most popular tourist destinations in the country, is home to Disney World and Sea World.
Orlando, where virtually all the major hotel and motel chains offer accommodations, could serve as the base for a visit. It's an easy drive on a superhighway, passing through miles and miles of orange groves.
On a launch day, visitors who have written ahead to NASA and obtained a pass may drive onto the causeways of the Kennedy Space Center. The roadways offer a direct view of the rocket and shuttle across about six to eight miles of water and wetland.
But only 1,000 passes are issued, so most visitors have to content themselves with watching from outside the center's compound. The center sits on a peninsula that runs north to south, parallel to the mainland and separated from it by the Indian River. U.S. Route 1 runs along the river, on the mainland, and it is along that highway that some of the best viewing is available for those without special passes.
Especially good spots are in Titusville, directly across the Indian River from the shuttle launch sites. Route 1 there offers an unobstructed view of the shuttle and its rocket from about 10 miles away. The Titusville police allow launch spectators to park along Route 1 while they walk to the river's edge. Other good viewing points are slightly to the south, in Jetty Park at Port Canaveral and on Route A1A along the beach in Cocoa Beach or Cape Canaveral.
Wherever visitors go to watch, a portable radio (for updates on launch time) and binoculars are musts.
A perfect complement to a launch viewing is a visit to the Kennedy Space Center's Spaceport USA. The Spaceport - a mix of museums, movies and bus tours of actual launch sites and rockets - is open, with a few exceptions, every day from 9 A.M. to dusk. It is closed on the days of some launchings, so visitors in town to watch a launch sometimes have to plan on visiting the center the day before or after.
Information on the Spaceport's hours of operation and on launchings can be obtained by calling 407-452-2121. Admission to the Spaceport is free; there are fees for the bus tour and the Imax movie. The center has free kennels and will provide free cameras (not film) for the day to visitors.
A must-see at the Spaceport is a 37-minute movie, shown on a 5 1/2-story Imax screen, that takes the audience along on a shuttle mission. The images are nothing short of spectacular, and viewers feel as if they're actually floating in space. The movie (cost is $2.75 for an adult, $1.75 for a child) offers all kinds of insights into aspects of life aboard the shuttle that most viewers probably never even thought about. (One of the best images: astronauts sleeping, strapped in their bunks, arms floating at their sides in the weightlessness.) There's also a 20-minute free film called ''Boy From Mars.''
Exhibits at the Spaceport are a mix of technology and space-flight memorabilia. Here is the actual Apollo capsule that docked with a Russian Soyuz capsule in July 1975. Here is the space suit worn by James Lovell on Apollo 13 in April 1970. Here is a moon rock collected from the Taurus-Littrow Valley on Dec. 12, 1972. Here is a replica of the lunar vehicle that carried astronauts across the moon's surface at a speed of 10 miles an hour. (The real one was left on the moon.) A new exhibit is a walk-through simulated space station.
But perhaps the most exciting part of the Spaceport is a two-hour bus tour of the 140,000-acre Kennedy Space Center. (Cost: $4 per adult; $1.75 per child.) This is called the Red Tour and runs every 20 minutes. The tour winds through marshland and citrus groves, moving from shuttle launch site to launch site and offering an opportunity to inspect a giant Saturn 5 rocket (281 feet tall; 363 feet with an Apollo spacecraft attached), which is placed on its side so it can be viewed more closely.
Often, the tour seems to take place in a surreal land of giants where the size of everything is exaggerated, from the huge building where assembly of the space shuttles is completed to the crawler transporters, the 131-feet-long, 114-feet-wide tractors that haul the rockets to the launch site at 1 mile an hour.
The Blue Tour runs just once a day and goes to the historic sites on the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, such as Complex 19, where the Gemini flights blasted off in 1965 and 1966, and Complex 34, where three Apollo astronauts died in a flash fire in their capsule on Jan. 27, 1967. It also includes a look at some of the early rockets.
For those who get hungry during their tour of the Spaceport, it has restaurants and an inexpensive cafeteria (where a hamburger costs $1.15; a chef's salad, $2.95).
The Spaceport is by far the most popular attraction on Florida's mid-Atlantic coast. But there are other things to do in the area besides watch shuttle launchings. It boasts some of the best surfing on the Atlantic Coast, particularly off Cocoa Beach. And even for nonsurfers, it's worth a visit to Ron Jon's Surf Shop on Route A1A in Cocoa Beach for a look at the surfing crowd and the latest in such musts for the well-got-up surfer as zinc oxide in Day-Glo colors.
In towns up and down the coast, boats are available for tours or rental. SeaEscape Cruises offers a day at sea, from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., aboard a cruise ship, sailing from Port Canaveral. (Cost: from $79 per adult, with some discounts for the elderly; $39 per child. Call 800-432-0900 in Florida or 800-327-7400.) The Little River Queen, a paddle-wheeler, makes two-hour sightseeing trips along the Banana River (call 407-783-2380).
For shoppers, Olde Cocoa Village is an Americana shopping district that offers jewelry and crafts along cobblestone streets.
The Space Coast also offers a wide array of outdoor sports, from golfing to windsurfing, Jet Skiing and airboat rides. Many vistors to Disney World prefer staying in this area because, unlike Disney's home near Orlando, it has the ocean and the beaches. For a detailed list of activities, hotels and restaurants, call 407-452-4390.
 
WHEN AND WHERE TO VIEW A LAUNCH
 
Scheduled Flights
The United States plans eight more space shuttle flights this year.
People planning a visit to the cape to view a launch should keep in mind that flights can be delayed for days because of technical malfunctions or bad weather. Here is the shuttle schedule for the remainder of 1990:
Feb. 22, Atlantis, with a Defense Department payload that reportedly is an advanced reconnaissance satellite.
April 18, Discovery, with the Hubble Space Telescope.
May 9, Columbia, with an astronomy laboratory.
July 9, Atlantis, with a Defense Department payload.
Aug. 29, Columbia, with a Space Life Sciences Laboratory.
Oct. 5, Discovery, with the Ulysses spacecraft to study the sun.
Nov. 1, Atlantis, with the Gamma Ray Observatory to study deep space.
Dec. 12, Columbia, with the International Microgravity Laboratory.
 
Getting Passes
For most of the launches, the Kennedy Space Center issues a limited number of car passes - 1,000 - that give a vehicle access to the causeway leading to the center. Cars with the passes may park on the causeway, and they enjoy a direct view across the Banana River to the launch pad six to eight miles away.
Passes can be obtained by writing a postcard well in advance to NASA Public Affairs, Kennedy Space Center, Fla. 32899. Write PA-PASS under the address. The passes are sent out three to four weeks before the launch date and should be displayed on the car's dashboard. Visitors with car passes should arrive two to three hours before launch time.
Car passes are not issued for launches - two this year - involving secret defense payloads. - J. S.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, It's Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO is a journalist who has traveled throughout Europe.

 BODY:
AS Americans start planning their summer vacations, travel agents are predicting the season's hot new destinations: Warsaw, Budapest, East Berlin and Prague.
Once viewed as some of the grimmest, grayest citadels of the Soviet empire, eastern Europe's biggest capitals are currently the toast of the Western travel industry.
The new appeal of these old cities started to surface last autumn, when many of the old-style Coummunist governments in Eastern Europe began to unravel. Tour operators, airline officials and travel agents now expect record numbers of Americans to visit the region this summer.
''The interest is just phenomenal, both from travel agents and consumers,'' said Bhavani Chandramouli, marketing manager for General Tours, one of the main package tour operators to the region. Last year 200 visitors took the company's 16-day ''Highlights of Eastern Europe'' tour, stopping in East and West Berlin, Prague, Budapest and Warsaw. The company expects twice as many this year for the tour, which will cost $3,399 from June to September, $3,299 in April and May and $3,349 from May 25 to June 9. 
In recent weeks, Americans have snapped up travel brochures, package tours and airline reservations for destinations in Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Bulgaria.
Some travel organizations that did not have such itineraries are setting up tours. Club Med, for example, best known for sun-and-fun vacations, took 140 Westerners last month on a seven-day, $2,000-a-person tour from Paris with stops in Prague, Berlin, Warsaw, Moscow, Budapest, Bucharest and Sofia - its first in Eastern Europe. The tour was arranged specifically to let visitors see the changes there, said Serge Trigano, Club Med's chief executive officer.
''It's clear everyone wants to be there today to see what's happening, to walk on the streets and see the people, to have a meal in a restaurant,'' he said. ''I think it's a new kind of way to visit a country.'' Club Med says it will repeat the tour in March.
How many western tourists these countries can comfortably handle, however, is a question. For years their history-rich cities and seaside spas have been supported by tourists from Eastern-bloc countries. While Americans, with their hard currency and democratic ideals, are being warmly welcomed, few Eastern European countries have enough hotel space and travel amenities to accommodate spur-of-the-moment visitors, particularly those wishing to stay in up-to-date Western-style hotels.
Package tour operators have already reserved large blocks of hotel space this summer, cutting the number of rooms available for independent travelers.
''Between mid-August and mid-September, it is impossible to get bookings in some countries,'' said Francis Goranin, who heads Vega International Travel Service, a Chicago agency that specializes in Eastern Europe. ''The U.S.S.R. and Hungary are extremely popular, though space is available if you go with a group.''
But calls to several large hotel chains indicated that rooms in late summer are still available in Warsaw and Sofia. A chance to visit a once shadowy part of the world as it changes is appealing to many Westerners. ''I'm thrilled to go,'' said John Caulkins, a senior at Vassar College who is traveling on his own to Prague this spring. ''I'm fascinated with the experiment there. It's something I want to experience first hand for myself.''
Irene Rawlings, a freelance arts writer from Denver, plans to visit Warsaw, Cracow and several small Polish mountain villages in March. Fluent in Polish, she last visited the country in the autumn. ''I am very much interested to see what the changes are like as Poland lurches to capitalism,'' she said. The wall has become something of a shrine to the changes throughout Eastern Europe, and visitors come to chip away a piece for themselves, take photographs and marvel at the swiftness of the revolution.
''We came because history was being made, and we wanted to be the first to see it,'' said Linda Benaroya of Englewood, N.J. She and her family cut short their visit to Paris over the New Year's holiday to make an impromptu visit to Berlin. ''It's a lot more educational for the kids than Disney World.''
ONLY Romania and Albania are not attracting visitors. A State Department advisory remains in effect for Romania, warning that travelers there should exercise extreme caution, and Albania has long been closed to American tourists.
For years, American travel to Eastern Europe was modest, limited mainly to people who had relatives there, and a few inveterate travelers. The region's appeal began growing in the mid-1980's, due largely to its relatively low cost and, at a time when terrorism gripped much of Western Europe, its safety.
More Americans visited Eastern Europe last year than ever before, though the numbers were still small. Hungary, with 150,000 visitors, was the region's biggest draw, topping even the Soviet Union, which had 135,000. Poland was host to 86,000 Americans in 1989, up from 40,000 in 1986. Czechoslovakia had 70,000 and Bulgaria 20,000. In comparison, Britain had about 2.8 million American visitors last year.
Already, business travel to Eastern Europe has increased sharply, particularly to Hungary and Poland. Pam American World Airways reported a 25 percent increase in the number of passengers for the autumn of 1989 over the previous autumn, largely because of business travel. And at the end of the year, Czechoslovak Airlines, which for years carried Americans to Prague on Soviet-made IL-62 planes, will switch to the European-made Airbus 310, adding a business-class section on trans-Atlantic flights.
Business travelers were the first to discover the difficulties of finding a hotel room, even though most big Eastern European cities have at least one Western-style hotel. At the Palace Hotel in Prague, for example, it is necessary to reserve at least a month in advance now for a $142 double room; or in summer, when rooms cost $247, six weeks ahead.
The hotel problem is particularly acute in Budapest. Over 20,000 rooms are available at the city's big international hotels, which include a Hilton, an Inter-Continental and a Hyatt. But because Budapest lacks office space, Western companies routinely rent hotel rooms as offices, keeping them even when their representatives are not in the city.
''Sometimes three to four weeks' notice is enough to book a room, sometimes six months is not enough,'' said Miklos Walko, general manager of Ibusz, the Hungarian National Travel Bureau. ''There's already a period in August this summer where there are no rooms.''
The Hungarian Government is seeking foreign investors to build new hotels and has set aside 10 prime Budapest sites. The first, a 220-room hotel set in the newly restored Gresham Palace, is a joint venture between Hunger Hotels, the large state-owned hotel group currently in the process of being sold, and Oberoi, a hotel group based in India. It is expected to open in three years.
Poland, which expects a 20 percent increase in visitors from the United States this year, already has a hotel that is not state-owned and operated. The $65 million Warsaw Marriott, which opened in October, is the first such hotel in Eastern Europe. A joint venture between Lot, the Polish airline, an Austrian construction company and Marriott Hotels and Resorts, the 520-room hotel is managed by Westerners and staffed by Poles trained by Marriott. To insure Western standards, Marriott chefs brought seeds from the Netherlands to raise fruit and vegetables, and the hotel supplies a local brewery with yeast for its beer. As at most luxury hotels in the region, prices are comparable to those in New York or Chicago, with double rooms priced at $185, payable only in Western currency ($165 through March).
Frequent visitors say Eastern Europe, though still cheaper than the West, has become more costly and is expected to grow even more expensive. ''To increase the living standard, they will need to increase wages, and then you can expect inflation,'' said Mr. Goranin.
ONE of the remaining bargains is food, which can be very good, according to George Lang, the Hungarian-born owner of the New York restaurant Cafe des Artistes. Vegetables may be overcooked, but each country has at least one national dish, like Hungary's traditional goulash, that is almost uniformly excellent.
''If anybody expects the elegance of a Four Seasons, he or she will be very disappointed in all of Eastern Europe,'' said Mr. Lang. ''If however somebody is looking for delicious home-style foods, in a casual and hospitable surrounding, often with live gypsy music, he will have a great time.''
A great deal of Eastern Europe still remains shabby and worn. Joran Kagan, vice president of Unitours, specializing in Jewish heritage tours, said, ''Americans are pretty spoiled. We try to prepare them for what to expect, but then they get there, and they're disappointed.''
But though buildings may be drab and cities gray, the people this year are different, according to George J. Nagorski, an aviation and travel consultant who often visits his native Poland. ''''A miracle has happened, and the people now have hope. Even though economically things are tough, the people look less somber and feel better.''
 
A SAMPLING OF EAST-BLOC TOURS
This summer, taking an organized tour may be the best way to find a place to stay in countries such as Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland. Tour companies reserve entire hotel floors months in advance. Following is a selection of tours; all prices are per person, double occupancy.
 
General
''Highlights of Eastern Europe,'' from Four Winds Travel (175 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10010; 212-777-0260; 800-248-4444), is a 15-day tour starting in Helsinki and going on to Warsaw, Crakow, Budapest, Bratislava, Prague, Dresden and East Berlin. Includes hotels, 13 breakfasts, 6 lunches and 10 dinners. In June, July and August the land price only is $2,798; in September $2,698. Air fares from $1,007.
''The Eastern Rhapsody,'' from Ted Cook Tours (Post Office Box 1398, Newport Beach, Calif. 92663; 714-645-8300), visits Yugoslavia, Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria in 16 days. Travelers fly to Zagreb, and from there to Budapest, Cluj, in the Carpathian Mountains, Sighishoara, Brasov, Bran (Dracula's castle), Bucharest, Sofia, Belgrade, Sarajevo, Mostar and Dubrovnik. In April the tour costs $1,919, in May $1,948, and by mid-June goes up to $2,108. Price includes air fare.
 
Bulgaria
''Discover Bulgaria,'' from Balkan Holidays, 161 East 86th Street, New York, N.Y. 10028; 212-722-1110, offers 11 days in Bulgaria and Prague. Cost is $1,349 in June, July, August and early September; $1,214 in May and late September and $1,199 in October.
No visa is required for groups of six or more with prepaid hotel reservations. Individuals can get a tourist visa valid for up to 30 days for $23 (rush $38) from the Bulgarian Embassy, 1621 22d Street NW, Washington D.C. 20008; 202-483-5885.
 
Czechoslovakia and Hungary

HEADLINE: OPPOSING ORTEGA

BYLINE: By Mark A. Uhlig: Mark A. Uhlig is chief of the Managua bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
BY THE TIME THE CANDIDATE ARRIVES, THE crowd in Granada, Nicaragua, is thousands strong. Ragged street vendors are making a month's pay in hours, and small boys, climbing up for the best view, cling to high shade trees like giant fruit.
In the multitude of blue flags, white banners and waving arms, the demonstrators can scarcely see their candidate's pickup truck as it makes its way to the front of the square. But as it reaches the stage, a silver-haired woman in a wheelchair is carefully lifted into view. Helped to her place beside a bust of her slain husband, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro thrusts up her hands in a victory salute. And the crowd explodes. ''Violeta! Violeta! Throw them out! Throw them out!'' Surrounded by outstretched hands, Mrs. Chamorro hugs everyone in reach. Then Nicaragua's most famous widow goes straight to her message. This is the town where my husband was born, she tells them. This is where he learned the values of freedom that cost him his life. This is where he would tell us to make a stand against the Sandinista regime.
''I never thought that I would return to Granada as a candidate, raising the banner steeped in the blood of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, to ask his people once again to put themselves in the front lines,'' she says. ''But Nicaragua must win its freedom once again. 
''All across the world,'' she continues, her voice rising, ''people like you are burying Communism and proclaiming democracy. So set your watches! Set them to the same hour as Poland, as Bulgaria, as Czechoslovakia, as Chile! Because this is the hour of democracy and freedom - this is the hour of the people!''
Coming from any (Continued on Page 62) other politician, the words would amount to little upon the vast polemical battlefield of Nicaraguan politics. But as the cheers swell around her, it is clear that the 60-year-old widow enjoys a special kind of authority.
It has been 12 years since Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Cardenal, a crusading newspaper editor, was shot dead on a Managua street by unidentified assassins, sparking an uprising that toppled the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle and swept the Sandinista Front to power.
Since then, hundreds of thousands of Nicaraguans, Mrs. Chamorro among them, have broken with the Sandinista regime. An entire rebel army has been raised and financed with American support. And the millions who mourned her husband have now buried 30,000 of their own dead on opposing sides in a bitter civil war.
But throughout, the martyrdom of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro has remained an almost sacred symbol of unity and sacrifice in Nicaragua's national memory. And as opposition parties prepare for national elections, that prestige has been enlisted to try to accomplish what war and counterrevolution could not. On Feb. 25, Mrs. Chamorro will lead the National Opposition Union, or U.N.O., a coalition of 14 parties, against the Sandinista Government of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra. The result, U.N.O leaders hope, will be a decisive referendum on Sandinista rule.
By thrusting her husband's name into the heart of political battles he never fought, Mrs. Chamorro has been obliged to reclaim his legacy even from the couple's own children, two of whom are high Sandinista officials. She has also made it a political imperative for her enemies to discredit the bond she cherished with her spouse. Sandinista leaders, portraying Mrs. Chamorro as a gullible widow, ridicule her candidacy as a stalking horse for American militarists and the Nicaraguan right wing. Unofficial characterizations are still more direct.
''What pain, Pedro,'' reads dripping red graffiti in Granada, not far from where the crowd has gathered, ''to know that your own wife has sold out to those who killed you.''
More important, Mrs. Chamorro's reliance on her husband's fame has reinforced the impression that, as president, she would have little else to offer. While opposition intellectuals labored over her coalition's platform, Mrs. Chamorro read none of the secret drafts, to say nothing of writing one. Even strong U.N.O. supporters have questioned whether she has the capacity to be anything more than a docile, if distinguished, creature of her advisers.
Yet on the stage in Granada, the cheers rain down on Pedro Joaquin Chamorro's widow. And to the officials who stand near her, sharing in the moment, all of those issues miss the point.
''She is a symbol, and that is enough,'' says one U.N.O. official. ''Not of the past, or the present, or even the future. She is a symbol of what might have been.''
VIOLETA CHAMORRO WAS at home, listening to the radio, when she learned she had been chosen to run for president of Nicaragua.
In a sweltering former restaurant a few blocks away, leaders from more than a dozen anti-Sandinista political parties had bargained, schemed and fumed for several days straight, trying to decide who would lead them in the elections. After 10 years of revolution and war, driven by Soviet arms and the near-fatal obsession of an American administration, a regional peace treaty had given exhausted Nicaraguans the chance to decide their future in a closely watched election. Amid a deep economic crisis and growing popular discontent, the timing for an anti-Government campaign seemed ideal.
But even as they grappled for position, the politicians, in the wilted, open-collar shirts that pass for business dress in Nicaragua's heat, knew that the very stakes of the vote put it beyond the reach of anyone in the room.
Back and forth, they debated names of peers who might find acceptance from the unwieldy coalition, which reached from Communists to conservatives. But from the start, the absent figure of Violeta Chamorro dominated the sessions. On Sept. 2, with journalists pressing close around them in Managua's sticky evening air, the leaders announced that they had reached a decision. The news crackled over the airwaves, and Mrs. Chamorro heard a spokesman read her name.
''I am not a politician, as I have said many times,'' she says, sitting in the study of her house. ''But I believe that this is a patriotic duty - that as a Nicaraguan I have to do this for my country.''
With her grandmother's smile - and her wheelchair, made necessary by a recently broken knee - Mrs. Chamorro could be the mathematical inverse of a traditional party boss. But in the study, a cool, dark sanctuary filled with photos, diplomas and family treasures, she is surrounded by reminders of the lifetime that made the nomination possible, even inevitable.
When she first met her future husband, 19-year-old Violeta Barrios could hardly have been further removed from the politics that addicted him. A sheltered upper-class girl from Rivas, near the Costa Rican border, Miss Barrios, at the insistence of her father, had attended women's colleges in Texas and Virginia to learn English. ''It was his obsession,'' she says, with a smile, of her father, a wealthy cattleman who had attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But in classes filled with other young, aristocratic Latin American women, she found little time or need to progress beyond the lazy consonants and dropped endings of her rural Nicaraguan Spanish.
Returning to Rivas, Violeta had settled into a life of parties and privilege when her brother introduced her to a heavyset college friend whose parents owned a newspaper in Managua. Pedro Joaquin Chamorro fell in love at first sight. A year later, Violeta gave in to his repeated proposals of marriage, beginning a close, if one-sided, life of politics, centered on resistance to the Somoza dictatorship.
In the small, personal world of Nicaraguan politics, the Somozas held power, having exploited the American-founded National Guard to form a personal military dynasty. But the Chamorros held claim to a longer and far loftier family history that included several presidents and a sense of self-worth undimmed by even the formidable solipsism of the last Somoza ruler, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
When Pedro Joaquin Chamorro's brother met then-President Somoza at a Managua swimming party in the 1960's, the family resemblance apparently rang a bell with the dictator, who asked, with regal curiosity, ''Do I know you?''
''I don't know,'' answered the brother, in a withering retort that quickly became famous. ''I'm Jaime Chamorro. Who are you?''
After his father, also an editor, died in 1952, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro focused his energies on La Prensa, the newspaper his family had acquired in the early 1930's. But his time was also consumed with politics, carrying his wife along on a wave of dramatic and often quixotic challenges to the Somoza regime. Accused of rebellion in 1956, Chamorro was imprisoned, then banished to an isolated village. He escaped to Costa Rica, where Violeta joined him for several years in exile.
Through it all, she says, ''my work was to be his wife - to take care of my children, take care of the house, accompany him on his trips, take food to him in prison - going to drop off the food, there and back, nothing more.'' But it was on just such a domestic errand that her life, and that of her country, would change abruptly.
On Jan. 10, 1978, Mrs. Chamorro was shopping for her daughter's wedding dress at a mall in downtown Miami when her brother-in-law rushed in with a message. The family, he said, would have to return at once to Nicaragua. There had been an accident.
''I knew at that moment that there wasn't an accident,'' she says. ''I knew they had killed him. I could see it all so clearly.'' To this day, Violeta Chamorro says, she does not know who ordered the assassination. ''I do not believe in the justice of Somoza or the justice of the Sandinistas,'' she says. But for the crowds that filled Managua's streets, the killing unleashed decades of frustration and anger, and for Mrs. Chamorro it was the fulfillment of a fate that she says she knew and understood.
''Pedro and I talked a lot about sadnesses and joys, and one of those sadnesses was death,'' she said. ''One day, when we had already said the rosary, he said to me, 'They're going to kill me, and you are going to have to take over the responsibilities.' And I told him, 'Oh no, Papacito, I want to go first, before you, because I don't want the responsibility. It's something that we can't know. It's the will of God.' ''
ON JULY 19, 1979, THE news photos riveted the world: triumphant Sandinista guerrillas rode into Managua on a vast, surging tide of supporters, claiming victory over a shattered, corrupt regime. Picture editors puzzled over the unfamiliar young man at the head of the five-member revolutionary junta, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, a scruffy, intense guerrilla commander with thick-frame glasses. But beside him rode a dark-haired woman whose name and face had already been made famous by tragedy.
In the chaotic months that followed her husband's murder, Violeta Chamorro and her family had become almost inevitably intertwined with the Sandinista guerrillas, who had no direct connection with Pedro Joaquin Chamorro but whose 18-year struggle was pushed to a denouement by his death. Mrs. Chamorro's eldest daughter, Claudia, and youngest son, Carlos Fernando, worked actively for the revolution. The Chamorro family pitched in with a $50,000 loan, never to be repaid. And Mrs. Chamorro agreed to lend her prestige to the cause.
''They told me that they needed me, they needed the name of my husband, and the name of La Prensa,'' she says. ''It wouldn't have been patriotic to refuse.''
But in the bare-knuckle politics of the revolutionary regime's first months in office, Mrs. Chamorro was soon relegated to an outsider's role. After nine months of bitter isolation, she left the Government, citing health problems, but privately accusing the Sandinistas of betrayal.
''It was going to be democratic, it was going to be pluralistic, but it turned out to be just the opposite,'' she says, in the broad strokes that are the trademark of her political conversation. ''It is a Marxist, Communist Government that has betrayed the Nicaraguan people.''
She objected to the Sandinistas' insistence on expanding their victorious army and their efforts to seize a dominant role in the emerging Council of State. But more than that, she rejected the new regime's entire approach to government. ''I remember when I was in the junta,'' she said, ''they were telling me, 'You have to cut coffee and take classes in Marxism.' But it would make more sense to pick up a book and study. Why cut coffee - just to put on a show?''
At the same time that Mrs. Chamorro resigned from the junta, disputes over coverage of Sandinista policy led to an open split at La Prensa. Outvoted by other members of the Chamorro family, Pedro Joaquin's brother, Xavier Chamorro Cardenal, and much of the paper's staff broke away to form an unabashedly pro-Government newspaper, El Nuevo Diario. Mrs. Chamorro became publisher of La Prensa, making her almost overnight the most visible and influential voice of opposition to the Government she had just left. ''I had never been a journalist,'' she says. ''But I had watched my husband for 27 years, and you learn through doing. We kept it going, holding on by our fingernails.''
La Prensa became an immediate target for Sandinista harassment and censorship, and amid growing tension between Nicaragua and the United States, the newspaper's battle to publish soon took on a far broader significance. Never more than a modest, tabloid-quality publication, La Prensa began receiving donations from a wide variety of foreign sources - though not, Mrs. Chamorro pointedly asserts, from the C.I.A. - and quickly became a cause celebre for Americans who charted each move against it as a barometer of Sandinista repression.
Yet the very prominence of Mrs. Chamorro's battle against the Sandinistas further divided her own family. Two of her children followed her into the opposition camp - her eldest son, Pedro Joaquin, who became editor of La Prensa, a position he eventually gave up to go into exile as a director of the American-backed contra rebels; and her daughter, Cristiana, perhaps fiercest of all the Chamorros in her opposition to Sandinista rule. But Mrs. Chamorro's two other children, Carlos Fernando and Claudia, remain firmly committed to the revolution they joined after their father's death.
Carlos Fernando Chamorro, a soft-spoken, cerebral man, has been one of the Sandinista Front's most respected voices since its first days in power. At age 23, he became head of the Department of Agitation and Propaganda and editor of the official Sandinista newspaper, Barricada. Claudia joined him, serving first as the new Government's Ambassador to Costa Rica, then as a ranking diplomat alongside her husband, who is now Nicaragua's Ambassador to Spain.
Before the opposition named its candidate, there was speculation within Government circles that Carlos Fernando would be asked to step down as editor of Barricada if his mother were chosen. But he has silenced any criticism, overseeing an unflinching campaign of words against his mother's party. His uncle, Xavier, has done the same at El Nuevo Diario. Claudia, meanwhile, recently wrote an open letter in both papers denouncing her mother's political coalition.
''The U.N.O. brings together all of the political enemies of my father,'' she wrote. ''Those who have found refuge in it include the followers of the Somoza Government; the former members of the official and collaborationist opposition of the regime; the ex-members of the National Guard; the members of the pseudo-opposition who always opposed the libertarian ideas of my father and the integration of the united anti-Somoza opposition for which he fought so hard.''
Family members say that such pointed attacks have taken a profound toll on Mrs. Chamorro, who spent 27 years of her life knitting together the family that has now been unraveled by political factionalism. But the injury is felt equally by her pro-Sandinista children, who see her as playing a humiliating role in an American-engineered drama.
''I respect my mother as my mother,'' says Carlos Fernando, sipping coffee at the warehouselike offices of Barricada. ''But I think at this point she is being used as an instrument of American policy. My attitude would be very different if U.N.O. were an expression of a genuine national sentiment. But the U.N.O. campaign is financed and made possible by the United States.''
Accusations that Mrs. Chamorro's coalition is a puppet of the old Somoza dictatorship, the United States and the American-backed contra rebels have been the dominant theme of Sandinista press attacks against U.N.O. In the pages of Barricada, La Prensa is almost never called by name, but described as ''the newspaper of the National Guard,'' the Somoza dictatorship's army. ''U.N.O.'' is used interchangeably with ''contra,'' producing headlines such as ''U.N.O. Kills Four.''
The allegations have been reinforced by the fact that several leaders of the U.N.O. campaign, including Mrs. Chamorro's younger son, Pedro Joaquin, are former contra leaders. Such claims are also strengthened by the United States' own actions, including the involvement of the American Embassy in advising U.N.O. leaders, admissions by United States State Department officials that contra troops have reinfiltrated Nicaragua to dramatize their presence during the campaign, and the decision by Congress to appropriate $9 million for the Nicaraguan elections.
But even Sandinista supporters admit the picture can be overdrawn. The return of contra leaders to participate in a peaceful electoral campaign, they note, has long been advocated by the Sandinistas themselves as an alternative to the contra war. And as Mrs. Chamorro's campaign has come to overshadow contra activities, rebel leaders who remain outside the country have repeatedly discounted her importance, suggesting that the election is a Sandinista-created diversion to discredit that war.
Diplomats note that the American aid cannot be used for direct campaigning, and must be split among several purposes, including largely neutral functions of poll watching and the verification of registration lists. Moreover, under Nicaraguan law, money destined for U.N.O. must be split with the Government commission administering the vote, a provision that leaves only $1.8 million for Mrs. Chamorro's coalition.
The denunciations clearly irritate Mrs. Chamorro. ''I call it 'barricuda,' '' she says, referring to her son's newspaper. Yet, though they no longer talk politics, the mother and son still see each other regularly. Mrs. Chamorro invites Carlos Fernando to come home for lunch ''whenever his stomach starts growling.''
Among the children, too, private relationships have been preserved. When young Pedro Joaquin, as part of a contra delegation, traveled to Managua in the spring of 1988 for peace talks with the Government, he was allowed to cross the heavy cordon of Sandinista security police surrounding his hotel to spend an evening alone with his brother. And when Sandinista and contra leaders converged on Caracas last year to attend the inauguration of President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, the Chamorros took the opportunity to hold their first family reunion in many years.
''The Sandinistas have tried to split families, to divide them psychologically, mentally, in their ideology,'' says Mrs. Chamorro. ''But I think that, deep inside, it is very difficult for those divisions to last. For that to happen, you would have to have hearts of stone.''
IN A GLASS-FACED CABINET in Mrs. Chamorro's study lies the cream-colored pullover her husband was wearing when three gunmen pulled alongside his car on a Managua street. A grieving maid washed out some of the blood, but jagged bullet holes left the garment little more than a pile of shreads. Next to it in the case are his sunglasses and billfold. And at the back of the house, restored and carefully covered with canvas, is the tan Saab Pedro Joaquin Chamorro was driving that morning 12 years ago.
In the worst years of the civil war that followed, with her children grown and on opposite sides of the country's deep political divide, Mrs. Chamorro's four-bedroom house was a portrait of a widow's loneliness. But the silence has now given way to the frenzy of a candidate's life. The once-quiet living room now springs alive in the drama and glare of televised news conferences, and the backyard fence gleams with coils of razor wire for security. A house next door has been rented as extra office space for Mrs. Chamorro, (Continued on Page 72) who since her knee injury in early January must let much of the campaign come to her. Day after day, a small parade of politicians, advisers, businessmen and journalists arrives to confer with the candidate, filing past a blue- and-white sidewalk wall that declares, in chest-high letters: ''Vote - Violeta - Victory.''
Before she was nominated, many opposition politicians and even family members doubted that Mrs. Chamorro could bear up well under the strain and exposure of a presidential campaign. But she has only seemed to flourish.
''She is a person with no political experience, and some thought this would be very difficult for her,'' says Virgilio Godoy Reyes, who lost the nomination to Mrs. Chamorro, then became her vice presidential candidate. ''But she is very effective at speaking with the people; she loves to be out in the crowds. Her enthusiasm has really surprised us.''
Even within her own campaign, few people are willing to predict how Mrs. Chamorro and the opposition will fare on Feb. 25. Although the economic situation is severe, the Sandinista Front retains a strong base of support, particularly among young people, and has benefited from public outrage over the American invasion of Panama. Opinion polls have produced uneven results, giving Mrs. Chamorro anywhere from a 20-point lead to a 40-point deficit. Many foreign experts believe the Nicaraguan people's reservations about expressing their true political views to outsiders may make even the most sophisticated election polls irrelevant.
But opposition and Sandinista officials agree that much of U.N.O's performance at the voting booth will hinge on Mrs. Chamorro alone. ''I keep marveling at how right they were to pick her,'' says one Western diplomat. ''No one knows how they will do with her. But everyone knows how they would do without her.''
In her transition to political life, Mrs. Chamorro has benefited greatly from the work of other anti-Sandinista politicians and intellectuals, who spent nearly two years developing the campaign platform. Among other measures, the plan calls for abolition of the military draft; an end to most Government economic controls; encouragement of private enterprise, and a program to give poor farmers full title to the Government-owned lands they now cultivate as state or cooperative farms.
The ready-made set of detailed propositions - worked out in dozens of drafts that circulated first clandestinely, then openly as the election process got under way - has helped Mrs. Chamorro deflect charges that she is unfamiliar with complex issues. But the fact that she played no part in formulating the party platform reinforces criticism that she is simply a mouthpiece for others - an image she finds irksome.
''It's not like the Sandinista Front goes around saying it is,'' she protests, bringing the subject up herself, ''with someone who is telling me 'say this, say that.' ''
Friends and opponents agree that Mrs. Chamorro is best at discussing broad themes, such as the country's exhaustion with war and a Sandinista ideology that she says is forced upon Nicaraguan children ''before they have even left the womb.''
''The people have been betrayed,'' she says. ''They want a change, and how can you blame them? It is because of this Government that we have this war, Nicaraguans against Nicaraguans, the exodus of our professionals, of journalists, of farmers, of everyone, because no one can bear to live here.'' ''The first thing I'm going to do,'' she says at another time, ''is abolish compulsory military service. Then, so that not even Mr. Gorbachev can get his hands on them, I'm going to send all of the weapons to the bottom of the sea.''
Mrs. Chamorro also frequently raises the issue opposition leaders consider their strongest: the country's economic crisis. Although Sandinista officials blame the decline on the war and the American trade embargo, U.N.O. hopes voters will reject the regime that has seen the Nicaraguan economy shrink by more than half since the revolution, cutting real wages to less than 10 percent of their former value and reducing private consumption by 70 percent.
But in interviews, the candidate shies away from most substantive questions, referring them to her advisers or saying that precise answers must wait until after an opposition victory. Asked about her policy on agrarian reform, a central concern in the Nicaraguan countryside, she says only that she will study the problem case by case and that she has a ''grupito de abogados,'' or little group of lawyers, working on it.
Even on crucial issues such as how to handle the contra army - which still maintains more than 3,000 guerrillas inside the country and 7,000 more in Honduran base camps - Mrs. Chamorro avoids direct comment. ''As far as I'm concerned, the contras have been stopped for a long time now,'' she says. ''I can't tell you anything about them because I don't know their leaders, but I understand that they are finished.'' Among the politicians, diplomats and reporters who deal with her frequently, Mrs. Chamorro is widely admired for her casual, motherly style of conversation, which quickly abandons the pretense of formal Spanish for the ''vos'' form, an intimate, antiquated form of address used only in Nicaragua and a handful of other Latin American countries. But she is also famous for slips of memory and language that sometimes leave her listeners agape.
''When they closed La Prensa,'' she says, ''they told us it was because we were supporting the war - when the President, the old one, what was his name? The one I've forgotten now, from the United States. . . .'' ''Reagan,'' an aide tells her. ''Reagan,'' she repeats, regaining her stride. ''When Reagan approved $100 million for the war. . . .''
Like Antonio Lacayo Oyanguren, her campaign manager and son-in-law, many of Mrs. Chamorro's personal advisers are close friends or family members. The group also includes her son, Pedro Joaquin, and is led by Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, the former contra leader who is married to Lacayo's sister. But the members of the group have little direct connection with the elaborate 14-party coalition leadership that sponsored Mrs. Chamorro's candidacy. And many foreign diplomats and even U.N.O. officials believe that the combination of an inexperienced candidate and two powerful sets of competing advisers could create an explosive conflict of authority.
Sandinista leaders have publicly committed themselves to turning over the reins of government if they lose. But a victorious U.N.O. would still have to contend with the Sandinista's almost undisputed control over Nicaragua's large army and security apparatus.
The problems of finding a modus vivendi with a defeated Sandinista Front would only be compounded, the officials argue, by the continued existence of the contra army. Contra leaders have repeatedly said they will oppose any government in which the Sandinistas retain military power. The resulting collision of forces - the Sandinistas, the contras and the perpetual specter of a United States invasion - could tear a Chamorro regime apart.
For some of her supporters, the complexities of such a scenario argue for the very qualities that Mrs. Chamorro would bring to the job.
''This is precisely why Violeta became the candidate,'' says Francisco Mayorga Balladares, Mrs. Chamorro's chief economic adviser and a respected opposition theorist. ''If you had a strong leader who represented very strongly a certain point of view, it would be a disaster, because this is a very fragmented society.''
But others in Mrs. Chamorro's campaign do not try to project beyond election day. ''Violeta wasn't chosen for her abilities as president,'' another opposition strategist says bluntly. ''Violeta was chosen to win.''
NOT FAR FROM MRS. epitaph: ''He never gave up.''
The cemetery is a riot of fallen stones and tangled weeds, held in check only by a work detail of convicts trucked in once a year from a prison on the edge of town. But a dozen years after her husband's death, Mrs. Chamorro still visits twice a week.
''She is very dedicated to him,'' says a watchman who has witnessed her ritual for years. ''You can't work here and not know her.''
In the election fever that has gripped Nicaragua, the cemetery is one of the few significant expanses of urban land not festooned with campaign flags, banners or slogans. But for Mrs. Chamorro - and for the opposition that supports her - the memories it holds will be decisive.
Under regional peace accords, there will be a massive international effort to supervise the fairness of the vote. By election day, some 450 observers from the United Nations and the Organization of American States will be in place to oversee balloting. A distinguished group organized by former President Jimmy Carter has already visited three times to help resolve conflicts over the voting rules.
Politicians on all sides say that the Sandinistas' ability to deliver their supporters to the voting booths could be offset by an exceptionally high overall turnout of voters - perhaps reaching the level of voter registration last fall, when 90 percent of eligible Nicaraguans signed up to cast their ballots. But opposition leaders know that, finally, ballots must be cast for a candidate. And on election day, Mrs. Chamorro's strength will be decided not by the structure of her campaign, or even the fairness of the vote, but by the power of memory.
At the cemetery, the watchman, a middle-aged man whose skin has turned to leather from years in the sun, walks a visitor back to his waiting car.
''Pedro Joaquin Chamorro has been dead for many years,'' he says. ''But in times like these, people don't forget.'' As the visitor pulls away, the watchman turns back toward the thin iron cross. Then, with a gentle, almost reverent motion, he stoops to straighten the flowers on Mr. Chamorro's grave.
