The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 11, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3056 words

HEADLINE: SATURDAY NIGHT

BYLINE: By Susan Orlean: Susan Orlean is the author of ''Saturday Night in America,'' from which this article is adapted. The book will be published by Alfred A. Knopf in May.

 BODY:
SATURDAY NIGHT IS different from any other night. On Saturday night, people get together, go dancing, bowling, drinking, out to dinner, get drunk, get killed, kill other people, go out on dates, visit friends, go to parties, listen to music, sleep, gamble, watch television, go cruising, and sometimes fall in love - just as they do every other night of the week. But on Saturday night they do all these things more often and with more passion and intent. Even having nothing to do on Saturday night is different from having nothing to do on, say, Thursday afternoon, and being alone on Saturday night is different from being alone on any other night of the week. 
For most people Saturday is the one night that neither follows nor precedes work, when they expect to have a nice time, when they want to be with their friends and lovers and not with their bosses, employees, teachers, landlords, or relatives - unless those categories happen to include friends or lovers. Saturday night is when you want to do what you want to do and not what you have to do. In the extreme, this leads to what I think of as the Fun Imperative: the sensation that a Saturday night not devoted to having a good time is a major human failure and evidence of a possible character flaw. The particularly acute loneliness you can feel only on Saturday night is the Fun Imperative unrequited. But most of the time Saturday night is a medium of enjoyment.
For the last few years, I have traveled around the country and spent Saturday nights with a variety of people in a variety of situations, with the intention not to define Saturday night but to illustrate it. What I wanted to know about Saturday night was not so much what is fun to do with your spare time as what, given some spare time and no directives or obligations, people do.
DISTINGUISHING SATURDAY NIGHT FROM the rest of the week began around 700 B.C. with the introduction in Assyria of once-a-week ''evil days,'' and it has remained constant throughout human history, including but not ending with ''Saturday Night Fever.'' I don't know of anything else that has social significance spanning ancient Babylonia and Babylon, L.I.
The origin of Saturday night's distinctiveness was religious - one day each week set aside as sacred, to contrast with the six others that were profane - and over time became economic (a day of rest versus a day of labor). Before this century, days of rest were permitted mainly so that laborers could restore - ''recreate,'' in Victorian terms - their strength and then return to another six days of hard work.
Eventually, as affluence and easy credit spread through the American middle class after World War II, weekend ''recreation'' became an end in itself. Fun was viewed as an entitlement of the middle class rather than an exclusive right of the rich and elite. The satisfying life, after the war, included an imperative to have fun, and Saturday night was the center of it.
How is Saturday night different now from the past? There is no doubt that AIDS has quashed some of the abandon that Saturday night both symbolized and contained - not just in gay nightclubs, but in all bars and clubs and parties. There are other ways social behavior and Saturday night have changed in tandem. A sex researcher told me he believed many people used to have sex only on Saturday nights, in some cases because it was their only chance, and in others because an unconscious sense of guilt made them feel it was improper on ''regular'' nights of the week. He also ventured that having sex on Saturday night was titillating for some people because it was only hours before they would go to church. Sexual liberation, that researcher concluded, has probably changed that. Then there's the effect of indoor plumbing on Saturday night: when baths were once-a-week events at the neighborhood bath-house, Saturday had the distinction of being bath night for most people.
Saturday night happens to be when most people take part in whatever is the current entertainment trend. They might watch a break-dance contest one month, and a lip-synching contest the next, and a lambada-dance (Continued on Page 82) demonstration the one after that. I began to think of this aspect of Saturday night culture as the Palace of Social Meteors. Every city I've ever visited seems to have a bar or nightclub called the Palace, the local showcase for whatever the current public diversion happens to be. I made a practice of avoiding the Palaces and all study of Social Meteors. Bar life is certainly a constant of the American Saturday night, but the ancillary activities that take place in them, I'm convinced, are mostly new ways to get people to spend money on drinks, and their evanescence proves only that people get bored with the ways they keep busy in bars.
It's hard to think about Saturday night without realizing that chronological time itself is something of an anachronism these days. Schedules are less rigid now than in the past. When I was a kid, grocery stores closed at 6 and were never open on Sundays. I still remember the first time I went to a 24-hour grocery at 4 in the morning, thinking that something fundamental had changed forever. You used to be out of luck for money on the weekend if you didn't get to the bank by 3 on Friday. Now most people I know don't even know when banks are open because they use 24-hour automatic-teller machines. Most stores are now open every day, since blue laws were repealed.
The way we perceive time changed when the American economy shifted from agriculture to industry. On a farm, the significant unit of time is a season. On an assembly line, though, you're inside all the time and you work all year round and you have no interaction with the natural physical world, so seasons no longer matter. What matters is the week, and you know that if you're annoyed to be back at work, it's probably Monday, and if you just got paid and feel more cheerful, it's Friday, and if you're happy, it's the weekend.
Now, as manufacturing, with its regular hours and rigid schedules, is displaced by a service and high-tech economy that runs incessantly, night and day, the convention of the five-day work week and the two-day weekend is coming apart. Many workers have unusual schedules - swing shifts, night work, three-day weekends. They also have their pay deposited electronically, bank by phone, shop at midnight, and tape ''The Tonight Show'' and watch it at breakfast. The idea of having to get to a bank by 3 on Friday or to watch Johnny Carson at midnight seems, in the 1990's, nostalgic.
Murray Melbin, a sociologist at Boston University, recently wrote that we have run out of land to colonize, so we are now colonizing nighttime, operating businesses 24 hours a day and setting up services to obviate the importance of time. Many people work from their homes via computer work stations and modem hookups and don't have work schedules. Soon, the week as we know it won't mean anything. Some people see this as liberation. Other people - I'm inclined to include myself in this camp - think it sounds awful. Maybe it would eliminate the problems of getting to work on time, but that's only because it means you're at work all the time. And the more the structure of the week disappears, the less extraordinary and special Saturday night will be.
I am not an enthusiast of the seamless week. I think the Assyrians had it right when they decided it was comforting to divide infinity into comprehensible, repeating units of time with distinct qualities. In particular, I would consider losing the singular nature of Saturday night - one night set aside to be off-limits to obligations - kind of a shame.
NOT LONG AGO, I SPENT AN interesting Saturday night in Elkhart, Ind. I had gone there to write about a local imbroglio that pitted the mayor, a young man with conservative tastes, against a group of people who liked to spend their Saturday evenings cruising in fancy cars through downtown. The Mayor saw the issue as a traffic problem; the cruisers saw his efforts as an infringement on their inalienable right to have fun on weekends. I saw it as a chance to see how seriously people take Saturday night.
I arranged to meet the cruisers at 9 o'clock, so I could ride with them on Main Street. At 7, I went to an Italian restaurant someone had recommended. I hoped the restaurant would be a quiet hole-in-the-wall. It was not. It was the sort of place that attracts every birthday celebration, first date, last date, prom date, anniversary party, engagement celebration and stag party within a 200-mile radius. I am not unaccustomed to being alone in a crowd, but this was the first time in my life I had dined alone at a restaurant - let alone a restaurant preferred by big, ostentatiously convivial groups of people - on a Saturday night. It was a largely disagreeable sensation.
I noticed that I was being noticed by the people seated near me. I decided that the best defense was to look busy, but reading the label on the aspirin bottle in my purse took only a minute. Next, I read the menu. Then I turned to the place mat, which had only a photograph of a beach - I never thought I would see the day when I would miss place mats with puzzles on them. I wondered whether I could leave without being too obvious, and if I left, whether I could get a more secluded dinner somewhere else.
My musing was interrupted by my waitress, a tall woman with curly brown hair, a high forehead and a voice that could cut through dry wall. Her nametag said MARIAN. She greeted me and asked if I was meeting someone. I said I wasn't. ''Here on vacation?'' she asked. When I said I was in town doing work, she gave me a long look full of pity. At that point, all I wanted was to get a quick dinner and get out. Marian, however, dawdled. After she took my order, she tidied my place setting and filled my water glass. She checked my salt and pepper shakers. I began to suspect that in her eyes I was a statistical freak - in the area of customers, a Fourth of July snowstorm. Finally, she grabbed a waitress passing by, turned her so she could get a good look at me, and said in a loud, clear voice, ''Just look at her! My God! All by herself and working on Saturday night!''
After that dinner, and after I had gone cruising, I set out to see how Americans spend Saturday night. Is it regional? Is it a matter of age and marital status? Relative wealth? Urban versus suburban versus rural? Is there such a thing as a typical Southern Saturday night, or a middle-aged Saturday night, or a working-class Saturday night? Is there some place that has sprung up to replace the vanished town squares and bars and bowling alleys where people used to gather when they wanted to get together and had no particular place to go?
This task had a few challenges. For one thing, many people, including me, often spend Saturday night at home. For a reporter, this is a tough world to infiltrate. And judging by many of the Saturday nights I've spent this way, their pleasures are too self-referential to bear description. It is also true that in the era of disaster news, people have come to expect to be written about only when something exceptional takes place in their lives. Quite often, people would ask me to come back when the town was having its jazz festival or mariachi festival or rodeo. That wasn't what I was after. I had this notion that Saturday night itself was a good enough subject. I liked the contrariness of examining leisure in an era that is career-crazy, and average citizens in an era that celebrates celebrity.
There were a few things about Saturday night I wanted to figure out. For instance, even though Saturday night is itself a democratic occasion, I wondered if most people choose to spend it undemocratically - that is, to spend it around people just like themselves. Some Saturday night situations don't appear to have any social parameters. One Saturday night, I hung around the emergency room of a large veterinary hospital in New York City. I'd heard there were certain animal accidents (cats falling out of windows, especially) that seemed to happen mostly on Saturday nights, and I wanted to find out why. I also wondered whether there was any similarity to the people who ended up at such a place on Saturday night when they didn't have an emergency. Some flattened cats did come in (it was a hot night, and a lot of people had probably left their windows open) but there were also a lot of people who just chose that night to have their dogs' teeth cleaned or their sick parakeets put to sleep. Except for sharing a somewhat unconventional notion of pet care, these people apparently had nothing in common. The animal emergency center aside, I saw some white people at a black church social I went to, and some black kids and a few upper-middle class white kids hanging around the white, blue-collar cruising crowd in Elkhart. But generally, it seems that Saturday night acts as a subset intensifier.
THE POSSIBILITY OF A dateless, hourless, calendarless future notwithstanding, I was happy to discover that Saturday night still does have a distinct personality and effect on most people. People still act differently on Saturday night for no reason other than it's Saturday night. For instance, there are fewer long-distance calls made Saturday night than any other night of the week. What is it about Saturday night that inhibits the urge to make calls? Is it that so many people are out, or that those who happen to be at home assume that anyone they want to call is out? Or does it just feel weird?
On Saturday night, there are the fewest airplane flights, the most murders, most taped radio shows, fewest television viewers, most visits to the emergency room, fewest suicides, most scheduled showings of ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show,'' most people breaking their diets, most liquor sold by the glass, the fewest number of calls to businesses offering products on television, and the highest number of reported incidents of cow-toppling in rural Pennsylvania. These might at first seem like weird specifics - informational dead ends, like knowing that 75 percent of all Iowans think Scotch tape is the best modern invention - but they really add up to a picture of what Saturday night in America is like.
It is a time when people listen to prerecorded radio shows, are too busy to watch television, have accidents, don't feel like killing themselves, go out for the evening and forget to close their windows and own curious cats with bad depth perception, feel like seeing campy movies, are in the mood to eat with abandon, drink in bars, aren't in the mood to order the five-volume set of Slim Whitman's greatest hits or aren't home to fall victim to the ad, see cows sleeping in pastures and are inspired to tip them over just for fun. It's in keeping with what the Assyrians had in mind when they first established the seven-day week.
FOR THE LAST FEW YEARS , while considering the nature of Saturday night, I have kept a clipping from The Chicago Tribune wire service over my desk, headlined: ''Leisure Time Shrinks By 32 Percent.'' The article says: ''Since 1973, the median number of hours worked by Americans has increased by 20 percent, while the amount of leisure time available to the average person has dropped by 32 percent. The difference between the rise in working hours and the drop in leisure time has been the time that people spend on work around the house and other responsibilities that do not qualify as work. The trend toward less and less leisure time has been steady and inexorable, according to a Harris Survey.''
If the law of supply and demand is universally true, the shrinking of leisure time could only serve to make Saturday night more valuable. In a world with 32 percent less leisure time, wouldn't a night imbued with pleasure and abandon remain an important and welcome tonic, no matter how irrelevant the conventional notion of time may come to be?
That equation seemed especially evident to me in Elkhart. It is a classic working-class town - more than half of its residents are employed at building, servicing, selling or outfitting recreational vehicles and customized vans - and the people I met there are probably among those Americans whose leisure time is shrinking the fastest. Accordingly, they considered Saturday night a matter of enormous consequence. ''The week is just something I get through until Saturday night,'' one man told me.
When Mayor James Perron banned cruising on Main Street, it set off three years of furious public debate. The superficial concern was traffic flow. What really got everyone roiled up was the idea that the city was legislating their leisure time. ''I'm a working man and I pay my taxes,'' the same man said, ''but no one's going to tell me how to spend my weekend. That's all mine.''
I also have posted over my desk something I found buried in a survey about leisure-time activity. It says: ''Fifty-four percent of those surveyed have sex at least once a week but ranked it below gardening and visiting relatives as regular activities.''
For a year or so, I didn't really know why I was so taken with this piece of arcane data except for its innate comic value. I went to spend Saturday night in a few dozen different places around the country. Time and time again I saw that Saturday night was indeed something special -a time when people are most at ease with themselves. Surveys and statistics of any sort began to seem less important once I realized that Saturday night is mostly mythic: larger than life, more meaningful the less closely it is examined, romantic in the purest way, more an idea than an event.
At last I figured out why that survey seemed to have a particular connection to my interest in Saturday night. According to the survey, most people have sex less often than they garden or visit their relatives, but I'm positive that they still consider sex the larger, more mystical, more mythic, more important, more noteworthy experience. That is how I finally feel about Saturday night. It is a matter of quality over quantity. If you add them up, there are many more weekdays in our lives than there are Saturday nights, but Saturday night is the one worth living for.

HEADLINE: 'YOU DON'T LOOK PUERTO RICAN'

BYLINE: By AVIS C. VIDAL; Avis C. Vidal directs the Community Development Research Center in the Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy at the New School for Social Research.

 BODY:

PUERTO RICANS
Born in the U.S.A.
By Clara E. Rodriguez.
218 pp. Boston: Unwin Hyman.
Cloth, $44.95. Paper, $14.95.
In ''Puerto Ricans,'' Clara E. Rodriguez, an associate professor of sociology at Fordham University, calls for more studies of the Puerto Rican community, and answers her own call with this profile of Puerto Ricans living in the United States since the end of World War II. Her book is concerned primarily with New York City, until recently the home of the majority of Puerto Ricans on the mainland, and it generally presents a useful assemblage of information in a format readily accessible to a wide readership. 
Ms. Rodriguez concentrates on four topics - race, education, housing and work - treating these topics in the context of both Puerto Rican history (particularly the island's distinctive relationship to the United States) and the American economic and social structure. Her characterization of Puerto Ricans as a unicultural, multiracial, integrated group entering a multiethnic, biracial, segregated society is intriguing, and she draws helpful examples of this contrast from both literature and personal experience. She notes, for instance, that ''nearly every Puerto Rican has heard, at least once in his or her life, 'You don't look Puerto Rican.' The implication is that there is a Puerto Rican 'look' - although, given the racial diversity of Puerto Ricans, it is hard to tell what this would be.''
Embedded in the basic description of the Puerto Rican community are nuggets of information and distinctive perspectives that many readers are likely to find quite thought provoking. Puerto Rican family income is less than half that of white families, and about 70 percent of black family income, Ms. Rodriguez tells us. Moreover, she says, Puerto Rican workers are more heavily concentrated than either whites or blacks in the rapidly declining manufacturing sector. Even some native New Yorkers may not know that at the time of its decline, the South Bronx housed the city's largest Puerto Rican community.
The limitations of the book stem primarily from its introductory, essentially descriptive, character. Ms. Rodriguez does not provide the reader with much insight into the implications of the points she raises. For example, she suggests that ''Puerto Ricans see themselves as racially different from the way they are seen by others'' because of differing attitudes toward race in Puerto Rico and in the United States. The implications of this discrepancy for census and other data are considered at some length, but its possible effects on Puerto Rican individuals, families or communities are not explored. Similarly, the reader gets no help in thinking through the implications of these cultural differences for the persistence of residential segregation or for policies intended to reduce discrimination.
In fairness to the author, it must be recognized that some omissions can undoubtedly be attributed to the paucity of work on Puerto Ricans that Ms. Rodriguez has urged scholars to address. In light of the increasing importance of the Puerto Rican population in New York and of the Hispanic population nationally, this lack is striking. For this reason, Ms. Rodriguez's book makes a real contribution.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1054 words

HEADLINE: NEVERTHELESS, THE MAIL ARRIVES

BYLINE: By BERYL A. RADIN; Beryl A. Radin teaches public administration at the Washington Public Affairs Center of the University of Southern California.

 BODY:

BUREAUCRACY
What Government Agencies Do and Why They Do It.
By James Q. Wilson.
433 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.95.
James Q. Wilson, always an innovator, has done it again. Most academics hope that their students and colleagues will someday honor them through a Festschrift - a collection of articles or essays contributed by a number of authors in honor of a colleague or teacher. Mr. Wilson, now a professor of management at the University of California at Los Angeles, has turned the practice on its head. This study of the behavior of government agencies draws on the work of his students over a quarter-century. Mr. Wilson honors them by writing a volume that rests on the books, articles, doctoral dissertations and seminar papers completed by his graduate students, mostly at Harvard. 
As he notes in the preface, his is ''a book filled with details about police departments, school systems, the CIA, the military, the State Department, regulatory commissions, the Postal Service, the Social Security Administration, the Army Corps of Engineers, the Forest Service, and many others.'' It is dense - weaving a mountain of findings from empirical work around a classic set of organizing themes: the purposes of organizations, the individuals who staff them (whom he calls operators, managers and executives) and the contexts in which they work.
Mr. Wilson uses the findings to show bureaucracy as a complex and varied set of institutions, not the monolith it seems in the classic work of the German sociologist Max Weber. It is the complexity, Mr. Wilson argues, that helps to explain the behavior of bureaucrats. They are not individuals who are uncontrolled or gone awry. Rather, they are people who are behaving in response to the incentives, punishments, rules, laws and organizational structures that make up our public agencies.
''Only two groups of people deny that organization matters'' according to Mr. Wilson, ''economists and everybody else.'' Economists believe that organizations are black boxes that convert inputs into outputs; noneconomists argue that only people in organizations - not the organizations themselves - matter. Indeed, organizations transform the individuals within them. The tendency of bureaucrats to become averse to risk is not accidental. ''All organizations by design are the enemies of change . . . government organizations are especially risk averse because they are caught up in a web of constraints so complex that any change is likely to rouse the ire of some important constituency.''
While many of these arguments are not new, Mr. Wilson presents them economically. He writes that three key constraints affect public bureaucracies: inability to keep the earnings of the organization; inability to allocate the resources in accord with the preferences of the organization; and lack of control over the choice of goals. These constraints in turn limit efficiency; as a society we value political equity, accountability and authority, and have been unwilling to cede them to anyone, let alone unelected bureaucrats.
Mr. Wilson reminds us that legislators judge government programs differently from the way they judge government bureaucracies (an observation that helps to understand the Congressional propensity for ''micromanagement''). He identifies four kinds of agencies (he calls them production, procedural, craft and coping organizations) and uses this typology to comment on differences among their activities.
Despite this clear conceptual framework, at times ''Bureaucracy'' raises more questions than it answers. Problems are created by Mr. Wilson's determination to integrate so many diverse sources of information. Much of the research work that is the basis for the book focuses on one organization at a time and does not lend itself to an aggregate approach. It does not provide the basis for a real understanding of why this agency seems to work well and that one does not.
Further, Mr. Wilson's reliance on his own earlier work on regulation appears to contradict other findings included here. His discussion of the arbitrary and rigid use of rules sometimes seems to be overdrawn; he does not differentiate between types of rules (between substantive and procedural rules, for example) but, rather, he is critical of rules per se. He seems to believe that government in the United States has reached its maximum size, commenting that ''almost every agency one can imagine already has been created.'' This fixed view of American society is not credible, particularly in light of Mr. Wilson's own analysis of the relationship between bureaucracy and political culture.
In an interesting chapter called ''National Differences,'' he argues that politics and culture explain the differences between bureaucracies administering similar policies in the United States and several European countries. Although his discussion of the distinctive character of the American bureaucracy is convincing as far as it goes, it fails to relate these observations to the special demands on public agencies that are created by the heterogeneity, size and diversity of the American population itself. Large federal systems - such as those found in Canada or India - might serve as a more useful point of comparison.
The book concludes with a defense of bureaucracy. Mr. Wilson comments that we live in a country where Social Security checks arrive on time, where institutions operate, letters get delivered, passports are obtained in a week. He notes that ''there are not many places where all this happens. It is astonishing it can be made to happen at all.''
But missing from ''Bureaucracy'' is an analysis that helps the reader to understand why the ''bash the bureaucracy'' movement has reached epidemic proportions around the world. The National Commission on the Public Service, headed by Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, reported last spring that despite the enormously important work to be done, the public sector has ''been clouded by a sense of frustration inside government and a lack of public trust outside.'' The 1988 Presidential political campaign had already indicated a willingness by both candidates to address these perceptions. One wishes that Mr. Wilson had focused more directly on them as well.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
No Joy, but Also No Panic in Florida

BYLINE: By DAVID PITT

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 10

 BODY:
There is no joy in Port St. Lucie, 109 miles north of here.
Nor, for that matter, is there much to speak of in Kissimmee, Yuma, Plant City, Mesa, Dunedin or any of the 25 communities in Florida and Arizona that would normally be awaiting the arrival of the 26 major league baseball teams for spring training, that magical solstice that revitalizes local economies and winter-benumbed fans alike.
On the other hand, there is no widespread panic either, despite Friday's reaffirmation by the baseball owners that they still planned to keep camps closed until a new labor agreement is reached with the players.
For one thing, a settlement was still theoretically possible in advance of the officially scheduled opening of the training camps next Friday.
For another, many businessmen and officials in some spring training communities -there are 17 in Florida (with two teams in West Palm Beach) and eight in Arizona - remained cautiously optimistic this week that they could weather the losses, even if the whole exhibition season was lost. 
But in a handful of smaller towns, such as those in Florida that lack beaches, dog tracks, jai alai emporiums, alligator farms, parrot jungles and other alternative attractions, spring baseball provides almost exclusively for their tourist-season dollars, and the mood this week was gloomy.
In Winter Haven, the inland Florida bastion of the Boston Red Sox, 218 miles north of Miami, most residents' yearly earnings mainly come out of two things: the citrus industry and spring baseball, neither of which look particularly prosperous enterprises at the moment.
Last month, a record cold snap froze much of the county's fruit and vegetable crop, a disaster that caused an estimated $600 million in losses statewide and hurt hundreds of people among Winter Haven's 25,000 residents.
''A lot of our local employees were already reeling because of the freeze, and it'll just be terrible if spring training is canceled,'' said Henry Philpot, general manager of the 325-unit Holiday Inn, which has set aside 75 rooms for the regular Red Sox players and almost as many for the minor leaguers.
The hotel is also counting heavily on two Boston-area travel agencies, which traditionally fly in scores of dyed-in-the-wool Red Sox fans.
''This is the time of year that a waitress who makes $2.01 an hour is going to be getting extra tips for six or eight weeks, money she really needs this year, especially if her husband works in the groves,'' Philpot said. ''Plus we hire extra people and give out overtime, and all of that is money that folks here have come to depend on year after year.''
''We did a definitive study a few years back showing the economic impact of having the Red Sox here, and it was $8 million to $10 million a year,'' said Joyce B. Davis, executive vice president of Winter Haven's Chamber of Commerce. ''We have not assessed what the impact would be this year if they didn't come, but certainly it will be significant.''
In Dunedin, Fla. (population 35,000), the Gulf Coast winter home of the Toronto Blue Jays, apprehension is also beginning to grow, especially since the town just spent $2.2 million on a new stadium and was counting on income from this season's exhibition games to start paying off the bonds.
Officials say the town stands to lose $300,000 in the event of a six-week lockout, although their contract with the Blue Jays includes guarantees that would eventually allow Dunedin to recover direct losses. But that won't help the groceries, hardware stores and other small businesses that will lose income they have come to rely on during the winter.
 
Reduction in Revenue Seen
Moreover, Pat McGarr, executive vice president of the Dunedin Chamber of Commerce, predicted that local hotels and motels, most of which remain totally booked for now, face at least a 50 percent reduction of income if a lockout sparks a wave of cancellations.
It could mean devastation for Dunedin's season, McGarr said.
But in large cities like Miami (Baltimore Orioles territory), Phoenix (Oakland Athletics), West Palm Beach (Montreal Expos and Atlanta Braves), many business people, especially hotel and restaurant operators, say that while die-hard fans will be emotionally devastated by a spring-training lockout, they fully expect that throngs of Northerners will still find reasons to leave the snow and slush.
Even in some smaller places, like Port St. Lucie, home to the Mets and more than 16,000 year-round residents, many people saw little reason for despair.
''It probably won't hurt us much at all economically, after all, it's Florida and it's wintertime,'' said Joanne Bovee, sales director of the Radisson Hotel in Port St. Lucie, an Atlantic Coast community where the Mets have been working out their preseason kinks since 1987, when they moved from St. Petersburg.
''The fans will be disappointed, of course, and some of the smaller businesses here will be hurt,'' she said. ''But this is the height of the season, so we would fill up anyway. There's always the beach, you know.''
 
A Matter of Big Business
Florida's Department of Commerce estimates that spring training is worth about $330 million a year, much of that in money spent by the teams, as well as in ticket sales, hot dogs, beer, souvenirs, pregame and postgame bar receipts, hotel and restaurant costs, rental cars and everything else under the sun that goes with baseball's annual rebirth. Others argue that if they could add in all the incalculable losses, such as free baseball-related publicity for tourism, the figure would be far higher.
But the $330 million generated by spring training, Florida officials are quick to note, is a drop in the ocean compared to the nearly $30 billion that tourists spend in the state each year.
On top of that, lockout or no lockout, the minor league teams are still coming to places like Port St. Lucie, and their money is just as good. While the Radisson, the team hotel for the Mets, has set aside 30 rooms for the regular players, it is holding 80 rooms for the minor leaguers.
''And they eat breakfast and dinner here, too, so that's quite a good revenue for us,'' a spokeswoman said.
 
Less Effect in Fort Lauderdale
In Fort Lauderdale, where the Yankees have been loosening up every winter since 1963, the effects of a lockout are likely to be even more negligible, said James Vance, an official of the city's Chamber of Commerce.
''It's not going to have quite the economic impact here that it might have in other parts of the state,'' Vance said, noting that Fort Lauderdale, like many parts of Florida, still has plenty of tourist appeal even without spring baseball. And the traditional spring-break invasion of college students is looming.
According to a Florida study two years ago, of the nearly $300 million generated by spring training in 1986, the 18 teams that winter in Florida spent $11.9 million for food, housing and transportation.
Fans, on the other hand, spent $282.6 million, plus $3.4 million buying tickets, peanuts, hot dogs and so forth at the 17 stadiums around the state.
Officials say most of the 1.3 million people who watched Grapefruit League games last year were either Florida residents or out-of-state people who planned their vacations around baseball.
 
Canadians Expected Anyway
Many Florida businessmen and officials say that while many people may cancel their vacations in the event of a lockout - large numbers of St. Louis Cardinal fans, for example, may decide not to make the yearly drive from Missouri to St. Petersburg - there is one group of visitors that is virtually certain to show up in Florida, no matter what: Montreal Expos fanatics from snow-bound Quebec.
Between the Quebecois rooters and the Atlanta Braves fans, who share the same stadium, officials in the Expos' headquarters of West Palm Beach think that spring training generates at least $30 million a year, but that if it is canceled, the Canadians, at least, will still be in town.
''If you live in Quebec, and you've been coming here for 30 days a year for six years to watch the Expos and get away from that weather, would you seriously consider canceling your trip?'' asked Dennis Grady, executive director of the West Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce. ''No way. You're going to look outside at the snow, and say, 'Well, I may not get to see any baseball, but I'm going to be at the beach and I'm going to play a lot more golf.' ''
''But what's a guy going to do sitting in Lakeland waiting for the Detroit Tigers?'' Grady added. ''Go to the corner, watch the light change? There's no beach to go to there.'' He paused.
''Sorry, I've got nothing against Lakeland,'' he said. ''Maybe I said that because I'm a Cleveland Indians fan getting in a shot at the Tigers.''

HEADLINE: Outdoors;
Facing Spawning Challenges

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant

 BODY:
The Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans faces a double challenge created by dwindling stocks of Atlantic cod and severely depleted spawning runs of Atlantic salmon in many of Newfoundland's rivers.
As early as last September, the Canadian-American Atlantic Salmon Federation, which is the largest salmon conservation organization in North America, and its regional affiliate, the Salmonid Council of Newfoundland and Labrador, were asking the department for a five-year closing of Newfoundland's commercial net fishery for salmon. At the same time, another organization, the Salmon Preservation Association for the Water of Newfoundland, asserted that the federal government's inadequate management plan for the commercial harvest of salmon had resulted in ''nothing less than a total rape of the resource at the expense of our salmon rivers and this province's economy.''
The federation has long been asking for a reduction in Newfoundland's commercial harvest of salmon, maintaining, among other things, that many of the nets are set in locations that result in interception of significant numbers of salmon bound for the rivers of other provinces and New England. 
Last year, natural causes erased most of that problem. Lack of rain in Newfoundland resulted in large numbers of salmon milling about in river estuaries waiting for enough water to begin their upstream spawning runs. The netters focused on those stalled legions of Newfoundland fish, and in many locations, particularly along the province's south coast, only a few salmon escaped the nets and moved upriver to spawn. This also devastated the sport fishery in those streams.
Canada has an Atlantic Salmon Advisory Board appointed by the minister of the Department of Fisheries and Oceans. The board's membership embraces three user groups, commercial and sport fishermen and native (Indian) bands.
In January 1989, the first year after the termination of Canada's five-year management plan for Atlantic salmon, the advisory board met in Montreal to discuss a second five-year plan. Of that meeting, said David Clark, who is president of the Atlantic Salmon Federation and that organization's representative on the board, ''the debate between the user groups was less acrimonious than it had been in the past.'' He added that the commercial fishermen seemed somewhat resigned to a reduction of their salmon harvest in Newfoundland.
''We felt, after private discussions with senior public servants and politicians, that we were going to succeed in getting quotas imposed on the commercial salmon fishery and all that was left for debate was the level of those quotas,'' he said of the sport fishing interests.
A few weeks later, Clark said, the Canadian Government announced that it was reducing the commercial take of cod in an effort to rebuild depleted stocks. This move created a furor, he added, with commercial fishermen blaming the Government for overstating the health of those stocks through the 70's and early 80's and for allowing the fishery to expand during that period.
Having been obliged, Clark said, to further restrict the cod fishery, ''the Government didn't have the stomach to give the commercial fishermen a double dose of bad medicine and did virtually nothing about salmon.''
Fishing, whether for cod or salmon, is vitally important to Newfoundland's depressed economy.
The government did set an allowance of 1,400 metric tons for the Newfoundland commercial salmon fishery. This was not an enforceable quota, but that proved academic because the actual take was only 930 metric tons. Over the last decade, the production of salmon in the rivers of Labrador and Newfoundland has been in decline, and for the last three years that decline has accelerated. This has taken place even though the goal of the first five-year plan was to stabilize, or even increase, Atlantic salmon populations throughout the Atlantic provinces.
The salmon shortage, said Clark, ''has resulted in Newfoundland's sport fishing interests coalescing under the leadership of Tom Humphrey of Grand Falls.'' Humphrey is president of the Salmonid Council.
There are 26,000 domestic salmon anglers in Newfoundland and 3,500 commercial fishermen with salmon licenses. It is estimated, said Clark, that the latter are taking more than 90 percent of the annual harvest.
Late last November, the Department of Fisheries and Oceans convened a workshop under the chairmanship of Wayne Shinners, one of its deputy ministers, in Newfoundland to hear what residents had to say about the condition and management of its salmon resource. A one-year moratorium on salmon fishing was discussed. Clark said that Indian groups indicated that they would support whatever was necessary to restore the salmon stocks. The commercial fishermen said that if they were not allowed to fish, anglers should be similarly restricted.
Shinners's department has announced another reduction in the cod quota for this year, and, he said, there will probably be additional cuts in 1991 and 1992. The smaller quotas have already created hardships for commercial fishermen, he says, and adds that major fish processing plants employing thousands of workers are scheduled to be closed.
Commercial fishermen have long been aware that cod stocks are dwindling, Shinners said, adding that their immediate concern is how the harvest will be allocated between the inshore small boat fleet and the big blue water trawlers. The reduced cod quotas have, Shinners said, made dealing with the salmon problem doubly difficult, in part because many commercial cod fishermen also hold licenses to net salmon.
Nonetheless, Skinner added that he has every expectation that additional steps will be taken this year to protect the salmon, whether river-by-river or river zone harvesting, enforceable quotas, or even, perhaps, a one-year moratorium on commercial salmon fishing with the netters being compensated for loss of income.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
BASEBALL FINANCE SETS A GALL STANDARD

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
In international finance, gold was always the standard. But in baseball finance, gold and glory always combined to set the standard. Once upon a time, Babe Ruth signed an $80,000 contract with the Yankees in 1930, right after the Wall Street crash. As the President of the United States that year, Herbert Hoover was being paid $75,000. And when the Babe was asked if he thought he deserved to be making more money than the President, he supposedly replied:
''Why not? I had a better year than he did.''
But now baseball finance has a new standard. Call it the gall standard. The gall of the club owners. By proposing revenue sharing, a pay-for-performance scale and a salary cap in the current labor negotiations with the players, the club owners have the gall to try to bank even more profits by restructuring the system in which they are prospering as never before. 
Don't fret that the season is in jeopardy. Even if the spring training camps don't open on time, the season will. The owners might be stubborn, but they're not that stupid.
Not that the players aren't part of the problem. In creating labor unions in this nation more than a century ago, Samuel Gompers did not have multimillion-dollar baseball players in mind. But there's too much money in baseball now for either side to be too rigid in its demands. The players aren't struggling for a living wage. The club owners won't go out of business if the current system is retained.
After all, the current system has produced the symbol of baseball's gall standard: Pascual Perez, a 32-year-old right-handed pitcher who has a three-year, $5.7 million contract with the Yankees.
But the club owners, after having knighted nine players with annual salaries of more than $3 million in the last few months, want to negotiate an economic structure that will protect them from themselves. They want a system that will prevent them from guaranteeing somebody like Pascual Perez $5.7 million for three years, especially when Perez doesn't guarantee anybody anything but a jar of headache tablets.
Perez has emerged as the gall standard's classic example of extravagance without excellence. Here is a pitcher with a history of drug and alcohol problems who had a 9-13 record with the Montreal Expos last season. Considering his past, a 9-13 record might jeopardize his career. Instead, George Steinbrenner bestowed $5.7 million upon him.
Don't blame Perez. If the Yankees and their principal owner were dumb enough to offer him that much money, he was smart enough to accept it. As he has explained, ''The reason I jump to New York is simple: they pay.'' And now he can afford to pay for a chauffeur. When he pitched for the Atlanta Braves, he once drove around the interstate highways circling the stadium there for an hour before stopping to ask directions.
Perez's contract has been the measure of just about every player's new contract, or at least every pitcher's. If a 9-13 pitcher is worth a three-year, $5.7 million contract, what's a good pitcher worth? Even crazier, what's an even worse pitcher worth?
Not that the Yankees have been the only team signing players for more than they are worth. Much more. But the club owners can't spend so much money on so many journeymen players and expect the players union to allow them suddenly to decide to be thrifty.
Not when total revenue for the 26 major league clubs was at least $1 billion in 1988, the last year for which figures are available. Not when television rights and ticket prices keep rising. And not when the club owners twice were found guilty by arbitrators of collusion in ignoring the availability after the 1985 and 1986 seasons of such outstanding free agents as Tim Raines and Jack Morris, to name two. A charge of collusion after the 1987 season has yet to be ruled upon.
Ever since salaries began soaring in the free-agent era after the 1976 season, the feeling here has been that players and pitchers who produced were not only worth whatever salary they could command but also were a financial bargain to their club owners.
In the beginning, Reggie Jackson and Rich (Goose) Gossage, among other free agents, were not the only reason the 1977-78 Yankees were the last franchise to win the World Series in two consecutive seasons, but they also contributed to Yankee Stadium attendance records. Since then, the Mets won the 1986 World Series with such high-salaried attractions as Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez. Because of Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield, the Yankees continued to attract two million spectators. And now Rickey Henderson of the Oakland Athletics and Will Clark of the San Francisco Giants are selling tickets in the Bay Area.
But in the process, somehow the salaries of journeymen ballplayers rose as proportionately as those of the best players.
In other areas of entertainment, that has never been true. At a Frank Sinatra concert, he gets the big money but the violinists don't. In a Jack Nicholson motion picture, he gets the big money but other actors don't. In baseball, however, most of the violinists and the other actors, alias a light-hitting second baseman or a useful middle-inning relief pitcher or a 9-13 starter such as Pascual Perez, are millionaires, too.
That's where the club owners never held the line on salaries. The union and the agents outsmarted them. Now the club owners want a system that will minimize the value of agents. The club owners have only themselves to blame, but they're trying to blame the union.
Of all the sports in America, baseball has a reputation as the most romantic. But a labor dispute is a reminder that, for its fans, baseball is a romance of unrequited love. And undetermined expense. When baseball's new collective-bargaining agreement is finally signed, the fans will eventually pay for all the increases in costs and salaries.
That too is part of baseball's new gall standard.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Security Guards: New Position at Camps

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
On page 3 of the memorandum telling the clubs not to open spring training camps until otherwise notified, the heads of the owners' negotiating team wrote: ''Major league training camps shall remain closed during the duration of any labor dispute and the P.R.C. will arrange for a security service to guard all spring training camps 24 hours a day during the labor dispute.''
On first reading, that statement could be taken to mean that the Player Relations Committee wants to make sure that players don't sneak into spring stadiums in Florida and Arizona on their own during a lockout and use the clubs' facilities. The P.R.C., however, wants to make sure that the clubs don't sneak players in.
Scott Sanderson understands the purpose of the guards, but he wonders if their presence would make a symbolic statement.
''Does it suggest that the owners don't trust each other?'' asked Sanderson, the Oakland pitcher who is also a member of the players' negotiating committee. ''Does it mean they're concerned about getting a jump on each other by conducting illegal workouts?'' 
After posing the questions, Sanderson linked the thought to the players' mistrust of the owners based on their labor experiences in the 1980's.
''If that is the case,'' he said, ''that suggests to me that one team can't trust another about starting practice and they're asking us to trust them. It adds a little more skepticism.''
The guards will very likely take up their positions Thursday. No spring workouts are scheduled until Friday, but Thursday is the technical reporting date for pitchers and catchers. The P.R.C. has said that any players who have been working out on their own at their teams' facilities in Florida and Arizona will not be permitted in the parks beginning Thursday if the owners and players don't have a new collective-bargaining agreement.
Sanderson has raised his views about the security guards with Charles O'Connor, P.R.C. general counsel. O'Connor doesn't deny the reason for the guards, but he thinks Sanderson takes it too far in assessing ''trust.''
''We want to assure everybody that everybody is playing by the same rules,'' the owners' chief negotiator said. ''It's the competitive side of baseball. I told him to take it to its logical conclusion. It's like the N.C.A.A. or a high school athletic association would do. It's de rigueur.''
O'Connor alluded to college and high school rules about such matters as beginning preseason practice.
''He thinks it's making a point,'' the lawyer added, ''but it only has to do with when you can open training, when you can bring players in. That's what it's about.''
 
Owner Strategy Puzzles Miller
 Marvin Miller sits on the sidelines and wonders what it's about - the lockout, that is. Miller, during whose union tenure salary arbitration and free agency were created, is puzzled by the owners' bargaining strategy and wonders what is really behind it.
On one hand, he speculated that the owners, despite their stated intention of improving labor relations, are out to break the union. (Of the idea of improving relations, Miller recalled his first meeting with Ray Grebey, the negotiator whom the owners dismissed after the 50-day strike in 1981. ''He said his primary aim was to improve the relationship,'' Miller related of the man the players came to view as a would-be union-buster.) But as he continued thinking out loud, Miller offered another, more intriguing speculative view of the P.R.C. motives.
''Maybe the lockout is aimed at the 'have' owners,'' Miller said.
He meant the ones whose revenue is significantly greater than that of most of the clubs and who spend much more lavishly, the Yankees and the Angels, for example. The Yankees, the epitome of a ''have'' team, have a local television deal that will pay them $485 million over 12 years. George Steinbrenner, however, is firmly opposed to a greater degree of revenue sharing among owners than already exists.
Miller offered this possible reasoning by the owners: ''We can't get you to agree to share local television. You threaten to sue if we take it by legislation. Since we can't get it from you, we have to use the players.''
A lockout, Miller noted, would affect the ''have'' teams first and most. If they lost games that were to be televised, they would lose significant local television revenue. If those owners, on the other hand, were to offer to share that local revenue with the ''have-nots,'' the owners wouldn't have to go to the players with their revenue-sharing plan and they would have no need of a lockout.
 
A Peculiar Relationship
 As the American League player representative, Paul Molitor, the Milwaukee Brewers' third baseman, is an important member of the players' labor negotiating team. As chairman of the Player Relations Committee, Bud Selig, the Brewers' owner, is an important member of the owners' bargaining team.
''It's made it somewhat peculiar, to say the least,'' Molitor said. ''There's enough respect there that I don't think it would cross the border of friendships that have been established. Yes, we are on different courses in that room, but once we're out of the room, we can continue our relationship. I'm not concerned for our relationship. It just makes it somewhat strange.
''When you have a problem, whether it's about a player or your organization, you call Bud. He's a good sounding board.''
Molitor related that after a negotiating session in Tampa, ''we hopped on a plane together and flew back. We had a chance to review what happened. We had a chance to exchange ideas on revenue sharing.''
 
Relief Pitchers' Bonanzas
 Relief pitchers, as a group, have fared remarkably well in personal negotiations this winter. Mark Davis, a free agent, led the economic parade out of the bullpen with a four-year, $13 million contract from Kansas City. Then came the three-year deals: John Franco of the Mets, $7.6 million; Jeff Reardon of Boston, $6.8 million; Dan Plesac of Milwaukee, $6.5 million; Tim Burke of Montreal and Jeff Russell of Texas, $6.3 million each, and Roger McDowell of Philadelphia, $6 million.
Dennis Eckersley of Oakland is entering the last year of a three-year contract worth $2,387,500 in salaries (he has earned $350,000 more in bonuses). His salary for 1990 is $787,500. Eckersley has been the best of the relief pitchers for the last three years.
Ed Keating, Eckersley's agent, took seven categories and 16 relievers and determined that Eckersley's average rank based on three-year statistics is 2.43. Closest to him is Plesac at 3.71.
Eckersley ranks first in four categories: baserunners per inning (0.87), opponents' batting average (.204), strikeouts-to-walks ratio (7.7 to 1) and total walks (31). The right-hander, who walked only three batters in 57 innings last season, is third in saves (94), fourth in strikeouts per inning (.97) and sixth in earned run average (2.49).
It sounds as if Keating is preparing a salary arbitration case, but the statistics are aimed at the contract extension Eckersley will soon have from the Athletics.
''They said they are going to do something,'' Keating said. ''They have already agreed to do so. I haven't sent them any numbers. I'm waiting until everyone is done. They said they would do something in spring training. We said we don't want to start the season without it. We're not saying it in a threatening way. Sandy Alderson is good people. We just want Dennis to be protected.''
Alderson, the Athletics' general manager, was in a similar position with an underpaid Dave Stewart and gave him a two-year extension for $7 million earlier this winter. As Stewart did, Eckersley will most likely receive a large signing bonus to take care of his relatively low 1990 salary and will get hefty salaries for two more years.
 
Applying Lockout Language
 Tom Henke would like to join that parade of relief pitchers, but the Toronto Blue Jays seem to be heading toward arbitration with him Wednesday rather than signing him to a three-year contract. Actually, Henke had agreed to a $7.3 million contract, but the deal fell apart over lockout language.
Henke wanted protection against a possible lockout in 1991, just in case this year's labor dispute somehow became next year's. But the Blue Jays declined to accept one of three proposals made by the pitcher's agent, Craig Fenech: apply the lockout language only to this year, flip-flop the 1990 and 1991 salaries if there were no lockout this year but one next year or, if there were a lockout next year, take $1.9 million of his proposed 1991 salary of $2.6 million and pay it out as a deferred signing bonus.
Henke has told the Blue Jays he will leave as a free agent after the coming season if they do not sign him to a three-year contract. If he leaves, perhaps he can lead a whole new parade next winter.
 
1-13 Good for $660,000
 Pitching for Atlanta and Montreal, Zane Smith went through last season with only one victory. He lost 13 games. Last week the Expos signed him for $660,000 for the coming season. That's a raise of $135,000, or 25.7 percent, just a little more than the cost-of-living increase.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Two-Families in Bushwick;
Widening the Paths to For-Sale Housing

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, where other news lately has been grim, something of a home-building resurgence is under way. It has demonstrated that even in one of the poorest sections of the city there are people of moderate means willing and able to invest thousands of their own dollars in a new house.
That, in turn, calls attention to the entire for-sale component of the city's 10-year housing plan, which began in 1985. What started as a program to build one- or two-family homes for buyers typically with incomes from about $25,000 to $50,000 has widened into an effort to achieve impressive figures on housing production. That can only be done with multifamily construction.
The shift raises two key questions: Will city government will be able to assist middle-income production while holding the subsidy-per-unit within reasonable bounds? And are the undoubted benefits worth the significantly greater risks of multifamily development? 
Various models have been considered, all with attendant difficulties. The administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins will no doubt find itself wrestling with the issues.
An example of the two-family option is the completed development called Bushwick Estates - 49 two-family houses on George Street, off the commercialized Wilson Avenue. The location was a dreary pocket of little-used territory not far from Bushwick's substantial industrial buildings, many of them nearly vacant. It is also close to the Morgan Avenue station on the L subway line.
Four blocks away Maria Hernandez was killed by a gunshot through the window of her house last August, apparently in reprisal for the vigorous campaign she and her husband had been waging against drug dealers. In the same neighborhood, 14-year-old Jose Luis Lebron was killed on Jan. 31 by a police officer who was investigating a robbery and mistakenly thought the boy was armed. Five days before that, another teen-ager, Louis Liranso, was also shot and killed by a police officer.
BUT an affordable new house exercises a powerful appeal, notwithstanding the community's considerable concern, in particular, over drug traffic.
Bushwick Estates brought forth buyers such as Alfredo Mora, a welder who was born in Ecuador, and his wife, Buenaventura, a nurse and graduate of Hunter College. They have an infant son, and Mr. Mora's mother and sister have moved into the apartment on the first floor. Half the other owners on George Street also rented to relatives. ''We saved for four years,'' said Mrs. Mora. They put $13,000 of their savings into their house at contract time and about $6,000 more a year later, in November, for closing costs. The rent they receive helps offset their $1,140 monthly housing cost. The price of the house was $132,000.
The cost to build the houses averaged $173,400, figuring a zero land cost. The average public subsidy was $40,000 a house, or $20,000 a unit.
The Ridgewood-Bushwick Senior Citizens Council, the marketing agent for the houses, had 200 qualified applicants from Bushwick for the houses. Those who had to be turned away are on the list for future Bushwick developments. The developer was the New York City Partnership, which spent five years - from 1983 to 1988 - getting the city-owned land into construction, mainly because it was difficult to find bank financing and a builder in that location.
The Beechwood Organization of Williston Park, L.I., which did the job, was the only eligible respondent when the Partnership's invited builders to take it on. The architect of the buff-brick houses, trimmed with white aluminum siding, is the firm of Fakler & Eliason of Fresh Meadows, Queens.
Beechwood is a partnership of Lesie Lerner, an architect, and Michael Dubb, a landscape architect. They have built houses in East Meadow, North Hills, Great Neck and New Hyde Park on Long Island, but they found it good business to take on steady work in Bushwick with an assured market and a profit, when they hold within budget, of 10 percent on each house.
FOR security, they fenced in their entire construction site before they began, with spiral razor wire above the eight-foot barrier. ''The last thing that happened is that we took the fence down,'' said Mr. Lerner.
Beechwood provided touches not always seen in assisted housing: a canopy over the separate entrance doors to the two units. Owners can enclose them for added security and privacy if they wish. There are also small balconies, mansard roofs and an attempt to provide stylistic variety in the facades.
The Partnership had to presell all the houses before construction could begin. As a rule, about half the houses are presold in a new-market area before builders and banks are prepared to accept the risk of new construction in an untested market. The amount of underused industrial land in the vicinity made it even harder for banks and builders to envision it as a residential neighborhood.
THERE is more to come in Bushwick now that the market is better established. This year Beechwood will build 51 more two-family houses, El Rosario Partnership Homes, near Our Lady of the Rosary of Pompei Church, between Bushwick Avenue and White Street, on Siegel and McKibben Streets. And 120 other two-family houses are to be developed by Beechwood elsewhere in Bushwick, 70 of them on scattered sites.
But two-family houses, in which the Partnership has specialized, is only one form of for-sale housing. Under the 10-year plan of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, the goal was to produce 23,000 housing units for the moderate- to middle-income market through the Partnership. The plan also envisioned 5,000 one-family houses produced under the Nehemiah Plan, following the pattern established under that name by the East Brooklyn Churches in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
Beyond that there were to be 9,000 units in combination developments - with condominiums selling at market prices and presumably generating profits that would be used to lower rents for new rental buildings.
Names like Spring Creek in eastern Brooklyn and Melrose Common in the southern part of the Bronx would come to the fore as centers of large-scale new development. With the proceeds generated from land sales for the market-rate effort in the Arverne section of Queens on the Rockaway Peninsula, a large-scale infill development would be produced in nearby Edgemere.
For the Partnership, starts of 2,000 units are scheduled this year. That figure would double next year if the projected multifamily developments go forward, said Kathryn Wylde, president of the Partnership's housing affiliate, and state and city provide the necessary subsidies. Some would be in three-family houses - an owner with two tenants. Others would be in midrise buildings, typically of 8 to 12 stories.
But midrises pose a problem, as the Tibbett Gardens development of 750 units in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx is demonstrating. First there is the question of community acceptance. Though approved by the Board of Estimate, Tibbett Gardens has been opposed by community leaders and Borough President Fernando Ferrer. Beyond that, there is the issue of public cost: City officials estimate the required subsidy at $45,000 an apartment, including the value of the land, assuming all apartments are sold within a year.
But additional loans are required to hold down the interest expenses built up during the construction period, and the extent to which they are repaid depends on the speed of sales. According to city officials, if it took six years to sell the full development, the subsidy requirement would rise to $60,000 an apartment; if all escrowed money were used, the subsidy could be as high as $90,000 an apartment.
The Tibbett Gardens plan, proposed by the Real Estate Board of New York, has been criticized by the office of State Comptroller Edward V. Regan as one in which the public benefit does not justify the public costs or risk. It has written of its concern to the Financial Control Board.
There are other possible forms for assisted multifamily middle-income development. One is a limited-dividend cooperative: the city would provide land and subsidies up to $40,000 an apartment; a nonprofit sponsor would enter the picture; tax-exempt financing would be available; buyer income would be limited to a maximum of about $42,000 in most locations (or more in a poorer, or targeted, area). The underlying mortgage on the building would help hold initial purchase prices down.
Another model is the condominium-renter approach launched by the Koch administration with the Lefrak Organization and the Milstein Organization on two sites. Success there depends on the strength of the market when condominiums are sold. Profits from market-rate sales would subsidize the rents for lower-income buyers.
But midrise and high-rise construction is expensive and risky. Even the costs of pure construction are at least 30 percent higher than they are for small houses, and the development risks are far greater. In the end, the Dinkins administration may find it extremely difficult to meet the production goals laid out by its predecessor.

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
Waterfront Plunge Is Paying Dividends

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
WHEN Michael DiScala and James Gardella bought the Lock Building near the waterfront of the South Norwalk neighborhood 17 years ago, they knew that the city was at its nadir. The partially rented, 125,000-square-foot factory was losing $60,000 a year and was surrounded by derelict industrial buildings in an area that attracted street people.
Confident that someday development then swirling around Norwalk would revive the city, they paid $200,000 for the two-acre property. Today, the building is at the hub of a spreading, multimillion-dollar restoration wedged between the new $30 million Maritime Center - a waterfront aquarium complex converted from a 19th-century factory - and the old City Hall, to be expanded into a the 96-room Maritime Inn by Robert Katz, a local developer.
Around the corner on Washington Street, the Collins Development Corporation of Stamford turned abandoned factories and ship chandleries into an enclave of antiques shops, clothing boutiques, restaurants, art galleries and condominiums that on weekends and holidays draws droves of tourists. 
Recognizing the DiScala building as the link securing a two-square-block historic district, Norwalk officials are expected to grant final approvals this month to tear it down and, in its place, allow construction of a $70 million, 552,000-square-foot complex of apartments, offices, shops, restaurants and parking for 900 cars.
The project, to be called Maritime Square, was designed by the Norwalk architectural firm of Beinfeld Wagner & Associates. Mr. DiScala, president of M. F. DiScala & Company, a local real estate concern, is the developer, with Mr. Gardella a passive owner-investor.
''It represents critical mass - the more the better for the overall success of South Norwalk,'' observed Sal Buono, senior vice- president in the Stamford office of Grubb & Ellis, a nationwide realty company. ''More businesses, hotels and other tourist attractions are needed, but in the short haul, continuing growth in that area will depend upon lenders. Local banks are having problems, so alternate sources must be sought.''
Mr. DiScala said he is not worried about financing. ''We have been approached by banks and pension funds from Japan, Germany and the Netherlands,'' he said, ''although we have never used foreign financing before. The Japanese have taken a liking to Fairfield County and to big, self-contained, mixed-use projects like this, where diversification takes some of the gamble away.''
He has also talked to Chase Manhattan, but says American lenders are interested only in short-term construction financing while foreign lenders have a long view and will do the permanent financing required to pay off the construction loans.
''MONEY from foreign lenders is not only available but cheaper,'' he said, ''by about a half a percentage point.''
Owning the property helped tremendously in developing it. ''You never sell the land,'' he said. ''No matter how long it takes, you hold it and wait. My father came to this country when he was 21. He liked Norwalk and he kept buying property here. We still have a European attitude. Syndicates out for a fast buck are not our style.''
Once the project is approved, he anticipates an eight-month period for working drawings, bidding and financing. Demolition and construction would then begin early next fall, with an opening in 1993.
His company will oversee the selection of retail tenants to complement those on Washington Street and along West Avenue, where the Gap, a Clark's of England shoe store and other retailers have recently opened, and will remain on the premises as manager.
Some 200 apartments, mostly one-bedroom units of about 750 square feet, and six two- and three-bedroom penthouses with views of the Norwalk River and harbor, will occupy the upper four floors of the six-story building. The remaining space will contain 45,000 square feet of offices, 35,000 square feet of retail space lining the entire length of the ground floor, and 10,000 square feet of restaurants. Seven elevators and a concierge will serve residential and office tenants.
No decision has been made on whether to rent or sell the apartments as condominiums, although Mr. DiScala believes the glut of condos now on the market will have been absorbed by the time he is ready to open.
Edward Leary, director of the city's planning and zoning department, said: ''Norwalk has 441 unsold condominiums on the market, 321 units approved for construction, 676 units under construction, and applications pending for another 540 units, including those at Maritime Square and 300 units to be built by the Starrett Corporation in their redevelopment of the South Norwalk railroad station.''
Late this month, the city is expected to enact a one-year moratorium on multifamily housing of 12 units or more, followed by new regulations limiting the number and location of such housing. Maritime Square is in one of the few districts that will be exempt.
Coordinating with the city's plans for more parking at the Maritime Center, DiScala will buy the municipal parking lot opposite the center, incorporating it into its project, and assigning 400 parking spaces to center visitors. ''The city saves about $4 million by not having to build the garage,'' said Mr. Leary.
MARITIME SQUARE will achieve its length of 630 feet by building over part of Marshall Street just east of the Maritime Inn and extending to Water Street. A landscaped cul-de-sac will mark the new end of Marshall Street, from which pedestrians can go through an areaway to the Maritime Square Plaza entrance on Water Street, and cars may enter the garage. A second garage access will be on Ann Street at the project's north end. Residential tenants will have reserved spaces; the rest will be open to the public.
Additional tourist attractions under consideration include Mayor Frank J. Esposito's plans for transient docking facilities on the river enabling visitors to arrive by boat, and for a city-owned building next to the Maritime Center to be sold to accommodate the Museum of Cartoon Art, founded by Mort Walker, originator of the ''Beetle Bailey'' cartoons, and now in Rye Brook, N.Y. A planned extension of Water Street north to I-95 would alleviate traffic congestion.
