HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: South Street Seaport;
Delays in Redevelopment Imperil Historic Properties

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
COLLAPSE and construction. The signals are as contradictory as any area can send and they are found within a few yards of one another in the South Street Seaport Historic District in lower Manhattan, symbolizing both the tenuous redevelopment and continued abandonment of that 19th-century quarter.
What is under construction is the headquarters of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey, on Water Street, between Beekman Street and Peck Slip. Meanwhile, two doors north, a large chunk of brick wall has fallen off the top of a 153-year-old coppersmith shop and warehouse.
Speaking generally about the 11-block district along the East River, David F. M. Todd, chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said: ''I'm disappointed that things haven't moved faster. The longer this drifts, the more the deterioration.'' 
''Projects within the district are now viewed as highly risky,'' said Dana C. Rowan, vice president of N. M. Palermo, a real estate concern headed by Douglas E. Palermo that has several holdings in the area. ''Risky projects typically demand higher yields from lending institutions and investors, translating into fewer dollars left over to pay for the high-quality restoration work these buildings deserve.
''The Seaport is at a critical point, where it can either build momentum toward finishing the restoration and redevelopment work or it can continue to suffer from failed or half-hearted attempts,'' Mr. Rowan said.
In that context, attention has turned to a parking lot on the west side of Water Street, between Beekman Street and Peck Slip, that Paul and Seymour Milstein have been trying to redevelop for seven years. Five of their proposals for 250 Water Street - including a 43-story apartment tower - have either been rejected by the landmarks agency as inappropriately large or withdrawn.
The landmarks commission voted Tuesday on the Milsteins' latest proposal, for a 12-story office building with 407,000 square feet, designed by Platt & Byard Architects. But there were not enough members either for or against the application to produce the six-vote majority needed to dispose of the matter. Another vote may come Feb. 20.
Opponents and supporters of the project agree on one thing: it may represent a crucial turning point. Critics said it would be a troubling precedent, an oversized building in a small-scale historic district.
Advocates said its size had been reduced acceptably and that the project would spur economic activity, and much-needed rehabilitation, in the district.
''Commencement with 250 Water Street, in its current design, will do much toward re-establishing confidence in the future of the Seaport,'' Mr. Rowan said, adding that it might determine whether Palermo went ahead with a redevelopment project of its own at Water and Beekman Streets.
David Feinberg, who owns property on Peck Slip and Water Street, also urged the commission to approve the Milstein building. ''If we don't do this,'' he said, ''you won't have to worry about future meetings, because there won't be a Seaport.''
His description is not completely hyperbolic. Take the case of the four-story Samuel Thompson coppersmith shop and warehouse, 247 Water Street, which was built in 1837. It is an elegant study in contrasts, with massive granite piers on the ground floor and delicate, 24-pane window frames in the top floor.
BUT a passerby does not need an engineering degree to see that it is in distress. The facade sags at either end, without a right angle anywhere, and the piers lean perceptibly. Last month, after a snowfall and windstorm, a whole section of the upper facade fell to the street, leaving a yawning hole.
Gerry Bakirtjy, an architect in the neighborhood who testified in favor of the Milstein proposal, said, ''If the economic vitality of the district is not restored soon, there won't be any original fabric left to save.''
Opponents of the project see an equal threat to the district posed by a building as large as the Milsteins'. They urged the commission to keep 250 Water Street within the height of two other major projects.
One is the Seamen's Church Institute headquarters, designed by James Stewart Polshek and Partners. It will have seven floors and 32,000 square feet and include a rebuilt version of the 191-year-old Schermerhorn ship chandlery, 243 Water Street, which has been reduced to its brick facade. The first four floors of the new building will be red brick, to match the chandlery, and the upper stories, set back from the street line, will be white steel and glass.
This project has been approved by the commission and foundations are in place.
The other major project is a 242-room hotel, combining three new buildings with 10 existing structures on both sides of Front Street, between Beekman Street and Peck Slip. It is being developed by the Metropolis Group, whose principals include Robert Reveley and James Fusco, and designed by Rafael Vinoly Architects. The hotel has about 170,000 square feet and its highest portion has eight floors.
Most of the project has been approved and the developer expects to begin foundation work in the spring.
AFTER changing size and shape considerably, the Milstein proposal emerged last fall as a 15-story office building with about 480,000 square feet, clad in brick and granite at its base, with cast stone and glass in the upper stories, which are stepped back.
''We came away with the impression that the design was acceptable except in terms of size,'' one of the architects, Charles A. Platt, told the landmarks commission. ''What was done - this was much to the horror of our client because these are the most valuable floors - was that floors were taken out of the middle of the building. By taking the floors out, the whole thing shrinks.''
But it has clearly not shrunk enough to satisfy many preservation and neighborhood groups, Community Board 1, the South Street Seaport Museum, and Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, among other elected officials.
''The latest proposal, despite the eloquent presentation, is a rogue elephant masquerading as a butterfly,'' said Lloyd N. Merrill, chairman of the Southbridge Towers co-operative and a committee chairman on the community board.
''If you approve this latest incarnation, you're only rewarding the Milsteins' persistence,'' said Rita Grolitzer, a resident of Southbridge.
In testimony read by an aide, Ms. Messinger said: ''This latest attempt comes closest to being acceptable. But the issue is not whether this proposal is more reasonable than those which have preceded it.
''At 148 feet,'' Ms. Messinger said, ''it would tower over existing buildings within the district, which average four to five stories, as an imposing and intrusive presence.''
About the existing structures, Christabel Gough of the Society for the Architecture of the City, said: ''They housed small businesses. Their smallness speaks to us of a period of our history which should not be forgotten.''
But the architect Hugh Hardy, who wrote on behalf of the Milstein proposal, argued that ''we are no longer a society of small-shop keepers living above the store and the requirements of modern development therefore demand buildings larger in scale.''
Other supporters of the project in its current form include the New York Landmarks Conservancy, whose executive director, Laurie Beckelman, has been named by Mayor David N. Dinkins to succeed Mr. Todd as head of the landmarks panel.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Still Homesick After All These Years

BYLINE: By ERIC J. ADAMS; Eric J. Adams' first book, ''Loss of Innocence: A True Story of Juvenile Murder and Justice in America,'' will be published next summer by Avon Books.

 BODY:
During the turbulent mid-70's, several friends and I just out of high school bought a used van and traveled west.
We were young and restless refugees from suburbia, angry at society, our parents, our upbringing, out environs. We undertook the journey with no destination, traveling west only because that was guaranteed to take us farthest from the Island.
I remember rigging a pole in the center of our van to support all our belongings strapped precariously on the roof. We were determined never to return. With our eight-track recorder playing, we drove the interstate highway through New Jersey, Ohio, Missouri and the prairies of Kansas until we came to rest within a valley deep in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado. 
Fifteen years have passed since then. Though a few of my traveling companions have returned to settle permanently in New York, I never have. After remaining in Colorado for a decade, I moved farther west to San Francisco. I have a career now, a wife, a son. I think I've grown wiser. I certainly view life differently.
Lately I have been asking myself with more frequency than I'm comfortable with if the time has finally come to move back to Long Island. I shudder at the idea, but oddly, I am drawn to it as well.
Once, when my hair was long and I lived in a log cabin in a town with a population smaller than my graduating class, I could not conceive of returning to the purgatory of suburbia. It was the worst of all possible worlds for an idealistic teen-ager searching for the meaning of existence. With its housing developments, shopping malls, highways and Cadillacs, suburbia lacked the grit of the city and the reality of the country. Long Island was a limbo-hell without a soul. What meaning could be discovered in a place whose geographical and spiritual center was Fortunoffs? For me and many others my age, Long Island was no place to live in, it was a place to flee from.
Somehow I made it through college, cut my hair, learned that you're obliged to pay some dues, jump through some hoops. I moved to a city. My values changed. The times have changed, too. The 70's, which formed my identity, were rife with political and social upheavals. The Vietnam War was ending. Feminism rising. Corporate America justly losing a degree of sanctity in the public mind. And social justice was earning the recognition it deserved. It was an era of change and hope, of idealists readily swapping what was for what could be.
With the 80's we learned how quickly idealism can tarnish. War was a state of mind. The ring of the cash registers drowned out accusations of corporate greed. And in a world saturated with child abuse and crack, how does one measure social justice anyway?
The country took a shift toward the conservative, the materialistic. Though I hate to admit it, I guess I did, too. The change in me and the change in times have made living on Long Island an option again. Suddenly Long Island wasn't the living hell I had imagined. There are obvious reasons to return. Though I haven't lived in striking distance of Roosevelt Field for quite some time, by a quirk of fate I married a woman who grew up just around the corner from me in Roslyn Heights. We moved to San Francisco independently.
One day, based on our acquaintance as children, we stepped out for a drink. Then we began dating. We surprised ourselves more than our parents when we announced our engagement. ''You travel halfway around the world,'' a relative told me at our engagement party, ''only to marry the girl next door.'' He said it as if his astute perception implied a greater cosmic message, that I had erred in moving away in the first place.
It would have been different had I married a spouse from San Diego or Minnesota. Mine is a big Jewish family and Kathy's a big Catholic family, and if anyone is looking for a double-whammy of guilt to return home they are invited to move in with us. Our families are good enough to keep the direct pressure to a minimum, but their intentions are always clear.
But what's so wrong with living close to the relatives? My mother is growing older. I see it in the way she walks and talks. My father in no longer around to help her, and my sister moved her family to Vermont when the Long Island economy became too much to bear.
Suddenly, I feel both the obligation and the desire to take care of my mother, to let her know her grandson, and for him to know her before it's too late. She is a vibrant woman who never lost the mysteries and ebullience of the old country, a wonderful storyteller and the quintessential grandmother. She still lives in the house where I grew up and though she is blessed with friends and relatives, she values her children above life itself. That will never change. With my sister and I gone, no parade of friends and relatives can make her feel anything but alone. Meanwhile, the years tick by.
Kathy's family is huge and effervescent and welcoming with an embrace that is almost smothering. They exude vitality and warmth. They moved recently to a co-op on the ocean in Long Beach and they spend summers at a country home in upstate New York. They are continually planning family gatherings and outings and showering each other with gifts and surprise parties.
I kind of like the idea of our son, Jesse, growing up knowing his families. They have so much to give and are so willing to give it. San Francisco is a wonderful city and we have lots of friends there, including many couples like us with babies. Invariably, however, we lose touch with them or they move away. Our friendships run wide but rarely do they run deep.
Maybe we could put up with tract housing and Fortunoffs if the deal came complete with grandparents and aunts and uncles. Maybe we could stand to bear the Long Island Expressway congestion if we were on our way to visit people who loved us and our son, unconditionally and forever. Family is family, and if ever there was a concept endemic to New York, it is this.
For me, perhaps more than Kathy, there is also the desire to come to terms with the past. I left Long Island an angry young man. On my visits back in subsequent years, I always viewed it with a certain distaste. I saw it as corrosive and gray. It was how I imagined Moscow to be, dreary and oppressive. The accents were thick and the attitudes inhospitable.
By comparison, San Francisco and most major cities west of the Mississippi seemed undeniably more livable. But New York is my city. I grew up there. It shaped me. Just as one has to come to terms with one's parents, I feel compelled to come to terms with my city. Some circle within me would never be completed if I failed to stare Long Island in the face, forgive its trespasses and asked it to forgive mine.
That process has already started. Now that I know how difficult it is to save money to buy a home, those small houses with little backyards don't appear as ridiculous as they did. Now that I have a son who will be attending school, I can understand the desire to live in a good school district. Establishing a family is more work than I ever expected and so I have had to lower my ideals slightly. Long Island and I are not so far apart anymore.
So, after late-night phone calls with our families, Kathy and I invariably discuss the merits of moving back to Long Island. It's a hard decision. We are both very independent by nature and we know that by moving back we would be forced to endure the unconscious domination of our families.
Our interfaith marriage complicates the matter. In San Francisco, it's easy to strike a balance between our religions. In New York, we would have to deal with the pressures of family every Friday night or every Sunday morning, not to mention every Passover and Easter.
Away from Long Island we have created a comfortable sense of family by incorporating attitudes and lifestyle decisions that don't make much sense to our families (What do you mean you don't eat meat?). We've come to enjoy the freedom and the responsibility to be whatever we choose. In New York, there are so many roles we would be expected to fill.
When we visit we are welcomed guests. The distance makes us celebrities and we enjoy that status. When we are apprised of those little family spats that consume families and pit relative against relative, we thank our stars that we are long-distance observers to the drama and not players on the crowded stage.
We also love the West. There is a great spirit of optimism and faith in humanity in San Francisco, a city of unfathomable tolerance. Just as we have embraced San Francisco, San Francisco has embraced us. Even the earthquake couldn't shake us out of town. Only Long Island could. Long Island and our families.
Will we move back? We don't know. It seems that when one of us becomes resigned to returning, the other can't bear the thought of leaving.
Moving away from Long Island was so easy. Why is it so hard to think about moving back?

HEADLINE: Budget Plan Puts Pressure On the Towns

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
WHETHER the $7.2 billion budget that Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed last week is a masterwork of hard-nosed cost-cutting, as many Democrats contend, or a magician's trick full of trap doors, as the Republicans see it, one thing is almost certain as the debate over it goes on: aid to towns and cities, although up from last year, will not be enough. And while the Governor's budget would not raise taxes, municipalities probably will.
Municipal officials say that with demands surging for services from education to garbage disposal, state aid has not kept up in many communities - even during the boom years of the mid-1980's, when grant totals from the state were rising by double-digit amounts. Generous increases in funds are a fond memory in the current era of budget austerity. 
In the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, aid to towns from state operating funds has risen 7.5 percent from last year, and total grants have gone up 6.2 percent, to $2.2 billion. But 127 of Connecticut's 169 communities had to raise property taxes again for the current year, according to the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, the group that represents towns' interests before the General Assembly. The increases pushed the average per capita property tax burden over $1,000 for the first time, the group said.
Mr. O'Neill's budget, which he presented to the General Assembly on Wednesday, would increase the operating-fund aid to the towns by 2.9 percent; total municipal grants would grow by 5.8 percent, to $2.36 billion, mostly through the sale of bonds.
Those are across-the-board figures from the proposed budget. Some towns would not even fare that well. In Stratford, for example, the total amount of ''formula grants'' from the state - the single largest category of direct aid - would rise only 1.88 percent, to $11.4 million, in the year that begins July 1.
''The state has once again not kept pace,'' said Stratford's Town Manager, Ronald W. Owens.
Mr. Owens said Stratford was forced to raise its property taxes by 6 percent this year. Last year, the increase was 8 percent. Even with such increases, the town has been running deficits in its budgets, according to figures from the state's Office of Policy and Management.
Even more troubling to Stratford, a town of 51,000 people, are the state-aid totals for education, which is the largest and fastest-growing budget category, accounting for nearly 50 percent of the total $78 million town budget.
State budget documents show that the single largest direct education grant for Stratford, the education cost-sharing funds, would rise by 3.9 percent, to $6.6 million, under the Governor's budget. The second-largest grant, to help Stratford meet special-education costs like the state-mandated programs for disabled children, would remain unchanged at $2.18 million.
Unfortunately, Mr. Owens said, the special-education costs are growing fastest. ''Our special-education costs are increasing by leaps and bounds every year,'' he said.
 
Growth in Local Aid
What promises to add further consternation as the budget talks unfold at the Capitol are the means by which Mr. O'Neill's budget officers arrived at the local-aid totals.
With a $90.1 million deficit projected for the year that ends June 30 - and, according to the Assembly's budget office, a gap of $417 million for the next year - Mr. O'Neill said he had slashed spending by $600 million from the amounts requested by the state agencies and had arrived at an overall spending increase of just 4.5 percent for the coming year - the lowest rate of state spending growth in 15 years.
In his speech before the combined House and Senate, in which he outlined the budget and opened the legislative session, Mr. O'Neill pointed with pride to the fact that local aid - up 5.8 percent - had been maintained as well as it had in the face of such austerity.
Within hours of the address, however, the Republicans, who make up the minority in both chambers of the Assembly, were charging that the growth figure was deceptive and that the local-aid funds were at the heart of it all.
Their argument, which promises to echo through the remaining three months of the session, is that Mr. O'Neill propped up the local-aid totals by improperly depleting a $215 million property-tax-relief fund. Under current law, they said, the fund was only supposed to be distributed in installments of $42 million a year until the money was gone.
 
'There's No Magic'
Under Mr. O'Neill's spending plan, which budget officials defended as the only way to keep local aid intact, about $180 million of the relief fund would be drained over the next year, with the money going either into the state's main spending account, the General Fund, or directly into grants for municipalities. The remaining $35 million would be enough for one regular disbursement in the following year.
''There's no magic,'' said Anthony V. Milano, who heads the Office of Policy and Management. ''The budget would have been cut had we not had the resources of that fund.''
Mr. Milano said that about $300 million in state expenses that would ordinarily be paid from the General Fund were shifted onto other accounts, like the relief fund, or taken off the budget altogether.
For example, if Mr. O'Neill's budget is passed intact by the Assembly, the Hospitals and Health Care Commission, the Liquor Control Department and the Workers' Compensation Commission - all of which regulate segments of the Connecticut economy - would have their operations funded by ''assessments'' levied upon the businesses that the agencies oversee. Their combined $8 million budgets would simply be removed from state accounts.
''When you start taking things off the budget, that's deceptive,'' said Richard Foley, the state Republican Party chairman. ''It's a dishonest budget.''
Mr. O'Neill, who has said he will seek a third term in November, swept aside such criticisms in his speech to the Assembly, in which he called on lawmakers to restore their spirits and ''stand up for Connecticut.'' The techniques within the budget itself, he seemed to be saying, were evidence that Connecticut would survive its troubles and thrive again.
''This budget says that government will get leaner, but it also says we will get more efficient,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''As resources dwindle, innovations spread. Threatened with stagnation, we respond with change.''

HEADLINE: RINGWOOD JOURNAL;
Residents Angered by Plan to Develop Part of Sterling Forest

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: RINGWOOD

 BODY:
AFTER the rains, this Passaic County borough takes on the appearance of a picture postcard: reservoirs glisten and mist hangs over macadam roadways with a serene beauty.
But a proposal to develop a vast tract of the privately owned Sterling Forest just across the New York State border has angered many longtime residents and environmentalists. They contend that such construction would wreak havoc on existing water tables, endanger water quality and threaten roadway infrastructure built decades ago to accommodate local traffic. A way of life also is at stake, they say. 
''I don't think that it's a question of perceiving a threat; I think that the threat is there,'' said Peter Cannici, the Mayor of Ringwood. ''But if they start building all that up, what happens to one of the last areas of natural beauty where people from all over have come to get away from the cities?''
Any development would be environment-conscious and well studied, say representatives of the Sterling Forest Corporation, based in Tuxedo, N.Y., which has maintained the 18,000-acre tract for some 40 years. The land, which includes miles of hiking trails and a ski center and is the site of the annual Renaissance Fair, had been a major producer of iron ore used in both the Revolutionary and Civil Wars. Many descendants of the original miners still live in the area.
The corporation has pledged that no more than 25 percent of the tract, or 4,500 acres, would be developed as either condominiums or single-family houses. It says the development would not detract from the rural setting.
''There are no set plans yet in terms of what might be constructed,'' said David A. McDermott, a corporation spokesman, stressing that studies had been commissioned to examine the effect the proposed development would have on the environment in surrounding communities in both Passaic and New York's Orange and Rockland Counties. The investment group has retained the services of 13 scientists and environmental experts to research the plan.
Mr. McDermott said that in the last two years the corporation had given assurances to neighbors that the tract would be enhanced, not depleted, by limited construction.
''It would make absolutely no sense for us to hurt the environment here, from both an economic and preservational standpoint,'' he said.
But Jerome Wyckoff of Ringwood, a retired book editor who was born and raised in the area, says that any development, limited or not, threatens the land, which, as an avid hiker, he has come to know and respect.
''All you have to do is look around here and smell the air and drink from the water to know that what we have is precious,'' he said. ''Over the years, development in the area has elevated the flood table and no matter what any one person or group says, if you increase the development, you heighten the problem.''
Mr. Wyckoff, the founder and a former chairman of the borough's Environmental Commission, of which he is still a member, feels that recent flooding in the area is due to development and that wildlife will also suffer if the corporation is allowed to develop the land.
''New Jersey is one of the most populated and industrialized states in the union,'' he said, ''and the importance of open space and a preserved natural environment have to outweigh what we've become.''
While some residents are strictly opposed to any type of housing developments, others say a more realistic approach or compromise might be in order.
''What we have now is something that we really don't want to see changed because we are surrounded by a greenbelt effect,'' said Charles E. DeDeyn, Ringwood's Borough Manager, explaining that about 63 percent of the area is made up of state parkland, reservoirs and watershed property.
Two years ago, Passaic County officials condemned about 2,000 acres of Sterling Forest property to protect it from development. The county and the corporation are in litigation to establish a fair market price for that land, which the county wants to buy.
''Many of us have a problem with high-density development such as town houses or condominiums because waste, no matter what precautions are taken, will eventually find its way into feeder streams that supply our reservoirs,'' Mr. DeDeyn said. One solution, he says, might be construction of single-family houses on property zoned for two- or three-acre lots, but only if waste management systems are put in place that can safely guard against leaching.
Last month, the corporation made public a 21-point plan that it would use to develop the tract and safeguard its natural resources, Mr. McDermott said. It calls for the study of air quality, community design, open-space preservation, fiscal and flood impact, solid- waste management, recreational use and the use of mass transit to reduce automobile traffic in the area.
For Jeffrey H. Tittel, 32 years old, a Ringwood biologist who is the spokesman for Citizens for Land, Environment and Neighborhoods, a local environmental group, the corporation's pledge has done little to lighten residents' fears.
''It just makes me nervous,'' Mr. Tittel said. ''Any developer is going to make promises to protect this and to protect that, but when the developing is done and problems start to arise, are they going to be there to back up their claims?''
Both the group and borough officials also say that local taxes will have to be raised significantly to improve narrow secondary roads.
For Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, the region has special significance and its preservation a heartfelt meaning. As a member of the House Interior and Insular Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, he helped to start Congressional hearings to study the issue.
The forest's preservation, he said, ''is our last chance to put a limit on suburban sprawl and protect the natural greenbelt around New Jersey and New York State.'' A Franklin Lakes native, Mr. Torricelli fondly remembers class trips as a youth into the region to study nature, and he feels that any efforts to eliminate or reduce such land would result in a loss to residents of both states, especially children.
''We're too crowded, and that's the reality,'' he said, ''and to hack away at an area enjoyed by generations of residents who discovered and enjoy nature is self-defeating.''
A bill before Congress, co-sponsored by Mr. Torricelli, Representative Marge S. Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, and Representative Peter Kostmayer, a Bucks County, Pa., Democrat, seeks to authorize a $250,000 National Parks Service study to weigh purchasing the land for preservation. The land's purchase price promises to be a future issue.
''Will it cost us money?'' Mr. Torricelli said. ''Yes, it will, but I think it's something we owe future generations. And we owe it to ourselves as well.''

CORRECTION-DATE: February 25, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 11 about an outcry by Ringwood residents over a proposal to develop a portion of Sterling Forest misstated Jerome Wyckoff's role on the borough's Environmental Commission. He is a past chairman and a longtime member of the commission, not its founder.

LENGTH: 1698 words

HEADLINE: The Clock Is Ticking on David's Island Project

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
THE release of a long-awaited Federal review of the proposed $1 billion residential complex on David's Island, a deserted 78-acre site off the coast of New Rochelle, has renewed a bitter public debate and set the stage for a final state study that will determine whether the project can proceed.
The two state agencies responsible for the final decision have agreed to hold new public hearings on the proposal. No dates have been set, but the hearings must be conducted before the end of the six-month deadline set in motion by the completion of the final environmental-impact statement.
The release on Jan. 23 of the $15 million environmental-review statement, which was prepared by the developer under the direction of the United States Coast Guard, reflects the Federal agency's view that the environmental issues raised by the project have been adequately documented and that the state agencies with regulatory jurisdiction have sufficient information to begin their review.
 
What the Opponents Say
Opponents of the David's Island proposal say the Federal review does not adequately measure the environmental impacts of the project. They welcome the opportunity for further debate. ''When an environmental-impact statement is done with the developer footing the bill, it is ridiculous to think it will be absolutely neutral,'' said Elaine M. Price, a member of the Mamaroneck Town Council who is coordinating municipal opposition to the project in surrounding communities. 
The two state agencies, the Departments of State and of Environmental Conservation, have agreed to hold the parallel but separate hearings because of the public interest involved, spokesmen for both departments said last week. They denied that the adequacy of the Coast Guard's review was an issue.
The project is the largest residential development ever proposed for Westchester's Long Island Sound Shore and would be the largest and most expensive residential development built in the county in recent years, planning officials said. The hearings will provide an additional forum for supporters who maintain that the project will stimulate the city's stagnant economy and support its schools. Opponents, on the other hand, will have an opportunity to contend that the proposal will destroy the area's fragile environment.
The proposed development for the city-owned island includes a 2,000-unit condominium complex, 100,000 square feet of commercial space, an 800-slip marina, a restaurant and a heliport, connected to the mainland by a 3,465-foot bridge.
Because it has the regulatory responsibility for deciding whether to issue a permit for the bridge, the Coast Guard supervised the preparation of the final environmental statement.
 
Coast Guard Comments Studied
The intention of the developer, Xanadu Properties Associates, to build a bridge is the only feasible alternative for the estimated 3,701 people the project is expected to house, the regional office of the Coast Guard has concluded. The proposed $40 million bridge would be built over one-fourth of an acre of Glen Island Park. The park is owned by the county. The Coast Guard's comments on the bridge and every other aspect of the plan are now being scrutinized by state, county and municipal agencies, the city of New Rochelle and by citizens and environmental groups. These groups have until March 14 to submit their comments on the four-volume document to the Coast Guard.
But attention is focused on the state agencies because the actions they take will determine the future of the project. Under both Federal and state environmental laws, the request for a Coast Guard permit automatically requires a review by the New York Department of State, which supervises the environmental protection of the state's coastline through its Coastal Zone Management Plan. The nine-year-old state environmental plan establishes 44 criteria that a coastline-development project must meet, said William F. Brown, a spokesman for the Secretary of State, Gail F. Shaffer.
The department ''tries to strike a balance between development and preservation,'' Mr. Brown said, and its ultimate recommendations have the force of law.
Two years ago, Xanadu Properties withdrew a proposal before the Department of State could consider it, Mr. Brown said, adding, ''They knew we planned to reject it.''
The developers subsequently tried to meet the department's concerns and modified their proposal, reducing the maximum height of the buildings to 31 stories from 55, providing limited public access to the site and offering to build their own sewage-treatment plant.
 
Three Primary Issues Remain
Issues of height, public access and sewage treatment remain as the New York Department of State's primary concerns, Mr. Brown said. ''We can scale down whatever we decide is too ambitious for that area of the Sound,'' he added. His department can require the developer to amend the plan in order to proceed with the project, Mr. Brown said.
Issues from the size of the proposed marina to the effect of adding treated sludge to Long Island Sound will be the particular focus of the hearings conducted by the Department of Environmental Conservation, said Ralph Manna, the regional director.
While neither of the two departments technically has overriding jurisdiction, the action of the Department of State could decide the issues, Mr. Manna said. Referring to the 44 criteria in the Coastal Zone Management Plan, he said: ''The coastal-consistency issues of the Department of State are very important to us. These issues become the binding terms by which our department plays out the rest of its decisions.''
If, for example, the Department of State requires the developer, Xanadu, to reduce the height and density of the project or to provide additional public access and Xanadu refuses, then a decision by the Department of Environmental Conservation on the adequacy of the sewage treatment would not be necessary, Mr. Manna said.
 
The Deadline Is July 24
A decision by the two state agencies as to whether the proposal is consistent with state policy must be made by July 24, Mr. Brown said, under the six-month parameters established by state environmental law.
Should the two state agencies approve the David's Island plan with few modifications, the focus of interest could shift to a different set of elected officials. The city of New Rochelle is expected to ask the County Board of Legislators to forward a home-rule message to the State Legislature, requesting a non-park use of part of Glen Island Park.
The request, which would need approval by the Board of Legislators first, would require a change in state law. Several county legislators have publicly opposed the use of county park land for a bridge, and the outcome of a vote by the board is not certain.
 
New Rochelle's Role
Several members of the Board agreed last week that they had no reason to begin any action. ''We haven't been asked to take any action by anybody,'' said Diane A. Keane, a Republican legislator from Rye. But she added: ''A lot of peope are lobbying us on this project.''
''It's up to the city of New Rochelle to request action from us,'' said Stephen P. Tenore, a Republican legislator from the city. ''There is absolutely no reason for us to take any action unless the city asks us.''
Gordon Marshall, one of several partners in Xanadu Properties, said he was optimistic that the project he has nurtured for most of the last decade is on its way to becoming a reality. ''I have made a lot of compromises throughout the environmental-review process,'' he said last week. ''We have shown good faith and been very flexible.''
Xanadu Associates has reduced both the height and density of the buildings, agreed to allow public access during daylight hours, reconfigured traffic patterns and changed the location of the proposed bridge in accordance with a Coast Guard request. The company is ready to construct a $3 million to $4 million sewage-treatment plant as soon as the necessary approvals are obtained, Mr. Marshall said.
''There are no adverse environmental impacts in the project as it is presently proposed,'' Mr. Marshall said. ''We have the money, we are ready to put people to work and we are ready to spend money locally.''
 
'David's Island Is a Must'
Strong support for a project that is expected to generate 2,000 construction jobs and $13.26 million a year in property taxes has come from New Rochelle's business community, labor unions and school leaders.
''Whether we like it or not,'' said former Mayor Frank Garito at a recent meeting of New Rochelle business leaders, ''development has to happen if we are going to preserve our quality of life. The only way to preserve that quality of life is to produce the tax base to pay for it. David's Island is a must.''
Last year, New Rochelle residents absorbed a 9.9 percent increase in school taxes, said Dr. James Gaddy, the Superintendent of Schools. He added that ''there is no way we can continue to put that burden on our taxpayers.'' The school community supports the development of David's Island, he said, although he added that ''the project should address environmental and community concerns.
 
The Fears of Environmentalists
Environmentalists adamantly oppose a project they call a ''mini-city,'' one which they say will worsen pollution in the already-fragile waters of the Sound.
They argue that the western end of the Sound, from New York City to Bridgeport, is dying from hypoxia, or the loss of oxygen from the water. This, they add, is the result of sewage - including treated effluent - and the evidence of destruction includes numbers of dead fish. Support for this theory comes from reports of the Long Island Sound Study, a Federally sponsored research project to develop a plan to clean up and maintain the Sound with support from New York and Connecticut.
A coalition of neighboring municipalities also opposes the David's Island plan. ''When it comes to a developer's rights on Long Island Sound, we all have an interest,'' said Caroline Silverstone, Supervisor of Mamaroneck. ''Environmental impacts cross municipal borders.''

LENGTH: 423 words

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.;
An Arts Center For Downtown

BYLINE: By CATHERINE C. ROBBINS

 BODY:
HURT by sliding oil prices and the death of the uranium industry in the 80's and anxious about cuts in spending at nearby defense-related industries, this city is trying to revitalize its downtown, stimulate convention business and attract new industry.
One of the most recent moves was a decision by the City Council to put a new performing arts center on the last piece of vacant land around Civic Plaza. The plaza is ringed by government offices, corporate and banking headquarters, parking facilities, two hotels and a convention center. Across the plaza, other projects are at or near completion. 
The plaza and its 962-space underground parking garage will be renovated starting late this year. Beta West, a Denver subsidiary of U.S. West, also in Denver, will complete its 350,000-square-foot office building next month on the Civic Plaza and will open an adjacent 405-room Hyatt Regency Hotel in August. A convention center to which 106,000 square feet is being added will open this fall with 718 parking spaces. It will increase exhibit and meeting space by 40 percent and permitting meetings of up to 5,000 delegates.
To complement both its downtown and convention centers, the city doubled the capacity of the airport, to 22 gates, in May 1989. Dennis Campbell, director of sales for the Albuquerque Convention and Visitors Bureau, said bookings extending to the year 2000 increased by 158 percent in the last six months of 1989.
The decision to build the arts center downtown was controversial. Development pieces are coming together there, but the city's uptown urban center competes for public investment.
Downtown's 35 buildings contain 2.35 million square feet of office space (not counting the Beta West building). Uptown's 48 buildings offer 1.82 million square feet.
In the fourth quarter of 1989, the vacancy rate for both areas was about 23 percent. Developers in the uptown area - about five miles northeast of downtown - clamored for the city to choose their sites for the arts center. But the city's own planners and citizens groups strongly supported downtown.
While the location issue was settled in November, the arts center's size is uncertain. Some Councilors, nervous about revenue shortfalls, want to trim its $64 million price tag. A proposal to reduce the number of theaters from three to one has been rejected. Until the cost and size questions are settled, the search for an executive director will be suspended, and city planners do not expect to meet the scheduled completion date of 1994.

And Bear in Mind
 (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION: A Political Life in the Reagan Era, by Peggy Noonan. (Random House, $19.95.) Ronald Reagan's speechwriter, an articulate true believer in her President's greatness, is also a wide-awake observer of comings and goings in the Administration, rendering what she saw and heard into fine, sometimes brusque and rough-cut social comedy.

MARY REILLY, by Valerie Martin. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Stevenson's story of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde from the unexpected viewpoint of a housemaid, a woman fierce with love, loyalty, and the will to figure out what's going on between good and evil.
EVERY GOOD-BYE AIN'T GONE: Family Portraits and Personal Escapades, by Itabari Njeri. (Times Books/Random House, $17.95.) An impassioned, skillful, frankly subjective attempt to explore and expose the depth of a black American family heritage.
PALACE WALK, by Naguib Mahfouz. (Doubleday, $22.95.) Now available in English, the first volume of "The Cairo Trilogy," reputed to be the masterpiece of the Egyptian novelist and 1988 Nobel laureate, nobly supports that reputation.
THE MIRROR MAKER: Stories & Essays, by Primo Levi (Schocken, $16.95.) Pointed fables, nutshell sermons, nature walks left behind by Levi's truly tragic suicide in 1987.
SWEET TALK, by Stephanie Vaughn. (Random House, $16.95.) Ms. Vaughn's fine first story collection offers harrowing situations made alternately funny and sad by lively, believable characters.

PUB-DATE: February 12, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1785 words

HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA;
MANDELA, FREED, URGES STEP-UP IN PRESSURE TO END WHITE RULE

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, Feb. 11

 BODY:
After 27 and a half years in prison, Nelson Mandela finally won his freedom today and promptly urged his supporters at home and abroad to increase their pressure against the white minority Goverment that had just released him.
''We have waited too long for our freedom,'' Mr. Mandela told a cheering crowd from a balcony of Cape Town's old City Hall. ''We can wait no longer.''
''Now is the time to intensify the struggle on all fronts,'' he said. ''To relax our efforts now would be a mistake which generations to come will not able to forgive.'' [Transcript of the address, page A15.] First Speech Since '64 Mr. Mandela's 20-minute speech, which he prepared before leaving prison today, constituted his first remarks in public since before he was sentenced in June 1964 to life imprisonment for conspiracy to overthrow the Government and engage in sabotage. 
He asked the international community not to lift its sanctions against South Africa, despite the recent changes introduced by President F. W. de Klerk, which culminated in Mr. Mandela's release.
''To lift sanctions now would be to run the risk of aborting the process toward ending apartheid,'' he said.
 
An Eloquent Militancy
Mr. Mandela's voice sounded firm and his words as eloquently militant as when he defended violence as the ultimate recourse at his political trial in 1964. Though he looked all of his 71 years and was grayer than artists' renditions over the years had depicted, he walked out of Victor Verster prison erect and vigorous.
In Washington, President Bush rejoiced over the release of Mr. Mandela, spoke to him by telephone and invited the anti-apartheid leader to visit the White House. [Page A17.] Mr. Mandela gave no evidence that his militant opposition to apartheid had been tempered by the more than 10,000 days he spent in confinement. But he also said nothing that would have surprised the Government had he said it during his years of incarceration. Indeed, there appeared to be nothing in Mr. Mandela's initial remarks after his release to give the Government much consolation or encouragement.
Although he has been viewed as a potential leader for all South Africans, he stressed time and again that his loyalty lay with the African National Congress, for which he was working underground when he was jailed in August 1962 on charges of incitement and leaving the country illegally. He was serving time on that conviction when he was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1964.
Mr. Mandela told a crowd that he remained a ''loyal and disciplined member'' of the African National Congress and still endorsed its policies, including its use of armed struggle against the white minority Government.
He said he saluted the congress's military wing, Spear of the Nation, and its ally, the South African Communist Party, ''for its steady contribution to the struggle for democracy.''
But he also thanked the Black Sash, an organization of white women working to end apartheid, and the predominantly white National Union of South African Students for being ''the conscience of white South Africans.'' And he held out an olive branch to all whites, asking them to join in shaping a new South Africa.
 
'A Political Home'
''The freedom movement is a political home for you, too,'' he said.
In his first speech after his release, Mr. Mandela may have taken an orthodox line with a mass audience sympathetic to the African National Congress and might in private discussions eshow greater flexibility on the question of discussions that the Government wants to have with blacks, who are 28 million of the population, compared with the 5 million whites of the ruling minority.
He said he was only making some preliminary comments following his release, and would have more to say ''after I have had the opportunity to consult with my comrades.'' By this he meant the leaders of the African National Congress now in exile in Zambia as well as colleagues still based in South Africa.
But he appeared to discourage any leading role for himself, such as the Government has in mind, saying, ''A leader of the movement is a person who has been democratically elected at a national conference.''
 
De Klerk Offers Talks
President de Klerk has invited black leaders to join talks leading to the formulation of a new constitution that would let black South Africans take part at last in their nation's politics.
Mr. Mandela acknowledged to the crowd that he had conducted a dialogue with the Government during his last years in prison. But he added: ''My talks with the Government have been aimed at normalizing the political situation in the country. We have not yet begun discussing the basic demands of our struggle.''
''I wish to stress that I myself have at no time entered into negotiations about the future of our country, except to insist on a meeting between the A.N.C. and the Government,'' he said.
He described Mr. de Klerk, whom he has met twice since December, as ''a man of integrity.''
''Mr. de Klerk has gone further than any other Nationalist President in taking real steps to normalize the situation,'' Mr. Mandela said.
 
Still a 'Harsh Reality'
''But as an organization we base our policy and strategy and tactics on the harsh reality we are faced with,'' he said. ''And this reality is that we are still suffering under the policies of the Nationalist Government.''
The National Party, which Mr. de Klerk now leads, instituted apartheid after taking power in 1948.
Mr. Mandela said the Government had to take further steps before negotiations could begin.
As a prerequisite for negotiations, he reiterated two demands that he had conveyed from prison through recent visitors. These are are the lifting of the state of emergency, which was imposed in June 1986, and the release of all political prisoners, including those accused of crimes committed in the struggle against apartheid.
''Only such a normalized situation which allows for free political activity can allow us to consult our people in order to obtain a mandate,'' Mr. Mandela said.
He said the people had to be consulted about who would represent them in talks with the Government.
 
Democratic Election Urged
''Negotiations cannot take place above the heads or behind the backs of our people,'' he said. ''It is our belief that the future of our country can only be determined by a body which is democratically elected on a nonracial basis.''
Mr. Mandela appeared to allude to a formula under which a constituent assembly, in effect supplanting the existing Parliament, would draft a new constitution. Such a plan would mean the creation of an interim government in South Africa and has previously been rejected by Mr. de Klerk for the foreseeable future.
Mr. Mandela walked out of Victor Verster Prison near Paarl at 4:15 P.M., 75 minutes later than the release time announced Saturday afternoon by Mr. de Klerk. Acquaintances of the Mandela family said his departure from the prison was delayed by family discussions.
He was greeted by about 5,000 supporters lining the asphalt road outside the prison farm where he has been held since December 1988. Some waved the black, green and yellow flags of the African National Congress, from which Mr. de Klerk removed a ban on Feb. 2.
Mr. Mandela was then driven 40 miles from Paarl to Cape Town, passing several hundred people who had parked by the roadside or waited on overpasses in hope of seeing him. They held homemade signs, some of which read simply, ''Welcome home.''
A huge crowd, which organizers said reached 250,000 people, assembled in the square in front of the old City Hall in Cape Town to greet Mr. Mandela. Reporters covering the rally put the crowd's size at only 50,000 people at its peak. They became impatient and sometimes unruly, waiting up to six hours in the hot sun and had dwindled to about 20,000 by sunset, when Mr. Mandela finally appeared.
 
Blacks a Minority in Area
In the 1950's it was Government policy to prevent blacks from settling in the Western Cape, so they are not in the clear majority in Cape Town, where Mr. Mandela was released. People of mixed race, known as ''coloreds,'' are the largest population group in Cape Town, where whites also outnumber blacks.
Blacks, who account for nearly 75 percent of the population in the country as a whole, are in the overwhelming majority in the Johannesburg region, where Mr. Mandela can expect his most tumultuous welcome.
The festive occasion was marred by violence after some youths who had been drinking on the fringes of the rally started breaking windows and looting shops in downtown Cape Town.
The police tried to disperse them by firing shotguns and tear gas, and some of the youths retaliated by throwing bottles and stones. At one point, drunken protesters invaded a Chinese restaurant, snatched up the liquor and wine and threw bottles at the police from the rooftop. One man in the crowd was also injured in a knife fight.
 
Two Reported Killed
The South African Press Association reported tonight that 2 people had been killed and 13 wounded in the confrontations. A physician treating casualties on the scene estimated that 100 people had been wounded, mostly by buckshot. Most suffered only light injuries, including three journalists covering the rally.
Cheryl Carolus, a spokeswoman for the United Democratic Front, which helped organize the rally, attributed the violence to outsiders who, she said, were ''beyond our usual crowds, or who supported the rival Pan-Africanist Movement.'''
At times, some supporters at the rally had to scramble for cover as the police chased or fired at looters and stone-throwers. The Rev. Allan Boesak, a prominent figure in the anti-apartheid movement, pleaded for more than 45 minutes with the crowd to maintain discipline and move back.
Dullah Omar, a lawyer representing the Mandela family, said Mr. Mandela had been unaware of the violence.
 
Due in Johannesburg Today
This evening, Mr. Mandela failed to appear at a news conference arranged by the reception committee that is handling his schedule. A representative said Mr. Mandela would meet the press later this week in Johannesburg.
Mr. Mandela and his wife, Winnie, are expected to fly to Johannesburg on Monday and proceed to their home in the black township of Soweto.
One of the organizers, Saki Mocozoma, said security considerations precluded him from revealing where the Mandelas were spending their first night.
Mr. Mandela also paid tribute to his wife, who has lived apart from him for more than 27 years, and their children. ''I am convinced that your pain and suffering was far greater than my own,'' he told them.

GRAPHIC: photos: Nelson Mandela leaving Victor Verster prison yesterday after spending 27 years in South African jails. (Reuters) (pg. A1); Nelson Mandela and his wife, Winnie, saluting supporters yesterday in Cape Town after Mr. Mandela was released. (Associated Press); map of Cape Town, South Africa (pg. A14)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1279 words

HEADLINE: Rural Doctor's Struggle to Care for the Poorest

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TCHULA, Miss.

 BODY:
There aren't many doctors like Ronald Myers, a jazz-playing, Baptist-preaching family practitioner whose dream has always been to practice medicine in the kind of place most other doctors wouldn't even stop for a tank of gas.
But there are plenty of places like Tchula, a forlorn patch of Mississippi Delta poverty where it is hard to find a street that's not rutted, a sign that's not crooked, a paint job that's not peeling or a life that's not perched on the brink of economic ruin.
Dr. Myers's story - how hard it has been for him to get here and how hard it may be for him to stay - provides a dispiriting look at health care in rural America. The situation is worsening because the Government's program to provide doctors for the nation's neediest areas is being dismantled as health care needs continue to grow. 
''Working in Tchula, Miss., is like working in a third world country,'' said Dr. Myers, who became Tchula's only doctor when he opened a clinic this month in an abandoned restaurant next to an empty liquor store. ''The needs are that great. So how is it that here's a well-trained physician who wants to come to an area that's desperately poor, and I can't get any assistance? I can't get a loan. I'll take a tongue depressor if someone will give me one. There's a problem somewhere.'' In poor rural areas, particularly in the South, regular medical care is seldom more than a distant dream. In areas like Tchula and nearby Belzoni, where Dr. Myers previously worked, infant mortality rates are three times the national average, most women receive little if any prenatal care and people usually see a doctor only when they have no choice.
''The health problems in this area are staggering,'' said Dr. Henry Bartee, who operated a practice here before giving it up two years ago and now practices 12 miles away in Lexington. ''I would say 70 percent of the people who walk through the door are either hypertensive or they have diabetes. Many have significant heart disease and their cholesterol levels are all sky high. A lot of people have never had a Pap smear, a breast examination or a pelvic or rectal exam.''
It is a common story, especially in the South. In Tennessee, the state says, more than a third of the 95 counties have no doctors who deliver babies and almost half do not have enough doctors to provide adequate basic health care. In South Carolina, all but 9 of the 47 counties have doctor shortages, and the state says it needs 225 family practitioners, obstetricians and pediatricians.
 
'I Feel Right Being Here'
Dr. Myers is rare in his profession, a physician who went to a good deal of trouble to practice where no one else would. A 33-year old Milwaukeean who graduated from the University of Wisconsin Medical School, an accomplished jazz pianist and an ordained Baptist minister, he said coming to the rural South was always his goal in medicine.
''I feel God put this burning desire in my heart to serve in the rural areas of the South where the need is the most,'' said Dr. Myers, whose new clinic office is decorated with black-history and black-pride posters and mementos from his musical career. ''I feel right being here. I feel it's what I was called to do.''
Tchula, about 60 miles north of Jackson, has 2,000 people, and the population of the area served by Dr. Myers's clinic is 4,500. Mayor Jessie D. Banks says 70 percent of the town is unemployed in winter, when there is no agricultural work to be found.
Dr. Myers began work in Belzoni a year and a half ago as part of his agreement with the National Health Services Corps, which pays a year's worth of medical school costs for each year the recipient agrees to serve in an underserved area.
While he served at a clinic there, he saw that the need was even greater in Tchula, 21 miles away, where there was no doctor at all. He decided to set up his own clinic in Tchula, using money he had made working overtime at emergency rooms, and to work there in the evening after spending his days at Belzoni.
The Federal Public Health Service, which oversees the program, told him he was not authorized to practice in Tchula and ordered him to stay in Belzoni. Officials told him that they did not think a medical practice could survive in Tchula and that doctors fare better when they can take advantage of existing health care organizations. Too Poor to Support a Practice? Undeterred, Dr. Myers took his fight to elected officials and the Mississippi news media, winning so much attention that the Public Health Service relented. He now operates full-time in Tchula while living in a double-wide trailer in Belzoni.
But getting permission to be in Tchula was only half the battle. To cobble together his clinic, he has had to rely on makeshift financing, advances from medical suppliers and his own wits. He has no lab equipment and does his own urinalysis under a microscope.
Dr. Bartee thinks that all this is in vain, that Tchula may be too poor to support a physician. ''The patients he will be seeing will primarily be indigent, Medicare-Medicaid patients, and it's almost impossible to make a living just seeing those patients,'' Dr. Bartee said. ''He's got to have some outside help.''
Dr. Myers wonders why the Government does not encourage the doctors it brings to rural areas to stay there by helping them set up practices. But increasingly, the problem is not keeping rural doctors but getting them there in the first place.
Started in 1972, the National Health Services Corps has placed more than 13,000 doctors in the nation's most underserved communities. But its financing has been slashed from $79.5 million in the 1980 fiscal year to $7.5 million in 1990, and six doctors leave the program for every one who enters it. Now it is unclear whether the program will survive at all. Its plight reflects both the Reagan-era budget cutbacks and an assumption that turned out to be erroneous: that because there was a nationwide oversupply of doctors, large numbers would stay in the rural areas where they were placed.
 
Bemused Cries of 'Hi, Doc'
''It was hoped that natural diffusion would take care of a lot of our needs,'' said Joseph Hayden, the corps's associate director. ''But it didn't.'' Today's needs, he went on, ''are just as great now as they were in 1980.''
Dr. Tom Dean, a family practitioner in Wessington Springs, S.D., who is president-elect of the National Rural Health Association, said that without the health service corps there would be ''a lot of needy people who just will not get care.''
''It would be just another critical hole in the theoretical safety net that's supposed to exist but we all know it really doesn't,'' he said.
If the poverty is most pronounced in the rural South, the problems are national, he said. The vast distances between towns in the West can make problems particularly acute there.
Dr. Myers, who is greeted with admiring if slightly puzzled cries of ''Hi, Doc,'' as he walks through Tchula's dilapidated business district, seems unfazed by the economic prospects here. He has already arranged for an ophthalmologist, a surgeon and a podiatrist to see patients at his Tchula Family Health Center. He doesn't expect to solve the health problems of the Mississippi Delta. But he wonders whether the statewide educational initiatives that have been hailed as the salvation of the South will mean much if no one addresses the health-care needs.
''Here you're putting all of this money into educational reforms, and you've got these sick, malnourished kids whose mothers never got any prenatal care,'' he said. ''If they're not healthy, how are they going to be able to learn?''
