The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 12, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 3550 words

HEADLINE: FEDERAL AID, NEW YORK HOMELESS - A SPECIAL REPORT;
Bush Homeless Plan: 'Godsend' or False Hope?

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
On the night of Sept. 25, 1988, a previously obscure piece of Federal legislation was ushered onto political center stage before a television audience of millions.
During the season's first Presidential debate, a panelist asked George Bush what he would do for the homeless, ''this voiceless segment of our society.''
Mr. Bush answered without hesitation. ''I want to see the McKinney Act fully funded,'' the Republican candidate said. The McKinney Act? The reference hardly resonated in the living rooms of America. Most viewers had never heard of the McKinney Act, and Mr. Bush's terse answer offered virtually no basis on which to judge it. 
But Mr. Bush has kept his word. Last year, at his urging, Congress came close to fully financing most McKinney programs for the first time since the act was passed in 1987.
And the legislation remains a central provision of the Administration's plan for helping the homeless. As recently as last month, Mr. Bush pointed toward funds from the McKinney Act in telling a convention of home builders in Atlanta that ''my Administration is going to do its part'' in working to ''solve the problems of the helpless and the homeless.'' $67 Million for New York The act itself is a quiver of 16 programs, each taking a different aim at homelessness. Some of the programs support shelters, with food or funds. Others provide services like job training, health care or treatment for alcohol or drug abuse.
The funds approved last year are likely to raise New York State's share to about $67 million, from $45 million. Because the money filters through a variety of governments and private organizations, it is impossible to determine how much of it is spent in New York City.
But despite the McKinney Act's broad aims and the recent increase in financing, many of those who provide shelter and services to the homeless say the McKinney Act falls short in at least these three respects:
* It provides relatively little money.
* It creates daunting bureaucratic obstacles.
* And it provides almost no funds for low-income housing, which advocates argue must be part of a solution to homelessness.
''It's much ado about nothing,'' said Douglas H. Lasdon of the Legal Assistance Center for the Homeless in Manhattan. ''It gives people the impression that something's being done, but it's not.''
Measured in paint or plaster, protein or pajamas, the law, named for Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a Connecticut Republican who died shortly before its enactment, has made a difference in the lives of dozens of New York organizations. Some McKinney money goes straight to nonprofit agencies working with the homeless; other programs filter the funds through state or local governments. The funds have bolstered longstanding relief efforts and, in a few cases, supported innovative new programs.
Because the legislation helps local groups, Mr. Bush has linked it to his vision of an America burning with ''a thousand points of light'' - a multiplicity of volunteer efforts that chase away the shadow of need.
But critics of the act point to the numbers in arguing that it leaves more dark than spark. Even if Congress approves Mr. Bush's latest budget request, the McKinney Act would provide only $749 million a year nationwide, a figure that advocates say pales beside the undetermined billions spent by local and state governments and private organizations.
 
'A Drop in the Bucket'
In New York State, the McKinney Act has contributed an average of about $35 million a year for the last three years, according to Government figures. By contrast, a single agency of the New York City government, the Human Resources Administration, spends about $330 million a year on programs to assist the homeless, city officials said. A study of state government spending showed $500 million spent on programs for the homeless in a 20-month period, beginning in April 1987. Other governments and private groups spent many millions more.
''The Federal resources are a drop in the bucket,'' said Nancy Travers, assistant commissioner in the State Department of Social Services.
Housing statistics offer another measure of the act's modest scope. City officials say homelessness stems in part from the destruction of boarding houses and hotels where single people used to lodge, many suffering from mental illness or alcoholism. Over several decades, urban development has destroyed tens of thousands of units of single-room-occupancy housing. According to the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the McKinney Act has helped replace 91.
While estimates of the number of homeless people are notoriously imprecise, advocates say that on any night 30,000 people sleep in public and private shelters in New York City and perhaps as many sleep in parks, subways and streets.
 
Part of a Larger Plan
Anna Kondratas, an assistant secretary of Housing and Urban Development and a key Bush Administration figure on policy toward the homeless, said she agreed that the McKinney Act had offered modest money and many bureaucratic difficulties. But she said its sums, which the Administration is working to increase, loom larger in perspective outside New York, where state and local spending on the homeless is unusually high. And she said the Administration has taken steps to reduce the law's red tape.
Further, the McKinney Act is only one part of a larger Administration plan to help the homeless, she said, adding, ''We must go far beyond the McKinney Act.''
The President's proposed budget, released last month, seeks about $1.2 billion for a low-income housing initiative called Project Hope. About $246 million of that is designated for those who are homeless. In addition, Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp has pledged to offer the homeless 10 percent of the Federal Housing Administration's foreclosed single-family homes, a move that he said will make at least 5,000 homes available.
In another move to help the homeless, the F.H.A. plans to offer insurance for single-room-occupancy housing, to make its development more financially attractive.
Many advocates for the homeless said those steps are worthy but small, compared with the drop in Federal appropriations for subsidized housing, to $7.9 billion in 1990 from $30.2 billion in 1981. ''It takes us slightly beyond the McKinney Act, but just slightly,'' said Maria Foscarinis, director of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, who was a chief lobbyist behind the act's passage.
 
A Bill Signed at Night
The McKinney Act was never intended to solve the problem of homelessness, only to provide temporary relief. ''It was a given from the beginning that this was just an emergency measure,'' Ms. Foscarinis said.
Nonetheless, the law, was a significant political step. President Ronald Reagan had long argued that the care of the homeless was a local responsibility, not a Federal one.
Mr. Reagan took the unusual step of signing the bill at night, to communicate what one White House aide called a ''lack of enthusiasm'' for the very programs that Mr. Bush began to tout a year later. In thumbing his nose at the measure, critics say, Mr. Reagan may have sent a signal encouraging the bureaucratic slowdowns that they say have subverted it.
The act's effectiveness was further limited by the lack of full financing, the yearly gap of several hundred million dollars between the ceilings that Congress authorized and the money it actually appropriated. A Success Story A Young Mother Enrolled in College If small in the universe of total aid to the homeless, the McKinney Act registers large in the world of several local programs. Among them is Bethany House, home to 10 young mothers and their children in a former convent in Brooklyn.
''In our instance it was a godsend,'' said Sister Nancy DeCesare, the program director. ''It helped keep us alive.''
With a yearly budget of $350,000, the program was $80,000 short last spring, she said, and about to reduce its size. A $45,582 grant from a McKinney program has helped meet the many mundane needs of mother and child: textbooks, snowsuits, underwear, playpens.
Natasha Castillo, 20 years old, is among the beneficiaries. She and her daughter Nefertiti, who is now 17 months old, moved into Bethany House last May. Like most of the program's residents, Ms. Castillo grew up in a succession of foster homes. They were unimpressive enough to have left her vague about the number of moves or the names of her substitute parents.
 
'You Learn to Be a Family'
Her natural parents died when she was 6 - something to do with drugs, she said, though relatives have not shared the details. She thinks her mother was pushed off a roof in the Bronx.
At 16, Ms. Castillo joined a Job Corps program in upstate New York, where she became pregnant by a fellow student. She said they began sharing an apartment in the Bronx, where ''I didn't do nothing but get up, stay in bed, and eat all day.'' They fought. She left. When she moved into Bethany House, her boyfriend threatened to kill her.
But she credits her stay there with arresting what had become a downward slide. ''I didn't care about nobody,'' she said. ''In here, you learn to be a family - how to show your emotions.''
Ms. Castillo gets up at 6 A.M. -house rules. She attends counseling sessions and classes on sex education and how to be a parent. Last semester, she enrolled at Borough of Manhattan Community College. ''A freshman's supposed to have a 1.75,'' she said, ''and I had a 2.08!''
Her classmates were surprised to learn she was homeless. ''They thought homeless people were supposed to be bummy and smelly,'' she said.
Ms. Castillo keeps several prized clippings taped to the mirror in her room. One is a school brochure depicting a young black woman, like Ms. Castillo, arms confidently crossed, schoolbook in hand. ''Now I'm making it,'' it reads.
''I like the words,'' Ms. Castillo said. ''Cause I'm making it, too.'' The Funds at Work Keeping a Few Men Off the Streets A recent visit to the Bronx offered a different look at McKinney money at work. The setting is Harbor House, a home for 34 mentally ill drug addicts. Some have spent years living on subways. Others have camped behind the bushes in Central Park. Most have tried to kill themselves.
It doesn't take much to ruin their day. Peter P.'s community college instructor recently returned an essay with the comment, ''Great job!'' Peter said the note sent him running to his psychiatrist. ''I said, 'Do you think the brother's jacking me up or what?' ''
Harbor House combines group living and group therapy, with an emphasis on self-help. Residents are expected to help run the program and monitor one another's welfare.
One type of monitoring goes by the name of ''pull-ups'': brotherly admonitions like ''don't slouch'' or ''turn down the T.V.'' Less brotherly confrontations occur in twice-weekly encounter sessions, where streetwise colleagues cast a skeptical eye on the games addicts play. The result is often a verbal brawl.
Toward the end of one recent session, Pedro E. accused Ali R. and Miguel L. of being ''crime-ees'' - friends growing close for the wrong reasons.
Ali had a few thoughts in response. Few are printable. He began by denouncing Pedro's ''disrespectful, irresponsible attitude'' and ended by likening him to untreated sewage.
You too, said Pedro. ''How do you think I feel, Mr. Positive,'' he taunted. ''I got problems, man, or I wouldn't be in here.''
 
Double Afflictions
Psychiatrists say the vitriol of such confrontations is an important part of treating drug addicts, whose abilities to deceive themselves and others often triumph over softer approaches.
Ali agreed. ''They were showing me concern,'' he said after the session.
The model used at Harbor House, called a therapeutic community, has been used widely for drug addicts and occasionally for the mentally ill. But administrators at Harbor House said they are the first to try the approach on men suffering from both afflictions. Most programs for drug addicts exclude the mentally ill and vice versa. As a result, hard-core homeless people suffering with both problems fall through the cracks.
Without McKinney money - $575,000 in renovation funds and $354,000 a year toward operations - administrators said the program could not exist. ''The McKinney program has been particularly good to us,'' said Elizabeth L. Sturz, president of Argus Community, the home's parent organization. ''If not, there would be another few dozen men out on the street.'' The Criticism Good-News Agency 'Is in a Shambles'
Critics of the McKinney Act say these accomplishments do not justify Mr. Bush's repeated celebrations of it.
They lament not only the amount of money provided but also what they call the impediments to its distribution. These have included technical points, involving things like application requirements and deadlines, and what the critics call bureaucratic sloth in administering the program.
One object of criticism has been the Interagency Council on the Homeless, which Congress created with the act. It was to provide one-stop shopping for the thousands of diverse community groups looking for McKinney information: details on deadlines, matching-fund provisions and the like. Beyond that it was supposed to proselytize, to reach out and spread the good news of available Federal funds.
But until very recently, critics say, the council did neither. Its first chairman, Samuel R. Pierce, then H.U.D. Secretary, sent a letter telling field personnel not to let the council's work ''intrude upon a coordinator's existing duties for an extended period of time.'' And by most accounts they didn't. ''We have received no information, assistance, consultation or advice from them,'' wrote Grace K. Lewis of the Ohio Department of Mental Health, in one of a dozen such letters submitted to Congress last March. ''For all intents and purposes, the Interagency Council doesn't exist.''
 
Took Time to Lobby
But the council did find time to lobby the National Association of Home Builders to exclude ''strident'' views from a 1988 conference that sought Mr. Pierce's attendance.
''It is perhaps generous to say that the council is in a shambles,'' concluded Representative Cardiss Collins, an Illinois Democrat, whose House Subcommittee on Employment and Housing held hearings last March.
With the change of Administrations, H.U.D. officials have replaced all nine of the council's professional staff members. Local officials say that while those changes are welcome, the McKinney Act is almost three years old and the council is only beginning to perform its role. Bureaucratic Knots Application Form With 66 Pages Those agencies that do get the word about McKinney programs often describe them as user-unfriendly. Applications are often difficult, they say, reimbursements slow, and program regulations inhibiting.
Sanctuary for Families, a Manhattan organization that runs two shelters for battered women, learned in February 1988 that it had been awarded $11,500 in McKinney money to buy a new boiler. The problem was collecting it: records show the check arrived 15 months later.
''It was completely ridiculous,'' said Alisa Del Tufo, the executive director, who estimated that she spent about 60 hours trying to untie the bureaucratic knots. ''Thousands of dollars were wasted trying to administer the stupid thing. I would never do it again.''
In trying to establish a shelter in Elizabeth, N.J., Michael Fabricant ran up against a different McKinney problem. He started a nonprofit corporation, hoping to find a rundown building, renovate it, and provide housing for five homeless families.
He needed about $200,000 for the project and sought to raise half of it from H.U.D. Then came the complications. H.U.D. regulations required organizations to have control of the site before applying for the funds. But market economics lean the other way: It takes money to buy property.
Eventually, through a sympathetic real-estate broker, Mr. Fabricant found an owner willing to wait the six months it would take to apply. But when Mr. Fabricant discovered that it would take several months more for the Government to release the check, even if the project were approved, the building owner balked.
And so did Mr. Fabricant. ''I've given up on H.U.D.,'' he said. ''What we're doing is raising money through church groups. Who knows if it'll ever materialize?'' #17 Pages of Fine Print The mere bulk of some applications has dissuaded some smaller nonprofit groups - pivotal to Mr. Bush's thousand-points strategy - from applying.
Bensonhurst Homeless Residence Inc., a Brooklyn shelter with 12 beds, is among them. The group heard that it might be able to get money to expand. Then it got the application. The preface alone was six pages. The main document ran 33 pages, with 26 sections seeking information on things like zoning, legal authority, flood plains, equal-opportunity certificates, environmental reviews, operating budgets, development schedules and employee assistance programs.
Then came 17 pages of fine print called ''24 CFR Parts 840 and 841: Supportive Housing Demonstration Program; Rules and Notices.''
And its sequel, ''Notice of Changes to Final Rule'' - a 10-page postscript.
''When we got all the forms, forget it,'' said Joseph Buccheri, the director. ''You had to have a Philadelphia lawyer on staff.''
Ms. Kondratas, the assistant H.U.D. secretary, agreed that bureaucratic impediments have reduced the program's effectiveness. ''It could have been better run, even at the levels funded,'' she said. In some cases, she said, the bureaucratic burdens were written in by Congress, which required things like environmental reviews.
In other instances, the problems come from competing interests. Without proof of site control, for instance, the Government might award money to projects that fall through. This, she said, would waste time and leave valuable funds idle. She said H.U.D. has since revised its rules so that groups may apply if they can show they are likely to acquire property. Surplus Property Why a Golf Course Wasn't Available Perhaps the clearest indication of how bureaucratic barriers have stood between the McKinney Act and its goals can be seen in the case of surplus Federal property.
The act requires Federal agencies to make unused property available to groups working with the homeless. Mr. Bush cited this program during the debate, saying, ''There are certain Army bases that the act calls for that can be used in certain cases to shelter people when it's rough.''
But Government officials say that no more than two dozen of an estimated 5,000 such properties have actually been turned over to the homeless. A Federal district judge accused the Defense Department last year of ''flirting with contempt of court'' through its resistance to the law.
Ms. Foscarinis, the lobbyist who led the fight for passage of the McKinney Act, has twice filed suit to speed the surplus-property program along. Two dozen Federal agencies were supposed to draw up lists of idle property and forward them to H.U.D., which would determine which were suitable. Instead, H.U.D. was allowing the agencies to make that determination.
This, Ms. Foscarinis argued, was a fatal flaw since few Federal agencies are eager to surrender their property. And few did - 18 out of 24 agencies wrote H.U.D. to say they could not find a single piece of available property. In September 1988, Judge Oliver Gasch of Federal District Court in Washington ordered H.U.D. to take over the duty.
 
A Matter of Definition
But what is idle property anyway?
The McKinney Act defined it as ''underutilized.'' Underutilized, as the Federal bureaucracy chose to interpret it, was a specific, technical term lifted from the rulebooks of Federal property law. It was not to be confused with ''unutilized'' property. Or ''surplus'' property. Or ''excess'' property. Each of those types of empty property had their own technical definitions and, in the Government's eyes, they were not available to the homeless.
Underutilized, in the eyes of groups working with the homeless, wasn't so complicated. It was empty buildings where the homeless might live, or idle land on which a shelter could be built.
In Bob Nasdor's eyes, it was three empty acres in Montclair, N.J., where decades earlier a military golf course had stood, and where he wanted to build homes for 30 homeless families.
He said that when he asked the Government how to apply for the land, he was told that it was ''excess,'' not ''underutilized,'' so he could not have it.
Judge Gasch dismissed the Government's interpretation out of hand, commenting wryly that Government lawyers were ''not daunted'' by the contradictions in their own arguments. Among them was the contention that the McKinney Act intended to offer to the homeless buildings that were half empty but not those that were completely so.
The Government had ''interpreted the act to exclude almost all unused Federal properties from consideration,'' he ruled.
Ms. Foscarinis said: ''They have done everything possible to sabotage the program. They've fought it every step of the way.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Those For Whom 'Peace Dividend' Means Deficit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The movements that were fueled by the cold war are finding that its apparent demise may be good for the world but bad for their business.
Membership is dwindling, and contributions are drying up. Staff members, as well as donors, are defecting to new causes.
The Institute for the Common Defense in Washington, proponent of a stonger military, has disconnected its phone and is apparently no longer in operation. 
Nuclear Times, the peace movement's most popular magazine, stopped publishing six months ago.
 
'They're in Trouble'
Morale at SANE/Freeze, the largest peace group in the country, plummeted when debt forced the group to lay off a quarter of its national staff and cut salaries.
The American Security Council, one of the most successful pro-defense lobbies, has lost half its 300,000 members since 1985. To stay solvent, the group recently sold land adjacent to its headquarters in the Washington suburbs.
''They're in trouble now that peace has broken out,'' said Paul Warnke, the chief arms negotiator in the Carter Administration. ''It's what the Salk vaccine did for the March of Dimes.''
Just as that organization had to refashion its mission to address birth defects when polio no longer threatened the nation, so hawks and doves are searching for a new role in the age of Gorbachev.
 
Searching the Horizon
''We are moving from nuclear disarmament to nuclear waste,'' said Janice Kelly, fiscal manager for Women's Action for Nuclear Disarmament, based in Arlington, Mass. ''People's priorities keep changing to something more glamorous on the horizon.''
In the 1980's, Communism was the common adversary and Ronald Reagan was the common rallying point, said Howard Phillips, chairman of the Conservative Caucus, a Washington-based advocacy group that has had financial difficulties.
Recalling the old days of fund raising, he said, ''It was possible to put your fishing line in the barrel and come up with a 20-inch bass.''
For decades, the anti-Communists and peace groups confronted each other at demonstrations, faced off on the talk shows and raised millions of dollars to elect sympathetic candidates and unseat opponents. They fed and prospered from each other's rhetoric as well as their own successes. What's Left to Fight For? Now both are sides fighting a tide that is moving to new shores, to issues like abortion, poverty and the environment. Some conservatives are foreseeing what the essayist Charles Krauthammer has called the ''conservative crackup'' as longtime supporters splinter into new directions.
''It's hard to maintain your edge when you continually win Presidential elections, the economy continues to be strong and then on top of that the Berlin wall collapses,'' said John Buckley, a political consultant to conservative groups.
Since the changes in Eastern Europe, fund raising for anti-Communist efforts has dropped off, said Bruce Eberle, a direct-mail fund-raiser whose clients include many conservative groups. ''There's less interest in the issue,'' he said.
Peace groups whose ranks had grown during the arms buildup under Ronald Reagan are suffering the same malaise as conservatives.
 
'A Casualty of Victory'
''Basically, Gorbachev put us out of business,'' said Elliott Negin, the former editor of Nuclear Times, who has been freelancing since his magazine folded. ''Hey! Look at me. I'm happy about it, but I'm a casualty of the victory.''
Mr. Negin said the magazine was finally forced to close after private foundations, which provided one-third of the publication's operating expenses, decided that nuclear disarmament was no longer a crucial issue.
At Physicians for Social Responsibility, a Washington-based disarmament organization, donations are down 58 percent from a year ago, said John Loretz, director of communications.
''We saw a very steep rise in our membership through 1985, the height of the arms race,'' Mr. Loretz said. ''But when people felt the threat of nuclear war was more remote, we saw a cooling off in contributions. The urgency is clearly not there in the mind of the public like it was a few years ago.''
 
Treaties Dash Fund Raising
John Miller, a staff member at the New York-based Mobilization for Survival, a group that has traditionally focused on disarmament issues, said there had been a noticeable fall-off in contributions. ''With every treaty signed, raising money becomes more difficult,'' he said. ''If you win a little bit, people think you've won the whole thing.''
Brent Bozell, finance director of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, argues that it is still possible to raise money for conservative causes, including foreign policy, but that the strategy must change.
There are opportunities, Mr. Bozell said, for conservatives who want to help shape the political and economic future of Eastern Europe. Money is pouring in for people monitoring elections and running training seminars in capitalism, he said.
''It can't be an anti-Communist movement but a pro-freedom one,'' Mr. Bozell said. ''That's the new reality.''
 
Work to Be Done
Both hard-liners and peace activists stress that their work is not yet done. Cold Warriors warn against premature complacency and excessive faith in Mikhail S. Gorbachev. And peace groups note that despite the talk of peace, the military budget proposed by President Bush for the next fiscal year is still larger than this year's.
''In our mailings and our newsletters, we are raising the cautionary sign,'' said David Keene, who heads the American Conservative Union. The group, which a decade ago numbered 750,000, today claims 50,000 donors. ''What Gorbachev is saying is very encouraging, but the Soviets are not changing their defense spending. They're still pouring money into Nicaragua and Afghanistan, and the cold war is not over for those people who are dying in these parts of the world.''
Peace groups are fighting just as hard to diminish the perception that the United States and the Soviet Union are disarming. It is one of the most difficult hurdles peace groups are facing, said the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., president of SANE/Freeze, which claims 170,000 members.
''It's great, what's going on,'' Mr. Coffin said. But he added: ''The military budget is our Berlin wall, and the Congress its guard. Bringing down that wall is a very big job for the peace movement.''
Despite efforts to regroup their forces, defections from the peace movement have already begun.
''I can't see myself staying around much longer,'' said one organization's director, who asked not to be identified. ''The world has changed, and I am looking for other idealistic causes. There are a lot of other pressing needs now.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: GERMAN WHIRLWIND;
Whose Terms, NATO's or Moscow's, For a Unification That Seems Likely?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 11

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union sowed the wind last October when he signaled that it was time for the old East German leadership under Erich Honecker to go. Now, perhaps long before he expected it, he may reap the whirlwind of German unification.
In separate meetings over the last two weeks with the leaders of East and West Germany, Mr. Gorbachev appears to have accepted the inevitable absorption of East Germany, where 400,000 Soviet troops are still stationed, by the more powerful and populous West Germany, where more than 200,000 American troops are posted.
But if the general outcome is already preordained, the form and conditions of unification are not. Whether a united German state will be neutral and demilitarized, as Soviet policy since Stalin has insisted, or remain aligned with the West as a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, as the United States and the West German Government insist, will be decided in a flurry of negotiations leading to an anticipated meeting in the fall of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. 
Mr. Gorbachev, like President Bush, seems to have realized that he cannot veto that process, but he can shape it. On Saturday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreed in several hours of talks with Mr. Gorbachev in the Kremlin that while unification was for the Germans to decide, it could not take place against ''the legitimate interests of our neighbors, friends and partners in Europe and the world.''
Exactly what either Moscow or the Germans mean by that is uncertain. Some diplomats think a neutral demilitarized Germany is what Mr. Gorbachev wants. But even if his abandonment of Mr. Honecker last fall was a clever ploy to bring that about, few here believe he has been in control of the situation since.
 
Power Over East German Events
The West Germans have more power over events in East Germany these days than Soviet or East German officials do. Once the East German border was opened in November, East Germans were free to move to West Germany, and 2,000 to 3,000 a day have been doing so ever since. As the drain continues, local government authority, public services and civic morale in East Germany have been steadily undermined, and West German politicians and political parties have moved into the vacuum.
Mr. Kohl acknowledged that in their talks this weekend, he and Mr. Gorbachev discussed the subject of West German politicians' interference in the campaign for parliamentary elections in the East on March 18.
''I pointed out that among them were a number of personalities who are very well known here - Willy Brandt, for instance, and Egon Bahr - and that strengthened their understanding here,'' Mr. Kohl said at a news conference Saturday night. Mr. Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, and Mr. Bahr, his former foreign policy adviser, are highly respected as the architects of West German reconciliation with Moscow and Eastern Europe in the 1970's. Both are also members of Mr. Kohl's Social Democratic opposition.
With their help, the new East German Social Democratic Party is expected to emerge as the winner of next month's elections there, and if it does, Mr. Kohl could face a stiffer challenge from the West German Social Democrats in his own elections in December.
But will East Germany still exist as a separate state by then? At the end of last month, its caretaker Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, got Mr. Gorbachev to acknowledge that German unification was, indeed, on the international agenda, dropping opposition expressed after the opening of the Berlin wall on Nov. 9. Soviet officials gave cautious backing to the ''Modrow plan'' for unity by stages, with both German states gradually dissolving from their respective alliances and becoming demilitarized.
But events in Germany are rushing ahead so fast that the Modrow plan won't be discussed when the East German leader meets Mr. Kohl in Bonn on Tuesday, the West German Chancellor said Saturday. A new emergency has arisen - the possibility of financial collapse in East Germany. So Mr. Kohl and Mr. Modrow will discuss a West German plan for replacement of the largely worthless East German currency by the West German mark.
The reason, the Chancellor implied, was to shore up the failing confidence of the East German people in their economy and encourage some of them to stay put instead of fleeing to West Germany in search of a better life.
''We are in an unbelievably dynamic process,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''A process that we aren't accelerating, but that people in the G.D.R. are accelerating, day by day.'' But the dynamic is also complex. Pronouncements by West German officials in Bonn about imminent insolvency in East Germany can easily be self-fulfilling. And only officials in Bonn have the means to stave it off.
 
Access to Western Technology
The Soviet Union has vital economic interests in Germany. Western diplomats here speculate that if Mr. Gorbachev is willing to see East Germany go under, one reason is that a united Germany would offer him far-greater access to Western technology, investment, trade and credit than it now has.
East German foreign trade with the Soviet Union, equally divided between imports and exports, is nearly three times as much as West Germany's, and includes long-term contracts for deliveries of machine tools and other heavy industrial products vital to the Soviet economy.
Mr. Kohl said Saturday that even if all those factories soon became absorbed into the West German economic system, ''We can arrive at an agreement satisfactory to the Soviet Union.'' He gave the same answer to the question about what would happen to the Soviet troops stationed there now. But both problems will not be easy to resolve.
Over the coming months, Mr. Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and their East German counterparts will be holding a continuous round of consultations with the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France - the four occupying powers who defeated Hitler in World War II. And this fall, some kind of framework for German unity seems likely to be discussed at a summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
 
Idea of a Neutral Germany
Some of Mr. Genscher's recent statements imply that standing bodies of the conference could eventually replace the Warsaw Pact and the NATO alliance, and provide the security guarantees that neither Mr. Gorbachev nor Mr. Kohl was willing to spell out in public this weekend. Eventually, a united Germany would have to negotiate a peace treaty with the 80 countries that had declared hostilities by the end of World War II.
And some of them, a Western diplomat speculated, would not be comfortable with the Soviet idea of a neutral Germany, a country of 78 million people demilitarized or armed, like neutral Switzerland. Perhaps for that reason, Mr. Gorbachev did not publicly insist on it in his talks with Mr. Kohl, who said later, ''From German soil should emanate not war, but peace.''
''German unity has always been an academic question for the Soviets,'' an East German diplomat said the other day. ''I think now they don't quite know what to do. They're just trying to keep up with developments, and save what little they can.''

HEADLINE: New Notions On Old Crisis In Argentina

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
Like many of his countrymen, one of Argentina's leading industrialists was talking the other day about what is wrong with his country and what ought to be done about it.
''How many civilized countries are there where it is possible to make fortunes doing absolutely nothing?'' Hector Massuh asked. ''Where people get rich,'' he continued, ''without ever having produced anything, without having created a business, planted a tree or seeded grain - fortunes made by just moving papers around, placing financial instruments here and there?''
Here, he noted, the Government has to pay such high interest on its domestic debt, quite aside from its problems with foreign debt, that people of modest needs can live off the interest from just a few thousand dollars of capital. 
''There are entire provinces where people live without working,'' he said. ''Countries can't function that way.'' Argentine Riddle: Why?
Argentina is passing through another of its increasingly frequent economic crises, with inflation that is expected to exceed 50 percent for January alone just the tip of an iceberg of structural problems. As a result, many people go to extremes in describing the problem or proposing solutions.
Such talk is not new. What is sometimes called ''the Argentine riddle'' has been debated by historians, economists and political scientists for decades. It is this: Why has a basically European immigrant population been unable to create an advanced industrial nation and liberal democracy on a resource-laden piece of the earth? The answers expressed these days by ordinary Argentines make the experts sound bland.
It is not unusual to hear taxi drivers say they would welcome an invasion by the United States, ''even if they planted the Stars and Stripes right there in that plaza,'' as one said.
Other Argentines in this city of 11 million people talk of immigrating to Australia or speculate about how their lives would be if their parents or grandparents had not decided to come here from Italy. The successes of the once-poor ancestral homelands of about 40 percent of Argentines are the subject of envy and admiration.
The novelist Oswaldo Soriano said in a conversation a few months ago that his solution for Argentina was for Italy to invade and annex this eighth largest country in the world in land size. Argentina, he said, ''would provide plenty of cheap, skilled labor for Italian industry.''
 
Causes: Fear of the Left
The author, a self-described leftist, said with a more or less straight face that there would be almost no resistance to an Italian occupation, while invasion by Spain or the United States would stir anti-colonialist passions.
Carlos H. Waisman, a sociology professor at the University of California at San Diego, in a new book, ''Reversal of Development in Argentina,'' offers a complicated explanation of what went wrong.
He says that going into the 1930's, Argentina was following the same path of development as other nations that are now world leaders but was gradually derailed by fears among ''political elites'' of leftist revolution, fear that he says was based on a ''distorted image of the working class.''
The result was the basically rightist form of socialism that Juan Peron promoted after coming to power in 1946. Although identified as Peronism, the concept enjoyed some acceptance from most political groups in Argentina until recently. The consequences, Mr. Waisman writes, have been ''stagnation and illegitimacy.''
Today, the list of troubles adding up to what President Carlos Saul Menem calls ''the long sickness of the Argentine economy'' includes fiscal deficits that typically exceed 10 percent of the gross national product, tax evasion as a way of life, low productivity, a bloated state payroll and heavy dependence on the state by private enterprise.
 
Promises on Several Fronts
There is also the poor quality of manufactured goods protected by high tariffs, the large amount of business that is done off the books or by the underground economy, the speculation and usury to which Mr. Massuh alluded, corruption, and the tendency of Argentines to keep their savings and investments abroad - an estimated $50 billion worth, almost equal the official gross national product.
Mr. Menem, going against the tradition of his party, the Justicialist movement founded by Mr. Peron, promises to eliminate all those failings. Since taking office in July, he has set forth a series of plans to reduce the state's role in the economy and says he intends to ''privatize private enterprise,'' an allusion to the custom of the Government's guaranteeing markets and profits for private businesses.
But curing these ailments seems to require immediate attention to every part of the economy at once, and the Argentine Government and society lack the money, skills, and, in some cases, the desire to do that. For instance, overhauling state enterprises will probably require firing people, an almost unmentionable idea at the moment.
Miklos Banyai, the Hungarian commercial counselor in Argentina, said he had noted some similarities between the problems of Argentina and his country. He said that both countries created ''overprotected industries'' after World War II, but that Hungary was now ''a bit ahead'' of Argentina in deregulating and taming its bureaucracy.
''Everything is complicated in Argentina,'' said Mr. Massuh, who with his father runs a paper and cellulose concern. ''To export is complicated. To import is complicated. If you want to pay your light bill that is complicated. Argentina has to become a simpler country with much clearer rules, and that's not going to be easy.''

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS: AN UNWAVERING OPPONENT AND AN UNPREDICTABLE LEADER OF SOUTH AFRICA;
Frederik Willem de Klerk

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
There is little in the personal and political history of F. W. de Klerk to suggest that he would be the South African leader to make the bold gestures that have set his country on a course of uncertainty and hope.
Mr. de Klerk, the ninth, and possibly the last, white man to lead South Africa since it was formed in 1910, had always stayed well in the safe middle ground of the tightly structured organization that is the ruling National Party. Until his selection as party leader a year ago this month, he had never taken a single initiative toward change.
But when he assumed the presidency in September, he was obliged to confront a series of daunting realities, from the state of the country's economy to continued criticism from abroad. In his inauguration speech, he urged his fellow white South Africans to join him in creating ''a totally changed South Africa.'' 
 
'Nixon in China' Syndrome
Mr. de Klerk may be an example of what historians have come to call the ''Nixon in China'' syndrome, in which a leader has accumulated the political credentials and capital to act against expectations. One South African official suggested recently in private that Mr. de Klerk also was exhilarated by the possibility of achieving a notable role in history as the man who presided over his country's transition from apartheid.
When Mr. de Klerk outlined his intention last week to free Nelson Mandela and make legal such opposition groups as the African National Congress in an effort to negotiate the shape of the country's future, he was keenly aware of the world audience and its high expectations toward his remarks. In 1985, Mr. de Klerk's predecessor, P. W. Botha, faced similar high expectations from abroad for a much-anticipated speech he was to give at a party congress in Durban.
Mr. de Klerk is said by several South Africans to have pressed Mr. Botha into making the defiant speech he gave, which produced deep disappointment and fueled the international movement to impose economic sanctions against Pretoria. The negative reaction to Mr. Botha's address is said to have had a profound effect on Mr. de Klerk.
In making the speech, Mr. Botha was following the instincts of generations of South African leaders to look inward to the concerns of their own Afrikaners, descendants of Dutch and Huguenot settlers who arrived in the Cape Town area in the 17th century. National Party figures like Mr. Botha were conditioned by electoral politics to placate right-wing voters by taking defiant stands against international critics.
While his predecessors were always preoccupied with their conservative constituencies, Mr. de Klerk may be the first South African leader to cast his vision more broadly, seeking approval from the world community.
Frederik Willem de Klerk was born in Johannesburg, South Africa's largest city, on March 18, 1936, to a family prominent in Afrikaner politics.
 
Known as F. W. From Early Age
His father was the headmaster of a school and flourished in Afrikaner politics, becoming the National Party's secretary in the Transvaal province, a post similar to the one the son was to occupy decades later. Mr. de Klerk's uncle was J. G. Strydom, South Africa's prime minister in the mid-1950's and a prime exponent of apartheid.
Mr. de Klerk was known as F. W. from an early age, not only because it is a common Afrikaner custom for men to go by their initials, but also to distinguish him from his grandfather, who was called Frederik Willem.
Mr. de Klerk grew up steeped in the Afrikaner outlook, viewing the world with a proud insularity. When the Afrikaners fought off African tribes in the 18th and 19th centuries, the settlers adopted a tactic of circling their oxcarts in a protective formation known as a laager. In recent years, the concept of the laager has served as a metaphor for the Afrikaners' closing of their ranks against criticism from abroad.
The Afrikaners were suspicious of the whites descended from English colonists and fearful of the majority black Africans. They developed the concept of apartheid, or racial separation, and purported to find justification for it in the Bible.
 
Extended Stays Abroad
Through party and group discipline, the National Party took over the Government in 1948 and has retained control since.
Mr. de Klerk has told people that extended stays in Britain and the United States earlier in his career gave him a broader perspective. His visit to the United States in 1976 was paid for by the United States Information Agency as part of a program for bringing foreigners with leadership potential to the United States.
He clearly delighted in travels to Lusaka, Zambia, one of the leading black African nations opposing apartheid, and to London and Bonn in the last year, saying he hoped South Africa's status as an international outcast would soon end.
Mr. de Klerk was about to accept a position in 1972 to teach law at Potchefstroom University, an Afrikaans-language institution, when he was invited to run for Parliament. His wife, Marike, initially resisted, but then encouraged him to seek a life in politics, taking a job as a bookkeeper to help boost the family income. They have two sons, Jan and Willem, and a daughter, Susan.
Mr. de Klerk, who trained as a lawyer, was long considered a rising star in Afrikaner politics along with his elder brother, Willem. While he began a bustling law practice, his brother, an ordained minister, became a leading editor of an Afrikaans-language newspaper. Both were members of the Broederbond, a semi-secret society of prominent Afrikaners from areas like religion, government and journalism, which until a few years ago was said to control the country.
His brother may have been one of those surprised by Mr. de Klerk's boldness. When Mr. de Klerk took over the party last year, Willem de Klerk associated himself with a rival party to the left of the National Party and told interviewers that he thought his brother was capable only of incremental, cautious changes.
His brother's philosophy, Willem de Klerk said, was ''don't rock the boat.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: MAN IN THE NEWS (TIMES COLUMN)

HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA;
Freedom for South African Releases Joy in New York

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
Inside the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, where the stickers saying ''Free Nelson Mandela'' have not yet been scraped off the doors, several hundred people gathered in an exuberant service yesterday, providing evidence that Mr. Mandela's release resonates far beyond South Africa.
After a time filled with singing and dancing and tears, the Rev. Herbert Daughtry led his congregation outside, where he stood on a table and delivered his sermon.
''I want to make my statement out in the street - I want to be like Mandela,'' said Mr. Daughtry, who conducted the service wearing a sweatshirt that said ''End Apartheid.'' 
 
Statement by Mayor Dinkins
While Mr. Daughtry preached joy tempered with sadness at the House of the Lord that South Africa is not entirely free, Mayor David N. Dinkins told a news conference at Gracie Mansion that he was elated by the news of Mr. Mandela's release. ''The Government of South Africa has taken a welcomed first step,'' he said.
Mr. Dinkins pledged to press for legislation in the City Council to strengthen New York City's 1985 law imposing sanctions against South Africa.
David Scott, an aide to the Mayor, said the law prohibits the city from doing business with companies that do business with South Africa. The proposed amendment, he said, would also prohibit doing business with countries that have indirect ties to South Africa.
At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, a gathering of over 200 people, including Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders, attending a convocation for peace in the Middle East gave a special tribute to Mr. Mandela.
The congregation gave a standing ovation to Susan Nmambosa, the representative of the African National Congress in New York. She said that while she had never seen Mr. Mandela, she said she ''felt like crying.''
She said that she was a child when he was taken into custody and she said that today, her -year-old son, said: '' 'Mommy, isn't it nice. It's Black History Month, and Nelson Mandela is coming out of jail?' ''
At the House of the Lord, in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn, many worshipers said they had been up all night, waiting for the moment when Mr. Mandela would speak.
''What does this day mean to New Yorkers?'' Mr. Daughtry asked, as the congregation called out encouragement. ''Well, it has a meaning that transcends New Yorkers. The question ought to be replayed, What does it mean for the people across the world?
 
Walls Are Coming 'Tumbling Down'
''In Africa the walls are coming tumbling down,'' he continued. ''And so for African-Americans in particular, it's a great day. We are linked with our brothers and sisters in South Africa.''
For the people who attended the service, it was a special day indeed.
''They woke us up at 7 in the morning to watch him on TV, but I was glad,'' said Terence Hill, age 10, Doris Pinn, a worshiper, said: ''I feel absolutely exhilarated, His incarceration was symbolic of the incarceration of blacks across the world - politically, socially and economically - and his release is symbolic of the breaking of the chains.''
When Mr. Mandela began his address on television, there was shouting and chanting at House of the Lord. And when he finished, raising his arm in front of him in a salute, his audience raised their arms in response.
On the side of the television, a sticker saying ''Free Mandela'' had been cut up and reconfigured, so that the congregation saw it as they strained forward to watch Mr. Mandela's speech. Now it said ''Mandela Free.''

GRAPHIC: photo: Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah, right, watching her father being released on television from her Amherst, Mass., home yesterday with her husband, Isaac Amuah, and their three children. From the left were Tukwini, 15 years old, Dumani, 13, and Kweku, 5. ''To see him walk out tall in a dignified way, it's just so wonderful to look at him,'' she said. ''I really never expected this moment, this day to come about.'' (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Valentine in a Survey: Marital Fidelity

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Like the overheated characters on television soap operas, a lot of the research into American sexual behavior has not done much for the notion of marital fidelity. Some studies suggest that 30 percent to 70 percent of married men and women have had affairs.
Now, just in time for Valentine's Day, a random nationwide public opinion sampling gathered by the Gallup Organization is offering what it calls new evidence to the contrary: that married Americans may be more monogamous than most people believed and that fidelity and love are thriving.
The findings are in a report, ''Faithful Attraction,'' written by the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley, the Chicago priest, sociologist and novelist. He concludes from the Gallup data that fewer than one in 10 currently married people have been unfaithful to their spouse. 
 
Fidelity, Prayer, Baths
''Marital fidelity is epidemic in America,'' Father Greeley says in his article, which will appear in the March issue of the magazine Psychology Today. Among other things, his statistical snapshot of modern marriage concludes not only that four out of five married people say they would marry the same person again but also discloses that 61 percent of married people pray together; 39 percent take baths or showers together and 20 percent have bought erotic underclothes.
But among some sex researchers and sociologists - and cynics - the poll, described as a survey on family and religion and commissioned by Psychology Today and two national television programs, King World's ''Inside Edition'' and ABC's HOME show - is likely to raise as many questions as it proposes to answer.
The survey, based on a nationwide telephone sample of 657 currently married - and not separated - men and women over the age of 18 had a a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. Its findings take sharp issue with the findings of icons like Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey, the sex researcher who, in the 1950's, suggested that as many as half the married men of the time and a quarter of the married women had had extramarital affairs.
 
Priest Is Called Naive
The survey also contradicts the more recent work of writers like Shere Hite, whose 1987 study, ''Women and Love: A Cultural Revolution in Progress,'' concluded that 70 percent of women married more than five years were having affairs. Her research was later attacked as crude and representing only the discontented.
Colin J. Williams, the former senior researcher for the Kinsey Institute in Indiana, ridiculed Father Greeley's work as ''very naive'' and among other things criticized Gallup's use of a telephone survey to ask people about their sex life.
''If I were having an affair, I sure wouldn't answer their questions about extramarital sex if my wife is in the next room,'' said Mr. Williams, a sociologist at Indiana University's Indianapolis campus. ''What if someone picks up the extension? How do I know for sure who is even calling? Like a lot of Father Greeley's work, it makes great pulp fiction, but it's hardly science.''
But Tom W. Smith, director of the General Social Survey at the University of Chicago's National Opinion Research Center, said the work by Father Greeley and Gallup is important because random, scientific polling techniques had been used to address questions of sexual behavior.
 
'The Most Underresearched'
''Given the importance of sexual behavior and its broad social implications,'' Mr. Smith said, ''there is no question this is the most underresearched topic among all the social sciences.''
It was data from the National Opinion Research Center's annual General Social Survey that inspired Father Greeley to write his current report. In 1988 and 1989, inspired by growing concern over AIDS, researchers asked four specific questions about sexual behavior. The questions were on a questionnaire that the respondents filled out and sealed in an envelope, a method intended to increase faith in confidentialty. The respondents were asked how many sexual partners they had in the previous 12 months.
When Father Greeley and Mr. Smith tabulated the data for married people, they found that fewer than one in 20 said they had more than one sexual partner over the previous 12 months. ''The numbers astonished me,'' Father Greeley said.
 
Future Research Agenda
Michael Hout, chairman of the sociology department at the University of California at Berkeley, said the Gallup survey should be regarded ''as a first step, an important step,'' adding, ''The questions Rev. Greeley is raising ought to help shape a future research agenda.''
Dr. Pepper Schwartz, a sociologist at the University of Washington, agreed with the call for an agenda, but said she thought the Gallup numbers on infidelity were too low.
At the same time, Dr. Schwartz said she thought it was possible that her research for the 1983 book ''American Couples'' (which she wrote with Philip Blumstein) might have given a higher incidence of infidelity than there was then in the general population because her respondents were not scientifically chosen.
Of the people with whom Dr. Schwartz and Mr. Blumstein talked, about 30 percent of the husbands who had been married more than 10 years said they had had extramarital affairs and about 20 percent of the wives did.
''It's true that the conventional wisdom says infidelity is relatively common,'' Dr. Schwartz said. ''But we often disregard the large portion of the population who are, for example, very religious or very inhibited.''
Father Greeley said the view that infidelity is widespread was underscored even in the Gallup survey. Even though less than one in 10 respondents indicated unfaithfulness to the spouse, he said, only a quarter strongly agreed with the proposition that ''most couples are faithful to one another.''

HEADLINE: South Korea Slows Export of Babies for Adoption

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
South Korea, the source of more than half of all foreign babies adopted into American families in recent years, is phasing out its program of sending babies from its orphanages overseas for adoption.
Since 1980, American couples have adopted more than 40,000 Korean babies. But as a result of a booming economy, a lower birth rate and unfavorable international publicity during the 1988 Olympics, South Korea has cut back drastically on the number of babies released for overseas adoption.
According to Immigration and Naturalization Service figures, South Korea sent 3,552 babies to the United States last year, down from a high of 6,188 in 1986. And the decline is likely to be even more dramatic over the next few years as the Korean Government shuts down its carefully controlled system for placing children abroad. 
In response, many adoption agencies are scrambling to expand their programs in India, Thailand, the Philippines, Brazil and Colombia. But international adoptions are an exquisitely sensitive indicator of world politics, and each shift of the political winds can open or shut doors to American adoptive families.
 
Field of Adoption Changes
''India is probably the next largest source of children, but the field of international adoption changes all the time,'' said Roger Bouwma, director of Bethany International Adoptions in Grand Rapids, Mich. ''If there's a change in the government and a very strong wave of nationalism, boom, you're going to see the children kept in their own country no matter what.''
Some adoption officials say a new religious fundamentalism in India is making it substantially harder to pursuade social service workers there to release babies to Christian adoptive homes in the United States.
By the same token, other political changes, like the upheaval in Eastern Europe, may lead to greater receptiveness to adoptions by families in the United States.
 
'Heartstrings Were Touched'
''When we saw Romanian orphanages panning across the television screen, we began to discuss it,'' said Deb Harter, program director at Adoptive Families of America, a Minneapolis-based information and referral group. ''And we started getting phone calls the same Monday morning from families whose heartstrings were touched by the sight of children who needed homes.
''The Romanian Government banned international adoptions in 1987, but our word from the State Department is that the new Government began considering a new law Jan. 15, and may have a decision by mid-February.''
But most adoption officials say it is unlikely that any country will emerge as a new South Korea, sending thousands of children a year to the United States.
''It was a unique situation, growing out of the Korean War and the feeling of responsibility for the Amerasian children there,'' said Susan Cox of Holt International, an agency in Eugene, Ore., that pioneered Korean adoptions. ''But now the birth rate in Korea has declined dramatically. They have put teeth into their one-child-per-family policy. Abortion is becoming more acceptable, and Koreans are adopting more themselves. And certainly there was some feeling of being attacked after the Olympics, with stories calling babies one of Korea's big exports.''
 
Olympic Publicity Cited
Consul Baek-Sang Cho of the South Korean Embassy in Washington said in an interview published by the Adoptive Families group's magazine, OURS, that the Olympics coverage ''forced my Government and the Korean people to sit down and think about what direction Korean international adoptive policies were heading.''
Mr. Cho, who has since moved to the embassy's political section, said he could no longer discuss adoption policies, but the consul general said the quoted comments generally reflected Government policy.
''I want the American people to understand that Korea is now a country, like Japan or the U.S., which is fully able to take care of its own, and as such, we do not wish to send our children to foreign countries,'' Mr. Cho said in the interview. ''The Korean Government does intend eventually to decrease all foreign adoption to near zero. This, of course, will come about gradually as Korean society adjusts to accepting nonrelated children for adoption.''
Koreans have traditionally avoided adoption because of their culture's strong emphasis on ancestry and bloodlines.
Most families seeking to adopt babies from overseas for the first time are being directed by their adoption agencies to other Asian countries, or to South and Central American countries that are expanding their programs. But some families that already have one Korean child are willing to face increasingly long waits to get another.
''It's very important to me that our child have a sibling from the same birth country,'' said Meg Kelsey Wright of Northampton, Mass., who adopted a South Korean baby, Anna, in 1985, and applied in 1987 for another. ''We have made Korean-American friends, and I've been doing some Korean cooking, and I want to be able to support her in learning about her culture. Every year, besides her February birthday, we celebrate ''gotcha day,'' the day in June she came to us, when I get her something from the Korean culture. We feel very enriched.''

HEADLINE: Minnesota Senator's Troubles Stir Little Sympathy at Home

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Minnesota is a state known for its virgin lakes, pioneer spirit and politics so squeaky clean that a city council candidate was once fined for giving away Hostess Twinkees to his constituents.
So the troubles of Senator David Durenberger, a Republican under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for allegations of financial improprieties, are being seen as, well, outright un-Minnesotan.
The new allegations, appearing almost weekly, appear to be trying the patience of ordinary citizens, some of whom have called radio and television talk shows to denounce Mr. Durenberger in terms that range from unflattering to downright scathing.
Senator Durenberger was earlier accused of trying to circumvent Senate limits on income by entering into a questionable $100,000 book deal, of improperly collecting Senate money for his Minneapolis condominium and getting lobbyists to pay for 22 trips to Boston that critics say were made largely for personal reasons. He has denied any wrongdoing while apologizing for lapses in judgment. 
 
New Questions Surfaced
Just as confused and saddened Minnesotans were beginning to come to grips with those charges, new issues were raised by The Minneapolis Star Tribune. The paper reported recently that Mr. Durenberger had received nearly $1 million in loans below the prime interest rate for, among other things, a swimming pool.
And while talk of book deals and condominiums could be shrugged off as the ambiguous perquisites of power, everyone understood what a bank loan was. The idea of a break that big moved a businessman in the Twin Cities, who has paid interest rates of 23 percent on secured loans to keep his small business afloat, to call Nick Coleman, a columnist at The St. Paul Pioneer Press-Dispatch.
The columnist said the businessman, whom he identified only as ''Bob,'' termed the Senator's loans ''hilariously obscene'' and added, ''When I read that our esteemed Senator was borrowing at half the prime rate for his swimming pool, it makes me sick to my stomach.'' The caller said he had voted for Mr. Durenberger in 1988 but would not vote for him again.
 
Approval Rating Tumbles
Other ordinary citizens, while saying they personally liked the Senator, say they find it hard to get over even the appearance of impropriety.
''He's staying in the gray area and trying to make as much money as he can; boy, that irritates me,'' said Douglas MacArthur, a central Minnesota farmer in a call to Almanac, a St. Paul public-affairs program.
Indeed, the approval rating for Senator Durenberger has fallen from 73 percent last October to 41 percent, according to a poll of 800 adults, conducted Jan. 17-23 by The Minneapolis Star Tribune and KSTP-TV. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
The reason for the anger and disappointment, some political observers say, is that Minnesotans pride themselves on a kind of Nordic egalitarianism, and elitist pursuits represent a break from that code.
 
'Personal Attacks' Seen
''There's a sense of fair play, of helping people, cleaning each other's walks in the terrible winters,'' said Jim Rogers, host of a public-affairs radio program here. ''Nobody gets swell-headed because the weather's a great leveler. So when it looks like someone's playing it fast and loose with our clean politics, it's un-Minnesotan.''
But Greg Frank, political director of the Minnesota Republican Party, maintained that ''Minnesotans stand firmly behind Durenberger.'' He and other supporters of the Senator blame the news media for coming up with a new scandal seemingly every week. ''A lot of people are tired of the piling on that's been done in the media,'' Mr. Frank said. ''Personal attacks don't play well in Minnesota.''
Senator Durenberger has said he has no intentions of stepping down. But many people here are saying that if the ethics committee finds him guilty of any wrongdoing, he will be forced to do so. As a teacher from St. Paul put it, ''Minnesota is not a forgiving state.''
While most of the state's newspapers and many citizens are awaiting a decision by the ethics committee before passing judgment, The Mankato Free Press has called for his resignation. ''We decided he had become a pariah,'' said Michael Larson, the newspaper's editor.
State Democrats, fearing a backlash, have avoided pressing the issue. People like Patrick Forciea, a Democratic consultant, are hoping that, because of public pressure, they won't have to. ''The leash that Minnesota politicians are on is quite short,'' Mr. Forciea said.

GRAPHIC: photo: An ethics committee inquiry into charges of financial improprieties by Senator David Durenberger has been a blow to the pride and reputation of Minnesota. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
In Detroit, a Spotlight For Black Composers

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Social relevance is a relatively new occupation for symphonic music in this country. America's orchestras - created, maintained and in some cases destroyed - by small, white, prosperous urban enclaves - now find themselves in very different cities, places where minorities have grown into majorities, seek cultural identities appropriate to their status and have learned the uses of political power.
The question of how a basically European tradition can serve a new constituency has become for orchestra managers not just a matter of principle but one of economic survival. Nowhere is the answer more urgently pursued than in Detroit, whose population nears 70 percent black and whose symphony orchestra depends for one-sixth of its $16 million annual budget on the good will of Michigan legislators. 
One recent response was the widely publicized and debated hiring last summer of Richard Robinson, a bass player who was allowed to bypass the usual ''blind'' audition process in order to increase, to two black players, minority representation in the orchestra.
Another was last week's African-American Composers Forum, consisting of reading rehearsals by the Detroit Symphony of new music, a symposium at nearby Ann Arbor and a pair of concerts over the weekend at the Detroit Symphony's newly renovated Orchestra Hall.
Saturday night's program, repeated this afternoon, offered the first performance of the 28-year-old David Soley's ''Ente,'' ''Hiawatha's Wedding Feast'' by the turn-of-the-century composer Samuel Coleridge-Taylor and then excerpts from Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet.'' J. Rosamond Johnson's ''Lift Every Voice and Sing,'' which has virtually become an anthem for the black movement in this country, was sung by the Brazeal Dennard Chorale and by many in the audience as well.
If Saturday's concert was intended to demonstrate black musicians' ability to compose and perform in the European tradition, then that it did. On the other hand, one looked long and hard and without much profit for any sign of the orchestral medium as an expression of the black experience.
Young Mr. Soley's elegant and slightly abstracted music seemed a world away from the energy of ethnic insurgency. ''Ente'' follows, instead, other recent re-examinations of orchestral sound by European composers like Luciano Berio and Pierre Boulez.
In them, expression by means of sheer weight is rejected, but without a return to the smaller, finer ensemble of the pre-Romantic era. Size, in other words, is used more to yield variety than to accumulate power. Mr. Soley creates precisely mixed and clearly separated colors that are layered one upon the other and yet operate more as a multi-party conversation than as a concerted chorus of sound.
The orchestration is fairly traditional with some exotic percussion instruments added on. ''Ente'' is a confident and convincing eight-minute piece that might as easily have sprung from a bright young Hungarian or German as a black American.
''Hiawatha's Wedding Feast,'' by Coleridge-Taylor, the London-born son of an African father and an English mother, uses thumping rhythms and occasional pentatonic melody to underline Longfellow's familiar American Indian saga. But in much the same way, its roots lie less in any ethnic culture as in the plump and sedentary choral tradition of Edwardian England.
It would be nice to report that Coleridge-Taylor's music is buried treasure, suddenly unearthed. Unfortunately, it is painfully inept. Immobilized by its regular movement and limited sense of harmonic adventure, ''Hiawatha's Wedding Feast'' is dragged down and ultimately drowned in the undertow of relentless cadential formulas.
The Brazeal Dennard Chorale, which has a special talent for clear diction, sang it very well, and James N. Moore Jr. was the competent tenor soloist. Yet in the end Longfellow's leaden poetry gets pretty much what it deserves.
Leslie B. Dunner conducted. He held the difficult moments of ''Ente'' together, did the best he could with what Coleridge-Taylor presented him and, despite some missed ensemble connections in early numbers of the Prokofiev, maintained a forceful momentum throughout.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leslie B. Dunner conducting the Detroit Symphony on Saturday night in the premiere of David Soley's ''Ente.'' (The New York Times/Blake J. Discher)
