HEADLINE: A Chicago Exhibition on Lincoln's America

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
''A House Divided: America in the Age of Lincoln,'' an exhibition that has just opened at the Chicago Historical Society, is more than a show of bland manuscripts and evenhanded statements about the Civil War. The 600 rare documents and artifacts on view, together with a pointed narrative, have been arranged to make a case for the idea that it was slavery more than secession that led to the conflict.
The exhibition derives its name from the prescient speech on June 16, 1858, in Springfield, Ill., in which Abraham Lincoln, the Republican nominee for United States Senator, said: ''A house divided against itself cannot stand. I believe this government cannot endure, half-slave and half-free. I do not expect the Union to be dissolved. I do not expect the house to fall. But I do expect it will cease to be divided. It will become all one thing, or all the other.''
 
Tables, a Wall, a Printing Press 
It draws on material in the archives of the 133-year-old Chicago Historical Society, and is unmatched by anything now on display in the cases of the Lincoln Collection in Springfield or the Library of Congress in Washington.
Among the highlights of the exhibition are the table at which President Lincoln drafted the Emancipation Proclamation in the White House; the table from the Appomattox Courthouse that was used when the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee agreed to surrender to the Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant; a brick wall from the Libby Prison in Richmond, which held captured Union soldiers under harsh conditions, and the printing press of Elijah Parish Lovejoy, the editor of the Alton (Ill.) Observer, who was killed in 1837 defending his press against a mob opposed to his abolitionist writings.
It also features John Brown's Bible, in which Brown marked passages justifying his antislavery activity; a commemorative copy of the 13th Amendment, which abolished slavery and involuntary servitude, signed by President Lincoln and his Cabinet, and Lincoln's deathbed, acquired from the Petersen house in Washington, where the President was taken after he was shot in Ford's Theater across the street.
Union and Confederate artifacts of the Civil War - a surgeon's tools (including a menacing-looking saw), mess kits, rifles and cartridges, a howitzer, battle maps and General Grant's saddle - are also on display.
But the exhibition's emphasis is on slavery. Visitors will see slave shackles; copper tags, with numbers from South Carolina, which resemble Army dog tags and which were used to keep track of nameless rented slaves; posters offering rewards for the recapture of runaway slaves, and minstrel sheet music printed in the North, with caricatures of black dancers that showed racist imagery.
One of the most popular minstrel characters was named Jim Crow, a name adapted after the Civil War to mean the laws and customs that discriminated against blacks.
''The big themes we're showing are the true nature of slavery and Lincoln in history, and not just his toothbrush,'' said Prof. Eric Foner, as he walked through the winding exhibition rooms the other day. He is De Witt Clinton professor of history at Columbia University and the author of ''Reconstruction: America's Unfinished Revolution.'' Professor Foner and Olivia Mahoney of the Chicago Historical Society's section on decorativeand industrial arts are the curators of the exhibition.
''In emphasizing how critical the slavery issue was in the origins of the Civil War, 'A House Divided' reflects the thinking of the most recent generation of American historians,'' Professor Foner said. ''Many scholars of an earlier generation viewed the war as a needless conflict between two fundamentally similar societies. They argued that the war was caused by irresponsible agitators, who inflamed public opinion, and by blundering political leaders, who proved unable to resolve the resulting crisis. But in recent years, historians have become aware of the centrality of slavery to the fundamental divisions it created in the 19th century. As Lincoln observed in his second inaugural address, everyone understood that slavery was 'somehow' the cause of the war.''
''Many historians abandoned this insight in favor of other narrow economic questions as the cause of the sectional crisis,'' he continued. ''Of course, issues like immigration and the tariff were divisive. However, it's impossible to think seriously about American society without coming to grips with slavery, emancipation and the union, and that's what underlies the way we have constructed 'A House Divided.'
''Lincoln was committed to halting slavery's expansion and his election meant that the slaveholding economy could not continue. I wanted to place the Civil War squarely on the shoulders of slavery.''
 
Mingling People and Cattle
He pointed to an original poster labeled ''Sale of Slaves and Stock,'' advertising a sale held in Savannah, Ga., in 1852. It was a cash-only sale to settle an estate after the death of a slaveowner named Luther McGowan. On the same poster, people and cattle were mingled; no distinction was drawn between women, men, children, horses, mules and cows. One phrase shows a way that families were broken up: ''Slaves will be sold separate, or in lots, as best suits the purchaser.''
Thirty-six slaves, described as a prime lot, were on the block that day. Among them were: ''Melie Ann, 19 years old, housework, smart yellow girl, $1,250; Uncle Tim, 60, fair hand with mules, $600; Adam, 28, Cotton, prime young Man, $1,200; Angelina, 16, prime girl, house or field, $1,000; Sally, 10, handy in kitchen, $675; infant, 1, strong likely boy, $400.''
''We wanted to show the true reality, not the 'Gone With the Wind' view of slavery,'' Professor Foner said. ''When you hear about paternalism and how the masters loved their slaves, a different story is told by these original posters and broadsides.''
 
Taking Lincoln's Position
''A House Divided'' also examines some political and social issues from 1820 to 1865. It includes material about workers and the beginning of machine-made products. ''We take the position that Lincoln emphasized all the time: that he was pro-labor in the sense that free workers had an opportunity to be independent and prosper, unlike slaves who could not improve their condition in life because they had no economic or social mobility,'' Professor Foner said.
The abolitionist leader Frederick Douglass occupies a prominent place in the exhibition. There are portraits of little-known women who served the abolitionist cause. The exhibition also includes some Southern documents upholding slavery.
Moving on to the Senate race in Illinois in 1858 between Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas, the Democratic incumbent, electronic excerpts from the debates, read by actors, can be heard. The main issue was the expansion of slavery into the new Western territories, which Lincoln opposed. ''I hope that visitors won't be too disappointed when they listen to the high-minded rhetoric of Lincoln and Douglas compared to politicians today who often fail to discuss serious issues with similar eloquence,'' Professor Foner said.
 
On Paper, Concerns of a President
Lincoln aficionados can find several of his historic letters in the exhibition. There is the letter setting the terms of the debate with Senator Douglas. A letter he wrote concerning freedmen and former slaves entering the Army and donning Union blue may remind filmgoers of ''Glory,'' which focuses on the black infantrymen in the 54th Massachusetts. Written to General Grant on Aug. 9, 1863, about Gen. George Henry Thomas, the letter in part says:
''A word upon another subject. Gen. Thomas has gone again to the Mississippi Valley, with a view of raising colored troops. I have no reason to doubt that you are doing what you reasonably can upon the same subject. I believe it is a resource which, if vigorously applied now, will soon close the contest. It works doubly, weakening the enemy and strengthening us.''
In a letter to General Grant, which mentions Gen. Philip Sheridan and which is written from Army headquarters at City Point, Va., on April 7, 1865, Lincoln wrote:
''General Sheridan says, 'If the thing is pressed I think that Lee will surrender.' Let the thing be pressed.''
At the end of the exhibition, there is a copy of the 13th Amendment and of the Civil Rights Act of 1866 establishing black citizenship. The last word is given to Frederick Douglass: ''Verily, the work does not end with the abolition of slavery but only begins.''
''A House Divided'' was underwritten by grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities and many state agencies, private foundations and business organizations. It will not travel, but is to remain in the American History Wing of the Chicago Historical Society, Clark Street at North Avenue, at least until Lincoln's Birthday, 2000.

HEADLINE: Tougher U.S. Stance on Big Bank Deposits

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The Federal Government's intensified war on drug trafficking has for the first time clashed with the most profitable segment of the banking business.
Though banks have policies against taking drug money, their private international banking departments have long accepted and sometimes actively sought the deposits of foreigners looking to move hundreds of billions of dollars away from weak economies, or seeking to evade tax or currency laws or to hide their money for a variety of reasons.
That pool of anonymous money, known in banking parlance as flight capital, has often included the enormous profits of illicit drug transactions, and Federal prosecutors are now finding themselves entering the world of flight capital.
In a landmark case last week, two units of the $20 billion Bank of Credit and Commerce International were ordered to forfeit a record $15 million after a Federal judge in Tampa, Fla., accepted their guilty plea. In the indictment, prosecutors charged that the Luxembourg-based bank had a strategy to increase deposits by seeking, specifically, flight capital ''and the proceeds of drug sales, in conscious violation of the currency regulations, tax laws, and anti-drug laws of the United States, and of other nations.'' 
Though the bank's units pleaded guilty, five of their officials are now on trial. The Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which has offices in 73 countries, including the United States, specializes in private international banking. Its deposits included hidden funds of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed leader of Panama who is now in jail in the United States facing drug and money-laundering charges.
The Justice Department's decision to cite flight capital activity in a criminal case has broad implications for banks, according to banking experts and officials: The meaning of the case and other recent Federal Government actions, they say, is that large multinational banks, based in America or abroad, that do business in the United States must now begin to ask tougher questions about their foreign depositors and the souces of their money - or face possible prosecution.
 
'Never Discussed Before'
''The old argument by banks that their customer is just trying to escape the consequences of his economy'' is no longer sufficient, said John J. Byrne, the senior Federal legislative counsel for the American Bankers Association in Washington. ''Flight capital was never discussed before when we talked about money laundering,'' he continued. ''But the notion in the past that it was untouchable is not the case now.''
E. Lawrence Barcella Jr., a Washington lawyer for the Bank of Credit and Commerce, as well as several other banks, said, ''The U.S. and the international banking community better realize that there but for the grace of God go they.''
Mr. Byrne and other banking experts agree that banks should scrutinize their customers more carefully. But such inspection can be difficult and costly, the experts said, and it can conflict with what has been the basic nature of a business in which customers expect confidentiality.
Federal banking regulators are now asking banks for the first time to report ''suspicious transactions,'' including a financial transaction known as the back-to-back loan - a tactic central to the Bank of Credit and Commerce case and one that the prosecutors say is often used to hide money.
In such a transaction, a customer may deposit illegally earned money in one branch office of a highly respected bank, and the money is then used confidentially to finance a loan back to the same customer from another branch of the same bank. So the original money, that was illegally earned, is hidden, and if law-enforcement officials ask where the depositor got the funds he now has, he simply says it was a loan from the respected bank.
''The banking industry has a severe problem here,'' said Charles Morley, a former Senate investigator who is a consultant to the banking industry on money-laundering issues. ''Cash-to-cash loans are common in the international banking community. The Government is making them suspicious, and my concern is that the banking industry doesn't recognize this yet.''
 
No Reason for Suspicion
Mr. Barcella, in defending the banks during a recent interview, said that often in the case of a foreign depositor, ''they had no reason to suspect a customer was a drug dealer.'' He continued, ''They assumed he wanted confidentiality because it was flight capital.''
But the Government now rejects that argument, Mr. Barcella said, telling the banks, in effect, that ''the best explanation you can give is that you were helping break the laws of a foreign country.''
The Money Laundering Control Act of 1986, which was amended in 1988, makes it a crime to knowingly conceal the ''nature, the location, the source, the ownership or the control of the proceeds'' of various kinds of illegal activity, including many domestic white-collar crimes, but not violations of foreign currency or tax laws.
 
New Regulations
More recently, the Government has issued the new regulations and guidelines that require the banks to disclose ''suspicious transactions'' involving flight capital.
And now, by definition, it is considered suspicious if a deposit in one foreign branch is used to back a loan to the same depositor at another branch. ''Back-to-back transactions; that's how flight capital moves. That's what the Treasury now says is suspicious,'' said Mr. Byrne of the bankers association.
The Justice Department's money-laundering experts decline to comment on the flight-capital developments while the Bank of Credit and Commerce case is pending. But Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, in addressing the bankers association last fall, indicated that it was no longer free from close scrutiny. ''Wouldn't some bankers, even the Treasury itself, perhaps prefer to keep quiet about wealthy flight capital altogether?'' he asked.
 
Dilemma Facing Banks
The American Bankers Association's guidelines call on bank employees to report suspicious transactions, ''consistent with basic principles of customer privacy.'' But the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures American bank deposits, recently pointed out a dilemma now facing the bankers. It told the Treasury that if banks ''report a customer for possible money laundering and continue to do business with that customer, they face the possibility of violating the Money Laundering Control Act for doing business with a suspected money launderer.''
The agency added, ''If they terminate their relationship with the customer based upon their suspicions, they may harm the customer financially and face a lender liability suit.'' Other experts say these customers are not likely to file such lawsuits.
Flight capital was born decades ago, when Western banks helped perfect secret systems in which foreigners, many of them Latin Americans, buried money outside their home country. Gradually over the years, drug traffickers began taking advantage of these secret systems.
''The growth of flight capital in the 1970's laid the framework for money laundering in the 1980's,'' said James S. Henry, an economist formerly with the management consulting firm of McKinsey & Company. ''A whole set of techniques to move money, to hide money, bring it back through back-to-back loans - this was all developed in the 1960's and 1970's by private banking departments.''
As bank financial reports do not separate private banking activities, it is not possible to say what portion of total banking they represent. Whatever fraction of the banking business it comprises, private banking is highly profitable. Because of some of the obvious financial and security advantages, rich foreign investors are willing to pay high fees and accept low yields. Thus, a bank's return on equity for private banking can exceed 100 percent, Mr. Henry said.
''Private banking is the single most profitable activity for money center banks in the 1980's,'' Mr. Henry said.
Global figures on anonymous money are also hard to come by. Two years ago, the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland, estimated that between 1978 and 1987, some $170 billion in flight capital left 10 Latin American countries, but that figure did not include money hidden by falsified trade transactions, a common phenomenon in some of these countries.
Mr. Henry estimates that anonymous capital flows, including drug money and flight capital, now total $600 billion to $800 billion.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 12, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1538 words

HEADLINE: Bonn's Point Man on Currency

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 11

 BODY:
West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's call last week for talks with East Germany on creating a single German currency was a bold political maneuver - plus a daunting economic and financial challenge. And the challenge of putting the proposed monetary union in place, of making the West German mark the official currency of East Germany, would land on the doorstep of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank.
Karl Otto Pohl, the 60-year-old president of the Bundesbank, seems to be a reluctant conscript in Mr. Kohl's drive for a monetary union, which would sharply accelerate the pace of economic reunification of East and West Germany. When the Chancellor announced his proposal on Tuesday, Mr. Pohl branded it ''a very fantastic idea.''
Indeed, even before Mr. Kohl's announcement, Mr. Pohl and other Bundesbank directors had cast doubt on the merits of monetary union in the near future. First, Mr. Pohl said, East Germany needed to build its economy up to a level closer to the West's; he had doubts that shifting to another currency alone would solve East Germany's problems. For Bonn, he warned, a rapid currency union involved serious risks of rising inflation, higher interest rates and deepening budget deficits. 
 
Abrupt Change of Rhetoric
But Mr. Pohl, a central banker of proven political skills, having risen in the Government ranks as a protege of Helmut Schmidt, changed his rhetoric abruptly after the West German Cabinet backed Mr. Kohl on Wednesday. The Government set up a ''German unity'' committee to pursue negotiations with the East German Government on monetary union. Afterward, Mr. Pohl explained pointedly that his differences with the Kohl Government were mainly over matters of timing, not substance.
''One must not look at currency union with a shopkeeper mentality,'' Mr. Pohl said in a radio interview. He called Mr. Kohl's plan ''a historic decision that could not be approached with a faint heart.''
Mr. Pohl's changed tone is largely a compromise with reality. Established in 1957 and modeled closely on the United States Federal Reserve System, the Bundesbank has, by law, a high degree of independence, but it is required to support the general economic policy of the Government.
Besides, any move to create a monetary union would be a political decision for East and West Germany. The Bundesbank could not veto the move, regardless of the qualms of its top officials. Indeed, though Mr. Pohl sat in on the Wednesday Cabinet meeting, no Bundesbank representative will be on the Government's ''unity'' committee, set up to map out all aspects of reunification, beginning with monetary union.
 
'Really Irresponsible'
The Bundesbank, economists say, now finds itself in a difficult position. ''What the Bonn Government has done is really irresponsible,'' said Jonathan Hoffmann, an economist with Credit Suisse-First Boston in London. ''Having an independent central bank gives them the opening to make an extravagant political promise, and then step back and leave it up to the Bundesbank.''
Still, reservations about the proposed monetary union extend well beyond the Frankfurt headquarters of the Bundesbank. Many crucial particulars have not yet been discussed, notably the appropriate exchange rate. Beyond that, serious questions remain about how it will work and if it will have the desired effect of shoring up the East German economy enough to stop the steady drain of its citizens to the properous West, at the rate of nearly 2,000 a day.
The thinking behind the proposal is that monetary union would restore the flagging confidence of East Germans that their economy would be formally integrated into West Germany, giving the East Germans reason to stay home.
In East Berlin, there are clearly misgivings about a rapid monetary union. The economic integration that comes with the shift to a single currency, for instance, may bring widespread layoffs and higher prices as inefficient East German state industries fall by the wayside and subsidies are trimmed. For East Germany, a monetary union would amount to giving up its economic sovereignty.
 
'Social Consequences'
With an eye on the March elections, the Economics Minister of East Germany, Christa Luft, said ''a union has such huge economic and social consequences that a Government with only a few weeks left in office understandably cannot give its blessing.''
''Politically, the proposal could be a solution, but economically, I have my doubts for both sides,'' she said.
For the Bundesbank, the main worry about a rapid monetary union - and the economic reunification that would inevitably accompany it -is that it poses a severe inflationary threat. The most obvious, but less significant, source of inflationary pressure associated with monetary union would be the printing of more West German marks to exchange for Ostmarks.
Until a rate of exchange is decided, it is impossible to say how much additional money supply will be created. But it would not seem to be a big problem for the Bundesbank. For example, if one West German mark was issued and exchanged for five East German marks, the addition to the nation's money supply would be about 3 percent, by some estimates.
''The financing problem is manageable,'' Mr. Pohl said last week.
 
Larger Inflation Threat
But the larger inflation threat linked to monetary union would be posed by the huge amount of spending required to lift the East German economy toward the standards of the West. The forecasts are guesses at best, analysts admit, but the numbers range up to more than $600 billion over the next several years. Most of that money would presumably come from West Germany, through some combination of private and Government investment. And the higher spending, particularly by the Government, could well fuel inflation.
For an institution that has been called ''the world's financial conscience on inflation'' - fighting it even when there is none - the genuine prospect of inflation is a chilling matter.
Like other central banks, the Bundesbank is charged with regulating the amount of money in circulation and of credit supplied to the economy with the aim of maintaining the value of money. The Bundesbank takes its marching orders seriously indeed, helped by a powerful anti-inflation consensus in West German society.
Here, the word ''inflation'' has a tenacious grip on the national psyche. Many German families still have some memory of the hyper-inflation of the 1920's - the wheelbarrows full of currency that bought a loaf of bread or bowl of soup. That clearly colors the thinking of the Bundesbank policy makers, and even modest upturns in inflation are viewed with alarm.
In the late 1970's, West Germany's trading partners, particularly the United States, urged Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Government to act as an economic locomotive to pull Europe out of recession. While economic growth rose, so did inflation. By 1981 it was running at a 6.3 percent annual rate.
 
Playing on Fears
A year later, Mr. Schmidt was gone, replaced by Mr. Kohl and his center-right coalition, which made effective use of inflation fears in its election campaign.
That lesson was not lost on Mr. Pohl, a Social Democrat who was appointed president of the Bundesbank in 1979 by Mr. Schmidt. During the 1980's the Bundesbank kept its monetary policy fairly tight. Inflation dropped steadily, and in 1986 West Germany actually had deflation of two-tenths of 1 percent. During Mr. Pohl's tenure, West Germany has had the lowest inflation of any industrialized nation, and it is now running at a modest annual pace of about 3 percent.
Because of its success in limiting inflation, the Bundesbank is held in high esteem by most Germans.
Accordingly, its critics have been almost exclusively foreigners. For example, James A. Baker 3d, when he was Treasury Secretary in the Reagan Administration, would often accuse the Bundesbank of being obsessed with inflation, undermining the world's economic growth. The French Government has also pricked the Bundesbank from time to time about slow growth. In the French view, inflation of up to 8 or 9 percent is a sign of a robust economy.
 
Moderate to Rabid
Within the Bundesbank's 19-member central bank council, the views seem to range from moderately to rabidly anti-inflationary. Helmut Schlesinger, vice president of the Bundesbank, is often singled out as a true hard-liner. Mr. Baker once accused him of leading a cadre of inflexible monetarists on the Bundesbank's council that would fight inflation at any cost, including economic growth.
The council meets every two weeks at Bundesbank headquarters in Frankfurt to set monetary policy. It is headed by either Mr. Pohl or, in his absence, Mr. Schlesinger, and consists of the 8 bank directors and the presidents of the 11 state central banks, for a total of 19 members.
The composition is intended to represent fairly the federal structure of West Germany. Decisions are made by a simple majority of the votes cast. While the state central bank presidents usually take their cues from the Bundesbank directors, there have been instances in which the council went against their wishes.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Books on Greed Worry Wall St.

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
The husky-voiced caller from Pittsburgh was almost pleading. ''Tell me something that will restore my confidence in the free-enterprise system,'' he asked the guest on ''Larry King Live,'' a popular Cable News Network talk show.
Michael Lewis, the author of ''Liar's Poker,'' a book about Salomon Brothers, paused and then answered, ''I don't think there is much going on on Wall Street now that would restore your faith in free enterprise.'' It was every investment banker's nightmare.
It is bad enough for those on Wall Street that jokes about their profession have become a national pastime. Now, several recent books paint a devastating portrait of the Street and some of its most senior executives. 
 
Best-Selling Books
Two of those books have soared to second and third positions on The New York Times list of best-selling nonfiction hardcover books. ''Barbarians at the Gate,'' a Harper & Row book by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar, is an account of the takeover struggle for RJR Nabisco Inc., which ended with the company being acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. ''Liar's Poker,'' a hilarious first-person account of life on a trading floor, is published by W. W. Norton & Company.
The excesses of Wall Street have been popularized before in films like ''Wall Street'' and in the Off Broadway play ''Other People's Money.'' Both are works of fiction. Many people on Wall Street are divided about the accuracy of the portrait of the Street painted in the new books, most of which are nonfiction. But some executives said such harsh representations of Wall Street - whether accurate or not - could have serious repercussions. They come as the nation seems to be in transition to a new gestalt.
Old-fashioned values are coming into vogue again, spurred on by the model of an ostensibly kinder, gentler President, political analysts say. Conspicuous consumption is out; environmentally correct diapers are in. In such an atmosphere, some analysts say, a populist backlash might develop against business in general and Wall Street in particular.
''Culturally, you're probably looking at the leading indicators of a move away from looking at finance and business through favorable glasses,'' said Kevin Phillips, a political analyst in Washington with close ties to the Republican Party.
Mr. Phillips thinks that conservatives of the ''let's deregulate, anything goes'' school are already on the run, thanks to widely publicized debacles involving the savings and loan industry, overly leveraged companies and high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds.'' His views are shared by many on Wall Street, who worry that if the economy weakens and unemployment rises, public attitudes toward business could turn hostile.
''Some of these books are indictments of the business community as much as the Wall Street community,'' said John C. Whitehead, a former Deputy Secretary of State who was a senior partner at the Wall Street firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Although none were willing to discuss it openly, several prominent Wall Street executives said a new novel called ''Hanover Place,'' written by Michael Thomas and published by Warner Books, has aroused fears of a resurgence of anti-Semitism.
In its apocalyptic ending, the novel equates takeovers and insider-trading with a new money-grubbing culture. Many of the characters are Jewish and, in the novel, that produces a virulent anti-Semitic backlash.
The other books do not raise an issue of such gravity. But they do offer insights that many readers have found astonishing and disturbing. In Mr. Lewis's ''Liar's Poker,'' Salomon Brothers executives are depicted as an unruly band of juvenile delinquents whose idea of a good time is to rig chairs to collapse when sat upon and replace a suitcase of their colleague's travel clothes with wet paper towels. Sort of an ''Animal House'' with suspenders. The book also depicts Salomon underlings as selling undesirable securities to unsuspecting customers.
''Be very wary, suspicious, is the point,'' Mr. Lewis counseled Larry King's audience.
A spokesman for Salomon, Robert Baker, said the book was ''an amusing caricature.''
 
Treacherous Executives
''Barbarians at the Gate'' - and a less successful book published by New American Library on the same subject, ''True Greed,'' by Hope Lampert - depicts some of Wall Street's most prominent executives as even more treacherous. Deal makers named in both of these nonfiction books are shown as conniving and manipulative, more consumed with their own agendas than the goals of their clients. Readers are left with an overwhelming sense that the $25 billion acqusition of RJR Nabisco occurred not because it was worth that much, or because it made economic sense, but because it was the inevitable climax of a battle royal of egos.
In an interview with Mr. Burrough, Tom Brokaw, the NBC news anchor, asked the co-author of ''Barbarians'' if he had ever heard any of the principals say something like, ''Wait a minute, we do have an obligation to those people who live in places in North Carolina and Atlanta, Ga., and who depend on this company, really, for their daily paycheck and maybe for their financial future.''
Mr. Burrough replied, ''In fact, the evidence shows that the workers were the last thing anyone was concerned with.''
While some of those who are depicted in the books say the accounts are largely correct, others insist the portraits are exaggerated.
 
Other Side of the Picture
''There are a lot of very thoughtful, conscientious people who are interested in their clients, who put their clients before themselves,'' said Martin Lipton, a top takeover lawyer at the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton Rosen & Katz. ''You never see the other side of the picture because that would be called a 'puff piece.' It's books like ''Liar's Poker'' and ''Barbarians'' that sell.''
Henry R. Kravis, a partner at Kohlberg, Kravis, expressed concern that journalists were exaggerating Wall Street's faults. ''I'm afraid a lot has been blown out of proportion,'' he said. ''We could kill the goose that laid the golden egg: the capital markets of this country.''
The overriding issue may not be how accurate or representative these books are, but the extent to which they are perceived to be. Some people think the books have already had an impact. Many Wall Street figures speculated privately that the recent resignation of Peter A. Cohen as chief executive of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. was partly the result of his characterization in ''Barbarians'' as hot-headed, inept, even slightly thuggish. In a particularly memorable scene in the book, he tells one of Wall Street's top attorneys: ''Hey you, lawyer. I'm talkin' to you.''
Some financial figures thought it was no coincidence that Mr. Cohen's replacement, Howard Clark Jr., is known for being quiet, soft-spoken -a bow, as it were, to public opinion.
 
'Mirrors of Each Other'
The RJR Nabisco books could also cause some changes in corporate America, for Wall Street deal makers are not the only ones being sullied.
Henry B. Schacht, the chief executive of the Cummins Engine Company, maintains that corporate America must bear some responsibility for Wall Street's behavior. ''We're mirrors of each other,'' he said. By and large, Wall Sreet deal makers ''serve the requirements that are laid down to them,'' he added.
The furor over the recent books grows especially intense when discussions turn to two that deal with Jews on Wall Street.
''The New Crowd,'' a Little, Brown book by Judith R. Ehrlich and Barry J. Rehfeld, depicts a new generation of Jewish investment bankers as brash and ostentatious, in sharp distinction to what the authors feel is the understated wealth and dignified behavior of the German-Jewish investment bankers of the early 1900's.
But the book that stirs the greatest debate is Mr. Thomas's novel, ''Hanover Place.'' It uses a fictionalized firm, S. L. Warrington & Son, as a vehicle for describing the evolution of social attitudes on Wall Street over seven decades.
''It is a violently anti-Semitic book,'' said Mr. Lipton, the lawyer, echoing the view of Judith Martin, who reviewed the book for The New York Times Book Review on Jan. 7.
Mr. Thomas said that when he started writing the book, insider trading scandals involving Dennis B. Levine, Ivan F. Boesky and Michael R. Milken, all of whom are Jewish, led him to fear that ''an anti-Wall Street backlash, already brewing in the wake of uncontrolled '80's merger mania, might now take on a serious anti-Semitic cast.''
''I am not an anti-Semite,'' Mr. Thomas said. ''I would hate to have this book viewed as anti-Semitic because it is about anti-Semitism.''

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Learning to Invest In Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
SIFTING through Eastern Europe's startling developments, American corporations are slowly developing a strategy for investing in that part of the world - one that treats Eastern Europe as a source of low-cost labor and a platform for exporting products to rich Western Europe. Making consumer products for the hard-pressed Eastern Europeans is not, for American executives, an appetizing goal.
The emerging strategy is understandable. Eastern European currencies are not easily convertible into dollars or yen or marks. So why invest in a factory that would make, say, toothpaste for Czechoslovaks when the profits from such operations cannot easily be sent back to the United States or spent outside Eastern Europe. 
''Until you get the currency problem solved, American businessmen will consider their opportunities limited,'' said Richard Rahn, chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
And besides, there are not that many customers: only 43 million people in Hungary, East Germany and Czechoslovakia, the richest markets. It is far better, American executives say, to make light bulbs in Hungary, as General Electric is doing, and export them for francs or marks, which can be converted quickly into dollars and sent home.
Peter Rona, chief executive of IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company, who is helping United States companies get started in Eastern Europe, sums up the thinking this way: ''The big leverage is the low labor cost in the proximity of very high Western European labor costs. Without that there would not be much American interest in foreign investment in Eastern Europe.'' Wages in Eastern Europe are generally below $3 an hour, versus $10 an hour in most of Western Europe. So far Hungary, the easiest Eastern European country in which to set up shop, has drawn most of the meager American investment in the area -the total outlay still being below $300 million.
Among export-oriented companies setting up in Hungary are Samsonite (luggage), Guardian Industries (plate glass) and G.E., whose outlay of $150 million to purchase control of Tungsram, Hungary's only light-bulb maker, is easily the biggest American investment in Eastern Europe.
The plusses for G.E. are impressive, and so are the risks. On the plus side, G.E. sells high-tech lighting in Europe, but not screw-in bulbs and fluorescent lights. Tungsram had been exporting just these items to Western Europe, and controlled 4 percent of the market, which G.E. inherited.
''That 4 percent market share, with its hard-currency revenue, is worth more than the $150 million G.E. paid for the whole company,'' Mr. Rona said.
General Electric does not disagree. ''This will give us a good base to expand in Western Europe,'' said Frank Doyle, a senior vice president.
But for the low price, General Electric takes on the burden of converting an inefficient operation into an efficient one. Among other things, that means cutting the work force of 18,000, perhaps by half, a task that could embroil G.E. in Hungarian politics. (Some Hungarian economists argue that the state should first carry out these unpleasant but socially important tasks and then sell a revitalized Tungsram - for much more than G.E. paid.) But no one at Tungsram has been laid off yet by G.E.'s newly installed managers. Indeed, Mr. Doyle said, resignations and retirements might shrink the staff, without layoffs. And if attrition does not solve the problem, then G.E. and other companies setting up export operations in Eastern Europe have another way of controlling costs.
Inevitably, each of the Eastern European countries will devalue its money, seeking levels that will increase exports and eventually make their currencies convertible into hard currencies. Each devaluation means that wages and other costs will represent a smaller percentage of the dollars or marks that a G.E. or a Samsonite collects in revenue for its exports.
But if export-oriented investment strikes American companies as the safest route to profits in Eastern Europe, some are nevertheless attempting to serve local consumers. U S West, the telephone company, is putting up $5 million in a venture with Hungary's state telephone company to build a cellular phone network in Budapest.
Repatriation of profits will not become a problem until the network is up and running and revenues begin to flow, perhaps late next year, said Edward Mattix, a U S West executive. By then, converting florints into dollars may be easier than it is today - and even if it is not, then $5 million will have bought U S West an inside track in future Hungarian projects, Mr. Mattix said.
Clearly, manufacturing in Eastern Europe for export to the rich nations is a better business, just as it was for American companies when they first set up shop in East Asia. ''You didn't see people going into Singapore or South Korea for those markets, either,'' said Charles Movit, a senior economist at PlanEcon, a consulting firm. ''Eastern Europe is really very much the same thing.''

HEADLINE: Dean of Central Bankers Has Had Spotlight Before

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank and the man faced with the daunting task of overseeing German monetary union, should it occur, is no stranger to the spotlight. He is considered the dean of the industrial world's central bankers, having served in his position since 1979.
Mr. Pohl, who is 60 years old, is one of the three most powerful central bankers in the world, along with the chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, and Yasushi Mienom, governor of the Bank of Japan. 
Mr. Pohl is respected by his peers for his pragmatic approach to monetary policy and the political skills that have helped him shape international agreements like the Louvre accord to stabilize currency values in 1987 and the so-called Plaza agreement, signed in New York in 1985, which was intended to lower the dollar's value against other leading currencies.
In December 1989, he was elected to a three-year term as chairman of the Committee of European Community Central Bank Governors. In that post he will play a crucial role in guiding the community toward its own monetary union and a European central banking system. The model he prefers is the Bundesbank.
 
'Priority on Price Stability'
''A European central bank should be based on the same principles - if not the same structure - as the Bundesbank,'' Mr. Pohl has said, a sentiment he has voiced often. ''That means independence from governments and from community institutions, with a priority on price stability.''
While Mr. Pohl has given lukewarm support to the idea of a European central bank, he has frequently expressed doubts about whether European governments are willing to give away that much sovereignty over monetary policy. His views on German monetary union appear to mirror that position.
Originally appointed by the Social Democratic Government of Helmut Schmidt, Mr. Pohl, a member of the Social Democratic Party since 1948, was reappointed in June 1987 by Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition, despite some resistance from the Chancellor's Christian Democratic Union.
 
Worked as a Journalist
Mr. Pohl was born on Dec. 1, 1929, in Hanover, the son of a municipal clerk. He graduated from the University of Gattingen in 1955 with a degree in economics. He worked as an economic journalist for various newspapers, including Die Zeit, a highly respected weekly.
In 1970, Karl Schiller, the Economics Minister in Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government, hired Mr. Pohl, and he was eventually appointed Under Secretary for international monetary policy. In 1977, Mr. Schmidt assured him an appointment as vice president of the Bundesbank. He succeeded Otmar Emminger in 1979.
His tenure has been marked by a policy of relatively high interest rates and tight monetary policy to maintain currency stability and fight inflation. Mr. Pohl opposes deficits in public spending and state programs to fight unemployment. In 1984, under his leadership, the Bundesbank registered its highest annual profit to date, 13.2 billion marks.
Mr. Pohl, who has been married twice, has four children.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Are Tied to Events Overseas

BYLINE: y KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The extraordinary developments in the Germanys and political uncertainty in Japan have led to fears of higher inflation abroad. Those concerns will not dissipate quickly, and economists and portfolio managers say interest rate movements in the United States are likely to remain strongly dependent on developments in the overseas bond markets for a while longer.
''Near-term prospects for any overseas bond market rallies are dim,'' said Richard B. Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers. ''These higher rates will keep a floor under U.S. interest rates for the time being, and Treasury bond yields may flare further in response to international developments.'' 
After viewing developments in Japan and Europe, Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. concluded that a major role reversal is taking place: The United States, long the home of high consumption and low production, will be supplanted as a vibrant source of internal demand by the Germans and the Japanese. That will ultimately have a beneficial impact on interest rates in the United States, the analysts argue, but it will take some time for markets to arrive at that conclusion.
 
'Growth Rates Are Diverging'
''Our inflation rates are converging, but growth rates are diverging,'' Mr. Barbera said. ''In the future they are going to look like us in terms of big spending.''
The shift toward more consumption is most striking in the Germanys, which appear to be on an irreversible course toward reunification.
''Imagine what would happen to our budget if we suddenly granted statehood to Mexico,'' said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. ''Those are the sorts of needs we are talking about. Interest rates in West Germany will rise higher, as the full cost of this adjustment process becomes clearer. And rising interest-rate cycles in West Germany and Japan will delay improvement in the Anglo-Saxon countries,'' a reference to the United States, Britain and Canada.
In response to the developments, yields on West German 10-year bonds have climbed above 8 percent for the first time since the mid-1980's.
 
Rates Seem Too High
William H. Gross, a managing director at Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif., observed: ''From a domestic standpoint, interest rates do not belong at these levels; they are too high for where we are in the business cycle. But they are being pulled up by other economies that are growing faster than we are.''
Some analysts suggested that the developments in foreign bond markets will prevent the Federal Reserve Board from lowering American interest rates in the near term.
''Right now, German bonds are among the most attractive investment vehicles in the world,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.
''But it was a very good sign for American bonds that there was no after-effect last week in the United States market after the sharp selloff in the German bond market,'' he said. ''The more restraint we get from the Fed, the better bonds are going to perform.''
 
Bond Market's Rally
After pushing interest rates to their highest levels in the last 10 months in advance of last week's quarterly refunding auction by the Treasury, the bond market ended the week with a strong rally. The new bellwether 8.50 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price to yield 8.33 percent.
''We have had a nice rally of 30 basis points from the lows last week,'' said Mr. Gross of Pacific Investment Management. ''Near term, we have to rest. Things are not that different from last Tuesday, when the market hit bottom.''
The rally in the Treasury market also lifted prices in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds. The development could prove beneficial to New York City, which this week is expected to make its first public bond offering since the Dinkins Administration took office in January.
Unlike most New York City offerings, which are usually negotiated deals, the $250 million worth of general obligation bonds to be sold this week will be offered at competitive bid.
 
Setting 'the Right Tone'
A competitive auction ''sets the right tone,'' said Elizabeth Holtzman, the city's new Comptroller. ''It's a new administration, and we expect the competitive sale will get the city the best possible price under the circumstances.''
The Dinkins Administration is currently sifting options about who will serve as its financial adviser and form its core underwriting syndicate in the years ahead.
With those plums dangling, bidding for the bonds could be spirited indeed, analysts said.
''As the city goes through the process of selecting managers for its negotiated deals, this competitive sale gives underwriters the opportunity to put their bodies and their wallets on the line,'' said James F. Lynch, an investment adviser and editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, a newsletter published in New York.
''It is an excellent strategy, because the underwriters will want to look very good in the city's eyes,'' he said. ''Those investors who are thinking about buying these bonds should be aware of this mating dance and steer clear of this deal. They will probably be able to get better yields on these bonds in a week or so, because the underwriters will overpay for them.''
Late last week, dealers estimated that the bonds that mature in 2020 would be priced to yield 7.85 percent to 7.90 percent. The Standard & Poor's Corporation has an A-minus rating on New York City's outstanding debt. Moody's Investors Services, which has had an A rating on outstanding New York City bonds, said late last week it would update its rating today.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Will Panama's Woes Frustrate Democracy?

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
On Central Avenue in downtown Panama City, clothing stores are slowly reopening, selling jeans for $3, cotton shirts for less than $2 and plastic shoes for 99 cents. Shoppers browse under the protection of private security guards carrying shotguns, machine guns and revolvers.
The scene is a graphic reminder of the economic and political problems plaguing this country, which until recent years was growing faster than the other nations in Central America.
The economy has been battered by two years of sanctions from the United States, domestic restrictions on bank accounts to prevent runs and governmental corruption. The ousted Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has been accused of stealing hundreds of millions of dollars. Now rashes of looting, street violence and other crimes have left many stores without even their shelves. 
Political leaders of the main parties acknowledge that survival of the fragile new democracy after 22 years under military rule depends on how the economy fares in the coming months.
 
A Service Economy
What makes the process particularly tricky is that unlike other nations in Latin America, Panama's economy is largely based not on goods, but on services. Its financial center, free-trade zone and commerce from re-exporting merchandise represents the largest component of the economy in the country of 2.4 million people.
''There isn't a business that hasn't been touched,'' said Sam Kardonski, whose family owns the Tower International Bank, the Western Insurance Company and also runs the Sanyo Electric Corporation's Latin American operations. ''But even though the economy is down, there is a ray of hope. The tension that had been building up over the past years is broken.''
For its part, the coalition Government is embarking on a mix of policies that is partly Thatcherite privatization and partly Keynesian spending for public projects. At the same time, officials say they intend to ease price controls and ease trade barriers.
''We have a very difficult cash flow situation,'' Finance Minister Mario Galindo said in a recent inteview. ''It is very difficult politically for us. The next few months will be critical.''
 
Taxes: 'Anybody's Guess'
Asked for a projection about how much the Government can expect to receive from 1989 taxes, Mr. Galindo shrugged his shoulders and said, ''It's anybody's guess.''
He said the cash problems had forced the Government to decide to sell the state's main businesses, which include sugar and banana companies, a cement factory and Panamanian Airways. The utilities will remain in state hands.
One critical decision that must be made soon involves what to do with new foreign aid and existing revenues. The choice is a relatively simple one: create public projects to stimulate growth and promote employment, or alleviate the crushing $3.8 billion foreign debt and thus make the country credit-worthy again. Interest payments on the debt were suspended two years ago.
American dollars are used by most Panamanians as standard currency. The official currency, the balboa, is fixed to a gold standard and the Government is unable to print new money. This means that Panama has no inflation problem, but it also means that the only ways of adding to the public coffers are by taxing or borrowing.
 
Chaotic Transition
But credit has been hard to come by. And taxes, originally due on Dec. 31, could not be collected because of the chaotic political transition that followed the American invasion earlier that month. Taxes are now due on Thursday.
In the meantime, the Government payroll is being met with Panamanian money that had been frozen by the United States Government.
''The situation is very touchy,'' said Ruben Carles, the Comptroller General and a former economics professor who has provided a steady diet of disclosures to local reporters about what he says is the corruption under the military. ''We cannot satisfy foreign creditors first, leaving aside work on hospitals and other socially responsible construction.''
To the regret of American officials here, Panamanian leaders have said they are considering spending at least $200 million for building projects, a move aimed at reviving the moribund construction industry. A senior American official said the United States has been pressing for more spending to reduce foreign debt, which represents almost a third of the Government's total debt of $5.98 billion. With a gross domestic product of $1.76 billion, Panama has one of the world's highest ratios of debt to gross domestic product.
 
U.S. Aid Package
The Bush Administration has said it will provide a $1 billion assistance package, consisting of grants and loans to promote economic development and incentives for American investment and trade with Panama. Congress recently approved the first portion of the package, $42 million in emergency aid.
The entire package, about half of what Panama requested, also includes financing for an emergency public works program, new housing to replace that damaged by American troops, money to help Panama reduce its foreign debt and a decree lifting restrictions against American imports of Panamanian sugar.
''We are like a very sick man who needs his medicine desperately,'' Mr. Kardonski said.
A bloated Government payroll employs more than 150,000 people, padded by thousands of jobs created by the Noriega administration that were of no value to the country.
Still, officials say that a serious increase in unemployment, now more than 16 percent, will lead to political insurrection.
 
Fear of Unemployment
''We have to cut public spending, but we don't want to lay off 30,000 workers,'' Mr. Galindo said. Before the crisis, the unemployment rate was just under 12 percent.
Local banks have been facing a liquidity crisis that has been caused by severe restrictions on withdrawals imposed two years ago.
Banking officials say that under the regulations, $1.5 billion, or almost 20 percent, of the assets in bank accounts has been frozen under restrictions that limit the size of withdrawals from time deposits and savings accounts. The restrictions are scheduled to end by June 30, but may end by April if officials can persuade depositors not to take out their money immediately and cause banks to collapse.
Only a dozen banks have closed since the sanctions, leaving the number at 110.
The banking commission is considering setting up a contingency fund and a special discount rate for short-term borrowing in cash-tight situations, but no decisions are expected before the end of this week. Bankers report that while foreign deposits have begun to trickle back in, the refusal by most Latin American nations to recognize the new Government has made lending hard.
 
Establishing a Police Force
American troops have also been helping Panamanians establish a local police force, although many business executives are skeptical.
Looting has left them picking up the losses, since insurance policies have clauses that limit liabilities for acts of war. Without a fully trained local police force, street crime still persists - jails were opened during the invasion and many common criminals remain at large. There is also widespread fear that when the invasion force of American troops leaves the country by the end of February, violence will flare again.
The violence severely damaged businesses in Colon, a city on the Atlantic Ocean side of the Panama Canal that is 50 miles from Panama City and is the heart of the largest free-trade zone in Latin America, re-exporting $4 billion in goods each year. The bulk of these goods are from businesses in the United States, Korea and Japan.
But despite all the hardship, some business leaders are upbeat about the future.
Mr. Galindo, the Finance Minister, said just about the best news he heard recently came from the National Brewery, makers of the beer sold under the label Cerveza Panama.
Reflecting on a conversation with one beer executive who told him that rising consumption of its product means that the company will be paying a record amount in taxes, Mr. Galindo said, ''I suppose the recent events have encouraged beer drinking.''
