HEADLINE: Excerpts from President's News Conference on World Issues

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
 
BUSH: Afternoon. Well, this has been an extraordinary and positive week in East-West relations.
In the Soviet Union, progress was made at the Central Committee plenum on moving the Soviet political system toward pluralism and genuine respect for the views of the Soviet electorate. I commend this development, which demonstrates once again why our Administration has supported Chairman Gorbachev's efforts to extend glasnost and perestroika through the Soviet Union.
Secretary Baker's visit to Moscow made solid progress in pushing the U.S.-Soviet agenda forward in preparation for the June summit here. We made important headway on conventional arms control, Start, nuclear testing and chemical weapons, and continued to explore ways to reduce our differences on regional issues, especially concerning Central America and Afghanistan. 
All in all, Secretary Baker's talks in Moscow accomplished much of what Chairman Gorbachev and I intended when we set the goals for this meeting during our discussions at Malta. I am confident that if we continue this kind of momentum in our bilateral relationship with the Soviet Union, the June summit will be a major success.
And finally I want to congratulate Chancellor Kohl for his successful visit to Moscow. His visit reflects the accelerating pace of German self-determination. And the statements on German unity on the Soviet side -by the Soviet side - were most welcome. And we support Chancellor Kohl's position that a unified Germany should remain a member of NATO.
And let me also express my appreciation of Chairman Gorbachev's statesmanlike view that decisions regarding German unity should be left to the people of Germany.
I made a statement this morning on the wonderful news of the release of Mr. Mandela, so I will leave that to the question period. But, Terry, I understand you have the first question today.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Q. Mr. President, what is your reaction to Mr. Gorbachev's counterproposal for troop cuts in Europe? And in the wake of Secretary Baker's visit to Moscow, what do you think the likelihood is that there'll be three treaties to be signed this year - chemical, strategic and conventional?
 
A. Let me take the last one first. I'm not sure that there will be three treaties to be signed by the time we have this summit, but I think there's going to be progress towards all three. And it's still our goal to get that C.F.E. agreement signed.
On the troops, for Gorbachev in order to have either 195 or 225, we're going to stay with our proposal, because we don't see this, this linkage to that degree. We're talking about the forward deployment there in Europe, the 195,000. And that's what we're challenging him to reduce.
And we've got a big ocean between us and Western Europe, and so the argument that we should always have a linked reduction is one that I want to get away from now. ... Troops for Stabilization
 
Q. With the breakup of the Soviet empire, and you want Germany to remain in NATO, who's the enemy?
 
A. What was that?
 
Q. Who's the enemy? Who are they supposed to be fighting against?
 
A. Who?
 
Q. The NATO troops. The U.S. troops in Germany.
 
A. The U.S. troops are there as a stabilizing factor. Nobody can predict, Helen, with total certainty what tomorrow's going to look like. I've been wrong; you've been wrong; he's been wrong; she's been wrong, on how it's going to go. And we don't know - may I finish please? Our European allies want us there. I have a feeling that some of the Eastern Europeans want us there, because they know that the United States is there as a stabilizing factor. ...
 
Q. I've heard, Mr. President, that there's a wide perception that your whole military budget is out of synch, that you're tone-deaf as to what's been happening. And that there is a possibility of this money going for distressing domestic needs.
 
A. I don't think that perception is widespread with the American people. I think the American people want a cautious approach to this. I don't think any of us think we can see with clairvoyance what's going to happen the day after tomorrow. ... Sanctions on South Africa
 
Q. Mr. President, does the release of Nelson Mandela and the other steps announced by President de Klerk in South Africa alter in any way your views toward the United States economic sanctions, which, of course, the Reagan Administration and you, as a part of it, were never very enthusiastic about?
 
A. What do you mean? In the sense of - alter my views as to what we ought to do in the future?
 
Q. Well, as to whether they work or not.
 
A. Well, I don't know that one can attribute all the change in South Africa to sanctions. Now, we've got some sanctions on there. And by law they remain on until the South Africans have taken certain steps. And I think that, you know, somebody asked me about this yesterday. I said, Well, I can't judge.
Frankly, I think some are counterproductive. I happen to think American jobs there make good sense, and I don't think they perpetuate the status quo. But I think what's really changed is the mind-set of the South African leadership. And I think that we ought to give Mr. de Klerk certain credit for being able to look much more realistically about political change and hopefully more favorably about a society that eventually eliminates this racism that is equated with apartheid. Putting Discussions First ...
 
Q. Mr. Mandela continues to call for armed struggle to overturn apartheid. When he comes to the White House, would you urge him to adopt the nonviolent tactics of Martin Luther King?
 
A. Yes, I would. But I read his statement to be more on the defensive side when I looked at it this morning. Yes, we've always advocated nonviolence. And I think the United States ought not to move away from that. Yes?
 
Q. On the question of the sanctions, are there things that you can do for South Africa's Government apart from lifting sanctions? We realize that by law you can't lift the sanctions unilaterally. Are there other things you can do other than just asking the President to come to Washington?
 
A. Well, I would say out of the meeting with Mr. de Klerk I would have a clearer perception of what other things might be. I think having him here is a major step. ... Reward for de Klerk?
 
Q. Mr. President, there are those who say keeping on with sanctions that now is more of a time than ever to keep all the pressure on and if not - and if not keeping the pressure on, even go one step further. I wonder if you intended your invitation to Mr. de Klerk as a reward for what he's done, given that no South African President has ever been here before. And secondly, do you think it's time, regardless of what you think of sanctions, to reward them in some other way? ...
 
A. Well, I don't know about rewards. I think his coming here evidences the fact that we see in him a new brand of leadership, a man who is making dramatic changes in South Africa. The freeing of Mandela clearly is a very positive sign. And so I think there's more to be done, but there are things that he has done that I think deserve our support and I'd say appreciation. . . . Yeah.
 
Q. Mr. President, on Germany, would you be willing to consider a situation where a united Germany was not necessarily a full member of NATO?
 
A. No, I think that Chancellor Kohl is absolutely correct and we ought to support him. NATO membership. And I think it's stabilizing. I think it's good. There might be some flexibility, obviously, on deployment of NATO forces. But in terms of membership, I think that is the most reassuring and stabilizing concept. I happen to believe that it is most reassuring and stabilizing in terms of how the Eastern Europeans will eventually look at it. Maybe not today -
 
Q. - but you mean the same kind of membership that West Germany now has?
 
A. Sure. Yeah. But as I've said there's some flexibility on deployment of NATO forces into Eastern Europe. Nobody wants to threaten the Soviet Union. . . . The U.S. presence is a stabilizing presence. Yeah, Charlie.
 
Q. Mr. President, on the de Klerk visit that now seems to be almost a fait accompli, are there any conditions on that? ...
 
A. I said I want him to come. You have freed Nelson Mandela. You've taken certain steps that are positive. And we want to see more, want to see you go further. But you're welcome. And that's the way it is.
 
The Recent Trip
Yeah.
 
Q. Mr. President, do you have any second thoughts about the -
 
A. - I tried to identify the lady next to you, but go ahead.
 
Q. Do you have any second thoughts about the trip last week? I'm especially thinking of the war games with the Soviet tanks, particularly when your views on the defense budget are well known and the Central Committee was meeting at the same time.
 
A. No. I think it was a good trip. And I've read some tick-tock inside here, but it doesn't bother me a bit. I think that those people that were there understood that it - that training has applications elsewhere. We've seen recent areas where military force was used because it was well-trained. And so I stand by that as a very good trip. You see, I support our defense budget. . . . I think the American people want to see us stay strong.
 
Q. What signal does that send to Mr. Gorbachev, however, whom you've just praised a few minutes ago?
 
A. Well, it sent a pretty good one, I guess, because we came out of that meeting with some forward motion. And I salute him. . . . If you'd listened to some of the critique from Capitol Hill, you'd have thought it had been a disaster. And yet I've told you we've just completed one of the most successful ministerial summits that we've had with the Soviets. So you can't, the critics up there on the Hill can't have it both ways. Germany and NATO
 
Q. I just wanted to follow up on the Germany question. You said you thought that the Eastern Europeans would ultimately come to see this alliance with NATO as a positive thing, too. Are you suggesting, sir, that there's something less threatening about a Germany that is in alliance - any alliance -rather than a neutral Germany?
 
A. . . . They're good NATO partners now and they'll be good NATO partners then. And they're very closely linked to the United States. And I think that's a very good thing. ...
 
Q. Mr. President, you indicated you don't think that conventional talks are at an impasse. Would you be willing to consider an arrangement, an agreement, in which the U.S. was able to keep extra troops in Europe but at a number somewhat less than the 30,000?
 
A. Well, we've made our proposal. . . . I don't make these proposals without consulting the allies. And there's agreement that these are the proper levels. It's a level that has been scrubbed by our military, and I think there's happiness within our own military about this. For this time in history, I think it's the right level.
And so we're not out there trying to trade that away.
Yeah. Free Markets and Mandela
 
Q. Mr. President, you said - you talk often about the importance of free markets for democracy, but Nelson Mandela supports the A.N.C. view about nationalizing South African industries, including banks and mines. Now how do you feel about that, and does that pose a problem for real democracy in South Africa?
 
A. We are not for nationalizing; we're for privatization across the - and we're for free markets. And so if we have a difference there, that's fine; we'll discuss it with him.
But I'm not about to embrace the idea that what we want to do is go down to more socialism when socialism is folding, folding its hand and going over to the other side all across the world. And you see this.
So this is - this is, you know, a difference that we - if that's his view, why certainly we're not going to embrace that.
 
Q. Is that a severe obstacle, though, to having a successful democracy there? ...
 
A. I don't necessarily associate nationalization, socialization of industry, the goods and services produced belonging to the state. I don't see that as particularly helpful towards democracy, if that's what you mean. . .. What I do agree with Mandela is is to try to get a society that is not a racist society, doesn't support a concept of apartheid. A Role Like Carter's?
 
Q. Mr. President, on South Africa, the question is how far, how willing are you to become personally involved, your Administration become personally involved in facilitating negotiations between Mr. Mandela and President de Klerk? Are you ready to play a role like President Carter did in the Camp David accords?
 
A. If such a role would be productive, I certainly would. But I have the feeling from the talks with both men - just short phone conversations with both Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela - that they feel they can talk to each other without the U.S. catalytic role. But, sure, if we could be helpful in a way of that nature we certainly would. Yeah, Jerry. On Conventional Forces
 
Q. Mr. President, there are some people who are questioning the need for a conventional forces treaty at all at this point. The argument being that we're in a situation in which the East European countries are going to invite all the Soviet troops to go home anyway, and all that we'd be doing is codifying a Soviet presence that isn't even wanted in Eastern Europe. What's your response to that argument?
 
A. I'd say it's very interesting. And it may well be that the pressure on the Soviets will have them withdraw to lower levels. I don't think there's great sentiment in the Warsaw Pact countries for continued Soviet presence. And I'm not sure that it would negate the need to have an agreement. I think the Soviets would like to get our commitment, too.
But, you see, those troops are not wanted in Eastern Europe any more. Our troops are wanted by the free world. And I suspect, I can't prove it, that some countries in the Warsaw Pact countries today would see us not as a threatening presence but as a stabilizing presence.
Yes. ...
 
Q. Mr. President, what was your reaction to the rather effusive embrace of the South African Communist Party and the presence of the Communist Party flag on the balcony when Mr. Mandela made his speech yesterday?
 
A. I didn't notice that. But, you see, I think these Communist Parties for the most part are sliding downhill. And I think what's coming uphill, and triumphantly so, is democracy and freedom.
And I would hope that the steps that Mr. de Klerk is taking and has suggested be taken would enhance the view that democracy and freedom are on the move.
 
Q. A follow-up, sir. If Mr. Mandela persists in allying himself with a Communist party, would that change your view of his -
 
A. Too hypothetical. I mean what's good is that he's out there; he's been in jail a long time. And it's interesting back here, but I'm not embracing every position of the A.N.C. or some of the positions that are represented here today as Mr. Mandela's positions. What I am doing is embracing the concept that it's good that he's out of jail and that it's good that the South Africans seem to be moving towards a more equitable society.
Yeah. The 4 Powers and Germany
 
Q. Do you think it's time for a conference of the four powers on Germany?
 
A. No, not, not at this juncture. I know that idea has some credibility right now, but I think it's moving along pretty well. And we have always favored self-determination. ...
 
Q. If Gorbachev continues to insist on German neutrality, Mr. President, do you think that could create a dangerous impasse that would spawn a neutrality movement in West Germany?
 
A. Not necessarily. But I think that we've seen the Soviet Union position change on the whole concept or the whole acceptability of German reunification. It wasn't so long ago that Mr. Gorbachev and the Soviet system were positioned very skeptically about any reunification.
And that's what was so symbolic about the Kohl-Gorbachev meeting - so, so important about it. And I might say that, that it is a very emotional day for people in Germany, G.D.R. and F.R.G. Highly emotional. Brother separated from brother, cousin from cousin, and all of this now with a chance to have a peaceful reunification. ...
We ought to applaud the fact that the Soviets demonstrated a real flexibility on this question that we didn't think they had a few months ago. Reuniting and the Russians
 
Q. Do you now think that a German reunification is unstoppable, and that Gorbachev will back off his demand?
 
A. Well, I think, again, I'd just refer it to the will of the people there. And it seems to be moving very fast in that direction.
Yes.
 
Q. Mr. President, what is your visceral reaction to the resignation of Ariel Sharon and its affect on the peace process? And is this part of a pattern of the hard-liners losing out around the world?
 
A. You know, I just heard about this. And I have to understand more about what went on there. But Mr. Shamir was the proponent of these talks, and if this clears the way for the talks to go forward, that would be in keeping with U.S. policy. Yes.
 
Q. When you talked with Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela, did you talk about - and you talked about democracy and freedom - did you make the point that in our understanding of democracy the majorities rule?
 
A. We didn't go -
 
Q. - about de Klerk. Or will you talk with him about that when he comes here?
 
A. I'm sure we will, and with Mr. Mandela. But that did not come up in these conversations. ...
 
A. I'll just wait and see what happens when he gets here.
Yes, Sarah. You haven't had one for a long time. The Closing of the Bases
 
Q. Thank you so much. Sir, we have a big problem in this country with the bases that we have to close and the tens of thousands of personnel we have to let go out of the military and out of civilian roles, too. I wonder if you would be for taking these military bases and turning them into prisons rather than building new prisons, and if you'd be for using the extra housing for the homeless?
 
A. Well, Sarah, let me say this, that when military bases close, various communities historically seem to prosper. And I think of one in Waco, Tex., where a base was closed -it was years ago - all kinds of speculation that this would be the end of the world, and then gradually found out that it doesn't work that way.
And so I think there will be socially redeeming uses for these benefits that municipalities and county governments and others may - of these bases that these entities may want to use them for. And so I would say that it's a good question, because we can say to others, This is not the end of the world.
But let me say on base closings, these suggested closings were made without political favor, and I would hope that we could get the Congress convinced that the age-old adage -cut here, cut there, but don't cut in my district - could be laid aside now. And I hope that that's what will prevail.
I said out there in San Francisco that instant doves becomes feathery instant hawks on base closing only if it's in their district. And I want to see that changed. And I've got to convince these folks that we're not doing this some vindictive, political way. We're doing it to try to accommodate to what will be a new kind of defense force in this country.
Carl. Hopes for Summit Talks
 
Q. Mr. President, I wonder if you could clarify your position on your hopes for the June summit. Is it your view that it may be possible there, if not necessarily to sign formal treaties, but to substantially complete the C.F.E. and the Start and even maybe the chemical?
 
A. Chemical. I'd hope we'd be substantially completed. It's a good way to phrase it. Yes sir.
Yeah, Jim.
 
Q. Your Assistant Secretary for Africa seems to suggest that some sort of gestures were now needed toward South Africa. Has there been any discussion of that or have you pretty much ruled it out - any concrete move until the state of emergency is lifted?
 
A. Well, we have certain - we have certain provisions in the law that have to be met. But I would hope people would see the invitation to Mr. de Klerk as a, certainly as a gesture, but one that will have, after the discussions with him, I think, considerably more substance to it.
Owen. Stressing the Alliance
 
Q. Can you support a situation - back to Germany - where there is membership, let's say, political membership in NATO but not a military relationship that exists now with the possibility of no foreign troops on German soil in a unified Germany?
 
A. I don't - I don't think we're contemplating a neutralized Germany. And I instead stated my position in terms of the alliance. And that's the way we view it and I'm sure that's the way our allies look at it.
 
Q. How - could I ask how, since you had mentioned that unification is a matter to be left to the German people. If there were some referendum where they wanted a configuration without foreign troops on German soil, how would you deal with it?
 
A. I would cross that bridge when I came to it. But I would point out that Helmut Kohl, to his credit, is not considering that. Yes.
 
Q. Mr. President, in a different hemisphere, over the past couple of months, when asked why you're going to Cartagena this week, you said you want to show support for the Government down there. Now that you're just a couple of days away, do you expect to do anything more than that, than show the flag? Do you expect anything concrete to come out of it? Perhaps increased use of the military down there?
 
A. Well, I do think that we want to support Mr. Barco, a courageous leader. And I think going there will certainly indicate how strongly I feel about that. But I think there'll be more than that come out of it. I hope we can get agreement in terms of support for the anti-narcotics effort in three countries: Peru, Bolivia and Colombia. What was the last part? U.S. Warships in Drug War
 
Q. Anything in particular like the increased use of the military, the plan that seemed to have been scuttled earlier, to use U.S. warships off the coast of Colombia?
 
A. Well, what happened on that plan was some mischievous stories that suggested blockade. So one of the things I'll try to do -because there was never any intention of a blockade. Absolutely absurd. And yet that threw a panic amongst many of the Colombians who said, 'We don't want a blockade off our coast.' And that wasn't whatever had been intended. But in terms of interdiction, what I'd like to convince them is that we can be extraordinarily helpful, particularly to Colombia, in their courageous fight against narcotraffickers by a sophisticated interdiction effort. ... The Drug War at Home
 
Q. As you head for the drug summit, what would you tell the other leaders about the status of the war on drugs in this country?
 
A. One of the points I'll emphasize at the beginning is, look, I know you three leaders think that this is all the fault - not entirely, but a lot of the fault because of the demand in the United States. And let me assure you we're not just talking about interdiction. We're not just talking about anti-crime aspects of this in the United States. We're talking about major efforts on the demand side, a major initiative.
And it's a lot of it - most of it is out in the private sector, in the schools, to educate people against the use of narcotics. Because they think that it's all - that the United States is causing all this problem.
It's changed a little bit, because some of them are beginning to see user problems inside their own countries, or neighboring countries, or that have crossed the ocean even. So I think we've got to convince them that we are going out on all fronts. And I think I can do that.
 
Q. As a follow-up, sir: They're, from what we've heard, going to ask you for more money for crop substitution, to substitute other goods for the coca crop down there. Will the U.S. put its money where its mouth is on that?
 
A. Well, I will listen to what they have to say on it. . . .
Yes. Soviets in Eastern Europe
 
Q. You, sir, you said that Eastern European countries want the Soviet troops to leave, and you've also pointed to the progress in talks about conventional force reductions. But the fact of the matter is virtually all those Soviet troops are still there now, in Eastern Europe. Can you point to any real progress on the ground in terms of any changes in Soviet troop deployments in Eastern Europe, and to what extent do you see the continued press for reversals politically inside the East bloc that should cause those troops to continue to be deployed -
 
A. - I can't see a political change inside the Eastern European countries that would have an invitation go out to ''Please remain.'' I don't see any politics or any political changes that would make me think that that is a likely scenario right now.
But - and I do think that you put your finger on something. They have not - I don't know - I was looking for Brent to see if any have been pulled back at all.
VOICE IN BACKGROUND. Yes, they have.
 
A. And he says some have. So I'll have to get you the information on exactly what withdrawals have taken place.
 
Q. Mr. President, do you have a date for the summit with Mr. Gorbachev yet?
 
A. To what?
 
Q. Do you have a date?
 
A. I don't think we've set the exact date. The Chinese Students
 
Q. Mr. President, when you won the China veto vote, you said there were signs things were easing up in Beijing. Now they say they want before a citizen can leave the country to study abroad they'll spend five years at work. Isn't it backsliding, or is there some evidence that you have that things are easing up in China?
 
A. Well, I'm disturbed by that statement. I don't like that statement. Because I feel that student exchanges are very good things to have between our countries.
I know that some visas have recently been given to students, so I'd want to check the statement against the reality. I know that some students over there have been issued visas to come to the United States. But I saw the statement, and if you just want me to comment on the statement, I thought that was counterproductive, very much so. Oil Spill and Oil Leases
 
Q. Mr. President, has the current oil spoil on Southern California in any way changed your thinking about the wisdom of further development with offshore oil lease sales? And what is your timetable for when you're going to make the decisions on those lease sales?
 
A. You know, I saw somebody - the freighter, a tanker, had a hole punched in it, and I see a bunch of guys jumping up and down saying this proves you can't have any offshore drilling. I say to myself, I'm not sure I understand the connection between tankers. Do they want to cut off all tankers or do we just want to do our level best to make tankering safer?
I have said that we're not going to have drilling in highly environmentally sensitive places, but I'll be darned if I think we ought to shut down all offshore drilling everywhere. And I don't see that that a spill from a tanker really has much to do with whether you can drill an offshore well safely, because it's going on all the time. And this country depends on it. ...
 
Q. When do you plan to make your decision on those lease sales?
 
A. Fairly soon. I've read the recommendations and the report. It should be fairly soon. Janet. Inviting South Africans
 
Q. Mr. President, did Mr. Mandela and Mr. de Klerk accept your invitation? And if so, when are they coming?
 
A. I felt - I have to go back and look at my notes. But I felt they accepted in principle, both of them. I think Mr. Mandela said he wanted to talk - I thought he said to his executive council or something. But anyway he wanted to talk to some others. It came first, you know, right out of the first few hours. I must say he seemed very pleased at that. And I think Mr. de Klerk the same way. But there isn't, there wasn't, any time set on either of those invitations. Way in the back. The Lance Missile
 
Q. Mr. President, is this the time to re-examine the flexible response doctrines of NATO and particularly the wisdom of continuing work on the Lance missile?
 
A. Well, that decision will not be taken till 1992. That was an agreement between all the NATO partners. And I see nothing to change that at this point.
 
Q.
 
A. ...
 
Q. Mr. President, what role did anti-apartheid demonstrations in this country play in the release of Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners?
 
A. I don't know, because you had anti-apartheid demonstrations in many countries. So I think if people get the feeling in South Africa that apartheid itself is abhorrent to the United States, through whatever way they get that feeling, whether it's a statement by the President, whether it's some legislative action or whether it's some demonstration, that's helpful. But I can't help you on how you would quantify that.
Thank you all. I've got a 2:30 meeting. But thank you very, very much.

HEADLINE: Controlling The Damage;
Regulators Move Fast To Reassure Markets

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The speed with which Federal regulators responded to financial problems at Drexel Burnham Lambert's parent illustrates their awareness of how quickly problems at this particular Wall Street firm could spread through the complex structure of today's financial markets.
The focus of their concern was the ''junk bond'' market, a corner of Wall Street that Drexel invented and still sustains. More politely known as ''high risk, high yield'' securities, junk bonds are the debt of companies considered too young, too small, or too shaky to sell their bonds to traditional lenders.
What Drexel made popular was the notion that, provided the interest rate was high enough, even such speculative offerings could be a sound investment, particularly if investors sought safety in an assortment of such issues. Some borrowers would go broke, the theory conceded, but the extra-high interest paid by those that did not would more than make up the difference. 
 
Widely Held Securities
Drexel's theory - together with the firm's willingness to foster trading and confidence by standing ready to buy or sell such bonds - underlay the growth of a $200 billion market. Junk bonds are now counted among the assets of scores of perfectly conventional pension funds, mutual funds, insurance companies and tottering savings and loan institutions, With signs of trouble at Drexel -still the dominant junk bond firm -regulators clearly wanted to make sure that other firms do not pull back in panic from this already-fragile marketplace.
In the last six months, one company after another has stumbled under the burden of interest payments it took on when it sold junk bonds, with unsettling effects for scores of companies. Those problems, culminating in the unraveling of the Campeau Corporation's vast retailing empire last month, have made potential lenders more wary and potential borrowers more nervous. Their fear has permeated the credit markets.
Beyond the impact on corporate America, as junk bonds drop in value, so does the wealth of those who own them. Scores of institutions and investors could be left less able to weather economic shocks. Last week, for instance, many insurance companies saw their stocks tumble in value because of the market's concern about their holdings of junk bonds. And thrift institutions, themselves no paragon of strength, could be severely hurt if the junk market weakens further.
''Drexel may not be a household word to the average American,'' Gary Schilling, a Wall Street economist, said yesterday, ''but people are aware of the stock market, and they know that the market is built on confidence. God didn't set the price of General Motors stock; that price is set in the marketplace. And if there are problems with Wall Street, people could decide that the price should instantly be $20 cheaper.''
 
Timing Called Unfortunate
''This couldn't have happened at a worse time,'' Mr. Schilling added, ''because we are so dependent on the rest of the world to finance our deficits. So the regulators could see that it is imperative that the rest of the world should continue to have confidence in us and in our markets.''
While the speed of the regulators' reaction illustrates how seriously Drexel's troubles were taken, the nature of that response seemed to show that Washington and Wall Street had learned the lessons of the October 1987 market crash: The Federal Reserve, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange responded in close coordination.
As news spread yesterday of financial troubles at Drexel, officials at the S.E.C., the Fed and the Big Board apparently did not wait to see how the markets would react. The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange was on the phone with reassuring words to the heads of major brokerage firms. The Federal Reserve had similar conversations with top bankers, one top Wall Street executive said last night.
''This was a well-rehearsed contingency plan, far more so than in 1987,'' the executive said. ''They were reaching out to every nook and cranny where an exposure to Drexel's problems might exist.''
There were many such crevices. As rumors of trouble at Drexel swept through the market yesterday, people who were parties to transactions with Drexel became worried about completing those deals. ''Unless the regulators step in,'' another executive explained, ''people move to protect their own interests. What happens is, you have rumors, you have panic, and, by definition, a lot of allegations arise that are not true.''
 
Rumors Compete With News
Yesterday's scene at the stock exchange was a telling example. At the opening bell, traders were passing around an ominous, and inaccurate, rumor that a major brokerage house was going to file for bankruptcy protection. When the report about Drexel's problems moved across the traders' screens, they seemed to find the news less alarming than the rumors, and selling pressure began to ease. But as uncertainty grew about the extent of Drexel's problems, the market closed nearly 30 points lower.
Given the quick response by regulators, it remains to be seen how serious a threat Drexel's problems pose to the markets. A lot depends on whether other firms step in and absorb the leading role that Drexel has played in trading junk bonds. Without that liquidity - the ability of the market to absorb selling without a price collapse - there is really no floor under the value of billions of dollars in speculative bonds.
''It's not a financial panic; it is not a broad market event,'' said another executive, who declined to be named. ''But there are fragilities in the junk bond market.'' Underwriters tend to focus their buying and selling in the issues that they sponsored, and Drexel sponsored more than any other. The key, he said, will be for the regulators to get other firms to broaden their trading beyond the bond issues that they brought to market.

HEADLINE: CUOMO BUDGET GAP SEEN RISING AGAIN

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 12

 BODY:
In a reflection of New York State's declining economy, Cuomo administration officials said today that New York would end the fiscal year short more than $1 billion - $300 million more than they had estimated just last month.
Administration officials said they had revised their forecast on the basis of estimated income-tax payments for the month of January. And they said the latest figures were particularly alarming because they showed that, for the first time since the state's fiscal troubles of the 1970's, estimated tax collections were lower for the year than for the year before.
''It's unprecedented,'' said the state's Budget Director, Dall W. Forsythe. He attributed the sharp decline in income-tax payments to ''very poor conditions'' in the state's securities and real-estate industries. 
 
Other Cuts in Estimates
Today's announcement is in keeping with the stream of bad news that has emerged from the Governor's budget office over the last few months. The budget office has reduced its revenue estimates for the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, at least three times in the last four months. When the gap was first disclosed in November, it was estimated to be at least $250 million.
At the same time that the Cuomo administration cut its revenue estimates for the current fiscal year today, it also revised its estimates for tax collections for next year. Citing the slump in income-tax collections, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said expected state revenues next year would be $250 million lower than he had predicted a month ago, when he presented his budget to the State Legislature.
While direct connections between the state's economy and its tax collections are hard to draw, making the science of forecasting revenues painfully inexact, New York's treasury appears to be suffering from the effects of lower profits on Wall Street and in the real-estate market.
On Wall Street, financial analysts expect year-end bonuses for last year to be the lowest in seven years. And in the real-estate market, home prices in the New York metropolitan area, which peaked in 1988, have since fallen almost 7 percent, while new office construction, which helped fuel New York City's economic boom in the mid-1980's, has dropped off sharply over the last year.
''We are going through a very tough transition from a period of rapid economic growth to a period of slow growth,'' said Mr. Forsythe, the State Budget Director.
 
Back Into Balance
At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Cuomo said legislative leaders had agreed to try to trim next year's proposed $51 billion budget by $250 million to bring the spending plan back into balance. The Governor did not outline specific cuts, saying he would work with legislators to come up with measures they would accept.
To cope with the shortfall for the current fiscal year, now estimated at $1.1 billion, the Governor said today that the state would have to borrow more than $600 million by issuing short-term deficit notes to be repaid within a year.
The rest of the shortfall is supposed to be made up through spending cuts that the Governor ordered in November and through the use of state reserve funds, including the Court Facilities Fund and the Hazardous Waste Fund.
Some financial analysts have questioned the prudence of the Governor's plans and have suggested that the heavy short-term borrowing, which will not have to be paid back until after the November election, is simply a way of putting off the state's financial problems until after the campaign season. Governor Cuomo and all 211 state legislators are up for re-election this fall.
 
'Merely Responses'
Today, analysts said they were concerned that the administration had not developed a lasting solution to the state's recurrent financial problems and was relying too heavily on reserve funds.
''These are not solutions, they are merely responses,'' said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. ''This approach has the potential of seriously stripping the state of all of its reserves.''
Today's announcement came just as state budget negotiations for the coming fiscal year were getting under way, and it seemed likely to delay further the process, which rarely concludes on time, even under the best of circumstances. But after a closed-door meeting this afternoon, both the Governor and legislative leaders insisted that they were committed to putting next year's budget in place by the legal deadline of April 1, which they have missed for each of the last five years.
''We're still committed to that date,'' Governor Cuomo said. Effect on Tax Cut The gloomy announcement also made it appear even more likely that the next phase of the state's income-tax cut, scheduled to go into effect in October, will be suspended as the Governor has proposed. The State Senate's Republican majority has come out against this proposal, as have most business groups in the state. But to put the tax cut into effect as scheduled would cost the state $400 million, a sum that the state appears less and less likely to be in a position to pay.
In a departure from the usual budget-season posturing, the State Senate's Republican majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said today that he would work with the Governor to try to come up with spending cuts in an effort to balance next year's budget. Usually at this time of year members of the Senate's Republican majority accuse the Democratic Governor of inventing fiscal problems to conceal money.
''The Governor's indicating a very dismal picture,'' Mr. Marino said. ''We are working together trying to put together a budget by April 1.''

HEADLINE: Bush Facing Threats Usually Avoided

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
When President Bush flies to Colombia on Thursday for a conference on drug trafficking, overruling objections from almost all his senior aides, he will face dangers that Presidents normally avoid.
But in deciding to go to the one-day meeting, which will be primarily a photo-taking session and is expected to produce few significant agreements, Mr. Bush concluded that his desire to show solidarity with President Virgilio Barco of Colombia outweighed any increased risk he was assuming, the officials said.
''You'd have to say that he's going into a more unstable environment than the President usually goes into,'' a senior Administration official said. ''You have something amounting to armed forces inside Colombia, both the cartels and guerrilla organizations, with immense amounts of money and access to the international arms market.'' 
Officials involved in planning the meeting said they were satisfied that Mr. Bush can be protected against any possible attack by Colombia's drug traffickers during his visit, which will last only about six hours. Mr. Bush will be under tight military and Secret Service guard that will exceed even the usual precautions taken on the President's travels.
 
Little Evidence of a Threat
The officials said the actual threat to Mr. Bush's life is far less than some news accounts have suggested. ''There is little actual evidence that a threat exists,'' the senior official said. ''We're really talking potential threat, rather than indications that the drug cartels plan an attack on the President or something like that.''
But extraordinary precautions are being taken by the Colombian military, Colombian officials said, including fighter escorts for Air Force One, having warships off the Colombian coast and planning against possibilities like an attack by anti-aircraft missiles on the President's plane, which carries electronic devices and other equipment intended to foil such weapons.
The Colombian military is also providing thousands of soldiers for the conference of the Presidents of the United States, Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, which will be held in an old fort on a secluded peninsula near the city of Cartagena.
Before Mr. Bush made his final decision to attend the conference, a choice that graphically illustrates Mr. Bush's insistence on handling diplomacy himself, most of his senior advisers cautioned against going, officials said.
 
Opposition by Advisers Wanes
Since then, the opposition has abated in the Administration, the senior official said, but the White House has confronted nearly unanimous opposition outside of Washington.
''I haven't talked to anybody who thinks the President ought to go,'' the official said. ''I mean out around, people come up and say, 'Why are you going?' ''
Mr. Bush's plan to attend the drug conference has bipartisan support in Congress. Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, the senior Republican on the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations of the Committeee on Governmental Affairs, said he hoped it would prove ''that we and our Andean allies are beyond the unproductive, finger-pointing stage of recent years.''
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said, ''I think that it goes a long way in trying to repair the damage of a faulty foreign policy.''
In Cartagena, the four leaders are to issue a joint communique that will outline some new measures to combat cocaine production and export.
Judging from the draft of the joint statement, the conference will reflect some deep differences between the United States and the other nations.
The communique will include promises of increased American economic aid and more activity by Federal drug agents in stopping the flow of chemicals used to process cocaine and in tracing shipments of automatic weapons to South America. But the Andean leaders are likely to seek more economic aid than the United States is willing to provide.

(Reuters)

HEADLINE: 42 Poorest Lands, Fearing Loss In Leverage, Plan Drive for Help

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, Feb. 11

 BODY:
In an atmosphere of gloom and foreboding, representatives of the world's 42 poorest nations met here this weekend to devise new ways to convince richer countries that nearly half a billion people need help desperately.
The sense of urgency is heightened by the fear that the lessening of East-West tensions will reduce the leverage that poor countries can exercise on the superpowers.
In these nations, which the United Nations lists officially as Least Developed Countries, the 1980's have brought more degrading poverty, declining literacy, worsening health and generally lower living standards - all made worse by large population increases, fragile environments, vulnerability to natural disasters and, often, limited civil rights or outright repression.
''In a world of plenty they remain poor,'' said President H. M. Ershad of Bangladesh in his opening speech Saturday. ''In a world of movement, their lives are static. In a world full of hope, they are fated to despair.'' 
 
A Category of Their Own
Nine of the poorest countries are in Asia, 28 are in Africa, 1, Haiti, is in the Americas, and 4 are island nations in the Pacific or Indian Oceans. Bangladesh, with about 110 million people, 85 percent of them living below minimal nutritional levels, is the largest in population. It acts as spokesman for the group.
This first ministerial meeting of least developed countries, which ends on Monday, is expected to restate forcefully a plea that aid donors and international lending organizations treat the poorest nations separately from the rest of the developing world. The poorest countries have effectively fallen into a category of their own.
''The L.D.C.'s, being the poorest and weakest in the international community, deserve first consideration,'' Anwarul Karim Chowdhury, head of the economic section of Bangladesh's Foreign Ministry and organizer of the conference, said in an interview Friday. ''We have done all we can, but the people living in absolute poverty have increased. The effects of our belt-tightening, our structural adjustments, are falling worst on the most vulnerable groups, particularly women and children.''
The group of 42 will meet with donor nations in Geneva at the end of March in preparation for a larger international conference in Paris in September on the plight of the most disadvantaged countries. A similar conference took place in 1981, when there were 31 such nations.
 
No Goals Are Met
None of the major development goals set at that conference have been met.
In the world's poorest nations, there is now additional apprehension that aid, already dwindling, may all but dry up as Europe, the United States, Canada and Japan respond to the unexpected opening of Eastern Europe, where investment returns are likely to be quicker.
''The world is a safer place to live,'' Mr. Chowdhury said. ''But we feel concerned about the rush to Eastern Europe when the overall resource kitty is limited.''
''Now that the East and West have patched up, everyone suffers in the L.D.C.s,'' he added, explaining that with the big power blocs no longer needing to compete for advantage in the third world, a source of leverage was lost.
According to statistics compiled by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, average annual per capita income in the 42 countries, about $200, is only a quarter of that in the developing world as a whole.
Mr. Chowdhury said the eradication of poverty and the improvement of women's - and thereby children's -lives would be given high priority in meetings this year.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
U.S. and Soviets Confident as Trade Talks Open

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union opened talks today on ending nearly a half-century of trade restrictions. Both sides expressed confidence that an accord could be ready for signature when President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Washington in June.
Among other things, an agreement would help the Soviet Union by cutting the unusually high duties that the United States levies on imports from the Soviet Union. 
Mr. Gorbachev is under increasing domestic pressure to show economic improvements. Mr. Bush's decision to seek a trade agreement, which was announced at the summit meeting in Malta in December, is a sign of American support for Mr. Gorbachev's economic and political reforms.
''We got off to a good, fast start,'' said a senior official at the Office of the United States Trade Representative, speaking at the end of the first day of negotiations.
The United States team is being led by the Trade Representative, Carla A. Hills, and the Deputy Trade Representative, Julius L. Katz, and includes officials from several other departments, including State, Treasury, Commerce and Labor.
Asked whether he was optimistic, Yuri N. Chumakov, the Deputy Soviet Trade Minister who heads the Soviet team, said: ''It's not a question of optimism. We are soldiers in this case.'' He was referring to the Malta directive that an agreement be reached by June. He added that his team was ''not pessimistic.''
Reflecting more open Soviet emigration policies, Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev at Malta that he would work toward granting ''most favored nation'' tariff status to Moscow as part of a trade accord. The United States is also seeking some concessions from the Soviet Union, especially assurances of greater access to its markets, for example, for machinery and other heavy equipment, where the American share has been running at under 5 percent.
As Mr. Chumakov put it tonight, the agreement could be ''a very big support for exports of U.S. goods in the Soviet market.''
Economists here say American consumers could see prices for products like Soviet vodka drop by as much as $1.25 a bottle. Prices could also be lower for luxury imports like furs and caviar.
Soviet exports to the United States are chiefly petroleum products, inorganic chemical elements and minerals, and nonferrous waste and scrap metals, as well as vodka and furs.
Given the intense competition from Japanese, South Korean and Western European exporters, it is unlikely the Soviet Union will sell more consumer goods in the American market, at least over the short term.
The principal American export to the Soviet Union is food. Over the first 11 months of last year the United States exported $3.82 billion to the Soviet Union, with most of this grain. Imports totaled $658 million.
Some American officials say they think the easing of trade restrictions over the next three to four years could lead to two-way trade in the range of $10 billion to $12 billion.
Both American and Soviet officials indicated that the issue that will probably give them the most trouble will be the duration of the agreement.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); MALTA (90%); EUROPE (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (73%); 

CITY: MOSCOW, RUSSIAN FEDERATION (73%);

HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA;
Black South Africans in New York Area Are Upbeat but Cautious

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Black South Africans in the New York area said in interviews yesterday that the release of Nelson Mandela improved the prospects for negotiations between the Pretoria Government and South Africans opposing apartheid.
Some of the South Africans, scholars, students and participants in anti-apartheid organizations, said they interpreted the release as an acknowledgment by the Government of the strength and pivotal role of the African National Congress, the leading anti-apartheid organization, which was granted legal status on Feb. 2.
Some also said that Mr. Mandela's return to the political scene would increase cohesiveness within the anti-apartheid movement. And many routinely referred to what they viewed as continuing evils and rigidity in the South African Government's policies and laws. 
''The release of Mandela has removed a major roadblock toward a negotiated settlement'' said Bernard Magubane, a professor of anthropology at the University of Connecticut at Storrs.
 
Group Called Unconquerable
Professor Magubane, whose books include ''The Political Economy of Race and Class in South Africa,'' said Mr. Mandela's release showed that the South African Government had recognized the durability of the African National Congress, to which both he and Mr. Mandela belong.
''For almost 40 years the party that rules South Africa has used the resources of the white-minority state for the destruction of the A.N.C. and the demonizing of its leadership, including Mandela, who for almost 27 years was a non-person whose picture couldn't be shown in any of the South African newspapers, nor his words be quoted,'' Professor Magubane said. ''Suddenly, we have this regime not only unbanning the A.N.C., but also devoting a whole day to observe the release of Mandela on its TV network,'' he said. ''What this suggests to me is that there has been a realization in the regime that the A.N.C. and the ideals of political force for which it was formed are unconquerable.''
 
Release Is 'Not Enough'
Seloka Phirwa, a member of the staff at the African National Congress's observer mission to the United Nations, said the release of Mr. Mandela ''is an indication that the regime may be getting serious about negotiations at long last.''
But he noted that various conditions set by opponents of apartheid for negotiations with the Government remain unfulfilled. Letting Mr. Mandela go, he said, ''has been a bold step, but it's not enough.''
Peter Molotsi, who teaches history and African studies at Rutgers University and is a member of another anti-apartheid group, the Pan-Africanist Congress, said Mr. Mandela's release ''raises hope for better things to come regarding the interests of African people'' in South Africa.
''I do believe and hope that his release is setting a new stage for the struggle of the African people in the country,'' he said.
But Dr. Molotsi emphasized that ''we demand the release of all other political prisoners.'' And he said the congress ''still stands unwaveringly committed to a unitary South Africa based on one person, one vote,'' and insists ''that the land ultimately return to the African people.''
That means, he said, that ''the indigenous people'' become the owners of all the land in South Africa.
 
Continued Sanctions Backed
The current labor secretary of the Pan-Africanist Congress, Lesoana S. Makhanda, said Mr. Mandela was being released ''merely into a larger jail, which is the rest of South Africa.''
Mr. Makhanda, who was in Manhattan yesterday, said Mr. Mandela took positions, in his first public pronouncements after being released, that dovetailed with important Pan Africanist Congress positions.
Mr. Makhanda said ''we are quite happy'' that Mr. Mandela affirmed that economic sanctions against the South African Government should remain in place and that, as Mr. Makhanda put it, ''there is not a necessity for armed struggle to be discarded.''
A student leader, Thoahlane Thoahlane, said, ''I see the release of Mandela as a symbol of unity amongst different groups within the country.'' Mr. Thoahlane, president of the New York chapter of the South African Azanian Student Movement in North America, called the return of Mr. Mandela ''a uniting factor among people who oppose the apartheid system.''
 
Mandela the Symbol
Jerry Mofokeng, an actor and a theatrical director, said he thought Mr. Mandela's re-emergence would give the anti-apartheid movement new cohesiveness and strength. He said Mr. Mandela ''in a sense personifies the hope for freedom not only for blacks but for the entire nation.''
Mr. Mofokeng said Mr. Mandela's first declarations after leaving confinement were tantamount to saying to the Government, ''Hey guys, listen, I have the same demands as I had when you put me in here. They are just the same. I am even saying we must be more intense than we were.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Empathy's Drawback: No Room To Disagree

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Question: How do you tell the difference between President Bush and the Democrats in Congress? Answer: That is just what the Democrats would like to figure out.
The Democrats are becoming increasingly aggravated by their inability to draw distinctions between themselves and Mr. Bush. Part of the reason for this is that the Democrats can't agree on who they are. But equally important is that even when they do take a firm stand on something, Mr. Bush usually closes right in to say he shares their concerns. 
Mr. Bush has proven to be quite effective at the politics of empathy. Education. The Environment. Civil Rights. Child Care. These are all issues of potential weakness for a Republican President. They are also issues on which Mr. Bush has expressed his concern.
The next step for the Democrats is to say concern is not enough; we need action. Mr. Bush is ready there, too. The week after he said that bigotry must end, the Democrats (joined by a few Republicans) introduced legislation to shore up civil rights laws that had been curtailed by the Supreme Court.
The Administration had said no legislation was needed. Within hours after the bill was introduced, the Justice Department reversed the stand. The Administration would support legislation, although not as sweeping as the Democrats' bill.
A central goal of Mr. Bush's domestic agenda seems to be to prevent substantial political space from opening up between him and the Democrats. It is the exact opposite of the Reagan approach.
Where President Reagan resisted civil rights measures, Mr. Bush says he is for them. Where Mr. Reagan proclaimed his opposition to abortion, Mr. Bush talks about how the big tent of the Republican Party can shelter various views.
The Democrats have been searching for new issues to define themselves. They planned to make ''economic competitiveness'' a watchword. But before the ink was dry on their speeches, the President was visiting high-tech laboratories.
The Democrats protest that the details are crucial and that Mr. Bush's rhetoric does not match reality. You can't be an education president and call for only a 2 percent increase in education spending, Speaker Tom Foley declared after Mr. Bush's State of the Union Message.
But from a distance, which is how most Americans view politics, it looks like all those Washington insiders are just haggling over the fine points, with Democrats wanting to spend more, and everyone remembers Mr. Bush's warning to Congress that voters did not ''send us here to bicker.''
In fact, the Democrats would be doing well were the public even to notice that they are bickering with the President. When Republicans organized two focus groups in Chicago to gather impressions of the President and his Message, not one of the 24 people knew that the Democrats had responded to the address. Nor did anyone know who Tom Foley is.
In the short run, Mr. Bush's approach has helped to keep his popularity at the ionospheric levels he achieved at the end of his first year. But more than that: He and his strategists are beginning to think like leaders of a majority party, and are trying to assemble the broad and disparate coalitions that used to be both bane and benefit of the Democratic Party.
The difficulties were apparent the other day when Mr. Bush gave a speech about global warming, although he never used the phrase. Writing the speech was a struggle, as the White House sought to demonstrate concern without frightening manufacturers and utilities with plans to require costly controls.
Inside Washington there was great fascination with the internal Administration feuds over this speech. But outside, all that people know is Mr. Bush wants to help. ''So he wants to plant a billion trees,'' said Tony Podesta, a Democratic political consultant, capsulizing the Democrats' frustration. ''The Democrats are left with: 'Should we try to plant a billion and a half?' ''
Mr. Podesta also described both the frustration and grudging admiration Democrats have these days for the strategists of the Bush Administration: ''I think they're really underestimated. They have a bumbling schedule and a clumsy attitude toward intra-party politics. There's no soaring rhetoric. But they've tended to occupy two-thirds of the political space. If you continue to blunt whatever argument your opponent can offer against you, you create a situation in which it becomes impossible to attack you.''

HEADLINE: Coal Accord in Doubt as Fines Stand

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
A judge in Virginia refused last night to suspend $64 million in strike fines levied against the United Mine Workers of America, raising doubts that the long, costly and sometime violent walkout against the Pittston Coal Company would end soon.
The union has said that until the fines are lifted it will not ask its membership to vote on a tentative contract agreement reached with Pittston during round-the-clock negotiating sessions Dec. 31.
But the union's general counsel, Robert Stropp, said in Lebanon, Va., that union leaders would reassess that decision, The Associated Press reported.
 
Community Service Proposed
Contending that the fines, many for strike-related violence, are unfair and the most onerous ever set in a labor dispute, the union has proposed that in place of monetary punishment its members do 10,000 hours of community service. It also promised that it would adhere to strike laws in the future. The union was accused of scores of violations of specific court orders during the strike, with many violations involving unruly picketing. 
Pittston joined the union in court yesterday, reversing its earlier hard line against strikers and arguing that suspension of the fines was justified because of the labor peace that would follow. Some coal industry officials said Pittston was reacting not only to economic pressure but to the union's promise to obey strike laws.
But the judge, Donald McGlothlin Jr. of Russell County Circuit Court in Lebanon, Va., was unmoved by the union and company arguments, saying they were ''an affront'' to justice and would set a bad precedent for breaking the law in future labor disputes. The company's decision to reverse its stance on union lawbreaking was ''incredible irony,'' he added.
Judge McGlothlin gave both parties 10 days to return to his court with new arguments on whether he should cancel the fines.
 
Dispute Over Work Rules
The strike by 1,700 miners, now in its 10th month, is mainly a dispute over work rules and health benefits. It is the most serious labor dispute in the coal industry in a decade.
Other conditions that the union and company negotiators said had to be met before a ratification vote have largely been satisfied in recent weeks.
Judge McGlothin's decision yesterday followed an agreement Friday by the National Labor Relations Board to set aside all charges before it resulting from the strike, both union and company actions. It was the board that first extracted the union's pledge to adhere to strike laws in the future.
The union has said ratification of the proposed new contract, which includes special arrangements for administering health and retirement funds, also will not take place until trustees of those funds approve the proposed changes. Union officials said tonight that they considered such approval all but certain, and they suggested that the ratification process would begin in a matter of hours should the fines be suspended.
 
Health Benefits Are Focus
No details of the tentative agreement have been released, but both sides have agreed from the outset that the strike has national implications.
The main sticking point has been health benefits, with the union arguing that they are inviolate in an industry with numerous health hazards, and the company arguing that the benefits have become so expensive that it is having trouble remaining competetive.
Pittston is Virginia's largest coal producer. Its last economic report indicated the strike had cut its production by a third or more and cost it more than $27 million in lost sales and other expenses.
The mine workers union, which has about 65,000 active members around the country, began the walkout with a strike fund of almost $100 million. The 1,700 strikers have been getting $220 a week in strike benefits, slightly more than a third of their usual salary.
Industry officials estimate the strike has cost the miners a total of $65 million in lost wages and benefits. Merchants and other business people in southwest Virginia also report significant losses because of the strike.
Only about a third of the nation's coal is now mined by union labor, compared with more than 90 percent in the 1950's. Automation has eliminated almost half a million mining jobs and, at the same time, increased mine production.
But union labor is still important in the coal fields because labor unrest means instability in an industry that is increasingly competitive both at home and abroad.

HEADLINE: Jewish Group Faces Reorganization

BYLINE: By ARI GOLDMAN

 BODY:
The American Jewish Committee, widely regarded as the dean of Jewish organizations in the United States, plans a major restructuring that it hopes will give the group a sharper focus and reduce its costs.
About 40 of the group's 275 employees will be laid off and $1 million will be cut from its $16 million annual budget, Sholom D. Comay, president of the committee, said last week.
Mr. Comay confirmed the extent of the cuts after they were reported in the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, a Manhattan-based news agency.
The American Jewish Committee, a civil rights group with offices in 31 cities around the country, is involved with a wide range of activities in areas like education, public policy, Israel and interfaith relations. It will receive a ''top-to-bottom review,'' Mr. Comay said, to determine what areas should be cut or streamlined. 
 
Consensus at Board Meeting
Mr. Comay, a lawyer and corporate executive from Pittsburgh, said he received a mandate to proceed with the reorganization from the committee's board, which met this month in St. Petersburg, Fla.
There was a consensus at the meeting that the committee had branched off into too many areas and needed to focus its work under the broad cateogory of ''intergroup relations.'' As a result, he said, emphasis would now be placed on eliminating bigotry, working for peace in the Middle East, strengthening the Jewish family and enhancing the relationship between the United States and Israel.
Committee officials said there was a consensus to eliminate the organization's activities in Western Europe and South America. In addition, the international relations offices in New York and Washington will be merged into one office in Washington.
The elimination of the committee's liberal magazine, Present Tense, was made public last week. Its conservative journal, Commentary, will continue to publish.
 
An Economic Decision
Mr. Comay said the decision to stop publishing one magazine and keep the other represented an economic judgment, not an ideological one. He said Commentary was able to raise private money to keep it afloat, while Present Tense was not.
The American Jewish Committee was founded in 1906 by a number of prominent Jews, including Jacob Schiff, Mayer Sulzberger, Louis Marshall, Oscar Straus and Cyrus Adler. Prompted by a wave of pogroms against Jews in Russia, the members, mainly of German descent, formed the organization ''to prevent the infraction of the civil and religious rights of Jews in any part of the world.''
At the outbreak of World War I the committee helped organize the American Jewish Relief Committee, a central relief fund for war victims. With the rise of Hitler in Germany and the outbreak of World War II, the group worked to press the Roosevelt Administration, the Vatican and the League of Nations to save Jewish lives. When it found that its efforts had largely been in vain, the committee again turned to the massive job of refugee relief.
While its early attitude toward Zionism was sometimes ambivalent, the committee became an enthusiastic supporter after Israel declared its independence in 1948.
Over the years the committee has investigated and battled anti-Semitic groups in the United States, disclosing the work of hate groups and Nazi sympathizers. And it has taken a leading role in the struggle for equal rights for blacks in the United States.
 
External Challenges Cited
In recent years the committee has suffered from staff instability; it has changed executive vice presidents five times in the last decade.
Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, the author of ''The Jews in America'' and a columnist for Present Tense, said the committee has been challenged externally by more aggressive groups.
''The committee has been outflanked on the anti-Semitism issue by the A.D.L. and the Wiesenthal Center, which have more rock-'em, sock-'em styles,'' Rabbi Hertzberg said, referring to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and the California-based Simon Wiesenthal Center.
He also noted that another organization, the American Jewish Congress, has attracted many liberals with its willingness to criticize hard-line positions of the Israeli Government under Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.
The committee, Rabbi Hertzberg said, has been left with an identity crisis. ''It is left asking itself, 'What is our mission?' ''

CORRECTION-DATE: March 15, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 13 about reorganization plans by the American Jewish Committee referred incompletely to its intentions for a role in Western Europe and South America. The human rights group has since said that while ending its formal staff structure along geographic boundaries, it will continue to pursue issues of concern to the Jewish community wherever they arise.

HEADLINE: Smoking Limits Gain in Virginia

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Feb. 12

 BODY:
A bill to limit smoking in this tobacco state won preliminary approval today in the House of Delegates, over the objections of health lobbyists and legislators who had backed a bill calling for stricter regulation.
The bill would require establishment of no-smoking areas in state and local government buildings. It would allow local governments to impose stricter rules against smoking, but would limit local efforts to ban smoking in small businesses, in theaters and on public transportation.
The measure passed in a voice vote and was due for a final House vote Tuesday. If approved, the bill will have to be reconciled with more stringent legislation recently approved by the Senate.
Some legislators worried about the reaction to the bill in a state whose economy was built on tobacco.
''Seldom in my career have I built my own political gallows and provided the rope,'' said Delegate Charles R. Hawkins, a Republican from tobacco-growing Pittsylvania County. ''If I vote for this, I might be doing that.''
It would allow local governments to demand no-smoking areas in restaurants and would ban smoking in elevators, schools, indoor service lines and school buses.
But the measure would prohibit local ordinances from regulating smoking in businesses with less than 10,000 square feet of floor space or in privately owned meeting rooms, in theaters or on public transportation. The bill does not address smoking in private work areas.
The rejected rival bill, similar to that already approved by the Senate, would have allowed workers to declare their areas smoke-free by a two-thirds vote.

HEADLINE: Sunrise in South Africa

 BODY:
The jail that opened Sunday for Nelson Mandela began to free a nation even as it freed a man. After 27 years, and with the whole world watching, South Africa saw a half-mythical prisoner recalled to political life. Mr. Mandela rose impressively to a remarkable occasion. Calmly and without bitterness, he displayed the measured dignity the old Romans described as gravitas. 
Mr. Mandela praised his radical followers for their steadfastness, but reminded them that democratic principles had to be respected. He excoriated the hateful system of apartheid, but praised President F. W. de Klerk as a man of integrity. He defended the ''armed struggle'' but hoped that a new climate would soon end the need for a ''defensive'' response to racial repression.
And while urging the West not to lift economic sanctions until apartheid is finally buried, he called for open negotiations to shape a new South Africa rooted in universal suffrage.
That won't happen quickly, or easily. But a corner was turned when South African television dared show the outlawed flag of the African National Congress as Mr. Mandela walked free through the vineyards of Cape Town. ''The sun is not just for the growing of grapes,'' a commentator said. ''The sun is shining on South Africa.''
By heeding those too long denied a place in the sun, Americans can help speed the transition. Global sanctions have plainly helped pry open prison doors, hasten the legalization of the African National Congress and other proscribed groups and bring about a partial end to the emergency. These steps are a vindication of sanctions, not an argument for repealing them.
President Bush has taken the right first step by inviting both Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela to Washington. For the moment, as Mr. Bush suggested yesterday, that seems ample reward for Mr. de Klerk's courage. Meantime, however, Congress needs soon to review its conditions for ending sanctions against South Africa. It may make sense to ease some penalties as Pretoria moves forward, thereby providing incentives for further change while keeping the legislation in force.
Under the 1986 sanctions law, the President can waive or modify sanctions if Pretoria frees all political prisoners and meets three of four remaining conditions. Mr. Mandela has been freed, but other political prisoners languish in jail. And only one of the other four stipulations - legalizing opposition political groups - has been met. The other three require Pretoria to end emergency rule, to repeal the laws imposing racial segregation and to begin good-faith negotiations between dominant whites and the huge black majority.
What those talks can achieve is far from clear. President de Klerk has repeatedly declared that any new constitution must provide guarantees against the domination of any group by another. For his part, Mr. Mandela offers this definition of his goals: ''Universal suffrage on a common voters roll in a united democratic and non-racial South Africa.'' Finding ways to mesh these principles, possibly in a federal system incorporating a bill of rights, won't be easy. But it's not impossible.
In any case, the first perilous steps have been taken on freedom's road. Enlightened South Africans are at last talking rather than shouting across racial barricades. Leaders are breaking the chains of dogma. In Cape Town as elsewhere in these amazing times, the unthinkable has become imaginable, and a struggle for human rights begun by nameless ordinary people has found champions in leaders like Mikhail Gorbachev, Lech Walesa, Vaclev Havel, F. W. de Klerk and, now, Nelson Mandela.

HEADLINE: Intellectuals May Have Changed, but They Haven't Faded Away

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Intellectual Issue for the 1990's Is Why America's Intellectuals Have Faded Away'' (Week in Review, Jan. 28) is actually a nonissue, as well as a case of nostalgic sour grapes. There are today more ''public intellectuals'' than ever, whether they are writing for Op-Ed pages and national magazines, are interviewed on national television or are working as consultants for government or private industry. 
What has faded away is a mono-poly, once held by a small group of famous essayists, literary critics and novelists doubling as social commentators, such as Edmund Wilson or Norman Mailer. Instead, public intellectuals are now increasingly recruited from among experts, in a variety of fields, who can also think broadly and express their ideas in plain English.
For better or for worse, economist-intellectuals get a large share of the limelight these days, for example, Milton Friedman and Kenneth Galbraith, or George Gilder and Robert Reich from a younger generation, but then their knowledge seems to be needed more than general intellectual insight in a public life that is marked by recurring economic problems.
 
HERBERT J. GANS
