HEADLINE: New Jersey Turnpike Plan Dwindles Despite $2 Billion in Debt

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Five years ago the New Jersey Turnpike Authority issued $2 billion in bonds to finance the widening of 35 miles of the state's most important road. Today much of the project has been abandoned, none of it is complete, and the authority is seeking large toll increases to pay the cost of the borrowed money it is still deciding how to spend.
Critics say the turnpike project is the tale of an independent authority swerving out of control: an agency that can borrow, spend, and make major policy decisions without close scrutiny by the state and without answering to the public.
The critics, who include regional planners and aides to former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, say the idea for the bond issue was quickly concocted by a turnpike chairman who wanted to run for governor and by Wall Street bankers who made tens of millions.
The authority consulted neither transportation nor environmental agencies as it designed the plan, which would have had a major effect on roads, mass transit and the environment in the nation's most densely populated state.
 
'Nobody Looked Closely'
Some of the state's experts who reviewed the turnpike plan say that when the authority borrowed the money, it had no clear idea of how long the project would take, how much it would cost or its effect on traffic and the environment. 
And the authority informed Governor Kean of the $2 billion bond issue only days before it was offered for sale.
''I see the turnpike as a classic case of an authority run wild,'' said Barbara L. Lawrence, a spokeswoman for the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit agency concerned with the metropolitan region. ''This independent authority has driven public policy in New Jersey. Nobody looked closely at the plan because it was presented to all of us as a fait accompli.''
The authority's executives say they have been unfairly criticized by state officials who are jealous of their independence. They have run the turnpike well for four decades, they say, and their decisions have been based on the best interests of the public.
The former chairman who started the widening plan, Joseph (Bo) Sullivan, said that the decision to borrow $2 billion had saved the public millions of dollars.
The bonds cost the public nothing in interest payments over the last five years, Mr. Sullivan said, and in the coming years the payments are likely to remain well below current market rates. ''The purpose of an independent authority is to work on its own to get the job done,'' Mr. Sullivan said. ''Doing great public works is always complicated. It didn't deter Robert Moses.'' Building Quickly, Planning Secretly Much like the public authorities headed by Mr. Moses, who designed much of the transportation system around New York City, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority was established as an independent entity in 1948, to build a 118-mile ''superhighway'' between Philadelphia and New York.
The roadway was completed in 23 months, an accomplishment its executives attributed to their independent role under the law. The authority is governed by a board of unpaid commissioners whose decisions can be vetoed by the governor, but the authority can borrow money, hire staff, and award contracts free of direct supervision by other state agencies or the Legislature.
The busiest toll road in the nation, the turnpike is now traveled by more than 600,000 vehicles a day. By 1984, the authority's staff was reporting increasing congestion, as the state's economy boomed and workers sought to get to and from hundreds of thousands of new jobs in northern New Jersey.
In 1985, Mr. Sullivan, the chairman, along with the authority staff, settled on a grand plan to ease the congestion, the largest construction project since the turnpike had been built.
On May 10 he announced that the turnpike would add one lane in each direction from New Brunswick to Newark and six lanes along the western spur. He also proposed a redesigned interchange at exit 16W, near the Meadowlands Sports Complex.
Public agencies usually finance such projects by borrowing in stages as costs are incurred. But the authority decided to borrow all it needed at one time.
Mr. Sullivan, in an interview last week, recalled that the investment banking firm of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company had advised the authority that if it borrowed the money in 1985, before the Tax Reform Act of 1986 went into effect, it could invest the money at a higher rate of return than it would pay in debt service. In effect, the bonds would pay for themselves until construction began.
The authority and its financial advisors put together the project and bond issue in the following months, largely without consulting the state's fiscal, transportation or environmental agencies, former Kean officials say.
''The turnpike put this together without talking to anybody,'' one former commissioner said. ''If they had started incrementally, scoped out everything, they would not have been able to say in good faith they could complete this in five years.'' Telling the Governor He Had No Choice Former top aides to Governor Kean say they and the Governor were stunned when Mr. Sullivan presented the finished bond offering to Mr. Kean, giving him less than two weeks to review and approve the plan.
One former aide recalls that Mr. Sullivan told Mr. Kean that if he did not agree to the bond offering, the state would lose hundreds of millions of dollars. In an interview, Mr. Kean, who left office last month, said he had felt compelled to approve the plan.
''My question was, why can't we take a step back, take our time, do it in a different way?'' Mr. Kean said. ''They said it is so far along, it would jeopardize our financial reputation in New York.''
A memo to the Commissioner of Transportation, Roger Bodman, from Deputy Commissioner Michael F. Barrett, on March 18, 1986, concluded that the turnpike's traffic projections were overstated because the roads leading to the turnpike could not handle so many vehicles. The memo seemed to suggest that the authority had considered its highway in relative isolation.
The Transportation Department staff also said that by committing so much money to the widening, the the authority was depriving other worthy projects of funds.
Further, the department found that the authority had not comprehended the vast environmental problems of adding to the highway over the meadowlands. In many ways, it seemed to Kean aides, the authority had planned the project as if it were still the 1940's, before a vast web of environmental regulations had come into being.
''The extent of widening proposed by the Turnpike Authority appears excessive,'' Mr. Bodman wrote in a confidential memo to Governor Kean dated April 1. ''The authority's publicized schedule for advancing its plans to construction appears to be unrealistic.''
Despite criticism, the authority continued to embrace a major widening until last spring, when a study by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit rating firm, found that the expansion would cost $1 billion more than planned. Mr. Sullivan, who had left the agency in 1988 to explore a race for governor, blamed the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, the Army Corps of Engineers and other agencies for dragging out the project, ''The Corps of Engineers changed the rules on us tremendously,'' Mr. Sullivan said. ''We had no way of anticipating the environmental costs of the project.'' Project Is Scaled Back, But Not the Bond Issue Faced with the prospect of cleaning up dozens of landfills and toxic-waste sites, the authority's new chairman, Frank A. Loveys, said the authority would scale back the project and abandon the most environmentally difficult construction in the meadowlands.
The new plan called for adding six lanes to the highway between exits 8A and 9 below New Brunswick and one lane each way from exits 11 to 15E. The plan, which includes improvements, is expected to cost between $1 billion and $1.2 billion.
Mr. Loveys said that a toll rise was necessary to begin paying off the interest on the bonds, which will begin to cost the Authority more than $100 million a year begining next November.
A provision in the bond issue permits the authority to return the unused portion of the $2 billion to bondholders later this year. But he described such a choice as unwise, saying that the funds are now borrowed at a rate of 7.2 percent, far lower than the state could expect to receive if it floats new bonds in the future.
A meeting is scheduled for tonight at 7 in Mount Laurel on a proposal to raise tolls as much as 135 percent over the next few years.
The new Governor, Jim Florio, has been highly critical of the independence of state authorities and the proposed toll increase. But he has not said whether he will approve the toll increase or the authority's plans to use the remaining funds.
Rather than retire bonds and return the unused portion of the funds, the authority told Governor Kean that it was willing to use the money to contribute to other projects, including mass transit. But again, critics say, the authority chose to make transportation policy decisions independently, often disregarding the opinions of outside experts and other agencies. Going Its Own Way On Hudson Waterfront Last year representatives of state agencies held a series of meetings on transportation projects proposed for the area between the Meadowlands and the Hudson waterfront. Among the projects were two plans to increase public access to the waterfront.
One, proposed by Hartz Mountain Industries, called for drilling a new tunnel through the Palisades and building a road and a rail or monorail system to the northern waterfront, near the Lincoln Tunnel. Hartz, the largest real-estate development company in New Jersey, owns property in the Meadowlands and on the northern waterfront.
Another project, called Bergen Arches, would bring buses, trucks and cars to the southern waterfront near Jersey City.
Participants in the meetings and aides to Governor Kean say that the authority repeatedly insisted on giving priority to the Hartz plan, and that its representatives threatened to boycott a news conference held by Mr. Kean last October to describe the plans.
In a recent paper on its capital plans for 1990, the authority again gives priority to financing the Hartz tunnel and monorail at a cost of $273 million.
Hartz contends the plan would be the fastest to build and the most economical for developing the waterfront, with its constricted road network.
But a Department of Transportation review of the projects concludes that the potential for development in the southern waterfront is greater than in the north, that the Bergen Arches project is likely to handle twice as much traffic, and that a dollar spent on the Bergen Arches project would develop three times as much commercial office space as a dollar spent on the Hartz project would produce.
One of the people disturbed by the authority's support for the Hartz project is Delores T. Prideaux, an authority commissioner who questioned whether Hartz Mountain's public relations consultant influenced the authority. The consultant, Alan Marcus, is also employed by the authority, which has paid him $166,000 in fees.
Mr. Loveys said that the authority had made no commitment to the Hartz project or any other plan for the Hudson waterfront and that the authority favored working with the state on the best transportation project.
Mr. Loveys said that although Mr. Marcus's work for Hartz and the Authority might give the appearance of conflict of interest, he was certain Mr. Marcus would do nothing to influence the authority in favor of financing Hartz projects.
''I have a higher standard on conflict of interests than even the public, trust me,'' said Mr. Marcus, when asked about Ms. Prideaux's criticism. ''I have offered to resign three times. The Turnpike Authority refused to let me go.''

HEADLINE: Idyllic Theory Of Goddesses Creates Storm

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
MARIJA Gimbutas is an eminent archeologist who says she believes the world once lived in peace. It was during the Stone Age, she says, when goddesses were worshiped and societies were centered on women.
Then, about 6,000 years ago, this Old European culture, in which the two sexes lived in harmony with one another and with nature, was shattered by patriarchal invaders who installed their warlike gods in place of the life-generating Great Goddess.
It is a thesis that has made the 68-year-old professor of archeology at the University of California at Los Angeles a heroine among many feminist social critics and religious thinkers and a controversial figure, to say the least, among her colleagues.
References to Dr. Gimbutas's theories are sprinkled liberally throughout a growing literature about goddess-based religion. For some time feminist writers have been seeking non-patriarchal mythologies and rituals in Jungian psychology, reconstructed notions of witchcraft, or even in pure creations of the imagination. But Dr. Gimbutas gives them something more: the seeming stamp of science and the reassurance of history. 
Her work was a major scholarly source for Riane Eisler's ''The Chalice and the Blade,'' a sweeping analysis of cultural evolution that has become a minor classic in the women's movement. In ''The Once and Future Goddess,'' a new book on goddess symbols and images, Elinor W. Gadon calls Dr. Gimbutas's research germinal and fundamentally important.
''Marija Gimbutas is the one world-class scholar showing that what feminists wished were true is in fact true,'' said John Loudon, a senior editor at Harper & Row who worked on the archeologist's book published last year, ''The Language of the Goddess.''
Dr. Gimbutas is indeed a prolific scholar, the author of 20 books, including a monumental study of Bronze Age Indo-European cultures, and more than 200 articles. She has directed five excavations in Europe, reads more than 20 languages and brings to her work an extraordinary knowledge of European folklore and mythology.
But the skepticism about this thesis by many leading archeologists and anthropologists is unmistakable, although it is almost always comes with expressions of respect for Dr. Gimbutas's other contributions and with concern for her struggles with lymphatic cancer.
Yet the growing acceptance of her theories among nonexperts has led some of these scholars to feel that they should make their own criticism more widely known. In the end, they say, Dr. Gimbutas's work raises sensitive questions not only about prehistoric civilization but also about the relations between speculation and scholarship and between scholarship and social movements.
Dr. Gimbutas argues that between 7000 B.C. and 3500 B.C. the people of Europe lived in sedentary agricultural societies that worshiped the Great Goddess, delighted in nature, shunned war, built comfortable settlements rather than forts and crafted superb ceramics rather than weapons. The social system was matrilineal. Women headed clans or served as queen-priestesses. Men labored as hunters and builders. But neither men nor women dominated the other sex.
Death was not absent from this world. Death-wielding goddesses are found among the female deities that predominated in this period but their worship, Dr. Gimbutas theorizes, was always closely linked to themes of life and regeneration.
Between roughly 4000 B.C. and 3500 B.C. this peaceful and harmonious ''Old Europe'' was shattered by waves of Indo-European invaders on horseback, the theory holds. These marauders from the Russian steppes transformed Europe. Their warrior gods dethroned the nurturing Goddess. Her various manifestations were incorporated into the male-dominated pantheons as wives, daughters or consorts, sometimes eroticized like Aphrodite or militarized like Athena. Patriarchy and hierarchy replaced sexual and social egalitarianism.
The Goddess religion and its symbols went underground, putting on the masks of subordinate but still powerful female Greek and Roman deities, of the Virgin Mary, of mysterious figures in folklore and fairy tales. But a substratum of Old Europe survived in harvest customs and peasant beliefs about springs, rocks, trees and animals, in medieval magic and the practices that Christian authorities persecuted as witchcraft.
This secret stream is essential to decoding much of Western culture, Dr. Gimbutas maintains, but it is also a source of ancient wisdom that modern civilization must tap to counter its own alienation from nature.
It is a dramatic story of paradise lost and now rediscovered. Originally set forth in a 1974 book, ''The Goddesses and Gods of Old Europe,'' it inspired, besides feminist thinkers, a number of women artists who were captivated by the remarkable images of ancient female figurines in Dr. Gimbutas's book and later publications.
 
Ideas Welcomed by Some
Her ideas have been welcomed by eminent figures like the mythologist Joseph Campbell, who wrote a foreword to Dr. Gimbutas's latest volume before he died in 1987, and the anthropologist, Ashley Montagu, who hailed that book as ''a benchmark in the history of civilization.''
But many other investigators of prehistoric Europe have not shared the enthusiasm. Bernard Wailes, a professor of anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania, says that most of Dr. Gimbutas's peers consider her ''immensely knowledgeable but not very good in critical analysis.''
''She amasses all the data and then leaps from it to conclusions without any intervening argument,'' Mr. Wailes said. ''Most of us tend to say, oh my God, here goes Marija again,'' he said.
Ruth Tringham is a professor of anthropology at the University of California at Berkeley who is an authority on the same time and geographical area of prehistoric Europe as Dr. Gimbutas. Choosing pages at random from ''The Language of the Goddess,'' she repeatedly voiced dismay over assertions that demanded, she said, serious qualifications. ''No other archeologist I know would express this certainty,'' Ms. Tringham said.
Linda Ellis, an archeologist at California State University at San Francisco, who took courses from Dr. Gimbutas as an undergraduate at U.C.L.A. and has worked at some of the same archeologiscal sites in southeastern Europe, said, ''We're looking at small agricultural villages of no more than between 10 and 25 homes.
''We can tell a lot about their economy, what they traded, what they made, what they ate, how they built homes, with whom they had contacts. The problem becomes how far you can push that, how much you can say about how a person thought,'' she said. Ms. Ellis makes it clear that she thinks Dr. Gimbutas has gone too far.
David Anthony, an assistant professor of anthropology at Hartwick College in Oneonta, N.Y., whose areas of research also coincide closely with Dr. Gimbutas's, said that, contrary to her claims, the cultures of Old Europe built fortified sites that indicate the presence of warfare. There is also evidence of weapons, including some used as symbols of status, and of human sacrifice, hierarchy and social inequality, Mr. Anthony added.
The collapse of Old Europe is not fully understood, he said. It may have been due to a change in climate, the exhaustion of the soil, internal social dissent or population pressures.
Mr. Anthony agreed that the arrival of migrants and the emergence of less sedentary, stock-grazing societies around 3000 B.C. was a principal component of later European developments. But there was not real evidence that the migrants caused the collapse rather than followed it, he said.
 
'Extremely Foreign' Societies
There is also no evidence that women played the central role in either the social structure or the religion of Old Europe, he said. These were ''important and impressive societies,'' he said, but rather than Dr. Gimbutas's ''Walt Disney version'' they were ''extremely foreign to anything we're familiar with.''
Dr. Gimbutas said in an interview that the 19th-century Swiss scholar Johann Jakob Bachofen and his followers Robert Briffault in France and James Frazier in England were among her forerunners.
In ancient laws and legends and in the beliefs of isolated tribes or communities, they found vestiges of an earlier matriarchal stage of human civilization centered on worship of a mother goddess.
Dr. Gimbutas tempers her forerunners' notion of strict matriarchy, but her similarities to these predecessors divides her from many colleagues.
Anthropologists are now uncomfortable with what, a century ago, were popular schemes of civilization passing from one well-defined stage to another. Archeologists reject Dr. Gimbutas's reliance on the folklore and mythology of historical times to interpret objects from many millenia earlier.
But what others see as Dr. Gimbutas's weaknesses, she sees as weaknesses of her discipline. Archeologists are not interested in religion, she said, and they lack the knowledge and language skills to use comparative mythology and folklore to interpret their findings.
Her own interpretations involve extended chains of associations. Using stripes or hatchmarks or other motifs as clues, she identifies figurines, often from societies thousands of years apart, with specific animal deities, which in turn are assigned specific religious functions.
 
'A Very Brave Woman'
All of this she subsumes into the ''cohesive and persistent ideological system'' of the Great Goddess. It is a method that Mr. Campbell, in an introduction to her book, compares to the one used in deciphering the Rosetta Stone but her critics find fanciful or abitrary.
''In a way she's a very brave woman, very brave to step over the boundary and to take a guess,'' said Ms. Ellis. But Ms. Ellis strongly rejects Dr. Gimbutas's detailed assertions.
Dr. Gimbutas calls the enthusiastic reception of her work by artists and feminists ''an incredible gift'' coming late in her life. But ''I was not a feminist and I had never any thought I would be helping feminists,'' she said.
Still, ''The Language of the Goddess'' rings with a fervent belief that knowledge about a Goddess-worshiping past can guide the world toward a sexually egalitarian, nonviolent and ''earth-centered'' future.
This immediate, some would say ideological, agenda is one thing that disturbs some archeologists and anthropologists. They recall how easily their fields have been bent to ideological purposes, including the use Nazi scientists made of Indo-European prehistory to bolster claims of Aryan superiority.
In endorsing ''The Language of the Goddess,'' Gerda Lerner, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin, who has written on the origins of patriarchy, said that although Dr. Gimbutas's theory ''can never be proven,'' by simply providing an imaginative alternative to male-centered explanations, the theory can ''challenge, inspire and fascinate.''
Dr. Gimbutas's critics agree that speculation and intuitive leaps are essential prods to scholarly progress.
''But it is the responsibility of the leaper to be aware that they are leaping and to make other people aware of it also,'' Ms. Tringham said.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
How a Grim Black Area Got That Way

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The ''Throwaway People'' of tonight's ''Frontline'' live in Shaw, a beat-up, beaten-down district of Washington where the facts of life are grimly familiar: unemployment, single-parent welfare families, school dropouts, drugs and crime. This hour, on Channel 13 at 9 P.M., offers a close-up of sites off the Beltway.
The reporter and narrator, Roger Wilkins, looks back on the way Shaw, once a vibrant black community, got this way. Families from the rural South, who came north between 1910 and 1970, found opportunity; low-skilled jobs paid enough for a man to support his wife and children. They lived in ghettos, but life had stability. 
The civil rights movement changed that. The most successful won the opportunity to leave; a quarter of a million moved from Washington to its suburbs between 1970 and 1980.
''America creamed off the luckiest and best-trained blacks and assimilated them to some degree,'' says Mr. Wilkins. ''And Shaw was left with the less fortunate.''
The neighborhood guides are Ernest Peterson, who owns a messenger service that employs 16 young black men, and Frank Wright, who works at a settlement house. They are gloomily realistic about Shaw's thousands of ill-educated, unskilled young men, a third of whom are destined to be arrested on drug charges by the time they are 30 years old.
''They're true businessmen,'' Mr. Peterson says of the boys of Shaw. ''Just got a terrible product.'' What they don't have, he adds, is the sort of hero that luckier American boys have: the father who comes home after work, has dinner with them and asks what they've been up to.
Mr. Wilkins, who teaches history at George Mason University in Virginia and is associated with the Institute for Policy Studies, a left-leaning think tank in Washington, faults Washington for diverting war-on-poverty money to Vietnam and is particularly tough on the Reagan Administration for ''crippling'' training and job programs. Taken together with the coming of crack in the mid-1980's, he says, Administration indifference has proved devastating.
More conservative voices have blamed the wrong sort of Government assistance in pre-Reagan years for some inner-city ills. All parties might agree with Mr. Wilkins's message: ''The crisis of black poor men is now the central destructive fact of community life.''
''Throwaway People'' also goes into prisons, where so many of Shaw's youths wind up. (''The black man,'' says an inmate, ''is on the 10 most endangered species list.'') And it goes into nurseries, where babies, some born crack-addicted, are beginning a life of misery. Mr. Wilkins reports there are only three such nurseries in Washington, helping 30 children, about 2 percent of those in need.
The facts are not new, but they cannot be reported too often, and this hour does it in a quietly forceful way. It ends by noting yet a further assault on what remains of a community in Shaw: gentrification. Mr. Peterson predicts, ''And when enough people come in here who don't look like the people who are here now, you'll see the schools improve, you'll see public safety improve, the garbage will get picked up, the streets will get swept.'' The losers, presumably, will be swept into another neighborhood, perhaps a little further from the White House.
 
NO LIGHT, NO END, NO TUNNEL - THROWAWAY PEOPLE, a documentary produced by Sherry Jones for ''Frontline''; David Fanning, executive producer; Judy Woodruff, anchor. On PBS at 9 P.M.

The Turmoil at Drexel

 
Drexel Burnham Lambert said its worsening troubles had forced it to seek new funds or a merger partner. The news touched off concerns about the stability of the financial markets. The Government has moved in to deal with the problems at the Wall Street investment house whose fortunes have risen and fallen with the high-risk ''junk bond'' market. [Page A1.] 
 
The speed with which Federal regulators responded to the financial problems at Drexel Burnham Lambert illustrates their awareness of how quickly problems could spread through the financial markets. News analysis. [A1.]
 
The prices of ''junk bonds'' skidded sharply again as investors reacted nervously to news that Drexel Burnham Lambert was scrambling to raise much-needed capital. [D24.]
 
 
 
Markets

 
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply on what dealers described as profit taking after the strong rally that followed last week's Treasury refunding auctions. [D1.]
 
A late spurt of selling depressed stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 29.06 points, to 2,619.14. [D10.]
 
Platinum futures prices jumped after Nelson Mandela endorsed anti-apartheid violence and nationalization of South Africa's mining industry. [D17.] The dollar ended narrowly higher. [D17.]
 
 
 
Companies

 
Perrier may be able to correct marketing problems arising from the weekend recall of its bottled water. Perrier's advantage is its dominance over competitors. [D1.] Source Perrier rushed to reassure consumers that it had dealt with the problem. [D6.]
 
Neiman Marcus filed a $19 million lawsuit against Federated Department Stores, Allied Stores and Olympia & York, accusing them of inducing Allen I. Questrom to resign as head of the Neiman Marcus stores to accept the post of chairman and chief executive of Federated and Allied stores. [D1.]
 
Time Warner said it lost $222 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a profit of $56 million, or 97 cents a share, in the similar period of 1988. For the year, the company said it lost $256 million, in contrast to a profit of $282 million, or $4.88 a share, in 1988. [D1.]
 
Georgia-Pacific will sell its safety paper business to Simpson Paper, in a move intended to remove a possible antitrust objection to its hostile takeover offer for Great Northern Nekoosa. [D2.]
 
GMAC Mortgage completed an agreement to buy Residential Funding, a mortgage-servicing subsidiary of Anchor Savings Bank, for approximately $62 million. [D16.]
 
Safeway Stores is going public again. The Oakland, Calif., supermarket chain, taken private in a leveraged buyout, told the S.E.C. it wanted to sell 10 million common shares. [D4.]
 
Four defendants in the Guinness stock-manipulation case went on trial in a London courtroom. [D6.]
 
United Airlines' labor unions have approached Richard Ravitch to become head of the airline if they are able to complete a buyout, people involved in the effort said. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
U.S. Notes And Bonds Off Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday on what dealers described as profit taking in the wake of the strong rally that followed last week's Treasury refunding auctions.
Concern about losses in foreign bond markets also prompted selling in the United States, dealers said.
Bond prices bore the brunt of the selling here and prices of some long-term issues fell in moderately active trading by more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount.
 
Talk About Drexel
Word that Drexel Burnham Lambert is seeking a major investor or a merger partner firmed prices early in the session. Investors apparently sought a safe haven in high-quality Treasury issues, fleeing from the high-yield, high-risk ''junk bond'' market, which Drexel pioneered. But as the day progressed, the urge to take profits, dealers said, outweighed the safe-haven inclination. 
In the already skittish junk-bond market, investors reacted negatively to the news about Drexel. Traders said that prices of most issues declined by one to two points.
Yesterday's selloff was preceded by a fairly successfuly series of Treasury auctions in which the Government sold $30 billion of notes and bonds. Yields on those securities were high enough to attract wide institutional and individual interest in the securities. That prompted a rally in prices that, by the end of last week, had pushed yields on some securities down by as much as 30 basis points, or hundredths of a point, below the levels at which they were auctioned.
''Everybody has big profits in the refunding issues, and foreign markets are collapsing, so people are selling,'' one Government bond trader said.
 
Acute in West Germany
The selloff in foreign bond markets was particularly acute in West Germany, where the movement to integrate the two Germanys has intensified fears that a sharp increase in inflation will be an inevitable byproduct of reunification. Rising inflation erodes the real rate of return on fixed income investments like bonds.
West German bonds, which were battered all last week, came under heavy selling pressure again yesterday, and yields on the Government's 7 1/4 percent 10-year bonds of 1999 rose by 20 basis points, to 8.48 percent, said analysts at Salomon Brothers. Yesterday's increase put the yield on 10-year German bonds above the yield on 10-year Treasury notes, now at 8.37 percent, for the first time in more than a decade.
''Developments abroad were unfriendly for the Treasury market,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''But the rally last week was overdone, and the market was vulnerable.''
By late in the day, the 8.50 percent bonds of 2020 that were auctioned last Thursday were offered at a price of 100 26/32, down more than a point, to yield 8.42 percent, compared with 8.33 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8.50 percent 10-year notes auctioned last Wednesday were offered at 100 26/32, down 19/32, to yield 8.37 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 23/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.28 percent.
The selloff had little impact on the short-term Treasury bill market, where rates on new three-month and six-month bills auctioned yesterday were well below those sold at the auction a week ago because of last week's rally.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.65 percent, down from an average rate of 7.83 percent last Monday.
Meanwhile, six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.65 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.72 percent a week earlier.
 
Easing Considered Unlikely
Word of Drexel's financial problems led some traders to speculate that the Federal Reserve Board might be forced to ease interest rates to help the firm and its creditors. But most economists said such a step was unlikely.
''The chances of a Fed easing due to Drexel are almost nonexistent,'' said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. ''That's why the Fed has a discount window. When a corporation gets into financial trouble, it can seek relief by borrowing at the discount window rather than expect to see a general decline in interest rates.''
The discount window is where troubled institutions can borrow from the Fedeal Reserve at a discounted rate, which is currently 7 percent.
Many of the concerns expressed about Drexel in the high-yield market yesterday centered around how the firm's portfolio of bonds would be disbursed if Drexel were bought by another company. A rapid liquidation would only put more pressure on prices, some traders said.
 
Drexel Role Questioned
But other analysts said that Drexel's portfolio, as well as its role as a source of liquidity in the secondary market in high-yield issues, was not that great. They said the real question was how mutual funds and others that buy high-yield securities would react if Drexel ceased to exist as an independent entity.
''Drexel used to advertise that, on a day-to-day basis, they had $2 billion worth of junk bonds in inventory,'' said Kingman Penniman, a senior vice president at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, securities firm. ''I am sure that it is somewhat less than that now, with most of it in old, generally illiquid Drexel deals. They weren't that active in the secondary market. It wasn't their role. They were the provider of issues to the market.''
Mr. Penniman said that most professional investors, sensing that Drexel's problems might cause a further slide in prices, had moved to the sidelines.
 
Philip Morris Issue
Elsewhere, the corporate bond market was highlighted by a $350 million offering of 10-year notes by the Philip Morris Companies. The 9.25 percent notes, which mature Feb. 15, 2000, were priced at $99.465 to yield 9.333, 95 basis points, or hundredths of a point, over the prevailing yield on the 8.50 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said prices of most actively traded issues fell by about one-half a point.
Municipal bond traders said that prices of most secondary tax-exempt issues fell by about half a point in fairly light trading.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Medical Insurance And Job Mobility

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
AMONG the many horror stories from people who have difficulty obtaining health insurance, that of Paul Tobias is a striking example. Mr. Tobias, an internationally known cellist who has appeared as a guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, said several major insurers had rejected him and his wife, Elizabeth Moschetti, a concert pianist. One insurer gave as the reason that ''there were too many AIDS cases in the arts community,'' he said. Eventually the couple went to the Empire Blue Cross plan, where they pay $1,520 every 90 days for comprehensive coverage.
Looking beyond the personal problems of people with costly or minimal coverage and the 31 million Americans with no coverage, many economists and industry critics say the inadequacies in the system raise broad national issues. The growing number of exclusions and restrictions on eligibility for health insurance, these people say, may even affect flexibility and mobility in the work force. 
A worker whose child is asthmatic, for example, or a high-pressure executive with ulcers has to think seriously about health coverage when considering a change to a new employer. Insurers typically reject people with family health problems working for small businesses or offer them rates they cannot afford. Even large employers, who are often self-insured, may delay coverage for 6 to 12 months, during which they do not pay for treatment of a chronic condition.
Such problems can be significant, said Stephen Crane, a health policy analyst at the Boston University School of Public Health. ''People don't realize that there are gaps in coverage when they change jobs, particularly in going from a larger employer to a smaller one.'' Dr. Crane said one highly paid executive was in the process of switching jobs when he learned that his treatment for a gastric ulcer would not be covered for at least a year. ''He ended up continuing his coverage under his old employer's plan, which would not be financially possible for a lot of people.''
''We don't know how many people are in this never-never land,'' Dr. Crane said. As people grow older, he added, fear of losing benefits ''could act as a significant barrier to job mobility.''
Changing jobs ''used to be a free float,'' said Stuart H. Altman, an economist at Brandeis University and chairman of the Government commission that advises Congress on Medicare payments to hospitals. ''You were never asked a health question. But now it's a giant moat around our employment. People think it's the poor's problem. But some insurers go into an individual small firm and single out people'' who are refused health insurance because they are considered poor risks.
For instance, Lawrence C. Mitchell, president of Mitco Industries, a small manufacturer in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., said the company went without insurance for three years after its monthly health premiums were raised to more than $6,000 from $4,000. He said his 14 employees are ''baby boomers in their mid-40's, basically in good health,'' but they include ''a borderline diabetic,'' an employee with an enlarged heart and another employee whose wife had a relatively minor ulcer condition.
''It's a terrible situation,'' Mr. Mitchell said. ''It's almost forcing me to say I'm going back to a one-man shop and not hire employees.'' He said Mitco recently joined a Blue Cross plan and pays $4,200 a month.
Blue Cross of California is wooing small businesses, hoping to head off political pressure for a new state-imposed system. Both Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican, and the Democratic majority in the Legislature want to expand health insurance protection. Blue Cross of California recently announced coverage for small businesses, even those with expensive health problems, that would hold the rates to within 30 percent of what Blue Cross charges other small companies in the same area.
The Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group in Washington, is also wrestling with the problem. The group recently sent recommendations to the bipartisan health-care commission headed by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, who plans to report next month to Congress and President Bush.
Under the industry proposals, businesses with fewer than 25 employees could not be denied coverage even if a member of the group was considered ''uninsurable or a high risk.'' Once insured, ''neither the group nor an individual in the group'' could be denied coverage for health reasons, even if an individual moved to a different employer. High-risk people would be covered through an industry reinsurance fund.
The association said its program should be put in place in the 50 states, rather than by Congress. Insurance lobbyists in many states have often succeeded in fending off regulation.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges 29.06 on Slowest Day of Year

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
A late spurt of selling depressed stocks across a broad front yesterday in the slowest trading of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged by 29.06 points, or by 1.1 percent, to 2,619.14.
The Dow's drop came after three successive gains that amounted to nearly 42 points. Many traders attributed yesterday's activity to the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. 
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancing ones by more than 2 to 1 yesterday, as 1,042 fell in price and 479 rose.
 
Volume at 118.4 Million
At the same time, volume on the Big Bost rates peak out.''shares, far below this year's previous low turnover of 131 million on Feb. 5. That was the slowest day since since Dec. 26, when 77.6 million shares changed hands. On Friday, 146.9 million shares changed hands.
The traders said concern about higher interest rates, some profit taking and sharply lower bond prices combined to depress equities. By late yesterday, the new 30-year Treasury issue was down by a point, to 100 26/ 32, to yield 8.42 percent, up from 8.33 on Friday.
''Stock market worries are both internal and external and may not be sorted out for awhile,'' said Rao Chalasani, the chief investment strategist at Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc. in Cleveland. ''Earnings disappointments are internal, and interest-rate increases are external. Sideline cash is aplenty but may not be drawn in unless German and Japanese interest rates peak out.''
In the broader stock market yesterday, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped by 3.54 points, to 330.08, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index declined by 1.84 points, to 182.55.
Panhandle Eastern was the most active stock, slipping by 1/8, to 28 3/8, on a volume of 2.1 million shares. The stock went ex-dividend yesterday. Southwestern Public Service was another busily traded utility, dipping by 1/8, to 29 1/8, on a turnover of 1.5 million shares.
 
Time Warner Off to $101.50
Time Warner fell by 3 1/4, to 101 1/2. The New York-based company said it had lost $222 million in the fourth quarter because of costs from its acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. But analysts said that the earnings were in line with expectations and that the drop in the shares probably reflected the general anxiety about highly leveraged companies.
ASA, a fund that invests in South African stocks, dropped by 4 1/2, to 64 3/8, after Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, said he supported nationalizing private industry.
But gold stocks rose, reflecting the prospect that disarray in South Africa would limit the production of gold and drive up its price. Homestake Mining rose by 1/2, to 23; Newmont Gold by 7/8, to 56 1/8, and Hecla Mining by 5/8 to 15 5/8.
Hilton jumped by 2 7/8, to 64 5/8. NWA Inc. declined to comment on a report that its chairman, Alfred Checchi, was part of group seeking to raise refinancing for a bid for Hilton.
The traders said insurance stocks dropped, with General Re slipping by 1/2, to 85 1/4, and Chubb declining by 5/8, to 93 3/4. In over-the-counter trading, Ohio Casualty plunged by 3 1/2, to 39 1/2, and Safeco fell by 1 3/8, to 38.
Active blue-chip issues included Citicorp, up by 3/8, to 23 3/8, and General Electric, off by 1, to 62 1/4.
Berkshire Hathaway, the highest-priced issue on the Big Board, fell by 730 to 7,220. An article in Barron's magazine contended that the stock was overvalued based on the investments the company holds.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index dropped by 1.92 points, to 358.87, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index fell by 2.46 points, to 426.38.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Modest Gains As the Mark Remains Off

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly higher yesterday against most major currencies in quiet trading.
Currency dealers said the dollar continued to gain ground at the expense of the West German mark. The market remains concerned that a proposal to reunify the monetary systems of the two German states could hurt West Germany's economy.
Against the mark, the dollar traded late yesterday at 1.6755 marks, up from 1.6680 late Friday.
The markets, however, were slowed by the closing of Tokyo trading houses for a holiday, dealers said.
In London, the dollar fetched 144.20 yen, compared with 144.72 Friday. Later, in New York, the dollar stood at 144.37 yen, down from 144.725 yen Friday.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling cost $1.6960, up from $1.6930 late Friday, and $1.6918 in New York, down from $1.6955.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday quotes, included: 1.5005 Swiss francs, up from 1.4915; 5.6965 French francs, up from 5.6720; 1,246.00 Italian lire, up from 1,241.25, and 1.20065 Canadian dollars, up from 1.20025.
Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday: 1.6695 West German marks, down from 1.6750; 1.4960 Swiss francs, up from 1.4935; 5.6785 French francs, up from 5.6765; 1.8890 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8835; 1,242.00 Italian lire, down from 1,242.25; and 1.2023 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1987.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The Strategy For Benson & Hedges

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
DISPUTING the accuracy of recent reports in the advertising trade press, a top Philip Morris marketing executive says the company is not repositioning Benson & Hedges cigarettes as a brand for blue-collar smokers. Instead, the nation's largest tobacco company will try to maintain its edge with the current customers who like the cigarettes' image of style and affluence.
In a wide-ranging interview that also touched on Philip Morris's ad agencies and the drive to ban the tobacco advertising that nourishes them, David E. R. Dangoor, the senior vice president of marketing at Philip Morris U.S.A., denied reports that in one article's words said his company would ''dump upscale advertising in favor of a new marketing campaign directed at less affluent smokers.'' That article and others cited interviews with unnamed sources. 
''In this market, to maintain Benson & Hedges's position is the task,'' Mr. Dangoor said over a recent breakfast in New York. ''The loyalty level of current smokers is very high, so the main objective is to maintain that base and reinforce the brand's position for quality against the low-price brands.''
Benson & Hedges spends about $60 million annually on advertising, slightly less than a quarter of Philip Morris's total budget for cigarette advertising. But ad industry interest in the brand also relates to its history at Wells, Rich, Greene, the agency that introduced it 20 years ago with a witty television campaign that focused on the social problems created by longer cigarettes.
The agency has gone through several battles to keep the business in the face of Benson & Hedges's declining market share. Analysts estimate that the share last year was 3.7 percent, down a full percentage point from 1985. Wells, whose current ''For people who like to smoke'' campaign features chic urbanites in slice-of-life photographs, early this month survived another review for the account, which unleashed the latest rumors.
A 14-year veteran of Philip Morris, Mr. Dangoor, who is 40 years old, maintained that ''we are fundamentally happy with the agencies we've got,'' which include Leo Burnett and Backer Spielvogel Bates, in addition to Wells. But the Swedish native -who, with his narrow-collar shirt, European-tailored suit and swept-back, thinning hair looked like one of the Benson & Hedges ads' stylish characters - also declared, ''We are looking for the new makers in the advertising world,'' and cited TBWA and Omon among them.
''Leo Burnett is a terrific company,'' Mr. Dangoor said. ''Wells, Rich and Backer & Spielvogel are fine as well. But we want to find the great ad minds of the 90's. If you look at what made Philip Morris as a cigarette company, we always found small agencies. Leo Burnett was a small agency in the 50's, when we found them with Marlboro. The old man, Leo, spent 80 percent of his time on the brand.''
''In the case of a small agency like Omon, they could be the agency of record if we built a brand together, like we did with these others. We haven't found anything yet, but I'll give them a chance.''
The Philip Morris Companies has been aggressive in battling the mounting legislative efforts to restrict or ban tobacco advertising. Mr. Dangoor maintained that a ban was economically unsound, because it would eliminate the incentive to develop products.
''Advertising allows for innovation,'' he said. ''Let's hypothesize that there is a smoking device that in the future can replace cigarettes. As long as advertising is allowed and it seems profitable for companies to invest in research and development, such a device can come up. But if there is an advertising ban and your new product development can't give you advantages because you can't advertise them, I'm not sure a company would come up with that idea.''
Another threat to his company's cigarettes, Mr. Dangoor implied, was the magazines in which they are advertised. ''If you have a company as image-driven as we are, the clutter of print is a tremendous problem,'' he said. He particularly criticized women's service magazines, calling them ''a nightmare'' and asserting that magazine ad clutter was one reason Philip Morris in recent years had channeled most of the increases in its cigarette marketing budgets to direct marketing and sales promotion and, to a lesser degree, to outdoor advertising.
In magazines, ''there is a level of advertising saturation and oversaturation,'' he said. ''Outdoor, there's nobody near you.''

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
At The 'Junk Bond' Banquet, The Host Is Suddenly Absent

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. signals the end of an era in which speculative debt became Wall Street's stock in trade and America's corporate establishment was transformed by financiers buying companies for billions of dollars in i.o.u.'s.
The rapid disintegration of the firm, whose troubles were deemed serious but not life-threatening only a few days ago, also demonstrates just how quickly confidence can vaporize on Wall Street.
Drexel, once a minor player on Wall Street, became a titan by pioneering the sale of ''junk bonds'': corporate obligations of companies with low credit standing. Michael R. Milken, an evangelist for junk bonds who became America's highest-paid executive - in 1987 he took home more than half a billion dollars from Drexel - succeeded in persuading investors that the extra-high interest rates on such bonds more than offset the risk that they would not be paid.
By making huge borrowings possible, secured by no more than rosy forecasts of future profits, Drexel helped transform the mentality of corporate America. Corporate insurgents, armed with the pools of money that Drexel raised, went on the offensive, until no company felt safe from a takeover financed by borrowed money. Captains of industry rushed to borrow money and put it in shareholders' pockets, fearful that if they failed to do so, some raider might do it for them. 
''Its collapse is much less significant than its career,'' commented James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a financial magazine that has long been critical of Drexel. ''It did far more damage to the system by operating than it will by shutting down. The damage was the creation of debt that stood no chance of survival in anything except the balmiest summer economic weather.''
Before Mr. Milken, who is under indictment on charges of securities-law violations, the only junk bonds in existence were ''fallen angels,'' Wall Street's endearing term for bonds issued by companies that seemed solid when the loans were made, but later ran into hard times.
Drexel changed all that. It developed a close-knit pool of buyers eager for the ''high-risk, high-yield'' offerings. Many of those buyers were themselves substantial issuers of junk bonds.
A result was a wholesale relaxing of credit standards, fostering many corporate takeovers that would have been unthinkable a few years earlier. Now many of those bonds are shaky, as the companies struggle to come up with the cash to meet their obligations. The fate of those companies may be Drexel's most enduring legacy.
To be sure, some companies owe their existence to Drexel. Without junk bond financing, they might never have expanded or succeeded in becoming major forces in their industries. Turner Broadcasting System Inc., the cable television programmer, is notable among them. But many others, like Integrated Resources Inc., a financial services company, failed. It filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday. And Merv Griffin's Drexel-financed purchase of Resorts International Inc., the casino operator, took less than a year to wind up in bankruptcy court.
Some of the worst deals - at least in terms of how rapidly they collapsed - were underwritten not by Drexel but by competitors who lusted after the large profit margins that made Drexel the most profitable firm on Wall Street. The Campeau Corporation used financing underwritten by First Boston to build a department store empire that has filed for Chapter 11.
Now, such financing is difficult to obtain, at best. RJR Nabisco Inc., which was taken over in the largest leveraged buyout ever, last week was forced to delay a planned financing. The company is doing relatively well, but few investors want to lend to a firm so laden with debt. To meet its obligations, it may have to sell more of its operations than it had planned, assuming buyers can be found.
Yesterday, the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., the broker's parent firm, failed to meet its obligations and late last night filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws. The brokerage firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was not expected to file, but the distinction was of little practical importance.
''For all intents and purposes, they are out of business,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, a brokerage industry analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''Nobody will transact with them right now.'' The fear is that when it comes time for cash and securities to be exchanged, normally a week after a deal is made, Drexel might not be able to complete the trade.
It was the refusal of banks to lend to Drexel that sealed the fate of the parent this week. ''A brokerage firm is a highly leveraged financial institution with no lender of last resort,'' said an official of a Drexel competitor. ''When it comes apart, it comes apart very fast.''
While Drexel may be about to fade from the scene, the securities it sold will not. The junk bond market has been shaken by fears that Drexel will be forced to sell its bond holdings, but in the longer run the value of junk bonds will be determined by just how profitable their issuing companies are.
''At some point, these bonds trade on their own,'' Peter Lynch, the manager of the Fidelity Magellan mutual fund, said yesterday. Mr. Lynch, one of the most successful fund managers, said he had been buying some junk bonds, among them issues from the Fort Howard Corporation, a paper company, and the Kroger Company, a grocery chain.
For companies wishing to borrow money in the future, it is not clear how much tighter the credit standards will be. Throughout the 1980's, companies were able to borrow ever greater amounts against future income. When it was clear that the company could not sustain the debt load, as was often the case, arrangements were made in which no cash needed to be paid as interest for five years or more. By then, the theory went, operations would have improved or the company would have sold off assets.
When the smoke clears, it is likely that some lesser-quality companies will be able to borrow less than they could have otherwise. But others will no longer have access to the public debt market. ''Companies will go back to being financed privately or through their banks,'' said Gail Silberman, a bond analyst at Jefferies & Company.
Companies that have borrowed money are likely to have to struggle with new rules. The expectation that debt can be refinanced easily has already vanished. Many companies will have to reorganize, giving stock to borrowers to gain relief from onerous interest payments. Others may have to cancel plans for capital investment, or for spending on research and development, to obtain the cash needed to pay interest.

HEADLINE: THE COLLAPSE OF DREXEL BURNHAM LAMBERT;
Drexel, Symbol of Wall St. Era, Is Dismantling; Bankruptcy Filed

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the once-dominant investment house that fueled many of the biggest corporate takeovers of the 1980's, began selling off its securities yesterday, and its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection. The moves marked the demise of a firm that seemed to symbolize the fast-money era on Wall Street.
Drexel's securities business effectively collapsed yesterday after the parent company defaulted on $100 million in loans and other Wall Street firms sharply curbed their dealings with the investment house.
The parent, the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code late last night, a few hours after the company's board had approved the filing.
 
Subsidiaries Not Included
The parent's filing does not include the investment firm or a subsidiary that deals in securities issued by the United States Treasury. But unlike companies in other industries that file for bankruptcy, Drexel is not expected to re-emerge as a going concern, the firm's executives and lawyers said. More than most businesses, the survival of a securities firm, they explained, depends on the confidence of investors and other dealers; without that confidence, the business unravels quickly. 
''After it's all over, Drexel will be left with cash, and a lot of laid-off employees,'' one executive at the firm said.
Accordingly, the investment house that pioneered the use of high-yield ''junk bonds'' to finance high-risk ventures yesterday started the tortuous process of closing down. Executives from a number of Wall Street firms visited Drexel, examining the securities holdings of Drexel for possible purchases.
 
Gathering Resumes
And many of the firm's 5,000 employees began to get their resumes together. ''Everybody's looking to go out of this place in a professional manner,'' one executive said.
Because Drexel employs thousands of people in New York, the news of the firm's collapse stirred concern among public officials in the region.
The demise of Drexel represents ''a sad day for New Yorkers and a sad day for the American financial system,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat. ''It represents a significant blow to New York City's economy and marks the end of an era in American finance.''
The rapid collapse of the firm, which on Monday announced that it was seeking a merger partner because of a cash crunch, created fears among some Wall Street executives about the possible ripple effect on other firms. They said that with Drexel liquidating its huge junk bond portfolio, the value of other firms' holdings in the securities could well collapse.
''If forced sales take place, there may be a capital erosion problem starting,'' one Wall Street executive said. ''Drexel could end up taking some companies with it.''
Wall Street was stunned by the rapid decline of Drexel, but some executives said it was simply the way of the finance world. ''This is the nature of the financial services business,'' said Jeffrey B. Lane, president of Primerica Holdings and former president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''You go into a steady decline, and then you fall off a cliff.''
The stock market shrugged off the news on Drexel, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 4.96 points, to close at 2,624.10.
 
Pioneer in Junk Bonds
Yesterday's developments underline the stunning turnaround at Drexel, which was one of Wall Street's most powerful firms until last year, when it settled criminal and civil charges of securities law violations.
Drexel rose from being a Wall Street also-ran in the late 1970's to become one of the nation's most profitable investment banks in the late 1980's as a creator of the modern junk bond market. Under the guidance of Michael R. Milken, former head of its junk bond division, Drexel became a primary player in the takeover battles that swept corporate America during the last decade. With Drexel's bonds, smaller companies that never before could have obtained financing were able to make bids for some of America's largest corporations.
But things started to come unstuck for Drexel in 1986, when the firm was caught up in the scandals that swept Wall Street after the fall of Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager. Mr. Boesky paid $100 million to settle charges of insider trading and agreed to testify against Drexel and Mr. Milken.
 
Milken Indictment
Last year, Drexel pleaded guilty to six felony counts, agreeing to pay $650 million. Mr. Milken was indicted on 98 counts of racketeering, securities fraud and other charges, and has left the firm.
The rapid collapse of Drexel was precipitated by financial dealings between the firm and its corporate parent. Drexel said the parent had assets of more than $3.6 billion and liabilities of more than $3 billion. Federal bankruptcy law permits a company to enter Chapter 11 if the assets exceed the liabilities when there is a prospect of insolvency.
The parent company - which had sizable holdings of junk bonds and other securities that had declined sharply in value and could not be easily sold - last week began to siphon some of the $500 million in capital that the investment bank held in excess of the amount Federal law required.
That move quickly attracted the attention of the Federal Reserve, which alerted the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange, which monitor the activities of investment firms. The exchange was already conducting an audit of Drexel's holdings to insure that they were being accounted for and handled properly by the firm.
On Friday, Drexel executives held meetings with the Government agencies and the exchange, at which they were directed to stop moving cash from the investment bank to the parent company.
 
Marathon Meetings
Then, during a marathon series of meetings over the weekend, Drexel struggled to find a merger partner. At the same time, a number of banks, led by Citibank, attempted to put together a loan to bolster Drexel's deteriorating financial position.
Those efforts collapsed yesterday, and the firm announced that it was in default.
As the problems at Drexel continued to unfold, the S.E.C. and the Big Board had teams of auditors at 60 Broad Street, Drexel's headquarters, going over the firm's books.
In a statement yesterday, Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C., who has been a main coordinator in the effort to find a solution to the problems at Drexel, said in a statement that the commission and the Big Board were closely monitoring Drexel's financial position and that the firm was meeting the Federal requirements for capital.
Speaking early yesterday on Drexel's in-house communications system, Frederick H. Joseph, the chief executive of Drexel and the president of the holding company, told employees to begin liquidating many of the securities held by the firm in an orderly manner.
 
A Speedy Dismantling
The speed of Drexel's dismantling was surprising. A number of other Wall Street firms, like Salomon Brothers, First Boston and Bear, Stearns, were examining Drexel's holdings to see if they might purchase the securities.
But before any proposals were made for the purchases, Drexel had sold off billions of dollars' worth of Government and corporate bonds, stocks and other securities. The firm also sold tens of millions of dollars' worth of junk bonds from its portfolio of about $1 billion. Irritation at S.E.C. Government regulators were somewhat taken aback in recent days by the speed of Drexel's worsening financial troubles. Indeed, S.E.C. officials expressed irritation that they had not been more closely informed. ''The financing squeeze on Drexel didn't materialize over a weekend,'' one person said of the surprise by the regulators at the events. ''Nobody likes catching grenades, and none of them want to preside over the largest bankruptcy in Wall Street history.''
Some Drexel staff members also criticized the top management for not informing employees of the firm's eroding financial position. But Drexel directors insisted that the management had made the best of a difficult situation.
 
'Heroic Battle' by Joseph
''Truthfully, this has been a heroic battle by Fred Joseph,'' said Roderick M. Hills, a former S.E.C. commissioner who was appointed to Drexel's board after its settlement last year.
Drexel's day began with efforts by the firm's dealers to trade securities normally. But within a matter of minutes at about 10 A.M., executives were told by the S.E.C. and Mr. Joseph to halt their trading, pending an announcement by the firm.
Employees then waited for about 45 minutes to hear the news. Soon, the traders saw it running across the tape: Drexel had defaulted on $100 million worth of loans and was holding a board meeting to consider whether to file for bankruptcy.
In seconds, Mr. Joseph was on the in-house communications system, along with Steven Anreder, a spokesman for the firm, and one of the parent company's bankruptcy lawyers.
In his statement on the communications system, Mr. Joseph said that a large investor for the firm had not materialized and that the parent company appeared to be insolvent. He also said that the firm was continuing to discuss selling all or part of the firm to third parties. Mr. Joseph added that customer accounts would be transferred to Smith, Barney.
 
'An Unhappy Event'
For employees, Mr. Joseph said, the announcement was ''an unhappy event.'' But he added that all employees would receive their paychecksand that the checks would clear the bank.
At that point, to the consternation of some employees, a bankruptcy lawyer began to discuss with the employees what the meanings of a filing for the parent would be. ''Most employees don't have anything to do with that group and are mad because they think that's what brought the entire firm down,'' one executive said.
Executive job-placement firms reported a flood of calls from Drexel staff members yesterday worried about their future. ''We're getting 10 to 20 phone calls an hour from Drexel people,'' said Gary Goldstein, president of the Whitney Group, an executive search firm.
Drexel was also besieged by calls throughout the day from worried suppliers, executives of the firm said. Indeed, they say, the car service that some executives use to go home refused to accept the firm's business, fearing it would not get paid.
 
Holdings Are Diverse
After the discussion on the in-house communications system, Mr. Joseph said employees could begin to trade again and attempt to liquidate as much of the firm's holdings as possible.
Besides the $1 billion in junk bonds, the firm's holdings are diverse. More than one-fifth of those holdings were said by executives at the firm to be liquid, or easily convertible into cash.
For the rest of the day, Drexel began to move out of one business after another. By noon, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the over-the-counter market, said Drexel had voluntarily ceased making markets in 229 Nasdaq issues for which it was the market maker. Most Nasdaq issues have multiple market makers, and so would not have to be transferred to another firm.
Late in the day, rumors spread that Drexel was losing its designation as a primary dealer in Government securities. However, the Federal Reserve issued a statement saying the firm retained that status.

HEADLINE: Bush May Revive Plan for Warships Off Colombia

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
At his meeting in Colombia on Thursday, President Bush is likely to try to revive a United States proposal to deploy Navy warships off South America to monitor drug-trafficking flights, senior Administration officials said today.
But the officials said the Administration recognized that any effort to increase the role of the United States military in cocaine interdiction in South America was ''a big problem'' in the current climate between Washington and Latin America and was therefore not at the center of Mr. Bush's plans for the meeting in Cartagena, Colombia.
The meeting is not likely to produce any formal agreement on the use of American warships or any other expanded role for the United States military, the officials said. Disclosure of Pentagon plans to deploy an aircraft carrier off Colombia provoked a storm of protest there last month and forced Washington to delay the program. 
In another potential point of dispute at the four-nation meeting, the Administration made it clear today that Mr. Bush will not offer to increase United States economic aid to the Andean cocaine-producing nations beyond the $2.2 billion, five-year program that it has already proposed to Congress. The program focuses instead on drug interdiction and crop eradication.
Two days before Mr. Bush travels to Cartagena for the meeting with the Presidents of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru, the White House conducted an intense round of public relations to smooth the talks.
Mr. Bush signed a United Nations convention on drug trafficking and the White House made public a national study showing a continued drop in illegal drug use among high school students. Officials said Mr. Bush would use the survey in Cartagena as evidence that his Administration is working to cut demand for illegal drugs.
Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's press secretary, also announced that the Pentagon had cut the number of troops in Panama to fewer than were in the country on Dec. 20, when the President ordered an invasion to topple Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Mr. Fitzwater said 13,504 United States soldiers were now in Panama compared with 13,597 on Dec. 20. He said that met Mr. Bush's commitment to withdraw the entire invasion force before the end of February.
The announcement seemed largely a symbolic gesture to ease the irritation that the invasion brought in relations between Washington and Latin American governments.
The United States has not withdrawn all of the invasion force but simply lowered the overall number of troops in Panama by removing most of the combat soldiers and by rotating home some soldiers who were stationed in the country before the invasion.
Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, said today that the Cartagena conference was expected to produce a broad framework for cooperative anti-drug efforts.
He said the four Presidents would issue a statement including the current United States proposals for economic aid and promises to reduce exports of automatic weapons, cut exports of chemicals for making cocaine and increase efforts to stop money laundering.
Mr. Scowcroft said the idea of using American Navy ships to monitor flights by drug traffickers, which he said was intended to help the South American governments place land-based radar installations, was shelved after the Colombian protest last month.
A senior official said the military's role in anti-drug efforts is ''not at the forefront of our proposals.''
''The question is likely to come up because it was such a brouhaha,'' he said. ''But we realize that the flap over it has created such a problem that it's tough for people to deal with, and we're prepared to leave it on the shelf.''
