HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Party's Agenda: Liberty and Justice

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Soviet Communist Party adopted a platform last week endorsing the abolition of the party's constitutional monopoly on political power and other changes. The text of the platform was distributed on Monday night by the official press agency Tass. Here are excerpts from the platform, as translated by Tass.
The party seeks to place man in the center of social development, providing him with worthy living and working conditions, guaranteeing him social justice, political liberty and possibilities for comprehensive development and spiritual fulfillment, and regards this as its main goal. This is exactly what should determine social progress. 
The Soviet Communist Party stands for the earliest formulation of legal acts guaranteeing the rights and freedoms of citizens. The recognition of personal liberty as the key and vital value and a volte-face to guarantee the entire complex of human rights is perestroika's most important accomplishment. Now it is necessary to consolidate these rights, to rest them on a solid material, legal and political foundation. The party will uphold: Reliable legislative protection of a citizen's personality and honor, the immunity of his home and property, the secrecy of correspondence and telephone conversations, Stronger guarantees to realize the right to work, including payment according to the quantity and quality of work done and its final results. The formation of a mechanism to maintain employment, training and re-training of personnel and adequate material support for those who are forced to change their trade, profession or place of work, The development and strengthening of the political rights of citizens: participation in running the affairs of society and the state, freedom of speech, the press, meetings and demonstrations and the formation of public organizations. Law and order and requirements of Soviet laws should be strictly observed, Freedom for creative activities and attitude to talent as a national asset.
 
The Role of Law
Man's free self-determination in the spiritual sphere, the freedom of conscience and religion. Without abandoning its world outlook, the party will step up the dialogue between atheists and believers and pursue a policy that offers all churches the opportunity to freely operate within the law, contributing to mutual understanding between people, A higher role of the court of law in protecting civil rights, the establishment of public-state commissions exercising law-enforcing activities, The C.P.S.U. prioritizes the adoption of laws in the near future on the press and other mass media, freedom of conscience and religious associations, public associations, the order of emigration from and immigration to the U.S.S.R., Soviet citizenship, languages of Soviet peoples and other legislative acts that will guarantee the political and personal rights of citizens. ...
Every means envisaged by law should be used to combat crime, while the presumption of innocence and the right to protection and juridical norms should be strictly observed. ...
The solution of the food problem should rest on the development of all forms of economic management in agriculture. State-run, cooperative and individual farms and diverse forms of management, based on contract, leasing and other principles, should be given equal possibilities. ...
We continue to focus on efforts to increase the production of consumer goods. The C.P.S.U. will help implement measures to help satiate the market.
 
Property and Economy
The party advocates an effective finance recovery program, including such measures as the encouragement of deposits in savings banks at increased interest rates, the development of the insurance business, the distribution of state loan bonds on advantageous terms, the selling of dwellings, advance payments by the population for durable goods they plan to buy in the future and the selling of stocks and other securities.
More flexible economic instruments and quotas will be needed to prevent unfounded incomes and the issue of money in excess of the supply of goods. ...
The C.P.S.U. believes the existence of individual property, including ownership of the means of production, does not contradict the modern stage in the country's economic development. . . .
One of the most difficult aspects of the economic reform is finding an organic combination of plan and market methods to regulate economic activity.
Modern production is impossible without a centralized planned management. This essentially socialist principle of economic management has been adopted by many countries.
However, it is crucially important to determine the precise degree and methods of such management. Unlike in the past, when the plan attempted to encompass the entire process of production and distribution, there is now a need for a procedure in which planned, centralized economic management will be exercised through prices, taxes, interest rates, credits, payments etc. ...
The creation of a full-fledged market economy requires the formation of markets of consumer products, capital goods, securities, investment, currencies and research and development, and an early reform of the financial, monetary and credit systems.
 
The Environment
The restructuring of price formation is a sine qua non condition for the market to start regulating the economy. The artificial price levels and proportions, the burden of ineffective subsidies for some and ruinous deductions from others provide false reference points for economic management. They confound the assessment of management's effect, perpetuate scientific and technological backwardness and prevent the efficient utilization of the advantages of the international division of labor.
Competition between product manufacturers, including foreign firms, must become an important factor regulating and restraining the growth of prices. ...
The protection of nature is the protection of man. Toward the close of the 20th century, environmental protection has become a categoric imperative for preserving life on the earth. We must introduce world standards in this country and take an active part in international ecological cooperation.
The rapid industrial growth of the U.S.S.R., coupled with an attitude of neglect toward conservation measures, has led to grave pockets of ecological disaster. Urgent measures and large investments are required to rectify the situation. ...
The party's policy proceeds from the recognition of the sovereign will of the people as the only source of power. The rule-of-law state of the whole people has no room for dictatorship by any class, and even less so for the power of a management bureaucracy. . . .
The electoral system should be brought in line with the principles of universal, equal, direct suffrage. We wish elections to become an honest competition between representatives of all the sections of society, of individuals and ideas submitted to the judgment of voters by the party, public organizations and movements and individual candidates.
 
Party and Presidency
The development of society does not preclude the possibility of forming parties. The procedure for their formation will be established by law and reflected in the Constitution of the U.S.S.R.
The formation and activity of organizations and movements that expound violence and interethnic strife and that pursue extremist, unconstitutional aims should be prohibited by law.
The Soviet Communist Party does not claim a monopoly and is prepared for a political dialogue and cooperation with everyone who favors the renewal of socialist society. ...
The Soviet Communist Party holds that the separation of legislative, executive and judiciary powers is fundamentally important to the Government's efficiency. In Lenin's words, we should combine the advantages of the Soviet system with the advantages of parliamentarism. ...
The question of instituting the post of head of state - president - responsible to the Congress of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies and having the necessary powers is posed by society ever more insistently.
A president is needed to maintain the country's stable development, to speed up perestroika, to guarantee its irreversibility, to ensure the normal and effective functioning of all state and public institutions in the process of democratization, to ensure law and citizens' security, to protect the Soviet Union's interests and to represent our state on the international arena. ...
A rule-of-law state presupposes effective political guidance of the defense, the accountability of the military department to the supreme civil authorities, and maximum openness in the activity of the military department, taking into account the level of confidence among states. . . .
 
Self-Determination
Internal security. In view of the need to protect state frontiers, counteract foreign intelligence agencies, protect the Soviet constitutional system and the rights of citizens, we should be attentive to the needs of frontier and internal troops, which fulfill complex and at times dangerous duties.
Remaining vital to the maintenance of public order, interior and state security bodies should operate strictly within the law and under control of elective government bodies. ...
The principle of the self-determination of nations in a renewed Soviet federation presupposes the freedom of national-state entities to choose forms by which to structure life, institutions and symbols of statehood. Our ideal is not unification, but unity in diversity.
The party reaffirms its commitment to Lenin's principle of the right of nations to self-determination, including secession, and favors the adoption of a law on a mechanism for the exercise of this right.
At the same time we are convinced that the weakening and disruption of reciprocally diverse and interrelated ties could lead to negative consequences for all peoples, to say nothing about individual destinies, consequences that are very difficult to foresee.
That is why we resolutely oppose separatist slogans and movements that would lead to the destruction of the great multiethnic democratic state. ...
There is a need for rethinking the principle of democratic centralism. It should no longer be treated in such a way that it can be used to implement barrack-room, hierarchical discipline.
There is no other way to overcome Communists' dissatisfaction with their role in the policy and activity of the party. There is no other way to restore in each of them a sense of dignity and inner freedom.

HEADLINE: Survey Shows Use of Drugs By Students Fell Last Year

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The number of high school seniors who say they have used illicit drugs at least once continued a downward trend last year, although there was no decline in reported use of the highly addictive crack, according to a national survey released today.
The federally financed annual survey, by the Institute for Social Research of the University of Michigan, questioned 17,000 of the nation's 2.7 million seniors. It found that narcotics use continues to be a grave problem, with 50.9 percent of those questioned in 1989 reporting that they had at least tried an illicit drug like marijuana or cocaine, as against 53.9 percent in 1988 and 56.6 percent in 1987. The 3.1 percent of seniors who said they had used crack in the past year did not mark a shift from the previous year. 
Administration officials, highlighting Federal anti-drug efforts two days before the drug conference in Colombia on Thursday, called a news conference at the White House today to hail the study as evidence that their national drug strategy was succeeding and that narcotics use was becoming unfashionable among young Americans. At the drug conference, Latin American leaders are expected to urge Mr. Bush to intensify efforts to reduce drug demand in the United States.
''It is obvious from these survey findings,'' said Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. ''that young people have made dramatic changes in their own use of most illicit drugs, as well as changes in their attitudes toward drug use by others during the decade of the 1980's.''
Dr. Sullivan and other officials at the conference, including William J. Bennett, the Federal drug policy director, attributed the shift to heightened concerns among students about the ill effects of drug use.
But critics of Administration policy immediately questioned the study, noting that the figures probably understate the problem because they do not include high school dropouts, unemployed workers and other groups among whom the drug problem is pronounced.
The survey did break out figures for respondents who are frequently truant or have poor grades, and they showed that among those seniors the trends were generally the same as for the overall sampling.
The confidential survey of 17,000 students at 135 public and private high schools across the country, is one of the most widely used indicators of drug use in the United States. Although it can never be known how forthright students are in revealing their own drug use in the survey, those authorities who conducted it said they believe the trends over the years have been consistent and supported other surveys.
The institute that conducts the survey does not say the results show the exact percentage of high school seniors in the population as a whole using drugs. Since the figures that the institute provided are only for the group surveyed, they do not involve a margin of error as is the case when a survey group is used to project trends in the overall population.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan who is the chairman of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said that the survey was of ''extremely limited value'' and cited Federal figures showing a high school dropout rate of more than 27 percent. ''The individuals with the greatest drug and crime problems are not even included.'' Mr. Rangel added that the crack figures were not cause for optimism, saying that ''it is definitely not good news that crack use has not dropped.''
 
Crack Use Is Little Changed
The survey showed no significant reductions in crack use, with occasional use of crack among high school seniors surveyed not changing appreciably, falling to 4.7 percent in 1989 from 5.4 percent in 1987 for who reported ever using the drug. Still less change was reported among users who reported using crack in the past 30 days, the group with the most serious addiction problem. Use by people in that group remained virtually unchanged, at 1.4 percent in 1989 as against 1.3 percent in 1987.
Lloyd D. Johnston, a social psychologist at the University of Michigan and the principal investigator for the study, said that the crack problem may be even worse than the survey suggests. ''We know we are not going to capture many heavy crack users in these surveys,'' he said. ''And it is clear from other types of information that there are plenty of heavy users out there.'' But he said that with time there may be a decline in crack use, citing as evidence for that a slight drop in use from 1987 to 1989 among college students and other young adults also questioned as part of the survey.
There were other troubling signs in the survey, notably an increase in the reported use of PCP, a dangerous animal tranquilizer known for its hallucinogenic effects. Reported use of PCP among the seniors questioned rose to 1.4 percent in 1989 from 0.3 percent the year before. Dr. Johnston said he could not explain the increase.
The survey found little change in cigarette smoking rates in the past decade, with 29 percent of the seniors questioned saying that they smoke regularly. Dr. Johnston called the findings about cigarettes ''by far the most disappointing part of the story.''
Federal authorities also said they were concerned about the use of crystal methamphetamine, or ''ice,'' a stimulant that has many of the effects of crack and was included in the survey for the first time last year. About 1.2 percent of the seniors surveyed said they had used the drug in the past year, and use was highest in the west, where 3 percent of the seniors said they had used it.
 
Drugs Easier to Obtain
Despite the overall decline in reported drug use, a considerably higher percentage of seniors said it would be easy for them to get drugs. Forty-seven percent said they could get crack fairly easily in 1989, an increase of 4.9 percentage points from the previous year, while 58.7 percent said they could get cocaine, an increase of 3.7 percentage points.
On the positive side, the use of marijuana in the prior 30 days reported in the survey was down to 17 percent in 1989 from a peak of 37 percent in 1979. Cocaine use in the previous 30 days, which began declining in 1987, fell from 6.2 percent in 1986 to 2.8 percent in 1989. Amphetamine use in the prior 30 days was down to about 4 percent last year, from more than 12 percent in 1980. The reported use of tranquilizers, barbiturates and methaqualone have reached such low levels that they showed little additional decline.
Most of the seniors questioned said they drink alcohol, but the proportions declined. Sixty percent of the seniors said they had consumed alcohol in the previous 30 days, down from a peak of 72 percent in 1980.

GRAPHIC: graphs of drug use by high school students from '79 to '89; high school students who use crack or cocaine from '87 to '89 (Source: Institute for Social Research, University of Mich.)

HEADLINE: On Arms: Start, and Start Again

 BODY:
The news on Europe continues to astound. Moscow and Washington have now reached agreement on future troop levels in Europe and on a two-stage procedure for German unification. Even as they do so, they're also considering even more far-reaching talks on nuclear and conventional weapons. That sounds premature, but it isn't. 
Exploring further agreements is welcome for many reasons. It will help keep arms talks relevant to the rush of political events, like German unification - and the development of new weapons. It will reassure those who worry about shortcomings in the treaties now nearing completion. And it will reaffirm the need to make arms control a continuing process, not a once-and-for-all answer.
But to establish that process, first things first. The two sides must finish what they have already started: negotiations on Conventional Forces in Europe and the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks.
Presidents Bush and Gorbachev expect promptly to conclude the first treaties ever that require substantial cuts in superpower forces. They also know that the treaties will leave important questions unresolved.
The proposed Start treaty would cut the superpowers' nuclear arsenals by a third. But it will not slow the pace of modernization. Both sides are developing new, more accurate land-based missiles with multiple warheads that could threaten mutual deterrence. Some officials, notably Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, want to begin limiting these missiles in Start 1. But injecting this issue now would invite Soviet counterproposals and delay conclusion of the present talks. Better to make such missiles the first priority in Start 2.
Defenses, if further developed, could undo an agreement to cut offenses. But force cuts will take place over a number of years. That will leave time for Start 2 to spell out precisely which Star Wars tests should be permitted.
The newly agreed-on U.S. proposal for troop strength in Europe will cut U.S. troops from 305,000 to 225,000, and Soviet troops from 575,000 to 195,000 - leaving the U.S. with an advantage of 30,000. But Eastern European states want all Soviet forces to withdraw from their soil soon. Critics say problems can arise in setting troop ceilings too high.
For example, the new agreement countenances a larger Soviet presence than new East European governments want. That criticism has merit, but Moscow may very well wish to make deeper cuts to satisfy East Europeans or its own economic needs. And neither Mr. Bush nor the NATO allies is eager to negotiate even deeper cuts at this time. A second phase of conventional force talks is the logical place to set lower ceilings.
Only the rarest international agreement covers every contingency. Leaders on both sides must make judgments about priorities. Thus far Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev have, arguably, made the right calls. But as their June summit meeting nears, they will be under pressure to settle even more issues quickly. Their common interest is to resist -and begin talking, soon, about future talks.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: How Japan Can Reduce Its Huge Trade Surplus

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Toshihiko Mori of the Bank of Japan discusses (letter, Feb. 7) an Economic Scene column (Business Day, Jan. 12) that reports me to have placed the blame for the chronic trade deficit of the United States with Japan on both countries. What I said was that the trade balance with Japan cannot be improved by the United States alone. It requires complementary policies by Japan.
Mr. Mori points out that the United States deficit in the balance of payments on current account is equal to the deficiency of United States savings relative to domestic investment. This is a truism and does not show whether the cause runs from a deficiency of savings to the current account deficit or from a current account deficit to the deficiency of savings. 
When a country has a high rate of use of its productive resources, as the United States has, the imbalance arises mainly from a deficiency of savings to the current account deficit. Even then, there may be sectors of the economy, such as the automobile industry, in which a reduction of imports could result in increases in production, in employment, in income and savings.
No one disagrees with the proposition that the United States must increase private savings and reduce the budget deficit to adjust its balance of payments. That, however, will not result in a significant improvement in the trade balance with Japan unless Japan also reduces its savings.
To support this view I cited the increase of United States savings between 1987 and 1989. Over these two years, personal savings increased by $105 billion, and the budget deficit on a national accounts basis was reduced by $12 billion. Increased savings were largely absorbed by an increase in domestic investment, but there was also a reduction in the trade deficit from $160 billion in 1987 to about $112 billion in 1989.
Although the United States trade deficit with Japan is nearly 45 percent of the total deficit, it was reduced by only 9 percent in these two years. By contrast, the trade deficit with the newly industrialized countries of Asia was reduced by 30 percent and the deficit with Western Europe by more than 80 percent.
I emphasized that easing import restrictions would have only a minor effect on the trade deficit, although it would help United States exporters trying to sell to Japan. But if wages of Japanese workers were raised to reflect the value of their work to the economy, or if the foreign-exchange value of the yen were to appreciate to reflect the real international economic position of Japan, the United States trade balance would substantially improve.
Japan is the only large industrial country in which manufacturing wages have increased less in the 1980's than productivity - that is, unit labor costs have fallen. In the United States, unit labor costs in manufacturing increased by 23 percent in the last 10 years, and in Germany they increased even more. To maintain exchange stability, in countries whose relative international economic position has improved, as it has notably in Japan, wages should be increased even more than the increase in productivity in export industries.
To put it simply, workers in Japan are paid less than the economic value of their work. That is one reason personal consumption expenditures in Japan are a far smaller share of the gross national product than in any other large industrial country. Raising the share of wages in the national income would lower the undistributed profits of corporations and reduce the excessive level of savings. It would stimulate consumption of domestic goods and import goods, divert production from export markets to the domestic market and reduce Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States and other countries.
If, for some reason, wages cannot be increased, the yen should be allowed to appreciate. This would restrain exports, encourage a shift in consumption from home goods to import goods, hold down profits and savings, and reduce the trade surplus.
The yen is greatly undervalued because of the outflow of capital from Japan. The direct investment of Japan in the United States is in the interest of both countries. On the other hand, the huge Japanese investment in monetary assets denominated in dollars is not in the long-run interest of either country. Japanese investors have suffered large losses from these holdings, and the excessive amount of such investment has prevented the necessary appreciation of the yen.
Japanese legislation and policies have encouraged such investment. One instance is the forward purchase by Japan Airlines of $4 billion over 11 years at much more than the present rate. If there were an economic justification for this huge forward dollars purchase, Japan Airlines would not have incurred the large loss it has suffered.
 
EDWARD M. BERNSTEIN
 Washington, Feb. 9, 1990
The writer, guest scholar at the Brookings Institution, was director of research at the International Monetary Fund from 1946 to 1958.

HEADLINE: Give Commuters a Break in Deducting Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It has always amazed me when filing income taxes, based on gross income, that no provision is made to deduct the cost of commuting to and from one's place of employment.
Subway and bus fares rise along with the ever-increasing tolls instituted by bridge and tunnel authorities. Higher tolls lead the owners of independent buses that cross state lines automatically to raise fares. Such raises place another burden on commuters who are dependent on this mode of transportation, especially where a company has a mono-poly. A New Jersey line that is said to have one of the highest per-mile travel tariffs in the country has just announced a further increase.
Tolls and fares have risen alarmingly in the last decade, and many commuters pay hundreds, sometimes thousands, of dollars a year in job-related travel without any increase in salary to offset it.
At the same time, the quality of service has not improved and in many cases has even deteriorated. Accusations of mismanagement or misdirection of funds have been leveled, but to no avail. Commuters are the victims of circumstance, with seemingly no recourse, yet they face the prospect of greater travel expenses in the future.
When it comes to gross income and traveling to and from work, the situation can be summed up as nothing less than ''gross.'' An across-the-board method must be found that allows commuters to deduct a reasonable amount from their income taxes. It may be hoped this can be done before travel becomes truly prohibitive for workers and puts another dent in our economy.
 
DAVID B. WILLIAMS
 Bloomfield, N.J., Jan. 25, 1990

HEADLINE: Growth of Revenue Slows in New York

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You erroneously report that New York State tax revenues are ''in sharp decline'' (''Mr. Cuomo, at Least, Is Serious,'' editorial, Jan. 18). Not so. Total tax collections in New York State will increase, even if nothing is done to raise tax rates or impose new taxes.
New York State will not have less to spend than it did last year. However, the state will have less to spend than it had anticipated. This is the cause of the fiscal dilemma facing us. Should we retreat from tax cuts and impose new taxes to make up the difference, or should we live within our means?
It is preposterous for you to suggest that prudence demands new and higher taxes. The need for New York State to recognize the economic realities of slower revenue growth demands consideration of all the alternatives, spending cuts included.
The desire of State Senator Ralph J. Marino, the majority leader, to explore all those alternatives before leaping to embrace higher taxes is a course that you should indeed endorse.
 
CLARENCE D. RAPPLEYEA
Assembly Minority Leader
 Albany, Jan. 28, 1990

HEADLINE: De Klerk, Mandela - and Bush

BYLINE: By Chester A. Crocker; Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs from 1981 to 1989, mediated the Angola-Namibia peace plan.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For decades, we have been told that South Africa's racial conflict is at the stage of five minutes to midnight. For decades, the nation's future has been discussed in grisly scenarios: revolutionary upheaval, enduring white domination, racial partition and Lebanon-style chaos.
Suddenly, something has happened. Since taking office in September -especially last weekend, when he ended Nelson Mandela's 27-year prison sentence - President F. W. de Klerk has opened the first truly new chapter in the country's history since 1948. That was the year when his National Party swept to victory and began implementing apartheid. 
Before we can assess where the current moment will lead, we need to understand how it happened and why it happened now.
Although the significance can easily be overstated, there is a connection between the collapse of the Communist enterprise in Europe and events in South Africa. First, as Moscow disengages from military adventurism abroad, Afrikaner nationalists have been deprived of their external enemy and can now recognize their real problem: coming to terms with all the people of South Africa.
Similarly, the African National Congress and its hosts among the frontline states have lost a revolutionary ally. Violent confrontration and armed struggle always made more sense as a battle cry than as a practical road to liberation in South Africa. That is even more true today. Finally, Marxism, state socialism and one-party rule have been discredited globally; this undercuts their current and would-be practitioners in South Africa.
But the dramatic changes in the East do not offer a model for what will happen in South Africa. The white-minority Government in Pretoria is not capitulating; it has made a sober choice to pursue negotiations. It cannot be swept away by force.
The significance of Mr. de Klerk's boldness lies in his tacit recognition that negotiation can create new facts and fresh openings for compromise, and that negotiation is the only road to legitimacy.
What, then, has caused Mr. de Klerk to move so boldly? First, he represents the younger Afrikaner political generation, which learned the lessons of the 1980's and watched in frustration as former leaders waste one golden opportunity after another. For such people, 10 or 15 years ago the nationalist vision of apartheid had become a nightmare. The 1980's showed that it could not be defended at an acceptable price.
Second, the past three years have brought major improvements in South Africa's regional position. In a fascinating dance of regional diplomacy and military machismo, the rulers of South Africa and Cuba made precisely parallel moves and for parallel reasons: to get away from the quagmire of regional warfare. Maneuvering like scorpions in a bottle, they avoided hurting each other.
The December 1988 Namibia-Angola agreements, mediated by the U.S., transformed the strategic equation in Southern Africa. Now, Cuban forces are returning home from Angola, removing Pretoria's only conventional-warfare threat. This, in turn, makes it possible for South Africa to shed its costly and distracting colonial burden in Namibia, losing nothing of value and leaving in its wake a new neighbor with a negotiated and entrenched democratic constitution. A.N.C. military cadres have been relocated from Angola, the last neighbor still hosting them, while South African soldiers have come home from the regional wars.
Finally, doors have opened to trade, investment and diplomacy in other African countries.
As a result of this process, Pretoria will soon begin to enjoy a substantial peace dividend as resources are reallocated toward South Africa's own massive needs. This prospect, and the extraordinary skill with which Nelson Mandela has communicated his inclusive, reconciling vision to his former jailers - help explain how Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela are liberating each other from their physical and mental prisons.
The third factor in Mr. de Klerk's new thinking is his own readiness to listen to diverse views and reflect on hard and enduring facts. There is nothing new about those facts. Inexorable socio-economic trends have created a more integrated society.
Increasingly, racial laws and policies were neither observed nor enforceable. Unrest, repression and political paralysis in the mid-1980's only reinforced a long-standing economic gloom, converting sporadic capital flight into sustained capital export. Confirming the private sector's vote of ''no confidence,'' the sanctions of the 80's added an external apartheid tax to the huge burdens imposed by bureaucrats and ideologues in Pretoria.
From these considerations, three things are clear. First, the pressure has been growing steadily over decades. What is new is the emergence of a leadership that comprehends the situation and seems to wish to address it now. Like Mikhail Gorbachev, President de Klerk is the product of the party machine in which he was formed and wants to escape from conceptual, ethnic and statist economic prisons.
Second, the pressures for change are overwhelmingly internal. It denigrates the struggle for decency and democracy by generations of black and white South Africans to presume that any particular set of policies by any distant nation can ''end apartheid.'' Thus, this is a time for Americans to restrain our messianic impulses and admit the possibility that the breakthroughs and tragedies occurring around the world are not necessarily the result of some American action or inaction.
But we and other major nation's clearly have choices to make about our roles. President Bush is correct about the need for a review of policy. It must be acknowledged that the U.S is unlikely to have much impact if it fails to rise above past domestic wrangling. Mr. Bush has set precisely the right tone in seeking to remove the partisan poison that has diminished the participants in past debates.
The real issue to be reviewed is not sanctions. It is whether the U.S. should actively seek to foster negotiations now. If so, we would be placing our words and actions in support of the process of negotiation and the parties who participate in it.
The first kind of support can take many forms - making active, substantive use of our excellent channels of communication to all actors; serving as a supplementary catalyst, when appropriate; holding out the promise of tangible U.S. backing for the results of negotiation.
The second kind of support means making a U.S. commitment to negotiators who commit themselves to defining a democratic structure appropriate to the circumstances of their country. It does not mean that we are the ally of any particular side.
If we really want to see negotiations begin, we must avoid linking our discussions of when to lift sanctions to the South African debate about the ''conditions'' for negotiation. That debate could go on and on, especially if outsiders encourage it by taking sides.
At some point soon, a responsible American policy should ask South Africans to get on with it. At that point, we could stop punishing the old South Africa, which Nelson Mandela has done so much to change, and start lending our support to the new South Africa, which he and Mr. de Klerk want to build.

HEADLINE: Eulogy to John Doe, a Symbol of 'All Hurts'

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
It came time yesterday to eulogize the homeless man killed last month on a subway platform at Columbus Circle, and still no one knew his name.
All that could be said about the middle-aged man was that he had appeared violent, disturbed, and something of a loner. And that another middle-aged man, Rodney Sumter, says he killed him out of fear for his life and that of his 3-year-old son.
 
He Is Still Unidentified
Since the homeless man was killed on Jan. 22, records checks have failed to identify him, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner's office. Further investigation could take as long as six months, she said. 
But it appeared yesterday that the symbolism of his death would not wait.
Almost no one came to St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church, on Avenue B opposite Tompkins Square, expressly to mourn John Doe, as the speakers awkwardly called him. The man, who witnesses say spat at Mr. Sumter and hit him for no apparent reason, was not known to have had any friends. The memorial was organized by The Partnership for the Homeless.
Michelle Sumter, Mr. Sumter's wife, came to pay respects, she said. Several homeless people were ushered in from the neighborhood to listen: one left, one asked for change from a man in the next pew, another fell asleep.
But of the problems that the dead man came to embody, there was much to say. So into St. Brigid's filed a handful of advocates for the homeless, for subway riders and for Mr. Sumter, an unemployed construction worker who had himself worked with the homeless. Most of the 30 people in the audience were reporters, photographers and television cameramen.
After rock-and-roll spirituals by a well-amplified church quartet, the pastor of St. Brigid's Church, the Rev. George Kuhn, began a sermon with the observation that he knew almost nothing about the man, save the circumstances of his ''brutal murder.''
 
'Homeless People Are Not Wanted'
Behind dark sunglasses, Mrs. Sumter appeared to fight back tears. And Father Kuhn went on: ''He seems almost, when you think about it a little bit, like a symbol of all of the hurts and violence of this society.''
''Homeless people are not wanted in our country,'' the pastor said. ''We have to say I am ready to give my all so that this does not happen again.''
When the service ended, most of those in attendance recessed to a back corner of St. Brigid's for several interlocking news conferences. The conferees varied in their viewpoints, but agreed that both the man who died and the man who killed him were victims of a faulty system.
Mrs. Sumter at first declined to comment but when microphones were pushed toward her, she said that the killing had traumatized her family.
Her husband, who is charged with first-degree manslaughter, is deeply distraught, she said, and her son will need psychotherapy.
''He still has fear of going into the train station,'' she said. ''It's something that will be with us for the rest of our lives.''
 
Venting His Anger
Peter P. Smith, president of The Partnership For the Homeless, a nonprofit advocacy group, lashed out at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for refusing, he said, to adequately face the problem of homeless people in the subways. He asked that District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau investigate the M.T.A.'s possible culpability in the killing.
Roy Innis, national chairman of the Congress On Racial Equality, vented anger, he said, on behalf of both Mr. Sumter and common people around the city.
''The million or so riders who ride the subway and the millions more who walk the streets are conflicted,'' he said, concerned about the homeless but uncertain how to deal with unpredictable and irascible homeless people like the man Mr. Sumter killed.
And Mr. Sumter's lawyer, Simeon Greenaway, charged the District Attorney's office with ''a compounding of the tragedy,'' by prosecuting his client.
 
'Exploiting the Death'
Mr. Innis said that Mr. Sumter had wanted to attend the memorial. He was advised against coming to avoid ''the impression of exploiting the death of John Doe.''
Early yesterday morning, few people at the Columbus Circle subway station said they had any memory of the dead man.
''He was all over,'' said one porter who recalled the man vividly, and asked not to be identified. ''But this was one of his main stations that he used to come to.''
People living in the station say its tunnels and stairwells have little to recommend them save the soft, malodorous heat that fills them in winter. While the transit police occasionally harass them, few others seem to show any concern for them at all, they say.
The porter, who did not want to be identified, placed the dead man in a category different from most of those cocooned in sacks of old clothing, dreaming on the stiff wooden benches and chilled concrete floors.
Often, the porter said, Mr. Sumter's aggressor, a short, heavyset man in his late 50's or early 60's, would stretch out next to young women and verbally abuse them.
''Every time I cleaned up, he'd go in and pull out the trash bags and throw them on the floor,'' the porter said. ''He'd walk around in people's face, cursing. You couldn't carry on a conversation with him. He was different from the other ones - violent.''
On the steps leading up to the station's 57th Street and 8th Avenue exit, a stooped man who called himself Robert took a hit from a crack pipe and pondered the man's end.
''I'll tell you,'' Robert said. ''He had no right spitting on anybody. That's what they say he did. But the guy had no business killing him. People are always harassing us.''

HEADLINE: Dinkins Present as Labor Talks Start

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Breaking with tradition, Mayor David N. Dinkins appeared yesterday at the first negotiating session on a new contract with municipal workers and warned that New York City's fiscal problems would require ''tough decisions.''
But after a brief statement in which he assured city workers that they were ''politically and philosphically'' important to him, Mr. Dinkins turned the talks over to the professional negotiating team and departed.
''With the fiscal difficulties I inherited, and which came to light only after I took office,'' Mr. Dinkins said, ''the outcome of negotiations has become even more critical, not simply for me, but for all New Yorkers.'' 
 
Trying to 'Set a Tone'
The session was held in the 14th Street headquarters of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which is negotiating on behalf of its 6,000 members, from lawyers to blacksmiths. Mr. Dinkins attended the session at the request of Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237, who is a longtime political supporter.
In the past, mayors have tried to stay away from the bargaining table, to avoid blame if talks go badly and to avoid the appearance of undermining their negotiators. Mayor Koch, according to former city negotiators, took part in critical negotiations only once, in 1980, when police officers were threatening job actions.
Mr. Dinkins told reporters that he wanted to ''set a tone'' for the talks and did not plan to become involved personally.
But he faces a problem. After six weeks in office he has not hired a chief negotiator. Several labor officials said he had discussed the job with Harold Ickes, a labor lawyer and top campaign adviser.
Contracts for the teamsters and police officers, firefighters and sanitation workers expire on June 30, while contracts for most other city workers expire in the fall. This year's negotiations have been complicated by a slowing economy that has cut into city revenues and produced a budget gap of $450 million this fiscal year and nearly $1.2 billion in the year that begins July 1. #17 Percent Rise Sought So far, the city has included a reserve of 1.5 percent a year for increased labor costs. In yesterday's talks, Mr. Feinstein proposed a contract that would provide almost 17 percent in raises and new benefits over two years.
This includes a general salary increase at the projected rate of inflation, 2 percentage points for workers whose salaries lag behind others in comparable jobs and 1.7 percent to set up an annuity fund of $3 a day to supplement the retirement of city workers.
Each percentage point increase in a labor settlement costs the city more than $100 million if extended to all municipal workers, according to city officials. So 17 percent could cost the city more than $1.7 billion over two years.
Mr. Feinstein said that during the Koch administration he frequently called the Mayor and top city officials while negotiations were under way, and he did not think anything would change now.
''I don't have any sense that the fact that David Dinkins knows us is going to make any difference in what he does,'' Mr. Feinstein said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 21, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about New York City's labor negotiations misidentified a segment of the membership of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Local 237 negotiates on behalf of horseshoers, not blacksmiths. Blacksmiths are represented by Local 5 of the International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers.

HEADLINE: F. R. Collbohm, 83, Ex-Head of Rand, Dies

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 13

 BODY:
Franklin R. Collbohm, an aviation engineer who became the founding president of the Rand Corporation, the nonprofit research organization, died Monday at his home here, three weeks after a suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old. Mr. Collbohm, who studied engineering at the University of Wisconsin, worked for the Douglas Aircraft Corporation at Santa Monica, Calif,, on designs for the Douglas DC-1, DC-2 and DC-3 aircraft. 
In 1946, while still an employee of Douglas, he was asked by Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces in World War II, to consider assembling a talent pool to study long-range problems.
In 1948, Mr. Collbohm broke Rand away from Douglas, establishing it as an independent, not-for-profit corporation that specialized in scientific research related to national security.
Mr. Collbohm retired from Rand, which is based in Santa Monica, in 1967.
A widower, he is survived by two sons, Robert of Santa Monica and Carl of Middleburg, Fla., two sisters, a brother and a granddaughter.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
American education has a new buzzword: restructuring.
It's not exactly clear what the term means. Indeed, everyone who uses it seems to have something different in mind. The common thread appears to be that recent efforts to improve public schools have fallen short and that some drastic new strategies are necessary. 
''To improve our schools we need a total redesign of our educational system,'' said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States.
Mr. Newman was the principal organizer last week when more than 150 governors, state legislators and educators from across the country convened in Baltimore to brainstorm on restructuring. The session was sponsored by the National Governors' Association and the commission, a federally supported organization that coordinates the education policies of the 50 states.
The 1980's was a decade of school reform. Inspired in part by a 1983 report, ''A Nation at Risk,'' by the National Commission on Excellence in Education, virtually every state legislature enacted new policies ranging from tighter course requirements for high school diplomas to higher pay for teachers.
Now, a growing number of political and educational leaders are concluding that those efforts were not enough. As Gov. Michael Castle of Delaware, a Republican, told the meeting, education spending has increased by 29 percent in the last eight years but ''the test scores in the United States of America are the same.''
''We need to restructure our schools,'' Mr. Castle said. ''More of the same will not bring the results we need.''
A logical first step, many people agree, is to decentralize the management of schools - something that is already under way in a number of large city school systems. Joseph A. Fernandez, the new Schools Chancellor in New York City, earned a national reputation as superintendent in Miami by creating a network of schools run by management teams consisting of the principal, teachers and, in some cases, parents and representatives of the local community. He plans to push a similar program in New York City.
Beyond the decentralizing of schools, restructuring can mean just about anything. The Bush Administration has given a high priority to school choice, a system under which parents would pick the public school their children would attend. The assumption is that by forcing competition the schools would be encouraged to become better.
Others define the heart of restructuring as changing what happens in classrooms. Theodore Sizer, a professor of education at Brown University, has worked with dozens of schools seeking to cut down lecturing by teachers and to encourage students to take a more active part in their own learning. Mr. Castle urged the development of ''new ways of measuring student progress'' and new ways to ''better and differently train teachers.'' Still others look to computers and other forms of new technology as the basis of restructuring, using them to help in instruction.
No one believes that the path to restructured schools will be either straight or smooth. In Rochester, for example, efforts to create management teams in local schools drew an unsuccesful lawsuit from principals and other middle managers, who argued that the change usurped contractually guaranteed management functions. Mr. Fernandez could face a similar challenge in New York City.
Thomas Dornan, president of the North Carolina Forum for Education, recounted an incident in that state where the finance director for a local school district refused to set up a fund to be controlled by the staff of a local school. ''It took a letter from the state controller to free up the money,'' Mr. Dornan said.
Indeed, it is by no means clear how many American teachers even want the new responsibilities that come with decentralized schools. Adam Urbansky, president of the teachers union in Rochester, noted that most teachers have been trained to go along with policies enacted at higher levels. He estimated that no more than a slight majority of his members are enthusiastic about the powers they enjoy under their current contract.
For such reasons Marc Tucker, director of the National Center for Education in the Economy, argued that restructuring - whatever concrete forms it takes - involves nothing less than a ''cultural transformation'' of public schools.
''Executives who have decentralized big corporations will tell you that this is what they did,'' he said. ''They radically changed people's attitudes about the organization and their role in it. Gorbachev is trying to do the same thing in the Soviet Union, trying to mobilize masses of people who have never had much control of their lives and aren't sure how to handle it when given the opportunity. The same thing has to occur in our schools. They call it perestroika. We call it restructuring.''

HEADLINE: Women's Game Draws Rising Crowd Support

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY

 BODY:
On Saturday night at Seattle, more than 7,000 spectators watched Washington upset Stanford in women's basketball. On Sunday afternoon at West Lafayette, Ind., more than 13,000 watched Iowa upset Purdue in women's basketball. Both games were televised nationally and not blacked out locally and still drew large crowds.
Those attendance figures tell much about the rapid climb of college basketball for women. Starting in the 1970's, the Federal government's Title IX program required colleges to provide equal funding for women's sports. Before that, few colleges had women's basketball teams. Now colleges that have men's teams invariably have women's teams. 
''Women's basketball is a highly skilled, highly competitive game,'' said Coach Pat Head Summitt of Tennessee yesterday.
''I think the game is doing great,'' said Coach Tara VanDerveer of Stanford. ''Play is improving and can get better.''
Summitt and VanDerveer spoke at the Grand Hyatt Hotel yesterday in Manhattan at a National Collegiate Athletic Association symposium on women's basketball. The panel included coaches and players from Stanford (20-1), Tennessee (19-4), Purdue (17-4) and St. Joseph's of Philadelphia (18-4), four of the nation's leading teams.
 
Play Is Under the Rim
All speakers agreed that the level of play had risen dramatically.
''You can see it every year,'' said Jennifer Azzi, Stanford's all-America shooting guard. ''Crowds are getting bigger. People are getting excited. The Final Four will be in Knoxville this year, and there's already a big billboard on the Interstate advertising it.''
In many ways, women's basketball is different from men's. Women's games can be intense and competitive, and a 30-second clock keeps the ball moving. But women cannot dunk the ball, so they do not have a Michael Jordan or a Dominique Wilkins to play over the rim. They cannot run as fast or jump as high as men.
''That doesn't mean I can't jump or can't run,'' Azzi said. ''I can shoot as well as a man. I know because I work out with men in the off season. So people who don't think a girl can play basketball are crazy.''
VanDerveer said she was often asked how the women's game compared with the men's.
 
'Team Game'
''It's a fair question,'' she said, ''but there are so many variables. Our game is so young, and so much is new. I didn't play high school basketball because my school didn't have a team. I didn't have any role models growing up. Now millions of young girls are playing and watching us and have role models.
''We play on the same court as the men, but is a comparison fair? Is it fair to compare college men with the pros? The pros may have higher skill levels, but in college you see more teamwork. The college and the pro games are different for the men, and the games for college men and college women are different, too.
''I think we have more of a team game, with more screening, more passing. Our game is still new. I don't know if we will ever be as - I don't want to say accepted - as men's basketball, but I don't know that we have to compare our game with the men's. If our games are played well, people will want to watch.''
Television is showing more women's games than ever, so the audience is greater. But the sport has not had a big-name player since Cheryl Miller in the mid-1980's, and no American professional league has been able to survive.
''When I graduate this year,'' Azzi said, ''I hope to play overseas, maybe Italy. For a season of six or seven months, I can make $50,000 to $150,000 plus an apartment and a car. So I might make more money out of that than from my degree in economics. But it's too bad I can't stay in the United States and play pro ball here. Maybe some day.'' Lack of Exposure While women's basketball may have a long way to go, it has come a long way.
''We haven't had exposure,'' VanDerveer said. ''At Stanford, the team has been in existence only 15 years.''
''We're in the early stages,'' said Coach Lin Dunn of Purdue. ''Our school has been giving scholarships only four years.''
''We're young,'' Summitt said. ''We have to remember that.''
Still, there is obvious pride in the product.
''Some people have told me they enjoy the way we play more than the men,'' said Coach Jim Foster of St. Joseph's ''If you like basketball and like fundamentals, women's basketball is a pure joy to watch. We're the best-kept secret in the country.''

LENGTH: 1036 words

HEADLINE: Satisfying Menages a Trois: Husbands, Wives Restaurants

BYLINE: By ANN BARRY

 BODY:
''WHEN gourmandism is shared,'' the French gastronome Brillat-Savarin wrote, ''it has the most marked influence on the happiness which can be found in marriage. A married couple who enjoy the pleasures of the table have . . . a subject of conversation which is ever new; they can talk not only of what they are eating, but also of what they have eaten, what they will eat, and what they have noticed at other tables.''
Many marriages depend on shared interests, of course, but for husband-and-wife teams in the demanding restaurant business - a work day can run from 9 A.M. until well past midnight - can there be too much of a good thing?
Interviews with a dozen husband-and-wife restaurant teams suggest that the balancing of business and personal lives requires a well-defined division of responsibilities founded on talents and preferences. 
Usually the wife commands the front of the house, dealing with patrons and reservations and supervising the dining room staff, while the husband serves as chef, ordering the food and managing the kitchen staff. The sparks tend to fly if one invades the other's territory, especially at an inappropriate or stressful moment.
Robert and Mimi Del Grande have operated Cafe Annie in Houston for eight years. ''If you end up competing with each other to do the same things, you've got problems,'' Mr. Del Grande said. ''Our areas of expertise are so different; it's a finely tuned thing.''
Certain issues may be discussed in concert - a new dish, a troublesome employee - but typically the final word lies with the person whose domain it is. ''It's a matter of mutual respect,'' Ms. Del Grande said.
Barbara Lazaroff, who with her husband, Wolfgang Puck, operates Spago and Chinois on Main in Los Angeles, describes the same notion as a constant attempt to ''compartmentalize'' life.
''The hardest thing is to separate the personal persona from the work persona,'' she said. ''Any business between two people shouldn't become a sexual battleground. When a business discourse gets personal, you're off the track at that point. Wolf has said you shouldn't take business home. I say you shouldn't take home to the business.
''This, of course, is nearly impossible. So what I'm talking about is a semblance of balance.''
Privacy is precious for a restaurant couple. A few wedge in a quick lunch, keeping the staff at bay; others consider a walk or taxi ride home at the end of the day a blessed retreat. But views varied as to the nature of their communication.
While the food business can be an exhilarating source of discussion, some admit to a fear of becoming Brillat-Savarin's couple in extremis. ''We realized we weren't having a real conversation, even though we were talking all day long,'' said Deann Bayless who, with her husband, Rick, owns the Frontera Grill in Chicago. ''There was not any personal communication. Part of the solution is just accepting the fact that it's a different kind of relationship. And we work hard to make personal time away from the restaurant.''
Barry Wine of the Quilted Giraffe in New York, who has been in the business with his wife, Susan, for 14 years, sees it in a different light: ''If Susan and I are debating, even though it's in the context of the restaurant industry, we're really talking academic issues. Building a restaurant is a design issue, having our own farm for vegetables and flowers is an agricultural interest, the concept of a service charge becomes a sociological-political-economic matter.''
As a consequence of the continual flow of conversation, a restaurant couple doesn't experience the typical ''Hi, how was your day?'' syndrome.
Margaret Fox, who owns Cafe Beaujolais in Mendocino, Calif., where her husband, Christopher Kump, is chef, said: ''Spending so many hours under the same roof, you already know so much that has happened in the other person's life. So when you have the chance to be together, it doesn't have the impact. The relationship is diluted through exposure, and conversation can be diminished to restaurant patter.''
A restaurant team's social life is clearly affected by the rigors of the profession. Most of the couples said their close friends simply accepted the limits. On a day off, most couples did not feel up to entertaining except in the most casual way, and either preferred to loll about at home or meet friends out for dinner.
What constitutes a social life, however, has numerous interpretations. Many try to incorporate a social engagement with friends in their restaurant. John and Sally Darr, who have been married 34 years and in partnership at La Tulipe in Greenwich Village for 11 years, set aside Friday evenings to dine with friends at their restaurant. Yet it has a professional edge: to critique the operation from the patrons' viewpoint.
The Wines regard their staff as something of an enlarged family. Their dinner with the kitchen staff late every afternoon is thus a social occasion - albeit, only a half-hour or so. But Frank and Frances Stitt, who operate the Highlands Bar and Grill in Birmingham, Ala., separate their social life from the restaurant. ''Friends are not in the restaurant business,'' Mrs. Stitt said. ''We rarely socialize with people we work with.''
The addition of children in a couple's life (the home is usually near the business) has a great impact, mainly, it seems, on the wife. ''It continues to be a very difficult balancing act,'' Ms. Stitt said. ''Sometimes I feel I'm not good at any of my jobs because I can't devote a hundred percent of the time to the job, or to the child or to my husband.''
Not all restaurant marriages stand the test of time. Ultimately, what keeps many couples together is friendship. ''We'd be divorced if one of us was in another business,'' said George Germon, who with his wife, Joanne Killeen, owns Il Forno and Lucky's in Providence, R.I. ''With the kind of demands of the business, we would never see each other.''
''We both love the business,'' Ms. Killeen said. ''We are both committed. There's something wonderful about having the same goals. To have a buddy along the way to reach your dream, to have someone you can trust completely, is a very satisfying situation.''

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:

Record Enrollment?
In an average week, a publisher might sign contracts for anywhere from two to five new books, but it is rare to have a week as productive as Random House had recently, when it acquired books by seven high-profile authors.
Walter Wriston, the retired chairman of Citicorp, will write about ways in which new technology is going to change the world as profoundly as did the Industrial Revolution. And William Styron, the novelist, in a book entitled ''Darkness Visible,'' will describe his struggle with depression, a struggle that involved committing himself to a mental hospital in the winter of 1985-86. 
Nonfiction works on undisclosed subjects will be written by Brandon Tartikoff, the president of NBC Entertainment; David Rockefeller Sr., the retired chairman of Chase Manhattan, and Gail Sheehy, journalist and author of the best-selling ''Passages: Predictable Crises of Adult Life.''
J. M. Coetzee, the South African author, has a new novel, set in his homeland, entitled ''Age of Iron,'' And Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49ers quarterback, will write his autobiography.
Joni Evans, the publisher of Random House, said that while all the negotiations were concluded in the same week, some of the books had been under discussion for several years. Some were acquired in auctions, each author was represented by a different literary agent, and the books will be edited by five different Random House editors. Moreover, while some of the books will not be published for a couple of years, the Styron, Wriston, Coetzee and Montana books may be published next fall.
''It's wonderful when projects you've been involved in for years finally work out,'' Ms. Evans said. ''But it's even more memorable when so many important projects work out in the same week.''
 
Updating the Ending
''Ivana Trump: A Very Unauthorized Biography,'' by Norman King, is listed in the Carrol & Graf catalogue for publication in July. ''We're still going to publish on time,'' said Kent Carrol, the publisher. But in view of the recent breakup of Ivana and Donald J. Trump's marriage, Mr. Carrol added, ''The author is furiously writing a new last chapter.''
 
Sun Also Rises
Simon & Schuster has acquired world rights to ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' an expanded, revised version of a much-debated book that is a best seller in Japan. The author, Shintaro Ishihara, a legislator and former Government official, contends that Japan holds the technological balance of power in the world, and must therefore no longer be deferential to the United States. In his view, Japan is on the rise and the United States is declining.
The book, scheduled for publication here next winter, has been widely circulated in Washington in an unauthorized translation. Richard E. Snyder, chairman and chief executive officer of Simon & Schuster, said that Mr. Ishihara voiced ''powerful, nationalistic themes,'' but he added that the book would be very important ''for Americans and Europeans to read carefully.''
Mr. Ishihara's co-author on the Japanese edition was Akio Morita, the chairman of the Sony Corporation. But Mr. Morita, who has admitted to having had differences with Mr. Ishihara, will not be involved with the version to be published by Simon & Schuster.
 
Rights-Abuse Works
Yale University Press and Human Rights Watch recently announced a joint publishing program to distribute more widely reports on human rights abuses around the world.
The Human Rights Watch, created in 1987, is the umbrella organization for Africa Watch, Americas Watch, Asia Watch, Helsinki Watch and Middle East Watch. Those committees issue periodic reports of human rights abuses in their region, based on fact-fnding missions by lawyers, journalists and government officials. In addition, Human Rights Watch publishes an annual ''State of the World'' volume, as well as books on torture, prison conditions and related topics.
Human Rights Watch will continue preparing those reports, but Yale will begin offering the co-published books and reports beginning with its fall 1991 list. Yale will also be responsible for design and production of the books. The J. M. Kaplan Fund, a charitable organization with headquarters in Manhattan, is providing about $40,000 to help finance the program.
 
A Ken Kesey Flurry
Ken Kesey, the author of ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' has signed a contract with Viking for a novel about Alaska, to be published in the fall of 1991. Meanwhile, three other books by Mr. Kesey will have been published by Viking or Penguin by the end of this year.
The Alaska novel, tentatively called ''Sailor Song,'' is set in the next century at an economically depressed fishing village, at which a Hollywood movie company arrives to make a motion picture of a classic children's book.
Penguin recently published ''Caverns,'' a mystery set in 1934 that Mr. Kesey wrote in collaboration with the 13 members of his graduate writing seminar at the University of Oregon. In October, Viking will publish ''The Further Inquiry,'' about Neal Cassady, the noted figure of the Beat generation. Also in October, Viking will publish Mr. Kesey's ''Little Tricker the Squirrel Meets Big Double the Bear,'' a story that the author has often performed with the accompaniment of a trio or a full symphony orchestra.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Twisting Road of Humor To an Imperial America

BYLINE: By Herbert Mitgang

 BODY:

Emperor of America
By Richard Condon
300 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
Who would dare to combine the styles of the ''Manchurian Candidate'' and ''Prizzi's Honor,'' more or less, and invent a character who heads the Royalty Party, not in Naples but in the United States? None other than Richard Condon in his latest sendup of the American scene and Presidency. 
In ''Emperor of America,'' his 23d novel, Mr. Condon is a little more hortatory than usual. He seems to be warning readers against electing a kingly ruler, as Sinclair Lewis once did in his cautionary anti-dictator novel, ''It Can't Happen Here,'' about a flag-waving general in the White House. Mr. Condon obviously aims to be serious, but he can't help it if his writing is outrageous. He keeps putting English on the eight ball, giving his story screwy turns.
''Emperor of America'' is written with a wink and a smirk and the confidence of an author who has resolved that he's not going to hold back his strong opinions, not at his exuberant age of 74, even if they come across like rabbit punches.
Without giving away every detail of the convoluted plot, it can be revealed that Mr. Condon is not an admirer of the former President and First Lady, Ronald and Nancy Reagan, who play more than cameo roles in his satire. He doesn't even like their pet, whom he calls a ''dear little rented dog.'' They are mentioned at least a dozen times during the establishment of the fictional imperial presidency.
The time is March 18, 1990. At 11:04 A.M. on that day next month, a nuclear device is exploded in Washington, wiping out the District of Columbia and evaporating 1,397,200 people. The catastrophe causes the White House to vanish, demolishes the Capitol and destroys every national building but the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency. The Royalist Party shares responsibility with the National Rifle Association for causing the atomic explosion.
Afterward, news is sent out by the television networks in the form of daily mass exorcisms that were started, Mr. Condon writes, ''by the Reagan Administration (1981-1989): the constant moral bloopers; the Grenada mockery; the Lebanese disasters; the Iran-contra scandals; the Persian Gulf debacles; the Libya fixation; the Supreme Court appointment messes; Congressional committee exposures; the charges, arraignments and indictments of high Federal officials beyond any count of corruption in White House history.''
Here is the country's mood after the bomb: ''The Royalists had best access to where the American people lived; that vast diamond-bright area of daytime television and prime-time soap.'' He continues, ''The Reagan Administration - that shining definition of reigning glamour and romance associated with queens, big money, great dressmakers, great poverty, colorful (moderate) mullahs, glamorous (if shocking) scandals and entertaining South American drug lords - had overtaken the national imagination of a society which had been compartmentalized by money.'' Naming names, ''The yuppie virus, which had been fed by the decade of Ron and Nancy, the bull market and eight unrelenting years of political fantasy, struck as AIDS had struck.''
But follow the money and the military. How does an Army colonel, Caesare Appleton, become the first Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the United States and then Emperior Caesare I? Blame Nicaragua, which the author calls ''an evil empire,'' for his rise to power. With breeding techniques, the Sandinistas swell their population from 3 million in 1980 to 21 million people, ''almost all of them fierce males who wanted to invade and occupy the United States, rape the flower of American womanhood, desecrate the flag and ban the Pledge of Allegiance from all American schoolrooms.''
Colonel Appleton beats the Sandinistas on the battlefields of Portugal and Southeast Asia, becomes a national hero and takes over as a Royalist. It helps, of course, that his manipulative mother gets him to sign up with the William Morris Agency to make money and a name for himself.
In case of doubt about how Mr. Condon feels about the former President, some of his characters pause now and then to emphasize his views indelicately: ''Ronald Reagan was the greatest President this country has ever produced. He gave us the F.B.I. race wars, the Qaddafi bombings, the 'Star Wars' flapdoodle, the Grenada farce, the Bitburg shaming, the endless bank failures, the Lebanon disasters, the crumbling national airlines, the rape of HUD, the oligarchy of Big Oil, insured inflation and the shoring up of sinister Israeli politicians - all to keep our people diverted and entertained until the Royalty Party could consolidate its position.''
And that's not all. The novel also includes cocaine, rape, the mafia, abortion, a House of Lords in Dallas (where the author lives), sibling rivalry, momism and a huge statue erected on Government grounds to former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew. By the end of ''Emperor of America,'' Mr. Condon has had more fun than anybody; most of the time his humor is wild enough to work.

The Collapse of Drexel
Drexel Burnham Lambert began selling its securities and its parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The moves mark the demise of a firm that had come to symbolize the fast-money years on Wall Street. [Page A1.] 
It is the end of an era in which speculative debt became Wall Street's stock in trade. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [A1.]
Unlike banks, securities firms are not answerable to any Government agency with the authority to supervise them in their entirety. News Analysis. [D5.] The Federal Reserve and S.E.C. worked to limit damage to the financial markets. [D5.]

HEADLINE: A Big Chicago Realty Firm Stops Paying Some Bills

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 13

 BODY:
One of the nation's largest real estate firms said today that many of its commercial properties were so troubled financially that it had no choice but to stop paying certain bills.
The announcement by VMS Realty Partners, which last fall valued its properties at more than $9 billion, was both a commentary on the poor health of the real estate industry and on VMS's condition in particular.
As property markets have sunk into recession in the Southwest, the Southeast and the Northeast, hundreds of developers have filed for bankrupcty and real estate lenders have seen their portfolios of bad loans grow. The announcement by VMS is the latest indication that real estate in many regions remains depressed. 
The announcement seemed to suggest that VMS was in such difficult straits that it was more prudent to postpone paying bills than to continue depleting cash. It left unclear, however, whether its difficulties were so severe that the firm might have to file for bankruptcy.
But experts who have followed the firm said its prospects were grim.
 
Position of Xerox
Today's action may also reflect a desire by the Xerox Corporation, one of VMS's four general partners, to limit its exposure to losses from the firm. Xerox originally committed $200 million to VMS and increased that in November by extending a $125 million line of credit. By no longer making nonessential payments to outsiders, however, VMS has presumably stopped its cash outflow. That, in turn, could help Xerox salvage part of its investment.
In its heyday in the early 1980's, VMS was one of the largest real estate syndicators, raising more than $1.5 billion through more than 100 real-estate limited partnerships. The firm's properties include the Boca Raton Hotel in Florida and the Omni Park Hotel in New York.
Some real estate professionals said VMS had been far too optimistic in its assumptions about future rents and property values.
''I'm not sure, but I would bet 100 to 1 that VMS will not be around for long,'' said Scott Miller, a Houston-based consultant who has followed VMS for years.
VMS's decision to hold non-essential payments will directly affect suppliers that provide it with short-term credit. The biggest impact, however, will be felt by the eight publicly traded real estate investment trusts that VMS sponsored beginning in 1986, after tax law changes wreaked havoc with VMS's core limited-partnership business.
 
Borrowing From Trusts
VMS borrowed more than $1 billion from the trusts to purchase a broad array of commerial properties, including hotels and office buildings. Now that VMS is facing a cash crisis, the trusts will not get paid anywhere near the amounts they are due.
For some time, many VMS properties have been in such bad shape that the firm has had no choice but to make cash advances to keep them current on their obligations.
In such a fashion, the trust investors were able to receive a return on their mortgage loans and the banks that lent against VMS properties received payments. But with today's announcement, VMS has effectively said that, in its view, it no longer makes financial sense for the firm to continue pouring money into properties that are not showing signs of improvement.
It will now be up to the various lenders involved - the banks, the trusts and others - to hold talks and decide how to divide what little positive cash flow the properties generate.
Today's announcement was considered a surprise. In November, the firm's new chief executive, Jeffrey A. Park, said VMS, while troubled, was solvent and not facing a cash crisis. VMS sent letters to a number of its investors suggesting that the firm's prospects were encouraging.
Investors today bid down the price of the trusts' shares. The VMS Mortgage Investment Fund, fell 57 percent on the New York Stock Exchange to $1.625, down $2.125. The VMS Hotel Investment Fund, traded on the American Exchange under the symbol VHT, fell 43 percent, to $1.625, down $1.25.
