LENGTH: 1732 words

HEADLINE: Intel: Supplier Rising As a Big Competitor

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HILLSBORO, Ore.

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation, once just a supplier of chips to computer makers, is increasingly becoming their competitor, making everything from personal computers to supercomputers. Some of Intel's customers are grumbling, but industry analysts say the diversification makes sense for a company that already makes the most complicated and important part in a computer.
Intel has quietly operated its computer systems business since 1975. While this unit historically concentrated on add-on boards and computers for industrial uses, it has diversified broadly in the last two years, and it now accounts for a bit less than 30 percent of the company's $3.2 billion in revenues, Intel says. Already a big producer of personal computers, Intel last month announced both a new supercomputer and a line of computer work stations aimed at the technical market.
Intel's computer business sells primarily to original equipment manufacturers, companies that resell its machines under their names, sometimes packaged with proprietary software or other equipment. Big resellers of Intel's personal computers include the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Unisys Corporation. 
 
Customers Are Uncomfortable
Such arrangements do not please companies that make their own machines using Intel microprocessors and memory chips. Companies including Compaq Computer, Zenith Data Systems and AST Research have complained about Intel's entry into their business. They say they are uncomfortable competing with a big supplier.
Intel executives say personal computers are both a logical extension of their core business and a response to customer demands. In recent years, some customers that once bought only chips and later bought circuit boards have begun to buy complete computers. If Intel did not supply these customers, a third party would, the Intel executives add.
''It's almost a misnomer today to say that Intel is a computer component and systems company,'' said Leslie Vadasz, president of the Intel Systems Group, which is based in Hillsboro, a suburb of Portland. ''We are a computer company delivering our product in different levels of packaging.''
 
Same Power, Fewer Chips
As semiconductor technology has advanced, placing ever more transistors on a single chip, so the number of chips in a personal computer has declined, from about 170 plus memory in 1984 to 10 plus memory today for the same level of performance. Some Intel officials think the number could drop to one chip plus memory by 1993.
With fewer chips, manufacturing a computer becomes a simpler process. As this shift occurs, the percentage of a machine's value contributed by Intel increases while that of the computer manufacturer declines, making it more worthwhile for some companies to buy finished machines than to support the manufacturing capacity to build them. Ultimately, personal computers could be like videocassette recorders, where a handful of manufacturers produce all the machines, regardless of what brand name is on the box.
As the maker of the microprocessor, which is the most important and most technically complex piece in a personal computer, Intel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., is in an unusually strong position to build upon its expertise - in part because the International Business Machines Corporation made its personal computer an open system, one that that can be cloned or copied by other manufacturers.
The other big chip makers in the United States do not have a microprocessor comparable to Intel's. Motorola Inc., which makes the microprocessor used in Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh, cannot become a computer maker as easily because Apple does not tolerate clones. Motorola microprocessors are also used in work stations and in file servers, computers that operate networks; to date Motorola has made some file server products, but no work stations.
 
Largest Supplier of PC's
For those companies in the market that lack the manufacturing prowess of an I.B.M. or Compaq, Intel is well positioned to manufacture whole machines. Indeed, for original equipment manufacturers, Intel is already the largest supplier of PC's using 32-bit microprocessors, like its 386 and 486 chips.
Computer makers that still prefer to build are worried by this strength, as well as by their new position as rivals of their important supplier.
Intel ''moving into the systems business puts us on a collision course,'' said John P. Frank, president of Zenith Data Systems, a unit of Groupe Bull of France and a big Intel customer. ''It is not good business to compete with your best customers.
While many customers complain about Intel's competing with them, ''Intel can get away with it because customers have no choice,'' said Michael Slater, editor of the Microprocessor Report, an industry newsletter based in Palo Alto, Calif. Intel has a monopoly on the microprocessors used in the latest generation of personal computers from I.B.M., Compaq and other manufacturers.
 
'A Messy Situation'
''Intel says we only sell to original equipment manufacturers, as if their own customers don't sell to O.E.M.'s and as if the O.E.M.'s that buy those products don't sell into the same customer base,'' Mr. Slater said. ''It's a messy situation.''
Andrew S. Grove, Intel's president and chief executive, acknowledges the conflict, but says it is unavoidable. ''At a given time that we have I.B.M. resolutely buying at the chip level, there are other major companies, such as A.T.&T., which have decided to out-source'' whole machines, he said. He continued, ''Between I.B.M. and A.T.&T. I don't want to make a choice; I want to supply both of them.''
He added: ''It's easy for me to understand that we are doing things our customers would rather have us not do. Doing this puts an extra responsibility on us; we have to play this game on a meticulously level playing field, with absolute integrity.''
 
Not Favoring the Systems Group
Accordingly, the Intel Systems Group is treated like any other big chip customer with regard to pricing and allocation. For example, it was not the first to receive shipments of the new 486 chip last year.
Customers say that in this regard Intel has played fair, which has helped make its entry in their business tolerable. If Intel began playing favorites with its own systems unit, some companies say they would have to consider shifting to other manufacturers' microprocessors.
While customers complain, securities analysts praise Intel's move. Because the capital costs of computer assembly plants are so much lower than those of semiconductor fabrication, increasing revenues through computer manufacturing is more cost-effective for Intel than adding semiconductor capacity, they say. Noting the companies that have grown large and profitable selling machines based on Intel's microprocessors, they say it is natural for Intel to enter this business.
 
Building PC's 'Makes Sense'
Rajiv Chaudri, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, said: ''The value in a PC is in the semiconductors; the most valuable semiconductor is the microprocessor, and that is theirs. Between the $200 microprocessor and the $5,000 box there is not a lot of technological value added. This is something that both opportunistically and strategically makes sense for Intel.''
Thomas J. Thornhill, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton in Larkspur, Calif., estimated that Intel's systems business accounted for $812 million in 1989, or about 26 percent of the company's $3.2 billion in revenues; he expects it to earn a little more than $1 billion in 1990. ''I would expect the Systems Group would have lower income-statement margins than the semiconductor business, but the rate of return on capital is very attractive,'' he said.
As a logical extension of its PC business, Intel recently introduced three work stations. Like the personal computers, these machines are based on its 386 and 486 microprocessors, but they operate on the Unix software operating system rather than MS-DOS, and they are aimed at technical rather than business customers. Like Intel's personal computers, the work stations will be sold through original equipment manufacturers and will compete primarily with the products of Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company. Both are Intel customers.
Intel also sells a line of add-on boards for enhancing a personal computer's performance - the only products it sells to retail stores under its own name - and a series of specialized computers for communications and network purposes. Its most ambitious offering is the iPSC 860 supercomputer, which uses multiple microprocessors to offer performance the company says exceeds that of the most powerful conventional supercomputers. This machine does not compete directly with the products of any Intel customers.
Not every Intel Systems business succeeds. An early venture in digital watches was an expensive flop, and last year the company decided to abandon Biin, a joint venture formed with Siemens A.G. to develop a powerful computer for business customers based on multiple microprocessors. The company said the cost of continuing the effort would have exceeded the potential return.
 
Prospects for Growth
Despite its diversification, Intel's systems business has consistently remained under 30 percent of the total revenues of the company, largely because of the runaway growth of its microprocessor business. The success can be credited largely to Intel's technical prowess - it invented the microprocessor, the dynamic random access memory chip and the electronically programmable read-only memory chip, all in 1971 - and the adoption of Intel's microprocessor by I.B.M. for its personal computers.
Looking forward, Dr. Grove said the systems business's growth was tied to the rate at which United States and European companies pulled out of manufacturing. ''The faster it erodes, the faster Systems will be a larger portion of Intel,'' he said.
As more Western computer manufacturers decide it is better to buy machines than to build them, Intel must work to avoid the intrusion of companies, many of them from East Asia, that would buy Intel parts, assemble them into computers and then sell them to computer companies, Dr. Grove said. ''I don't want these economic trends to leave us further behind in the food chain,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Support for Airline Deregulation

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
After an extensive study of airline competition, the Transportation Department has found no cause for alarm in the shrinking number of major airlines in the decade since the industry was deregulated.
But the study cited a few ''pockets of problems'' as a result of the industry's new hub-and-spoke system of routes, which has led to a concentration of market power in some cities and overcrowded skies in others.
Although just eight airlines now carry 90 percent of the nation's air traffic, the study, to be released in Washington today, finds that they are competing vigorously. The public now enjoys more service and lower fares than it did several years ago when there were twice as many major airlines, the study said. 
 
Legislation for Competition
Officials of the Transportation Department who provided a copy of the study's main conclusions and discussed its implications in an interview said that Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner would arm himself with the study's voluminous data and argue vigorously against any move to re-regulate the airlines, whose routes, fares and finances were deregulated in 1979.
The study, which took nine months, has been one of the Bush Administration's department's most important examinations of transportation policy and comes amid signs of further consolidation in the industry and amid proposals in Congress for legislation that would require the Federal Government to encourage competition in markets where little exists.
In announcing the findings in Washington, Mr. Skinner is expected to declare that from the standpoint of insuring competition in the industry, deregulation has been a stellar success, with only a few areas of concern.
The study identified two main problems under deregulation, the officials said.
''Not all travelers and markets have enjoyed the same level of benefits,'' the study concluded. ''Passengers departing from or traveling to some highly concentrated hub airports pay higher fares. And while hub-and-spoke operations have fostered industry efficiency, they have also increased airport congestion.''
 
Price of Concentration
The study found that in eight cities where a single airline has established an important operating hub and provides most of the daily flights, fares are on average 18.7 percent higher than at other cities. The eight cities are Minneapolis, Cincinnati, Dayton, Ohio, St. Louis, Pittsburgh, Memphis, Salt Lake City and Charlotte, N.C.
This phenomenon has long troubled many members of Congress, especially those whose districts include these concentrated hub airports.
Second, the officials said, the study shows that in some crowded markets, including New York, Washington and Chicago, a serious shortage of airport capacity has limited the access of new competitors to the marketplace.
The Bush Administration holds that adding capacity to the national airways is the most important measure that can be taken to foster competition in the industry, and has requested several billion dollars in additional spending on airport expansion and modernization of the air-traffic control system in the years ahead.
 
Sanguine Conclusions
The department's sanguine conclusions about consolidation in the industry stand in marked contrast to the deep concern expressed by Mr. Skinner and his staff at the outset of the project last year. Since then, the prospect of further consolidation in the industry is continuing, with the possibility remaining that weaker carriers like Pan American World Airways, Trans World Airlines and Eastern might not survive.
But the study concluded that the survivors would be vigorous competitors, their routes extending across the nation and their revenues bolstered by sharp gains in international air traffic.
Between 1978 and 1984, the industry expanded from 30 to 38 large carriers, and in 1984 16 airlines shared 90 percent of all traffic. Now, after 11 mergers and 16 acquisitions, there are 29 large airlines, eight of which provide 90 percent of the service. The eight are American, United Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines, USAir, Texas Air, which owns Continental and Eastern, Trans World Airlines and Pan Am.
 
Contrary to Intuition
But the study reached the conclusion, which it called ''seemingly counterintuitive,'' that the changes in the industry have led to ''more service at a lower cost.''
The reason, the study found, was that the development of hub-and-spoke operations by the surviving carriers, which rely on centrally situated airports where passengers make connections on the way from one city to another, has produced more efficient airlines and more choices for passengers.
The study found several positive trends, all brought on by the hub-and-spoke development of the industry.
At many airports, the new system has provided additional service. The majority of cities with air service had more frequent flights in 1989 than in 1978, it said.
Smaller cities have benefited as much as larger ones because hubs have been set up at small cities and because spokes have been established to them. The growth in weekly flights to 28 large cities was 61 percent between 1978 and 1989, the study said. Flights to medium-sized cities increased 70 percent, those to small cities grew 33 percent, and those to towns and rural communities grew 44 percent.
 
More Choice for Flyers
When service between pairs of cities is examined, competition has markedly increased because passengers can choose among airlines making connections through different hubs. In 1988, more than 55 percent of all air travel was between pairs of cities served by three or more airlines, up from 28 percent in 1978. The number of city pairs served by one carrier, on the other hand, has remained fairly constant.
In 698 travel markets, or pairs of cities, where one airline is dominant, passenger fares were on average 14 percent higher than they were on routes with competing airlines, the study found.
The noncompetitive routes accounted for 10 percent of the total passenger mileage nationwide.
But over all, after taking inflation into account, fares declined by an average of 15 percent from 1984 to 1988, the period of consolidation among airlines, and small cities benefited from the greatest decline in fares, the study found.
Fares have been rising since 1987 even faster than the rate of inflation, but the long-term trend remains down, the study said. It noted that this trend had been in place for decades, even before the industry's deregulation. AMRd (american) UALd (united) NWAd (Northwest)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Global Warming: Look or Leap?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FOR George Bush the candidate, global warming was hot stuff - not as critical to the nation's future, perhaps, as ending prison furloughs for murderers, but near the top of the list of issues that mattered to the quiche and Volvo crowd.
For George Bush the President, global warming is another of the universe's great mysteries, worthy of careful study but not precipitous response. Indeed, in deference to those who believe the globe may even be cooling, Mr. Bush now discreetly refers to the issue of ''climate change.''
This transformation has been widely reported as an ideological victory for John Sununu, the President's conservative guru. But it also represents a technocratic victory for President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, and in particular for one council member, Richard Schmalensee, an expert on regulation from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The council's annual report, published last week, offers the economist's case for looking a while longer before we leap. 
In a bow to Mr. Sununu, a former nuclear engineer, the report notes that computer forecasts of warming necessarily turn on primitive assumptions about atmospheric dynamics. It is even conceivable that the ''greenhouse effect,'' caused by the accumulation of atmospheric pollutants that trap solar energy, will be more than offset by cooling caused by increased cloud cover.
But the council's views carry the most credibility on the council's own turf. The economic burden imposed by a temperature increase, the report says, may be relatively modest, while the costs of containing the greenhouse-effect pollutants over the next century may prove extraordinarily high. Increased summer temperatures could directly affect health. But while ''the average temperature differential between New York City and Atlanta is as large as the most extreme predictions of warming,'' the report notes, ''there is no evidence that Atlanta's warmer climate creates a greater health risk than New York's.''
Higher temperatures are likely, however, to reduce overall agricultural productivity. According to the Department of Agriculture, the net costs worldwide of a doubling of carbon dioxide, the primary greenhouse gas, would run from $35 billion to $170 billion annually.
That is a lot of money. But it amounts to just 1 percent of current world income. And as the council argues, it is in the same ball park as the costs of Government regulations that now distort food production and reduce its total value. To put it another way, freer markets in agriculture, the council suggests, could more than offset greenhouse-effect losses.
On the other side of the ledger, controlling carbon dioxide emissions would be no small undertaking. There is no practical way to trap carbon emissions from smokestacks or tailpipes. And according to one study cited by the council, the energy conservation needed to reduce carbon dioxide output by 20 percent in the United States over the next 110 years would cost from $800 billion to $3.6 trillion.
Nor, the council notes, would that titanic conservation effort be worth much if the rest of the world did not follow suit. Europeans and Japanese, who are less addicted to fossil fuels than Americans, may be ready to make the sacrifice. But developing countries, most notably China, are not about to slow industrialization to keep Boston cool or spare Iowa from drought.
Is the council right to be so cautious? While it is hard to find an economist who believes the benefits of slowing global warming exceed the costs, many economically sophisticated environmentalists still believe many anti-greenhouse measures are worth it in any case.
One class of extremely potent greenhouse gases, the chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's) used primarily in refrigerators and air-conditioners, are also responsible for most damage to the ozone layer. The United States is already committed to ending CFC production gradually to forestall a worldwide epidemic of skin cancer. Why not buy a little extra insurance against global warming, environmentalists argue, by accelerating the phase-out?
Then there is the issue of energy conservation. Some forms of carbon-controlling conservation, almost everyone agrees, would be extremely expensive. But other measures - for example, efficiency improvements in home appliances and commercial lighting - would probably save more in electricity bills than they would cost in new equipment.
The council accepts in principle the idea that some anti-warming initiatives could be justified on unrelated merits. The challenge for the Bush Administration will be to translate those principles into policy - to stop looking at global warming as a yes-or-no question and look for cheap ways to exploit the maybes.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Gained 1.6% In January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales rose a strong 1.6 percent in January, the sharpest gain in more than a year, the Government said today. Analysts said the broad advance demonstrated enough consumer confidence to hold off a recession.
''Consumer spending is still alive,'' said John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. Most categories showed advances that ''suggest to me that the consumer is coming back in the first quarter, taking up his normal pace of spending.'' 
The Commerce Department said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $146.4 billion and posted the steepest increase since a 2.1 percent gain in October 1988.
December sales, which originally were said to be up two-tenths of a percent, actually fell two-tenths of a percent, dragged down by a 2.6 percent decline in automobile sales, today's report said. Auto sales represent about 20 percent of retail sales.
 
Car Sales Increase
But car sales, prompted by new incentives that continued into February, were up 5.4 percent in January. The gain in car sales was the largest since a 6.6 percent advance in October 1988.
Excluding the often-volatile auto category, retail sales still rose six-tenths of a percent last month.
''The underlying strength is really quite remarkable,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York government securities dealer. ''You really had strength across the board.''
''It hints that consumer confidence is not fading,'' Mr. Jones said. ''As long as consumers stay positive, since they count for two-thirds of G.N.P., the economy is likely to stay out of a recession.''
Retail sales account for about one-third of consumer spending, which itself represents about two-thirds of the gross national product, the nation's output of goods and services.
 
Growth Slowed
The economy - particularly the manufacturing and construction sectors - slowed in the fourth quarter of 1989, squeezed by high interest rates as the Federal Reserve Board kept a tight rein on credit to combat inflation.
Durable goods - those expected to last more than three years - felt the brunt of the sluggishness since many of these products are financed through loans.
But durable goods sales rose 3.9 percent in January, after falling 2.1 percent in December. Sales of building materials were up 2.3 percent, and purchases of furniture and other home furnishings rose 2 percent.
Purchases of nondurable goods, like food and clothing, advanced three-tenths of a percent on top of a gain of nine-tenths of a percent in December.
For the three months from November through January, overall retail sales were up 3.8 percent.

HEADLINE: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;
For Those Tied to Drexel, Concern but No Panic

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Those who have a vested interest in the fate of Drexel Burnham Lambert and of the ''junk bond'' market that Drexel created and once dominated are scattered across the business landscape.
Ranging from the commodities markets to the insurance industry, the roster includes mutual funds, banks, the Federal Government and the employees and creditors of all the corporations that have sold the speculative bonds that Drexel pioneered.
For now, most of those directly affected seem to be taking a wait-and-see stance until Drexel's fate is settled. There is attention and concern but no panic, several analysts said. 
Drexel's legal and financial problems have obviously hurt the market for high-yield speculative bonds, and the strain worsened yesterday on the news that Drexel planned to file for bankruptcy protection.
Even that troubled arena behaved better than expected yesterday. And some analysts expected the market would ultimately find its bearings. ''At the end of the day, it is the companies you lent the money to who are going to pay you back, not Drexel,'' said Gail Silberman, a bond analyst with Jefferies & Company in New York. ''Someone will end up owning Drexel's junk bonds - someone who is content to sit there and collect principal and interest payments in the years ahead.''
 
Insurance Companies
Insurance companies are among those that already own a lot of the bonds Drexel brought to market. While many companies may have to reduce the book value of those assets, only a few firms hold enough ''junk'' assets to be substantially affected by such shrinkage.
Moody's Investors Service Inc. has identified several insurance companies with a ''material exposure'' to the junk bond market, said Weston Hicks, Moody's associate director. Heading the list are Executive Life of California and its New York subsidiary, they are the principal operating arms of the First Executive Corporation of Los Angeles.
The other companies are the United Pacific Life Insurance Company, owned by the Reliance Group of New York; the Presidential Life Insurance Company, a public company whose stock is traded over the counter, and Fidelity Bankers Life and First Capital Life, both owned by the First Capital Holdings Corporation of Los Angeles.
''We're watching the situation,'' Mr. Hicks said. ''We are somewhat concerned about these companies, but in most cases, they are very liquid on a near-term basis.'' He said the five companies were not likely to be ''forced to sell at a loss.''
Randolph B. Root, a partner at Kwasha Lipton, a benefits advisory firm, said the Drexel developments ''are a good reminder'' that purchasers of annuities, guaranteed investment contracts and similar insurance investment products ''should pay more attention to who your insurance carrier is.'' But he said the junk market's troubles would probably not spread beyond a handful of insurers.
 
Mutual Funds
Mutual fund investors, of course, have a direct stake in how their funds' portfolios fare in the months ahead. So far, Drexel's problems have not prompted a significant exodus from high-yield funds.
''It was very quiet,'' said a spokesman for Fidelity Investments in Boston. At T. Rowe Price in Baltimore, Steven Norwitz, a vice president, said: ''Anybody who was queasy about the market has already left it. The ones who are left understand the risks and probably are going to just ride it out.''
Although Drexel's junk-bond activity dominated its public image, the brokerage house was also active in other arenas. It trades over-the-counter stocks, a variety of commodity products including oil futures and precious metals, and government securities and foreign currencies.
In all those markets, Drexel is not the force it has been in junk bonds. Nevertheless, an active player may withdraw, and the markets must prepare for that possibility. Yesterday, some markets had to deal with the widespread uncertainty about Drexel's status.
 
Crude Oil Futures
The crude oil market was especially unsettled. Drexel is a member and an active trader on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where futures contracts on crude oil are traded. The exchange assured its other members yesterday that Drexel's customer accounts were safely insulated from the company's problems.
But some oil trading firms were uneasy about Drexel's ability to meetlonger-term delivery contracts. The result was a decline in the price of near-term crude oil contracts.
Hosts of other businesses and people also have a significant stake in the recovery of the junk bond market.
The banks that lent money used to finance the original junk-bond deals usually did so with the expectation that additional junk bonds would be sold to repay their loans. Such refinancings require a functional high-yield market.
So does the Federal Government's effort to rescue the savings and loan industry. Many savings institutions that were taken over by regulators held large portfolios of junk bonds. A decrease in the value of those assets will require an increase in the taxpayers' share of the rescue costs.
Obviously, some companies that sold junk bonds are vulnerable to market upheaval, which is likely to raise their cost of additional capital and force them to spend more operating revenues on interest payments.
The market upheaval might also make it harder for those companies to sell the assets they originally intended to sell, said Alfred Rappaport, an accounting and corporate finance specialist at Northwestern University's Kellogg School.
''Transactions will get even more difficult to do,'' Professor Rappaport said. ''When the companies do find buyers for assets, the buyers may not have the debt capacity to complete the transaction.''
And to the extent that assets cannot be sold and debt costs rise, the pressure on some weaker companies will increase. ''Their problems are in the economics of their operational cash flow,'' Professor Rappaport said. ''And their creditors, their employees and their communities are all stakeholders in that.''
 
Insurers Exposed To 'Junk' Problems
Insurance companies are evaluated on the amount of ''junk'' or high-yield bonds held relative to the insurers' capital. The number shown is the multiples by which junk bond holdings exceeded capital on Dec. 31, 1988.

HEADLINE: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;
The Fed Nightmare

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
For years, E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has warned anyone who would listen that Wall Street firms have as much potential to disrupt the financial system as commercial banks do - if not more. Thanks to their rapid growth in the 1980's, securities firms today - like banks -have billions of dollars of financial obligations. Yet, unlike banks, securities firms are not answerable to any Government agency with the authority to supervise them in their entirety. Regulators fear that gives them too much leeway to get into risky ventures.
The collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. raises many of Mr. Corrigan's fears anew. Drexel's financial problems, which seemed to spring up overnight, materialized in a unit of the firm - the brokerage firm's parent company - that was not regulated by any Government agency. Yet the mere possibility that problems in that unit could cause pressures elsewhere in the financial system raised the specter that the Fed might be forced to extend credit to the financial system to assure the rescue of a securities firm over which it had no direct control. 
''This is a nightmare that none of them wanted to confront,'' said Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
 
Fed's Overall Responsibility
Technically, only banking institutions and some savings and loan associations have the right to borrow emergency funds from the Federal Reserve. The Fed, however, also is charged with protecting the integrity of the financial system as a whole, and it is in that capacity that it could have been forced to put its own money to work.
So far, that seems to have been unnecessary. Under the supervision of the Federal regulators, Drexel yesterday proceeded to sell off or liquidate various portions of its brokerage business. Perhaps even more surprising, the financial markets reacted calmly both to the news of Drexel's problems and to the sale of securities Drexel held, which might have been expected to send prices down.
But if the markets were on their best behavior, and if the situation seemed under control, Wall Street officials cautioned that there was still much about the situation that is unknown or unresolved.
 
Problem of Retail Customers
For example, while most of Drexel's retail accounts were sold to other brokers last year, there are still some retail customers whose accounts have not been transferred. These accounts may require some form of Government guarantee against possible losses before any other firm would agree to take them over.
Some Wall Street executives speculated that there could also be unforeseen problems with complex, exotic products that created financial obligations for Drexel but which may have been on the books of other subsidiaries and which might not, therefore, be included in a regulatory safety net.
''What about options contracts, what about futures contracts, what about interest-rate swaps, what about non-dollar-denominated interest-rate swaps?'' asked Henry Kaufman, who is the head of a New York investment firm bearing his name.
It is precisely this lack of information that is at the heart of many regulators' complaints. Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has urged Congress to pass a measure that would enable his agency to receive information about other affiliates of a securities firm, rather than just the broker-dealer.
And Mr. Corrigan, in an aptly timed speech in late January, took that suggestion even further. He said: ''It seems to me that careful thought should be given to the suggestion that minimum capital standards and a limited degree of consolidated supervision should apply not only to registered broker dealers, but to the securities firm as a whole, including its parent holding company.''
Wall Street executives have long feared that the Fed intended to extend its regulatory reach over their industry as well. But Mr. Corrigan has stated that his interest stems from concerns for the health of the nation's payments systems.
 
'Potential to Disrupt the System'
Mr. Corrigan wrote in 1987, in a document on financial regulation that was widely read, ''The hard fact of the matter is that linkages created by the large-dollar payments systems are such that a serious credit problem at any of the large users of the system has the potential to disrupt the system as a whole.''
Drexel's problems come at a time when Congress is considering erasing the regulatory barriers between banking and the securities industry. If the financial industry were restructured along those lines, firms like Drexel could gain the right to rely on the Fed to provide a safety net.
Fed officials are reluctant to grant that privilege without gaining an increase in their regulatory powers. Some Wall Street executives thought it was no coincidence that the regulators were apparently working hard to preserve Drexel's broker-dealer unit, which is regulated by the S.E.C. and the New York Stock Exchange, and the government-securities subsidiary, which reports its financial condition to the Fed, but seemed prepared to let the unsupervised units fail.
''My instinct is that they are going to try to keep their hands off,'' Mr. Litan said. ''They're very nervous about setting a major precedent, especially in the midst of a debate over financial restructuring.''

HEADLINE: The Collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert;
Washington Unshaken by Drexel's Fall

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve and the Securities and Exchange Commission worked today to limit damage to the financial markets from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., but there was no sense of panic or drama here.
''The notion that this will have a tremendous rippling effect throughout the economy is probably overstated,'' one Administration economist said.
Another Fed official noted with some pleasure that ''the markets reacted quite positively.'' Stock and bond markets opened the day shaken by the Drexel news, but for the most part recovered by day's end with small losses or small gains. 
An investment banker with close ties to the Bush Administration said, ''My sense of the view in the Government is that this is quite manageable.''
 
Greenspan Watching Situation
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has been in close contact with E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, a Fed official said, but he added that Mr. Corrigan was in charge of the operation.
Mr. Greenspan did not feel it was necessary to call a meeting of the other Fed governors, the official said, and none went to New York on official business today.
Mr. Corrigan issued a statement this morning saying that the New York Fed would ''carefully monitor'' the situation.
A former Fed official who talked with people in his old office today said the central bank was assuring commercial banks that were Drexel's creditors that they would eventually get back most of what they were owed and that the Fed would provide loans to tide them over if necessary.
Federal banking regulators said today that they were surprised that the Drexel situation had not created more problems in the financial markets. They said a review of Drexel's finances last year led them to believe that a crisis at the company could cause the capital markets to plunge.
Treasury officials met with their counterparts from the S.E.C. and the Federal Reserve today, but the Treasury's role was limited. A Treasury official said the department had been concerned about the effect of the Drexel collapse on individual investors but had determined that the problem was not a serious one.
 
Auditors Checking the Books
A team of auditors from the New York Fed and the Securities and Exchange Commission has been poring over Drexel's books for several days.
An S.E.C. statement today said that ''detailed financial information submitted by Drexel Burnham Lambert'' indicated that for now the brokerage house had a positive balance sheet and remained in compliance with rules on money reserves.
To protect the assets of the brokerage subsidiary, the commission today barred it from transferring any more money to its parent company without regulators' approval.
Congress is not in session this week, but few lawmakers are likely to feel sorry for Drexel. ''I can't see anyone here lifting a finger to save them,'' said a senior Banking Committee staff assistant.
 
U.S. Faces Losses
The collapse of Drexel could cost the Government hundreds of millions of dollars. The Government holds about $1 billion in ''junk bonds'' that were in the portfolio of savings and loan institutions that have been taken over. In addition, according to a regulatory official, Federal insurance programs for banks and pension funds could be affected.
Nonetheless, there is no talk here about a bailout, like the ones that preserved the Chrysler and Lockheed Corporations, or an expensive Government restructuring operation like the one that followed the bankruptcy of the Penn Central Transportation Company.
''That's not on anyone's mind,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who sits on the House Banking and Budget Committee.
Mr. Schumer was one of those who expressed confidence in the regulators. ''The Fed,'' he said, ''is getting better and better at scrambling to make sure things are calm, that there is liquidity, that the market is preserved. That's the main goal of regulators, not whether companies survive or fail.''

HEADLINE: Government Shift on Data

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Commerce Department intends to abandon its computerized model of the economy, one of very few in the Government, and the monthly publication associated with it called Business Cycle Developments.
Allan H. Young, the director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis, called the moves part of ''a restructuring of our program'' to better utilize resources at a time of budgetary restraint. But he said the department would continue to compile its index of leading indicators, which had been thought to be a candidate for elimination.
About 30 pages of data contained in Business Cycle Developments will be retained and published as part of the Survey of Current Business, another monthly publication, Mr. Young said. The changes, assuming Congressional approval, are to begin this spring. The 12 employees performing the affected work will be transferred to other duties.
The disappearance of the department's economic model, which was for internal Government use, will force various Federal agencies to obtain such services from the private sector.
It could not immediately be determined to what extent, if any, the Federal Reserve would make available its model of the economy to other bodies. Mr. Young described the two systems as ''basically equivalent.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Rise Despite Drexel

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Reverberations from the financial crisis at Drexel Burnham Lambert were felt in the credit markets yesterday as prices of short-term Treasury securities moved higher and bond prices recorded gains of more than half a point.
Although huge questions remain unanswered about how Drexel's difficulties might affect the financial system, most firms said it was business as usual yesterday, with concern expressed but no signs of panic.
''This doesn't look like a financial catastrophe to me,'' one government bond trader said. ''In terms of liquidity in the money market and the Treasury market, there has been no substantive effect.'' 
William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm, said, ''The markets seem to feel the fallout from Drexel will somehow be contained.''
Some people had been worried that the market might not be able to absorb Drexel's portfolio of Government securities, after the firm said it intended to liquidate its positions and subsequently dissolve its government securities unit, Drexel Burnham Government Securities Inc.
But market participants said those worries were unfounded, given the size of the Treasury market. $2 Billion No Trouble ''Even if they had $2 billion worth of securities in inventory, which wouldn't be the case, we have absorbed that amount in liquidations by savings and loan organizations with no trouble in two days,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Goverment Securities.
To get the best price, Drexel has reportedly asked Salomon Brothers to sell Drexel's portfolio of Government bonds and notes. The First Boston Corporation has reportedly been asked to act as agent in the sale of Drexel's portfolio of corporate bonds.
Finding a buyer for the government securities unit, which is a primary dealer in government securities, would have proved much more problematic.
''Who would want to buy it?'' the bond trader asked. ''There are already too many primary dealers.''
Primary dealers are dealers that make markets in Government securities. The Federal Reserve Board conducts its open market operations only through primary dealers.
Aside from the flight to short-term issues spurred by Drexel's troubles, a rebound in the German bond market also aided Treasury prices, dealers said.
Results of yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills reflect the desire of investors to move funds into safe, short-term investments.
 
Large Number of Bids
The bills were sold at an average discounted rate of 7.42 percent. More than $36 billion worth of bids were placed for the $9.5 billion worth of bills that were sold, the largest amount of bids since July 1987.
At the last one-year bill sale on Jan. 11, one-year bills were sold at an average rate of 7.21 percent, when interest rates were generally lower.
Noncompetitive bids, a good proxy of individual investor interest, totaled $1.3 billion, the largest such bid in more than a year.
Actively traded three- and six-month bills in the secondary market were also popular vehicles, and rates on those securities fell sharply.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.52 percent, down 11 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by 10 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.53 percent.
Bond prices, which zigzagged in early trading, moved higher throughout the afternoon.
In late trading, the 8.50 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 3/8, up 19/32, to yield 8.37 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered late yesterday at 97 27/32, up 10/32, to yield 8.26 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 7/8, up 5/ 32, to yield 8.19 percent.
 
'Junk' Decline Reversed
Elsewhere, bids on issues traded in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market fell early in the day after Drexel said it was contemplating a bankruptcy filing. Those declines were reversed later on, and junk bond traders said by the end of the day prices of most issues had risen one to two points.
''There are a lot of wild cards up in the air right now,'' said Frank V. Columbo, director of high-yield research at Dillon, Read & Company. ''But we are at a point where on a fundamental basis a lot of issues are attractive.''
Prices of actively traded issues the secondary corporate bond market rose by between 1/4 of a point and 3/8 of a point, dealers said.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Rise Sharply On Stock Market Strength

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The price of copper futures surged yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange in reaction to the stock market's resilience amid reports that the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. would file for Federal bankruptcy protection.
Copper futures settled 3 to 4.55 cents higher in New York, with the contract for delivery in February at $1.0545 a pound, its highest level in about four weeks.
The copper market has been taking its cues lately from the stock market as a forecaster of the nation's economic climate, and the activity yesterday demonstrated how closely the two markets are tied. 
Copper is used heavily by industry and in home and office construction, so the shape of the economy is perceived as an indicator of copper demand.
 
Lower at Opening
Copper futures opened lower, reflecting expectations that the troubles at Drexel would lead to a drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
The Dow did drop in early trading, falling about 19 points before buyers came in and pushed it up to nearly a 5-point gain by the close.
Analysts said the Dow's reverse sparked a turnaround in copper futures, which then soared as technical buy signals were tripped.
Randolph Donney, an analyst with the brokerage firm of Elders Futures Inc., said the Commerce Department's report of a 1.6 percent rise in retail sales last month also supported the copper market.
Precious metals futures were notably quieter after rallying sharply on Monday amid concerns about possible supply disruptions in South Africa.
 
Gold Off by $1.60
Gold futures finished $1.60 lower across the board on the Comex, with February at $417.60 an ounce; silver futures were 2.8 to 3.3 cents higher, with March at $5.333 an ounce; platinum futures settled $1.40 to $1.70 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with April at $522.50 an ounce.
Sugar futures fell sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange after a West German statistician, F. O. Licht, forecast record world production of 107.9 million metric tons for 1989-90.
Sugar futures finished 0.27 cent to 0.38 cent lower, with March at 14.56 cents a pound.
Petroleum futures ended mixed on the New York Merc in advance of the American Petroleum Institute's release of the weekly report on United States stocks.
In the report, which was released after the close, the institute said gasoline stocks rose by 7.5 million barrels last week, compared with market expectations ranging from one million to three million.
 
Crude Oil Stocks Fall
The Washington-based trade association said crude oil stocks fell about two million barrels, as expected, while supplies of petroleum distillates, including heating oil, rose by 870,000 barrels, compared with market expectations for an increase of up to three million barrels.
West Texas Intermediate crude settled 13 cents lower to 29 cents higher, with March down 13 cents at $21.90 a barrel; heating oil was 0.62 cent to 0.90 cent higher, with March at 56.85 cents a gallon.
The wheat market led a decline in grain and soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting improved crop weather for winter wheat and South American soybeans, and signs of disappointing foreign demand.
Wheat settled unchanged to 4 1/2 cents lower, with March at $3.85 1/2 a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to a quarter-cent higher, with March at $2.41 3/4 a bushel; oats were unchanged to a half-cent higher, with March at $1.39 1/2 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1 3/4 cents lower, with March at $5.64 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading As Gold Finishes Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly higher in quiet trading yesterday, although the prospect of a bankruptcy filing by the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. eroded some of its earlier gains.
Gold prices declined after a mixed performance overseas.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $417.60 an ounce, down $1.60 from late on Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $417.50 an ounce, off $1.20. 
Currency dealers said technical factors were largely responsible for pushing the dollar higher. But they said an announcement from Drexel that it planned to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code depressed the dollar.
Linda McLaughlin, a trader with the Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said the market was concerned that a Drexel filing would force the Federal Reserve to provide more liquidity in the market, which would lower interest rates.
Lower interest rates tend to depress a currency's value because they make dollar-denominated investments less attractive.
In Tokyo, where trading ends as the business day in Europe begins, the dollar closed down 0.24 yen, at 144.48 yen. It was quoted at 144.25 yen in London, and at 144.35 yen in New York, down from 144.37 yen.
The dollar was stronger against the British pound. Sterling brought $1.6907 an ounce in London, down from $1.6960 late on Monday, and $1.6895 in New York, down from $1.6918.
Against the West German mark, the dollar rose to 1.67625 marks from 1.6755 marks.
But the dollar closed lower against the yen in New York. It was quoted at 144.35 yen, down from 144.37 yen late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Monday, included: 1.4975 Swiss francs, down from 1.5005; 5.7015 French francs, up from 5.6965; 1,245.75 Italian lire, down from 1,246.00, and 1.20095 Canadian dollars, up from 1.20065.
In London, gold fell to $418.65 an ounce, from $419.50 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose 75 cents, to $419.75 an ounce.
Earlier, in Hong Kong trading, gold rose $5.17 an ounce to close at $419.58.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Koop's Idea For Alcohol Ban Debated

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
AGREEING with a group of communications professionals that ''advertising works,'' the former Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop, yesterday called for a complete ban on broadcast beer and wine advertising to prevent alcohol abuse and drunken driving, particularly among young people.
But his recommendation, made at a meeting of marketing, advertising and media executives in New York, was strenuously opposed by a pair of prominent First Amendment lawyers, who said it smacked of the central planning that even Eastern European nations are abandoning.
In a spirited debate at the annual television workshop of the Association of National Advertisers, Dr. Koop and Bruce A. Silverglade, the director of legal affairs at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, an advocacy group that supports limitations on alcoholic-beverage advertising, laid out the arguments for advertising restrictions that appear to be gaining adherents in Congress.
Opposing them were Burt Neuborne, a professor at New York University Law School and a former legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union, and David H. Remes, a lawyer with Covington & Burling, a law firm in Washington that represents the Tobacco Institute. 
Last year, testifying to Congress before leaving his post, Dr. Koop recommended that a variety of restrictions be legislated against broadcast advertising of alcoholic beverages. Since leaving office, he has stepped up his attacks on the marketing of beer and wine, leading to his recommendation for a total ban.
Children, he said, see 100,000 beer commercials by the time they turn 18. He said that field research conducted by the National Commission on Drunk Driving had shown that these ads, in which drinking ''is visually associated with sex, patriotism, active life styles and health,'' have an impact on convincing young people to drink.
''The great majority of young people testified they began to drink because of the advertising,'' Dr. Koop said. ''Advertising works,'' he told the audience of communications professionals. ''You people know that better than anybody.''
But Professor Neuborne responded that it did not work that well, asserting that no studies had linked alcohol abuse to advertising. Staking out a position as a First Amendment absolutist, he attacked Dr. Koop's recommendation for an ad ban.
''We have commited ourselves to a society where the commands are cumulative and come up from the people, not from some central planners,'' he said. He called banning any form of advertising ''a mortal blow to the fundamental moral, political, social and economic structure of America.''
The debaters sparred most aggressively over the issue of tobacco and alcohol advertising directed at women and minorities, an issue highlighted recently by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company's plans, later abandoned, to test-market a cigarette aimed at blacks called Uptown.
Professor Neuborne and Mr. Remes both attacked what they called the ''paternalism'' inherent in attempts to restrict advertising to women and minorities. ''For years, centuries, what we have done is suppressed the ability of blacks and women to compete equally in this society,'' Professor Neuborne said. ''I find it absolutely tragic that this same philosophy surfaces in the notion that blacks are not capable of making the same choices about products as others can.''
Mr. Silverglade, however, noted that the recent controversy over Uptown had been spurred by attacks on the marketing of tobacco to black Americans made by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Louis W. Sullivan, who is black.
Although a vocal critic of much food advertising and of alcoholic-beverage advertising, Mr. Silverglade took a conciliatory stance toward marketers and advertisers, maintaining that ''defending beer ads on television that have an impact on youth is bad public relations.''
He argued that the alcoholic-beverage industry should accept some restrictions on its advertising, such as not running television commercials until after 9 P.M. and mandatory anti-drinking commercials, in order to ward off more serious marketing and advertising problems.
As an example, Mr. Silverglade reminded the audience that the reduction of Federal Trade Commission oversight of advertising during the Reagan administration had impelled the state attorneys generals to police advertising more vigorously.
Dr. Koop said he would accept restrictions on alcohol advertising. ''But I'd like to start at the bargaining table,'' he said, ''with a total ban.''

HEADLINE: For Many Women, One Job Just Isn't Enough

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
Amid the great wave of women sweeping into the American labor force in recent years is a group whose numbers are increasing even faster: women who hold more than one job.
Government studies show that moonlighting among women is becoming as commonplace as it is among men, in both the percentage of working women and in absolute numbers. The figures for men, by contrast, have changed little in decades.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics found in a sampling of the work force last May that the number of women with two or more jobs had quintupled, from 636,000 in 1970 to 3.1 million in May, while the number of moonlighting men rose much more slowly, from 3.4 million to 4.1 million.
 
Staying Above Poverty Line
Reasons for the surge among women are enmeshed in social and economic shifts of the 1970's and 80's, economists and Government officials say. With jobs opening that were once denied them, some women moonlight to gather experience for new careers, and some do extra work to build up savings or pay debts. 
But as the last two decades have brought a record number of divorces and families maintained by single women, many of the women take two jobs because it is the only way to eke out a working-class life and stay above the poverty line.
The changes in family life are apparent in Harrisburg, a state capital with a diversified economy and unemployment near the national average of 5.3 percent. The Harrisburg area in central Pennsylvania, with a population of 591,000, resembles many older towns in its struggle to recapture a prosperity that has drifted to the suburbs.
Patricia Keammerer, 42 years old, is a recently divorced mother of a 10-year-old girl. To get by, she holds three jobs. She is an administrative assistant in the Harrisburg school system, works two nights a week and every other weekend at a fabric store, and from her home manages 41 homes that investors rent out. She moonlights, she says, so her daughter, Sara, can live in the same neighborhood and attend the same school.
Celeste Henderson, 40, is another single parent who must strive to make ends meet. She has been separated for years from a husband who has not provided child support for their three children - two daughters who married last year and a 17-year-old son, Rick, still at home. Ms. Henderson earns $11.50 an hour as a secretary at Amp Inc., a big electronics company. She says that is not enough to provide for Rick and herself. So on weekends and two nights a week, Ms. Henderson works as a saleswoman at a kitchenware store, for $5 an hour.
Another woman, Linda Jackman, 42, might seem fairly well off, but she doesn't think so. Divorced and without children, she makes $35,000 a year as an official in a state government job and $5,000 a year selling curtains part time at a branch of the J. C. Penney Company Inc. She says she moonlights to set aside money for a down payment on a house.
 
Women Face More Burdens
Sabina Mitnaul, 26, earns $16,500 as a secretary, and her husband receives a $10,000 stipend as a graduate student. They say that is not enough to cover expenses that include $395 a month for rent, $195 a month to pay off their 1986 Renault Alliance and credit-card payments. So Ms. Mitnaul works five nights a week from 6 to 11 as a data entry clerk, for $5.50 an hour.
The increase in moonlighting among women illustrates the larger role they are assuming in the economy. ''I put emphasis on the fact that women's contribution to families is increasing no matter how you measure it,'' said Heidi Hartmann, an economist who is the director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. ''More of them are economically responsible for families, while there has been no big change in men's economic responsibility.''
For men and women, the incentive to moonlight has risen as it has become harder for people to manage on one paycheck, Government statistics show. When increases in the cost of living are taken into account, hourly wages have slipped about 5 percent in 20 years.
Some families have managed to get ahead of inflation, because so many wives, like Ms. Mitnaul, have gone to work and so many single women with children, like Ms. Henderson and Ms. Keammerer, have taken two jobs. And typically, a woman who moonlights has to work more than a moonlighting man to earn the same pay. The average woman working full time is paid 70 percent as much as the average man working full time.
 
Who Moonlights and Why
The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which surveys moonlighting occasionally, found in its sampling that the number of women with two or more jobs had jumped from 2.2 percent of 28.9 million working women in 1970, to 5.9 percent of 52.8 million who were working in May.
The number of men with two or more jobs rose in the 20 years from 3.4 million out of the 48.7 million men who were working in 1970 to 4.1 million of 64.3 million working men last year. The percentage of moonlighting among men declined, from 7 percent in 1970, to 6.4 in May.
For men and women, the survey showed that moonlighting was concentrated among people 25 to 44 years old, the most able-bodied and most likely to have children to support. These workers said they moonlighted more to make ends meet and pay debts than for other reasons, like saving.
The survey also showed that most moonlighting men were married, while most moonlighting women were divorced, separated, widowed or had never married.
Labor Department officials cautioned that the figures might understate the number of people holding more than one job. Many are paid in cash for their extra work and might not report those earnings to the Government, to avoid paying taxes on them.
 
There is a Typical Pattern
Ms. Henderson's chronicle of motherhood and moonlighting illustrates a typical pattern. ''I got married at 18,'' she said, ''and after about five years my husband and I started to do badly. So when we broke up, I went back to school and got an associate's degree in secretarial science from Harrisburg Community College.''
Thirteen years ago, Ms. Henderson started a secretarial job at Amp, and she began moonlighting then as well. ''When the kids were smaller,'' she said, ''I'd work around the Christmas season. For five years I did that.''
As Ms. Henderson sees it, she needed to moonlight not to make the payments on her car, currently a Dodge Omni, or to pay the rent on her duplex in a working-class section of Harrisburg, but to give her children the things their friends and classmates had. ''You have to see that they enjoy their youth,'' she said.
'When the kids got to be teen-agers,'' she said, ''their tastes got more expensive: bikes, clothes, records.'' She started working at a second job year-round, most recently in the kitchenware store. For a time, she worked every weeknight from 6 to 9:30, and on weekends. With just Rick left to support, Ms. Henderson cut back her moonlighting late last year.
''It was my responsibility to maintain my family,'' she said. ''Even today I don't have a bad feeling about it.''
Ms. Henderson's 22-year-old daughter, Marty Mayo, graduated with honors from a vocational high school, joined the Dauphin Deposit Bank here as a data entry clerk and has moved up to processing loans. Married to a man in the Army who is now stationed in Greece, Ms. Mayo also moonlights, working nights at a Rite Aid store while a cousin watches her 2-year-old daughter.
Ms. Mayo said that as a child, she that missed having her mother at home when she returned from school but that her mother saved her the embarrassment of looking poor to the other children. ''My mother worked so we could have nice things,'' she said.
 
Some Complain of the Stress
Some women who moonlight complain of the stress, but they also appear to be strivers. Many take courses to qualify for better jobs that might free them from moonlighting. Ms. Keammerer, for example, who holds three jobs, is studying to teach special education; Ms. Henderson is studying business administration, which could qualify her to move to Amp's accounting staff.
''Those who moonlight here,'' said Kenneth Washington, president of the Urban League of Harrisburg, ''are usually controlled types who will go out and seek another job when they have money problems and not go on welfare.'' They go to unusual lengths to mesh their work schedules with those of their children and to make the most of a modest income.
Ms. Keammerer, for example, works from 7 A.M. to 3 P.M. at the high school, finishing about 20 minutes before her daughter leaves school. She said she arises at 5:30 weekday mornings and wakes Sara at 6:15. She has to start work an hour before Sara starts school, so she takes Sara to her mother's home nearby.
''She gives her breakfast and makes sure she gets on the school bus,'' Ms. Keammerer said.
From 5 to 8 P.M. Tuesdays and Fridays and alternate weekends, she works at the Fabric Mart, a store within walking distance from her rented townhouse.
For the Mitnauls, strains arise from debt. They go home to South Carolina for a week over the Christmas holiday with gifts for their parents, her four siblings and his five.
For Ms. Mitnaul, as for many other women, moonlighting seems a necessary evil. She said she had been doing it off and on for four years: ''Once I get it into my system, I get used to it.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Sues Longshoremen's Locals And 44 People, Citing Ties to Mob

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
The Federal Government yesterday sued six longshoremen's locals and 44 union officials and reputed organized-crime figures, including John Gotti, in an effort to end what the authorities say is Mafia domination of the New York and New Jersey waterfronts.
The civil suit seeks the removal of corrupt officials, the return of ill-gotten funds and court trusteeship of the six locals until new elections are held and mob influence is wiped out.
Federal prosecutors described the case, the latest in years of legal actions against the union, as a hybrid of a civil suit brought in 1988 to oust corrupt leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and an earlier attempt to rid organized crime from unions at the Fulton Fish Market.
 
'Embezzlement of Union Funds'
The United States Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, who announced the lawsuit at a news conference in Manhattan yesterday, said the suit ''seeks to remedy decades of organized-crime involvement in the New York and New Jersey waterfront.''
''The criminal acts include extortion, bribery, mail fraud, assault, murder and - the complaint alleges - year after year after year, extensive embezzlement of union funds,'' he said. 
If successful, Mr. Thornburgh said, the action would end a ''hidden tax'' paid by consumers in the higher prices for goods moved through the waterfront by shippers subject to extortion and kickback payments.
The suit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan under RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. It would bar members of the Gambino and Genovese crime families and members of the Westies, a small, violent gang with Mafia ties, from any involvement in business or union activity around the harbor.
The defendants would not be subject to fines or jailing unless they violated the terms of an eventual court order.
Reached last night in Bal Harbor, Fla., where he was attending a union meeting, John Bowers, the union's president and a co-defendant in the suit, denied that the three New York locals, which he also heads, were subject to any organized crime influence.
''I can't believe it,'' he said of the suit, which he said he had not seen. ''All I know is, in the locals I have there's no mob influence and nobody's ever told me there's any mob influence.''
Mr. Gotti's lawyer, Bruce Cutler, called the suit a ''continuing vendetta to try to throw his name around.'' He added, ''This case is of no import to anyone.''
Decades of investigations have given the 90,000-member longshoremen's union almost mythical status as a focal point of Mafia involvement in labor. The organization was expelled from the American Federation of Labor for corruption in 1953.
A number of present and former union officials have been jailed for racketeering and other crimes. The position of General Organizer of the longshoremen, for example, was held by four reputed Mafia dons, three of them convicted in succession on racketeering and income tax charges, officials said. One of those convicted, Anthony Scotto, and the current general organizer, Anthony Pimpinella, were named in the civil suit yesterday.
 
Just Like a Puppet
Nonetheless, prosecutors said the reputed mob figures charged in the suit so fully controlled the union that they were able to replace jailed officials with others loyal to them. The union has kept some officials in place even after conviction, saying they were entitled to await the outcome of appeals.
''We know only too well that out of office does not mean out of power,'' said James Fox, the assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in charge of the New York office.
With increasing mechanization and the general decline of the shipping industry, membership in I.L.A. locals in the New York area has fallen from 27,750 in 1960 to 4,577 now. But waterfront commission and F.B.I. officials said the union has kept a stranglehold over shipping and stevedore companies and other waterfront business.
F.B.I. and Waterfront Commission investigators began to assemble the case three years ago, officials said. Some of the predicate acts with which the case tries to prove a pattern of mob involvement date back 20 years.
Filing of the suit was postponed to avoid confusion during Mr. Gotti's recent state trial on assault and conspiracy charges. Investigators said the suit would have been filed regardless of the outcome of Mr. Gotti's recent trial. The Government's brief in the union case cites surveillance tapes entered in the state trial as ''the most compelling evidence of the Gambino family's domination'' of the union's largest affiliate, Local 1814 in Brooklyn.
After Mr. Gotti's acquittal last week, the office of the United States Attorney in Manhattan held off filing the suit to coincide with a visit yesterday by Mr. Thornburgh to New York, a senior law-enforcement official said. #12th Civil RICO Case The case filed yesterday is the 12th to use civil provisions of the RICO statute against organized crime. In one such case, a court appointed trustee was named in 1986 to take over Local 560 of the teamsters union in Union City, N.J. When a court supervised election was held in December 1988, the members returned the union to associates of the late Anthony (Tony Pro) Provenzano, a convicted racketeer.
A more sweeping action by the Justice Department in 1988 sought to oust the leadership of the 1.7-million-member teamsters international. The case was settled last March when the union agreed to the naming of a court-appointed administrator and investigators to control union discipline, corruption and the union's elections in 1991.
In the suit yesterday, the Government opted not to prosecute the union's international organization, but instead to focus on a specific area.
''We attempt here to put an entire economic marketplace effectively under court supervision,'' said Otto G. Obermaier, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
 
A Difficult Task Ahead
In that, legal experts likened the 1987 action taken against mob involvement in labor at the Fulton Fish Market. Although the Government failed in January 1989 to win a court takeover of the major union at the market, an outside administrator was left in place to guard against organized crime activity. A Federal court said the Government had failed to prove that the union's top two leaders were controlled by the Genovese crime family.
Prosecutors yesterday admitted that they face a difficult task. Compared to the 1988 international teamsters case, in which the Government set out to prove the inaction of union leaders on evidence of corruption by the officials of various locals, the waterfront suit would require far stronger proof, tying organized-crime figures to union activities.
''Nobody is saying that this is going to go our way,'' Mr. Fox said. ''It's just a new way to use the RICO statute to try to separate the mob from the unions.''
The suit asserts that before and during Mr. Gotti's leadership, the Gambino family has controlled Local 814 in Brooklyn and, through the Westies and their leader, James Coonan, have controlled Locals 1809, 824 and 1909 on the West Side of Manhattan. The Genovese family, reputedly controlled by Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, dominates Locals 1804-1 of North Bergen, N.J., and 1588 of Bayonne, N.J., the suit contends.
Of the 32 present or former union officials named as defendants, 21 were identified in the suit as members or associates of organized crime groups. Another 12 reputed mob members also were named, along with several waterfront businesses cited solely for purposes of recovering illicit gains.
